Lo Chih-chiang, a spokesman for the president, said at a news conference that the president felt sorry that the judge, the fourth in one month, was being probed on suspicion of taking bribes.

"Although it shakes the public's confidence in the judiciary, in order to put the house in order, you have to endure the dust whipped up during cleaning," the spokesman quoted the president as saying.

Ma was cited as saying that many problems in the judiciary have developed over a long period and will take a lot of effort and time to eliminate, "but we must give the prosecutors carte blanche to do it."
The president made the comment after being briefed by Prosecutor General Huang Shyh-ming about a Ministry of Justice plan to set up the country's first anti- corruption agency.

A day earlier, prosecutors searched the residence of High Court judge Yang Ping- chen and 19 other locations in the investigation of a corruption case involving the judge, a lawyer and various others. However, they did not question Yang at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 13, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish- American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Watch out for imminent storm

TEXT.P: In a seminar held in Taipei Wednesday, China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits Vice President Li Yafei said the so-called "1992 consensus" refers to an understanding reached between Taiwan and China in 1992 "to separately verbalize the one China principle."

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou often says that the "1992 consensus" means "one China, separate interpretations, " which seems to differ from China in terms of the wording. In fact, the so-called "1992 consensus" is in substance "one China." The Ma administration has no way of skirting this, no matter how it interprets the consensus.
The Ma administration is well aware that the Taiwanese people are against the so-called "one China" and therefore uses the "1992 consensus" as a smokescreen to fool the people.

Meanwhile, it has been denying the people their right to referendum again and again, suppressing their voices. Once the Taiwanese people lose their freedom of speech completely, China will not allow "separate interpretations" and will make Taiwan accept its version of the consensus.
The Taiwanese people must be on the alert for the approaching storm and take action to protect Taiwan and themselves. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic commission to be headed by vice minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 10:41:44 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have agreed that an economic cooperation commission to be established under a recently signed trade pact will be headed by vice ministerial-level officials from each side, government sources said Friday.

When Vice Economic Affairs Minister Francis Kuo-hsin Liang met with China's Vice Minister of Commerce Jiang Zengwei in Beijing during an investment-soliciting visit last week, they discussed the structure and operation guidelines of the new body to be formed under the bilateral economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed June 29, the sources said.
During the meeting, Liang expressed Taiwan's expectation that a vice ministerial-level official from each side will be assigned to head the new commission.

The Chinese side did not oppose the proposal, the sources said, adding that as the commission will serve as a platform for negotiations on cross-strait economic and trade affairs, it will be manned by officials in the relevant fields.
The commission will become operational once the ECFA clears the legislative floor, the sources added.
High on the agenda of the new cross-strait economic cooperation commission will be negotiating four key agreements to fulfill the ECFA's ultimate goals, the sources went on.
The ECFA follow-up agreements will cover investment, merchandise trade liberalization, service market opening and a trade dispute settlement mechanism.

Talks will first focus on investment and trade dispute settlement, the sources said, adding that Taiwan hopes the new investment agreement will offer well-devised protection for Taiwanese investors in China.
The Legislative Yuan is scheduled to hold an extraordinary session next week to screen the free trade agreement-like ECFA. The exact dates for the session were expected to be announced later Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Paper shade remains unpierced

TEXT.P: We have previously described the "1992 consensus" as an evolving concept and have likened it to a paper shade that lets light through and yet has a separation function. We have also urged Taiwan and China not to pierce this flimsy shade.

According to the latest interpretation of the "1992 consensus" by Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits Vice President Li Yafei, the consensus means "separate verbalizing of the one China principle by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."
The "one China principle" is different from "one China." It can be viewed as an inclusive concept, while "one China" is exclusive.
The point of Li's statement is that the two sides should seek common ground rather than picking at their differences. This will make sure the paper shade is not pierced.
Li's remarks were like wetting the paper shade with spit, but nevertheless, the shade was not pierced. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Mettle to root out judicial corruption

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Huang Shyh-ming reaffirmed his determination Thursday to crack down on corruption in the judiciary, saying the integrity of judges and prosecutors is the only line of defense for justice.

After a number of senior judges, prosecutors and civil servants have come under investigation recently in a spate of graft scandals, Huang said it is his obligation as Taiwan's top prosecutor to rid the country of corrupt officials and judicial personnel.

President Ma Ying-jeou also threw his support behind the anti-corruption drive after being briefed by Huang on a Ministry of Justice initiative to set up an anti-corruption agency under its jurisdiction.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

In a new drive to streamline discipline in the judiciary, the Taiwan High Court decided Thursday to refer two of its judges to the Control Yuan for discipline over misconduct that has tarnished the reputation of the judiciary.

One of the judges, Kao Ming-tse, is accused of having illegally acquitted the son of a colleague at the Supreme Court in a traffic violation case, while the other, Yang Ping-chen, is allegedly involved in a collective bribery case.

Yang's residence was searched Wednesday as part of the probe into his role in the acquittal of former high court judge Chang Bing-lung. Chang was recently given a 12-year prison sentence for taking bribes. Prosecutors are still investigating Yang's role in the case.
The high court disciplinary panel decided to refer the two cases to the Control Yuan -- the supreme watchdog body for government behavior -- after more than seven hours of heated debate.
The panel took the action a day after prosecutors and investigators raided 20 locations in cities and counties in northern Taiwan in a new drive to wipe out graft in the judiciary.

It was the second large-scale probe into suspected corruption in the judiciary in recent weeks and was carried out under a Special Investigation Division-led judiciary self-correction campaign aimed at ridding the judicial system of graft and ensuring its integrity.
Three high court judges and a prosecutor have been detained since mid-July on bribery charges involving former Miaoli Magistrate Ho Chih-hui. (Aug. 13, 2010).
China Times:

On Thursday, top prosecutor Huang ordered a probe into the case involving Kao, who is accused of having lobbied other judges on his panel to acquit the son of Hsiao Yang-kuei, a Supreme Court judge, in a traffic violation case.

Hsiao's son was convicted at his first trial in the Keelung District Court, but was acquitted by a panel of three judges headed by Kao in the Taiwan High Court at his second trial. As the High Prosecutors Office did not appeal the acquittal, the case was then closed.

Speculation has been rife that prosecutors and judges at various levels faced influence peddling pressure throughout the investigative and court hearing procedures. Huang ordered an extensive probe into the case.
Responding to a backlash from the judicial community over the recent "self- correction" crackdown, Huang said that "bad apples" account for only a small number in the judicial ranks.
"Judicial personnel need not be panicked by the drive, " Huang said, but he stressed that no official or judge is too senior to be probed as long as sufficient evidence is available.

During a meeting with Huang, President Ma was quoted as having told Huang: "Although it shakes the public's confidence in the judiciary, in order to put the house in order, you have to endure the dust whipped up during cleaning." (Aug. 13, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwanese support workload-sharing between men, women
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 12:34:46 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: As high as 85.6 percent of the respondents to a recent government survey think men and women should share the workload either in the workplace or at home, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) reported Friday.

On gender perception, 80 percent of the respondents said they did not agree that "the husband is the head of the household and the wife should do her best to obey her husband, " while 72.1 percent disagree with the idea that "unmarried women cannot be enshrined in ancestral temples after death, " the RDEC-conducted survey on gender equality found.

The results also show that 68.4 percent of the respondents disagreed with the notion that "every woman should give birth to at least one male child to continue the family line, " and 60.2 percent did not agree that "men should bear the responsibility of making money to support their families, while women's work is handling household chores and caring for the family."

Regarding a proposal that both paternal and maternal grandparents can be referred to by the same honorific, 50.1 percent of respondents said they agree, while 44.1 percent said they disagree with the proposal. Chinese tradition has different honorifics for both sets of grandparents.

Generally speaking, 53.5 percent of the respondents think that at present, men hold higher social status than women in Taiwan, while 31.6 percent believe Taiwan has achieved gender equality. Only 9 percent think women's social status is higher than men's, according to the poll.

On sexual harassment and violence, 98.2 percent of those polled said they had not suffered physical sexual harassment over the past one year, and 91.6 percent reported they had not suffered verbal sexual harassment during the same period.

It was also found that 72 percent of the respondents were aware that they can call 113 to seek help if they fall victim to domestic violence or sexual assault. Meanwhile, 77.2 percent said that overall, gender equality exists in the workplace.
The survey was conducted July 27-28 among 1,091 adults around Taiwan. It had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.97 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC ranks world's No. 8 cell phone firm in Q2: Gartner
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 12:37:37 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Smartphone maker HTC Corp. was listed as the world's eighth-largest cell phone seller in the second quarter of this year, the first time the Taiwanese company has ranked among the top 10 mobile device companies in the world, Gartner said Thursday.
In the second quarter of last year, HTC accounted for 0.9 percent of the total global cell phone sales, shipping 2.47 million units worldwide.
The company's growth "reflects the popularity of its Android portfolio but also a more aggressive branding strategy compared to the same period of 2009," Gartner said in a statement.
According to Gartner, Android became the world's third most popular smartphone operating system after overtaking Apple's iPhone OS, and also took the top spot in the United States.
Gartner said global mobile device sales to end-users totaled 325.6 million units in the second quarter of 2010, up 13.8 percent from a year earlier.
During the same period, smartphone sales totaled 61.6 million units, up 50.5 percent year-on-year, and made up 19 percent of worldwide mobile device sales, Gartner said.
Nokia grabbed the top position in worldwide cell phone sales in the second quarter, shipping a total of 111.47 million units to end-users, which represented a 34.2 percent share of the global market.

Samsung sold 65.33 million units, accounting for 20.1 percent, and claimed the second position in the world, while LG's sales totaled 29.37 million units, accounting for 9 percent of the world's total sales.

Research in Motion (RIM) was the world's fourth-largest cell phone firm, selling 11.23 million units and representing 3.4 percent of the global sales, while Sony Ericsson held the No. 5 position with sales totaling 11.01 million, accounting for a 3.4-percent market share.

Motorola took the No. 6 position and a 2.8 percent market share, selling 9.11 million units, while Apple sold 8.74 million units, grabbing the seventh-largest position and claiming a 2.7 percent market share.

"Although the mobile communication devices market showed double- digit growth this quarter, average selling prices (ASPs) were lower than expected and margins fell, " said Carolina Milanesi, Gartner's research vice president.

Gartner said companies, such as LG and Samsung pursued market share by penetrating a low-margin market but this move proved risky as LG's ASP in the second quarter fell 27.8 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Contradictions within property market

TEXT.P: A report released Wednesday by the Ministry of Finance shows that Taipei City's revenue from land value increment tax declined by NT$110 million in July from the previous month. The situation is believed to be the result of recent measures taken by the central bank to cool the overheated property market in the greater Taipei area.
On the same day, however, a building located near the Taipei Railway Station was auctioned off at a record NT$8.33 million (US$261,000) per ping (one ping equals 3.3 square meters).

The phenomena are related to the polarization of wealth distribution and rural-urban development. More and more high-income earners are scrambling to buy luxury residences in prime areas to show how wealthy they are, pushing housing prices higher and higher. This group of people has no need to borrow money from financial institutions and therefore is not affected by the property market cooling measures.
On the other hand, those at the bottom of the wealth pyramid cannot afford to buy homes unless they can secure a bank mortgage. Any credit control measures by the government impacts them directly.

The skyrocketing housing prices in prime areas of Taipei City can be attributed to the scant land availability there. To resolve the problem, Taipei City and the soon-to-be-established Xinbei City should be merged into a single new metropolis as soon as possible. With proper planning and development, many prime areas would be created, which would help stabilize land prices. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to hold investment promotion in Tokyo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 14:46:32 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is scheduled to hold an investment- solicitation meeting in Tokyo Aug. 24 with the aim of seeking the cooperation of Japanese investors to jointly tap into the massive Chinese market, a ministry official said Friday.

The meeting, aimed at attracting Japanese investment to mainly explore China's medical and health-care market, is expected to see the participation of 400 Taiwanese and Japanese companies, the official said.

Anticipating that enormous business opportunities will be created in the wake of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan signed with China June 29, Japan's Mizuho Corporate Bank inked a memorandum of understanding with the MOEA in January to broker cooperation between businesses in Taiwan and Japan seeking to invest in China and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries, according to the official.

He added that with the medical and health-care service sector included on the ECFA's "early harvest" list of goods and services eligible for preferential market access treatment, Taiwanese businesses will be allowed to set up hospitals in areas with high concentrations of Taiwanese businesses, including Shanghai City and Jiangsu, Fujian, Guangdong and Hainan provinces.

This factor has spurred great interest among Japanese businesses in cooperating with Taiwanese investors to grab a share of the potentially lucrative medical and health-care market in China, the official added.
The Japanese bank unveiled in May a list of 10 Japanese small and medium-sized enterprises interested in cooperating with Taiwanese businesses.

The participants in the Tokyo meeting are expected to include members of a development association of medical and health-care industries across the Taiwan Strait headed by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Liao Kuo-tung and aimed at developing and integrating the medical markets on either side of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.78 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 15:31:57 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.78 percent Friday on a technical rebound after the market incurred heavy losses in the past few sessions amid concerns over the global economic climate, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 61.79 points to 7,891.58 after moving between 7,830.46 and 7,906.35 on turnover of NT$131.15 billion (US$4.10 billion).

The market opened up 0.21 percent as bargain hunting emerged and the momentum accelerated, led by the bellwether electronics sector, which had been hard hit, in particular, by worse-than-expected July sales reported by personal computer stocks, dealers said.
The buying also spread to old economy shares, as investors still embraced high hopes that increasing economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait will boost their earnings, they said.
A total of 2,673 stocks closed up and 1,065 were down, with 299 remaining unchanged.

The construction sector scored the highest gains, up 2.4 percent. Plastics and chemical stocks rose 1.2 percent, paper and pulp shares added 1.0 percent, machinery and electronics gained 0.9 percent, and textile stocks added 0.80.
Foodstuffs and financial stocks gained 0.3 percent, while the cement sector fell 0.10 percent.
After the index rose to breach the key 8,000-point mark Monday, investors scrambled to take profits, pushing the market down 2.63 percent in the past three trading days.
"Despite the selling, the market has held itself well above 7,800 points, paving the path for today's rebound, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
Tang said bargain hunters were eyeing small and medium-sized high-tech stocks, while the electronics heavyweights appeared lackluster.
As fears of further volatility on Wall Street remained in place, many foreign institutional investors tended to stay on the sidelines and to leave large-cap high-tech stocks alone, Tang said.
"Without aggressive buying from foreign investors to boost the high-tech heavyweights, the broader market still traded in a narrow range," Tang said.
"I expect consolidation will continue to dominate market movements. It will not be easy for the bourse to surmount the resistance ahead of 8,000 points next week," he said.
Among the small and medium-sized stocks, touch panel maker Wintek rose 6.88 percent to NT$37.30 and optical storage media firm Gigastorage gained 6.13 percent to end at NT$45.90.
However, large-cap United Microelectronics Corp. closed unchanged at NT$14.10, while rival Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. fell 0.17 percent to finish the day at NT$60.10.
In the old economy sector, Prince Housing rose 3.13 percent to close at NT$16.50, while Taiwan Pulp and Paper gained 4.18 percent to end trading at NT$14.95.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA leads to new model for Taiwan-Japan cooperation: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 15:46:17 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The recently concluded cross-Taiwan Strait trade deal is likely to bring forth a new model for cooperation in which Japan can use Taiwan as a base to access the Chinese market, a Cabinet official said Friday.

According to Minister without Porfolio Yiin Chii-ming, who has just returned from Japan, Japanese businesses are paying great attention to the issue following the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, under which selected Taiwanese products will gain zero-tariff entry to China.

Yiin said that while in Japan, he read a news report that quoted Japan's new ambassador to Beijing as saying that "if Japan does not sign a free trade agreement with China, Japan will sink," showing the impact of the cross-strait ECFA on foreign countries.

The minister said the ECFA, combined with direct cross-strait shipping and air links and the soon-to-be-launched air links between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport, will significantly enhance Taiwan's competitive edge.
Taiwan's rich experience with the Chinese market also makes Taiwan a perfect partner for Japanese businesses intending to enter the Chinese market, Yiin said.

The minister was speaking at a news conference held by the ruling Kuomintang legislative caucus to discuss the benefits of the ECFA's early-harvest program, under which China will reduce the tariffs for 539 Taiwanese goods to zero within two years after the agreement takes effect.

According to a forecast by the Cabinet, the program will create 60,000 jobs in Taiwan, increase output by NT$190 billion, raise the gross domestic product by NT$54.9 billion and allow Taiwan to save NT$29.5 billion in tariffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-St. Lucia tennis camp concludes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 16:43:12 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A two-week Taiwan-sponsored tennis camp for Saint Lucian youths ended Thursday in the Caribbean nation, according to a statement from the Republic of China Embassy in Saint Lucia.
The camp was organized by the embassy in collaboration with Saint Lucia's Ministry of Youth and Sports and the Saint Lucia Tennis Association.
It was coached by six tennis players from Taiwan's Fu Jen Catholic University, along with coaches from two local tennis schools.
More than 200 guests attended the closing ceremony, including Taiwanese diplomats and Saint Lucian officials.
As part of the ceremony, the six tennis ambassadors from Taiwan put on a magic show, while local camp participants performed Shaolin martial arts, Taiwanese songs and a "tennis dance. "
Several awards were also presented to the participants in the categories of best athlete, most potential, best progress and best sportsmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-premier diagnosed with Legionnaires' disease: hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 17:01:06 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Tang Fei was diagnosed with Legionnaires' disease after being flown to Taiwan on an emergency flight from China early Thursday for treatment of a lung infection at Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, a hospital spokesman said Friday.

After diagnosing him with Legionnaires' disease, a type of pneumonia caused by bacteria called Legionella, doctors treated him with erythromycin, an antibiotic, and notified the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) of his case, the spokesman said.

After conducting a chest X-ray and examination Friday morning, a doctor said Tang showed improvement in his pneumonia, heart irregularities, shortness of breath and pleural effusion -- fluid accumulated around the lungs.
Other checks also showed improvements, such as a decrease in lung inflammation indicators and an increased white blood cell count.
Moreover, his vital signs, including pulse, body temperature and blood pressure, all fell within normal ranges, the spokesman said, adding that Tang was fully conscious and had regained his appetite.

According to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw, anyone can be infected with Legionnaire's disease, which is spread through aerosols -- tiny airborne water particles that evaporate very quickly -- from an infected source such as a shower head, a hot tub or other piped water.
Chou said the condition is not contagious.
Chou also said that because Tang caught the disease outside Taiwan, the CDC has no plan to investigate the source of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to consider raising Chinese visitor quota
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 17:21:01 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is being prompted to consider increasing the daily quota of Chinese people allowed to visit the country, thanks to the increasing and seemingly unstoppable growth in the number of Chinese visitors.

Asked about the current Chinese visitor quota, which restricts the entrance of visitors from China to 3,000 people per day, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said Friday that the government will carefully study whether or not to raise the quota.
"There are many factors involved," Lai said, noting that pursuing the growth of tourism should not just focus on the volume of visitors.

Shao Qiwei, president of the Beijing-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association, who is currently visiting Taipei to attend a travel fair, said earlier in the day that the volume of visits to Taiwan by Chinese travelers is expected to surge to 1.5 million this year.

The number will soon break the 3-million barrier, Shao predicted, advising the authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to outline strategies in advance to handle the rising number of Chinese tourists.

In response, Chen Mei-hsiu, chief of the Tourism Bureau's Hotel, Travel and Training Division, said visits by Chinese reached a peak between April and June. During this period, the daily number of visitors reached as high 7,200 at one point, she said.

This was possible because the quota sets a maximum number. If the actual number of arrivals on any given day falls below the quota limit, the shortfall can be carried over and added to the following day's accumulated quota, and so on.

In July, the volume of Chinese visitors returned to the normal level of below 3,000 per day, Chen went on, adding that she expects another wave of Chinese visits in October, when Chinese workers have a long vacation to celebrate Oct. 1 National Day.

Chen said that any adjustment will be made depending on market demand, but added that the bureau must still consider many factors, including the number of hotels, tour buses and tour guides in the country.
"The quota of 3,000 will be enough until the end of the year, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC mission introduces dragon fruit technologies in Saint Lucia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 17:30:39 (By Wu Hsien-shen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Embassy in Saint Lucia sponsored a dragon fruit tasting event Thursday to introduce the tropical fruit and growing technologies to farmers and fruit traders in Taiwan's Caribbean ally.

Staff members of the Taiwanese agricultural technical mission in Saint Lucia demonstrated dragon fruit cultivating technologies and the fruit's characteristics to participants in the event, including Saint Lucian agricultural promotion officials, executives of farm produce cooperatives, supermarket operators, farmers and journalists.

According to Tom Chou, the ROC ambassador to Saint Lucia and host of the event, dragon fruit plants begin flowering 12 to 18 months after planting with organic fertilizer and deepened drainage, making it an ideal source of income for farmers.
Chou said many of the farmers in attendance were highly interested in the fruit and said they would plant it after the demonstration.

According to the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture, dragon fruit has been cultivated in Taiwan for more than 17 years and has been proven effective to avoid indigestion and brain disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug ring busted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 18:12:20 (By Johnson Sun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Police announced Friday that they had busted a drug-smuggling ring thanks to information exchanges between local police and their Japanese counterparts.

Police said they arrested the mastermind of the ring, a 64-year-old surnamed Yang, along with four of his subordinates, in the departure lounge at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport the previous afternoon, as well as three drug mules, including a 29-year-old disabled woman.
Police also seized 559.5 grams of amphetamine the mules had hidden inside their body cavities.

Yang had previously been sentenced to 15 years in prison for heroin smuggling by Taipei Shihlin District Court in 2007, police said. However, he fled into a mountainous area in Shihting, Taipei County, and was put on the wanted list.
Police said Yang would often find street people to serve as the ring's drug mules, paying them between NT$50,000 (US$1,560) and NT$200,000 for each run, depending on the volume of each shipment.

They said that Yang would arrange for his subordinate, Lin, who is familiar with the Tokyo drug market, to keep a close watch on the drug mules during their time in Japan, and would then take them back to Taiwan after they had made their deliveries.
According to the police, between February and May, six mules working for the ring were arrested after arriving in Japan, with the Japanese authorities seizing 4.6 kg of amphetamine in total.

The smuggling came to the attention of police after TV celebrity Juan Mu-hua complained that he and other members of a Taiwanese tour group were detained at a Japanese airport in early March after two members of the group were caught smuggling drugs. The two were later found to be members of Yang's ring.
Police said Taiwan-produced amphetamine, due to its high degree of purity, can sell for NT$20,000 per gram in Japan, almost double the price sold in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA lauds local produce at agricultural pavilion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 18:54:54 (by S. M. Yang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan agricultural pavilion at the 2010 Taipei Cross-Strait Travel Fair, which runs from Friday to Aug. 16, presents visitors with a mix of fun and educational activities related to the country's agriculture, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said.

With 250 booths -- almost a quarter of the total booths at the exhibition -- the council is ambitious in promoting and marketing Taiwan's agricultural achievements in its first appearance at the fair, COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said in the opening remarks.

According to the council, the pavilion exhibits popular local produce such as tea leaves and features tasting stands for agriculture and fishery products included in the "early harvest list" of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , with the goal of attracting more buyers from mainland China.

The council estimates that within three years of signing the ECFA, the export volume to China of just three of Taiwan's agricultural products -- groupers, tea leaves and a special type of orchid called oncidium -- will reach US$110 million, seven times the amount in 2009.
Aside from inviting celebrities to share their travel experiences at the pavilion, the council has also prepared a do-it-yourself tea-making stall.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20-somethings most likely to defy ghosts in buying homes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 19:12:17 (By Lin Yi-feng and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: People in the 20-29 age bracket are the most fearless in buying residential property during "ghost month, " while those over 50 still harbor strong superstitions, a local real estate company said Friday.

Analyzing data on home transactions it brokered between 2006 and 2009, H&B Realty Franchise System found that the share of all homes bought by people in the 20-29 age bracket during "ghost month" (19.2 percent) was a staggering 45 percent higher than the 13.2 percent share young adults averaged during the previous "normal" month.
In contrast, the average share of the 50-59 age bracket during "ghost month" was 11.8 percent, down from 20.4 percent in the previous month, a 42 percent plunge.
"Ghost month, " the seventh month of the lunar calendar, is the time when the Gates of Hades are opened to let ghosts and spirits into the world of the living for a month-long party.
There are many traditional taboos associated with "ghost month, " including the belief that buying real estate during the month will invite the ghosts into the house and bring bad luck.

But with all age groups below the age of 50 showing increases in the share of homes they buy during ghost month, the taboo seems to be followed today mainly by older generations, said Hsu Chia-hsing, director of the H&B Realty's research division.
Young home buyers in the 20-29 age bracket had a material reason for defying the traditional taboo.
"The trend shows that young home buyers actively struck deals in 'ghost month' because they felt there was a better chance of negotiating deeper discounts," Hsu said.

The 40-49 age group, which usually accounts for the most home purchases of any age bracket throughout the year also had the highest share (31.4 percent) during "ghost month, " followed by the 30-39 age group with a 27.6 percent share.
The shares of both groups rose by more than 3 percentage points compared to the month before "ghost month," Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Powerchip's China LED plant to open in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 19:25:09 (By Kang Shih-jen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Memory chip maker Powerchip Technology Corp. said Friday its LED materials plant under construction in Xuzhou, China, part of a plan to diversify its business, will begin operations in 2011.

Speaking on the sideline of a technology forum in Shanghai, Powerchip Chairman Frank Huang said the new plant will benefit from Xuzhou's geographic advantage and convenient transportation links after it becomes operational.
In March, Powerchip announced it would invest US$15 million through a third location in the Xuzhou facility, which will produce LED EPI wafers and chips, core LED materials.

Huang said the company plans to invest a total of US$300 million in LED production facilities in China to help cushion the impact of a down cycle in Powerchip's core business -- dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip manufacturing.

Powerchip is one of many Taiwanese high-tech firms, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp., that have invested in the production of energy efficiency or renewable energy products, such as LEDs and solar cells, and are also targeting China's market.

In the first half of the year, 925,000 LED TVs were sold in China, 10.6 percent of all flat panel TVs sold there during the period. This market penetration rate is expected to rise to 25 percent in the second half of the year, indicating the LED sector will grow accordingly.

Last month, TSMC said it would raise its 2010 capital expenditure to US$5.9 billion from the previously planned US$4.8 billion and assign about US$100 million to business diversification, which the market believes will be directed at the LED and solar power sectors.
The global DRAM sector is suffering from declining prices because of demand weakened by the eurozone's debt problems and the slowing pace of global economic recovery, market observers said.

DRAM prices staged a significant rebound in the fourth quarter of last year after a meltdown amid the global financial crisis in 2008, and the momentum extended into the first quarter of this year before the European debt problems surfaced.

Several Taiwanese DRAM makers, such as Powerchip, Nanya Technology Corp. and Inotera Memories Inc., are migrating to advanced production process in an attempt to cut costs to reduce the impact of product price falls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan Science Park to offer 7,857 jobs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 19:33:13 (By Li Hsin-chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A Central Taiwan Science Park (CTSP) official said Friday that 25 companies in the science park are seeking 7,857 new employees to meet higher workforce demand for production expansion.
The companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp., will team up to hold an Aug. 15 job fair and recruitment drive, the official said.

TSMC needs 3,050 new employees, mostly engineers, to man a new 12-inch wafer plant and planned solar energy production facilities, while AU Optronics is looking for 1,800 newcomers, also mostly engineers, he said.

LED epiwafer and chip producer Lextar Corp. will offer 1,000 jobs at the job fair, while IC testing and packaging firm Siliconware Precision Industries Co. will provide an additional 860, the official added.
"The large job fair reflects the increasing need for technology talent to meet the needs of expansion on a recovery in the global market," the park official said.
With the global economy rebounding from a financial meltdown in 2008, the number of employees in the CTSP has been increasing accordingly, he went on.
"As of July, the number of employees had reached 21,785, the highest level since the science park began operations in 2003. No-one in the science park is on unpaid leave," he said.
In March, the CTSP held a similar job fair, offering 2,660 jobs and attracting about 7,000 applicants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Companies complain of space shortage at Taichung Computer Show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 19:39:18 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Companies participating in the 2010 Taichung Computer Show complained of a shortage of space at the Taichung World Trade Center at the exhibition's opening on Friday, the organizer said.

The 2010 Taichung Computer Show drew more than 100 companies that presented more than 400 booths in a space originally designed to accommodate only 250 booths, Taichung Computer Association Chairman Sun Teng-yuan said.
"The central Taiwan area needs a large-scale exhibition center, and the construction of such a facility should be completed as soon as possible," Sun said.
In response to the complaint, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu promised to accelerate the construction of a planned exhibition center in the central Taiwan city.

Chu Hui-lan, chief of the Taichung City Department of Economic Development, said that the first stage of construction on the new exhibition center -- located at the former site of Taichung Airport -- is expected to finish in just over two years.
By then, the facility will be able to accommodate an exhibition with 2,000 booths, Chu said.
Once the second stage is finished, the center will be able to accommodate 3,000 booths, she added.
This year's show runs through Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inspected products found to bear misleading information
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 19:59:34 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Manufacturers of 15 products recently inspected by the Consumers' Foundation were found to have provided misleading information on their packaging or labels, the foundation reported Friday.
The foundation recently purchased three types of cookies, eight instant beverages and ordinary beverage products, and four other varieties of products, on which to conduct random checks.

All the products looked at provided false or misleading information such as product names, pictures of products and product descriptions, said Yu Kai- hsiung, publisher of the foundation's Consumer Reports Magazine.
For example, Hokkaido Milk Cereal is actually made in Taiwan and the product's list of ingredients does not contain a single item from the Japanese prefecture of Hokkaido, Yu said.
Meanwhile, the packaging of one brand of crackers shows a picture of a wide variety of vegetables on the box, although only green onions are actually listed on the label.

The legend "Dahu strawberry" is highlighted in big letters on the packaging of a strawberry yogurt product, despite the fact that the product does not actually contain strawberries, while a honey tea product does not actually contain any honey, Yu added.
Yang Nai-yen, a foundation member, warned consumers to pay more attention to what they are buying and to avoid consuming excessive amounts of drinks containing artificial flavoring.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen urged manufacturers of the poorly packaged products make improvements in the packaging and labeling of their products and to stop making misleading claims to consumers.

According to the Food Sanitation Management Act, the Department of Health could fine manufacturers up to NT$200,000 (US$6,266) for misleading consumers, Yu said, adding that the manufacturers are also at risk of being fined NT$25 million by the Fair Trade Commission (FTC).

Yu also urged the DOH and FTC to address the situation and warned that if they fail to do so, the foundation will file a complaint with the Control Yuan accusing the two agencies of shirking their duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSBC move will not increase cost of changing money: central bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 20:01:08 (By Lin Yi-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The cost of foreign exchange transactions will not be affected by HSBC's decision to stop supplying Taiwanese banks with foreign banknotes in October, Taiwan's central bank pledged Friday.

A local newspaper reported that HSBC, which has a large share of the global wholesale banknote trading market, will stop supplying Taiwanese banks with foreign banknotes on Oct. 19, which could make it more expensive for the public to buy or sell U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Hong Kong dollars or other foreign currencies.
After HSBC's withdrawal from the market, Bank of America (BOA) will become the only supplier of foreign banknotes in Taiwan, the report said.
The Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) believes, however, that BOA can handle the added demand.
"Although BOA will be the only bank that supplies foreign banknotes, it will be asked to fully meet the needs of the people, " said Spencer Lin, head of the central bank's Bureau of Foreign Exchange.

Lin contended that the withdrawal of HSBC from the banknote market will not make buying and selling of foreign exchange more expensive, and he said the central bank has already asked BOA to supply banknotes for the same price as previously.

HSBC said recently that it decided to stop the service because foreign currency transaction procedures have become stricter and more complex since the attacks on New York City on Sept. 11, 2001, due to the requirements of anti-terrorist and anti-money laundering organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second extra legislative session to last two weeks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 20:21:13 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislature will start an extraordinary session next week to screen a recently signed trade pact with China and several critical bills, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.
"The extra session will last two weeks, " Wang said after presiding over a meeting of legislative caucus leaders of major political parties earlier in the day.
It was the only thing the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties agreed on during the meeting, Wang said.

The ruling and opposition camps remained divided on issues regarding the screening of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, such as whether the pact should be subject to a line-item review or be passed or vetoed as a package.
Wang said the issue will be further discussed at an informal plenary session Monday.
The upcoming extra session will be the second of its kind since the Kuomintang- controlled Legislative Yuan went into summer recess.

In addition to examining the ECFA deal, the session is also expected to screen urgent bills presented by the ruling party, including five bills that will pave the way for enforcing the ECFA as well as three bills that amend existing laws to allow admission of Chinese students into local tertiary education institutions.

The five ECFA-related bills are an intellectual property rights protection agreement with China and amendments to current trademark law, patent law and regulations on customs duties and plant registration.

Also high on the KMT-proposed list are a package of draft amendments to the National Health Insurance to smooth the way for the introduction of a second generation health insurance program and draft revisions to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law that will ensure no changes to the legislative constituencies for 10 years.
The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), however, questioned the propriety of dealing with those bills in an extra session.

Ker Chien-ming, the party's top legislative whip, said a provisional session should only deal with urgent bills, while those that will have an impact on the national well-being or popular interests should be addressed at regular sessions.

"Our stance is that the coming extra session should only screen the ECFA deal, and its supplementary bills should be examined at the next normal legislative session," Ker said, adding that the DPP will only submit a bill on holding an ECFA referendum at the extra session.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP touts ECFA effects while meeting foreign business group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 20:32:39 (By Garfie Lee and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew welcomed a Guatemalan business delegation Friday, saying the group came at a good time to seek trade or joint-venture deals as Taiwan was coming out of the global financial crunch and has recently signed a landmark trade pact with China.

"Our economy is regaining growth momentum after a recession amid the 2008-2009 global financial tsunami and relations across the Taiwan Strait have greatly improved in recent years, helping our businesspeople become more confident of their prospects, " Siew said while meeting the group.
Moreover, Siew said he believes that the recent signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will make Taiwanese businesses even more competitive in the global market.

Noting that Taiwan has already forged close links with Guatemala in medical care, economics, agriculture and technology, Siew said the Taiwanese government will work to strengthen business ties with the central American ally.
"We will also encourage our business groups to invest more in your country and help promote Guatemalan products in Asian markets, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local university sees breakthrough in world ranking
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 21:11:12 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) ranked 127th in Shanghai Jiao Tong University's most recent annual ranking of world universities released Friday.

NTU, one of Taiwan's most highly reputed academic institutions, moved up 23 notches from the year before, vaulting past the National University of Singapore for the first time since the index began in 2003 to lead all universities in the worldwide Chinese community.
The National University of Singapore ranked 145th, falling from 140th in the 2009 ranking.
Among Taiwan schools listed in the top 500, Taiwan's National Cheng Kung University was ranked 256th, followed by National Chiao Tung University at 313th and National Tsinghua University at 314th.
In Hong Kong, the Chinese University of Hong Kong was the highest ranked at 179th, advancing 56 notches from its previous ranking. It was followed by the University of Hong Kong at 207th.

Beijing-based Tsinghua University was scored as the best university in China, placing 191st in the ranking. Peking University, also located in Beijing, ranked 199th and was followed by Zhejiang University at 213.

Harvard University in the United States remained ranked as the world's top university for the eighth year in a row while the University of Tokyo in Japan, which ranked 20th, was seen as the best university in Asia.

The universities were evaluated based on criteria such as the number of Nobel prizes and Fields medals won by staff and alumni, the number of highly cited researchers on staff, and the number of articles by faculty published in Nature and Science magazines.

NTU said its move up the ladder proved the success of the government's project to help domestic universities rank among the world's best academic centers. It attributed much of its progress to being scored higher than in 2009 (16.1 to 10.3) for the number of highly cited researchers on the staff.
The number of articles by faculty published in renowned academic magazines also helped improve its ranking, NTU said.

Beginning in 2005, the government subsidized top universities to upgrade fundamental facilities, improve the content of the curriculum and integrate research centers to help them be recognized as among the world's top universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials paint rosy picture of cross-strait tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 21:35:53 (By Alex Chiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese tourism official said Friday that the annual number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan is expected to hit 3 million soon and urged the two sides to make adequate preparations.

"It has been two years since Taiwan opened itself to mainland tourists and the number of visiting tourists has since been increasing at a rate beyond our expectations, " Shao Qiwei, chairman of the China National Tourism Administration and the Cross-Strait Tourism Association, said at the opening ceremony.
"If things go well, the number of visits made by mainland tourists to Taiwan could reach 1.2 million for 2010," he said, noting that "all direct cross-strait flights fill up."
The figure could exceed 1.5 million this year if the number of visiting Chinese professionals is included, which would mark a 109 percent increase year on year, Shao said.
In 2009, Chinese tourists made 606,174 visits to Taiwan, up 200 percent from a year earlier, according to Taiwan's official figures.
Since Taiwan opened to Chinese tourists in July 2008, Chinese tourists -- who are only allowed to travel in Taiwan as part of tour groups -- have made a total of 1.28 million visits to Taiwan.
Against this backdrop, the number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan should soon beat the 3 million target, Shao said.
Shao, at the head of a Chinese delegation, is visiting Taiwan to attend the 2010 Taipei Cross-Strait Travel Fair, which opened Friday and will run through Aug. 16.

A record of nearly 1,200 representatives from 190 tourism associations or travel agencies throughout China took part in the fair, the organizers added, saying that a total of 871 booths are in use, including 516 by Taiwanese exhibitors.
This year's fair is three times larger than past fairs.
The organizers predicted that the total number of visitors to the fair would surpass 150,000.

While Chinese exhibitors showcased folk songs and dances and martial arts performances at their booths, exhibitors at the Taiwan agricultural pavilion provided samples of tea, dried fruit, nut crackers, sausages, dried squid and other well-known local food.
"Taiwan has very good agriculture and we hope to promote Taiwan's agricultural products here at the fair, " exhibitor Lin Yu-ping told the Central News Agency at the event.

Janice Lai, director-general of Taiwan's Tourism Office and the Strait Tourism and Travel Association, said Taiwanese made 4.08 million visits to China last year, with the figure likely to hit 5 million this year.
"We don't just want to appeal to Chinese tourists, but also those from other parts of the world," she said.
Wang Yixue, the honorary president of China's Huangshan Municipal Association of Travel Services, told CNA that his association was taking part in the fair for its fifth year in a row.
"Taiwan has been a major source of tourists to Mount Huang and we want to use this opportunity to help local people understand how to enjoy an in-depth tour there," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Smartphone users advised on countering virus attacks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 21:40:44 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Online security experts in Taiwan suggested on Friday that smartphone users download software, update their phone systems, and take extra precautions when visiting websites on their devices to avoid virus attacks.

Samson Tai, the director of the sales engineering department at Taiwan's major anti-virus solution provider Trend Micro Inc., urged smartphone users to pay special attention when opening PDF or Flash files on webpages as there might be security holes.
"When you open a PDF file on your smartphone, a virus could invade your phone and steal your information," he said.
Tai urged users to keep updating their phone's operating systems or application software as updates will fix security holes.
Smartphone users are particularly vulnerable to giving away personal account and password information on fake shopping or bank websites, Tai said.

Many users often don't realize it when they are visiting fake websites on smartphones because website addresses are either very small or hidden on mobile phone screens for better viewing, " Tai told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview.
He suggested that smartphone users resort to anti-virus software that can help them identify if the websites they are visiting are real or not.
The issue of viruses attacking smartphone systems has gained urgency recently after media reported that a Trojan virus has infected smartphones using the increasingly popular Android platform.

Luke Lin, an analyst with Taiwan's Digitimes Inc., told CNA that free anti-virus software that can deal with the problem is available on the Internet, but he said he expected cases of virus attacks on smartphones to increase as sales of the phones grow.
In one case last month, according to Lin, a wallpaper software for Google's Android phones reportedly stole users' personal information.
Thomas Chuang, a consultant to the Taiwan branch of U.S. computer security giant Symantec, said that in the past, hackers launched attacks for the sake of fame, but the situation is different now.
"Many of the attacks are now launched by crime groups to steal personal accounts and passwords," Chuang told CNA by telephone.
"Or they try to profit from having your smartphone send out large numbers of text messages or wiretap your phone calls," he said.
Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., Taiwan's third largest telecom operator that sells Apple's iPhones, HTC smartphones and Nokia smartphones, has yet to be hit by the bugs.
"So far, we haven't heard of any such case in Taiwan or from our users, " spokeswoman Alison Kao told CNA in a telephone interview.
Chunghwa Telecom Co., Taiwan' largest telecom operator, also said that it was not aware of any attacks on the smartphones it distributed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fruit farmers complain of costly macaque attacks
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 21:57:37 (by Shwu Fen Wang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Fruit farmers from Chai mountain complained at the Kaohsiung City Council Friday of massive financial losses resulting from macaques raiding their orchards.

The monkeys often destroy crops such as lychees, longans, and bamboo shoots just before the beginning of the harvest season, seriously damaging the crops, said Li Kuo-hsiung, a farmer who said he was fed up with the ordeal.
The worst thing is that the farmers aren't allowed to catch the monkeys, Li said.
The monkeys are protected under the Wildlife Conservation Law.

In response to the farmers' complaints, Kaohsiung City Economic Development Bureau Deputy Lin Ying-pin said the damage caused by the animals is not within a wildlife conservation area, so it cannot be compensated.
Once the Legislative Yuan finishes amending the national park law and makes Chai mountain a national natural park, however, he said he would do everything possible to help.
Kaohsiung City Councilor Li Chiao-ju urged the city government to assist the farmers in applying for help.
Li Kuo-hsiung's application for national compensation in 2004 was rejected by the Supreme Court in 2007 because the farms were not in the wildlife conservation area.
Li and other farmers have been seeking the government's help since 2001, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Mazda announces vehicle recall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 22:06:43 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Mazda Taiwan Corporation said Friday it will recall approximately 13,250 vehicles to deal with potentially problematic power steering lines that could make steering difficult.

The recall involves Mazda3 2.0, Mazda3 2.0 Sport and Mazda 5 series models produced from March 2007 to December 2008 in which the power steering lines may have been contaminated during the manufacturing process.
Mazda said it will replace the steering pump and oil pipe in each of the recalled vehicles and clean the steering system for free.
Drivers of these vehicles may experience poor driving performance or have difficulty steering, according to the company, or the steering system's warning light may come on.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Aug. 13 (II)

TEXT.P: NT$46.27 billion investment as of Aug. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation calls for action against misleading food names
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug.13 (CNA) 08/13/10 22:48:25 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation said Friday the government should tighten enforcement of food labeling regulations as many snacks and soft drinks sold in the local market bear misleading names and labels.
"In a recent spot inspection, 10 of the 15 food products we checked carried names or illustrations that could mislead consumers," said Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the foundation.

A locally produced brand of oat flakes, for instance, has "Hokkaido" in its name, which could mislead consumers into believing that the snack originated on the Japanese island of Hokkaido, Hsieh said.

In another case, the packaging of a box crackers showed colorful pictures of nearly 10 kinds of vegetables, but the crackers contained only one kind of vegetable -- green onion -- according to their label.
Meanwhile, a "Dahu strawberry yogurt" marketed by a noted food processor does not contain any strawberries, Hsieh said.
Likewise, a "honey pear tea" drink distributed by an international food conglomerate does not contain honey.
These companies might have violated the food labeling law as the names and packaging of the products in question could mislead consumers, Hsieh said.

"The Department of Health and the Fair Trade Commission should not take a hands- off attitude or turn a blind eye to such dishonest marketing strategies at the expense of consumers' interests, " Hsieh said.
If the two agenices fail to step up law enforcement, Hsieh said the foundation will file an appeal to the Control Yuan, the highest-level monitor of government behavior and civil servant integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Next Media's NT$3 billion TV gamble
DOC.DATELINE: 08/13/10 22:51:10 (Business Today 711)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Next Media from Hong Kong, known for its sensationalist scoops and celebrity gossip, launched an online video broadcasting service on July 30 after it received the latest in a string of National Communications Commission (NCC) rejections to its application for a cable TV license.
Next Media has been rejected three times since it began applying in 2009.

Many viewers of Next Media's online premiere were surprised by its content, which they described as similar to DaAi TV, a Buddhist TV channel with news programs focused on positive and inspiring stories.

Perhaps it is the media group's strategy to win over the hearts of NCC commissioners and convince them to approve its cable TV license. The group's controversial CEO Jimmy Lai could face a big business crisis if the group's future TV programs follow the same style.

Lai is betting the company's future on TV with a NT$3 billion (US$93.75 million) investment as its publications in Taiwan -- the newspaper Apple Daily and the weekly Next Magazine -- saw last year's advertising revenues fall 4.9 percent and 19.4 percent respectively.
Only two of Next TV's five channels received approval from the NCC -- the movie channel approved in March and the sports channel on July 28.
While the company's sports channel was approved, however, its applications for news, entertainment, and general information channels was put on hold for the third time.
Two days later, the company began streaming Next TV for free through the station's website, which doesn't require government approval.
Next TV's online broadcasting started with four one-hour live news programs and an entertainment news show on weekdays, with replays of the programs filling the rest of the day.

To differentiate itself from other channels, Next Media has invested heavily in equipment. All of its content is digitized and produced in high definition -- well ahead of the Taiwanese government's goal of TV channels' digital conversion in 2012.
It also acquired scanning equipment used in Hollywood animation films so it can produce 90-second clips about news stories in one and a half hours at the reporter's request.

While the company's print media in Taiwan often leads the agenda of local news channels, its TV operation takes a more conservative approach. The station has a team of senior editors dubbed "the internal NCC" that closely monitors and advises on the content of each story.

"There are no worries about not receiving licenses from the NCC, because Next TV's news programming is so toned down now, it looks like advertisements promoting government policy, " a Next TV anchor said.

According to Lai, the monthly cost of running Next TV is NT$100 million. Everyone is watching how long he can keep spending on the station before getting the license and if he will keep the current style after the NCC's approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment in EPZs exceed NT$40 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 23:15:49 (By Lin Huei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New investment in Taiwan's export processing zones (EPZ) reached NT$46.27 billion for the year as of Aug. 12, the Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
Administration head Shen Jong-chin said the figure had already exceeded the government-set target for 2010 by nearly 22 percent, a reflection of Taiwan's rebounding economy.
He said manufacturers investing in the zone are mainly involved in the semiconductor, electronics and solar energy sectors.

The new investment is expected to create 8,800 new job opportunities, the administration said. A total of 59,913 people are currently employed in Taiwan's EPZs, 1,911 more than the 58,002 employed in the zones in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Goat auctions expected to return soon: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 23:28:25 (By Yang Su-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The auctioning of goats at markets in the central Taiwan counties of Changhua and Yunlin is expected to resume before Aug. 31 after a successful nationwide inoculation against goat pox virus (GPV) , an official at the Council of Agriculture said Friday.

The massive GPV outbreak, which began with a case reported in Yunlin on April 9, has been effectively controlled by the inoculation launched on June 22, said Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the council.
According to the bureau, 99 percent -- or 225,159 heads -- of the goats in Taiwan had been vaccinated as of Aug. 12.
The number of affected goat farms declined from 98 in early July to 32 a month later, the bureau said in a statement released Friday.

While breeders and butchers all expressed concern over when goat trading would resume, the bureau decided to hold a meeting of experts in the next few days to determine whether the outbreak could be considered over, the statement said.
According to bureau statistics, 186 goat farms were reported affected by GPV between April 9 and June 22, during which 17,350 goats were culled.
After the nationwide inoculation began, 347 farms were reported affected, with 5,206 goats culled.
Huang said that some of the reported cases after the launch of the vaccination occurred before the goats at those farms were given shots.
There are around 2,500 goat farms in Taiwan.

Goat meat prices rose at meat markets in Changhua and Yunlin soon after the outbreak, with the wholesale price growing from NT$140 (US$4.39) per kilogram to between NT$190 and NT$210, according to Huang.
GPV -- a highly contagious disease characterized by fever, ocular and nasal discharges -- is spread via contact among the animals. GPV cannot infect humans and can be destroyed by high temperatures.
Taiwan first reported the virus in July 2008 in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, an outbreak that is believed to have been related to animals smuggled in from GPV-affected countries.
At that time only two goat farms reported GPV infections and the disease was brought under control in a week after culling the goats on the two farms, the Council of Agriculture said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Mazda announces vehicle recall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 22:06:43 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Mazda Taiwan Corporation said Friday it will recall approximately 13,250 vehicles to deal with potentially problematic power steering lines that could make steering difficult.

The recall involves Mazda3 2.0, Mazda3 2.0 Sport and Mazda 5 series models produced from March 2007 to December 2008 in which the power steering lines may have been contaminated during the manufacturing process.
Mazda said it will replace the steering pump and oil pipe in each of the recalled vehicles and clean the steering system for free.
Drivers of these vehicles may experience poor driving performance or have difficulty steering, according to the company, or the steering system's warning light may come on.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Aug. 13 (II)

TEXT.P: NT$46.27 billion investment as of Aug. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation calls for action against misleading food names
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug.13 (CNA) 08/13/10 22:48:25 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation said Friday the government should tighten enforcement of food labeling regulations as many snacks and soft drinks sold in the local market bear misleading names and labels.
"In a recent spot inspection, 10 of the 15 food products we checked carried names or illustrations that could mislead consumers," said Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the foundation.

A locally produced brand of oat flakes, for instance, has "Hokkaido" in its name, which could mislead consumers into believing that the snack originated on the Japanese island of Hokkaido, Hsieh said.

In another case, the packaging of a box crackers showed colorful pictures of nearly 10 kinds of vegetables, but the crackers contained only one kind of vegetable -- green onion -- according to their label.
Meanwhile, a "Dahu strawberry yogurt" marketed by a noted food processor does not contain any strawberries, Hsieh said.
Likewise, a "honey pear tea" drink distributed by an international food conglomerate does not contain honey.
These companies might have violated the food labeling law as the names and packaging of the products in question could mislead consumers, Hsieh said.

"The Department of Health and the Fair Trade Commission should not take a hands- off attitude or turn a blind eye to such dishonest marketing strategies at the expense of consumers' interests, " Hsieh said.
If the two agenices fail to step up law enforcement, Hsieh said the foundation will file an appeal to the Control Yuan, the highest-level monitor of government behavior and civil servant integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Next Media's NT$3 billion TV gamble
DOC.DATELINE: 08/13/10 22:51:10 (Business Today 711)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Next Media from Hong Kong, known for its sensationalist scoops and celebrity gossip, launched an online video broadcasting service on July 30 after it received the latest in a string of National Communications Commission (NCC) rejections to its application for a cable TV license.
Next Media has been rejected three times since it began applying in 2009.

Many viewers of Next Media's online premiere were surprised by its content, which they described as similar to DaAi TV, a Buddhist TV channel with news programs focused on positive and inspiring stories.

Perhaps it is the media group's strategy to win over the hearts of NCC commissioners and convince them to approve its cable TV license. The group's controversial CEO Jimmy Lai could face a big business crisis if the group's future TV programs follow the same style.

Lai is betting the company's future on TV with a NT$3 billion (US$93.75 million) investment as its publications in Taiwan -- the newspaper Apple Daily and the weekly Next Magazine -- saw last year's advertising revenues fall 4.9 percent and 19.4 percent respectively.
Only two of Next TV's five channels received approval from the NCC -- the movie channel approved in March and the sports channel on July 28.
While the company's sports channel was approved, however, its applications for news, entertainment, and general information channels was put on hold for the third time.
Two days later, the company began streaming Next TV for free through the station's website, which doesn't require government approval.
Next TV's online broadcasting started with four one-hour live news programs and an entertainment news show on weekdays, with replays of the programs filling the rest of the day.

To differentiate itself from other channels, Next Media has invested heavily in equipment. All of its content is digitized and produced in high definition -- well ahead of the Taiwanese government's goal of TV channels' digital conversion in 2012.
It also acquired scanning equipment used in Hollywood animation films so it can produce 90-second clips about news stories in one and a half hours at the reporter's request.

While the company's print media in Taiwan often leads the agenda of local news channels, its TV operation takes a more conservative approach. The station has a team of senior editors dubbed "the internal NCC" that closely monitors and advises on the content of each story.

"There are no worries about not receiving licenses from the NCC, because Next TV's news programming is so toned down now, it looks like advertisements promoting government policy, " a Next TV anchor said.

According to Lai, the monthly cost of running Next TV is NT$100 million. Everyone is watching how long he can keep spending on the station before getting the license and if he will keep the current style after the NCC's approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment in EPZs exceed NT$40 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 23:15:49 (By Lin Huei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New investment in Taiwan's export processing zones (EPZ) reached NT$46.27 billion for the year as of Aug. 12, the Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
Administration head Shen Jong-chin said the figure had already exceeded the government-set target for 2010 by nearly 22 percent, a reflection of Taiwan's rebounding economy.
He said manufacturers investing in the zone are mainly involved in the semiconductor, electronics and solar energy sectors.

The new investment is expected to create 8,800 new job opportunities, the administration said. A total of 59,913 people are currently employed in Taiwan's EPZs, 1,911 more than the 58,002 employed in the zones in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Goat auctions expected to return soon: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/10 23:28:25 (By Yang Su-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The auctioning of goats at markets in the central Taiwan counties of Changhua and Yunlin is expected to resume before Aug. 31 after a successful nationwide inoculation against goat pox virus (GPV) , an official at the Council of Agriculture said Friday.

The massive GPV outbreak, which began with a case reported in Yunlin on April 9, has been effectively controlled by the inoculation launched on June 22, said Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the council.
According to the bureau, 99 percent -- or 225,159 heads -- of the goats in Taiwan had been vaccinated as of Aug. 12.
The number of affected goat farms declined from 98 in early July to 32 a month later, the bureau said in a statement released Friday.

While breeders and butchers all expressed concern over when goat trading would resume, the bureau decided to hold a meeting of experts in the next few days to determine whether the outbreak could be considered over, the statement said.
According to bureau statistics, 186 goat farms were reported affected by GPV between April 9 and June 22, during which 17,350 goats were culled.
After the nationwide inoculation began, 347 farms were reported affected, with 5,206 goats culled.
Huang said that some of the reported cases after the launch of the vaccination occurred before the goats at those farms were given shots.
There are around 2,500 goat farms in Taiwan.

Goat meat prices rose at meat markets in Changhua and Yunlin soon after the outbreak, with the wholesale price growing from NT$140 (US$4.39) per kilogram to between NT$190 and NT$210, according to Huang.
GPV -- a highly contagious disease characterized by fever, ocular and nasal discharges -- is spread via contact among the animals. GPV cannot infect humans and can be destroyed by high temperatures.
Taiwan first reported the virus in July 2008 in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, an outbreak that is believed to have been related to animals smuggled in from GPV-affected countries.
At that time only two goat farms reported GPV infections and the disease was brought under control in a week after culling the goats on the two farms, the Council of Agriculture said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 14, 2010, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
