TEXT.P: The 2008-2009 global financial crunch not only battered Taiwan's economy but also exposed the vulnerability of its public finances.

Tax revenue is known to form the bedrock of a country's financial health. The higher the ratio of tax revenue in government spending, the healthier the country's finances. In Taiwan, however, the ratio fell below the alarming level of 60 percent to a record low of 59 percent last year.
The taxation woes could be attributed partly to the global financial disaster, but "human error" should take even greater blame for the plight.
For years, the government has lacked the mettle to engage in sweeping tax reform, turning a blind eye to flaws and imbalances in our taxation structure.

At the turn of the century, the government promised to balance the budget in 10 years. The vow has turned out to be empty talk because the government still has to rely on borrowing to stay afloat. More ironic is that debt is expected to account for a record high 13 percent of its total expenditure this year.

Given its financial fragility, the government cannot afford to sit on its hands any more. The decline in the ratio of tax revenue in government spending mainly stems from erosion of the tax base. As starters of a badly needed financial reform, action should be taken to expand that base.

Moreover, the government should create more income sources based on the "users pay" concept or by collaborating with private groups to better utilize its huge real estate holdings. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 16, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar almost flat in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 10:34:40 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$31.958 at 10 a.m. Monday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.002 from Friday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kaohsiung's Liuho Night Market wins top honor in online voting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 10:48:28 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Liuho Night Market in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung has won the top spot in all six categories of competition in an online poll on Taiwan's best night markets, the Tourism Bureau said Monday.
As of Sunday at midnight, Liuho had been voted the most environmentally friendly, most visitor-friendly, most interesting, easiest to shop at, most popular and best for food, the bureau said.
With night markets emerging as a "must-visit" tourist attraction for vacationers to Taiwan, the Tourism Bureau has made them a major theme of its tourism promotion for 2010.

The "most special night market" competition is part of the promotional campaign. In the first stage of competition, 10 major night markets were selected by travel agents and tourist industry executives. The top 10 were then put to an online poll that began July 20 and ended at midnight Aug. 15.
Taipei's Shilin Night Market emerged as the first runner-up in all six categories of competition, and Luodong Night Market in Yilan County won third place in all the categories.
On criticism about the fairness or credibility of the online voting, tourism officials said the results of the first-stage competition and the online voting accounted for 20 percent each in the race.

The final stage of competition, which will be evaluated by a panel of seven experts in food, tourism and other related fields through unannounced spot surveys, will account for 60 percent of the final scores, the officials said, adding that the results will be announced Aug. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tenor wins world vocal competition in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 11:33:06 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan tenor Fernando Wang won the first Singapore International Vocal Competition Sunday, beating out 149 competitors.

In addition to Wang, Taiwan sopranos Hong Yuqing and Lee Yeu-tsyr were among 12 vocalists who entered the finals. Hong, the gold medal winner of the New York- based New Tang Dynasty Television's 2008 vocal competition, placed fourth at the Singapore competition.
Each singer performed three songs, and despite fierce competition Wang came out ahead.
"Did I really win? " a surprised Wang asked before receiving the trophy.
Wang told the Central News Agency that he hadn't expected to win because he thought he could have done even better.
Wang also said he felt "honored" that his vocals could bring others pleasure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Typhoon-free summer buoys tourism

TEXT.P: Major vacation resorts around Taiwan, particularly seashore areas and lakeside spots, have been flooded with holidaymakers this summer, thanks to an absence of typhoons and less rainfall than usual.

Many mountain resorts, however, are still reeling from devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot, which battered Taiwan last August. As major mountain roads leading to those regions are fragile or unstable, the number of tourist arrivals at Alishan, Guguan and Maolin remains limited a year after the disaster.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the developments:
United Daily News:

Sun Moon Lake has emerged as the most popular tourist attraction, with the number of tourist arrivals totaling 4 million in the first seven months of the year, a figure that already exceeded the total for the whole of last year, according to statistics compiled by the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration.

Of the figure, 700,000 were Chinese visitors, surpassing the 500,000 Chinese tourists to the lake recorded in all of 2009, said Tseng Kuo-chi, director of the Sun Moon Lake administration office. Major hotels in the area have seen occupancy rates grow by 10 percent to 20 percent from the year-earlier levels, Tseng added.

The number of visitors to Kenting on the southern tip of Taiwan as well as the those to the islands of Liouciou and Green Island have also hit new records. Private bed and breakfast owners and cabin operators in the Kenting resort area said they have been so busy this summer that they don't have time to read newspapers or talk on cell phones.

The nearby National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium has been receiving more than 7,000 visitors a day since the beginning of summer vacation, a conspicuous contrast to the several hundred recorded in the few months after the Morakot disaster.
In comparison, the number of tourists to Alishan was only 40 percent of its pre- typhoon figure as the main line of its alpine railway has not resumed operation, local travel service providers said.

The number of visitors to spa resorts in mountainous regions in the hardest-hit Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties also remained limited, with Maolin attracting only 6,000 visitors in June, less than 10 percent of the number posted in the same month last year. (Aug. 16, 2010).
China Times:

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will sponsor a food festival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- in the near future in an attempt to shed its reputation for offering bad food at expensive prices.

MOTC Minister Mao Chih-kuo said existing and would-be restaurant and beverage shop operators at the airport will be invited to demonstrate their culinary arts and present gourmet dishes at the festival.

Food sold at the Taoyuan airport has long been criticized as costly yet unpalatable. Mao said his ministry has invited noted local gourmet food providers to open stores at the airport after the airport administration is transformed into a corporation in November.

The soon-to-be-held food festival will be a warm-up event to mark the airport's management reform, Mao said, adding that in the future, the airport will sponsor a food festival quarterly or biannually in an effort to upgrade service quality. (Aug. 16, 2010).
Liberty Times:
The curtain fell on the Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival Sunday after a 44-day run that attracted more than 586,000 visitors.
The Yilan County Government, which organized the event to attract tourists to the county, said it had for the most part attained its goals.

The event was suspended for two years under the previous magistrate. Current Yilan Magistrate Lin Tsung-hsien said he was happy to see the event resume its past glory and vowed to make the festival even more interesting next year. (Aug. 16, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate to visit Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 13:18:15 (By Chen Shao-kuo and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu- hsing said Monday that he is scheduled to visit Singapore Sept. 6-9 to learn from the city state's experience in developing its economy.

Taiwan could develop its tourism industry by building casinos, Yang said, adding that he hopes to learn more about Singapore's development experience so that he can develop Kaohsiung in a similar way.
Yang said he is planning to visit Singapore's harbor area, amusement parks, casinos, financial operations center and media.

Although several mayoral candidates have said they want to follow Singapore's development model, Yang said he does not care who made the proposal first and that he will demonstrate his words through action.
He also said the city state's efficiency is worth learning from and that he plans to send local young people to Singapore to gain experience.

Yang shocked his opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) colleagues earlier this month by announcing his decision to run in the year-end mayoral election for the Kaohsiung special municipality in defiance of his party's choice of candidate.
Yang, who enjoys voter support in his county but who lost to incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu in the DPP primary, said that he hopes to turn Kaohsiung into "a second Singapore."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister plans visit to Indonesia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 14:07:53 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang plans to visit Indonesia at the end of September to survey opportunities for trade and investment in the textile, food and machinery sectors, government sources said Monday.

As Indonesia has built better relations with China, Shih is expected to use the visit to break the ice, hoping to improve bilateral ties with the Southeast Asian country, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs officials.

The officials said Shih is likely to lead a delegation to visit Indonesia on Sept. 29 if the country's economics authorities will treat the Taiwanese delegation on an equal-footing basis and launch a ministerial-level welcome for the Taiwanese delegation.
If Shih is informed that he cannot enjoy equal treatment in Indonesia, the ministry said the Taiwanese delegation will be led by a vice minister of economics affairs.
The ministry plans to organize an investment surveying group for the visit, while four trade promotion groups from Taiwan will join the delegation.

Apart from representatives from the textile, food and machinery sectors, state- owned enterprises such as Taiwan Sugar Corp., oil firm CPC Corp., Taiwan, and Taiwan Power Co. are expected to be represented in the delegation, the officials said, adding that Indonesia has expressed hopes that Taiwan Sugar will invest in the country to expand sugar production and meet demand.
The officials said 18 Taiwanese firms including garment maker TEXMA International Co., Ltd. have signed up for the visit.

Earlier this month, the ministry said it had targeted Indonesia and Vietnam as potential free trade agreement (FTA) partners after Taiwan announced it had agreed with to enter negotiations on a bilateral trade pact with Singapore.

The ministry officials said that after Taiwan and China signed the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in late June, the island is gearing up to boost business ties with Southeast Asian countries to penetrate the huge Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) market.

Taiwan is the 10th largest foreign investor in Indonesia, focusing on textiles, furniture, footwear, mineral resources and metals, while Taiwanese investors have also been engaged in the services and agriculture sectors there.

The officials said the ministry is aimed at helping old economy companies in Taiwan to relocate their investments in Southeast Asia, with Indonesia one of the priority destinations as Taiwanese investors on the mainland face rising labor costs.

The officials said that as new investment regulations have taken effect in Indonesia to attract foreign investors, Taiwanese investors could consider the country a springboard into the Southeast Asian market and even to Middle East and African markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Time for DPP to stop name-calling
DOC.DATELINE: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 08/16/10 14:11:17 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: has long been constrained by its pro-independence and China-hostile ideology and likes to brand those who hold different political views as "traitors of Taiwan."

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing is the latest victim of the DPP's name-calling strategy. DPP hardliners do not hesitate to accuse Yang of selling out Taiwan after he announced his candidacy in the November mayoral election without the party's endorsement, nor have they accepted his decision to conditionally support a newly signed trade pact with China.

In the face of China's rise as a new economic powerhouse, the DPP should think twice before pointing fingers. Under the current Kuomintang modus vivendi approach, relations across the Taiwan Strait are moving toward reconciliation and co-prosperity. Public opinion polls also show solid support for the cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

If the DPP continues its anti-ECFA rhetoric, it may find itself losing the opportunity to stage a comeback. At a time when the DPP is charting a new platform to guide its development over the next decade, it should bravely shed its prejudiced way of thinking and work out new strategies with visionary broadmindedness that will bring new hope to Taiwan. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 16, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Adapting to new global economic model

TEXT.P: A few weeks ago, the global economy seemed to emerge from the shadow of Europe's debt crisis as global stocks rallied and Asian shares surged to record highs. But last week, major stock markets around the world were generally lower due to uncertainty over the global economic outlook.

This indicates that short-term economic fluctuations have become a major part of the new economic model following the 2008-2009 global financial crisis and could cause difficulty for businesses when making decisions concerning investment and operations and for government when formulating policy.
For Taiwan, the new normal economic model is definitely a stiff challenge for its heavily export-reliant economy.
If Taiwan is to adapt and remain firm in the volatile global economic environment, it should adopt the following strategies:

First, adopt open trade policies to inject new momentum into economic growth. The economic cooperation framework cooperation recently signed between Taiwan and China can be seen as a big step forward toward the establishment of a free trade area in the region.
The government should also start negotiations with China on reaching agreements on trade in products, trade in services investment guarantees and the establishment of a dispute resolution mechanism.
It should also quicken its pace of inking trade agreements with Singapore and its other major trade partners.

Second, fully improve efficiency of the supply chain to drive economic growth. To this end, the government should put more efforts into promoting innovation and talent cultivation, and speeding up the adjustment of the country's industrial structure.

Third, strengthen the government's risk-bearing capacity. Under the new economic model, economic uncertainty will increase. Therefore, the government should work to increase its risk-bearing ability and endurance.

Finally, upgrade the government's competitiveness. Singapore's brilliant economic performance lies in its government's resolution and governance. If Taiwan's government wants to catch up with the city-state, it should improve its governance. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 16, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior KMT official, mayoral candidate to visit Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei/San Francisco, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 14:31:06 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General King Pu-tsung is scheduled to visit Singapore in late August to enhance the party' relations with the city state, a KMT official said Monday.

KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin told CNA by telephone that King plans to visit Singapore Aug. 23-25 and that Huang Chao-shun, the KMT's candidate for the Kaohsiung municipality mayoral election in late November, will accompany him.

King, who was scheduled to arrive back in Taiwan Tuesday after a six-day visit to the United States, wants to promote the ruling party's diplomacy with Singapore and help Huang in her election campaign, according to Su, who is accompanying King on his current U.S. visit.
Huang plans to visit Singapore's airport, harbor and petrochemical companies during her visit, the KMT spokesman said.

Meanwhile, one of Huang's election rivals, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, said that same day that he is scheduled to visit Singapore Sept. 6-9 to learn from the city state's experience in developing its economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.62 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 15:52:04 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.62 percent Monday as rotational buying boosted small and medium cap stocks and select financial firms to reverse early losses on Wall Street's weakness at the end of last week, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 49.64 points to 7,941.22 after moving between 7,850.56 and 7,941.22 on turnover of NT$119.43 billion (US$3.74 billion).

The market opened down 0.09 percent and moved to a low in early trade on falling U.S. markets as investors became more cautious about the earnings outlook of the electronics sector for the second half of this year, dealers said.
However, select financial stocks on low valuations attracted bargain hunting and turned stronger in late trade, helping the broader market get out of the earlier slump, they said.
A total of 1,825 stocks closed up and 1,783 down with 307 stocks remaining unchanged.
The textile sector scored the highest gains, up 2.8 percent. Foodstuffs rose 1.0 percent, paper and pulp stocks added 0.6 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks gained 0.5 percent.
The financial and the plastics and chemical sectors closed up 0.4 percent each, while the construction sector closed unchanged and the cement sector fell 0.2 percent.
The local market moved in a narrow range without aggressive buying by foreign institutional investors, TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.

"Many foreign institutional investors took to the sidelines, holding a wait-and- see attitude toward the earnings outlook of local high-tech heavyweights as there have been signs of falling global demand," Shih said.
Shih said that although China's economic fundamentals remain sound -- lending support to the global economy -- Taiwan's high-tech sector still depends on the United States and Europe for consumption.
"Uncertainty over the U.S. and European economies is expected to continue to haunt the local bourse and lower the willingness to chase share prices even if the index stages a rebound," Shih said.
Shih said the local bourse witnessed active rotational buying in non-electronics stocks Monday, while the buying avoided large cap high-tech shares.

"Select financial stocks received a boost by renewed high hopes for increasing cross-strait exchanges, " Shih said."If the financial sector extends gains, the broader market may not suffer heavy losses despite a slower electronics sector."
En Tie Commercial Bank added 4.39 percent to NT$16.65, Chang Hwa Bank gained 3.49 percent to NT$19.30 and Fubon Financial rose 1.33 percent to NT38.00.
Among high-tech heavyweights, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. closed up 0.33 percent at NT$60.30, while United Microelectronics Corp. fell 0.71 percent to NT$14.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence groups stage anti-ECFA protest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 16:10:53 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: About 50 pro-independence groups started a two-day sit-in protest Monday in front of the Legislative Yuan, calling for a referendum on a cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact and a transparent review of the pact at an extraordinary legislative session slated for Aug. 17-30.

The protesters, led by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Taiwan Nation Alliance (TNA) expressed their opposition to the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed by Taiwan and China in late June and demanded an ECFA referendum during the sit-in, held on the same day that an informal legislative meeting was held to decide on the agenda for the extraordinary session.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei, the protest organizer, accused the government of rejecting the Taiwanese people's right to referendum, saying that if it is true that the ECFA will bring across-the-board benefits to Taiwan as touted by the government, the government should keep his hands off and allow the people to determine whether the trade pact should have been signed.
Huang also said that the signing of the ECFA has tied the two economies together and could be seen as a prelude to eventual unification with China.
The government's Referendum Review Committee has twice rejected the TSU's ECFA referendum proposal.
He said the party will not halt its push for an ECFA referendum and that it will initiate a proposal to disband the review committee.

Meanwhile, Lo Rong-kuang, a minister of the Taiwan Presbyterian Church, said that China is a politics-led regime, that all the economic and cultural activities it promotes have political intentions and that its eventual goal is to annex Taiwan.

Despite the situation, the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has chosen to dance to Beijing's tune and is willing to take the political risk of tying Taiwan economically to China, which could make Taiwan locked into China, Lo added.
Yao Chia-wen, the head of the TNA, also said that the groups plan to continue the sit-in until the ECFA review is completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65 years after WWII, Taiwanese veterans hope to be recognized

TEXT.P: Distant memories of the Pacific War and the deaths of fellow child-workers and comrades still bring tears to the eyes of Lee Hsueh-feng and Lin Teh-hwa, two of more than 200,000 Taiwanese directly involved in World War II.

At around the time of the 65th anniversary of Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombings that led to the end of the World War II, there are still no formal ceremonies in Taiwan or memorials erected to commemorate former military men like Lee and Lin.

This is why they appeared at the War Memorial Park located in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, an important military and industrial center during the Japanese colonial era from 1895-1945, and called for the government to pay due respect to Taiwan's World War II veterans.

"Maybe it (the lack of recognition) is because we were seen as Japanese, which we really were at the time, " said 85-year-old Lin, who joined the Japanese Imperial Navy in 1943 at 17 as a volunteer because soldiers' families received special benefits.

Lin, who hails from central Taiwan, said he made the decision because "I had four older brothers. And at 17, I feared nothing, including death." He was fortunate to stay in Taiwan as a naval driver instead of being sent to the South Pacific theater, but said that "serving in the Japanese military was living hell," nonetheless.

Lee, on the other hand, went to Yamato City in Japan's Kanagawa Prefecture that same year, in the first group of Taiwanese child workers, called "shonenko" who answered a call from the Japanese government to build fighter planes. In all, more than 8,000 boys aged 12-14 left their families, homeland and childhood with the promise of an education in Japan. However, the promises and their dreams were never fulfilled.

In December 1944, 25 Taiwanese boys were killed in a United States' air raid on Nagoya. Lee, at 17, was the oldest of the group, and assumed the responsibility of taking care of his "brothers, " who often got homesick and cried at night.
"We had a very hard time (in Japan) but we were a happy group of kids. Losing them (the 25 boys) just broke my heart, " Lee recalled, adding that 300 of them never returned to Taiwan after the war.

Those 25 boys, along with 30,304 Taiwanese soldiers killed in the war, including former Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui's older brother, are still remembered at Tokyo's Yasukuni Shrine and have never officially returned to their homeland either, Lee lamented.

Lee said he often wonders how he was able to tell his grandchildren that "grandpa built fighter planes for the Japanese Imperial Air Force at your age" in a time when most university students in Taiwan have little understanding of Taiwan's history and when some of them even think it was Japan rather than the United States, that bombed Taiwan in war.

Liang Chih-hsiang, 82, was one of the very few who fought as a Japanese soldier in the South Pacific before being recruited and sent to China by the Kuomintang (KMT) government to combat the troops of the Communist Party of China.

Yang Liao Shu-hsia, 83, was a 16-year-old student in the Japanese territory in Shanghai when the war in the Pacific broke out. She volunteered to be trained and serve as a military nurse and was not able to return to Taiwan until 1947.
Stories like these could go on and on. Those who were involved in the war are now in their 80s and, as Lee puts it, will be "naturally fading away" soon.

There should be a memorial in Taiwan like the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall in Washington, which lists the names of those who died and those who remain unaccounted for in the Vietnam War, because the war experience is a collective memory of millions of people, said Jiang Chung-hwa, chairman of the Taiwan Extra-Patriot Veterans Association (TEPVA).

The association is seeking collaboration from dozens of civic organizations, as well as donations from the public, to establish a memorial park where a monument can be erected and ceremonies can be held annually for the families of the World War II Taiwanese soldiers and service members to commemorate their loved ones.

"There has been so little commemoration of the war in Taiwan in which millions of people were directly or indirectly involved. This is a strange society, " said TEPVA Secretary-General Chuang Sheng-huang.

Citing statistics from Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare, Chuang said that around 8,000 Taiwanese soldiers and more than 120,000 other service personnel were involved in the Pacific War, 15,000 of whom are listed as missing in action.

Taiwan's society today is known for its diversification, but the same goes for Taiwanese society in the 1940's, according to Chuang. "Some of the soldiers volunteered, while some were forced to fight for Japan. Some thought of themselves as Taiwanese while others regarded themselves as Japanese," he said.
"There were even some Taiwanese who volunteered to fight for the KMT in the Chinese civil war," he added.

"Irrespective of the political ideology, the war memories and humanity are the same then and now. What we're trying to do is to reveal history and let history speak for itself," he said. By Chris Wang CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Advocates urge harsh punishment for 'liger' breeder
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 16:44:47 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: An animal rights group on Monday called for the immediate seizure of two newborn ligers -- a hybrid of a tiger and lion -- from a private zoo in Tainan County, saying the operator should be severely punished for illegally cross-breeding two different species of protected animals.
Environmental and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) said Huang Kuo-nan, the owner of an educational farm, violated the Wildlife Conservation Law by allowing two types of protected animals to mate.
The group is urging the government to mete out harsh punishment on Huang, known as the "snake king, " to deter others from copying the behavior.
On Sunday, a six year-old tigress gave birth to three ligers but only two survived, according to Huang.
Kuo Yi-pin, the head of the Tainan County Government Agricultural Department, said tigers and lions are protected animals and therefore, it is illegal to artificially cross-breed the two.
The county officials are scheduled to visit the farm and will slap Huang with a NT$50,000 fine and confiscate the cubs if any legal discrepancies are found, he said.

"Cross-breeding two protected species is completely against nature. We are urging the Council of Agriculture (COA) to seize the two cubs immediately and bring Huang to real justice. A fine of NT$50,000 is a mere slap on the wrist, " said Lin Tai-jing, an EAST researcher.
Lin said a light fine of NT$50,000 is "too little to pay to legalize an illegal behavior."
"It is like paying the government for a permit to breed ligers, " she argued.

Huang, however, said he did not artificially breed the animals but admitted he has kept a male lion and a tigress in the same space for the last few years, dubbing the two "childhood lovers" and describing the births of the cubs as an "accident."

Earlier this month, Huang was the target for animal welfare advocates when he was accused of selling live tigers and bears as well as tiger bones and bear paws -- both believed to have medicinal properties.

Huang has cried foul over the accusations, saying he runs a legitimate business. Huang was a member of the COA's wildlife conservation panel from 1995 to 2000 and is currently under investigation for the illegal trade of endangered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 16:46:34 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.05 to close at the day's high of NT$32.010.
Turnover totaled US$530 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.960 and moved to a low of NT$31.917 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. senator visits Legislative Yuan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 17:09:36 (By Chou Yung-che and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Arlen Specter, a democrat from Pennsylvania, paid a courtesy call on the Legislative Yuan Monday to learn about the impact Taiwan's trade pact with China will have on its ties with Beijing.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng talked with Specter for an hour on the sideline of an informal gathering of lawmakers of various parties to discuss the agenda of a special legislative session scheduled to open the following day.
Wang told journalists after the meeting that Specter is the first U.S. senator to have visited the Legislative Yuan for the last two or three years.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who accompanied Wang during the meeting, said Specter was interested in the ramifications that Taiwan's economic cooperation framework agreement with China will have on ties across the Taiwan Strait.
Specter, whose home state of Pennsylvania has imposed anti-dumping duties on tires imported from China, was reported to want to know how Taiwan's trade with China is proceeding.

Lin quoted Wang as briefing Specter on the historical background of the political disputes between Taiwan and China, the long way the two sides have come in their ties, and the long way the two sides are expected to go before they can come to terms with each other politically.
The speaker was reported as telling Specter that Taiwanese products face intense competition from similar products from China, especially towels.

The reason is more the cheap labor costs in China than Chinese dumping, and the Taiwanese authorities have had to resort to heavier tariffs to protect local towel producers, Wang was quoted as saying.
Specter, who had just concluded a visit to Vietnam, complained about what he called China's assertiveness over disputed islands in the South China Sea.

But he was supportive when he learned from Wang that Taiwan has staked out territorial claims to these islands too and has deployed armed forces on several of the disputed territories, according to Lin.
Lin said Specter also compared notes with Wang on Taiwan's requests to buy arms from the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pegatron still probing Apple kickback accusations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 17:27:27 (by Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Pegatron Corp., a manufacturing arm of personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc., said Monday it was still investigating accusations that an Apple manager coached its unit in China on how to bid for contracts.
A U.S. federal grand jury indicted Paul Devine, an Apple global supply manager, for allegedly taking at least US$1 million in kickbacks from six Apple suppliers in Asia.

According to the indictment document released last week, China-based Kaedar Electronics Co., which is wholly owned by Pegatron, was among six Asian firms that received confidential information from Devine to help it negotiate favorable terms in supply contracts with Apple between 2005 and 2008.
The others accused include Cresyn Co. Ltd. in South Korea and Jin Li Mould Manufacturing Pte. Ltd in Singapore.
Pegatron spokesman Lin Chiu-tan said his company was still checking on the accusations and pointed out that Pegatron did not own Kaedar until 2008.
He said Pegatron needed time to better understand the allegations.
Kaedar is a computer component manufacturer and also makes casings for iPods.
The Wall Street Journal had previously reported Pegatron was working on iPhones based on the code division multiple access (CDMA) mobile standard for Apple.
When asked whether Pegatron's business ties with Apple could be affected by the kickback scandal, Lin said he did not think so.
Pegatron shares fell when the stock market opened after the scandal surfaced, with institutional investors dumping the stock on fears that orders from Apple would be cut, analysts said.
Pegatron closed down 4.26 percent at NT$38.20 on the main board Monday.

Pegatron was spun off by AsusTek in the first half of this year as AsusTek planned to focus on building up its own brand as a computer vendor and outsource production work to Pegatron and other OEM suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first WTO representative publishes new book
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 17:30:10 (By Alex Chiang)

TEXT.P: Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's first representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) , unveiled his new book on tax regulations Monday, saying that he did not expect his daughter, who co-authored the book, to enter his field of expertise.
"I did not try to influence her, and I didn't expect that she would specialize in the same field, " Yen, a former finance minister, said at a luncheon.

Yen said that his daughter, Yen Huai-shing, wrote dissertations on WTO issues and international tax for her master's and doctoral degrees, and has now become an important member of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) 's Taiwan WTO center.

"When I asked her to help me with my book, she initially didn't want to agree. But she later felt sort of a sense of responsibility (as a scholar) and finally agreed to accept my request, " Yen said to laughter from the audience.
His daughter did not attend the luncheon because of a research engagement, he said.

Yen Ching-chang said that the Chinese-language book is aimed at updating a previous edition that did not include tariffs as Taiwan was not a member of the world trade body when it was published in 1998.

Yen, who served as Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO from 2002 to 2005, also expressed his appreciation to another co-author, Albert Hsueh, who is the Taiwan chairman of accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister backs review of insurance reform bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 17:56:15 (By Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Amid protests against an attempt to have a national health insurance reform bill reviewed at a special legislative session next week, the health minister said Monday that if civic groups had their way, "30 years wouldn't be enough" to complete the reform.
The second-generation health insurance program is on the right course, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said, "and what's right should be done."

Yaung made the remarks while answering reporters on a request by civic organizations, including the Consumers' Foundation and the National Health Insurance Surveillance Alliance, to hold more public hearings on controversial proposals to the reform plan before it is sent to the legislature for ratification.
Representatives of the civic groups rallied in front of the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day, urging lawmakers not to hastily review draft revisions to the National Health Insurance (NHI) program.
They said 26 of the planned articles to govern the second-generation health insurance system were controversial.
Pushing through the reform without resolving the controversial aspects first would only make matters worse, they said.
Part of the controversy focuses on a proposal to calculate premiums on the basis of total household income rather than on the salaries of individuals.
Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Huang Yu-sheng has said that in most cases, authorities will have no way to accurately determine the total income of households.
The campaigners also urged the government to first handle problems that have been eroding the current system, such as doctors who prescribe useless medications to bring money to the hospital.

In response, Tai Kuei-ying, director-general of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, said the Legislative Yuan's committee of health affairs has saved all the controversial proposals for debates between ruling and opposition lawmakers.
The bureau will respect the outcome of the talks, she said.
At present, "the most important thing is for the second-generation health insurance program to be placed on the agenda for the legislature," Tai said.
Only with debate can a "reasonable direction" for the reform be found, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature to start two-week extra session
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 17:57:03 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan decided at an informal session Monday to start a two-week extraordinary session the following day to screen a number of critical bills, as well as a recently signed landmark trade pact with China.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled legislature also held a vote to decide that the agenda for the Aug. 17-30 extra session will include the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and five related bills.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -proposed bills, including an ECFA referendum initiative and a bill on amending the Act Governing Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures, were blocked from the extra session agenda.
The session will be the second of its kind since the ruling party-controlled legislature went into summer recess.

During the first extra session held in July, the KMT steamrolled a motion to put the ECFA directly to a second reading despite strong opposition from the DPP, which called for a line-item review of the accord at the first reading.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said before the opening of Monday's session that the ECFA will be screened article by article and will then be put to a vote as a single package in the second reading.

In addition to the ECFA, the five ECFA-related bills -- a cross-strait intellectual property rights protection agreement, as well as amendments to the current trademark law, patent law, and regulations on customs duties and plant registration -- will also be screened during the second extra session.
The agenda further includes three Ministry of Education-initiated packages of legal amendments to pave the way for the admission of Chinese students to local tertiary education institutions.

Also to be addressed are draft revisions to the National Health Insurance program to smooth the way for the introduction of a second-generation health insurance system, as well as amendments to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law to prevent any rezoning of legislative constituencies for the next 10 years.
The session will also deal with draft amendments to regulations governing retirement benefits for former presidents and vice presidents, as well as the tobacco and alcohol taxation act.

DOC.HEADLINE: OTC companies to brief institutional investors in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 18:04:43 (By Han Ting-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Seven electronics companies listed on Taiwan's over-the-counter (OTC) market will attend a briefing for institutional investors in Tokyo on Aug. 23, the first such briefing in Japan in four years, GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) said Monday.

According to GTSM, which operates Taiwan's OTC and emerging markets, Japanese institutional investors are generally unfamiliar with companies traded on Taiwan's OTC market because they view the market and its listed companies as too small to be considered as investment targets.
"We hope this ice-breaking trip to Japan will help change Japanese institutions' impression and improve their understanding of Taiwan's OTC-listed companies," GTSM Chairman Gordon Chen said.
The seven companies attending the briefing, organized jointly by GTSM and Japan's Nomura Securities, are among the 50 most capitalized enterprises on the OTC market.

They are: solar cell manufacturer Motech Industries Inc., image sensor provider PixArt Technologies Inc., nand flash manufacturer Phison Electronics Corp, IC testing provider Chipbond Technology Corp, battery pack supplier Simplo Technology Co., e-paper provider E Ink Holdings Inc., and wireless communication device supplier Advanced Ceramic X Corp..
A similar briefing will also take place in Hong Kong on Aug. 24.

This will be the fourth consecutive year GTSM invites OTC blue chips to participate in overseas investor briefings, with previous events held in London, New York, Hong Kong and Singapore all receiving positive responses, Chen said.

The GTSM chairman said that in MSCI's changes to its equity indices in May, 17 Taiwanese companies listed on the OTC or the emerging stock market were among the 36 stocks from Taiwan added to the MSCI Global Small Cap indices.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese tourists coming to southern Taiwan: Chinese official
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 18:21:31 (By Chang Che Fon and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor has great potential for attracting tourists from China, the president of the China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association (CSTEA) said in a meeting with representatives of the tourism industry in southen Taiwan Monday.

Vacationing is now gaining popularity in China. With Hong Kong portrayed as a shopping heaven for tourists from China, Kaohsiung has great potential for developing into a cruise vacation center, said Shao Qiwei, who also serves as director of China's National Tourism Administration.

Lin Fu-nan, president of the Kao-Kao-Ping Tourism Alliance, a union of tourism- related industries in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas, presented southern Taiwan as an ideal destination for independent Chinese travelers, and promoted more direct cross-strait transport and exchanges of tourism personnel in the southern Taiwan area.
Shao gave his assurance that the alliance's voice will be heard by the authorities in Beijing.
Unlike the existing country-wide group tours, future independent travelers from China will be more likely to tour individual cities of their choice, according to Shao.
Details and regulations regarding the new travel options will be concluded in future cross-strait negotiations, he added.

With the number of Chinese visitors expected to hit 3 million this year, cross- strait charter flights alone are not enough to meet demand, Shao said, adding that an increase in sea transport is required.
Responding to Shao's promise to introduce more Chinese travelers to Taiwan and to Kaohsiung in particular, Lin said that southern Taiwan is fully prepared to receive the increased number of tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP braces for upcoming extraordinary legislative session
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 18:27:05 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Monday that the party is consistent in its stance that a recently signed cross- Taiwan Strait trade pact should be reviewed article-by-article and that it will submit a new draft of a government revenue allocation law during an extraordinary legislative session slated to start the following day.
Tsai made the comments at a DPP legislative caucus meeting before the Legislative Yuan held an informal meeting to decide on the agenda for the extraordinary session scheduled for Aug. 17-30.

The DPP had originally planned to only raise a referendum proposal on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed by Taiwan and China in late June, but Tsai announced at the DPP meeting that the party will also present a new draft of the Act Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures at the extraordinary session.

Tsai said that an additional NT$98 billion (US$3.07 billion) in subsidies was originally planned for local governments, but an Executive Yuan version of the act has sharply slashed the amount of subsidies to be available.

For example, the extra annual budget for the soon-to-be-established municipality of Xinbei City has been cut by NT$18.9 billion, while that for the upgraded Kaohsiung municipality has been slashed by NT$4 billion-NT$5 billion, according to Tsai.

She added that the DPP hopes its version will help inject the necessary funds to the new special municipalities to be formed at the end of this year and bridge the financial gap between Taipei City and the other local governments.
Tsai said the DPP hopes the Legislative Yuan will soon complete a substantive review of the act and urged the ruling Kuomintang to put it on the agenda for the upcoming extraordinary session.

Asked whether the KMT legislative caucus' insistence that the Legislative Yuan should vote on the ECFA as a single package will cause clashes between the ruling and opposition parties, Tsai said she will let the DPP caucus decide the party's strategy for dealing with the ECFA topic during the session.

As for whether the ECFA issue will have an impact on the year-end five special municipality elections, Tsai said that if the KMT insists on rushing the bill through, it could hurt its chances on election day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County confiscates newborn ligers (update 1)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/16/10 18:36:05 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Tainan County government on Monday afternoon confiscated newborn ligers -- hybrids of a tiger and a lion -- from a private zoo to be sheltered at a research institute in Pingtung and said the zoo operator will be fined.

Wu Hsing-hao, the chief of the Forest and Natural Conservation Section of the Department of Agricultural, said the three one-day old cubs -- two alive and one that died at birth -- will be kept at the National Pingtung University's Institute of Wildlife Conservation.
In accordance with the Wildlife Conservation Law, zoo operator Huang Kuo-nan, known as "the snake king, " will face a fine of between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000 for breeding protected animals, Wu added.
Earlier in the day, an animal rights group called for the immediate seizure of the ligers, saying Huang should be severely punished for illegally cross- breeding two species of protected animals.
The Environmental and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) said Huang, who possesses an array of wildlife, should be dealt with harshly to deter others from copying the behavior.

"Cross-breeding two protected species is completely against nature. We are urging the Council of Agriculture (COA) to seize the two cubs immediately and bring Huang to real justice. A fine of NT$50,000 is a mere slap on the wrist, " said Lin Tai-jing, an EAST researcher.
Lin said NT$50,000 is "too low a price to legalize an illegal act."
"It's like paying the government for a permit to breed ligers," she said.

Huang, however, said he did not force the two animals to breed, but admitted he kept a male lion and a tigress together in the same space over the last few years, dubbing the two as "childhood sweethearts" and describing the births as "an accident."
Earlier this month, Huang was accused by animal welfare advocates of selling live tigers and bears as well as tiger bones and bear paws -- considered by some to have medicinal properties.

Huang cried foul over the accusations, saying he runs a legitimate business. Huang was a member of the COA wildlife conservation panel from 1995 to 2000 and is currently under investigation for the alleged trade of endangered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC unit's net income jumps in Q2
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 18:47:57 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Contract chip maker Vanguard International Semiconductor Corp., a subsidiary of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , said Monday its second quarter net income was up 157 percent from a quarter earlier because of strong global demand.
Vanguard posted NT$567 million (US$17.75 million), or NT$0.34 per share, in net profit, on sales of NT$4.23 billion, the company said in an investor conference.
In the April to June period, shipments of wafers rose 16 percent from the previous quarter, and the company's average selling price gained 2 percent to boost total sales by 18 percent.

Vanguard's second quarter gross margin rose six percentage points from a quarter earlier to 22 percent. Large-sized logic ICs accounted for 42 percent of sales, while small-sized logic ICs made up 23 percent, the company said.

Vanguard President Fang Leuh said the company has decided to increase 2010 capital expenditure to NT$3.6 billion from the previously planned NT$1.6 billion to expand production capacity. Just over 30 percent of the NT$3.6 billion was spent in the first half of the year.
Fang said Vanguard will expand the monthly capacity of its second 8-inch wafer plant to 116,000 units in the fourth quarter from 113,000 units in the third quarter.
Currently, the company runs two 8-inch wafer plants.
Vanguard's capacity utilization was 83 percent in the first half of the year, but Fang expected that to reach nearly 100 percent in the third quarter, with shipments set to rise 7-9 percent.
Also in the third quarter, Vanguard's gross margin is expected to rise to 24-26 percent because of a slightly higher average selling price, Fang said.
TSMC currently holds a 37.44 percent stake in Vanguard.

DOC.HEADLINE: English version of trade pact with China to be posted online
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 19:27:03 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs decided Monday to make a virtue of necessity by granting a request by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to make public the English version of Taiwan's economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

An anonymous economic official said the Ministry of Economic Affairs must translate the pact into English to inform the World Trade Organization (WTO) of its agreement with China as is required by the WTO of its members.
The ministry made the decision on the eve of a legislative special session called to ratify the pact inked by Taiwan and China June 29.

The English translation will be done by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which will have thorough discussions with related ministries about the meaning of the pact, and will notify China of its final English version to ensure that there are no differences between each other's English versions presented to the WTO, the official said.
Only after the English version has been confirmed by the Chinese authorities will it be posted on the ministry's website.

However, the official said the English version is only for the purpose of informing the WTO and that any differences between it and the Chinse version will be resolved according to the Chinese version.

The DPP lawmakers, who oppose the pact on the grounds that Taiwan's closer economic ties with China will undermine its political independence, had demanded that the Executive Yuan present an English translation of the pact that can be debated in the legislature.
According to the DPP, the Chinese version of the pact "might have hidden snags" that could be exposed only in the English version to be given to the WTO.

As the ruling Kuomintang, which controls two-thirds of the legislative seats, is determined to bulldoze the pact through the legislature in a special session set to begin the following day, a free-for-all, which is typical method of filibustering used in the legislature, is anticipated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins first match in Junior League Baseball World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 19:32:17 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan defeated Guatemala 7-2 on the first day of the 2010 Junior League Baseball World Series tournament that opened Sunday in Taylor, Michigan, according to sources with the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA).

Taiwan was to encounter Ukraine the following day, the CTBA said, noting that Ukraine is an unknown quantity for Taiwan's young players, who have rarely met the nation in international baseball games.
The Junior League Baseball World Series sees the participation of 10 teams of 13- and 14-year-olds divided into two pools -- the United States and the international pool.

The U.S. pool groups the five best teams from the western, southeast, central, southwest and eastern regions of that country. Taiwan is in the international pool, which also groups Ukraine, Mexico, Guatemala and Canada.
The top two teams from each pool will go through to the semi-finals slated for Aug. 20, with the final set to be played the day after.
Taiwan won an Asia-Pacific tournament last month to earn its ticket to the world series.
The country won the championship in 1992 and again in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taroko Express hires new group of female conductors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 19:37:40 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) has hired four young women as conductors on the Taroko Express as part of its ongoing effort to upgrade service quality, a train administrator said Monday.

"The four have just completed a training program, " said the TRA official. "Their recruitment underscores our efforts to accelerate the introduction of new blood to our staff and upgrade service quality."

The new recruits will be led by Hsiao Tsai-ting, the first woman ever hired as a conductor on the Taroko Express in March 2009. She was assigned to a permanent office job in January 2010 but will occasionally get back on the train to help the young women learn their job.
"Hsiao will lead the new female conductors in working 15 runs between Taipei and Hualien, " the official said.

Among the four new female conductors, who average less than 30 years of age, Hsu Jui-ting is a third-generation employee of the company. Her grandfather once worked for the TRA and her father is still an employee of the railway administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan weightlifter wins silver at Youth Olympics
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 20:01:27 (By Tang Pei-chun and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese weightlifter Kuo Hsing-chun won a silver medal at the Youth Olympics Games here Monday, the first medal of the competition for the country.
Kuo, who was competing in the women's 53 kg division, won the second place with a snatch of 77 kg and a clean and jerk of 97 kg, giving a total of 174 kg.
Kuo heaved a sigh of relief when she was cleared for the 53 kg division because h r weight dipped to 52.9 kg only that morning and there had been concerns she would be too heavy for the category.

Bulgarian lifter Kostova Boyanka won gold with a snatch of 85 kg and a clean and jerk of 107 kg for a total of 192 kg, while Safitri Dewi of Indonesia took bronze with a snatch of 71 kg and a clean and jerk of 100 kg for a total of 171 kg.

Tai Hsia-ling, the minister in charge of Taiwan's Sports Affairs Council, attended the event and afterward presented Kuo with a congratulatory message on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou, as well as a cash prize.

The games, which are the first Olympics designed for athletes between the ages of 14 and 18, opened in Singapore Saturday. Some 3,200 athletes from around the world are competing in 26 sports over 12 days.
Taiwan is fielding a 40-member delegation to the games under the name of Chinese Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Gourmet review' to be held in effort to improve airport food
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 20:42:53 (By Bien Chin-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport authorities will organize a food review as part of efforts to improve its unenviable image as a place for "awful and expensive food, " the airport's office director announced Monday.

Beginning in October, a public review of the food on offer at the airport will be held on a regular basis to encourage caterers at the airport's two terminals to present more appealing food, said Wei Sheng-chih.
Complaints among passengers using the country's main gateway are all too common, with the food uniformly criticized as being of dreadful quality, overpriced and with little choice.
Responding to the criticisms, Wei said the airport has made some improvements, including introducing popular restaurants to cater to passengers using the airport.

He said it will further invite passengers, food critics and travel tour organizers to review the food at the airport to prompt the caterers to offer more local gourmet foods and make dining at the terminals more attractive.
His office will also take measures to encourage the businesses there to drop their prices to more reasonable levels and to provide consumers with a wider variety of dining options, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pitcher Kuo takes lead in best setup man poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 20:56:25 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese baseball pitcher Kuo Hong-Chih has taken a solid lead in an online poll on Major League Baseball's website asking fans to name this year's best setup man.
As of 8 p.m. Monday Taiwan time, the Los Angeles Dodgers' Kuo had garnered 34 percent of the votes, the most among the six choices given.
He was followed by Arthur Rhodes of the Cincinnati Reds, who had 20 percent, with Daniel Bard of the Boston Red Sox ranking third with 15 percent.
Scott Downs of the Toronto Blue Jays, Luke Gregerson of the San Diego Padres and Matt Thornton of the Chicago White Sox received 10 percent, 9 percent, and 9 percent, respectively.

Kuo's lead in the poll is not surprising because his numbers have been outstanding all year. The 29-year-old left-handed reliever has a 3-1 record with four saves, 17 holds and an ERA of 0.88 in 39 appearances.
Even more indicative of how well he's pitched, Kuo's WHIP -- walks plus hits surrendered per inning -- is only 0.80, with 1.00 considered excellent.
He has been so effective that Dodgers' manager Joe Torre recently installed him as a closer in place of Jonathan Braxton, who has struggled recently.
In his first outing since the switch, Kuo shut down the Atlanta Braves in the ninth inning of a 2-1 victory to pick up the save.
Kuo was voted by the fans on Major League Baseball's website at the 2008 Setup Man of the Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Guangdong governor visits Taiwan seeking cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 21:20:58 (by Bien Chin Feng, Chung-sen Lin and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of 1,000 people headed by Guangdong Governor Huang Huahua arrived in Taiwan Monday for "Taiwan-Guangdong Week, " a week-long tour focusing on enhancing cooperation in many fields.
The delegation is also expected to procure US$5.2 billion in goods while in Taiwan.

"Taiwan-Guangdong Week, " described by organizers as a "journey of cooperation and nostalgia, " hopes to underline the importance of cross-strait strategic economic, agricultural, and tourism cooperation.
Huang said he received a warm welcome from Taiwan's people on his first trip here in "Beautiful Formosa, " and he hoped for frequent communications between Taiwan and Guangdong in the future.

Upon the arrival of the delegation, Falun Gong practitioners filed a complaint against Huang with the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office for the "crime of genocide" and allegedly violating "civil rights, " and they asked prosecutors to arrest him before his departure.

Huang established a Falun Gong persecution organization and attempted to persecute and torture Falun Gong practitioners in rehabilitation centers while serving as the Guangzhou City secretary of Communist Party of China, said Chu Wan-chi, the lawyer representing the Falun Gong group.
Chang Ching-hsi, the director of the Taiwanese Falun Dafa Association and professor of economics at National Taiwan University, said that Huang has destroyed many families in Guangdong.
Chang said that Falun Gong adherents in Taiwan will continue to file complaints against Chinese government officials entering Taiwan with records of human rights violations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Adimmune Corp. to set up databank for locally produced flu vaccine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 21:23:16 (By Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer said Monday it is conducting clinical trials to establish a databank on the efficacy and safety of locally produced seasonal influenza vaccine.
"Clinical trials will involve about 350 people in various age brackets to assess the effectiveness and side effects of our influenza vaccine," said Adimmune Corp. spokeswoman Shen Ya-hui.

Taiwan usually imports its flu vaccine from abroad, but few foreign vaccine manufacturers have ever conducted clinical tests on Taiwanese people to evaluate their responses to the products, Shen said.
As a result, she said, there is no data or information about the extent of the protection the imported flu vaccines can provide to Taiwanese people.

Taking influenza A(H1N1) as an example, she went on, foreign studies have shown that older people might be as much as 30 percent immune because of the higher chance that they were infected with a less virulent form of the virus in the past.
However, Shen said, Adimmune-conducted clinical studies have shown that Taiwanese people are only 3 percent immune to H1N1 infection.

The company's new vaccine, Shen continued, will be able to provide protection to local people against the virulent and sometimes fatal H1N1 form of the virus, because it contains one of the virus strains that was prevalent in Taiwan last year.

According to Shen, Adimmune is conducting the clinical trials among both adults and children, with tests on 120 adults in two age brackets -- those aged 18-60 and those older than 60 -- getting under way Aug. 9.

The pediatric clinical trials, which will be conducted among children in three age brackets -- those aged between 6 months and 3 years; those aged between 3 and 9; and those aged between 9 and 18 -- are scheduled to start later this month.
Moreover, Shen said, the company will also conduct trials on those aged between 6 months and 1 year in order to establish an extensive databank on vaccine efficacy and safety.

As the publicly financed influenza immunization program will be launched in mid- October, Shen continued, Adimmune will complete a mid-term report on the results of the clinical trials before the program's launch.
Afterward, the company will continue to monitor the sustainability of its vaccine's effectiveness and to track any possible side effects.
"We will come up with final reports in February, June and August next year, " she said, adding that the company hopes its clinical research will help enhance local people's confidence in its product.
The Department of Health has already ordered a total of 3 million doses of influenza vaccine from three companies -- Sanofi-Aventis, Novartis and Adimmune -- for the free immunization program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- China UnionPay, Taiwan banks' new opportunity
DOC.DATELINE: 08/16/10 21:28:28 (The Taiwan Banker, August 2010)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Eighteen Taiwanese banks gained a new source of income on June 30 when Chinese visitors were given permission to withdraw cash from the banks' ATMs in Taiwan using their China UnionPay cards.

Because Chinese nationals visiting Taiwan can only bring 20,000 Chinese yuan (US$2,953.60) into the country, permitting use of the cards is expected to provide a windfall for local banks, which will collect a fee for every card transaction.
UnionPay cards are commonplace today, with 1.8 billion cards issued worldwide, of which 1.7 billion are bank cards and the remainder branded credit cards.
Considering that more than 1 million Chinese nationals are expected to visit Taiwan this year, banks could generate considerable fees from liberalized use of the card.

Taiwan began accepting UnionPay cards as a payment method in August 2009, launching a fierce competition among banks to become the "acquiring bank" for local merchants because of the attractive fees the cards represent.
Payments made with UnionPay cards in Taiwan totaled NT$5.5 billion (US$171.88 million) from August last year to June this year, officials said at the June 30 launch ceremony.
China UnionPay gets 1.2 percent of each transaction and the "acquiring bank" -- the bank that processes the credit card payment for the merchant -- gets a fee of about 2 percent of the transaction.

The four major acquiring financial institutions in Taiwan at present are the National Credit Card Center, American Express, Chinatrust Commercial Bank and Taiwan Cooperative Bank, with market shares of 25.8 percent, 24.7 percent, 22 percent and 5.27 percent respectively.

Perhaps even more lucrative will be ATM fees. Local banks will charge UnionPay cardholders US$1 per withdrawal, of which NT$10 will be given to the Financial Information Service Company (FISC) , responsible for settling interbank payments with China UnionPay, and NT$1.5 to the Bankers Association of the Republic of China.
The remainder, about NT$21, will go to the bank, so if China's 1 million visitors make an average of two ATM cash withdrawals per person per trip, local banks will make NT$42 million in fees.

Among the 18 banks, which have 16,000 ATMs or 64 percent of the total found in Taiwan, Taishin Bank and Chinatrust are expected to profit most from the fee windfall as they have more ATMs than their rivals. Five more banks are expected to join the system at a future date.

Another major opportunity for Taiwanese banks in the future will be fee income on credit card payments and cash withdrawals in China. ATMs in China currently do not accept Taiwanese bank cards unless the cards are co-branded with an international organization, such as Visa or MasterCard.

While the FISC is pushing to have all Taiwanese bank cards accepted in China, Taiwanese banks are also looking to issue UnionPay cards for use in China once the government lifts restrictions on the business.

The advantage of the UnionPay cards would be that they save cardholders currency exchange costs, as it would convert yuan into Taiwan dollars directly without first converting it into U.S. dollars, as is the case with Visa and MasterCard at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA aims to make e-commerce trillion-dollar business in six years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 21:56:01 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday that it will invest NT$450 million (US$14.06 million) in e-commerce over the next six years in a bid to develop it into a NT$1 trillion business within that time period.

The MOEA noted that e-commerce bucked the trend by growing when the world was in sharp decline during the economic crisis that began in 2008, which is why the MOEA proposed an action plan on Mandarin Chinese e-commerce development with the aim of making Taiwan the operations center of the world's Chinese e-commerce.
Under the draft proposal, the government will invest the money between now and 2015.

The MOEA has estimated that the revenues of e-commerce in 2010 will be NT$452 billion, and that although there are currently no e-commerce businesses in Taiwan with revenues of over NT$10 billion per year, the first such business could be revealed next year, with a further seven companies with annual revenues of NT$10 billion by 2015.

Yeh Yun-lung, director-general of the MOEA's Commerce Department, said that if Taiwan can succeed in branching out its e-commerce business, especially in the vast China market, then its growth will be stunning.
"If we can take the China market, then we feel that it will become a trillion dollar business in five or six years," he added.

Yeh noted that the ministry's action plan will include the marketing of special Taiwanese products and cyber services to the Chinese market, as well as the promotion of cross-agency coordination to solve any problems of Taiwanese e-commerce in the Mandarin market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu's ranking climbs to new career best
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 22:02:05 (By Oscar Wu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun moved up four notches to 40th in the latest Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) rankings released Monday, the highest ranking of his career.

Lu picked up 115 points for winning two qualifying matches and reaching the third round of the main draw at the Rogers Cup in Toronto last week, but it was not enough for him to move inside the top 40.
He has been ranked in the top 50 since reaching the quarterfinals of Wimbledon in early July.
The 27-year-old hopes to push even higher this week, but he will face his toughest draw of the summer, going up against Australian Lleyton Hewitt of Australia in the opening round.
Hewitt may be vulnerable, however. He has only played two hardcourt matches this summer and was forced to retire in the second set of a match in Washington, D.C. in early August with a calf injury.
If Lu were to defeat the Australian, he would then play world No. 5 Robin Soderling of Sweden.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China travel fair misses visitor number target
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 22:41:28 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A travel fair in Taipei that hosted a record number of participating Chinese travel agents failed at its close Monday to reach the organizers' goal for the total number of visitors over its four-day run.
A total of 118,003 people visited the Taipei Cross-Strait Travel Fair, a number that fell short of the organizers' original target of 150,000 visitors.

This year also marks the first time Chinese exhibitors will not attend the Taipei International Travel Fair slated to take place Nov. 5-8 this year, after taking part in the fair organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) and the Beijing-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association.
TVA spokeswoman Chen Ying-ting blamed the upcoming start of the new school semester for the poorer- than-expected turnout.
"As the summer vacation is coming to an end, not many families have further travel plans," she told CNA in a telephone interview.
"Some parents might also be looking to save money to pay for tuition as the schools open next month," Chen added.
"So although many big discounts were offered at the fair, many people were still not attracted," she said.
The organizers of the show said that in an effort to boost visitor numbers in future, they are considering moving the fair to June next year.

A record of nearly 1,200 representatives from 190 tourism associations or travel agencies throughout China took part in the fair, the organizers added, saying that a total of 871 booths were manned, including 516 by Taiwanese exhibitors.
Chen lauded the Chinese exhibitors for adopting different promotion tactics this year.
"This year, their booths were better designed. They also put on folk songs, dances and martial arts performances," she noted.

Despite their tactics, however, the Chinese exhibitors apparently failed to compete with their Taiwanese counterparts in attracting visitors to their booths, as the majority of visitors lined up for discounted dining coupons offered by some of the Taiwanese exhibitors, mainly local major hotels.

Another favorite among the visitors was the Taiwan agricultural pavilion, consisting of 250 booths offering tea, dried fruit, nut cookies, grilled sausages, dried squid and other well-known local delicacies.

Asked whether the Chinese exhibitors were dissatisfied with the turnouts at their booths, Chen said they actually had better turnouts than they had enjoyed for the past four years, but she did not provide specific figures.
"This year, they also learned from their Taiwanese counterparts how best to cater to local visitors, and will probably follow suit next year," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$1.45 billion budgeted to upgrade police equipment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:02:45 (by Chiachen Hsieh and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved on Monday a three-year NT$1.45 billion (US$45.3 million) budget to fund a program that will upgrade the equipment used by the police force and strengthen officers' skills.

The budget will fund the "Police Development Program, " which involves enhancing the emergency command system, developing better bomb-defusing and forensic skills, purchasing police vehicles, and strengthening high-tech crime investigation capabilities.

Expanding databases, updating maps, augmenting the digital recording system for reported crimes, and developing a system to help hearing and speech impaired people report crimes are all part of the emergency command system plan, said Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

On buying new vehicles, the National Police Agency said 45 percent of police force vehicles are being used beyond their expiration date and 57 percent of patrol cars have traveled more than 500,000 kilometers.
Jiang said 359 old police cars and 571 motorcycles will be eliminated, and 397 new cars and 147 motorcycles will be purchased.
The focus on developing forensic skills will be on improving forensic technology and increasing laboratory efficiency.
Jiang noted that there is no shortage of weapons for police on duty, but he hopes to purchase more guns for shooting ranges next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's public-sector wages to stay steady next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:23:19 (By Lee Ming-chung, Justin Su, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government will not raise the pay of military personnel, government employees and teachers in public schools in 2011, the Central Personnel Administration announced Monday.
The issue could be reconsidered in the future, however, if the economy continues to improve and the government's financial woes ease, the administration said.

National Civil Servant Association Chairman Chen Chuan-ching said his group "understood" that the decision was made because of major concerns over the country's financial difficulties, which became worse due to the global financial crisis in late 2008.

According to the administration, public-sector wages have not been adjusted since 2005, when salaries were raised by 3 percent. Civil servants, military personnel and teachers also received a 3 percent raise in 2001.
Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang of the ruling Kuomintang said the lack of pay hikes could hurt the the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou's plan to build a clean and efficient government in Taiwan.
He contended that Taiwan has fallen behind Hong Kong in fighting corruption because civil servants there are paid more than their peers in Taiwan.
From the viewpoint of many people in the country, however, the wages of local public servants are not low, especially when considering the benefits they enjoy, Hsieh said.
If public servants were given a wage hike now when most people working in the private sector are paid less and have less security, Kuo said there would likely be protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG reaches agreement with Yunlin County over fire compensation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:51:06 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) reached an agreement with the Yunlin County government Monday on compensation over a string of recent mishaps at its petrochemical complex in the county's Mailiao Township.
The FPG agreed to pay up to NT$500 million (US$15.63 million) in compensation for the agricultural and fishery losses caused by the two fires last month.
The agreement was reached after FPG Vice Chairwoman Susan Wang met with Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen.
The county government made several requests during the meeting, including asking the Formosa Plastics Group to pay for a health risk assessment and epidemiology investigation in the area.

On setting up a NT$10 billion agricultural and fishery stability fund, Formosa Plastics agreed to set aside NT$3 billion over four years, with the county government hoping to solicit assistance from the central government for the remaining amount.
The FPG also agreed to subsidize a forestation project of up to 2,600 hectares to help cut carbon emissions.
The Yunlin County government asked the company to stop production once it has operated for 20 years and rehabilitate the seashore areas where the petrochemical complex is located.
"Formosa Plastics says it respected the request, but refused to comment on it," according to Vice Yunlin County chief Lin Yuan-chuan.
The FPG turned to talk with the county govenment after its negotiations with township residents over compensation broke down earlier in the day.

The residents vowed to block all three major roads leading to the complex Tuesday, forcing Formosa Plastics to ask police to help deal with the situation and alert employees to head to work earlier than normal.
Mailiao Township Council head Hsu Liu-pin said town residents have put up with the complex for more than 10 years since it first began operating in 1998.
"The residents want justice now," Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$1.45 billion budgeted to upgrade police equipment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:02:45 (by Chiachen Hsieh and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved on Monday a three-year NT$1.45 billion (US$45.3 million) budget to fund a program that will upgrade the equipment used by the police force and strengthen officers' skills.
