The budget will fund the "Police Development Program, " which involves enhancing the emergency command system, developing better bomb-defusing and forensic skills, purchasing police vehicles, and strengthening high-tech crime investigation capabilities.

Expanding databases, updating maps, augmenting the digital recording system for reported crimes, and developing a system to help hearing and speech impaired people report crimes are all part of the emergency command system plan, said Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

On buying new vehicles, the National Police Agency said 45 percent of police force vehicles are being used beyond their expiration date and 57 percent of patrol cars have traveled more than 500,000 kilometers.
Jiang said 359 old police cars and 571 motorcycles will be eliminated, and 397 new cars and 147 motorcycles will be purchased.
The focus on developing forensic skills will be on improving forensic technology and increasing laboratory efficiency.
Jiang noted that there is no shortage of weapons for police on duty, but he hopes to purchase more guns for shooting ranges next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's public-sector wages to stay steady next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:23:19 (By Lee Ming-chung, Justin Su, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government will not raise the pay of military personnel, government employees and teachers in public schools in 2011, the Central Personnel Administration announced Monday.
The issue could be reconsidered in the future, however, if the economy continues to improve and the government's financial woes ease, the administration said.

National Civil Servant Association Chairman Chen Chuan-ching said his group "understood" that the decision was made because of major concerns over the country's financial difficulties, which became worse due to the global financial crisis in late 2008.

According to the administration, public-sector wages have not been adjusted since 2005, when salaries were raised by 3 percent. Civil servants, military personnel and teachers also received a 3 percent raise in 2001.
Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang of the ruling Kuomintang said the lack of pay hikes could hurt the the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou's plan to build a clean and efficient government in Taiwan.
He contended that Taiwan has fallen behind Hong Kong in fighting corruption because civil servants there are paid more than their peers in Taiwan.
From the viewpoint of many people in the country, however, the wages of local public servants are not low, especially when considering the benefits they enjoy, Hsieh said.
If public servants were given a wage hike now when most people working in the private sector are paid less and have less security, Kuo said there would likely be protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG reaches agreement with Yunlin County over fire compensation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/16/10 23:51:06 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) reached an agreement with the Yunlin County government Monday on compensation over a string of recent mishaps at its petrochemical complex in the county's Mailiao Township.
The FPG agreed to pay up to NT$500 million (US$15.63 million) in compensation for the agricultural and fishery losses caused by the two fires last month.
The agreement was reached after FPG Vice Chairwoman Susan Wang met with Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen.
The county government made several requests during the meeting, including asking the Formosa Plastics Group to pay for a health risk assessment and epidemiology investigation in the area.

On setting up a NT$10 billion agricultural and fishery stability fund, Formosa Plastics agreed to set aside NT$3 billion over four years, with the county government hoping to solicit assistance from the central government for the remaining amount.
The FPG also agreed to subsidize a forestation project of up to 2,600 hectares to help cut carbon emissions.
The Yunlin County government asked the company to stop production once it has operated for 20 years and rehabilitate the seashore areas where the petrochemical complex is located.
"Formosa Plastics says it respected the request, but refused to comment on it," according to Vice Yunlin County chief Lin Yuan-chuan.
The FPG turned to talk with the county govenment after its negotiations with township residents over compensation broke down earlier in the day.

The residents vowed to block all three major roads leading to the complex Tuesday, forcing Formosa Plastics to ask police to help deal with the situation and alert employees to head to work earlier than normal.
Mailiao Township Council head Hsu Liu-pin said town residents have put up with the complex for more than 10 years since it first began operating in 1998.
"The residents want justice now," Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 17, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full- scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

Taiwan shares open higher

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: A holy place for Taiwanese politicians
DOC.DATELINE: 08/17/10 10:11:25 (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 17, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: "Singapore fever" appears from time to time in Taiwan. Politicians scramble to visit Singapore, professedly to learn from the city state's experience, and take pride in seeing Lee Kuan Yew. There are also articles discussing "if Singapore can, why can't Taiwan?"
Singapore has thus become a holy place for Taiwanese politicians. But in all these years, what has Taiwan learned from Singapore?

In the latest outbreak of the fever, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu- hsing, who quit the Democratic Progressive Party to run in the year-end election for the new special municipality of Kaohsiung, will visit Singapore next month. Kuomintang Secretary-General King Pu-tsung, meanwhile, will also accompany his party's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao-shun to the city state, with a plan to meet Lee.

Taiwan has not matched any of Singapore's achievements, including its liberalized economy, strict laws, clean and competent civil service, enterprising government and business sector, strong leadership, and good use of the country's excellent strategic position.
Democratic development is the only area in which Taiwan has surpassed Singapore. It is ironic that two major candidates in a democratic election are going on a pilgrimage to authoritarian Singapore.
We bet the upcoming Singapore visit by Yang, King and Huang will have no effect on Taiwan at all, as if they had never been there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Emerging challenges of demographic transition

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total fertility rate -- the average number of children to be born to a woman over her lifetime -- is likely to drop below 1 this year for the first time to 0.94, according to a biennial demographic assessment released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Monday.

For many years, Taiwan has lagged behind other major Asian countries in terms of both fertility rate and birth rate -- the average annual number of births during a year per 1,000 persons in the population.

According to the latest CEPD estimate, Taiwan's population will reach zero population growth in 2022, four years earlier than previously forecast, and the population will begin to decrease from the following year.
The advent of zero growth will impact the education system and labor market, and the country's competitiveness will also be adversely affected, CEPD officials warned.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Chen Shih-chang, director of the CEPD's Department of Manpower Planning, said Taiwan's low fertility rate has led to the rapid aging of the population. Fourteen percent of the total population will be over 65 years old in 2017, a ratio that will make Taiwan an aging society as generally defined in the international community.
The aging of the population will have serious social consequences, with schools having difficulty recruiting students and companies having a hard time finding employees, Chen said.

At present, Taiwan still benefits from a "demographic dividend, " with every 100 working-age people supporting an average of 36 dependents, but it will shift to a "demographic debt" in 2034 when every working-age people will have to support an average of more than 1.5 dependents, a phenomenon that will pose a heavy burden on the economy and health care system, Chen said. (Aug. 17, 2010).
China Times:

Taiwan's fertility rate has been on a steady decline since reaching 1.6 in 2001. It hit a low of 1.03 in 2009, the world's second lowest, higher only than that of Germany, according to the latest CEPD report.

The report predicted that the fertility rate will drop further to an estimated 0.94 this year because of the traditional superstition that the Year of the Tiger is not a good time for babies to be born.

Nevertheless, the CEPD optimistically forecast that the fertility rate will rebound next year and may reach a peak in 2012 -- the Year of the Dragon, traditionally seen as an auspicious time for birth. Moreover, it said the government has offered incentives to encourage birth, including childbirth and rearing subsidies.
The CEPD also suggested that the government speed up efforts to craft a comprehensive health care system, promote a healthy way of life and improve the social security system.

With Taiwan facing a rapidly aging population, the CEPD said the government should increase investment in manpower cultivation and boost the labor participation rate, encourage economic immigration and extend the mandatory retirement age. (Aug. 17, 2010). Liberty Times:

Former CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said the aging population will have a negative impact on GDP growth because it will lead to a decline in the size of the working population and reduce consumer spending.

He noted, however, that some academics have a different view on the issue. They believe that as Taiwan has limited space and natural resources, slow population growth may not necessarily be a bad thing and that per capita GDP will not necessarily decline, Hu said.

But Chou Chi, a Shih Hsin University economics professor, said population aging will not only affect labor productivity but also increase young people's financial burden as well as health care and social welfare spending. (Aug. 17, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Restoring fairness to consumers
DOC.DATELINE: After Taiwan was admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) 08/17/10 11:56:43 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: in 2002, the price of rice wine gradually rose from NT$22 per bottle to NT$180 per bottle, with the alcohol excise tax accounting for NT$111.

The unreasonable situation resulted in the hoarding of rice wine and prevalent bootlegging. This is demonstrated in the plunge in Taiwan Tobacco & Liquor Corp.'s rice wine sales, from 220 million bottles per year before WTO accession to 7.5 million bottles afterwards.

This painful experience could have been avoided had Taiwan insisted that rice wine, 96 percent of which is used for cooking, be taxed as "cooking wine" instead of distilled spirits during WTO accession talks.

The Executive Yuan is finally taking action to address the situation, which has drawn widespread public complaints. After successfully dropping the price of rice wine to NT$50 per bottle by taxing alcoholic beverages based on alcohol content from June 1, 2009, the Executive Yuan decided recently to amend the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Act to re-categorize rice wine as "cooking wine, " which would decrease the price further to NT$25 per bottle.

Taiwan should fully prepare to fight the case at the WTO and make the United States and European Union understand that under the national treatment principle (which bars treating imported goods differently from similar domestic goods in the local market) , imported cooking rice can also enjoy a lower excise tax rate.

The people of Taiwan have too often paid an unreasonable price just to gain accession to the WTO. The latest move by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou will remedy the previous error and restore fairness to consumers. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Increasing cross-strait military imbalance troubling, says U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/17/10 12:19:14 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite closer economic and cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, a Pentagon official said Monday that China's military buildup opposite Taiwan is troubling.

"We do see a continuation of troubling -- of troubling trends -- that include what we perceive as an increased Chinese activity in strengthening their hand across the strait, " said the Pentagon official, referring to the just-released report "Military and Security Developments Involving the People's Republic of China 2010."

"This is a time when we've seen progress on the diplomatic front and the economic front, and yet in the security, the military field, we've seen no change in Chinese behavior, " said the official, whose name was withheld as he was speaking on background.

Pentagon authors said in the report that China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) is developing the capability to deter Taiwan independence or influence Taiwan to settle the dispute on Beijing's terms while simultaneously attempting to deter, delay, or deny any possible U.S. support for the island in case of conflict.
"The balance of cross-Strait military forces continues to shift in the mainland's favor," the report said.
China's comprehensive military modernization is supported by the continued increase in government funding, the report said.

On March 4 of this year, Beijing announced a 7.5 percent increase in its military budget to approximately US$78.6 billion, continuing more than two decades of sustained annual increases in China's announced military budget.
According to the report, by December 2009, the PLA had deployed between 1,050 and 1,150 CSS-6 and CSS-7 short-range ballistic missiles to units opposite Taiwan.
"It is upgrading the lethality of the force, including by introducing variants of these missiles with improved ranges, accuracies, and payloads," the report said.

The PLA has made modest improvements in the transparency of China's military and security affairs. However, many uncertainties remain regarding how China will use its expanding military capabilities, the report said.
The limited transparency in China's military and security affairs enhances uncertainty and increases the potential for misunderstanding and miscalculation, one official said.

"(It is) also perhaps even more troubling given China's increasing military capabilities -- a cycle that increases the risk that miscommunication and misperception could lead to miscalculation, "another senior official said at the press briefing.

The cross-strait military imbalance becomes more obvious when the scales of the two sides' armed forces are compared. China's army maintains 400,000 ground forces personnel based in three military regions opposite Taiwan, compared to Taiwan's 130,000.

In the air force, the PLA bases 330 combat fighters within unrefueled operational range of Taiwan, along with 160 bombers and 40 transports, while Taiwan has 388 jet fighters, 22 attack/bombers and 21 transports, according to the report.

A comparison of naval forces shows that the PLA has a 15: 4 edge over Taiwan in destroyers, a 40:22 edge in cruisers, a 25:12 edge in amphibious ships, and a 32:4 edge in diesel attack subs, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA Airways shares boosted by earnings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 12:56:59 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: EVA Airways' share price rose sharply in heavy trade Tuesday morning after the carrier reported strong earnings for the first half of this year, dealers said, but prices fell back later in the session.

EVA Air shares jumped by the maximum 7 percent to NT$26.25 in the first half hour of trading but were then hit by profit-taking. At 12:43 p.m., it was up NT$0.15 at NT$24.70, with 125.6 million shares changing hands.

EVA Air announced Monday that it posted NT$5.22 billion (US$163 million) in net profit in the January-June period, compared with a net loss of NT$1.68 billion for the first half of 2009 and NT$2.84 billion for the entire year.
In 2008, the carrier also registered a net loss of NT$16.89 billion amid skyrocketing international fuel prices and a global financial meltdown.
"Investors are happy with the six-month earnings as the world's airline business climbed from a low on a global economic recovery, " Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.
Miao said the summer vacation has lifted passenger numbers and the economic recovery has driven increases in air cargo volume.
"In Taiwan, the airline sector has a plus to further boost their bottom line, " Miao said. "That's direct flights across the Taiwan Strait."
TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih agreed, saying the 2010 Shanghai Expo, which opened in May, attracted many Taiwanese tourists.

Earlier this year, EVA Air and rival China Airlines said the load factor on the route between Taipei Songshan Airport and Shanghai Hongqiao Airport exceeded 90 percent, and hoped authorities in both countries would raise the number of flights to meet demand.
"EVA Air's share price has been boosted recently by strong demand across the Taiwan Strait. Cross-strait ties have stirred up much speculation of more momentum in the stocks," Shih said.
Stable fuel prices have also helped underpin the company's strong first-half earnings, the analyst said. Fuel spending accounts for 20-22 percent of a carrier's total operating costs.

Shih said, however, that the stock was moving toward technical resistance at around NT$26.25, and he warned investors of a possible pullback after recent robust gains, as in fact happened later in Tuesday's session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protest against Formosa Plastics leads to clashes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 13:05:35 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Clashes erupted between protesters and the police Tuesday morning when thousands of angry local residents blocked all three major roads leading to the Formosa Plastic Group's (FPG) petrochemical complex in Yunlin County after compensation talks broke down the previous day.

Using blow horns and loud speakers, the angry crowd laid siege to the complex, demanding that the conglomerate pay residents NT$1.8 billion (US$53 million) for polluting the area and harming their health and promise to relocate later this decade.
Close to 1,000 police and at least three prosecutors were dispatched to the scene in an effort to clear the way for complex employees and keep watch against any illegal activities.

According to local reports, seven people were arrested by 10 a.m. for ramming through police lines. Police said the demonstration violated the Assembly and Parade Act because the organizer did not obtain prior approval from authorities to hold the protest.
On Monday, the third round of compensation talks ended in acrimony when the plastic giant refused to agree to the residents' demand for a NT$1.8 billion compensation package.
Wang Chang, the FPG representative, said the demand was unacceptable and the company has already reached its maximum by offering NT$500 million in overall compensation.
The group also agreed to subsidize a forestation project of up to 2,600 hectares to help curb carbon emissions.
The talks came after a huge fire on July 25 which set one of the complex's oil refining plants ablaze, the second fire at the complex in three weeks.

Residents of Mailiao Township where the complex is located and of other nearby villages accused the plant of having poor safety precautions and of neglecting the potential health risks for people living near the facility.
The residents, mainly farmers and fishermen, have formed self-help groups and demanded that the plant shut down immediately until a more thorough health risk and safety assessment has been conducted.
The complex in Mailiao Township is the fifth largest in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: The opposition's policy
DOC.DATELINE: 08/17/10 14:31:58 (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 17, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: We have consistently urged the government to draft a plan for Taiwan's long-term economic development, but we also hope that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as the largest opposition party, will present a comprehensive set of economic policies and arguments.

In response to a recent announcement by Taiwan and Singapore taht they plan to begin free trade talks, the DPP said this was no breakthrough because the effort was launched when it was in power. The party also said Taiwan should set some priorities and put the United States, Japan and the European Union at the top of its list in the effort to sign free trade agreements with other countries, instead of targeting Singapore as a matter of expediency.
The DPP's statement amounted to a denouncement of itself for failing to set priorities in the past and an admission that it had approached Singapore on an FTA because it was convenient to do so.

A similar contradiction was seen in the DPP's position on the Kuokuang Petrochemical Park. Although the DPP promoted the project when it was in power, it is now saying that the economic value of the project should not take precedence over environmental concerns. This amounts to a confession that when the DPP was in power, it attached greater importance to the economy than to the environment.
These examples show that the DPP still has not developed a comprehensive policy or set of core values regarding Taiwan's economic development.
The DPP should drop the strategy of merely using political rhetoric to win votes. It should instead work hard to take the lead in terms of policies and to gain the people's approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Security pact covers Tiaoyutas: U.S. State Department
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 16 (CNA) 08/17/10 14:32:21 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A U.S. Department of State official said Monday that the Japan-U.S. security pact still applies to the Senkaku Islands even if the administration of President Barack Obama has not stated so explicitly.

The Senkaku Islands, known in Chinese as the Tiaoyutais, have been under the administrative control of the government of Japan and are therefore subject to the Japan-U.S. security treaty signed in 1960, Philip Crowley, assistant secretary under the State Department's Bureau of Public Affairs, said at a news briefing.

Taiwan has been one of the countries along with Japan and China that claims sovereignty over the uninhabited island group, a stance that has been a thorn in unofficial bilateral ties between Taiwan and Japan.

The Kyodo News reported recently that the Obama administration has not explicitly stated that the islands are subject to the Japan-U.S. security treaty -- in a shift from the position held by former President George W. Bush.

Washington is believed to have shifted its position to avoid irritating Beijing while trying to secure China's cooperation in helping the U.S. recover from the financial crisis, Kyodo cited a source familiar with the matter as saying Monday.
On whether the Obama administration has shifted Washington's stance on the Senkaku Islands, Crowley said, "We have not changed our position."

The stance of the preceding Bush administration was that the Senkaku Islands have been under Japan's administrative control since having been returned as part of the reversion of Okinawa in 1972; that Article 5 of the 1960 U.S.-Japan Security Treaty applies to the territories under the Japanese administration; and that Article 5 of the pact applies to the Senkaku Islands.

When the Japanese government sought confirmation of the U.S. position on the island in March 2009, the Obama administration repeated the first two formulations but it did not mention directly that the Senkaku Islands are covered under the pact, the Kyodo report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President envisions mechanism to boost trade ties with Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 14:47:25 (By Garfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Tuesday for an institutionalized mechanism to boost trade between Taiwan and Japan, basing his optimism on what he called a beneficial triangular scenario after the signing of a landmark trade deal with China.

"The clinching of a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in late June has helped create a beneficial three-way situation among Taiwan, China and Japan, allowing them not to 'take sides' in the relationship, " Ma told a group of professors from the University of Tokyo and Keio University at the Presidential Office.

Citing an analysis by Nomura Research Institute, Ma said Japanese companies would stand a better chance of success (78 percent instead of 68 percent) tapping into the Chinese market if they team up with their long-term Taiwanese partners in the ECFA era.
With this in mind, Taiwan hopes to build an institutionalized trade and commerce mechanism with Japan to enhance bilateral exchanges, the president said.
"But the two sides are still assessing the form of the bilateral mechanism that should be established," he added.
Since assuming office in May 2008, Ma said, he has been eager to pursue improved ties with Japan and some initial progress has been made.
Taiwan, for example, opened a Hokkaido office in Sapporo last December and from October this year, Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport will resume two-way direct flights, he noted.
Taiwan's next initiative in boosting ties with Japan will be to sponsor an exhibition of the National Palace Museum's treasures there, he said.
