DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.12 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 15:39:46 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed down 0.12 percent Tuesday after gains posted by old economy stocks were offset by slowing momentum in the high-tech sector as concerns linger over global demand in the second half of the year, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 10.13 points to close at the day's low of 7,931.09, off a high of 7,973.15, on turnover of NT$132.36 billion (US$4.14 billion).
The market opened up 0.27 percent and quickly moved to the day's high as select non-high tech sectors with close business ties with China extended gains from the previous session.
But the electronics sector remained haunted by fears of a slower global economy, prompting investors to cut their holdings, dealers said.
A total of 1,842 stocks closed down and 1,870 finished higher, while 300 remained unchanged.
The foodstuff sector posted the highest gains of any sector, rising 3.9 percent. Construction shares rose 2.1 percent and textile stocks gained 1.8 percent.

The financial sector closed down 0.6 percent, the plastics and chemical sector lost 0.4 percent, the paper and pulp sector fell 0.3 percent, and cement and machinery and electronics shares fell 0.2 percent.
"Expectations remain in place that traditional industrial stocks, such as food and textile firms, will benefit from closer ties across the Taiwan Strait," Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
Lin said investors also have high hopes that Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) will soon include more Taiwanese old economy stocks into its emerging market index.
Recently, the non-high tech sector has outperformed the broader market, Lin said,

"But its strength was not significant enough to help the market overcome the strong technical resistance above 8,000 points." Lin said, "As long as trade in the high-tech sector is slow, the market is unlikely to get out of its current doldrums."
Lin said electronics have lost steam as foreign institutional investors remain sidelined on fears of further volatility on Wall Street.
He said growing margin trade has also been a factor destabilizing the market, and described the NT$274 billion of outstanding shares bought on margin as very high.
In the foodstuff sector, Uni-President Enterprises rose 6.87 percent to NT$38.10 and Taisun Enterprise added 6.91 percent to NT$20.10.
Among textile stocks, Shinkong Synthetic Fibers added 2.06 percent to NT$12.40 and Far Eastern New Century rose 1.65 percent to NT$39.95.
Personal computer firm AsusTek fell 3.35 percent to NT$230.50 and smartphone maker HTC lost 1.93 percent to NT$611.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese violinist moves audience to tears in Peru
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 15:56:39 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese violinist Yo-yo Fann, playing with Peru's National Symphony Orchestra in Lima Sunday, moved the audience to tears with his rendition of a famous Peruvian piece "Song of Eagles."

According to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Peru, the performance by the 23-year-old Fann was so enthralling that not only was the audience in tears, but the violinist was invited to return to Peru for another concert.
Conductor Pablo Sabat, who is also a renowned Peruvian pianist, said that despite Fann's youth he was able to give a perfect interpretation of Brahms Violin Concerto during the concert.
Sabat said that he was very pleased to perform with Fann and looked forward to doing so again.
As part of his schedule in Peru, Fann gave a solo concert Aug. 11, which was also very well received, and performed with the National Symphony Orchestra Aug. 14 at Lima's National Museum.
Taiwan's representative to Peru Huang Rong-kuo said Taiwan has gained greater exposure and a brighter image in Peru as a result of the two performances.

Fann, who is a graduate student at Juilliard School, has won several competitions and awards in Taiwan, New York, and Germany. They include the Regina Rubinoff Award at Steinway Hall, the Manhattan School of Music Preparatory Division Concerto Competition, the Taiwan National Youth Competition, and "Best Sonata" at the International Violin Competition at Kulturstiftung Hohanlohe.
He has participated in the Aspen Music Festival, Oberlin Baroque Performance Institute Festival, Summit Music Festival and Atlantic Music Festival.
Fann has undergraduate degree in Violin Performance from DePaul University in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth Olympics medalist wants to meet birth father
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 16:13:43 (By Lu Tai-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Youth Olympics silver medalist Kuo Hsing-chun, who has professed a desire to meet her birth father, was supported by her mother Tuesday, who said she respects her daughter's desire to meet her father, who she has never met.

Kuo, who took silver in the women's 53 kg weightlifting division at the games in Singapore with a total score of 174 kg., said upon receiving her medal that she hoped to meet her dad and share her glory with him.
Kuo appealed to the Taiwanese public to help her find her father.
Kuo's mother, overwhelmed by mixed feelings of her daughter's exceptional performance in international competition and her heart-rending wish to find her dad, said she would not oppose her search.
"I'll bless her if she insists," Kuo's mother said.

Kuo said Hsing-chun's father left home when she was only a few months old and never returned. She also pointed out that although she brought the infant Hsing- chun back to her father's maternal home, her father did not come to visit.
Kuo said Hsing-chun has been a source of pride, as the child has always been happy and thoughtful, has barely mentioned her dad and has taken the family's poverty in her stride.
It has always been Hsing-chun's philosophy that "poor people can be happy too," her mother said.

Tai Hsia-ling, the minister of Taiwan's Sports Affairs Council, attended the weightlifting event in Singapore and afterward presented Kuo with a congratulatory message on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou, as well as a cash prize.

The games, which are the first Olympics designed for athletes between the ages of 14 and 18, opened in Singapore over the weekend. Some 3,200 athletes from around the world are competing in 26 sports over 12 days.
Taiwan is fielding a 40-member delegation at the games under the name of Chinese Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan forge agreement to boost sports exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 16:47:55 (By Tang Pei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Olympic sport promotion organizations of Taiwan and Japan inked an agreement Tuesday to boost bilateral cooperation and interaction.

Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas Tsai signed the deal with his Japanese counterpart Tsunekazu Takeda, president of the Japanese Olympic Committee, in Singapore during the first Youth Olympic Games there.
Tsai said he expects that "the links and friendship between the two organizations will become closer and that sports exchanges will also become more frequent in the future" thanks to the new deal.

According to the accord, the two sides agree to share information on Olympic sports activities, give each other support, and encourage athletes and coaches of the two countries to attend sports events such as the Olympics.

Athletes and coaches are also allowed to train in each other's country while the bilateral cooperation includes exchanges of personnel, such as officials, staff in charge of sports affairs and judges.
In addition, the two sides have agreed to coordinate on measures to combat the use of banned drugs in sports.
Also present at the signing ceremony were Taiwan's Sports Affairs Council Minister Tai Hsia-ling and Taiwan's representative to Singapore Vanessa Shih.
The Youth Olympics opened Aug. 14 and will run through Aug. 26, with the participation of athletes from 205 nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 16:55:13 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, dropping NT$0.04 to close at NT$31.970.
Turnover totaled US$499 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.010 and moved to a low of NT$31.873 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fame of late president's look-alike reflects new tack toward China

TEXT.P: A man who closely resembles late President Chiang Kai-shek has become Taiwan's secret weapon with the Chinese communists -- not in fighting them as did the generalissimo but in getting them to visit Taiwan on vacation.

Lee Deng-ke, 82, once served as a body guard for President Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of President Chiang Kai-shek, but he only began gaining recognition when he served as a volunteer guide at a Hualien theme park after retiring from Chiang's entourage.

Visitors often mistook him for Chiang Kai-shek, giving a local travel agent the idea of using him as a drawing card after improving relations with China opened the door to an influx of Chinese tourists in mid-2008.

Lee now serves as a tour guide who takes Chinese visitors to Chiang Kai-shek's mausoleum in Cihhu, Taoyuan County, and Chiang's residence in Shilin, Taipei City. He is often surrounded by his guests eager to have their picture taken with him at the sites.
Lee says that after having come in contact with so many visitors from China, he can figure out where in China they come from simply by the way they address him.
"People from southern China usually have a lot of respect for Chiang and will call me 'generalissimo, ' while people from northern China tend to simply call me Chiang Kai-shek."

Chiang, who led China in his capacity as a generalissimo of a junta during China's eight-year war against Japan, was forced to move his Chinese Nationalist government to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the communists.
He was known for spending his remaining years in Taiwan until his death in 1975 in the forlorn hope of revenging his humiliating defeat against the communists and reclaiming the Chinese mainland.

His staunchly anti-communist approach prevented any contact between Taiwan and China, but Lee's popularity reflects a new era of greater openness between the two countries that could bring more than 1 million Chinese nationals to Taiwan this year.
The new opportunity created by improving ties has also given Lee the chance to try to dispel the image that Chiang's Kuomintang (KMT) was notoriously corrupt.
When Chinese tourists offer him tips after taking their picture with him, Lee denies them the privilege of greasing the palms of "Chiang Kai-shek."
"The generalissimo is not so poor that he has to take tips, " Lee protests.
Because of his growing fame, Lee has been asked by many businessmen to endorse their products in commercials. There have been so many requests that he had to retain an agent to deal with them.
He may also give politics a go. Lee said he would not rule out making appearances for KMT candidates in the mayoral elections of Taiwan's five special municipalities.
So it should not be a surprise if the old generalissimo is seen barnstorming for his party's candidates during the upcoming campaign. enditem/ls By Maubo Chang CNA Staff Writer CNA photo 0059

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based cell phone maker expects TDR sales in Q4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 17:14:32 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Z-Obee Holdings Ltd., a China-based cell phone and communications equipment producer and distributor, is expected to list Taiwan depository receipts (TDRs) in the fourth quarter of this year, underwriter Polaris Securities said Tuesday.

"Z-Obee has filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange to issue TDRs, hoping to raise NT$880 million (US$27.53 million) for future business expansion, " said a Polaris Securities official in charge of the share sale plan.

He said that if the TDR application is approved by the Taiwanese authorities, Z-Obee will become the first company in the greater China area to be listed in Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan at the same time.
Z-Obee was listed on the Singapore Exchange in November 2009 and on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in March 2010.
According to the company's prospectus, Z-Obee is planning to issue up to 80 million TDRs, each one of which will represent one common share at NT$11 per unit.
Polaris Securities said Z-Obee is also planning to use the share issuance plan to build up its visibility in the Taiwan market for future product marketing and sales.

Z-Obee, which makes and distributes cell phones and components as well as communications solution designs, has launched its own cell phone brand "VIM" in China and Hong Kong, and is also developing netbook computers, set-top boxes and e-readers.
The company has a production base in Shenzhen and a research and development center in Shanghai.
China and Hong Kong are the company's revenue sources, making up 79.50 percent and 20.50 percent, respectively, of its total sales recorded in the April 2009-March 2010 period.
In the April 2009-March 2010 period, Z-Obee posted US$5.20 million in net profits, up 33 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan throws perfect game at Junior League Baseball World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 17:31:32 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan pitched a five-inning perfect game in a 13-0 victory over Ukraine in day two of the 2010 Junior League Baseball World Series held Monday in Taylor, Michigan, according to the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association.
It was the second consecutive win by Taiwan, which defeated Guatemala on the first day of the series.
Taiwan was scheduled to encounter Canada Tuesday.
The Junior League Baseball World Series sees the participation of 10 teams of 13- and 14-year-olds divided into two pools -- the United States and the international pool.

The U.S. pool groups the five best teams from the western, southeast, central, southwest and eastern regions of that country. Taiwan is in the international pool, which also groups Ukraine, Mexico, Guatemala and Canada.
The top two teams from each pool will go through to the semi-finals slated for Aug. 20, with the final match to be played the day after that.

DOC.HEADLINE: Little League team from Taiwan arrives in U.S. for World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C. Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 17:58:53 (By Jorge Liu and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A Little League team from Kaohsiung has arrived in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, less than a week before its opening game in the Little League World Series.

Players from Fu-Hsing Little League in Kaohsiung, the last team from Taiwan to win the Little League World Series in 1996, began acclimating themselves with the field and stadium after arriving in Williamsport on Aug. 15.
They will open their title bid on Aug. 22 at 6 a.m. Taiwan time against the Middle East champion, the Arabian American Little League from Dhahran, Saudi Arabia.
To advance to the tournament's final four, Taiwan must win Pool D, which also includes teams from Chitre, Panama and Vancouver, Canada.
If it succeeds, it will play the winner of Pool D, comprised of teams from the Caribbean, Japan, Mexico and Europe, for the international championship.
The winner of that contest then vies with the U.S. champion for the World Series title early Aug. 30 Taiwan time.

Taiwan was long a powerhouse at the annual tournament, winning 17 titles between 1969 and 1996, but it has had a dry spell since then, with this year's club from Kaohsiung only the fourth from Taiwan to even qualify for the World Series in the past 14 years.

Local interest in the tournament was rekindled last year after a team from Kueishan in Taoyuan County made a brilliant run before losing the championship game to a team from California, meaning expectations will be high this year for the Kaohsiung side.
Most of the players on this year's team attend Kaohsiung Municipal Fuh-hsing Primary School.

DOC.HEADLINE: International exhibit to feature work of young Taiwanese artists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 18:36:06 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The work of nine young Taiwanese artists will be featured at an international art exhibition in Taipei this month, which will give them an opportunity to break into the global art scene, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Tuesday.

Their work will be among the paintings, sculptures, multimedia, video, photography and installation art that will be displayed by 110 exhibitors from 15 countries or cities at Art Taipei 2010, said Hsu Keng-Hsiu, a CCA department director.

"The nine Taiwanese artists, who were selected by the CCA from a field of 202 competitors under the age of 35, will present their art in a section of the exhibition titled 'Made in Taiwan -- Young Artist Discovery,'" Hsu said.
One of the selected artists, Hsu Wei-Hui, uses a special medium -- cosmetic facial masks --to create installation art that shows various facial expressions such as horror, terror and happiness.
"Through my work, I want to examine issues relating to women's appearance and inner fears," the artist said.
Another artist, Lin Yu-Ting, uses cake decorating techniques to create several small houses that are reminiscent of those built in her hometown of Tainan, southern Taiwan, in the 1950s to 1970s.
"These structures all seem similar, but if you look closely, you will see that each one has its own special features, " said Lin, pointing at her miniature houses.
Lin said that as part of the process, she learned how to make an actual cake in order to refine her artistic skills.
"I plan to one day use this skill to create installation and video art of a community and a city scene," she told the Central News Agency.
The show, which is now in its 17th year, provides a platform for young upcoming Taiwanese artists to gain international exposure, said Hsu Keng-Hsiu.

"One of the artists who took part in last year's show, Ho Meng-chuan, has since signed a contract with the Saatchi Gallery in the U.K., while others have had opportunities to attend various international fairs in the United States and Shanghai," she said.
The exhibition is being organized by the CCA, the Taiwan Art Gallery Association and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and will be held August 20-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Displaced Morakot victims to be settled by next May
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 19:01:31 (By Chen Shao-kuo and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Over 100 permanent houses are expected to be completed by the end of next May in Kaohsiung County's Shanlin Township for the survivors of mudslide-battered Siaolin Village who were displaced by Typhoon Morakot last August, the county government said Tuesday.

According to the Planning Office of the Kaohsiung county government, construction on a 5-hectare site dubbed the "Second Siaolin Village" is scheduled to start Nov. 15, after confirmation of a donation from the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and the completion of administration tasks.
However, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing confessed that "the housing project might not be finished by next Chinese New Year" as touted by President Ma Ying-jeou.

Ma announced the project during a visit to the surviving villagers Aug. 8 -- the first anniversary of the disaster -- and expressed hope that all the Morakot victims will be settled before next Chinese New Year in February 2011.
A total of 145 households from Siaolin Village applied to move into the planned village and 106 applications have already been approved, the county government said.

More than 200 households in Siaolin Village were buried under a massive mudslide last August. A total of 85 surviving families had applied to live in permanent houses situated in the village of Wulipu and sponsored by the Red Cross, while over 20 households had applied to move into a housing project sponsored by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in Shanlin Township.

Typhoon Morakot slammed into Taiwan in August last year, bringing powerful wind and torrential rain that left more than 700 people dead or missing, including an estimated 400 buried in the village of Siaolin alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar makes push for change in approach on reverse mortgages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 19:15:32 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A real estate expert suggested Tuesday that Taiwan should treat schemes that help the elderly live off the equity built up in their houses as commercial products rather than social welfare benefits to ensure that the system can be sustained.

At a seminar on the subject on Tuesday, Chang Chin-oh, a professor in National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, strongly advocated using reverse mortgages and sale/leaseback to help senior citizens who have low incomes but a house of their own boost their disposable income.
But he said the focus of the proposed system to implement the schemes should be adjusted.
At present, government initiatives to launch the financing plans are being handled by the Ministry of the Interior, which treats them as pensions, with the government providing most of the financing.
Chang argued at a seminar on the subject, however, that loans are by definition financial products and involve managing flows of money, meaning that financial authorities should take charge of them.
He also contended that for the system to be sustainable, reverse mortgages would have to become commercialized rather than arranged by the government.
It would lift a heavy financial burden off the government's shoulders, and for markets, "more choices would be a good thing," he said.

Chang and other real experts have pushed for reverse mortgages as a way to cope with Taiwan's rapidly aging society and low birth rate, which could eventually limit senior citizen pensions and the income the elderly get from their children.

Reverse mortgages are simply loans made to a homeowner against the property's equity. The money can be released in one lump sum or in multiple payments, and is repaid when the property is sold or refinanced by the borrower's heirs after he or she dies.

The sale/leaseback option would allow the elderly to sell their homes to insurance firms, which in turn offer the seniors annuities based on the value of their properties while still allowing them to reside in their own homes as tenants.

The government is interested in launching both products on a trial basis next year to give more income options to seniors, but Chang also said special legislation would also be required to reconcile the schemes with existing law.

Taiwan has the second fastest aging population in the world behind Japan. At present, people aged over 65 make up 10 percent of the country's population. By around 2020, the aged population is expected to reach 20 percent in Taiwan, according to a recent report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier mediates dispute between Miaoli County, farmers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 19:18:06 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of farmers who are opposed to the acquisition of their farmland by the Miaoli County Government for a science park project agreed Tuesday during a mediation meeting with Premier Wu Deng-yi to consider a land swap.

Wu proposed that the farmers be allowed to keep their residential properties but turn over their farmlands to the county government in return for similar size plots in an area designated for farming in the science park.

Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chi-chen Chiang, who was at the meeting, said afterward that the Miaoli County Government agreed to allow those farmers who do not want cash compensation to keep their residential property.

However, their farmlands will be acquired by the county and they will be given similar size plots inside the proposed science park, Chiang said. The Miaoli County Government will help them to build irrigation systems that would make the land more arable, he added.

Attorney Chan Shun-gui, who represented the farmers at the meeting, said the proposal is worth considering and he promised to consult with the farmers at a meeting on Aug. 22 and give the premier an answer next week.
The dispute arose from the Miaoli County Government's decision in 2004 to acquire 28 hectares of farmland to expand the Jhunan Science Park, which is a branch of the Hsinchu Science Park.

Some of the farmers who objected to the acquisition plan staged an overnight protest Aug. 6 in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei after the local government used bulldozers to level the crops on their farmland.
The protest prompted Wu to step in -- a move that was seen an effort to avert a political storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: ChimeiInnolux ranked as China's top TV panel supplier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 19:44:00 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker Chimei Innolux Corp. ranked the top TV panel supplier in China for the second quarter of this year, grabbing a 23 percent market share in terms of sales volume, according to a report published Tuesday by WitsView, a Taiwan- based industrial research institute.
The report attributed the company's strong showing to its efforts to "devote itself to long-term business in China."

AU Optronics, another Taiwanese firm, and Samsung Electronics of South Korea, took the tied No. 2 position, taking a 22 percent share of the China market in the past quarter, while LG Display (LGD) of South Korea accounted for 19 percent of the China market to become the fourth-largest supplier, the report said.
The four suppliers from Taiwan and South Korea accounted for a total of 88 percent of China's TV panel market, according to the report.
"In recent years, China has become the single market that has demonstrated the most rapid growth in TV panel demand, " the WitsView report said.
"Major global panel makers consider China to be the key market, and gaining a foothold in this market will ensure a more effective panel outlet," it added.

In terms of region, Taiwanese flat panel makers accounted for 50 percent of China's total TV panel sales in the second quarter, followed by South Korea's 42 percent. Japanese and Chinese manufacturers shared the remaining 8 percent.
"There are fewer cultural and language barriers between Taiwan and China, which has benefited the bilateral collaboration, " the report said.
The research institute said the government's policy of allowing local panel makers to set up back-end product assembly bases in China has made Taiwanese firms competitive in the China market.

In February, the Taiwanese authorities further relaxed restrictions to allow local firms to set up no more than three sixth- generation or above flat panel plants in China as long as they can ensure a technology lead over China and promise to continue investing in Taiwan.
AU Optronics is seeking regulatory approval to set up a US$3 billion flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province.

As for aggregate flat panel shipment by screen area, LGD ranked the largest supplier in China, taking a 24 percent of the market, as 42-inch or larger panels make up a large portion of the company's shipments.
The market share of Chimei Innolux, AU Optronics and Samsung ranged between 21 percent and 23 percent in terms of panel area.
WitsView said flat panel firms in South Korea have gained an advantage in competition by frequently launching new products, such as LED TV panels and large panels of 42 inches or larger.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel makers decline to confirm orders from China group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:07:36 (By Pan Chi-i and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) and HannStar Display Corp. declined Tuesday to confirm whether they expect product orders from a delegation from Guangdong Province, China.
The two companies said that they were unaware of any plans for the Chinese delegation to visit their factories and could not comment on any orders by customers.
It has been reported that the 1,000-member delegation, which arrived in Taiwan Monday headed by Guangdong Governor Huang Huahua, is expected to place large orders with AUO and HannStar.
The one-week visit by the delegation from the wealthy Chinese province came on the heels of a promise last month by a similar group from China to buy US$5.3 billion-worth of flat panels from Taiwan.
Huang said Monday after his arrival in Taiwan that his delegation will place orders for more than US$6 billion worth of Taiwan products, which is over the US$5.2 billion reported earlier.
The order will be the largest to date from China's provinces since a group from Jiangsu Province placed an order for around US$4.2 billion-worth of products last November.

DOC.HEADLINE: International folk song festival to kick off in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:22:40 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Over 70 musicians and groups are expected to show up for the third annual Hengchun International Folk Song and Musical Festival to be held Aug. 21-29, to perform an array of traditional tunes during the event, the Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Tuesday.
According to CCA Minister Emile Chihjen Sheng, the festival is one of the biggest music events in Taiwan and its purpose is to "pass on the heritage of folk songs for posterity."
"No matter what your voice is like, it will always sound beautiful as long as you are singing the traditional folk songs that tell stories of your own culture," he said.
This year, groups from Greece, Switzerland, Nepal, Thailand, South Korea and the Philippines will also be featured at the festival.

One of the major highlights of the event is a performance by 84 year-old Taiwanese man Chu Ting-shun, a Golden Melody Award winner for his compilation of famous Hoklo traditional folk songs such as "Nostalgia" and "Spring Eternal."

"Taiwanese traditional songs are very beautiful and it will be a pity if this wonderful culture slowly disappears, " said Chu, who added that he is happy that his 10-year-old great-grandson has proved to be eager to learn the art.

Located in southern Pingtung County, the Hengchun Peninsula is one of the first places the early arrivals to Taiwan settled and is often dubbed the gateway to the Kenting National Park. The place is rich with Taiwanese, Hakka and Aboriginal cultures.
Pingtung Deputy Magistrate Chung Chia-pin said the vibrancy and combination of the three cultures makes his hometown the best place to hold such event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Guangdong Province seeks closer links with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:38:59 (By Kuo Mei-lan, Chien Chia-yi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Guangdong Provincial Governor Huang Huahua called Tuesday for in-depth cooperation between Taiwan and his province in various fields, from industry to tourism.
Huang, heading a delegation of more than 1,000 members, spelled out the call at a grand opening ceremony for a "Taiwan-Guangdong Week" at the Taipei International Convention Center.

More than 3,000 leaders and representatives of the political and business sectors on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait attended the ceremony, including Wu Poh-hsiung, an honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, and Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Chairman Wang Chih-kang.

In his address, Huang touted the week-long event held to enhance bilateral cooperation as the first of its kind since Taiwan and China signed a landmark economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in late June, describing it as the "first wind blowing from the east" since the ECFA and saying that it opens a new era of economic, trade and cultural links between Taiwan and Guangdong.

Addressing Guangdong's efforts to streamline trade and mutual investment between the two sides, Huang invited Taiwanese tourism and culture promotion associations to open offices in his province to promote Taiwan tourism.
He also proposed strengthening cooperation in the cross-strait LED and electric automobile manufacturing industries, as well as in the agricultural sector.

Wu for his part expressed thanks for the help provided to Taiwanese businessmen operating in the southern Chinese province to tide them over the global financial storm and said evidence shows that cross-strait exchanges played a key role in helping Taiwan to survive the crisis.

The Taiwan-Guangdong Week, described by the organizers as a "journey of cooperation and nostalgia, " hopes to underline the importance of cross-strait strategic economic, agricultural and tourism cooperation with a variety of activities, including investment and procurement workshops and conferences on technological and agricultural cooperation.
Also at the opening ceremony, Wang said that the Chinese delegation will purchase more than US$6.6 billion-worth of products while in Taiwan.

As one of the purposes of Huang's visit is to invite Taiwanese people to travel to Guangdong for the upcoming 2010 Asian Games and Asian Para Games, he said he will present 11,000 entrance tickets for the events to Taiwanese people.
The 16th Asian Games and 19th Asian Para Games are both scheduled to open in Guangdong Nov. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan closely monitoring China's military build-up: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:44:05 (By Tseng Yi-hsuan, Li Garfie & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: In the wake of a U.S. Pentagon report that stated China's military build-up opposite Taiwan has "continued unabated" despite warming cross-strait relations, the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday it has been closely monitoring the situation.
"The public has no need to worry," said military spokesman Yu Sy- tue
The Pentagon, in a report released Monday on China's military development, said that China is expanding its military advantages over Taiwan, and is increasingly looking at areas beyond the island.
"The balance of cross-Strait military forces continues to shift in the mainland's favor," the report said.

In response, Lin Yu-fang, a convener of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee said there is no need for the public to be "overly nervous" as the possibility of a cross-strait conflict is very slim, given the stable relations between Taiwan and China.

On the matter of an increasing military imbalance in favor of China, Lin said that Taiwan's small land area makes it impossible for China to deploy all of its forces in the coastal provinces of Fujian and Guangdong opposite Taiwan in preparation for a possible war.
"From a regional perspective, a relative balance is maintained to some extent," Lin said.

Since the administration of U.S. President Barack Obama took office, it has not approved any new arms sales to Taiwan, Lin said, adding that Taiwan would be forced to develop guided missiles or cruise missiles with longer range if Washington continues to stall on selling Taiwan more advanced weapons.
"The U.S. should seriously consider whether it would let Taiwan to go its own way," he said.
In January, the U.S. announced its intent to sell US$6.4 billion worth of defensive arms to Taiwan -- a package that was approved by the administration of former President George W. Bush.

Wong Ming-hsien, director of Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies (GIIASS) , said that China has made several strategic moves over the past year, going back and forth between the first and second island chains in the Pacific ocean.
He cited as examples China's naval advance from the Pacific to Indian ocean to deter pirates in the Gulf of Aden and its attempts to build aircraft carriers.

The latest Pentagon report indicates that the U.S. is trying to deal comprehensively with China rising power by offering an analysis of the security situation in the region, Wong said. He urged that Washington adopt a new strategy toward Asia as China's rise is becoming a reality.

For Taiwan's part, it is definitely necessary to build a self-sufficient national defense and to show determination for self-defence, which will give the country greater bargaining power in its increasing exchanges with China, he said.

Former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and top Taiwan envoy to the U.S. Joseph Wu said that the report points to the fact that in spite of improved cross-strait ties, China has never abandoned its attempt (to take Taiwan by force.)
However, GIIASS professor Wang Kao-chen suggested that Taiwan take a two-pronged approach to the problem.
Taiwan should build its missile-defense capability and at the same time try to convince Beijing that its military deployment will only make the Taiwan people more bitter against China, he said.
He further advised that Taiwan take a neutral stand in the latest row between the U.S. and China over right of access in the South China Sea and the situation on the Korean Peninsula.
Any involvement by Taiwan in these issues would be detrimental, both in terms of Taiwan's national security and its economic development, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers develop computerized vehicle-tracking system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:47:51 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Researchers at the Industrial Technology Research Institute in Hsinchu City have developed a computerized system that can help track the movement of vehicles on roads, an institute official said Tuesday.

Hsieh Hsi-hsing, deputy chief of the institute's Identification and Security Technology Center told a news conference that the current way of reconstructing the movement of a vehicle is by watching videotapes recorded by security cameras installed at intersections.
Only after discovering when and where the target vehicle appears on the video tapes can the vehicle's route be mapped out, which is time-consuming and liable to errors, Hsieh said.
In the new system developed by the institute, a computer can replace the humans needed to review the tapes.

The system transforms the features of the vehicle, including its color, plate number -- even only a few letters of the plate -- the vehicle type and other vital information into digital data and then examines the tapes for similar vehicles.
It is much quicker and more exact than screening performed by people, Hsieh said.
The system can work with the existing security camera system, Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen bridge to boost prosperity: President Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 20:55:58 (By Garfie Li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that a planned bridge linking outlying Kinmen Island with the neighboring islet of Little Kinmen is expected to become a new sightseeing spot and bring prosperity to Little Kinmen.

The proposal to build the bridge was passed by the Executive Yuan in February and the plan has been closely watched, as the bridge will make a much-discussed bridge between Taiwanese territory and China more feasible because Little Kinmen is even closer to China than Kinmen, lying just about five kilometers off the Chinese coast.

The construction of the bridge is expected to start by the end of this year, and the structure will not only become a landmark but will also serve as a platform for linking public utility lines, Ma said while meeting representatives from the islands of Kinmen and Matsu at the Presidential Office.
Premier Wu Den-yih said Aug. 15 that the government is clearing mines on the outlying islands and hopes to begin building the 5.3-km bridge by the end of this year at the earliest.

The estimated cost of the project is about NT$5 billion (US$156.56 million) , two-thirds of which will come from the central government, with the remaining third from the Kinmen county government, Wu said.
According to the government's plan, the bridge is expected to be completed in 2015.

Meanwhile, Ma also said that while purchasing new boats for a ferry service between northern Taiwan's Keelung and Matsu, the government should consider whether the new ferries can help boost local tourism.
Some local residents had suggested that the government should buy trimaran fast ferries from abroad to save travel time, but Ma said the government wants to purchase locally manufactured vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: Google Taiwan reports 48% growth in advertisement sales
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 21:19:38 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan branch of the search engine giant Google reported Tuesday year-on- year growth of nearly 50 percent in online advertisement revenues for the first half of 2010.
"Google Taiwan's advertisement sales rose 48 percent in the first half of this year compared with the same period last year, " the company's general manager Chien Lee-feng said at a press briefing.
"This also means that Taiwan is one of Google's fastest-growing markets in Asia," he added.

Citing figures from the Taipei Internet Advertising and Media Association (IAMA) , Chien noted that Google's revenue growth was higher than the projected 12.76 percent for Taiwan's entire online advertisement market this year.
In a press statement, Google Taiwan attributed its high growth rate to growing demand for keyword-search advertising as Taiwan's export-reliant economy recovers.
However, the company did not disclose its revenue figures.
Google Taiwan also hailed its collaboration with Taipei-based G.T. Internet Information Co., which has more than 20,000 clients, mainly local small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
"We are working with agents in various specialized fields, who will teach domestic SMEs how to market online," Chien said in a press statement.
Google is already Taiwan's largest online advertisement network -- it has partnerships with more than 20,000 online content providers and reaches 97 percent of local Internet users, Chien said.
In the statement, G.T. General Manager Cheng Born-win said that the majority of SMEs companies in Taiwan are unfamiliar with online marketing or have not used it effectively.
"As a result, they miss many overseas business opportunities," he said.
Google Taiwan will launch a series of programs throughout the country in the second half of this year to help SMEs get a better grasp of Internet marketing, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three cases of dengue fever confirmed by CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 21:27:48 (By Chen Li-ting, Chung Hsing-hsien and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced three new cases of indigenous dengue fever Monday, two of which were contracted from the original patient.
According to CDC officials, a 41-year-old female living in Tainan County's Guanmiao Township began experiencing flu-like symptoms and was diagnosed as suffering from flu Aug. 9.

CDC said that three days later, she developed diarrhea, nausea, and blood in her urine and stool. On Aug. 13th, the medical center she attended reported her to the CDC, which confirmed her as a type 1 dengue patient.
An immediate investigation into the patient's surroundings was conducted by the Tainan County Health Bureau to see if there had been any disease transmission.
Blood tests on a neighbor and a man who works in the same shop as the patient showed positive for dengue fever, said CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih- hao.
Both the original patient and her co-worker had consulted doctors who failed to diagnose them, said Chou, urging doctors to be on the alert for dengue cases.
Six family members and four other co-workers of the original patient showed no dengue fever symptoms.
According to the CDC, there have been 15 cases of indigenous dengue fever since March, and Chou said the peak season for the disease this year might begin earlier than usual.

CDC officials urged the public to clean up mosquito breeding sites around their residences as the most effective means of preventing transmission of the disease, adding that further information can be obtained on the Communicable Disease Reporting and Consultation Hotline 1922 or on the CDC's website at http://www.cdc.gov.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: Fake security site targets Facebook users
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 21:55:54 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A phishing website that claims to be able to safeguard users of the popular social website Facebook against spam and hackers is actually designed to steal private information, a security software maker warned Tuesday.

Symantec said in a press statement that it spotted the phishing website titled "Security and Privacy Update, " which appeared to advise Facebook users to take protective measures over their security and privacy.
Phishing is a computer term that refers to those who "fish" for sensitive information from Internet users such as email addresses, user names and passwords.
The website asked Facebook users to confirm their accounts on the webpage, but actually was trying to steal users' email accounts and passwords, the statement reads.

"This facebook Security used to protect your facebook from spam or hackers who want to ruin your facebook. For the safety of your facebook, please confirm your account here. Your facebook will be protected safely," the statement quoted the website as saying.
The company advised Internet users to check the addresses of the website they visit to make sure that the sites are genuine.

DOC.HEADLINE: 38 candidates vying for 32 seats on KMT Central Standing Committee
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 22:07:33 (By Lee Shu-hua and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of 38 candidates had registered by Tuesday's deadline to run for 32 seats on the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) decision-making arm, the Central Standing Committee.

The candidates' qualifications will be examined over the next two days and those eligible will be announced Thursday, while ballot-casting day is set for Sept. 18, according to a schedule announced by the party.
All of the 32 incumbent committee members except for Legislator Huang Chao-hsun and Sean Lien, the son of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, are seeking re- election,
Notable among the newcomers who threw their hats into the ring are legislators Chou Yi, Wu Yu-sheng and Lu Hsueh-chang.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung ascribed the relatively fewer candidates for the committee to the fact that the member's term is only one year.
"Some have suggested extending the term by one more year, which is something we might contemplate in the future," King said.

He denied that party members are not enthusiastic about sitting on the committee because of its diminishing role in shaping national policy, saying that the committee is more an advisor to the government than a policymaker.
"I myself stick to my role as a mirror that reflects public opinion on national issues," he added.
In addition to the 32 elected members, the committee has another five members appointed by the party chairman, and two members reserved for the party's youth wing.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% of households in community damaged by landslide get compensated
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 22:14:23 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of 409 households out of 482 in a community in Taipei County's Sijhih have received compensation, 13 years after their houses were damaged by a landslide triggered by Typhoon Winnie.
A statement issued Tuesday by the Taipei county government said that almost 90 percent of the NT$100 million (US$3.13 million) compensation had already been claimed by the victims.
The mudslide knocked down 200 apartments in the Lincoln Community and badly damaged 282 others, killing 28 people and injuring 50 .

As the real estate developer who built the community was unable to compensate the residents, the house owners demanded that the local government should pay, arguing that it shared the blame by permitting the developer to build apartments on a slide-prone hillside.
Various candidates who ran for county magistrate since that 1997 disaster had promised to help the dwellers to claim national compensation in attempts to win their votes.
The county government was eventually able to earmark NT$137.77 million as compensation for the affected residents, according to the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dispute over ban on Chinese students working in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 22:22:49 (By Justin Su, Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A war of words erupted Tuesday after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) questioned the government's intention not to write into law a promise that Chinese students will not be allowed to work while studying in Taiwan.
DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang argued in a statement that without the proposed law, Taiwan will be opening its doors to Chinese laborers "in an alternative way."
Citing examples in other countries that admit Chinese students to their higher education institutions, Lin said the percentage of Chinese students who work illegally is "very high."

In response to the DPP's insistence on listing the prohibition in the University Act, Legislator Lin Yi-shih of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , who is also chief executive of the party' Central Policy Committee, said there is no need to do so because the existing laws already stipulate the ban.

Lin pointed out that the Act Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area contains an article banning Chinese permitted to enter Taiwan from conducting activities inconsistent with the purpose of their stays.

The DPP, however, accused the Ma Ying-jeou administration of attempting to relax the restriction through the Employment Services Act, which treats Chinese students enrolled in local schools as any other foreign students, who are allowed to work for a maximum of 16 hours per week during semesters.
The limitation on working hours does not include summer and winter breaks.
DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling said that allowing Chinese students to work will affect part-time job opportunities for local students.

"Allowing 8,000 Chinese students to work would lead to the joblessness of 4,286 Taiwanese people, and the unemployment rate among local people aged between 20 and 24 would increase to 15.25 percent, " said DPP Legislator Lin Shu-fen at a press conference held earlier in the day by the DPP legislative caucus.

The disputes arose after Kuan accused the Presidential Office the previous day of intervening in talks between lawmakers of the ruling and opposition parties on three Ministry of Education-initiated packages of legal amendments to pave the way for the admission of Chinese students to local tertiary education institutions.
Kuan accused the office of overthrowing an agreement between the ruling and opposition camps to write into law the proposal to ban Chinese student from working while studying.
The Presidential Office denied the allegation.
The DPP is strongly opposed to the idea of opening Taiwan's doors to Chinese students out of fear that they might displace local students and workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Setting up trade offices on both sides of strait beneficial: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 23:04:49 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Setting up trade offices on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will facilitate business exchanges between the two sides, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said during a Tuesday dinner meeting with visiting Guangdong Governor Huang huahua.

Chiang said that trade organizations such as the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association and the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries will be able to set up offices across the strait under the recently signed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
The new policy will benefit Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China, Chiang said.

He noted that many Taiwanese investors in China's service industry are faced with difficulties resulting from a lack of legal protection. With the signing of the ECFA, however, the investment environment in China will attract more businessmen from Taiwan, he continued.

Following a "trade first, politics later" principle, cross-strait exchanges in the fields of education, medical science and culture are bound to have a positive impact on the people of both sides, he added.
In response to Chiang's statement, Huang said he will push for more cooperation between Guangdong and Taiwan in trade, as well as in the agriculture and the service sectors.
Huang is visiting Taiwan at the head of a 1,000-strong delegation of buyers from his province.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian office in Taiwan to be relocated
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 23:06:52 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT), Canada's representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official bilateral diplomatic ties, said in a press release Tuesday that its office will be closed Aug. 19-23 due to relocation.

No visa or passport services will be available during the relocation period, the CTOT said, adding that its office will reopen Aug. 24 at No. 1, Songzhi Rd., Xinyi district, located in Taipei's busiest commercial district.

"The new CTOT represents a significant re-investment for Canada and demonstrates the value we place on Canada-Taiwan relations. Over the next year, as the CTOT celebrates 25 years in Taiwan, we will be announcing a number of new initiatives which will make Canada an even more attractive and convenient place to visit, work, study or to do business, " said CTOT Executive Director Scott Fraser.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA passes legislative floor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/10 23:26:38 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: After a marathon debate and a standoff between lawmakers of the ruling and opposition parties, the Legislative Yuan approved late Tuesday the controversial trade pact signed with China in June.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT), which controls an absolute majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan, prevailed over the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) by having the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) passed in the second reading.

Under the law governing the execution of the duty of the Legislative Yuan, bills like the ECFA and others regarding agreements with other countries require only two readings, rather than the three readings required for bills related to all other issues.

Lawmakers began the meeting of the special session at 9 a.m. with endless debates on each article of the ECFA before they were able to move to decide the fate of the China trade with a vote after 8 p.m.

The KMT said the ECFA, signed June 29, is aimed at further liberalizing cross- Taiwan Strait trade and sharpening Taiwan's competitiveness, while the DPP objects to the pact on the grounds that it might compromise Taiwan's sovereignty and make the country overly reliant on China economically.
The Legislature Yuan also approved a cross-strait agreement on the protection of intellectual property rights in the second reading.

After being endorsed by the legislature, the ECFA is expected to take effect on both sides of the strait in September, according to sources with Strait Exchange Foundation, the simi-official body responsible for negotiations with China in the absence of formal contact.
