DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 18, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 10:24:06 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 47.43 points at 7,978.52 on a turnover of NT$3.93 billion (US$122.81 million).
The weighted price index fell 10.13 points, or 0.12 percent, to close at 7,931.09 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Taiwan should make weapons on its own

TEXT.P: According to an annual report released Monday by the U.S. Department of Defense, the balance of cross-Taiwan Strait military forces continues to shift in China's favor despite closer economic and cultural exchanges.
Taiwan's "window of vulnerability" is tempting an invasion by the other side. If it were not for an "international gendarme, " China could take over Taiwan right now.
Taiwan has become a watershed in the fight for East Asian supremacy between the United States and China. China's seizure of Taiwan would symbolize U.S inability to protect Taiwan and East Asia.
Ironically, because of mutual economic dependence with China, the United States is not willing to sell advanced weapons to Taiwan and offend China, fearing economic retaliation from Beijing.
This is why the United States would rather adopt a psychological warfare posture of "strategic ambiguity, " in which the uncertainty over the U.S. response deters China from invading Taiwan.

With its technological strength, Taiwan should manufacture weapons such as submarines, cruise missiles and unmanned combat aerial vehicles on its own. Taiwan already has an excellent foundation for a defense industry, and the military should now share its defense technology with the private sector to produce weapons for its own defense needs. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 10:32:03 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$31.892 at 9:45 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.078 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- China's missile deployment and military buildup

TEXT.P: A new U.S. Pentagon report on China's military buildup indicated that the military imbalance between China and Taiwan is widening, threatening stability in the region.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

The U.S. Pentagon's just-released report on military and security developments involving China said that by December 2009, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) had deployed between 1,050 and 1,150 short-range ballistic missiles targeted at Taiwan.

However, local news media cited a Ministry of National Defense (MND) magazine report in July as estimating that the number of Chinese short-range missiles targeting Taiwan will reach 1,960 by the end of this year.

Asked about the difference, a defense ministry official said Tuesday the research report carried in an MND academic publication in July only reflected the author's personal projection, not an authentic intelligence report.

According to the MND's 2009 National Defense Report, the PLA had deployed about 1,300 various types of short-range missiles and cruise missiles by the end of 2009. "This estimate was roughly same as the Pentagon's figure," the MND official added.

He further said the MND was not surprised by the content of the newly released Pentagon report which concludes that despite President Ma Ying-jeou's efforts to increase economic and cultural ties, China's military buildup continues unabated.
According to the official, Taiwan was a major source of intelligence and a consultative partner in the U.S. study on China's military strength. (Aug. 18, 2010).
Liberty Times:

The Pentagon report released Monday said China is extending its military advantage over Taiwan and increasingly looking beyond, building up a force with the power to strike in Asia as far away as the U.S. territory of Guam.

Pointing out that Beijing is rapidly expanding its armed forces to "deter, delay or deny" any possible U.S. support for Taiwan in case of a conflict, the report said the balance of cross-strait military forces continues to shift in China's favor.

The report further said the PLA is upgrading the lethality of the force deployed against Taiwan, including by introducing variants of its CSS-6 and CSS-7 missiles with improved ranges, accuracies and payloads.
Responding to the U.S. report, MND spokesman Yu Sy-tue said Tuesday the government is fully aware that China has not given up its intention to use force against Taiwan.
"We are closely monitoring China's military developments and we ask the public to rest assured," Yu added. (Aug. 18, 2010).
China Times:

With its shipbuilding technology advancing swiftly and increasing assistance from abroad, China is likely to begin building its first aircraft carrier before the end of this year, far ahead of the 2016 timeline previously forecast by some U.S. experts, the Pentagon report said.

China is also expected to build several more aircraft carriers and auxiliary warships in the next 10 years, the report said, adding that some of China's aircraft carriers will be commissioned into service during the period.

According to the report, Brazil will assist China in training its pilots to fly warplanes aboard aircraft carriers. Moreover, it said, China intends to procure 50 Su-33 warplanes to be posted on aircraft carriers for an estimated US$2.5 billion. However, negotiations for the deal have stalled due to China's alleged copying of Su-27 jet fighters without Russia's consent, the report said. (Aug. 18, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Tax system as investment bellwether

TEXT.P: Among the tax reforms promoted by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, cutting gift and estate tax rates to 10 percent and the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent have drawn the most attention. Both policies are aimed at attracting foreign capital inflows.
Under Taiwan's consolidated income tax system, however, dividends are treated as part of an individual's taxable income, which can be taxed at rates of up to 40 percent.

Hong Kong and Singapore also have consolidated income tax systems, but they exempt dividends from income tax. The individual income tax rates are 20 percent in Singapore and 16.5 percent in Hong Kong. While Hong Kong does not impose an estate tax, a 10 percent estate tax rate is levied by both Taiwan and Singapore.
In the eyes of foreign investors, both Singapore and Hong Kong provide friendly tax systems. Taiwan needs to work harder to reform its tax system in order to catch the eyes of foreign investors.

Trade liberalization has stirred up a world war on tax competitiveness, a situation that Taiwan should not take lightly. Whether the tax system is a bellwether or a stumbling block only involves a change in the government's mindset. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's ranking drops to 39th in the 2010 Global Cities Index
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 11:55:48 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei fell to 39th in a global cities survey released by the U.S. magazine "Foreign Policy, " down from 34th in the previous poll conducted in 2008.
The 2010 Global Cities Index, which looks at 65 metropolises worldwide, was jointly compiled by Foreign Policy, management consulting firm A.T. Kearney and the Chicago Council on Global Affairs.
The survey measures how much sway a city has beyond its borders -- its influence and integration with global markets, culture, and innovation.
New York and London remained in the top two spots in the latest survey.
Of the top 10 cities, five are in Asia -- Tokyo (3rd), Hong Kong (5th), Singapore (8th), Sydney (9th) and Seoul (10th).
Only three U.S. cities made the top 10 list: New York (1st) , Chicago (6th) and Los Angeles (7th).
London (2nd) and Paris (4th) are the only two European cities on the top 10 list.
The survey said more people are moving from rural to urban areas and that global influence is shifting from the West to the East.
Beijing's ranking dropped from 12th to 15th, while Shanghai's ranking remained at 20th.
This year's survey of 68 cities was the second ever done. The survey in 2008 looked at 60 cities from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Who should be held responsible?
DOC.DATELINE: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) 08/18/10 12:39:40 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: must be held responsible for the controversies surrounding the environmental impact assessments (EIA) of the Central Taiwan Science Park's third and fourth- phase expansion projects.

As a member of the Cabinet, EPA minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen should have acted early on to provide the health risk assessments that were missing in the EIA for the projects, in the hope that the administrative court would rule in favor of the government. But Shen totally ignored judicial rulings, which eventually led the court to issue an injunction to suspend the projects.
Any Cabinet members who cause such major problems should resign to take responsibility. But Shen has been pointing his fingers at others.

When it comes to stirring public resentment, Public Construction Commission (PCC) Minister Fan Liang-shiow is as expert as Shen. Two months ago, the PCC's refusal to resort to the arbitration process to sort out public construction disputes led a group of contractors to take out advertisements in local newspapers to express their anger.

It is time for the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to seriously consider replacing those Cabinet members who regularly drag down the government's approval ratings. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 18, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Protesters blockade Formosa Plastics complex, cause traffic chaos
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 12:40:18 (By Yeh Tzu-kang, Huang Kuo-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Local residents continued their blockade of an access road to Formosa Plastic Group's (FPG) petrochemical complex in Yunlin County Wednesday morning, disrupting traffic, but they later dispersed after venting their anger.
Led by a resident self-help association, the protesters used their bodies and cars to block traffic, causing traffic jams stretching about three kilometers.

On Tuesday, angry residents blocked all three major roads leading to the complex, demanding that the conglomerate pay residents NT$1.8 billion (US$53 million) for polluting the area and harming their health. They also wanted Formosa Plastics to promise to relocate the complex later this decade.
The company said it is only willing to pay as much as NT$500 million.
On Wednesday morning, the association again mobilized local residents to cut off one of the three main roads.
With the blockade taking place during working hours, many workers at the complex complained that the protesters were infringing on their right to work.
Meanwhile, Formosa Plastics' management called on the protesters to respect its employees' right to work, and it began adopting flexible work schedules.
But the disruption did not affect the company's production line or supply chain, with only 30 of the 400 oil tankers that pass through the complex daily being obstructed, company executives said.
In the chaos, police used patrol vehicles to clear a lane for traffic.

At the same time, some protesters gathered on another road leading to the front gate of the complex, prompting police officers to form a human wall to prevent workers at the complex from being disturbed.
After venting their anger, the protesters dispersed at around 8: 20 a.m. but threatened to initiate another blockade of the three main access roads during work hours on Thursday.

Formosa Plastics called for rational and peaceful communications and stressed that the company would go no higher than the NT$500 million in overall compensation it has offered, which represented an increase from the original NT$450 million it proposed.

Residents have pressed Formosa Plastics for compensation after a major fire at one of the complex's oil refining plants broke out on July 25 and contaminated neighboring farms and fish farms. It was the second fire at the complex in three weeks.
Residents of Mailiao Township and other nearby villages accused the plant of having poor safety precautions and of neglecting the potential health risks to local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: MSCI adds 11 firms to Taiwan Index
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 13:15:56 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) said Tuesday it has added 11 Taiwanese companies to its MSCI Taiwan Index after its quarterly index review.
After the adjustments, the number of MSCI Taiwan Index constituents rose to 118 from the previous 107, while no stock that had been on the index before the review was removed.

The 11 new constituents include computer and electronic component maker Pegatron Corp., memory chip firm Powerchip Technology Corp., KGI Securities Co., solar cell maker Simplo Technology Co., electronic paper display producer E Ink Holdings, solar cell manufacturer Motek Industries Inc., and LCD display maker Coretronic Corp.

The others are module maker Phison Electronics Corp., IC designer PixArt Imaging Inc., online gaming provider Chinese Gamer International Corp. and contract microchip maker Vanguard International Semiconductor Co.
"The change went beyond market expectations, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
"The market had expected MSCI would add old economy stocks into the index as that sector will benefit from the signing of a major trade pact across the Taiwan Strait," Lin said.

Taiwan and China signed an economic cooperation framework agreement in late June, granting preferential tariff status or market access to a total of 539 Taiwanese products or services exported to China. Most of the items belong to the non-high tech sector.
"MSCI still paid a lot of attention to the local electronics sector, which is the backbone of Taiwan's exports," Lin said.

According to MSCI, information technology stocks account for 58.56 percent of the Taiwan index, followed by financials with a 15.70 percent share, materials with a 12.19 percent share, and telecommunications services with a 4.34 percent share.
Currently, the top five in the Taiwan index weighting are Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., HTC Corp., MediaTek Inc. and Cathay Financial Holdings Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC food security forum opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 14:20:16 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The first-ever food security forum of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) opened in Taipei Wednesday, hoping to develop an action plan by the end of the three-day meeting, Taiwan's top agriculture officials said.

The forum will launch a discussion on establishing a regional food security mechanism, a pressing issue in light of climate change, said Chen Wu-hsiung, the head of the Council of Agriculture (COA) , which organized the forum.
The initiative was submitted by Taiwan, which uses the name of Chinese Taipei in APEC, in the APEC Agricultural Technical Cooperation Working Group last year, Chen said.

APEC is a forum for 21 Pacific Rim Member Economies to cooperate on regional trade and investment liberalization and facilitation. According to the COA, 95 delegates from 20 economies are attending the three-day meeting that ends Aug. 20.
With respect to Taiwan's food security, Chen said the government is paying attention to the issue and has developed a complete strategic plan to tackle the problem.
The plan involves building safety stocks, combating climate change, improving agricultural production efficiency, and forging sustainable agricultural development, he said.

Taiwan has increased its annual stock of rice -- Taiwan's food staple -- from 300,000 tons to 430,000 tons, Chen said. Although Taiwan is only 30 percent self-sufficient in grains, the domestic supply of rice has been stable and most of Taiwan's food imports are grass crops.
The COA has been working on revitalizing fallow land and has successfully replanted 20,000 hectares of the 220,000 hectares of idle farmland in the country, according to Chen.
The ministry also plans to restructure the agricultural sector to focus more on producing field corn and lower-quality rice that can be grown quickly in large quantities in case of a food shortage.
"High-quality rice is already abundant in Taiwan," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll shows manufacturers satisfied with ECFA: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 14:20:26 (By Yang Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A government survey asking 3,000 manufacturers about a recently signed trade pact with China found that most respondents said the trade pact is more beneficial than harmful, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Wednesday.
The ministry is scheduled to release the results of the poll on Thursday, following the Legislative Yuan's approval of the controversial trade pact late Tuesday.

It was the first official poll to ask local businesses about the effects of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed on June 29. The poll, conducted in July, asked manufacturers about the trade pact's likely impact on their revenues, imports, exports and investments.

According to the official, the poll found that only industries focusing on domestic demand -- such as apparel, clothing accessories and food -- said they would be hurt by the ECFA, which is expected to take effect on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in September.
Under the ECFA's "early harvest" program, the tariffs on 539 Taiwanese goods and 267 Chinese products will be reduced to zero within two years after the pact takes effect.

Some manufacturers in petrochemicals, machine tools and automobile-related industries that were not included in the early harvest list said in the survey that the government should start the next round of trade negotiations with China as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Census to be conducted at year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 14:57:00 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) will conduct a decennial population and housing census from Dec. 26, 2010 to Jan. 22, 2011, the agency said Wednesday.
The census will be carried out based on registration data and sample surveys, with 1.3 million households and 4.5 million people polled, according to the agency.
DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei held a meeting attended by more than 100 officials Wednesday to discussion preparations for the census.

According to the Statistics Act, the DGBAS is responsible for conducting the census every 10 years. The 2010-2011 census will be the sixth population and housing census since the Republic of China government moved to Taiwan in 1949, the agency said. Censuses were conducted in 1956,1966, 1980, 1990 and 2000.
All local governments will set up task forces in September to visit households during the census period. An estimated 17,000 people are expected to take part in the work.

Facing increased costs and low interest in being interviewed among the general public, some countries, including Singapore and Germany, have adopted a combination of registration-based census and sample surveys, rather than attempting to account for every member of the public.

After taking census trends into account, the Executive Yuan approved a proposal earlier this month to adopt the alternative census approach based on population and household registration in combination with data from sample surveys, according to the DGBAS.
About 80 percent of the world's countries plan to conduct censuses by the end of this year, which are expected to cover 90 percent of world's population, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for viable policy to protect Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 15:12:20 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged President Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday to present a viable policy to protect Taiwan's security as the cross- Taiwan Strait military balance continues to tilt in China's favor.
DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said that the situation has raised international concerns over security in East Asia.

Although the United States has reaffirmed its commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act, which governs arms sales to Taiwan, Ma has not taken any action or spoken on China's military buildup and missile deployment targeting Taiwan, Tsai said.
Instead, Tsai said, the president is hoping unrealistically for the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) to bring about peace in the region.
"Peace should not be built on the sympathy of one's rival or on one's own wishful thinking," he said.

According to an annual report released Monday by the U.S. Department of Defense, China has continued to build up its military power. The report said that as of December 2009, the People's Liberation Army had deployed between 1,050 and 1,150 CSS-6 and CSS-7 short-range ballistic missiles to units opposite Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hoping to learn from Guangdong Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 15:20:37 (By H. C. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Wednesday he hopes his city can learn from 2010 Asian Games host Guangzhou as it prepares to mount its own bid to hold the continent's most important sporting competition in 2019.

Wishing the best of luck to Guangzhou's visiting Mayor Wan Qingliang in hosting the Asian Games in November, Hau said both cities will be holding major international events late this year that could serve as benchmarks for each other.

"As Taipei will also host the Taipei International Flora Exposition starting in November, we hope the two cities can emulate each other to pursue greater perfection, " Hau said when addressing an Asian Games presentation led by Wan, who is visiting Taiwan as part of a 1,000-person delegation from Guangdong Province.
Guangzhou will host the 16th Asian Games and 19th Asian Para Games Nov. 12-27, while Taipei will hold the Flora Expo from Nov. 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011.
"We hope to get the benefit of some of Guangzhou's experience so that we can win the hosting rights, " Hau said.
Hau said more than 10 cities have expressed an interest in hosting the 2019 Games. They include Dubai, Hong Kong, Singapore, Manila, and Kuala Lumpur.

The winner of the bid is expected to be announced in April 2011. Taiwan has never hosted the Asian Games, though Kaohsiung came close to winning the right to host the 2002 Games before being defeated by Busan, South Korea, because of pressure against the bid from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close little changed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 15:48:00 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Wednesday after profit-taking emerged, focusing on textile, food and transport stocks, to reverse early gains on Wall Street's recovery overnight, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 6.99 points or 0.08 percent to 7,924.10, after moving between 7,897.18 and 7,983.76, on turnover of NT$134.55 billion (US$4.21 billion).

The market opened up 0.60 percent after Wall Street staged a one percent rebound overnight, and moved to the day's high before investors locked in recent gains -- especially in the old economy sector -- amid hopes that the local economy would benefit from increasing cross-strait business, dealers said.
A total of 2,204 stocks closed down and 1,495 up, with 363 remaining unchanged.
The textile sector suffered the heaviest losses, down 1.2 percent. Foodstuffs fell 1.0 percent, financial stocks lost 0.8 percent and cement stocks dropped 0.1 percent.
The construction sector rose 2.0 percent and the paper and pulp sector gained 0.4 percent, while plastics and chemical shares and machinery and electronics stocks added 0.1 percent.

"Technical resistance ahead of the key 8,000 point level remained strong, " Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said. "Many investors appeared unwilling to chase prices and push up share prices at the moment."

Huang said that while Narayana Kocherlakota, head of the U.S. Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, called fears about recent cautious comments by the Fed "unwarranted" on Tuesday, his words failed fo lend much support to the local bourse, although U.S. markets rebounded.
"There is so much conflicting information about the economic climate, " Huang said. "It's hard for investors to paint a clear picture of it."
Huang said a weaker high-tech sector was evidence that worries over global demand in the second half of this year still weighed on the market.
"I expect the local market will continue to trade in a narrow range. Further consolidation is needed before the index holds itself well above 8,000 points," Huang said.
In the textile sector, Far Eastern New Century fell 2.25 percent to NT$39.05 and Carnival Industrial shed 2.87 percent to NT$11.85.
Among shipping stocks, Evergreen Marine lost 5.37 percent to close at NT$22.90 and Yang Ming Marine fell 5.87 percent to NT$20.85.

However, the construction sector bucked the downturn on hopes that inflow from Chinese funds will boost commercial property prices, with Cathay Real Estate up 6.83 percent to NT$15.65 and Goldsun Development up 1.94 percent at NT$15.80.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official to visit Taiwan over airworthiness certification
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 16:46:03 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese civil aviation delegation will arrive in Taiwan late this month to attend a seminar on issues regarding the certification of aircraft airworthiness, an official said Wednesday.
The delegation will be headed by Li Jian, deputy director of the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China, said the official from Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).

At the behest of the CAA, the Taipei Airlines Association has joined China's Cross-Strait Aviation Transport Exchange Council in organizing the seminar on aircraft airworthiness issues, which, in the case of Taiwan and China, have proven difficult because of sovereignty disputes.

As aircraft are seen as an extension of national territory, countries that maintain aviation agreements tend to mutually authorize their licensed aircraft maintenance engineers to inspect aircraft from the other country and certify their airworthiness.

Taiwan and China, however, have avoided touching on aircraft airworthiness issues since they forged direct air links roughly two years ago because such themes involve sensitive statehood recognition issues.

The mutual certification of spare parts, maintenance engineers and maintenance facilities has proven thorny because the relevant certificates bear national titles and the issuance of such certificates involve the exercise of public authority.

That has led to inconvenience for carriers from the two sides and increased their operating costs because they have to stock spare parts and components on each cross-strait flight to meet contingencies.

Most Chinese carriers have posted licensed aircraft maintenance engineers at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, while Taiwanese carriers tend to station maintenance personnel at the Beijing and Shanghai airports to conduct airworthiness inspections.
They also have to assign licensed maintenance engineers on each flight to less frequently served destinations to inspect and maintain the aircraft upon arrival.
Although the Taiwanese and Chinese officials have met many times to discuss flight increase issues, they have never touched on airworthiness topics because of the sensitivity of the issue.
The CAA official said the upcoming seminar will mainly provide a forum for both sides to express their opinions and views on relevant issues.

"The forum will not be an occasion for negotiating airworthiness issues, " the official said, adding that the CAA hopes to know more about China's opinions and stances to pave the way for future talks.

According to airline sources, China once suggested that the Taipei Airlines Association and the Beijing-based Cross-Strait Aviation Transport Exchange Council be authorized to issue certificates of airworthiness. However, Taiwan has so far not yet accepted such a proposal.

The CAA reportedly has informed the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Office (MAC) of Beijing's proposal. The country's top China policy planning body has not yet make any response to the suggestion, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 16:46:16 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.004 to close at NT$31.966.
Turnover totaled US$625 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.970 and moved to a low of NT$31.750 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT Kaohsiung mayoral candidate to visit Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 17:24:09 (by Wang Shu-fen and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang's (KMT's) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao-shun will travel to Singapore at the end of August to learn from the city state's development experience, her economic consultant Ma Kai said Wednesday.
Huang, accompanied by a group of specialists, will visit places such as Singapore's airport and harbors to study the country's economic development and infrastructure, Ma said.

The delegation, composed of professionals from various fields, envisions the same type of prosperity and success for Kaohsiung as Singapore has had, said one of the members, Hu Nien-tsu, director of the Center for Marine Policy Studies at National Sun Yat-sen University.
As part of the plan, a special trade and investment district will be set up in Kaohsiung City to attract foreign investment, Hu said.
Among the 90,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Kaohsiung, 10,000 of the best ones will receive government assistance to improve their management capabilities, he said.
In addition, a "Business Incubation Center" will be established to encourage young people to start their own business or to find work in the city, he said.

Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, who is running as an independent for mayor of the greater Kaohsiung municipality, has also announced plans to travel to Singapore, saying he will go in September.
However, incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, the DPP's candidate in that municipality, said she has no such plans and that Kaohsiung has its own characteristics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan market to be rosy after ECFA: Hong Kong fund manager
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 17:36:57 (By Stanley Cheung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A mutual fund company in Hong Kong Wednesday recommended investors buy Taiwanese funds to capitalize on Taiwan's growth potential after the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) takes effect.

In an article published in the Wen Wei Po daily, Pegasus Fund Managers suggested that investors put out their feelers by buying into Taiwan funds. If there is further progress in Taiwan's effort to sign free trade agreement (FTAs) with other countries, investors can increase their purchases for long-term investment, the company said.
It predicted that the passage of the ECFA by Taiwan's Legislative Yuan will boost the chance for the stock index to challenge the 9,000-point mark by the end of this year.

The company also pointed out that experts from Taiwan and China will meet in the city of Guilin in China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in early September to discuss post-ECFA economic ties and likely raise the issue of Taiwan's FTA bids.
The company noted that Taiwan opened its door to Chinese tourists before the conclusion of the ECFA.
In the first half of this year, the daily arrivals of Chinese tourists averaged 3,440, more than double the same period last year, when the average arrivals were 1,661, the company said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU to launch new ECFA referendum: chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 18:06:57 (By Sophia Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei said Wednesday that the party has decided to push for a national referendum on a controversial trade pact with China for a third time.

During a luncheon with pro-independence groups, Huang contended that the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) ratified by the Legislative Yuan late Tuesday will mostly benefit a few businesses at the expense of the majority of Taiwan's people.
He also predicted that the existing ban on certain Chinese agricultural products and all Chinese workers will soon be lifted, which he said would have a negative impact on local citizens.
The government has adamantly denied that it would ease the twin bans as it liberalizes trade with China.

Huang complained that although the people have a constitutional right to hold referendums, the Executive Yuan's Referendum Review Committee has twice rejected the TSU's ECFA referendum initiative on technical grounds.
The party will initiate a new referendum to disband the committee and also start collecting signatures for a third ECFA referendum proposal, the TSU chairman said.

"We want to know to what extent the government will ignore public opinion," Huang said. "Referendums are the last line of defense for Taiwan's democracy. We will file ECFA proposals as often as they are rejected."
The third referendum proposal would still ask "Do you agree with the government's plan to sign a 'Cross-Strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement' with China?" the TSU chairman said.

Former Vice President Annette Lu, who was also present at the luncheon, accused the ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislative Yuan of rushing the bill through, saying that after the trade pact goes into effect, it could have many adverse political, economic, diplomatic and military effects.
Lu also said there was an immediate need to guide the public on ways to respond and adapt to the new ECFA era and formulate measures to deal with the deal's consequences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan entrepreneur calls for Asia-Pacific food safety mechanism
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 19:09:30 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Amid talks among Asia-Pacific economies of establishing a regional food security mechanism, a Taiwanese businessman with operations in China said Wednesday that the problem of food safety in the Chinese market was worse than that of food security.
Food stock in China is enough to meet demand, said Mark Han, chairman and executive director of DaChan Food (Asia) Ltd., which operates on both sides across Taiwan Strait.

Food safety issues, however, put the health of consumers in jeopardy, Han told reporters at the first food security forum of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) , which opened in Taipei earlier Wednesday.
The three-day forum aims to establish a regional security mechanism to protect against possible food shortages worldwide due to global climate change.

Han said that the problem of food security -- concerning the safe stock of food staples in a nation -- is not urgent in the region compared with that of food safety, and suggested regional economies actively make efforts to build a food traceability system on the APEC platform.
Taiwan's Minister of Agriculture Chen Wu-hsiung praised the idea of a system to ensure food safety in the Asia-Pacific region.
"But it's easier said than done," Chen said.
Taking Taiwan as an example, Chen said that after years of efforts the island still lags behind in traceability and certification of organic products.
Even in Japan, a developed country with modern agriculture, only 1 percent of its cropland is certified as organic, Chen said.
According to the Council of Agriculture, which organized the forum, 95 delegates from 20 economies are attending the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Delta Electronics in talks on projector sales for Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 19:24:08 (By Hang Ting-ting, Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Delta Electronics, Inc. said Wednesday it is in talks with potential buyers on the use of its projectors at the upcoming Asian Games in China.

"Delta is capable of developing and producing high definition projectors," said Delta's deputy spokesman Jesse Chou. "Such high-end projectors are very suitable for major sports events like the Asian Games."
"They (the potential buyers) are very interested in Delta's projectors," he said, but he declined to disclose any further details of the negotiations.
The Asian Games will be held in November in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province.

Earlier this year, Delta sold 500 HD projectors to Shanghai for display at the 2010 World Expo and has also shipped more than 1,000 units to some smaller Chinese cities, cashing in on China's policy of promoting home appliances in its rural areas.
Delta launched the world's first 95-inch short throw projector in May. Its new 3D technology was used in the broadcasts of the World Cup in July.
Earlier Wednesday, Guangdong Provincial Governor Huang Huahua led a delegation on a visit to Delta where they were given a demonstration of the company's high tech products, including HD projectors.
In a statement, the company said Huang highly praised Delta's technology and innovation and was impressed by the company's efforts to develop green energy technology.
On Tuesday, Delta and the city of Dongguan in Guangdong Province signed a letter of intent with a focus on a possible order for the company's LED lighting products.
At the signing ceremony, Delta said it will continue its efforts in Dongguan to develop LED lighting and related green energy products.
Delta currently operates seven plants and one research and development center in Dongguan, 18 years after it first established a a foothold in the Chinese city.
During his visit to Delta, Huang said his province will allocate 10 billion Chinese yuan (US$1.47 billion) for the development of the green energy sector over the next five years.
Market analysts said Taiwanese solar energy firms, which have listed China as the top destination of their exports, are expected to benefit from the green energy project in Dongguan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- When will 12-year free education be implemented?
DOC.DATELINE: The Ministry of Education (MOE) 08/18/10 19:55:48 (CommonWealth Parenting 15)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: has changed its chief 10 times since 1983 when it first proposed extending compulsory education from nine years to 12 years, but the plan is still on the drawing board.

As this is one of the 10 main topics to be discussed at the eighth National Education Conference Aug. 28-29, everyone is looking to see whether the government will unveil a timeline for implementing the proposal.

MOE statistics show that 96 percent of students who complete junior high school go on to senior high school or vocational school. However, the 12-year compulsory system is more about making public education free and getting rid of entrance exams.
The current compulsory education system, which has been in place since 1968, covers six years of elementary school and three years of junior high school.

For the government, implementing a 12-year system would mean additional budget allocations of tens of billions dollars per year and the amendment of laws -- neither of which are within the MOE's purview.

But the main obstacles to 12-year compulsory education are a lack of political will, the uneven quality of high schools, the level of preparedness of junior high school teachers to make the change, and an obsession among parents with top senior high schools.

"Ideally, what all parents want from a 12-year compulsory education system is for their children to enter top senior high schools which is impossible, " said Chou Yu-wen, a professor at National Taiwan Normal University's Education Department. One solution would be to improve the quality of senior high schools in general so that there is less focus on rankings that are based on acceptance scores and public opinion.

Another challenge is changing the teaching focus in junior high school from preparing students for senior high school entrance exams to guiding the development of teenagers. This aspect is not included in the MOE's pilot project for 12-year compulsory education.

In its efforts to move toward a 12-year system, the government over the last 10 years has been pushing the idea of a mechanism, other than a single decisive exam, to move students from junior to senior high school.

Currently, students either apply or are assigned to a senior high school in their area based mainly on the results of one of the two academic achievement tests that they take at the end of the ninth grade.

But last year, another method was introduced. Students were assessed on the basis of their overall performance during their three years in junior high school. Nine percent of students at that level gained entry to senior high school based on this assessment.

Chang Ming-wen, head of the MOE's Department of Secondary Education, said an estimated 60 percent of students nowadays choose schools near their homes instead of the so-called top schools. This indicates a change in societal values, which is necessary for the 12-year plan to progress, she said.

While 12-year compulsory education would not solve all the problems in Taiwan's education system, it would help take the exam pressure off teenagers in junior high school and give them a better chance at mature and independent development. It would also pave the way for further improvement of the education system.

DOC.HEADLINE: More money wired back from overseas accounts of ex-president's family

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors' Office said Wednesday that it has received an additional US$1.88 million (NT$59.97 million) from overseas accounts held by former President Chen Shui-bian's family members.

So far, US$10.4 million out of a total of US$21 million kept by Chen's family members in Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. and the Royal Bank of Scotland has been wired to Taiwan bank accounts designated by the SID.
The money in the Swiss bank accounts, which has been frozen since 2007, was held by the ex-president's son and daughter-in law -- Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui- chiang.

Apart from funds from the Swiss banks, US$7.98 million, the sum from sales of 54 bonds kept by the Chen family, was also wired back to the SID accounts, putting the total sum at about US$18.4 million.

In addition to the US$21 billion frozen in the two banks, the former first family in June 2007 also transferred to a Swiss bank NT$570 million (US$17.67 million) of the NT$740 million it had in a Cathay United Bank vault.
Prosecutors have said all the money stashed by Chen's family overseas was illegally acquired and should be confiscated.

The former president and his wife Wu Shu-chen were both sentenced to life in prison and fines of NT$200 million and NT$300 million respectively in September last year on charges of taking bribes, money laundering and forgery.

Chen and Wu appealed and had their jail sentences reduced to 20 years and fines cut to NT$170 million and NT$200 million respectively on June 11. Both prosecutors and the couple appealed the new sentences to the higher court. (By Lin Chang-shun and & Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China merchandise trade talks set for March: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:23:08 (Lin Shu-yuan, Huang Chi-kuan and Y.L. Kao )

TEXT.P: Taiwan will seek inclusion of 5,824 industrial products on a list for tariff reductions during talks with China on trade in merchandise that are scheduled to start in March 2011, an economic official said Wednesday.

The Legislative Yuan approved late Tuesday the controversial economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan signed with China in June, and was scheduled to handle relevant amendments to customs regulations late Wednesday.
After being endorsed by the legislature, the ECFA is expected to take effect on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in September, the official said.

The two sides will then initiate negotiations on investment agreements and are expected to start further talks on agreements involving trade in products, trade in services, and the establishment of a dispute resolution mechanism by the end of March, as stipulated in the ECFA, the official added.

After the amendments clear the legislature, commodity trade negotiations between Taiwan and China will focus on certain types of products that are given eight- digit numeric codes by the Directorate General of Customs, he said.
These include petrochemical and machinery tools items, as well as automobiles and flat panel display products.

There are 8,726 items with the eight-digit codes. Of them, 2,902 items are set to enjoy tariff exemptions under the ECFA's terms from Jan. 1, 2011, leaving 5,824 such products for the next talks, the official explained.

According to customs data, Taiwan's total exports to China of the 539 early harvest items amounted to US$13.84 billion in 2009, representing 16.1 percent of Taiwan's total cross-strait exports by value.

Meanwhile, China's total exports to Taiwan of the 267 early harvest items on China's list amounted to US$2.86 billion in 2009, representing 10.5 percent of the mainland's total cross-strait exports by value.

For China's part, Tang Wei, head of China's Ministry of Commerce's Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau, said Wednesday that China has completed the ratification process of the ECFA and is awaiting written notification from Taiwan.

According to Article 15 of the ECFA, following the agreement's signing, the two sides should notify each other with written documents after completing relevant legal procedures. The pact will come into effect the day after both sides receive the documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chunghwa Telecom to broadcast World Grand Prix volleyball games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:23:50 (By Chang Liang-chi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan's largest telecommunications operator, will broadcast the Taipei round of the 2010 FIVB World Grand Prix women's volleyball competition from Aug. 20-22 on its multimedia-on-demand (MOD) platform, the company announced Wednesday.
The FIVB, a Swiss-based international volleyball federation, has held the tournament since 1993.
It is Taiwan's third time joining the event since 1994. It also appeared in 2007, and placed 12th in both competitions.

Underlining its support for the sport, Chunghwa Telecom said it will broadcast the Taipei matches on the MOD, HiChannel and emome platforms, allowing subscribers to view the competitions on television, the Internet and mobile phones.

The Taipei round will be played by 2009 champion Brazil, Taiwan, Puerto Rico and 2009 European Championship bronze medalist Poland at the National Taiwan University Sports Center, with Taiwan scheduled to meet Poland on Aug. 20, Brazil on Aug. 21, and Puerto Rico, ranked 14th in the world, on Aug. 22.

The World Grand Prix is an annual women's volleyball competition of 12 teams -- four each from America, Europe and Asia. It consists of two phases, including a preliminary round with a system of rotating host cities and one or more final rounds with one or more host nations.

In this year's event, the preliminary round -- starting Aug. 6 in Brazil, Poland and Chengdu, China -- spans three weeks, with the top six teams qualifying for the final round from Aug. 25-29 in Ningbo, China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei art fair expected to draw record number of foreign exhibitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei August 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:30:01 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A record number of international exhibitors will participate in an art fair that will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center this month, the organizers said Wednesday.
Compared to last year when Art Taipei attracted 43 foreign exhibitors, this year more than half of the 100 exhibitors will be from abroad, the Taiwan Art Gallery Association said.

"In addition to the 53 overseas galleries that will be represented at the exhibition, we have, for the first time, invited about 60 international collectors to visit Taiwan for the fair," said vice chairman of the association Richard Chang.

One of the highlights of the fair will be the exhibition of internationally famous pieces such as Cai Guo-Qiang's gunpowder on paper work titled "Flora" and valued at US$800,000, the association said.
Zao Wou-Ki's watercolor painting "Sans Title", valued at 80,000 euros will also be on display, it said.
The exhibition will be divided into six sections -- Art Galleries, Mega Contemporary, Ela-Video, Art Taipei PHOTO, Made in Taiwan--Young Artist Discovery and Art Media.
Art Taipei PHOTO is a new section that will display contemporary works by Taiwanese photographers, said Joanne Chen, marketing director of the association.

It will include the work of award-winning artists such as Shen Chao-liang whose piece "Stage" will be on display, and the work of the winners and finalists of the 2010 Sony World Photography Award, she said.

In the video art section, award-winning curator Antoanetta Ivanova of Australia has been invited to serve as guest curator and will present digital and moving image artworks created by Australian artists.

"Art Taipei has built a good reputation in Asia, and we expect to stage a high quality show that would allow the many galleries and collectors to gain a better understanding of the development of art in Taiwan," Chang said.
Last year, sales at the fair amounted to NT$460 million, which was good considering there was a recession, Chang said.

The fair is being organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Taiwan Art Gallery Association and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and will be held August 20-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grandparents Day to be observed from 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:32:14 (By Lin Su-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education announced Wednesday that starting this year National Grandparents Day will be celebrated on the fourth Sunday of August to honor grandparents.

The designation of Grandparents Day, which falls on Aug. 29 this year, is also aimed at strengthening relationships between young and older generations to facilitate integration of traditional and modern cultures and promote intimacy among family members, the ministry said.

According to ministry officials, many countries around the world have long celebrated a national grandparents day to encourage family reunions and better care for senior people. For instance, Grandparents Day is observed on the first Sunday of September in the United States, on the fourth Sunday of November in Singapore, the last Sunday of October in Russia and on July 26 in Portugal.

Officials said the last Sunday of August was chosen with the hope that grandparents will observe the day together with their children and grandchildren before schools reopen in September after summer vacation.
As a publicity campaign to raise public awareness of the day, family education centers in various cities and counties around the country will sponsor summer camps for grandparents and grandchildren.

Meanwhile, the results of a survey on transgenerational interaction or relationships released Wednesday showed that 80 percent of grandparents interviewed could easily list the names of each of their grandchildren.
In contrast, only 36.7 percent of grandchildren responding to the poll could list the names of their grandparents, and 10.3 percent said they were totally unaware of their grandparents' names.
In Chinese culture, grandparents often call their grandchildren by their names, while grandchildren use terms for "grandmother" or "grandfather" when addressing or referring to their grandparents.

The poll also found that 40 percent of grandparents surveyed clearly remember their grandchildren's birthdays, but that only 5.8 percent of grandchildren remember all their grandparents' birthdays. Equally disappointing was that more than 60 percent of grandchildren did not know any of their grandparents' birthdays, the ministry said.

Although the poll results showed that 50 percent of the families surveyed have three generations living together, nearly 20 percent of grandchildren from those families have never vacationed with their grandparents.
According to the survey, grandparents most like their grandchildren to teach them how to use computers and cell phones and to help them stay healthy.
Similarly, the top things grandchildren said they wanted to teach their grandparents were how to live healthily, avoid fraud and use computers and cell phones.
The ministry commissioned National Chungcheng University to conduct the survey between mid-June and the first half of August. The university collected 3,857 valid samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team maintains perfect record at Junior League World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:35:04 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A team from Taiwan defeated Canada 10-0 at the 2010 Junior League Baseball World Series Tuesday in the U.S., virtually clinching a spot in the tournament's international championship game.
The victory, shortened to five innings because Taiwan was leading by 10 runs, improved the record of the Chung-Ching Junior Little League team from Taipei to 3-0 in the five-team international pool.

The club had already defeated teams from Guatemala (7-2) and Ukraine (13-0) in its first two games in round robin play and will face a team from Mexico on Aug. 20 Taiwan time to clinch first place in the international division.

The top two teams in the international pool after round-robin play will vie for the international championship on Aug. 21 Taiwan time, and the winner will play the U.S. champion a day later for the World Series title.

The Junior League World Series is the "older brother" of the Little League World Series played in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, featuring 13- and 14-year-old players rather than the 11- and 12-year-olds who play Little League.
Asia-Pacific teams have only been participating in the Junior League World Series since 1999, and no Asian team has ever won the tournament.

The Taipei club had to defeat teams from the Philippines, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Guam and Saipan to win the Asia-Pacific Regional Tournament and earn a spot in the World Series, being played in Taylor, Michigan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma expects Taiwan to become a regional trade hub after ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 20:50:20 (By Han Ting-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that Taiwan will quickly become an economic and trade hub in the Asia Pacific region after a trade pact with China takes effect.
Ma said that the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) has led many countries to reevaluate their investments in Taiwan and that most plan to increase their investments.

"With the Industrial Innovation Act, Taiwan is more likely to become a global innovation center, and likewise, with the ECFA and its supplementary measures, Taiwan will also become an economic and trade hub in the Asia Pacific region, " Ma said while addressing an innovation award ceremony following the Legislative Yuan's approval of the controversial trade pact late Tuesday.
After the regional hub is formed, Ma said more Taiwanese and foreign enterprises will be willing to set up their regional headquarters in Taiwan.

At the 2010 Lite-On Award ceremony, Ma also encouraged local companies to continue to enhance their innovation and R&D, with the aim of raising the country's R&D investment by 8 percent-10 percent by 2011 and make R&D represent 3 percent of the country's GDP in two years.
Ma said he hopes Taiwan will become a "country of innovation" instead of just specializing in original equipment manufacturing (OEM).
"It is good to see that Taiwanese companies are gradually transforming themselves from followers to pioneers," he said.
He also said that the government is planning to launch a major cross- disciplinary award for innovation talent next year as one of the events to celebrate the country's centenary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public to decide ECFA's fate if DPP returns to power: Tsai
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 21:01:23 (By Wen Kui-hsiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Wednesday that her party will let the people decide the fate of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) if the DPP were to return to power.

"It's regrettable and worrisome that the Legislative Yuan has failed to seriously screen the China pact and as a result, Taiwan's democracy has been greatly undermined, " Tsai said in comments on the legislature's passage of the pact a day earlier.

Calling the ECFA part of "an export-oriented economic development policy, " Tsai said it may benefit certain sectors and sustain Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) growth, but would certainly fail to create job opportunities or narrow the gap between the urban and rural areas.

Tsai cited Taiwan's sixth naphtha cracker operated by the Formosa Plastics Group in central Taiwan's Yunlin County as an example, saying it had fallen short of creating sufficient jobs for local residents.
She said the ECFA is "a result of faulty thinking" by President Ma Ying-jeou's administration as it resorts to lower Chinese tariffs as the only means of sharpening Taiwan's competitiveness.

China, which is full of uncertainty politically and economically, is free to raise or lower its tariffs for imports from Taiwan at any time, Tsai said, and "it would be quite risky to put Taiwan's development chances in the hands of China."
Tsai said that the DPP would not rule out the possibility of holding a referendum to decide whether to abolish the ECFA if the party returns to power.
The DPP was Taiwan's ruling party between 2000 and 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Calorie count absent from most fast food menus in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 21:12:23 (By Chen Hung-chin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Only one of the four largest fast food chains in Taipei City provides calorie information on their menus, the city's government said Wednesday.
According to the Department of Health under the Taipei City government, only McDonald's displays calorie amounts on its menus, despite the department advising the chains to do so in June.

The other three -- Kentucky Fried Chicken, Burger King, and Mos Burger -- did not reveal calorie counts on their menus, the health department said after conducting a surprise inspection earlier Wednesday.

Although there is no law requiring food chains to display calories, the department will continue to promote the campaign and monitor the chains, said Chiang Yu-mei, a senior technical specialist with the city's health department.
Chiang said that all fast food chains promised to take corrective actions, with KFC agreeing to print calorie counts from October.

However, Chiang said all four fast food chains have followed the department's advice to provide nutritional information near the counters in their stores and on their websites, and to promote the benefits of eating vegetables.
If the fast food chains do not improve their calorie labeling, the department will post their names regularly, the official said.
The department also said that it plans to advise calorie labeling for the city's bakeries and breakfast shops.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA gives Kaohsiung chance to become regional hub: magistrate
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 21:20:14 (by Chen Shuo-kuo, Tang Pei-chun and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The recently-signed ECFA provides Kaohsiung with an opportunity to become a new regional hub for research and development (R&D) , Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Wednesday in a county council meeting.
For example, Yang said, a Japanese factory agreed Tuesday to set up its R&D center in Kaohsiung County because it would enjoy tariff concessions on products exported from Taiwan to China.
Given the chance, Yang said, he would invite Foxconn Technology Group to invest in Kaohsiung and thus help move the area toward growth and expansion.
Kaohsiung's economy has been slow for the last 10 years, Yang said, adding that his mission is to turn the tide.

Kaohsiung, with its large hinterland, is capable of catching up, if not surpassing, Singapore in terms of international status, he said in an interview published by the Lianhe Zaobao (United Morning News) of Singapore on the same day.

But without the cross-strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), Taiwan would find it difficult to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries and would thus become marginalized, he said.
"Taiwan will then turn into the Philippines instead of Singapore," he said.
He said he supported the ECFA on condition that Taiwan does not open its market wider to agricultural products from China and does not allow Chinese laborers to enter the job market.
"Small countries must be wise in dealing with large countries, " Yang said.
He criticized the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as not dealing with the China issue in a pragmatic manner.
Yang recently quit the DPP to run as an independent in the election for mayor of the greater Kaohsiung municipality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan IC production value to rise 7.89 percent in Q3: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 21:29:29 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Production value of Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) sector for the third quarter is expected to rise 7.89 percent from the second quarter as global demand remains strong, a report from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

The strong demand is anticipated as the third quarter is the peak season for the global high-tech industry, according to the report released by Industry & Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) , a research unit of the MOEA's Department of Industrial Technology.
The ITIS said the local IC sector's production value for the third quarter is expected to hit NT$477.1 billion (US$14.96 billion), compared with NT$442.2 billion recorded in the second quarter.

In the second quarter, production value of the local IC sector rose 12.8 percent from the previous quarter. The ITIS said the slower growth in the third quarter reflects the high comparison base in the second quarter.
The ITIS added that a shortage of production capacity in the sector will also limit growth in the third quarter.
The report said the insufficient production capacity has prompted several IC heavyweights to raise their capacity expenditure for 2010.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the world's largest contract chipmaker, has hiked its capacity expenditure to US$5.9 billion from the previously planned US$4.8 billion, while United Microelectronics Corp. has raised its planned spending to US$1.8 billion from US$1.2 billion-1.5 billion.

During the same three-month period, production value of the IC design segment is expected to reach NT$137.5 billion, up 15 percent from the previous quarter on the back of demand for PCs, notebook computers, LCD TVs and cell phones, the ITIS said.

Production value of the IC manufacturing segment for the third quarter is expected to rise 5.2 percent to NT$229 billion, production value of the IC packaging segment may grow 5 percent to NT$76.1 billion and production value of the IC testing segment is likely to add 6.2 percent to reach NT$34.5 percent.

In the second quarter, production value of the IC manufacturing segment rose 15.4 percent from the first quarter to NT$217.6 billion, and production value of the IC packaging segment gained 13.3 percent to NT$72.5 billion.
Production value of the IC testing segment in the second quarter added 14 percent to NT$32.5 billion, and production value of the IC design segment grew 7.7 percent to reach NT$119.6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA implementation date not yet decided: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 21:36:13 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have not yet decided when an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed on June 29 will go into effect, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

The SEF, Taiwan's intermediary agency for handling cross-strait exchange affairs, said it was waiting for instruction from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) before completing the final step ahead of the pact's implementation -- officially informing its Chinese counterpart of Taiwan's completing the legislation for the agreement.
The notice will include a date proposed by Taiwan to put the ECFA into effect, the SEF said.

MAC is Taiwan's top authority responsible for mainland affairs. Unlike 12 other agreements Taiwan has signed with China to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation and interactions since 2008, the ECFA is subject to the legislature's ratification in Taiwan.
On Tuesday, the ruling party-controlled Legislative Yuan approved the accord.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial property in Taipei fetches record price
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 22:00:26 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: An office space in the Taipei Financial Center was sold in an auction Wednesday at a record price of NT$955,000 per ping (3.3 square meters) of the Dunbei Business District in Taipei City, the auctioneers reported.

The space, located on different floors of the building, totaled 1,905 pings and was sold to a funeral service called Lung Yen Life Service Co. at the bid price of NT$1.82 billion (US$56.86 million), said the auction house Savills Taiwan.
The winning bid was 46.5 percent above the ask price, Savills Taiwan said in a statement.
Savills Taiwan General Manager Gordon Kao said the price did not go higher because the buyer can only own part of the building.
"This auction failed to attract many bidders because some investors like to buy an entire building, but this building has several owners," he told reporters.

However, if the parking space is excluded from the auctioned office space, the price per ping reached NT$1.166 million, the second highest bidding price this year after NT$1.3 million per ping set by Taiwan's A-Data Technology Co. in buying the President Enterprise Corporation Tower in the Xinyi Planning District, Kao said.
Nevertheless, it was a "pretty good price," he said, noting that the building is new and is a 10-minute drive from Taipei Songshan Airport.

The deal came amid growing interest among foreign investors in Taiwan's commercial properties as they seek to capitalize on the business opportunities that are expected to result from the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that was signed between Taiwan and China in June.

Experts said that these investors are also anticipating opportunities in the tourism sector that would arise if Chinese tourists are allowed to make individual visits to Taiwan instead of in tour groups only.
Billy Yen, general manager of the real estate company DTZ, said 2010 marks a beginning for Taiwan's commercial properties because of the ECFA.
At a press conference Tuesday, Yen said that in the fourth quarter of the year DTZ will hold open bids for 41 urban properties in Taiwan that will have a total value of NT$30 billion.
That figure is higher than the combined value of the 136 public bids held by DTZ in Taiwan over the past 10 years, he said.
So far, insurance companies are showing the strongest interest in buying commercial properties, and some want to use the space as headquarters, he said.
The price of some commercial properties in Taipei jumped 27 to 31 percent in the first half of the year, Ko Hung-an, deputy head of Sinyi Global Asset Management Inc., told reporters recently.

Nevertheless, an increasing number of investors from Europe and Asia have been visiting Taiwan recently to look for properties, according to Tony Chao, the Taiwan managing director of the international real-estate company Jones Lang LaSalle.
"I have been working in Taiwan for more than 20 years and I had never seen a developer from Hong Kong or Singapore, but there have been some in recent weeks," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic talks to continue in ECFA's wake: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 22:34:33 (By Tien Yu-pin, Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue negotiations with China on further economic cooperation and at the same time seek to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, the minister of economic affairs said Wednesday.
Shih Yen-shiang said the two matters will proceed on parallel tracks after Taiwan's economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China takes effect.
Singapore has agreed to begin talks with Taiwan on the feasibility of an economic cooperation agreement and Taiwan will also be looking at Japan and South Korea, he said.
"It will not be long" before the talks with Singapore begin, Shih said.

Forging economic cooperation links with Taiwan's trading partners is one the major policies of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration, which has said this is key to preventing Taiwan's marginalization in the international market.
Shih said that when the ECFA goes into effect, Taiwan will set up a committee to handle economic cooperation affairs between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and China will do the same.
However, the two sides have not yet held any formal discussions on how to set up the committees, although they have talked about it on informal occasions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan science park signs MOUs with Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 22:40:49 ( By Li Hsi-chang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park signed two memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with Japan's Yokosuka Research Park Wednesday to improve the development of telecommunications technology and promote the industry, a government official said the same day.
Yang Wen-ke, director-general of the park's administration, said the MOUs would help not only to enhance Taiwan's international visibility but also accelerate technological innovation.
Shingo Ohmori, vice president of the Yokosuka Research Park, said the two parks could learn and gain benefits from each other through the cooperative agreements.
The Central Taiwan Science Park signed similar agreements with South Korea and the United Kingdom in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cruise ferry to resume Taichung-Xiamen service soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 22:58:55 (by Chen Ching-ping and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The cruise ferry Cosco Star, which carries passengers and cargo between Taichung and Xiamen, will resume service Aug. 25, operating one day per week, the Taichung Harbor Bureau (TCHB) said Wednesday.

The ship will sail every Wednesday and passengers on the first four trips will be offered a discount price of NT$1,500 (US$47) for a one-way ticket, said Kao Tai-shun, assistant vice president of China Ocean Service Co. which operates the service.
The TCHB has been working closely with the Taichung Association of Travel Agents to restore the service, which was suspended in July because of poor business and high operational costs.
The service was first launched in September 2009, with the ferry running on an irregular schedule between the two ports at an operational cost of NT$3 million (US$93,750) per trip, Kao said.
On 74 trips, it recorded only 6,381 person-trips and 900 pieces of cargo, he said.

Yu Chien-hsun, section chief of the TCHB's Stevedoring and Warehousing Department, said two of the problems were high ticket prices and the fact that people from Taichung were not used to traveling by ferry.
With the resumption of service, China Ocean Service Co. has agreed to drop its one-way fare to NT$2,300 (US$72).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to continue upgrading defense capability: Presidential Office
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 23:16:08 (By Li Garfie & Bear Lee )

TEXT.P: The government has been closely monitoring China's military build-up and will not halt its efforts to upgrade the nation's defense capability even as it seeks to further reduce tensions across the Taiwan Strait, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.
"There is no need for the people to worry about a reported cross-strait military imbalance in favor of China, " Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said.
He was responding to the opposition's accusation of "inaction" on the part of the Presidential Office after a U.S Pentagon report the previous day warned of China's continued military build-up.
Lo said that cross-strait military imbalance is a structural problem that dates back prior to 2008 when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was in power.
In its political posturing, the DPP administration never stopped provoking and confronting China, which led to the Taiwan Strait becoming one of two "flash points" in east Asia, Lo said.

President Ma, on the other hand, has spared no effort to reduce cross-strait hostility since he took office in 2008 and has forged 14 agreements with China to increase exchanges between the two sides, Lo said.

"President Ma has successfully turned the flash point in the strait into 'an avenue of peace and prosperity, ' an achievement that has been recognized by the United States, Japan, the European Union, and other countries around the world," Lo said.

Besides, since Ma took office, the U.S. government has approved the sale of two arms packages to Taiwan, valued at US$13 billion, which has contributed greatly to upgrading the country's defense capability, he said.

Quoting the ancient Chinese tactician Sun Tsu who said "the highest form of generalship is to balk the enemy's plans, " Lo said that the best way to put an end to conflict is "to replace confrontation with engagement, as the Ma administration has done.
Taiwan will strive to build a "lean but mean" military as a deterrent to war, instead of engaging in an arms race with China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature approves amendment to customs tariff law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/18/10 23:25:06 (By Chou Yung-chieh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Wednesday an amendment to the Customs Tariff Law as part of the measures to be implemented in line with a cross-strait trade pact.

Under the amendment, tariffs will be dropped to zero on 267 items from China, in a three-stage process between 2011 and 2013, in accordance with the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan and China signed on June 29.

The legislature ratified the ECFA Tuesday and passed the amendment Wednesday after an 11-hour meeting in which members of the various party caucus debated and voted on all articles of the revised law.

The tariff reduction on the 267 items from China will amount to an annual loss of NT$3.4 billion in customs revenue for Taiwan, while China will lose NT$29.5 billion when it removes the tariffs on 539 categories of imports from Taiwan under the ECFA, according to an estimate by the Ministry of Finance.
