DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 19, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly- established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 09:22:46 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened slightly higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 1.38 points at 7,925.48 on a turnover of NT$3.87 billion (US$120.94 million).
The weighted price index fell 6.99 points, or 0.08 percent, to close at 7,924.10 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Lifting Kaohsiung to stardom

TEXT.P: Singapore has suddenly become the centerpiece of the year-end mayoral election for the future special municipality of Kaohsiung, with the three major candidates seeking to "Singaporize" the southern port city.
Indeed, duplicating Singapore could be a resolution tailor-made for Kaohsiung, where businesses are languishing and the unemployment rate is among the highest in Taiwan.

Almost all the strengths of Singapore can also be found in Kaohsiung, including an exceptional deep-water port, pleasant climate, favorable natural environment and diligent people. For a long time, however, Kaohsiung was stranded by various trade barriers and closed itself off to prospering China.

Now, the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement has pried open the door to liberalization. Within the next few years, Taiwan will open its doors to the world and remove various trade barriers. If Kaohsiung can further give itself a makeover, upgrade its infrastructure and create a friendly living and business environment, then it will catch up with and even surpass Singapore.

It is not impossible to lift Kaohsiung to stardom. Remember that Kaohsiung used to be the world's third-largest port. The revival of Kaohsiung would be a sign of Taiwan's metamorphosis. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan vigilant in face of China's military buildup: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 10:54:53 (By Yang Ming-chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been closely monitoring China's military buildup while continuously seeking to upgrade it's defense capability, despite improved cross-strait relations, President Ma Ying-jeou told a Japanese daily Wednesday.
Taiwan's national defense system has remained vigilant in the face of China's incessant military expansion and upgrading, Ma said during an interview with the Japanese business daily Sankei Shimbun.

"Taiwan will maintain good military ties with the United States, including continuing to purchase weapons from the U.S., and Taiwan will continue to hone its defensive skills by conducting military exercises, " Ma said in the interview that was posted on the paper's website.
He stressed the importance of the Japan-U.S. security treaty signed in 1960, saying that it has since formed the bedrock of peace and stability in East Asia.

On a spate of accidents in which Taiwanese fishing boats were rammed or chased by Japanese patrol boats in waters near the diplomatically disputed Diaoyutai Islands, known in Japanese as the Senkaku Islands, Ma said Japan and Taiwan have had different stances on the thorny issue.
The time is not yet ripe for Taiwan and Japan to resolve this dispute, Ma said, adding that Taiwan will not ally with China against Japan in the dispute.
"This is an issue that Taiwan and Japan must tackle between themselves," Ma said.
"I hope both countries will work first to reach a consensus on how to address the matter regarding fishermen's rights," he added.

Ma also talked about Taiwan's signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, which was passed into law by Taiwan's legislature Aug. 17 and is slated to take effect later this year.
Under the law, China will remove the tariffs on 539 categories of imports from Taiwan, while Taiwan will give tariff concessions to 267 items from China.
Ma said mainland China has been the major barrier to Taiwan's bid to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries.

"The ECFA has obviously been a boost to Taiwan's FTA efforts, epitomized by new developments between Taiwan and Singapore, which could start talks on the signing of a trade cooperation pact soon, " the president told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- GDP growth rate and commodity price hikes

TEXT.P: Bloomberg News said Wednesday that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate could exceed 10 percent for the second quarter of this year, thanks to robust exports of microchips and flat panel monitors.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) is scheduled to release the country's second-quarter GDP growth data Thursday. It previously forecast 7.66 percent year-on-year growth for Q2.

Meanwhile, domestic food prices are facing inflationary pressure as international grain prices have spiked on a Russian export ban and abnormal weather in major grain-producing countries such as Australia and Canada.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issues:
United Daily News:

Bloomberg gave a rosy double-digit forecast on Taiwan's Q2 GDP growth after consulting 14 economists. It said that although Taiwan's major trading partners -- Japan, the United States and China -- have shown signs of economic slowdown, the country's economy continues steaming ahead.
Sustained economic recovery is fueling hikes in housing and consumer product prices and may even lead to a rise in capital costs, Bloomberg said.

Responding to Bloomberg's optimistic forecast, Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said Wednesday that she would not be surprised if the second-quarter GDP growth figure to be released by the DGBAS exceeds the original projection.

"For years, Taiwan has solely relied on exports for its economic growth, but this year, our growth structure has seen a change, with domestic demand or investment also contributing much to growth, " Liu said. "It is an encouraging development that exports and domestic investment have become our two growth engines." (Aug. 19, 2010).
Economic Daily News:

International wheat prices have risen by 20 percent since the beginning of this year, and soybean prices are also skyrocketing. Market sources said the price of the latest shipment of wheat bought by the Taiwan Wheat Flour Mills Industry Association reached US$330 a ton, up 30 percent from the previous shipment.
Maize prices on the international futures market hit a half-year high of US$9.1 per kilogram last week, up more than 10 percent from the spot market price, the Taiwan Feed Industry Association said.
With corn, flour and soybean prices rising on the international market, prices for eggs, meat, bread, cooking oil and other daily necessities are facing inflationary pressure.

Vice Premier Sean Chen has ordered the Ministry of Economic Affairs to closely monitor domestic commodity price fluctuations and take timely action to cushion price hikes by adjusting supplies ahead of the coming Ghost Festival, which falls on Aug. 24 this year. (Aug. 19, 2010).
China Times:

The DGBAS will also release a report on the survey of 2008 household income and expenditure later Thursday. According to tax data, Taiwan's wealth gap widened further in 2008, with the richest 20 percent earning 66 times more than the poorest 20 percent during the year.

The data also showed that Taiwan has 8,500 taxpayers who made more than NT$10 million (US$312,500) in 2008, with 4,700 of them living in Taipei City and 906 in Taipei County. The figures indicate that 66 percent of Taiwan's wealthiest people take residence in Taipei City and Taipei County, while only a tiny fraction of them live in the eastern Hualien and Taitung counties. (Aug. 19, 2010).
Liberty Times:

CEPD Chairwoman Christina Liu said Wednesday during a meeting with senior executives of major publicly listed conglomerates that the ratio of export orders produced at local companies' overseas factories had surged to 50 percent in June from 2000's 13 percent.

"Although such a trend will contribute to our GDP growth, local people will not benefit much from the gains as not many jobs will be created from increased export orders, " the country's top economic planner said. (Aug. 19, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The poverty phenomenon
DOC.DATELINE: Statistics from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) 08/19/10 11:24:03 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: show that the number of households living below the poverty line rose to a record high of 108,000 in the second quarter of 2010. The ministry, however, said the rise does not necessarily represent an increase in poverty and should be interpreted as the result of expanded welfare benefits.
This explanation leaves us totally speechless. In any case, the figure sends a very serious warning message.

The ministry said the number increased because looser criteria have been adopted since early 2008 to define households that are qualified for public assistance. But this means that the same criteria have been adopted over the last three years, so how can the development be attributed to the relaxed criteria?

Also, the MOI said the number was boosted by the increasing "minimum cost of living" in Taiwan. But the fact is that there has not been much change in the minimum cost of living over the past five years.

Another reason cited by the ministry is the relaxation of the criteria regarding real estate ownership by low-income households in 2010. But even before that, the number of poor families had been rising -- by 40,000 within the last 10 years.
Neglecting the economic aspects of the phenomenon, the government is missing an opportunity to thoroughly reflect on its industrial, educational and labor policies.

A bureaucratic culture that is capable only of interpreting figures positively and does not think in reverse is the root cause of an unprogressive government that must be corrected as soon as possible. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Designers' Week slated for early September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Sept. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 12:34:13 (By Sabine Cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Designers' Week 2010, an annual event that showcases the talent of Taiwanese designers and introduces their latest masterpieces, is slated for Sept. 3-12 in Taipei, a sponsor said Thursday.

The event will address four major themes -- culture, environment, life and community. It will bring together 13 groups of designers, including eight that made successful appearances at the same function in previous years and five groups making their debuts at the show, according to the sponsors.

This year marks the fourth edition of the show, which is being co-sponsored by the Designers Association of Taiwan, the non-profit Taiwan Cultural-Creative Development Foundation supervised by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, and the Huashan 1914 Creative Park.
The 10-day event will take place at the Huashan 1914 Creative Park on Bade Road in downtown Taipei, the sponsors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A crucial start for a golden decade

TEXT.P: The cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will take effect after Taiwan officially notifies China of its endorsement by the Legislative Yuan.

Under the ECFA framework, the two sides are expected to begin negotiations on four agreements regarding trade in goods, trade in services, investment protection and dispute settlement within six months from implementation, making a crucial start for Taiwan's passage toward a golden decade.

The issues of investment protection and dispute settlement must be handled first -- and quickly -- because the World Trade Organization (WTO) has set almost no rules on investment protection and China is unwilling to settle trade disputes with Taiwan at the WTO.

In addition to tariff reduction and market access, another important issue involving trade in goods and services will be removing the barriers formed by China's ubiquitous unwritten rules and administrative discretion.

The agreements on trade in goods and services will inevitably impact those Taiwanese industries that target the domestic market. The government should set up a mechanism similar to the European Union's structural funds to support its project to adjust Taiwan's industrial development. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Foxconn plans to increase China workforce to 1.3 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 13:27:29 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Foxconn Technology Group, a China-based subsidiary of Taiwan's Hon Hai group, said Wednesday it plans to raise its workforce in China to 1.3 million from the current 920,000 over the next 12 months.

Cheng Tien-tsung, deputy chief executive of Foxconn, said his group is migrating from coastal areas to inland China -- such as Chengdu in Sichuan Province and Zhengzhou in Henan Province -- and hiring new employees.
He said the group's Shenzhen base, which is planning to change to a three-shift schedule from the current two shifts, will also need more workers in the short term.
Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract maker of electronics products for high-tech giants such as Apple, Dell and Hewlett-Packard, is the parent company of Foxconn Technology Group.
Foxconn has faced tight scrutiny and harsh criticism from the public as it was accused of mistreating its Chinese workers after a spate of employee suicides at its Shenzhen complex earlier this year.

Amid escalating criticism, Terry Gou, chairman of Hon Hai Precision, apologized in June over the suicides and vowed to take good care of his employees by seeking assistance from sociology and psychological professionals.
Gou also strongly denied accusations that his company was running "blood and sweat" factories in China.

Hon Hai Precision announced two wage hikes in one week in June for its Chinese workers, bringing salaries to 2,000 Chinese yuan (US$294) a month from 900 yuan. The move triggered pressure on other foreign investors in China in terms of employee compensation, especially in coastal cities.
Foxconn is relocating its production to the Chinese inland area from Shenzhen to alleviate the impact from rising labor costs.

Cheng, however, said that Foxconn will not leave Shenzhen completely despite the production migration, adding that the group is planning to transform its Shenzhen production base into a research and development and quality testing center focusing on innovation.
In the long term, the workforce at the Shenzhen complex is expected to fall to 300,000-350,000 from the current 450,000, Cheng said.
Foxconn held an employee rally called "Love Your Life, Love Your Family" at plants across China on Wednesday as part of its efforts to boost worker morale after the suicides.
About 50,000 Chinese employees participated in the rally at Foxconn's facilities throughout China, according to media reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protesters blockade Formosa Plastics complex for third day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 18 (CNA) 08/19/10 15:25:20 (Yeh Tzu-kang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Local residents on Thursday continued their blockade of the three major roads leading to Formosa Plastic Group's (FPG) petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County for the third consecutive day, but dispersed after drawing complaints from motorists about traffic disruptions.

Residents in Mailiao and neighboring Taisi and Dacheng townships demanded compensation after a major fire at one of the complex's oil refining plants broke out on July 25, contaminating nearby farms and fish farms. The fire was the second at the complex in three weeks.
Residents began their blockade of the roads on Tuesday after compensation talks with FPG broke down.
They demanded that the conglomerate pay residents NT$1.8 billion (US$53 million) for polluting the area and harming their health.

They also demanded FPG promise to relocate the complex within 10 years. The company said it was only willing to pay NT$500 million -- higher than the NT$450 million it originally proposed -- but local residents rejected the offer.
During the blockade Thursday, protesters walked into the street at 6: 30 a.m., causing traffic jams stretching about 1 kilometer on one of the roads and drawing widespread complaints from motorists.

Dissatisfied with the county government's role in compensation talks, the protesters shouted "County Magistrate Su Chi-feng, step down, " and complained of "under-the-table operations." Formosa Plastics' management urged the protesters to respect its employees' right to work, while using shuttle buses to transport its employees.
Formosa Plastics called for rational and peaceful communications and stressed that the company will continue negotiations with local residents in an attempt to reach an agreement.
The protesters dispersed at around 9: 00 a.m. without saying whether the demonstration would continue Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates food processing equipment to Paraguay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 15:29:17 (By Fang Pei-ching and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated a set of food processing equipment to an agricultural association in Paraguay as part of efforts to promote bilateral cooperation and friendship, diplomatic officials said Thursday.
The equipment was previously used by Taiwan's technical mission in Paraguay for a food processing cooperation project.

After the project expired, the Republic of China Embassy in Paraguay decided to donate the appliances to an association of sesame growers in the Paraguayan province of San Pedro at the request of its governor Jose Ledesma.
At the donation ceremony, ROC Ambassador Huang Lien-sheng said it was an honor to make the donation to the high-quality processed food industry in Paraguay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close flat
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 16:01:57 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed flat Thursday after a tug of war between selling in old economy stocks and bargain hunting in large cap electronics, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 4.84 points, or 0.06 percent, to 7,928.94, after moving between 7,886.73 and 7,948.73, on turnover of NT$123.35 billion (US$3.87 billion).
The market opened slightly higher, up 1.38 points, despite lingering concerns over the global economic climate, dealers said.

During the trade, bargain hunters turned active, picking up select high tech heavyweights on low valuations in price, but profit taking pressure, in particular in the shipping and financial sectors, offset the gains, dealers said.
A total of 1,609 stocks closed up and 2,040 down, while 303 remained unchanged.
The machinery and electronics sector scored the highest gains, up 0.8 percent. Foodstuffs rose 0.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks gained 0.3 percent and cement shares added 0.1 percent.
The financial sector fell 1.9 percent, the textile sector lost 0.9 percent, the paper and pulp sector dropped 0.8 percent and the construction sector closed down 0.5 percent.

"Judging from the gains posted by large cap electronics stocks, I suspect foreign institutional investors stood on the buying side today after recent selloff, " TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.
Shih said further gains on Wall Street overnight gave some comfort to foreign investors and prompted them to resume buying.
"But, the buying was technical in nature as fears of weaker global demand on a slower global economy persisted," Shih said.
Such quick rotational buying is still dominating the trade and the local bourse still lacks a mainstream sector to push the index higher, Shih said.

"The market remains in a consolidation mode ahead of technical pressure at the key 8,000 point mark, " he said, referring to the latest profit taking in shipping and financial stocks, which recently staged a strong rebound amid optimism over cross strait business exchanges.
Shih said it will take some time to digest the selling before the market overcomes the technical hurdles ahead of the 8,000- point mark.

Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract maker of electronics products, was up 3.05 percent at NT$135.00, PC firm AsusTek rose 2.88 percent to NT$232.00 and IC packaging and testing service provider ASE increased 1.25 percent to NT$24.30.
Among financial stocks, Cathay Financial fell 2.03 percent to NT$48.25 and Chang Hwa Bank dropped 2.66 percent to NT$18.30.

DOC.HEADLINE: President backs decision to continue production at science park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 16:21:45 (By Lin Hui-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou defended Thursday the government's decision to allow industrial production to continue at the Central Taiwan Science Park's Houli site in central Taiwan, despite a court order to suspend the development project.
Ma said the decision was made based on the principle of "legitimate expectations, " which he described as the most important foundation of countries governed by the rule of law.
"We are abiding by the law rather than playing on words, " Ma said during the Seventh National Industrial Development Conference held in Taipei.
The Taipei High Administration Court ruled in July that all development work at the park's Houli and Erlin sites had to be stopped until environmental impact assessments were completed and approved.

The park administration agreed to stop work on the sites' infrastructure development but opted against shutting down companies that had already started production or were in the process of building their plants at the Houli site.
No companies had begun moving into the Erlin site at the time of the court's ruling.

Pointing to the constitutional stipulation that "environmental and ecological protection shall be given equal consideration with economic and technological development," Ma said this means that both legitimate interests will be weighted against each other to determine which one is more important.

He noted that the Basic Environment Act also states that in the event that economic, technological or social development will have a seriously negative impact on the environment, the protection of the environment shall prevail.
"It will depend on the impact as to which of the two will be given priority, which is the reason why environmental impact assessments are required," he said.
According to the president, economic development and environmental protection are equally important to Taiwan, and there are ways for them to co- exist.

For example, he said, there has been a long-running fight between environmentalists and Hualien residents over whether to continue a Suhua Freeway project tabled a few years ago, after the project failed to pass an environmental impact assessment.
The dispute was later resolved following the development of an alternative project to build a new expressway, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushes for U.S. to sell Taiwan F-16 C/Ds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 16:24:58 (By Garfie Lee and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the United States Thursday to sell F-16 C/D jet fighters to Taiwan to prevent the balance of military power across the Taiwan Strait from tilting further in China's favor.

"The purpose of procuring advanced jet fighters is not to provoke war but to beef up Taiwan's defense capability, " Ma said during a meeting with visiting U.S. Senator Roland Burris (D-Ill.) at the Presidential Office.

It was the third time in less than three weeks that Ma made such an appeal to the U.S. government, underscoring the urgency for Taiwan to acquire new jet fighters to upgrade its air force fleet in the face of China's continued military buildup.

On the previous occasions, he was in a meeting Aug. 6 with a delegation from the U.S. think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies, and with U.S. Senator Arlen Specter, who chairs the Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime and Drugs in the Senate, on Aug. 13.

Stressing that the people of Taiwan are most concerned with the issue of national security, Ma said he hopes the U.S. government will favorably consider Taiwan's request to purchase F-16 C/Ds for air defense in order to stabilize the cross-strait balance of military power, which has been shifting more substantially in China's favor over the past years.
He assured Burris that the proposed F-16 C/D procurement would be purely for the purpose of reinforcing Taiwan's air defense -- not to prepare for war.
"Our American friends can rest assured that the aircraft would be only for defense purposes and national security, " Ma told his guest.

On cross-strait relations, Ma said, the option for Taiwan and China is to resolve their disputes by peaceful means. Since assuming office more than two years ago, Ma said, his administration has been working hard to improve relations with China and has succeeded in reducing cross-strait tensions.

During the period, Taiwan signed 14 accords with China and this week the Legislative Yuan ratified the landmark cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and passed all related bills, he said.
"We will exchange instruments of ratification with mainland China soon to implement the trade pact," Ma said.
Meanwhile, he noted, Taiwan and Singapore jointly announced on Aug. 5 that they will explore the feasibility of an economic cooperation agreement that will be similar to a free trade agreement.
"Negotiations are scheduled to begin later this year," Ma said.
In the wake of the ECFA's signing, Ma said, Taiwan will speed up economic globalization to improve its competitiveness.

At the same time, he said, Taiwan is looking forward to making progress in its exchanges with the U.S. in the areas of trade, investment, education and judicial cooperation, and hopes that dialogue under the Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) will resume soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Controversial Chinese student bill set to be passed into law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 16:44:26 (By Ho Meng-kuei, Su Lung-chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Three controversial packages of amendments to pave the way for the admission of Chinese students to Taiwan's tertiary education institutions were likely to be passed into law Thursday after lawmakers across partisan lines made compromises to reach consensus on the issue.

Legislators from both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spent that day debating the bill at an extraordinary session before deciding to put it to a vote later in the day.
The rival lawmakers reached consensus the day before to facilitate the enactment by agreeing on a "one limit, two noes" proposal -- the bottom line of the KMT lawmakers.

The "one limit, two noes" proposal stipulates that Taiwan will impose a limit on recognizing medical credentials issued by China, that Chinese students will not be allowed to study in departments of local universities related to national security and intelligence, and that students without ROC citizenship will not be allowed to take part in civil service examinations.

While agreeing with the proposal, the DPP also demanded a clause saying that there should be restrictions to further regulate Chinese students working in Taiwan after they graduate from local higher education institutions.
The DPP had previously demanded that "three limits" and "six noes" be included in the law amendments.

The "three limits" refer to restrictions on the number of Chinese universities that the government plans to recognize, the total number of Chinese college students who can enter Taiwan to study, and a limit on the types of Chinese diplomas that will be accredited in Taiwan. The "six noes" would ban Chinese students from receiving scholarships or professional licenses, keep them from working or staying in Taiwan upon graduation, ban them from receiving extra points on examinations, and they would not be allowed to take part in civil service examinations.

Education Minister Wu Ching-chi said his office will respect the decisions made by the legislature on the controversial bill, although he said the "one limit, two noes" proposal seems to be redundant, as existing regulations in those regards are already in place.

Meanwhile, Ker Chien-ming, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said that since Chinese students are unlikely to be barred from entering, the DPP will propose hitting them with higher tuition levels -- a common practice for foreign students in most other countries.
"We'd like to negotiate with the KMT lawmakers over this issue, " Ker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes down on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 16:45:14 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.036 to close at NT$31.930.
Turnover totaled US$567 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.966 and moved to a low of NT$31.860 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Canada develop new method for hepatitis C detection
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 17:05:03 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Researchers from Taiwan and Canada have developed a new microscopy technology that allows for low-cost, portable imaging of the hepatitis C virus, making it more convenient to conduct screenings, a Taiwanese researcher said Thursday.

Under the sponsorship of Taiwan's National Science Council, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and National Research Council (NRC) Canada, an international research team recently combined technologies developed in Canada and Taiwan to create a screening device that can be carried in one hand.

Led by Kao Fu-jen, a professor at National Yang-Ming University, and Albert Stolow and John Pezacki from NRC Canada, the team jointly developed the high- sensitivity imaging system by re-engineering a DVD reading and writing head so that it can detect optical signals including fluorescence and tiny vibrations from a technique called coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering.

The device creates images from cell samples that allow researchers to determine whether the hepatitis C virus is present. The development is expected to help sharply increase the efficiency of the diagnosis of chronic hepatitis C, Kao said in a press release.
The size of the device allows for point-of-care testing, which is diagnostic testing at or near the site of patient care.
According to Kao, the hepatitis C virus is spread through contact with infected blood, and about 170 million worldwide are infected with it. Currently, there is no vaccine against the virus.

How the hepatitis C virus harms the livers of long-term carriers is still unknown, but the risk of people with hepatitis C contracting liver cancer is 10 times higher than for ordinary people, the press release said.

The goal of the collaboration project between Taiwan and Canada is to develop real-time, unobtrusive and efficient biomedical detection methods and instruments for widespread application for hepatitis C and other infectious diseases, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves 2011 budget plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 17:25:01 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Thursday the central government's budget proposal for 2011, with projected expenditure amounting to NT$1.7896 trillion (US$56.07 billion) and projected revenue of NT$1.6306 trillion.

The government will need to issue new debt of NT$429 billion next year to fill the NT$159 billion budget shortfall, repay NT$66 billion in principal for previous debt, and to cover four special budget proposals for 2011, officials said.

The special budget proposals include a NT$159.7 billion public construction expansion plan and a NT$17.3 billion flood control plan that were also approved by the Executive Yuan Thursday. The other two are a NT$21.7 billion plan on post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction and a NT$5.3 billion plan to clean up the Shihmen Reservoir that were approved at prior sessions.

According to Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der, tax revenue will rise NT$28.7 billion next year, mainly due to a NT$17.8 billion increase in revenue from individual income tax because of an economic recovery.

Lee said that by the end of next year, outstanding national debt will have reached NT$4.9618 trillion, accounting for 37.79 percent of the country's gross domestic product. The percentage will represent a record high, although it will remain below the 40 percent ceiling, he added.

By sector, educational, science and cultural spending account for NT$357.3 billion, or 20 percent, of the projected expenditure; social welfare spending accounts for NT$346.9 billion, or 19.4 percent; defense spending will be NT$287.2 billion, or 16 percent; and economic development spending accounts for NT$225.9 billion, or 12.6 percent, according to the Cabinet's proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Balanced development of industries, environmental protection urged
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 17:44:11 (By Lin Hui-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A business leader called on the government Thursday not to shelve major investment projects for the sake of environmental protection and not to make unreasonable demands for employees' interests and benefits.

At the opening of a two-day meeting on the development of national industry, Chen Wu-hisung, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, expressed his thanks to the government for ratifying the long- awaited economic trade agreement with China and suggested that the government should seek innovation and relax regulations.

Chen said that because industrial development is key to the country's overall development, there is a need to strike a balance between industrial development and labor welfare and between industrial development and environmental protection.
The government should also include industrial development into its national policy and ensure a balanced development of industries, the workforce and environmental protection, he added.
According to Chen, the business sector "absolutely supports environmental and labor protection, " but he said the approach should be improved.

Pointing to recent public outrage over pollution caused by two fires at the Formosa Plastic Group's petrochemical complex in Yunlin County, Chen said the incident provides a good opportunity for the industrial sector to review its operations and he called for more time to allow the industrial sector to improve.

He also suggested that the government should promote the greening of industries and the development of green energy industries, including pushing the development of electric vehicles, solar energy batteries and renewable energy industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists launch Fubon boycott
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 17:53:10 (by Chen Ching-fang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Environmental advocacy groups staged a protest against Fubon Financial Group at the group's headquarters in Taipei Thursday, urging consumers to stop doing business with Fubon due to its investment in the Kuokuang petrochemical project.
The public should cancel all Fubon accounts and credit cards, said environmentalists, who described the boycott as their first green movement against the financial industry.

According to a Fubon representative, the investment was made years ago as a demonstration of support for government development projects and Fubon has never interfered with the decisions made by Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co.

Environmental organizations have asked Fubon to consider its social responsibility and take people's well-being into consideration. Fubon should withdraw from the project and not participate in future syndicated loans, said Pan Han-sheng, the chairperson of the Taiwan Green Party.

Kuokuang's plans to build a massive refinery complex on coastal wetland in central Taiwan have raised public concern over possible water and air pollution that could severely affect residents and damage the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves statement on 2011 administrative policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:02:32 (By Lee Shu-hua and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved its statement on 2011 administrative policy during a meeting Thursday. The statement, along with the government's 2011 general budgetary bill, will be presented to the Legislative Yuan for examination and approval.
Premier Wu Den-yih said after the meeting that the Executive Yuan's policy was aimed at translating President Ma Ying-Jeou's vision for the country into a road map.
He urged the agencies under the Executive Yuan to play their parts in carrying out the policy.

A press release issued by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission -- the supreme planning agency of the nation -- said the policy statement includes four directions: bolstering the economy; improving reconstruction after disaster and beefing up prevention of mudslides and flooding; developing peace with China while exploring diplomatic ties with other states pragmatically; and promoting social security.

As to developing peace with China while exploring diplomatic ties with other states, the aims listed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs included cementing diplomatic ties with allies and improving cooperation and regular exchanges with states that do not recognize Taiwan diplomatically.
Meanwhile, the Mainland Affairs Council will push for pragmatic negotiations with China while promoting and institutionalizing economic and trade exchanges.
The Government Information Office will enhance the profile of the Republic of China on the international stage when it marks the country's 100th founding anniversary, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government agency told to solve naphtha cracker disputes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:31:50 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Thursday to help solve disputes triggered by two fires at Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG's) naphtha cracker complex within a single month that caused serious air and environmental pollution.

The two fires occurred in July, sending billows of black smoke into the air for several days and stirring up residents' indignation over the government's policies on industrial development and environmental protection.

In the face of the residents' protests, including traffic blockades surrounding the naphtha cracker complex for three consecutive days as of Thursday, Wu said at a regular Cabinet meeting that the government should stabilize national order and protect legal industrial production.
However, the government should also allow the people to vent their anger and voice their petitions, as well as help address points of contention, Wu said.
The premier asked the EPA to collaborate with the National Science Council to solve the environmental protection issue in a responsible manner.
Turning to an "environment vs. economy" clash involving land expropriation in Miaoli County's Dapu Rural Community, Wu told the Ministry of the Interior to address the dispute properly.
"The government should avoid expropriating good and in-use farmland," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China companies plan joint venture to make bus batteries
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:38:12 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan company that makes lithium iron phosphate (LPF) batteries said Thursday it plans to enter into a joint venture with a bus manufacturer in China to produce batteries for large buses.

Pihsiang Machinery Manufacturing Co. Ltd., which is primarily an electric scooter maker, said Thursday it intends to take a 15 percent stake in the joint venture with Foshan Electrical and Lighting Co. (FEL) of China and to provide the technology and materials for the manufacture of LPF bus batteries.
Under the terms of a letter of intent signed between the two companies, the battery factory will be set up in China, in Foshan, Guangdong Province, Pihsiang deputy spokesman More Huang said.
"We are engaged in negotiations and will try to finalize the investment plan soon, " Huang said.
The preliminary plan is to manufacture 15 million batteries for supply to FEL in the first year of the project, he said.
FEL is primarily a lighting equipment maker, but in the last two years it has acquired three bus manufacturing plants in China.
Huang said FEL plans to expand its annual bus production capacity to 2,000 units by 2015, by which time it will require 100 million LPF batteries per year.
FEL was impressed by Pihsiang's battery production technology after it tested the batteries in its buses in April, Huang said.
"Pihsiang holds the patents and FEL has the funds. We are going to be a good match," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF deputy head to visit China on investment-soliciting mission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:40:34 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday that he will visit China later this month to meet with Taiwanese businessmen there and solicit Chinese investment in Taiwan.

Kao Koong-lian, who concurrently serves as SEF secretary-general, said he will be accompanied by a group of officials from the SEF, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council on the Aug. 21-28 visit.
The trip will take the delegation to Shanghai and major cities in the southeastern coastal province of Zhejiang, such as Ningbo, Shaoxing and Hangzhou.

The delegation will brief Taiwanese businessmen operating in these areas on key points of the recently signed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, solicit their opinions about the pact and inquire about problems they face in their operations in China, Kao said.
"We will also introduce possible joint-venture and investment opportunities in Taiwan to Chinese business executives," Kao said.
The SEF is the intermediary body authorized by the government to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ambassador meets Paraguayan official on cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:49:01 (By Ku Lan-ying and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Huang Lien-sheng met Paraguay's newly appointed vice interior minister, Diego Gamarra, for wide-ranging talks Wednesday on bilateral cooperation in fighting crime and educational and cultural development, according to Taiwan's embassy in Asuncion.
To help improve law and order in Paraguay, Huang said during the meeting that Taiwan will donate training facilities to a major Paraguayan police academy.
Gamarra promised to launch a project to develop the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park in Asuncion into a new tourist attraction in the Paraguayan capital city.

In addition, Gamarra said he would coordinate with the Paraguayan public construction ministry to set aside a plot of land for the establishment of a Buddhism park to highlight bilateral cultural and religious activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT affirms 'solid' U.S.-Taiwan relations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 18:58:21 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) reaffirmed the "solid" relationship between the United States and Taiwan Thursday in response to a question regarding a domestic political controversy about current bilateral relations.

"I think the U.S.-Taiwan relations are pretty solid, politically and economically...but of course there is room for improvement, such as in the area of educational and cultural exchange, " said Sheila Paskman, spokeswoman of the AIT, the U.S. representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic ties.

Paskman was responding to a reporter's question about what Su Tseng-chang, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's candidate in the year-end Taipei mayoral election, said earlier this week in New York. Su said that the current administration of President Ma Ying-jeou "had boasted about its accomplishment of improving Taiwan-U.S. relations."

She also reiterated U.S. support for improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), a historic trade pact signed June 29 that aims to liberalize trade between Taiwan and China.

Paskman, who took up her position in July, declined to compare bilateral relations during the current and the previous administrations, saying that she was new to the job and was not in a position to make comparisons.

Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs responded to Su's comment with a press release Wednesday, citing comments by U.S. officials and U.S. support for the signing of the ECFA to highlight the current administration's success in managing Taiwan-U.S. ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Q2 economy up 12.53 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 19:15:01 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in the second quarter of this year grew 12.53 percent from a year earlier on the back of strong exports and recovering domestic demand, the government said Thursday.
The second quarter gross domestic product (GDP) growth beat a forecast of 7.66 percent the government made in May, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said.

The DGBAS also revised upward the GDP growth for the first quarter to 13.71 percent from a preliminary 13.27 percent. j Taiwan's economy in the April-June period grew for the third consecutive quarter after a global financial meltdown battered the island's economic fundamentals in 2008-2009.

Taiwan registered its worst-ever recession in the first quarter of 2009, with GDP falling 9.06 percent, before the local economy gradually recovered and climbed out of the recession in the fourth quarter of last year on rising global demand as the impact from the financial crisis faded.
In the second quarter, the local economy benefited from robust global demand, in particular from China and other emerging markets, the DGBAS said in a statement.

Meanwhile, domestic consumption recovered to boost sales in the local retail, restaurant, car and tourism businesses, while the high-tech sector expanded its production capacity to lift private investment, the DGBAS added.
During the three-month period, Taiwan's private consumption rose 4.41 percent from a year earlier and private investment gained 37.48 percent year-on-year.
In the first half of this year, Taiwan's economy grew 13.10 percent from a year earlier, the DGBAS said.
The agency said it has raised its forecast for 2010 GDP growth to 8.24 percent from the previous estimate of 6.14 percent.
It has also upgraded its estimated 2010 private consumption to 2.78 percent from 1.99 percent, while lifting the forecast of 2010 private investment to 23.40 percent from 18.38 percent.
The island's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to rise 1.23 percent largely on stable food prices, the agency said.

For 2011, Taiwan's economy is expected to grow 4.64 percent from 2010 with private investment up 1.44 percent, private consumption up 2.64 percent and the CPI up 1.43 percent year-on-year, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to address widening wealth gap issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 19:24:26 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that the government will not sit on its hands and allow the gap between rich and poor to keep widening unabated.

Responding to a newspaper report that the wealth gap has continued to increase over the past 11 years, Wu said he had directed Vice Premier Sean Chen to form a special task force to look into the issue and map out effective measures to address the problem.

The China Times cited official tax data as reporting that same day that Taiwan's wealth gap widened substantially in 2008, with the richest 20 percent earning 66 times more than the poorest 20 percent during the year.
Wu acknowledged that the government has an obligation to fix the wealth gap issue to allow all of the country's people an equitable share of the fruits of economic development.
"It will be extremely regrettable if the benefits of economic growth are grabbed by only a small fraction of our population, " Wu said.
He said the task force to be headed by the vice premier will come up with a concrete action plan to effectively narrow the wealth gap in stages, which he said will contribute to social harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2020 core industries to boost Taiwan's infrastructure: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 19:35:53 (By Lin I-feng and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MEA) has announced "2020 core industries" to highlight Taiwan's industrial infrastructure, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) Vice President Kung Ming-hsin said at the 7th National Industrial Development Conference Thursday.
The 24 industries listed under the "2020 core industries" banner include new industries such as green energy, traditional industries and service-related industries with potential for development.

Kung, one of the panelists at the conference, said that these industries will follow one of three pathways: upgrading programs; strengthening program; or an internationalization and technological upgrading program.
He added that to improve industrial performance, the industries should pay more attention to international issues such as environmental protection and try to get in line with international practices.
The "2020 core industries" cover a wide range of industries in the high-tech, traditional and service sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND censured for illegal promotion of generals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 19:53:48 (By Sofia Yeh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan censured the Ministry of National Defense Thursday for promoting as many as 124 generals without following normal standards during the tenures of eight defense ministers between 1994 and 2009.

The National Defense and Information Committee of the highest watchdog body approved a proposal by members Lee Ping-nan, Yu Teng Fang and Huang Huang-hsiung to censure the ministry for failing to stick to regulations governing the promotion of generals during the period.
The three yuan members in their investigative report confirmed allegations that "there were officers getting promoted through illegal means, which included paying bribes."
The reports said the 124 generals who got promoted not in compliance with regulations represented 13.63 percent of the total number of generals promoted during the period.

Lee Jye, who served as defense minister between May 2004 and May 2007, promoted the highest number of generals not in conformity with standards, at 35. He was followed by Tang Yiau-min (February 2002-May 2004) at 22; former Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen (May 2000-January 2002) at 18; Chiang Chung-ling (December 1994-February 1999) and Lee Tien-yu (May 2007-February 2008) , each at 15; Tsai Ming-shian (February-May 2008) at 12; Tang Fei (February 1999-May 2000) at six; and Chen Chao-min (May 2008-September 2009) at one.

Tsai, the last defense minister under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian and whose tenure was less than three months, had the highest ratio of inadequate promotion of generals, with four per month.
The Control Yuan, however, failed to mete out any punishment for the former ministers for the serious offenses, although there were discussions among the members on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low-cost fish recommended as offerings for Ghost Festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 20:30:28 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Agency and two fishery associations on Thursday urged the public to buy low cost fish such as milk fish, Taiwan tilapia and bass for use as food offerings during the Ghost Festival which falls on Aug. 24 this year.

Lin Chi-tsang, the head of Taiwan Provincial Fishermen's Association, said at a promotional event in Taipei that fish of around 0.6-kg are usually the most popular choice for religious rites, and that many of the low-cost seasonal species come in that size.

The wholesale price of milk fish is NT$73 per kilogram, about 20-30 percent lower than it was two months ago, while Taiwan tilapia of the same size cost NT$30-NT$40 each kg, and bass NT$60-NT$70 each, Lin said.

In comparison, the price of white pomfret is NT$600 per kg, while corvina of the same size cost NT$350 each. This price is even higher than the record NT$170-NT$180 per kg during Chinese New Year over the past few years.
The price of corvina has risen because of dwindling stocks and a decrease in imports from China due to increasing demand during the ongoing Shanghai World Expo, Lin said.
He therefore encouraged consumers to buy cheaper fish for food offerings during the festival, saying that the cost will be one-fifth of that of white pomfret.

Chinese families customarily celebrate Ghost Festival on the 15th day of the seventh lunar month with food offerings to their ancestors. They also make food offerings to ghosts in the belief that the spirits will therefore not intrude into the lives of the living and bring misfortune.
Fish, pork and chicken are usually the three most common choices of food for ghost month offerings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Soybean, cooking oil prices to stand solid on bumper crop
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 20:40:39 (By Yang Su-min and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Soybean prices will remain stable in the coming months thanks to a predicted bumper crop in September, though with a slight rise resulting from short-term wheat price volatility, an official of the Taiwan Vegetable Oil Manufacturers Association said Thursday.

Yang Ing-Wu, chairman of the association, said the U.S. Department of Agriculture has predicted a good U.S. soybean harvest in September, which will contribute to the stabilization of both soybean and cooking oil prices.
"The crude oil price and the weather so far have had no major impact on the cooking oil supply, " said Yang, adding that the upward rise in soybean prices will decline soon.
According to the association, the current price of cooking oil is NT$500-600 (US$15.84-US$19.01) per 18-litre barrel on the domestic market.
Yang said the import price of soybeans rose from US$9.34 to US$10.4 per bushel during the first half of August, with a slight margin triggered by wheat price volatility.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., EU observing Taiwan's move on rice wine tax cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 20:41:28 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The representative offices in Taiwan of the United States and the European Union (EU) both took a wait-and-see approach Thursday to an imminent amendment of a law that would lower the tax on rice wine, which both parties consider a violation of World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations.

The Executive Yuan passed a draft amendment to the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Law last month to adjust the tax on rice wine by moving it from the distilled spirit category to the cooking wine category. The amendment was expected to clear the Legislative Yuan late Thursday.

"We will carefully look at new laws or amendments that may conflict with the WTO obligations of members, particularly any changes that will treat domestic products more favorably than imported ones. We expect WTO members to act in accordance with their WTO commitments, " said Sheila Paskman, a spokeswoman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).
The European Economic and Trade Office said meanwhile that it will let the EU Parliament in Brussels handle the EU's official response.

Under the draft amendment, the tax on a 0.6-liter bottle of rice wine will be reduced from NT$29.25 (US$0.93) to NT$5.4 and the price of a bottle of rice wine will be cut to NT$25 from NT$50. The price adjustment has sparked questions in the U.S. and the EU as to whether it violates the regulations of the WTO, of which Taiwan is a member.

Citing public opinion surveys, the government has argued that 96.4 percent of the population use rice wine solely for cooking rather than drinking, in an effort to convince the U.S., the EU and other WTO members that lowering rice wine prices will not have an impact on other types of alcohol.

Both the U.S. and the EU -- the main producers of brandy and whisky -- fear that once the price of the kitchen staple is lowered, sales of whisky, brandy and other varieties of alcohol will be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Taipei wins bronze in bowling championship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 21:09:36 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei earned a bronze medal in the trio category of the World Tenpin Bowling Association World Men's Championships Wednesday, the Chinese Taipei Bowling Association announced in a press release Thursday.
The three-man team -- Hung Kun-yi, Cheng Hsing-chao and Wu Hao-Ming -- entered the semi-finals match with a 3,914 pinfall total but lost to Mexico at the competition in Munich, Germany.

A total of 365 bowlers from 65 countries were competing for medals in six events -- singles, doubles, trios, teams, all events men, and masters -- in the championships being held in Munich, Germany, the association said.
The association said the medal did not come easily as the competitors were strong and well-prepared.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers publish new findings on vitamin C uptake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 21:26:07 (By Lin Szu-yu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Researchers from Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences have identified a protein that carries vitamin C to muscle cells of the body to help repair damage and protect against deterioration.
The researchers said that the findings gave them a better understanding of an inherited connective tissue disorder called arterial tortuosity syndrome.
The study was published online in the journal "Human Molecular Genetics" on July 24 and has been highlighted as a "must read" paper by the influential "Faculty of 1000 Biology" research service.

The findings of the study may explain long-standing questions about how vitamin C enters mitochondria, which are the power centers of cells. Mitochondria provide the energy a cell needs to move, divide, produce secretory products and contract.
They are also known to take up and recycle vitamin C. However, up until now, the molecular mechanisms of vitamin C uptake by mitochondria have been poorly understood.
The research team led by Dr. Yuan-Tsong Chen, identified a carrier protein called GLUT 10, which is found predominantly in the mitochondria of smooth muscle cells and insulin-stimulated fat cells.
They found that GLUT 10 transports oxidized vitamin C to mitochondria, and also increases their uptake, which strengthens the cells' ability to detoxify and repair damage.

These findings provide a mechanism to explain how vitamin C enters mitochondria and show how abnormalities in GLUT 10 may lead to the abnormalities found in arterial tortuosity syndrome, the researchers said.
The results also provide new insights into the relationship between GLUT 10 and type 2 diabetes and reinforce the importance of vitamin C in fighting degenerative diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Discount bookstore turning to online sales
DOC.DATELINE: 08/19/10 21:50:46 (CommonWealth 453)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: News of a discount bookstore closing branches in Taipei to focus on its plan to launch an online store highlights the impact on the industry from competition on the Internet.

The Cheng Da Bookstore will close both of its Taipei branches near National Taiwan Normal University and National Taiwan University at the end of October and is working with Terry Chang, founder of Taiwan's first online bookstore -- books.com.tw -- on its online venture.
The bookstore's physical presence will be reduced to its two branches in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City.

Publishing industry sources said Cheng Da's Taipei branches are market indicators because of their good sales performance. If the move shows the market trend leaning toward the Internet, the outlook is not bright for smaller players.
Taipei's "book street" -- the section between the Presidential Office and the railway station on Chongqing South Road -- is feeling the most impact.

"Bookstores used to fill Chongqing South road but have been closing one by one in recent years. The books that keep the remaining stores open are books for exams or those in simplified Chinese," said Liu Chien-yu, chief editor of Socio Publishing Co., Ltd.
Facing the tough market, independent bookstores are diversifying to offer more to their customers such as holding lectures or selling coffee.
Specialization is another approach. The owner of A-Wei's Bookstore near Taipei's "book street" decided to sell second-hand books as he had bought many unwanted books cheaply from his customers.

According to Liu, bricks-and-mortar shops still have a place in the future and he said that whether virtual or not, both kinds of bookstores have their different appeals for consumers. He used the development between physical and electronic books to explain his prediction.

"Perhaps physical books in the end will become luxuries and collectors' items as they were in the past when knowledge was not widely available, " Liu said. "It will probably be a reflection of social status for people in the future to go to bookstores and buy books once online distribution is the norm."

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature revises law to open colleges to Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 21:52:57 (By He Meng-kui, Lin Szu-yu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of different parties at the Legislative Yuan approved unanimously Thursday the revision of three acts to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwanese colleges.

Lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which balk at any idea of fostering closer ties with China, gave up their opposition to the revision after their counterparts from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) agreed to write into law three limitations insisted upon by the DPP.

The three limitations are refusing accreditation of diplomas issued by Chinese medical schools, a ban on Chinese students enrolling in departments closely related to Taiwan's national security, and a ban on people without Taiwanese nationality taking national examinations to work as government employees or professionals.
The first condition is aimed mainly at preventing local people who graduate from Chinese medical schools from practicing in Taiwan.

Around 20,000 local people have already graduated from Chinese colleges despite local authorities' refusal to accredit Chinese diplomas, about 25 percent of whom have graduated in medicine, mainly traditional Chinese medicine.
The second and third limitations are intended to deny Chinese students access to Taiwan's security studies or to serve in Taiwan either as civil servants or as professionals in the private sector.
The revisions prompted a free-for-all between the ruling and opposition lawmakers when it was first debated at the legislature in July.

A further DPP request to prohibit Chinese students from working even part-time while studying in Taiwan was nixed by the KMT on the grounds that a similar prohibition is already provided for in the Act Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Instead, the two parties split their differences by passing a resolution along with the revision saying that Chinese students cannot work part-time in line with the prohibition stipulated in the earlier act.

The revisions have cleared the legal obstacles for local colleges, especially local graduate schools, to accept Chinese students, although the Ministry of Education (MOE) has not yet laid down detailed regulations for the program.

An education official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the accreditation of diplomas will not be applied retroactively, which means that Taiwanese students who studied and earned degrees in China before the revision was passed still will not have their qualifications recognized in Taiwan.
"It is the opinion of the majority during various public hearings we have held that we should not reward people who jump the gun, " the official said.

However, those who earned their Chinese diplomas before the regulations might be able to get local certification by taking an examination administered by the government exclusively for them, the official said.
Furthermore, the official went on, the MOE will accredit only the top Chinese colleges covered by a Chinese program formulated in 1998 to develop them into internationally recognized ones.

However, the National University of Defense Technology in Harbin, in Heilongjiang Province will be excluded from the 39 colleges under the Chinese program, while the Beijing Sport University, the Central Conservatory of Music and the China Central Academy of Fine Arts, all in Beijing, will be added to the list to make a total of 41 recognized colleges, according to the officials.

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has pushed hard for the policy of allowing Chinese students to study in Taiwan, saying that it will not only promote exchanges between the two sides and encourage Chinese students to develop sympathy for Taiwan, but will also help many local colleges plagued with a shortage of students to find students from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese students to be allowed in next March at earliest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 21:54:45 (By Lin Se-yu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Chinese students will be able to study in Taiwanese universities for doctorates or masters degrees from March next year at the earliest, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Thursday.

The Legislative Yuan approved earlier that same day three amendments to the Law Governing Relations Between the People in the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, the University Law and the College Law, paving the way for the admission of Chinese students into local tertiary education institutions.

MOE officials said local universities intending to enroll Chinese students in masters or doctoral programs should submit their plans before December, which should include information on faculty, hardware and software facilities, to be screened in accordance with the regulations governing Chinese students' recruitment and their stays in Taiwan.
The regulations are scheduled to be promulgated by the MOE next month.
MOE said a joint recruitment committee will be set up by next July to deal with issues related to applications, examinations and admissions of Chinese students.
The committee will also be responsible for admitting Chinese students for undergraduate programs according to their scores in China's university entry exam.

As China usually holds its annual university entry exam in early June, this means Chinese students cannot apply for Taiwanese undergraduate studies until their scores in next year's exam are available, usually in August.
The relevant universities themselves are authorized to handle their own recruitment of Chinese masters and doctorate students.

Expressing appreciation for the legislative passage of the revised laws, the associations of national universities, private universities and colleges and private technology colleges called for broader educational exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait by allowing universities to set up offices on either side to help smooth recruitment and academic cooperation.
In Beijing, a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council expressed welcome for the move, but said Chinese students in Taiwan should not be discriminated against.

DOC.HEADLINE: No danger of collision in airport close call: Singapore Airlines
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 22:05:45 (By Tang Pei-chun and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) rebutted Thursday Taiwanese media reports that one of its aircraft almost crashed into a Ukrainian cargo plane while waiting for takeoff at Taoyuan Taiwan International Airport July 15.
In a statement to Singapore daily Lanhe Wanbao, SIA said the plane took off only after the Ukrainian freight plane had taxied off the runway and there was "no danger."
According to the Taiwanese media reports, the Ukrainian pilot misheard orders from the control tower and was moving toward the passenger plane, nearly causing a collision.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), amidst the controversy, came forward to explain the incident.

The MOTC said the Ukrainian plane was asked to hold next to runway 05 for the SIA plane to take off. However, the control officer failed to notice when the cargo plane continued to taxi toward runway 05.
The cargo plane was at the end of runway 05 when the passenger plane took off, said the MOTC.
SIA said the plane waited for the cargo plane to clear runway 05 before taking off and that at no time were there any safety issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negligent air traffic controller receiving counseling
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/19/10 22:14:18 (By Wang Shu-fen, Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An air traffic controller at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport who nearly caused a collision between a cargo plane and a passenger flight in July has been moved to another post and is receiving counseling, an official said Thursday.
"The controller, who had been working in the airport control tower for slightly more than a year, was scared by his own mistake and feels deeply remorseful," the official said.
In the hope of helping him overcome the trauma and work well in his new post, he said, the airport administration has assigned a psychology instructor to offer counseling to the controller.

The "near miss" took place July 15 when a Ukrainian cargo plane nearly collided with a Singapore Airlines (SIA) passenger flight at the airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- because the Ukrainian pilot reportedly misunderstood the air traffic controller's order.

The Ukrainian plane was moving forward as it received an order to wait until the SIA flight carrying more than 200 passengers had taken off. However, the pilot misunderstood the order "hold short of runway 05" as "cross runway 05." As the cargo plane moved forward, another air traffic controller saw the danger and ordered it to speed up so it could be out of the way when the SIA plane started taking off.

Local media reports said the two planes came to within 1,100 meters of each other, or 11 seconds away from a collision. However, the Singapore daily Lianhe Wanbao quoted an SIA executive as saying Thursday that its crew had noticed the Ukrainian plane on the runway and decided to delay takeoff until after the Ukrainian plane had left runway. The SIA executive insisted that the "near miss" reports were not true as there was no dangerous scenario at all.

Nevertheless, an airport management investigation showed that the first air controller should have made certain that the Ukrainian pilot had understood his order and should also have used visual contact or radar to confirm the plane's position.
"The presence of two planes on the same runway violated the most fundamental rule" of air traffic control, the airport official pointed out.
The controller will be disciplined, he went on, adding that the airport administration's disciplinary panel is scheduled to meet next week to mete out a penalty.
The incident followed a host of problems and scandals afflicting the airport, including leaking restrooms, poor facilities, awful and expensive food and staff misconduct.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo said there are indeed structural problems at the airport that need to be tackled. The airport administration will be transformed into a corporation in November, at which time an enterprising spirit will be instilled to upgrade service quality, he promised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature OKs cut in rice wine tax, other law revisions

The move, initiated by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , drew mild opposition from Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), with some of the lawmakers questioning the constitutionality of the revision.

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) rebutted Thursday Taiwanese media reports that one of its aircraft almost crashed into a Ukrainian cargo plane while waiting for takeoff at Taoyuan Taiwan International Airport July 15.
In a statement to Singapore daily Lanhe Wanbao, SIA said the plane took off only after the Ukrainian freight plane had taxied off the runway and there was "no danger."
According to the Taiwanese media reports, the Ukrainian pilot misheard orders from the control tower and was moving toward the passenger plane, nearly causing a collision.

The MOTC said the Ukrainian plane was asked to hold next to runway 05 for the SIA plane to take off. However, the control officer failed to notice when the cargo plane continued to taxi toward runway 05.
The cargo plane was at the end of runway 05 when the passenger plane took off, said the MOTC.
SIA said the plane waited for the cargo plane to clear runway 05 before taking off and that at no time were there any safety issues.

The controller will be disciplined, he went on, adding that the airport administration's disciplinary panel is scheduled to meet next week to mete out a penalty.
The incident followed a host of problems and scandals afflicting the airport, including leaking restrooms, poor facilities, awful and expensive food and staff misconduct.
