DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 20, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Turn paperwork, lip service into concrete achievements

TEXT.P: Despite tedious filibusters and other procedural pole-greasing from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the landmark economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China has finally cleared the legislative floor.

The pact is of course no cure-all or panacea, but rather the right choice at a crucial time. It will usher in a new era in economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and will allow Taiwan to break through its diplomatic isolation and play a more important role in the process of Asia-Pacific economic integration.

The ruling Kuomintang has launched an all-out publicity campaign to propagate the ECFA's merits and benefits, which include creating 250,000 jobs, attracting US$17.1 billion in inbound investment from around the world and increasing the annual GDP growth rate by 1.7 percent.

Summarizing the accord's potential benefits into concrete figures makes it easy for ordinary people to understand and memorize. Quantitative figures, however, are less forgettable and easier to compare. People tend to expect more and more. Whenever the numbers fall a bit short of original expectations, the government faces the risk of immediate complaints and criticism.

The ECFA's signing therefore has posed a great challenge to the government. All public agencies should from now on pull out all the stops to turn written and verbalized benefits into concrete achievements that people can experience in their everyday lives. Only if action is substituted for paperwork and lip service in administrative measures can the deal prove its value. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: USTR expresses concern over Taiwan rice wine tax cut
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 10:38:26 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government expressed concern Thursday over the Taiwan legislature's approval earlier in the day of a tax reduction for rice wine -- a kitchen staple among Taiwanese consumers.

"The United States is concerned with the potential market impact of Taiwan's tax reduction on rice wine, " said an official with the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) in response to a query from CNA.
The USTR has already conveyed its concerns about Taiwan's tax cut directly to the Taiwanese authorities, the official said.

The United States expects all WTO members to abide by their WTO obligations. It would be inappropriate to comment on whether this, or any other specific issue, might be subject to WTO litigation, the USTR said.

Taiwan's Legislative Yuan approved a reduction in the tax on rice wine from NT$29.5 (US$0.93) per 600 c.c bottle to NT$5.4 Thursday. The move is expected to bring the price of local rice wine from NT$50 per bottle to NT$25.

The Ministry of Finance said that although the cut is expected to increase the sale of the wine from 7.5 million bottles per year to 210 million -- the amount before the NT$29.5 tax was imposed -- it is set to cost the government NT$1.47 billion in tax revenue.

In fact, there is a WTO tax bracket for alcoholic beverages for kitchen use -- which is what over 90 percent of Taiwan's rice wine is made and sold for. However, rice wine has been taxed as a distilled spirit, and other WTO members -- principally the U.S. and the European Union -- are under the impression that reducing the tax on the cooking wine will undercut their sales in Taiwan of spirits such as whisky and brandy, neither of which are used for cooking in Chinese cuisine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan expected to reach 8.24% GDP growth

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) revised upward Taiwan's projected economic growth for 2010 to 8.24 percent Thursday -- the highest level in 21 years -- on the back of strong economic recovery.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

According to DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei, the main reason for the revision is Taiwan's better-than-expected economic performance in the second quarter, when growth reached 12.53 percent. This marked the third straight quarter in which positive growth was recorded and the second consecutive quarter of double-digit increase.
Su said both exports and investment by the semiconductor sector beat expectations.
An increase in domestic demand also fueled a big boost, contributing 6.33 percentage points to the growth, she said. (Aug. 20, 2010).
China Times:
The growth projection of 8.24 percent for 2010 is the second-highest among Asia's "four little dragons, " after Singapore's 13 percent to 15 percent.

The DGBAS predicted that Taiwan's export volume will hit a record high of US$271.3 billion this year. Private investment, meanwhile, is expected to increase by 23.4 percent to reach NT$2 trillion, the highest level since 2004.
Gross national product per capita is projected at a record high of US$18,565, up more than US$1,000 from last year.
Tsai Hung-kun, chief of the DGBAS's Third Department, however, mentioned some uncertainties that could slow down economic growth in the second half of the year.

These include tightening of international monetary policy, termination of economic stimulus measures, and tightening measures likely to be adopted by emerging countries to prevent asset bubbles, he said. (Aug. 20, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Tsai said the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement is gradually producing its effect, with the tariff reduction for China-bound exports expected to boost Taiwan's economic growth by 0.4 percentage points in 2011.
The DGBAS forecast a 4.64 percent economic growth for Taiwan in 2011. (Aug. 20, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Brace for potential threat from Chinese students

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislative Yuan passed three packages of legal amendments Thursday to pave the way for the opening of local tertiary educational institutions to Chinese students.

Although some restrictions, including a ban on enrolling them on security- sensitive courses and on their participation in civil service exams, have been imposed, the open-door program still could lead to irredeemable calamity for Taiwan if the government fails to adopt measures to nip problems in the bud.
With a common language and similar cultural backgrounds, Chinese students will find it easier to stay in Taiwan after graduation than their peers from other countries.

The government has been unable to effectively address the problems involving Chinese citizens illegally working in Taiwan through marriages of convenience, and this plight could be exacerbated by the entry of 1,000 to 2,000 Chinese students into local campuses around Taiwan every year. Can our government effectively manage them?

If Chinese students take part-time jobs at lower wages that locals are prepared to accept, they might not only squeeze local students' job opportunities but could also drive down local wage levels. Are our law enforcement authorities competent enough to cope with such challenges?

Most alarming of all, will Chinese students and businessmen operating here get involved in major political events in Taiwan en masse? Local people should be prepared for all these potential threats. (editorial abstract -- Aug. 20, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's wealth gap widening: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 12:14:18 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's household income gap widened in 2009, with the average annual disposable income of the richest families reaching 6.34 times that of the poorest, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

It was the second-widest gap since 2001, when the average income of the richest 20 percent of local families was 6.39 times that of the poorest 20 percent, according to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The DGBAS attributed the widening wealth gap in part to the global economic crunch that fueled record high unemployment in Taiwan last year.
If social welfare subsidies and tax benefits are excluded, the income gap between the two groups hit an all-time high of 8.22 times the 2009 average, DGBAS officials said.

The survey divides families into five brackets in terms of annual disposable income, with the top 20 percent defined as the richest and the bottom 20 percent as the poorest. The largest income gap between these two brackets was 6.39 times, recorded in 2001.

The latest survey found that the average annual disposable income in the richest group of families reached NT$1.79 million (US$56,113) in 2009, compared to NT$282,000 for those in the poorest bracket.

The average annual disposable income in Taiwan stood at NT$888,000 per household last year, or NT$266,000 per household member, representing year-on- year declines of 2.9 percent and 2.6 percent, respectively, according to the DGBAS.
The average household savings made last year also marked the largest decline of any year, the survey found.

The wealth gap was narrowed 1.88 times last year as a result of comprehensive efforts by the government, said Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Nevertheless, Liu said, government welfare subsidies and tax breaks would not be a cure-all in terms of changing the structural fundamental of the gap between rich and poor.
"Only when the country's economy is powered by the dual engines of exports and domestic consumption can the problem of uneven distribution of wealth be addressed," Liu said.
"Investing in Taiwan, particularly in the service sector, is the key," she suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Belgian scholarship winners looking forward to visiting Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 13:07:39 (By Tsao Yu-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Twelve Belgian students who won scholarships from the Taiwanese government and were scheduled to leave for Taiwan Thursday to start Chinese language studies have expressed their high expectations for their visit to Taiwan.

One of students, identified only by the Chinese name Kang Mei-hsi, is the only scholarship winner this year under the Taiwan Scholarship Program. She studied at Wenzao Ursuline College of Languages in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan for five months last year under a student exchange program and said that Taiwan left a deep impression on her.
This time, she plans to stay in Taiwan for three years and will apply for a translation degree program at Kaohsiung's National Sun Yat-sen University, she said.
The other 11 scholarship winners, under the Ministry of Education's Huayu Enrichment Scholarship Program, will also come to Taiwan in the coming days.

One of them, again identified only by the Chinese name Ou Mei-jung, has studied Chinese in China and said she is fascinated with works of Chinese playwright and author of humorous, satirical novels and short stories Lao She. Ou is set to study Chinese literature at National Taiwan Normal University.

Taiwan's representative to the EU and Belgium David Lin said he was pleased to learn that Belgian young people are interested in visiting Taiwan and he recommended them to experience Taiwan's high speed rail and visit night markets during their stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Powerchip to raise 2010 capital expenditure by 40 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 13:15:52 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: An official of memory chip maker Powerchip Technology Corp. said Friday that the company has decided to raise its 2010 capital expenditure by about 40 percent for a production technology upgrade.

The board of directors has approved the proposal to hike the company's capital expenditure to NT$17 billion (US$533 million) from the previously planned NT$12 billion, said Powerchip spokesman Eric Tan.

"We aim to speed up the pace of migrating to the 45 nanometer production process from the current 63nm, " Tan said, adding that "the technology upgrade is expected to be completed in the middle of 2011," financed by the additional funds.
Tan said that as Powerchip has turned profitable in the first half of this year, there are no problems for the company meeting the fund demand.

In the first six months of this year, Powerchip posted NT$10.3 billion (US$322.65 million) in net profits on a recovery of global demand for dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips after a net loss of NT$20.7 billion recorded for the whole of 2009.
In 2008, Powerchip incurred NT$57.5 billion in net losses.
Due to the large accumulated net losses, the Financial Supervisory Commission in July turned down an application by Powerchip to issue up to US$179 million-worth of global depository receipts.
Tan said the rejection of the application has had no impact on the plan to hike its capital expenditure for the production technology upgrade.

Michael Chiang, an analyst with Taiwan International Securities, said it is necessary for DRAM makers to advance their production technology as DRAM prices are weakening now as the pace of the global economy recovery has appeared to slow.
"A higher end production process is expected to cut DRAM makers' operating costs," Chiang said.
"With operating costs down, the impact from falling product prices is expected to be offset," he said.
Powerchip rivals such as Nanya Technology Corp. and Inotera Memories, Inc. are also gearing up for technology upgrades for the same purpose, Chiang went on.
In addition, Powerchip said it will submit a GDR application again at some as- yet unspecified time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Income gap at alarming levels

TEXT.P: The prevalence of capitalism around the globe has led to a widening gap between the rich and the poor. Not only has the gap between rich and poor countries become enlarged, a similar predicament can also be seen in society.
The latest statistics released by the Cabinet show that the income gap between Taiwan's richest and poorest households has widened 66 times over the past 11 years.

In 2008, the average annual income of the top 5 percent wage earners amounted to NT$4.5 million (US$140,625) , compared to an average of NT$68,000 grossed by those in the bottom 5 percent bracket. In comparison, the income gap between the two groups was only 32 times 10 years previously in 1998.

The 2008-2009 global financial crisis could have contributed to the broadening of the wealth gap, as more people lost their jobs or saw their wages cut during the economic recession, while rich people at the pinnacle of the income pyramid remained intact.

Even though Taiwan might be able to achieve a 7 percent GDP growth rate this year, the wealth gap is not expected to narrow much because of the ever-rising ratio of "triangle trade" in the country's overall foreign trade.
"Triangle trade" refers to order-taking in Taiwan, production taking place in China and goods finally exported to third destinations such as America and Europe.

The ratio already shot up from 13 percent in 2000 to 50 percent in June this year. The triangle trade might help drive Taiwan's economic growth rate up, but only exporting companies and their shareholders will enjoy the fruits, while most other people and the domestic consumer market will not experience any positive impact, as revenues from this kind of trade are usually banked abroad.

In the face of this development, the government should craft a sound tax system and adjust the tax rate from time to time to ensure more equitable distribution of wealth while not scaring away investors. Otherwise, the rise of an anti- mercantile complex could be an ominous sign of social instability. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 20, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice wine issue hinges on international agreement: ex-WTO official
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 13:57:05 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A key question in Taiwan's controversial decision to cut the excise tax on rice wine is whether the move has violated the principle of equal treatment for imported and locally produced goods, a former World Trade Organization (WTO) official said Thursday.

Based on that principle, which is laid out in Article III of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the U.S. and European countries believe that Taiwan's excise tax on imported alcoholic and tobacco products should also apply to local products, Roderick Abbott, a former deputy director-general of the WTO, told the CNA.

Rice wine, which is used as a cooking ingredient in Taiwan, will soon be subject to a lower excise tax as the Legislative Yuan amended the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Act on Thursday to categorize the product as cooking wine, rather than a distilled spirit.

At present, distilled spirits are subject to an excise tax of NT$2.5 per liter of alcohol. The tax on a 0.6-liter bottle of red-label rice wine that contains 19.5 percent alcohol is NT$29.25, if it is taxed as a distilled spirit.

The excise tax on cooking wines is NT$9 per liter, regardless of their alcohol levels. Taxing rice wine as a cooking ingredient will drop the excise tax on red-label rice wine to NT$5.4 per bottle, which will in effect decrease its price from NT$50 to NT$25 per bottle.
The matter has raised the concerns among the United States and the European Union countries.

The Office of the United States Trade Representative on Thursday said the U.S. expects that "all WTO members will abide by their WTO obligations." But it declined to comment on the possibility of WTO litigation over the issue.
According to Abbott, the WTO does not accept the idea of different treatment for alcoholic products based on their ingredients.
For example, he said, the WTO determines that wheat-based whisky and grape-based cognac should be subject to the same level of tax because they are both liquor.
The WTO believes that alcohol level, rather than ingredients, should determine the tax categories for alcoholic products, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meeting of Europe-based Taiwanese to focus on attracting investment
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 14:14:33 (By Y.F. Tsao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission Minister Wu Ying-yih was scheduled to deliver a speech Friday in Belgium during the opening of an annual meeting of Taiwanese compatriot groups in Europe with the aim of encouraging Europe-based Taiwanese businessmen to return and invest in Taiwan, event organizers said Thursday.

With the meeting coming in the wake of the Legislative Yuan's ratification of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China Aug. 17 and the government's Aug. 19 upward revision of its GDP (gross domestic product) growth forecast for this year from 6.4 percent to a 21-year high of 8.24 percent, Wu will focus his speech on attracting overseas investment to Taiwan.

Wu said Thursday that in his speech, he will expound on the commission's goals, such as strengthening contact with Taiwanese businesses in Europe, enhancing economic and trade relations with them and bringing actions into line with national policy.

Its tasks also include planning activities to celebrate the centennial of the founding of the Republic of China next year, promoting private participation in the i-Taiwan 12 major infrastructure projects, encouraging the return of overseas capital, talent and technology to Taiwan and pushing Taiwanese expatriates in Europe to return and purchase property in Taiwan, according to Wu.

Taiwan's representative to France Michel Ching-long Lu and Taiwan's representative to the EU and Belgium David Lin will also speak on Taiwan's national competitiveness and the current situation in Taiwan-Europe relations, respectively, during the meeting. In addition, a seminar promoting investment in Taiwan will be held.
The meeting is expected to gather more than 100 Taiwanese expatriates living in Britain, France, Germany, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and Sweden, according to the event organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close little changed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 15:29:33 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Friday as rotational buying lifted old economy stocks to offset the impact of a Wall Street dive overnight amid global economic concerns, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 1.63 points or 0.02 percent to 7,927.31, after moving between 7,905.01 and 7,941.61 on turnover of NT$101.18 billion (US$3.17 billion).
The market opened flat, down 1.38 percent, but selling set in immediately to drag down the index to the day's low because of Wall Street's volatility, the dealers said.
However, rotational buying emerged to support the traditional industrial sector on optimism about their profitability, helping the broader market recoup earlier losses, they said.
A total of 1,436 stocks closed up and 2,115 were down, with 292 remaining unchanged.
The construction sector posted the highest gains, up 2.5 percent. Cement stocks rose 0.9 percent, textile shares added 0.7 percent and financial issues gained 0.5 percent.

The paper and pulp sector closed up 0.3 percent, and the plastics and chemical sector was 0.1 percent higher, while foodstuffs fell 0.6 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks ended down 0.4 percent.

"Buying in old economy stocks was the result of renewed hopes of rising economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait after the signing of the major trade pact with China," Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
Taiwan and China inked the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in late June, paving the way for closer bilateral business ties.

"The ECFA has prompted investors to speculate that more Chinese funds will enter the country to boost local commercial property prices, " Lin said, referring to the rebound posted by the construction sector.
"The trade pact is going to deliver a lasting positive impact on the local economy. The local bourse, therefore, appeared resilient despite a steep fall on U.S. markets," Lin said.
However, turnover was reduced as many investors remained on the sidelines, Lin said.
"Fears of further jitters on Wall Street kept investors from going on a buying spree that would have brought the local index out of the current period of consolidation," Lin said.
He said investors should cut stock holdings to 50 percent or less in their portfolios and keep as much cash as they can while waiting for fresh cues to act.

In the construction sector, Prince Housing gained 6.91 percent to close at NT$17.80, Cathay Real Estate rose 5.26 percent to end the day at NT$16.00 and Kuo Yang Construction added 2.90 percent to finish trading at NT$23.10.
However, flat panel maker Chimei Innolux fell 1.76 percent to NT$36.30 and PC vendor Acer lost 2.37 percent to end at NT$82.30 on the latest NASDAQ fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not splurge on centennial celebrations: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 15:42:02 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will not squander money on the celebrations to mark its 100th founding anniversary, President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

The budget for the activities that will be held this year and into 2011 will be roughly NT$3.2 billion (US$100.3 million) , one-sixth of the amount spent on the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and about half of the cost of the 2009 Deaflympics Taipei, Ma said.
He said he was deeply moved by the many offers by individuals to volunteer their time to help prepare for the celebrations.

Over the past 100 years, the Republic of China, founded by Dr. Sun Yat-sen on the Chinese mainland on Oct. 10, 1911, has weathered political twists and turns and has grown into a full-fledged democracy and an economic powerhouse based on Taiwan, Ma said.
"Today's Taiwan is a model of democratization for all Chinese societies around the world," he said.

He said Aug. 20 is a particularly significant date as it marks the founding of the Chinese Revolutionary League by Sun in 1906. This was the seed that grew into the 1911 Revolution, which in turn led to the collapse of the Qing Dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China, the president said at a press conference to launch the ROC centennial celebrations.

At the function, Vice President Vincent Siew said centennial events that have already been finalized include a rally in Taipei on Oct. 10 this year, a national gala in Taichung on the night of Oct. 10, 2011, and a huge concert -- the largest ever in Asia -- on Nov. 12, 2011 in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature keeps health insurance bill for next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 15:59:37 (By Chen Ching-fang, Chou Yung-chieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will not review a bill concerning the introduction of a second-generation National Health Insurance (NHI) program until next week, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator said Friday.
Lin Yi-shih, who is also director-general of the KMT's Policy Committee, told reporters that the legislature would take a break Friday because it had been busy for the previous four days.

The Legislative Yuan is holding a two-week special session Aug. 17-30 to deal with a number of priority bills. Items that already cleared the legislative floor earlier in the week include the economic cooperation framework agreement with China and several bills regarding the admission of Chinese students to Taiwanese universities and colleges.
The proposed amendment to the National Health Insurance Act is the only item on the agenda that was not reviewed during the session.

The bill mainly involves a new scheme for calculating premiums based on total household incomes rather than the existing system, which considers only individuals' salaries and wages. The change is considered essential to saving the cash-strapped program.
Legislators, however, were not optimistic about the bill's passage during the special session in light of the many controversies involved.

According to Huang Sue-ying of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, the legislature should not hurry the bill through without full discussion, given that there are 26 clauses in the bill that are highly disputable.
The KMT's Yang Li-huan said resolving the many structural problems regarding the NHI system is more important than changing the premium calculation method.
One urgent issue is how to control excessive medical procedures, which are generating very lucrative profits for medical institutions and leading to constantly expanding NHI expenditure, Yang said.
She also urged the Department of Health to compute the cost of keeping the insurance system operating.

Lin Hung-chih, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said that if the bill fails to clear the legislature in the special session, he hopes it can be listed as a priority for the next regular legislative session due to begin in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese people leading miserable lives under KMT rule: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 16:40:09 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators said Friday that Taiwanese people are leading miserable lives under the rule of the Kuomintang.

Citing six economic and social indices, Kuan Bi-ling, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said at a press conference that the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has created more people living technically below the poverty line than the previous DPP government.

The levels of substantive wages and salaries have continued to decline, while the number of people working temporary or dispatch jobs has increased, with their hourly payments diminishing, according to Kuan.

She said the unit price of a new property in Taipei City had skyrocketed to NT$624,000 (US$19,500) per ping (3.3 square meters) of floor space as of July this year, up from NT$553,000 per ping in 2006.
"Home buyers should eat nothing and drink nothing for 28 consecutive years to save enough money for a new apartment in the capital," she claimed.

DPP Legislator Wong Chin-chu said meanwhile that general wages and salaries in Taiwan have not grown for 10 years and that the current monthly average of substantive salary totals only NT$34,326, the lowest in 11 years.
The number of unemployed people aged between 45 and 49 totaled 65,000 in 2009, compared to 39,000 posted in 2008, according to Wong.
The number of families living under the poverty line stood at 93,000 in 2008, a figure that soared to 105,000 in 2009 and further to 108,000 by the second quarter of this year, Wong said.
"The Ma administration's tax reduction drives have benefited only business conglomerates," Wong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan two games away from Junior League World Series title
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 16:57:07 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan beat Mexico 8-5 at the 2010 Junior League Baseball World Series Thursday in the United States to reach the final four of the tournament.

The Chung-Ching Junior Little League team from Taipei had already defeated teams from Guatemala (7-2), Ukraine (13-0) and Canada (10-0) in round robin play, and completed a clean sweep of the five-team international pool with its win over the Mexican team from Guaymas.

Taiwan will face Guatemala, the second-place finisher in the international pool, again Friday U.S. time to vie for the international championship. The winner will play the U.S. champion Saturday U.S. time for the World Series title.
The Junior League Baseball World Series, being played in Taylor, Michigan, is the "older brother" of the better known Little League World Series played every year in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
The Junior League is for 13- and 14-year-olds while Little League is for 11- and 12-year-olds.
Teams from the Asia-Pacific region have only been playing in the Junior League World Series since 1999, and no team representing the region has ever won the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation to buy fruits from Tainan County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 17:08:49 (By Yang Ssu-jui and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: A group of buyers from China agreed Friday to purchase NT$10 million-worth of agricultural products from the Tsou-Ma-Lai Recreational Farm in Tainan County as part of economic cooperation efforts between Taiwan and China.

The delegation, from Guangdong Province's agricultural and fishing institutions, signed an agreement with the Tainan County Farmers' Association to buy pineapples, guavas, sugar apples and other produce grown in the county's Danei township.

The agreement was signed at a trade fair that is being held as part of a Taiwan- Guangdong week of activities and was witnessed by Guangdong Provincial Governor Huang Huahua and Taiwan's People First Party Chairman James Soong.

Soong said at the function that the recent signing of a cross-Taiwan strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) has helped to open up new opportunities for economic exchanges and will bring more business from China.
He expressed the hope that Guangdong buyers will continue to contribute to bilateral industrial and agricultural cooperation.
The group, headed by Huang, is scheduled to return to China Aug. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 17:14:29 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at the day's high of NT$31.935.
Turnover totaled US$440 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.930 and moved to a low of 31.909 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Belgian Sinologists promote Taiwan's online dictionary project
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 19 (CNA) 08/20/10 17:24:35 (By Tsao Yu-fang and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The online Mandarin Chinese dictionary compiled by Taiwan's Ministry of Education (MOE) is a powerful tool for foreign students learning Chinese, a senior Belgian journalist said Thursday.
Catherine Vuylsteke, the Asian page editor of the Belgian daily De Morgen, is now studying Chinese at National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan.
Vuylsteke expressed her appreciation of the dictionary in an e-mail to the Taipei Representative Office in Belgium. She also promised to help promote the tool to Chinese language teachers in Antwerp.
In addition to Vuylsteke, 11 other Belgian scholars and journalists have promised to help promote the dictionary.
The dictionary contains nearly 170,000 entries and has become the biggest Chinese dictionary data bank in the world, according to ministry officials.
The dictionary allows input using the zhuyin fuhao phonetic system, or "bopomofo, " and provides definitions in Chinese.
As of Friday, the dictionary had tallied more than 100 million visits. The dictionary can be found online at dict.revised.moe.edu.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts advise airport to improve policy implementation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 17:36:04 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A task force set up to improve the management of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport concluded a review meeting Friday with the consensus that the airport should prioritize strengthening its policy implementation and addressing human error issues.

Chang Yu-hern, head of the task force set up by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , said the panel has mapped out plans for improving airport management, including gathering information on passenger satisfaction by conducting focus group discussions and public opinion polls among airport workers.

According to information collected by the task force, passengers are most dissatisfied with the airport's 16 service items, including the bad and overpriced food sold at the airport, defective equipment such as luggage trolleys and unclear direction signs in the transit area.

As every member of the task force has been informed of the problems listed in the report, the most important thing is how to carry out improvement work in order to enhance the competitiveness of the airport, the country's main gateway.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Luo Shu-lei said the suggestions for resolving up to 100 problems at the airport raised by airline companies during the meeting were very helpful, but she also said human factors can help explain why the problems are there.
She suggested that the airport management should find out who is responsible for the problems and remove anyone found to be unsuitable for their position.

Noting that President Ma Ying-jeou has allocated a lot of money to lift the airport into the ranks of the world's best, Luo said it is evident that money is not the problem and that what matters most is how to improve staff management.

Pointing to a leaking toilet that left part of a terminal flooded and stinking for several hours earlier this month, Luo said that even though the airport operations control center must have obtained images of the leak from its video monitoring system, nobody made a report on the matter, which she said points to a management problem.
If the airport fails to address issues of human error, all its efforts go to improve efficiency will be in vain, she pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q2 communications equipment output value in Taiwan up 16 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 18:00:17 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The output value of the local communications equipment sector rose 16 percent in the second quarter of this year from a year earlier on the back of strong demand for consumer electronics products, a government report said Friday.

In the April-June period, increasing demand for cell phones and wireless local area network (WLAN) related products boosted the overall production value of the local communications equipment sector to NT$191.5 billion (US$6.0 billion), according to a quarterly report released by the Industry and Technology Intelligence Service (ITIS).
The second quarter figure was also 16.9 percent higher than in the first quarter of this year, the report said.
The ITIS is a research institute of the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The report said the output value of the cell phone segment totaled NT$78 billion in the second quarter of this year, up 34.3 percent from a year earlier and up 8 percent sequentially.
Smartphones accounted for more than 70 percent of the production value of the overall cell phone segment during the period, the ITIS said.
The production value of the global positioning system (GPS) segment reached NT$33.5 billion in Q2, up 52.3 percent from the first quarter but down 2.9 percent from a year earlier, it said.
The production value of the WLAN segment rose 42.8 percent from a year earlier and 5 percent from the previous quarter to NT$19.8 billion in Q2, the report added.

The digital subscriber line consumer premise equipment (DSL CPE) segment totaled NT$12.7 billion during the period, up 12.4 percent from a year earlier and also up 16.5 percent from the first quarter, the ITIS said.
Rising demand for smartphones is expected to further lift production value of the personal mobile communications device segment in the third quarter.
The segment's output value should rise 20.9 percent from the second quarter to hit NT$136.1 billion, the institute predicted.
The overall communications equipment sector is expected to see 22.3 percent year-on-year growth and 16.8 percent sequential growth to total NT$223.6 billion, the institute added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Student group threatens lawsuit over revised diploma law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 18:09:14 (By Lin Szu-yu and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: An association of Taiwanese students studying in China threatened Friday to take legal action against a newly approved package of legal amendments that restrict the recognition of medical diplomas conferred by schools in China.
Chen Cheng-teng, deputy head of the Taiwan Student Union (TWSU) said the restrictions will prevent Taiwanese graduates of Chinese medical colleges from working in Taiwan in the coming years.
"Such a restriction seriously infringes upon their legitimate rights as Republic of China citizens to work," Chen said.

In contrast to Taiwan's recognition of accreditation of medical schools in other countries around the world, the restrictions on the recognition of Chinese medical diplomas also violates the principle of administrative fairness, Chen said.

"Our association will retain a lawyer to file for a constitutional interpretation of the restriction from the Justices of Constitutional Court, " Chen said, adding that the group will also take the issue to administrative court.

Meanwhile, he went on, the TWSU will also file an administrative lawsuit against newly passed regulations that ban retroactive recognition of accreditation by 41 selected Chinese colleges and universities.

"That ban also is a stark violation of the principle of administrative fairness, since our government has traditionally allowed retroactive recognition of diplomas issued by legally accredited foreign tertiary educational institutions," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: July export orders fourth highest on record
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 19:25:19 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders posted their fourth-highest monthly total on record in July, but decreased compared with the previous month, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

Taiwan's export orders in July totaled US$33.83 billion, up 18.23 percent from a year earlier, on strong overseas demand for microchips and printed circuit board (PCB) products, according to the ministry.
The figure is only lower than that in March, April and June.
Huang Ji-shih, the head of the ministry's statistics department, said at a press briefing that Taiwan's export order value was expected to further rise in August.
With inventory adjustments, orders for all products except for electronics dropped in July. Electronics orders set their second-highest single-month record at US$8.36 billion.
Orders from China, including Hong Kong, totaled US$9.07 billion, compared with a record high of US$9.8 billion.
Meanwhile, orders from Europe totaled US$5.32 billion, compared with a record of US$6.6 billion, the ministry said.
Export orders indicate deliveries three months in advance and are considered a key economic indicator.
Taiwan's economy depends on exports, more than 40 percent of which go to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's water supply maintained by intense afternoon showers: CWB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 19:51:53 (By Wang Shu-fen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Although no typhoons have approached Taiwan so far this year, the water supply will remain sufficient until the end of the year thanks to intense afternoon showers, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Friday.

Typhoons, which usually occur in the period July-September, are the major source of rainfall in Taiwan, the CWB said, noting that it is unusual that there have been none so far this year. Taiwan gets hit by an average of three typhoons per year, it said.

The volume of plum rains, which are also vital to the maintenance of Taiwan's water supply, has decreased due to the impact of La Nina, a phenomenon associated with cooler than normal water temperatures in the Pacific Ocean, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists push for shutdown of new nuclear plant over safety issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 20:07:25 (By Sophia Yeh, Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Environmental activists rallied outside the Control Yuan Friday, asking the government watchdog to censure two agencies over alleged safety problems at a nuclear power plant being built in northern Taiwan.

The activists blamed the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and the top nuclear power regulatory body, the Atomic Energy Council (AEC), for the frequent occurrence of accidents during the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant in Taipei County's Gongliao Township.

Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Chairman Wang Chun-shou urged that work on the plant be suspended until its design and installment flaws are corrected, expressing particularly strong opposition to a trial run with nuclear fuel rods at the end of this year.

The government hopes the plant can begin operating commercially by Oct. 10, 2011 to coincide with the Republic of China's 100th anniversary, but environmental groups fear the target date could jeopardize safety.

Wang denounced the year-end trial as a "political show, " devised after Premier Wu Den-yih expressed the hope that the plant would open on the country's anniversary rather than at the end of the year as originally planned.

He said environmental protection organizations have exposed many construction flaws in the plant -- the fourth built in Taiwan -- including "deliberately changing the original designs and lowering the safety standards of the plant's parts.
"In the face of these public concerns, however, Taipower appears to have ignored them and continues to hastily build the facility, " Wang charged.

He also accused the AEC of being negligent in its duty to monitor the construction of the nuclear power plant, allowing Taipower to conduct tests despite reports of accidents caused by mechanical failure in recent months.
Local media reported that a major blackout occurred at the plant on July 9 with some 300,000 people gathered at a beach 200 meters away for the 2010 Hohaiyan Rock Festival.

Taipower later admitted at a meeting to review the accident that the company would not have been able to conduct an emergency evacuation of the massive crowds if it had been necessary, the reports said.
In response to the protest, Taipower executives admitted that "problems" have happened during tests on the new facility but insisted they could not be described as "accidents."

Taipower explained that the goal of the tests is to discover problems, and that the so-called "accidents" reported by the media were all "problems" unearthed by the company itself in its pursuit of absolute nuclear safety and quality.
Construction of the power plant was temporarily suspended in 2000 during the previous DPP administration in line with then-President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise to create a nuclear-free Taiwan.

The suspension, however, was lifted in early 2001 after the administration came under pressure from the legislature and segments of society. A consensus was reached that the fourth nuclear plant would be the last one built in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huge water screen to highlight 2011 New Year's countdown bash
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 20:45:59 (By Lee Chia-fei and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The world's biggest water screen will make its debut during the upcoming New Year's eve countdown celebration at Tachia Riverside Park, the organizers said Friday, but little else was revealed about the event that is being cloaked in mystery.

Details of the show are "confidential" because of the desire to push art and the audience experience to a whole new level, said Lin Hwai-min, a renowned choreographer and founder of Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, on behalf of all the artists participating in the program.

Described by creative director Lin Keh-hua as the largest-scale New Year's celebration ever to be held in Taiwan, the celebration in the park along the Keelung River will include fireworks, a flower exhibition and visual arts.

But one of the highlights will be when those at the park get to enjoy Alishan's famous scenic sunrise on the 200-meter wide water screen and listen to aboriginal music at the same time, the creative director said.

The event, which is being organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs and sponsored by the Taiwan Centenary Foundation, will also kick off celebrations for the 100th anniversary of the Republic of China, founded in 1911.

Emile Sheng, who heads both organizations, said the program will showcase Taiwan's diversity and creativity to the international community, and evoke a sense of national spirit that will help Taiwanese courageously launch the country's next 100 years.

Artists from different parts of the world have been invited to contribute their ideas to the program, including America-based contemporary artist Cai Guo-Qiang, Hong Kong lighting designer Leo Cheung, and Bruno Schnebelin of Ilotopie, a French theater.
All citizens are invited to come to the plaza in front of the Presidential Office for a flag-raising ceremony after the countdown, Sheng said.

The Taiwan Symphony Orchestra, the Taipei Philharmonic Orchestra and eight other musical groups have been invited to perform the national anthem, to be sung by Taiwanese soprano Hong Yu-jing, who finished fourth in the first Singapore International Vocal Competition this year.
In addition, the president will preside over a group wedding ceremony for 100 couples, Sheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP says amendment aimed at former president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 21:04:35 (By Sophia Yeh, Johnson Sun, Chang Che-fon and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday a legislative amendment that scraps benefits for ex-presidents or vice presidents found guilty of corruption at a first trial targets former President Chen Shui-bian.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said that although Chen's case is not yet finished, the legislature has been in a rush to deprive him of his benefits.
"For the public, this act represents a lack of the kindness that is characteristic of Taiwanese people," Tsai said.
Su Tseng-chang, a former premier and the DPP candidate for Xinbei City, said the revision seemed to be very "specific" in targeting former president Chen.
Su said he respected the legislature's decision, but pointed out that "overly political and controversial legislation will certainly widen the confrontation between the ruling and opposition camps."

Chen Chih-chung, the son of the detained former president and a candidate for the Kaohsiung City Council, called the amendment "vindictive" and said the move violated the principle of presumed innocence.

He also said that the amendment will cost the family dearly, as medical bills for his mother, who has been paralyzed from the waist down since 1985, are nearly NT$200,000 per month, and he is busy with campaign activities.
Chen Shui-bian's office will also face closure due to lack of funds, he said.
"The KMT has taken the vindictive move for the sake of the municipality elections, " he said, urging voters to speak with their ballots in the year-end elections.
The legislative revision of the statute was cleared during an extra session of the legislature on Thursday.

Originally, only former presidents and vice presidents convicted of sedition or treason would have their benefits scrapped. Chen, even though he has been convicted of corruption in the first and second trials and is presently being detained, has still received the benefits and preferential treatment accorded all former presidents.

But under the amended law, former leaders convicted of corruption in the first trial will be stripped of a monthly payment of NT$250,000 and personnel and other miscellaneous fees that amount to NT$8 million in the first year after stepping down, NT$7 million in the second year, and NT$6 million in the third year. Between the fourth and eighth years, the amount averages NT$5 million annually.
Security escorts will also be cut from the present eight to 12 guards to two or three.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX to hit 10,000 points in 'golden decade': CLSA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 21:05:33 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange Index (TAIEX) will likely hit the 10,000 point mark and stay above that level in the "golden decade" between 2010-2019 amid improving business ties across the Taiwan Strait, according to a CLSA Asia- Pacific Markets report released Thursday.

The report said the market began a turnaround after President Ma Ying-jeou of the China-friendly Kuomintang (KMT) took office in May 2008 by beating the pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the presidential elections.

On his second anniversary in office in May, Ma outlined a vision to build a "golden decade" for Taiwan's economic development by pushing for innovation, culture and environmental protection, while promising to enhance social welfare and promote peace with China to protect the island.
"The (KMT's) victory...sparked a positive turnaround in the Taiwan Stock Exchange Index after it had been among the worst performers in emerging markets over the previous decade, " the report said.
"While a cyclical downturn brings down our short term target to 6,800 (points) , we believe the index will undergo a phase shift, surpass and stay above 10,000 in the coming decade," it added.
The index closed at 7,927.31 on Friday.

The report said Taiwan has moved from a concept of "capital links" in which the island and China were expected to establish full economic ties, to the beginning of a payoff stage, in particular after the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with the mainland in late June.

With closer capital links with China, CLSA said, Taiwan will see "tremendous economic benefits" as the ECFA will grant it preferential status in tariff reductions and easier market access for 539 kinds of Taiwanese merchandise and services.
The trade pact is expected to serve as a springboard to signing further economic agreements with other countries as well, it said.
"We are excited about the possibility of a golden decade for Taiwan over 2010-19," the report said.

"We also believe this Capital Links-led outperformance will allow the benchmark (index) to overcome strong historical resistance, enabling it to surpass and remain above 10,000 points for most of this golden decade," it added.

In the report, CLSA recommended a buy on Asia Cement, Chinatrust Financial, China Airlines, EVA Airways, Far Eastern New Century, Huaku Development, President Chain Store, Uni-President Enterprises and Taiwan Fertilizer when the index hits a predicted cyclical downturn in the fourth quarter of this year or the first quarter of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: School battery recycling program yields fruitful results: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 21:20:55 (by Lee Hsien-feng and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Batteries recycled through a school program during the 2009-2010 school year amounted to 402 metric tons, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Friday.

The EPA, which helped launch the project seven years ago to teach children the importance of minimizing waste, said the average battery recycling rate between 2007 and 2009 reached 48 percent, passing the European Union's minimum battery collection target of 45 percent by 2016.

Among the 3,041 schools participating in the program in the 2009-2010 school year, 140 schools made the distinguished list and 56 schools will be awarded up to NT$100,000 (US$3,125), said Lee Shou-chien, department director of the Recycling Fund Management Board.

There were 238 more schools and 25,000 more students taking part in the recycling program than in the previous year, said the EPA, adding that 75 percent of the schools around the island were actively involved.
The EPA urged schools to continue promoting the zero waste concept and education about recycling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ammunition depots should be turned into tourist spots
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 21:22:05 (By Sophie Yeh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Four unused ammunition depots on a small islet in Penghu County built during Japanese colonial rule should be rehabilitated and turned into new tourist attractions, three Control Yuan members said Friday.

The three members -- Lee Ping-nan, Yu Teng-fang and Chou Yang-shan -- made the recommendation after completing an extensive study of the century-old ammunition depots in Penghu's remote Siyu township near Nisin Bay in the Taiwan Strait.
Three of the depots, built close together on the islet, had bronze plates as their inner walls and were equipped with airtight windows and two iron gates at each of their entrances.

Those features had led some to believe that the depots were toxic gas chambers or biochemical weapon research labs, Lee said, but an extensive study showed the speculation to be unfounded because their design and equipment did not live up to the standards for such facilities.
Moreover, samples of air, soil, water and 10 other items collected at the location did not test positive for traces of any toxic gases or chemicals, he added.
After extensive discussion with military historians and ancient ammunition experts, Lee said they concluded that the three depots were used to store smokeless ammunition.
"They have existed since 1907 when Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule, " Lee said, noting that they are the only depots of their kind ever to be found in Taiwan.
After World War II, the Republic of China government took control of the depots, which continued to serve as depots for a nearby army base and are now abandoned.

There is another abandoned depot in their vicinity, which was also built by the Japanese during their period of colonial rule, Lee said. The depot has brick outer walls and wooden inner walls and its floor stands one meter high, a design believed to be helpful in fighting humidity.

According to Lee, cultural heritage experts from the Council for Cultural Affairs and the Penghu County government who joined his team in surveying the four structures agreed that the depots should be designated national historic sites subject to special protection for their historical and cultural value.

"Given their rarity, special architectural features and building technologies, they should be preserved and refurbished to serve as tourist attractions and as a resource for studying World War II history, " Lee said.
He said the Ministry of National Defense has agreed to transfer control of the four structures to the Penghu County government.
Meanwhile, Lee said his team is also looking for the remains of a Japanese naval base in Penghu used to train suicidal commandos during the final years of World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: International volunteers learn to make brooms in central Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 21:37:16 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Young international volunteers from South Korea, Hungary and Hong Kong learned to make brooms after helping with farmwork Friday at a community in Changhua County that was once a major production center of straw brooms.

A young Hungarian woman, identified only by her first name Reka, said that although brooms were common in her country, it was "new and exciting" to see the straw brooms at the volunteers' workstation in the Sishih community of the county's Fusing Township.

Twenty-two domestic and foreign volunteers at the Sishih workstation organized by volunteer group Vision Youth Action will stay in the community for two weeks to help with public services, including painting the outside walls of a broom museum.
On Friday, senior residents gave the group a lesson on how to make straw brooms.
While the well-practiced locals finished brooms in less than five minutes, most of the volunteers spent at least half an hour to complete the job.
"It's an unforgettable memory," Reka said.

Lin Ching, chief executive of the Sishih community development association, said he was touched by the young people's enthusiasm for public service and interest in the fading skill of making straw brooms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to offer aid to flood victims in China, Pakistan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 22:45:01 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Friday instructed relevant administrative departments to outline measures to offer aid to thousands of natural disaster victims in China and Pakistan.
Ma telephoned Premier Wu Den-yih and National Security Council Secretary-General Hu Wei-jen to give the instructions, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih- chiang said.
Lo said that Ma was deeply concerned about the heavy damage and casualties caused by massive flooding in Pakistan and China.

Citing Ma, Lo said Taiwan, also being a victim of extreme weather caused by climate change due to global warming, feels empathy for what people in the two countries experienced. Ma referred to massive flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot that killed more than 600 people in southern Taiwan last August.
The president said Taiwan, as part of the international community, should help friends deal with natural disasters, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists call for action from FPG
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 22:53:42 (By S. F. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Environmentalists and academics urged the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Friday to assume its social role by quickly heeding protesters' complaints after a blaze broke out in late July at a company refinery in Yunlin County's Mailiao Township -- the second of its kind in a month.
Taiwan Environmental Protection Union representatives, academics and legislators Tien Chiu-chin and Liu Chien-kuo issued the call at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Stressing that the government must not ignore the increased environmental pressure facing the country, they called for a moratorium on heavily polluting projects, including the planned expansion of FPG's Mailiao facility and another major petrochemical plan in Changhua County.
They also asked the FPG to adequately respond to Mailiao residents' demands after the latest fire at its No. 6 naphtha cracker.

FPG's sixth naphtha cracker has long enjoyed government-supported advantages, including low-cost water, low-interest bank loans and the use of industrial wharfs, said National Taiwan University Professor Shih Shin-min, adding that it is time for the group to give back to local residents.
Instead of resorting to lengthy legal procedures to solve disputes, he suggested FPG and local residents establish a mechanism for dealing with pollution-related matters and disputes.
The recent fire triggered anger among Mailiao residents, who have long endured pollution, contamination and a string of public security threats over the past decade.
The company has offered a combined NT$500 million in compensation, but local residents have demanded NT$30,000 each -- about NT$1.8 billion in total.

Earlier the same day, local residents staged a protest for the fourth straight day, blocking two roads to the complex and causing traffic chaos during the morning rush hour. Some carried mock coffins to the site.
Vehicles were backed up for about one kilometer along the roads from 6:30-8:30 a.m. before the protesters dispersed.
A committee of residents from neighboring Sihu Township issued a six-point statement calling for, among other things, the opening of stations to monitor pollution.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- High-tech tycoon turns pineapple into bestseller
DOC.DATELINE: 08/20/10 22:53:52 (Wealth Magazine 352)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: A high-tech business tycoon has turned two special varieties of pineapples grown in his hometown in central Taiwan into a snack that has been selling like hot cakes over the past year.

Hsu Ming-ren, chairman of Asian Information Technology Inc., has used Taiwan's No. 2 and No. 3 variety of Smooth Cayenne pineapples grown in Nantou County as the key ingredient to make "Sunnyhills" pineapple cakes, which closely resemble the fruit's natural flavor.

The snack emerged as an instant success and has attracted a huge following. Among its fans are Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou and BenQ Group Chairman K. Y. Lee, who have made "Sunnyhills" pineapple cakes one of their companies' major gift items.
While free giveaways have allowed the brand to gain visibility by word of mouth, Hsu believes the quality local ingredients are also an important factor in the brand's success.
"The filling of most pineapple cakes on the market is mixed with winter melon. But we use only Smooth Cayenne pineapple, which is sweet but also naturally sour," he said.

The "Sunnyhills" plant uses 10,000 pineapples a day now compared to 2,000 a day last year, and the amount could rise further once the company's new factory is completed. The current facility employs 70-80 people.

"We have bought up most of the pineapples in Nantou and are now buying more from Taiwan's southern counties of Tainan and Pingtung. Our current production barely meets local market demand, " said Hsu Sheng-ming, Hsu Ming-ren's younger brother who is in charge of daily operations, in explaining why the company has not been able to expand abroad as planned.

With its remote production location, the company does most of its business through phone orders or selling online, typical of recent market trends. Only in July did the company finally open a shop in Taipei.

Besides pineapple cakes, Sunnyhills has teamed up with Taiwan's Challenge Bioproducts Co., Ltd. to develop health foods using bromelain -- pineapple enzymes that can be extracted from the stems that are discarded while processing the fruit.

Challenge Bioproducts is supplying the enzyme, known for its anti-inflammatory effects, to global drug company Teva Pharmaceutical's MultiWound unit for its Debrase gel dressing that can remove damaged skin tissue from serious burn wounds.
The gel dressing, which is aiming to become an alternative to the surgical method currently used to remove damaged skin tissue, is now undergoing phase III clinical trials in the United States.
Challenge Bioproducts said it was the high quality enzyme from Taiwan's Smooth Cayenne pineapples that enabled Sunnyhills to become its exclusive supplier, beating competitors in Thailand.

"Sunnyhills is a career worth investing in and has the potential to surpass my business of distributing electronic components, " Hsu Ming-ren said, in talking about how he believes that through dedication the business can stand out among its competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to compete in World Firefighters Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 23:01:01 (by Wang Hung-kuo and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei County Fire Bureau dragon boat racing team held a ceremony ahead of its departure for South Korea to compete in the World Firefighters Games 2010, bureau chief secretary Chen Chung-yueh said Friday.
The World Firefighters Games 2010 in Daegu, South Korea will run from Aug. 21 to Aug. 29, attracting thousands of current, retired and volunteer firefighters to partake in 75 sporting events.
Chen said that the team once finished the 500 meter Taipei County Congressional Cup in 1 minute, 52 seconds, proving they are as capable as the national team that will compete in the Asian Games.
He added that the team is confident in their ability to win and is eager to prove that dragon boat racing is a part of Chinese tradition.
Tsai Chia-chen, a female drummer on the team, said that even though she is not as strong as her male counterparts, she loves the competition and will do her best to make the country proud.
Captain Su Pai-chuan said that the Australian and the U.K. teams won the previous two games because foreigners tend to be more fit and most had solid backgrounds in canoeing.
He added, however, that his team was more diligent and had been undergoing intensive training.
According to Su, the team will bring a "special weapon" with them to the game -- lightweight carbon-fiber paddles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Balance of payments surplus registered in Q2: Central Bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 23:09:45 (By Kao Chao-fen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) announced Friday that Taiwan registered an international balance of payments surplus of US$15.38 billion in the second quarter of this year, including US$10.56 billion in current account surplus and US$5.91 billion in financial account net inflows.

Taiwan listed a favorable balance of payments of US$13.4 billion in the first quarter, with US$9.93 billion in current account net inflows and US$2.4 billion in financial account surplus, according to the Central Bank.

The balance of payments stands for an overall record of a country's monetary transactions with other nations during a period of time, including three primary components: current account, financial account and capital account.
Current and financial accounts are usually used as major indicators to show the change in the international balance of payments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteers to be recruited to improve Taoyuan airport service
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 23:13:07 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Volunteers will be recruited to help improve service quality at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, an expert panel charged with drawing up an airport management improvement package said Friday.

The task force reached the decision after holding extensive discussions with 24 business executives in the hotel, management, catering, travel and other related professional fields as well as noted culinary and travel writers.
The team also suggested that the Taoyuan airport, the country's main gateway, operate like a hotel or introduce hotel management methods into its operations.

It further said the airport should develop itself into a "small yet beautiful" facility that leaves travelers dazzled and deeply impressed by every detail and blends "flying, living, leisure, and travel."

The task force was assembled by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) in July after the airport was afflicted by a host of problems and scandals, including leaky restrooms, poor facilities, expensive food and staff misconduct.

Chang Yu-hern, head of the task force, said the panel has mapped out plans for improving airport management, including gathering information on passenger satisfaction by conducting focus group discussions and public opinion polls among airport workers.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the team between July 23-27 at Taoyuan Airport's two terminals, passengers are most dissatisfied with 16 of the most important services at the airport.
Respondents were most critical of the high cost of food, followed by the lack of food and beverage options, and the airport's surrounding landscape.
Defective equipment such as luggage trolleys and unclear direction signs in the transit area were also panned by poll respondents.

The survey collected 678 valid samples, of which 60 percent were provided by Taiwanese passengers and 40 percent by foreign travelers. Among the respondents, business and general travelers accounted for 40 percent each; family visitors made up 11 percent and travelers in Taiwan for other reasons 9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County magistrate pans Yunlin counterpart
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 23:32:05 (By Chen Chao-fu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin on Friday accused "certain political figures" of being anti-business, saying that he would take it upon himself to solicit businesses to invest in the southern Taiwan.

Yang was apparently referring to his Yunlin counterpart, Su Chih-fen, who he suggested had "set a bad example" by leading protesters against the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) and asking for huge compensation in the wake of two fires at its petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin last month.
"Political figures and parties cannot act so strongly against the businesses or they will drive business away," he said.

He said a local government head should play the role of "coordinator, " adding that when several industrial incidents took place in his county, he dealt with them keeping "industrial safety, environmental protection, business survival and public interests" in mind.
He urged the public not to turn against the businesses when attaching importance to environmental protection.
He said Kaohsiung's economy has been slow over the past decade, and that if it can develop its economy, then many Kaohsiung residents won't have to leave their hometown to make a living.
He lauded Hon Hai Group, headed by Terry Gou, saying that a fund under the group opened an organic farm to help flood victims in the wake of Typhoon Morakot in August 2009.
He expressed hope that Hon Hai will set up its operations and cloud computing centers in Kaohsiung and said he would continue to solicit Hon Hai's investment in the southern Taiwan city and county.
In response, the DPP said it could not agree with Yang's remarks and dismissed them as a "campaign gambit."
Earlier this month, Yang announced his intention to run as an independent for mayor of Kaohsiung municipality after failing to get a nomination from the DPP.
"If the same incidents took place at FPG's plant in Renwu Township, Kaohsiung County, Yang would not have made such a remark, " DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang said.
Lin said that for Yunlin residents, the two fires last month are a big issue, and that the fears among them "can't be easily understood by outsiders."
The DPP is confident in Su's coordination efforts with the residents, the government and the business group, Lin said.

Su said that residents of Yunlin and Kaohsiung counties have "different values and demands" of their chiefs, adding that if Kaohsiung County residents ask Yang to do certain things, Yang would also have to comply.
Meanwhile, an environmental group accused Yang Friday of malfeasance for allegedly covering up for an amusement park in his county.

E-DA World released tens of thousands of tons of polluted water into the Gaoping River, a major source of drinking water for residents of greater Kaohsiung, polluting the drinking water of Kaohsiung residents, an official of the Taiwan Water Resources Conservation Alliance alleged.

DOC.HEADLINE: White tigers from China pledged to Kaohsiung in ceremony
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/10 23:46:28 (By Chang Che-fon and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A ceremony was held Friday to mark the donation of two white tigers from China's Guangzhou to Kaohsiung City on Friday.

Guangzhou Vice Mayor Wu Yimin presented symbolic pictures of the two tigers to his hosts, and Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang and Kaohsiung Tourism Bureau chief Lin Kun-shan accepted them.

Chuang also exchanged gifts with Guangzhou Mayor Wang Qingliang and accepted 15 million yuan (US$2.2 million) for schools in southern Taiwan that were damaged by flooding triggered by Typhoon Morakot last August.
Chuang said the two tigers, which are currently being kept in Xiangjiang Safari Park in Guangzhou, have been under quarantine and will be sent to Taiwan soon.
Chang Po-yu, director of Kaohsiung's Shoushan Zoo, said members of the zoo staff have prepared for the arrival of the two tigers based on their experience in raising similar breeds.

Roughly a dozen protesters led by city councilor Huang Chao-hsing appeared at the ceremony in opposition to the donation, saying that raising white tigers will set a negative example for animal protection.
