DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 21, 2010, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal- gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Liberty Times: Economic growth irrelevant to common people

TEXT.P: Data released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that Taiwan's economic growth reached 12.53 percent in the second quarter, with growth for the whole year expected to hit a 21-year- high of 8.24 percent.
Despite these brilliant figures, there are not many things that are worth celebrating by common people.

First, the double-digit growth is mainly the result of the lower basis for comparison, and overseas production activities by Taiwanese businesses could also distort their contribution to the country's economy.

Second, statistics issued on the same day by the DGBAS indicate that the income gap between the richest 20 percent of families in Taiwan and the poorest 20 percent rose to a record 8.22 times in 2009, demonstrating that wealth distribution is becoming increasingly polarized in Taiwan.
Also, Taiwan's unemployment rate of 5.2 percent remains the highest among Asia's four little dragons. For those people who have jobs, their real earnings are inferior to 13 years ago.

Furthermore, the economic performance by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou is built upon high indebtedness, with debt issued during his term expected to reach NT$1.3 trillion by next year. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Price cut for red-label rice wine imperative
DOC.DATELINE: 08/21/10 13:05:55 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan amended the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Act on Aug. 19 to cut the price of locally-produced rice wine -- a kitchen staple for Taiwanese families. The amendment, however, drew concerns from the United States and European Union countries.

While the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative advised Taiwan, being a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), to respect WTO regulations, former WTO Deputy Director-General Roderick Abbott said that the WTO will ponder the issue based on the question of whether Taiwan has violated the principle of equal treatment for imported and locally-produced products.

Facing the dissuasions, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said the price cut concerns local consumers' right and benefits, which he is 100 percent sure will not be harmed even if Taiwan is eventually ordered to resume the WTO-ruled tax rate after years of lawsuits within the international economic bloc.
The following are excerpts from the local media's coverage of this issue on Aug. 21:
China Times:

The new tax rate on rice wine is expected to take effect in September at the earliest, Ministry of Finance officials said. Though both the USTR and the American Institute in Taiwan appeared concerned over the planned tax adjustment, they have so far not moved to file a complaint with the WTO, the officials noted.

State-run Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor President Hsu An-hsuen said the company is ready to rename the "red-label rice wine" -- used as a cooking wine in Taiwan -- "red-label cooking rice wine, " which will be marketed at the price of NT$25 per 0.6-liter bottle after the amended act on tobacco and liquor tax goes into effect.
The red-label rice wine is currently sold at NT$50 per bottle.

Responding to U.S. concerns, Minister Lee said that it is unfair to levy the same tax rate on rice wine used for cooking as distilled spirits for drinking, when the two are used for different purposes. He reiterated that Taiwan has not violated the WTO's regulations on equal treatment of locally-produced and imported products.
Liberty Times:
Saying the tax reduction proposal was initiated after careful study, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials underlined that Taiwan did not violate any WTO regulations.
If worse comes to worse, Taiwan will resume the original tax rate on the rice wine if the WTO rules the tax cut is against its regulations, the officials said.

The newspaper, however, criticized the move to cut the price of rice wine as an intentional strategy carried out to "butter up" voters ahead of the influential mayoral elections of five municipalities in Taiwan in November. (Aug. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Good for nothing

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang-dominated Legislative Yuan recently amended a law to strip former presidents or former vice presidents of their retirement benefits if they are found guilty of rebellion, treason, or corruption at a first trial.
The amendment is legally disputable based on the principle of presumed innocence.

The blue camp commonly believes that the court's failure to convict corruption- plagued former President Chen Shui-bian rapidly was responsible for its defeat in various by-elections over the past year. The blues therefore decided to penalize Chen on behalf of the court to boost their campaign for the year-end special municipality elections.
Such a view is both superficial and flawed.

Chen's response, on the other hand, is very shameful. He said the amendment will leave him a beggar after his release from jail. But he was obviously faking a pitiful situation, in light of the luxurious life led by his family.
While there was a useless emperor nicknamed "A-tou" in ancient China, there is now a good-for-nothing former president called "A-bian" in Taiwan. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO expects to set up joint venture with Wistron by year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 14:48:51 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) said Saturday it expects to set up a thin-film-transistor liquid crystal display (TFT LCD) module production joint venture in China with notebook computer contract manufacturer Wistron Corp. by the end of this year.
Hsiao Yawen, an AUO spokeswoman, said the investment plan is pending approval from Taiwanese authorities after the board of directors of both companies gave the green light to the cooperation.
"We expect the investment plan will be realized by the end of this year if we obtain regulatory approval," Hsiao said.

AUO and Wistron, which is the manufacturing arm of Taiwanese PC vendor Acer Inc., have agreed to set up the joint venture in the Zhongshan Torch Hi-tech Industrial Development Zone of southern China's Guangdong province.
The joint venture is expected to be capitalized at no more than US$10 million, with AUO to take a 51 percent stake and Wistron to hold the remaining 49 percent.
The new plant, which is tentatively named Zhongshan BriVision Optronics Corp., will be located in the "Wistron Optical Campus" of the Zhongshan industrial zone.

"The new business model of allying with one of the world's leading ODM manufacturers will hopefully help not only broaden customer base, but also provide in-time and value-added services for customers by joining the strengths from both sides, " AUO said in a statement on its website.

Before the joint venture with Wistron, AUO had worked with several Chinese electronics giants, such as Sichuan Changhong Group, TCL Corp., and Haier Group, to build flat panel module plants on the mainland.
Along with AUO's own plants, the company is currently operating TFT LCD module production plants in eastern China, southern China, northern China and southwestern China.

In the second quarter of this year, Taiwan ranked as the top TV panel supplier to China by taking 50 percent of the total TV panel sales on the mainland, according to WitsView, a Taiwan-based industrial research institute.

In terms of single firms, Taiwan's Chimei Innolux Corp. was the the largest TV panel supplier in China, grabbing a 23 percent share, followed by AUO and South Korea's Samsung, each of which took 22 percent, the institute said.
WitsView said China has become the single market that has demonstrated the most rapid growth in TV panel demand.
The policy of Taiwan's government to allow local panel makers to set up back-end module production bases in China has made Taiwanese firms competitive on the mainland, WitsView said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan garners one gold, three silver at int'l informatics contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 15:02:40 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan won one gold and three silver medals in the 2010 International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI), held Aug. 14-21 in Canada's Waterloo city, Ministry of Education officials said Saturday.
Four Taiwanese high school students joined the annual games, which was attended by 336 students from 84 countries, the officials said, adding that each Taiwanese team member managed to grab a medal.

The IOI is an annual computer science competition for secondary school students, which was initiated by Blagovest Sendov, a Bulgarian professor, in 1987. Two years later in 1989, the first IOI was held in Pravetz, Bulgaria.

Taiwan joined the international competition for the first time in 1994. In 2009, Taiwanese students won two gold and two silver medals in the 21st IOI in Plovdiv, Bulgaria, marking Taiwan's best-ever performance in the contest.
Taiwan is now seeking to host the 2014 game, according to the ministry.

The Taiwanese winners of this year's competition are: Chen Tien-wei of the Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal University, who garnered a gold medal; and his teammates, Lee Jui-min and Yang Chun-pai of Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School, who each grabbed a silver medal.
Lai Yu-hsuan of National Taichung First Senior High School took a silver, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Social welfare vs. negative income tax

TEXT.P: In a recent meeting held by an Executive Yuan employment promotion task force, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) was scheduled to deliver a report on the "earned income tax credit (EITC) " system, a refundable tax credit designed to both reduce the burden of payroll taxes and supplement the wages of low-income workers.

No discussion, however, was held on the plan because of differences between the MOF and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) . While the MOF thinks the EITC is a "social welfare" measure and should be the responsibility of the MOI, the MOI believes it is a "negative income tax" system and should therefore fall under the MOF's jurisdiction.
The buck-passing between the two ministries again exposes the hypocrisy and stupidity of Taiwan's bureaucracy.
Although "social welfare" and "negative income tax" can be two independent systems, the characteristic of the EITC is that it is a combination of the two.
The EITC is not only one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises but also a creative reform, but it has now become a "sacrifice," abandoned by both ministries.
If the situation is not dealt with properly, it will be subject to scrutiny by voters and will pose a stiff challenge to Ma's re-election bid in 2012. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese baseball team clinches international title in World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/21/10 15:31:53 (By Jorge Liu and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese baseball team won the international championship in the 2010 Junior League Baseball World Series Friday, by beating Guatemala 10-3.

The team's victory marked the second time that an Asia-Pacific team has won the league's international tournament, since teams from the region first began participating in the series in 1999. In 2007, a team from the Philippines won the international championship.

As a result of its victory in the league's international pool, the Chung-Ching club from Taipei will face the champion from the league's USA pool for the ultimate World Series title on Saturday U.S. time in Taylor, Michigan.
In the international pool's final competition, Taiwan led 5-0 through the first three innings, but Guatemala cut the deficit to 5-3 after the 4th inning.
In the 6th inning, Taiwan boosted a five-zero run and pulled away to 10-3 until the end of the match.
Prior to the game, Taiwan had defeated Guatemala (7-2), Ukraine (13-0), Canada (10-0) and Mexico (8-5) for a sweep of the round robin play in the five-team international pool.
The Junior League Baseball World Series, in its 30th year this year, is held annually for 13- and 14-year-old players. It is divided into two major groups: the international pool and the USA pool.
No Asia-Pacific team has ever won the Junior League Baseball World Series.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO China plan remains undecided
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 15:53:05 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A US$3 billion China investment application filed by flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) remains undecided, as the application has been excluded from the agenda of a review meeting of the Investment Commission to be held at the end of August, government officials said Saturday.

Officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said that as the Investment Commission has not received any comments from an MOEA technology review committee on AUO's adjustments in its commitment to invest in Taiwan, which is a prerequisite of the China project, the upcoming meeting is unlikely to process the project.

In March, AUO filed the application to set up a 7.5th-generation thin-film- transistor liquid crystal display (TFT LCD) plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province after the government relaxed restrictions to allow local flat panel firms to build up to three 6th-generation or above plants in China.
However, applicants must give an assurance that they can maintain a technology lead over China and promise to continue to invest in Taiwan.

For the Kunshan project, AUO, which is operating an 8.5th-generation plant in Taiwan, had previously promised to spend NT$400 billion (US$12.52 billion) to build four 10th-generation plants in the Central Taiwan Science Park.

However, after reassessing the fast-changing market, AUO later decided to adjust its Taiwan investment plan to build two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy related facilities instead of the four 10th-generation plants.

AUO was asked by the MOEA technology committee, which is led by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-Chiou, to submit more documents for the plan adjustments before the China project is forwarded to the Investment Commission, which is also under the ministry, for a final decision.

This development defied market expectations that the Investment Commission would approve the AUO China project by the end of August, since the science park approved the plan adjustments earlier this month.
The MOEA officials said the ministry is handling the AUO application "very carefully."

The approval from the science park came at a sensitive time, as the Taiwan High Administrative Court suspended the development of the third and fourth phases of development of the science park after residents sued the government for failing to present a reliable environmental impact assessment for the development.
AUO's NT$400 billion Taiwanese investment is supposed to be located in Erlin, in Changhua County, the site of the suspended fourth phase of development of the science park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to explain decision to cut tax on rice wine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 17:28:46 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government is working on a presentation of evidence to show that imported distilled spirits will never be affected by the recent tax cut on rice wine in Taiwan because the latter is used almost exclusively as a cooking ingredient and is seldom drunk, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Saturday.
If necessary, the government will send representatives to the United States and the European Union to explain why it has slashed the tax on locally produced rice wine, the officials said.
On Aug. 19, the Legislative Yuan approved a revision to the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Act allowing a cut in the tax on rice wine to NT$5.4 (US$0.16) per 0.6-liter bottle from NT$29.5.

The move raised U.S. and European concerns over a possible market impact due to the tax cut and the Office of the United States Trade Representative advised Taiwan Aug. 19 to respect World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations as a member of the economic bloc.
The European Union also said the cut violates the WTO principle of equal treatment for imported and locally produced goods.

According to government sources, it is anticipated that U.S. and European governments will not lodge litigation over the issue at the WTO in the near future because they have to collect opinions from the justice departments and liquor traders.
"So far, they have just expressed concern, " the officials said.

Rice wine, as a distillate, is taxed like whisky or brandy, but is used almost only for cooking. The U.S. and European Union are under the impression that cutting the tax on the kitchen condiment will somehow impact the sale of imported Scotch and other spirits sold for drinking.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's approved inbound investment projects up 30 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 17:47:57 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The number of approved inbound investment applications in the first seven months of this year rose almost 30 percent from a year earlier, the Investment Commission said Saturday.

During the seven-month period, the commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) approved a total of 1,121 inbound investment applications, including 367 projects in the retail and wholesale sector, 91 cases in the electronics field and 88 projects in finance and insurance, it said.
However, in terms of the value of approved inbound investments during the same period, the statistics show a double-digit decline from a year earlier.
The approved inbound investments totaled US$2.47 billion in the past seven months, down 18.93 percent year-on-year, the commission said.

Fan Liang-tung, executive secretary of the commission, said the decline reflects a high comparison base against last year, boosted by a US$480 million investment from Citibank and a US$250 million investment by Standard Chartered Bank.

Fan said that although the number of applications increased, a lack of large single cases dragged down the total investment amount, adding that the MOEA will make more efforts to encourage foreign investors to bring large investment projects to Taiwan.
He said the inbound investment projects in the January-July period were mostly under US$100 million per case.
However, he went on, based on the increase in the number of inbound investment applications, foreign investors have still shown faith in the local investment environment.
In July alone, the commission approved 172 inbound investment applications amounting to a combined US$252 million.
After Taiwan and China signed an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in June, the government has been gearing up to persuade foreign companies to use Taiwan as a springboard into China.
Earlier in the month, the Cabinet set up an "InvesTaiwan Service Center" to promote the nation as an ideal destination for foreign investors.

Meanwhile, The Council for Economic Planning and Development is scheduled to hold a series of conventions from Aug. 23 to introduce the local investment environment, while the MOEA is planning a similar event for Sept. 21.

In a related development, the commission approved a total of 140 outbound investment applications in the seven-month period, down 2.78 percent from a year earlier, but the value of the investments totaled US$1.5 billion, up 7.33 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier pledges to help pharmaceutical sector access China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 18:40:24 (By Yang Sz-ruei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih promised Saturday to help the pharmaceutical sector remove non-tariff barriers that are blocking Taiwan's exports of pharmaceutical raw materials to China.
Wu said the government will seek to negotiate the issue with China step by step so that the products can have a fair opportunity to access the Chinese market.

In light of the huge development potential of the pharmaceutical biotechnology industry, the government has included it as one of the "six emerging industries" that enjoy strong support from the government, according to Wu during a visit to ScinoPharm Taiwan in Tainan County, the country's leading manufacturer of pharmaceutical raw materials.
Ma Hai-yi, the company's president, said Taiwan's output of pharmaceutical raw materials totaled NT$12.24 billion last year, NT$5.43 billion of which were for export.
Of the export volume, more than 50 percent was produced by ScinoPharm, Ma said, adding that her company's goal is to become one of the top five pharmaceutical firms in the world.

According to Ma, ScinoPharm is at present focusing on the development of active pharmaceutical ingredients for anti-cancer drugs, and the products have successfully entered high-threshold markets such as the United States, Europe and Japan after obtaining safety certification in these countries.

However, Ma said, pharmaceutical raw materials from Taiwan still face many non- tariff barriers such as legal and trade restrictions imposed by the Chinese authorities when it comes to accessing the Chinese market. If these barriers are overcome, it will give a major boost to the output of pharmaceutical raw materials by Taiwan, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Harbor forges cooperation links with Guangzhou Port
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 18:47:01 (By Chang Che-fon and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ding-hsun signed a letter of intent with his Guangzhou counterpart Chang Min Saturday to promote cooperation and exchanges between the two ports on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

The signing ceremony was held in the southern city of Kaohsiung and was attended by Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Kuang- shih, Legislator Hou Tsai-feng of the ruling Kuomintang and Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang.
Guangzhou Mayor Wan Qingliang, who is currently on a visit to the country, was also present to witness the event.

Hsiao expressed hope that the new links will help Kaohsiung Harbor with its efforts to become a free trade port and he noted that in May, the harbor signed a letter of intent for cooperation with the port of Xiamen in southern China's Fujian Province.
Kaohsiung Harbor is Taiwan's biggest port.

According to Chang, Guangzhou Port in Guangdong Province was ranked the world's six-largest container harbor in 2009. It envisions becoming an Asian logistics hub and has set a goal of increasing its cargo-handling volume to 11.5 million TEUs this year, he added.
Under the letter of intent, Kaohsiung and Guangzhou agree to boost exchanges of personnel, information and experiences in harbor management.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to cut unemployment to below 5 percent by year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 18:49:35 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan aims to lower its jobless rate to below 5 percent by the end of this year as the local economy is on a strong rebound from the global financial meltdown, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan said Saturday.
At a job fair held by the council in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung, Wang said that due to the economic recovery, the job market has improved, with jobs surpassing demand.
Wang said the council will try to seize this good opportunity to bring down the jobless rate to below 5 percent by the end of this year.
The job fair involved around 50 firms offering more than 4,800 jobs.
Wang expressed hope that employers will increase salaries to attract talent that can contribute to industrial development.

On the same occasion, Lin San-quei, director of the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the CLA, said that apart from organizing job fairs, the bureau has set up a website and telephone hotlines to match employers with job-seekers 24 hours a day.

In the last two months, the Hsinchu Science Park and the Central Taiwan Science Park, two of the country's high-tech powerhouses, have held two large job fairs offering 10,000 and 7,857 jobs, respectively.
In June, the unemployment rate stood at 5.16 percent, up from 5.14 percent recorded in May, boosted by first-time jobseekers entering the market following graduation.
However, the job market has shown signs of significant improvement thanks to the revival of the economy, with the unemployment rate falling from a peak of 6.14 percent registered in August 2009.

In the second quarter, the economy rose 12.53 percent from a year earlier, beating a previous forecast of 7.66 percent on the back of strong export growth and rising private consumption and investment.

Taiwan recorded its worst-ever recession, with its gross domestic product falling 9.06 percent in the first quarter of last year before the local economy gradually recovered and emerged from the recession in the fourth quarter of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liger cub dies, another in critical condition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 18:55:22 (By Kuo Chu-chen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A male liger cub -- an illegally bred cross between a male lion and a tigeress -- died Friday with another listed as being in critical condition, an animal shelter said Saturday.

Pei Jai-chyi, director of the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology's Protected Animal Rescue Center in southern Taiwan, said the two ligers were in poor condition when they were brought to the center Aug. 16.
"The two ligers were obviously underweight and had weak immune systems when they arrived, " said Pei.
"Ligers usually suffer from genetic problems due to the cross-breeding of the two species, putting the cubs in an endangered situation from the moment they are born," he said.

He said the animals have poor chances of survival and are also prone to genetic problems. He added that the two cubs had been in intensive care since their arrival, which meant there had been no opportunity to conduct health checks on them.
Pei said the male cub was sent for an autopsy after it died and was found to have accumulated fluid in its lungs, as well as a distended kidney and spleen.

They were two of three ligers born to a tigeress on a private zoo in southern Taiwan. One of them died of hypothermia shortly after its birth, while the two were confiscated and taken to the center for intensive care.

Huang Kuo-nan, the owner of the zoo, has been accused of violating the Wildlife Conservation Law and fined NT$50,000 for allowing the animals to breed, a figure blasted by an animal protection group as "too little to pay for such illegal behavior."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold investment forum in Tokyo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 20:17:17 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday that it will hold a forum in Tokyo Aug. 24 to seek Japanese partners to collaborate with Taiwanese companies investing in China.

Working with Japan's Mizuho Bank, the Department of Investment Services under the MOEA has planned the convention that will be the second of its kind in Taiwan's ambitions efforts to seek cooperation with Japan for investing in China, said Ling Chia-yuh, director of the department.
The first forum was held May 21 in Taipei and prompted about 45 Japanese firms to express interest in teaming up with Taiwanese companies.

Ling said Mizuho Bank has found about 10 Japanese firms involved in semiconductors, content design for cell phones, solar energy and LED businesses, which are willing to hold talks with Taiwanese companies in the upcoming forum.
Approximately 450 Japanese firms are expected to participate in the forum, Ling said.
Lin Tsang-sheng, chief executive officer of Taiwan's President Group, which has established close business ties with China, will address the forum.
The group operates a wide range of businesses, including food manufacturing, retail, securities and merchandise trading.

Ling said that since Taiwan and China signed an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in late June, granting Taiwan preferential tariff status and easier market access, Japan has become more willing to form partnerships with Taiwan while planning investment in China.

In particular, with the Japanese yen rising sharply against the U.S. dollar, many small and medium-sized enterprises in Japan are eager to investigate investment opportunities overseas to alleviate the currency impact, he said.
Citing a report by Japan's Nomura Research Institute, Ling said about 68 percent of the Japanese companies that have invested on their own in China have said their projects have enjoyed success.
However, the rate is expected to rise to 78 percent if they work with Taiwanese partners, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: President: Economic development can help bridge wealth gap
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 21:34:10 (By Wang Hong-kuo, Yang Sz-ruei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma ying-jeou said Saturday that economic development can help bridge the wealth gap between rich and poor.

Speaking during a visit to a home for the mentally challenged in Taipei County, the president said that when the economy is in decline, the wealth gap widens, but when the economy develops, the improvements are reflected in the job market and household incomes.
"There are various ways to address the widening gap. First and foremost is to develop the economy and increase job opportunities to raise income levels," Ma said.

His remarks came in the wake of a recent government survey showing that Taiwan's household income gap widened in 2009, with the average annual disposable income of the richest 20 percent of families reaching 6.34 times that of the poorest, the second-widest gap since 2001, when the average income of the richest was 6.39 times that of the poorest.

Ma noted that Taiwan's economic growth in the first quarter was adjusted upward to 13.71 percent from the original estimate of 13.27 percent, and that the figure was 12.5 percent in the second quarter, both of which are high growth rates that have rarely been seen in recent years.
Meanwhile, on a separate occasion that same day, Premier Wu Den-yih said that although the economy has obviously taken a turn for the better, the widening wealth gap is still a cause for concern.

Making the comments on the sidelines of a job fair at the Tainan branch of the Southern Taiwan Science Park in which 47 companies were offering more than 9,000 jobs, Wu said the revenue of the Southern Taiwan Science Park in the first half of the year grew by 59.1 percent from the same period of last year, while the number of employees increased by more than 6,000 from the year-earlier level.
The economy has definitely rebounded, with many firms working overtime, he said.
But he lamented that the widening wealth shows that many people are still unable to enjoy the fruits of the economic growth.
He urged the firms to work harder with the government to address the issue, saying that "as long as the gap is not bridged, the government cannot feel at ease. "

DOC.HEADLINE: Forum highlights importance of technology for city development
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 21:40:12 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Participants in a forum held in Taipei Saturday highlighted the importance of technological development for the competitiveness of a global city and previewed a future trend of the rise of mega cities.

The future of a modern city has a great deal to do with its technological readiness and how tech-savvy its residents are, according to experts in various fields, including a social media website founder, a political candidate in the year-end Taipei mayoral election and an Internet guru.

"Of all the cities I have visited, I have seen some that have prospered because of their advanced technological development and I have seen some that have faltered, " said Alvin Yoon, founder of Plurk -- one of the most popular social media websites in Taiwan -- at the forum organized by Business Next magazine.

Yoon, who travels constantly on business, said that Taipei's Easy Card is one of the best innovations for a resident in everyday life because it can be used not only on almost every public transport system but also in libraries and designated stores, an innovation that had left him with a good impression.
According to the World Economic Forum (WEF) , Taiwan's Networked Readiness Index ranked No. 11 in the world and third among Asian countries in 2010.

The world is also embracing a trend toward the rise of mega cities, said Rebecca Chang, a former general manager of Google Taiwan. She added that the mayor of a mega city would be expected to have at least the same -- if not more -- impact than a head of state in the future.
The reason for this is simple, she said, because according to estimates, more than 70 percent of the people on Earth will live in urban areas in the future.

Chang said she is cautiously optimistic about Taipei's future as a technologically advanced metropolis, as the city ranked No. 39 in the Global Cities Index 2010 released the previous week by U.S.-based Foreign Policy magazine, and because Taiwan has always been one of the most successful countries in developing information and communication technology.

Su Tseng-chang, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's candidate in the Taipei mayoral election in November and an avid user of social media sites such as Plurk and Facebook, said technology and the Internet have changed the face of modern politics.

Citing the example of U.S. President Barack Obama, who is seen as the most successful political candidate to have run an election campaign on the Internet, Su said political candidates now are able to communicate with and mobilize voters, as well as to receive donations online.

"Modern politics is no longer a top-down process. It is now a bottom-up process and a two-way dialogue. The government and the cities are no longer run by the elite but by everyone who is willing to participate in the dialogue, " said Su, who has more than 55,000 fans on his Facebook fan page.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait youths kicks off concert series at Sun Moon Lake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/10 21:58:05 (By Lin Heng-li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The first of five concerts by young people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait kicked off Saturday on the banks of scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County.
The Nantou County government, the principal sponsor of the concert, said the young players were selected from Taiwan, Beijing and Singapore.

Under the guidance of renowned violinist Hu Nai-yuan and the National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra, they performed an evening show of classics such as Beethoven's Overture Egmont and Dvorak's Symphony No. 9 from the New World by the lake's Shuishe Wharf.
The orchestra will also perform in Taichung and Taipei Aug. 23 and 24, respectively, and in Beijing Aug. 29 and 30.

The Soave Children's Choir from Japan's Fukui Prefecture -- dubbed the Japanese Vienna Boys' Choir -- and the Wind Orchestra from Tokyo were scheduled to perform by the wharf Sunday to promote exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.
On the Taiwanese side, the Puli Choir and a Chinese musical group from Nantou County will perform a repertoire titled "Taiwan Folklore" in the same concert.
