DOC.HEADLINE: Four moderate earthquakes hit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 10:29:06 (By Chen Shun-hsieh, Shen Ju-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Four earthquakes jolted Taiwan early Sunday, but none of them caused any damage or casualty, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
Three of the quakes were centered in the northeastern county of Yilan and one in the eastern county of Hualien, CWB seismologists said.

The Hualien earthquake, measuring 5.4 on the Richter scale, hit at 0:37 a.m., with the epicenter located at 34.7 kilometers southeast of the county's Silin township at a depth of 27 km, according to the weather bureau.
The temblor was felt around Taiwan, but no damage was reported in the wake of the vibration, seismologists said.
Meanwhile, a magnitude-4.4 earthquake, centered 19.5 kilometers east of the Yilan seismological observation station, hit at 2:39 a.m., the CWB Seismology Center said.
Another temblor, measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale, shook the county again at 2: 47 a.m., with the epicenter located at 19 kilometers northeast of the Yilan seismological station.
Three minutes later, a 3.4-magnitude earthquake was recorded at a location 15.2 kilometers east of the Yilan seismological station, CWB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday Aug. 22, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang- kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Commercial Times: Let the poor also enjoy fruits of growth
DOC.DATELINE: 08/22/10 13:58:36 (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 22, 2010) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: While cross-Taiwan Strait commercial exchanges soar as a result of the opening of tourism and the signing of an economic cooperation pact, government figures now show that the number of families living under the poverty line in Taiwan has risen to 108,000, with 260,000 people involved, both record highs.

The widening gap between rich and poor is definitely not the result of Taiwan's closer economic engagement with China, but it is true that the new benefits created by improved cross-strait ties have not trickled down to everybody in Taiwan, particularly those at the lower end of the economic scale.

The signing of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) has made Taiwan's economy into a bigger pie. The government should waste no time in planning on and overseeing how the pie should be sliced impartially so that all sectors of society can reap the rewards.
The last thing the government should do is neglect to address the fairness of the distribution of newly generated wealth in the wake of the landmark trade pact.

If the government does indeed fail to act to resolve the problem, the ECFA might help to increase Taiwan's overall wealth, but it will also further polarize the country's wealth distribution, and in turn create new social injustice.
The administration cannot be too careful in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Should civil servants get pay raise next year?

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih recently decided against any raise for public-sector wages next year, but Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin appealed Saturday for a moderate upward adjustment of salaries for middle- and low-echelon civil servants.

Now that Taiwan's economy has regained momentum after the recession, the central government should raise the pay for middle- and low-ranking public-sector employees to let them share the fruits of economic recovery and simultaneously stimulate the private sector to follow suit.

Meanwhile, an article carried in the latest issue of the Monthly Bulletin of Statistics of the Republic of China said economic globalization and an exodus of local companies to China has led to a steady decline in the ratio of earned income to Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) and a polarization of domestic wealth distribution.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the developments:
China Times:
Hau said in an interview with this newspaper Saturday that judging from the current domestic economic situation, a modest pay hike will not fuel inflation.
He also said his proposal has nothing to do with his bid for a second mayoral term.

With Taiwan's GDP posting a higher-than-expected 12.53 percent growth in the second quarter of this year and the annual growth rate projected to hit a 21-year high of 8.24 percent, next year is indeed the right time to raise salaries for lower-ranking civil servants, Hau said.
His initiative reportedly has received support from some ruling Kuomintang legislators.
Several lawmakers have said in private that they will pressure the Executive Yuan to backtrack on its decision and raise public-sector wages by at least 1 percent or 2 percent in the coming year.

Major labor groups said they are not opposed to increasing public-sector wages, but they said that if the government wants to effectively stimulate domestic consumption to sustain economic growth, it should first raise the country's minimum wage, which has remained stagnant at NT$17,280 (US$540) since 2007.

The Ministry of Finance said the government will have to borrow an additional NT$7.1 billion if public-sector wages are raised by 1 percent next year. According to the Executive Yuan's 2010 budget plan, the central government must borrow at least NT$429 billion to make ends meet. (Aug. 22, 2010).
Liberty Times:

The article carried in the August issue of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics publication said that earned income traditionally accounts for the largest share of Taiwan's GDP. The ratio of earnings of employed labor to GDP reached a record high of 51.4 percent in 1990, but the figure has been declining steadily since 1995 and hit a low of 44.5 percent in 2007.

The trend could be attributed in part to economic globalization that has seen an influx of cheap labor from China, India and East European countries into the world market, with resultingly narrow room for wage hikes, the article said.

Another reason lies in the relocation of a large number of Taiwanese companies and their employees to China, the article noted. As a result, the ratio of earned income to GDP has declined substantially, while those of corporate earnings and consumption of fixed capital to the GDP have risen steadily. All these developments have contributed to a continued widening of the domestic income gap, it concluded. (Aug. 22, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate expected to rise slightly in July: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 14:42:08 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate is likely to continue to rise in July, with an improving economy offset by slowing demand from employers for new college graduates, an expert said Sunday.

The unemployment rate was 5.16 percent in June, edging up 0.02 percentage points from the previous month as this year's batch of graduates entered the job market. The unemployment figure for July was expected to be released Monday.

Hsin Ping-lung, an associate professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said that although the unemployment rate was expected to continue to rise in July, the rise would be very small, thanks to the improving economy.
Hsin added, however, that the unemployment situation for new college graduates has deteriorated further.
"That does not relate to the economy itself, it is more a structural problem related to excess supply, " Hsin said, pointing out that "there were just too many college graduates."
Under a trend of flat organizations, the demand for college graduates has been less than before, while a lot of entry-level jobs have also been superceded by computers, Hsin said.
"College graduates face fewer job opportunities and supply exceeds demand," he said.
If Taiwan ignores the problem and continues to produce a large number of college graduates, even a booming economy will not slow the worsening of unemployment among new college graduates, Hsin said.
He suggested that the government should concentrate more on higher technological and vocational education to fix the structural problem.
The local industry structure still requires a lot of low- and middle- class technical workers, he said.
Taiwan's high unemployment is a pressing issue for the government, with its unemployment rate in the second quarter of this year -- 5.2 percent -- the highest among Asia's "Four Little Dragons."
Taiwan's economy in the second quarter grew 12.53 percent from a year earlier, with exports growing the fastest among its Asian peers at 46.2 percent.
Premier Wu Den-yih has vowed to step down if his administration fails to bring the unemployment rate below 5 percent by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election complicates Haiti's post-quake progress: ambassador
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 14:53:47 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: A November election in Haiti is hoped to produce a president who can steer the Caribbean country through its post-quake efforts, but the process of electing a leader could be compounding the already snail-pace and problem-ridden reconstruction effort, according to a Haitian official.

Mario Chouloute, minister conseiller charge d'affaires to Taipei, said in an interview with CNA Friday that the country is embroiled in adouble whammy situation -- trying to rebuild the nation from scratch while organizing a major election at the same time.

The Jan. 12 7.3-magnitude earthquake left the capital of Port-au-Prince and nearby cities with colossal destruction. At least 15 percent of the population was directly affected and 300,000 people lost their lives. Many government buildings, including the Presidential Palace, were reduced to rubble.

Chouloute said nearly 5 million eligible voters lost their personal documents in the quake and the government is faced with the task of quickly devising a system to ascertain voter identification and issue them with new ID cards, all within two months.

"Its two difficult situations at the same time. [The election] complicates the situation in Haiti. Many institutions, many houses collapsed and many many people lost their identification and everything. So now the Electoral Council has to provide an electoral identification card to each Haitian citizen who can vote," he said.
The organization of the election will undoubtedly take a toll on the reconstruction effort, he added, reiterating that it is "two very difficult situations to be handled at the same time."
The Haitian diaspora in North American alone accounts for 2 million people, but Haiti does not have the technology or the legislation to permit overseas voting.

The Haiti Provisional Electoral Council released that day a list of 19 candidates qualified to vie for the presidency -- which does not include musician, record producer and politician Wyclef Jean, a Haiti-born U.S.-raised performer who said he was rejected because he did not have residency in the country.
One of the criteria to run for president in Haiti is proof of five-year's consecutive residency in Haiti.
Jean said he is not ready to throw in the towel in his bid, but did not confirm that he will appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for esprit de corps
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 15:38:12 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Quoting a citation of Taiwanese democracy trailblazer Chiang Wei-shui, President Ma Ying-jeou called Sunday for politicians across partisan lines to demonstrate esprit de corps for the cause of the nation.

Paraphrasing a renowned couplet by Chiang that reads "The compatriots must come together in unity. Unity is truly invincible, " Ma said in his weekly video program that partisan rancor has not only taken a toll on the nation's resources, it has also held up the country's growth and development.
"These are points of contention that have disillusioned the people," the president said.
He called for everyone in Taiwan not to forget the bitter lessons that the country has learned from political strife over the past years.
"We should exercise greater tolerance and magnanimity toward each other so that we can unite and strive in concert to create a brighter future for Taiwan," he continued.
He also saluted Chiang as not only a political pioneer but also a social reformer with global perspective.
He repeated Chiang's saying that "Taiwan's career is to serve as a guard on the frontline of world peace." To achieve that goal, Taiwan must change culturally from the roots, Chiang said.

Chiang (1891-1931) led the way for the first political movement and the first cultural enlightenment movement in Taiwan during the period of Japanese colonial rule. While he practiced medicine at the hospital he founded in Taipei, he diagnosed Taiwan itself and concluded that the people of Taiwan were afflicted with "knowledge malnutrition, " so he began to devote himself to the nationalist movement.

Founder of the Taiwan Cultural Association and the Taiwan People's Party, Chiang was one of the first people who tried to lift the status of the Taiwanese during Japanese rule through the formation of democratic political movements.

He died of typhoid at the age of 40, or 41 by traditional Chinese reckoning. He has been described as "Taiwan's Sun Yat-sen" by former Democratic Progressive Party Legislator and incumbent Control Yuan member Huang Huang-hsiung.
Huang, Chiang Chao-keng -- a grandson of Chiang -- and Wang Hsiao-po, a National Taiwan University academic, were also invited to appear and talk on the president's video presentation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese Taipei wins junior league world series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 15:43:00 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei defeated Texas 9-1 to win the Junior League Baseball World Series championship Saturday in the U.S. state of Michigan.
The Asia-Pacific champions from the Chung-Ching Junior Little League in Taipei City have won Taiwan its 18th title since 1992.
The championship game started out as a tight pitcher's duel before Texas scored a run in the bottom of the fifth inning, taking a 1-0 lead.

With batter Lin Tzu-wei slapping the ball through the Texan infield, the Taiwanese team managed to tie the game at 1-1 in the sixth, followed by three more in quick succession in the same inning to open up a formidable lead.
Entering the seventh inning, Taiwan secured its victory by adding a further five runs to the scoreboard.
Taiwan won 17 titles before withdrawing from the league in 1996. This was its first championship title since its return in 2003.

So far, Chinese Taipei baseball teams have given exemplary performances this year, earning a gold medal in the 2010 IBAF World Junior Baseball Championship in early August and a title in the Junior League Baseball World Series 2010.
Meanwhile, a team from Kaohsiung blanked Saudi Arabia 18-0 Sunday in its first match in the Little League World Series Baseball 2010 in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled population grows to 1.06 million: Interior Ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 15:56:17 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The number of registered disabled people totaled 1.06 million at the end of June, up 10,000, or 0.9 percent, from the same time last year, according to Ministry of the Interior figures released Sunday.
The ministry said the disabled population has been growing in recent years -- accounting for 4.6 percent of the total population at the end of June, up 0.03 percenttage point year-on-year.
The number of male disabled people was 610,175, compared to females at 454,164.
Those with missing limbs represented the largest group -- at 36.5 percent -- of the total disabled population, followed by those with organ dysfunction at about 11 percent.
Among the disabled categories showing a year-on-year growth, the number of people diagnosed with autism increased the most at 11 percent, while those with Alzheimer's disease rose by 8.7 percent.
Among the disabled over the age of 18, missing limbs accounted for about 38 per cent, while in the disabled under 18 years old, 37 percent were mentally challenged.
The percentage of disabled people in Taitung County was the highest in the country -- at 8.9 percent, followed by 7.5 percent in Hualien County and 7.1 percent in Yunlin County, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier expresses concern over AUO executives in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 16:29:13 (By Cheng Chi-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih expressed concern Sunday over the fate of three ranking executives of TFT-LCD giant AU Optronics (AUO) who have been barred by a U.S. district court from leaving the United States while an anti-trust probe continues.

Wu pointed out that he is not in any position to try to intervene or interfere in a judicial procedure in the United States, but said he has instructed Taiwanese officials posted in San Francisco to gain a better understanding of the surprise incident and to render assistance if possible.

The three executives -- Lai-juh Chen, Hsuan Bin Chen and Hui Hsiung -- have been ordered by the court to surrender their passports and to not travel outside the northern district of California without court permission.

They traveled to the United States two or three weeks ago in a bid to explain themselves in court and clear the AUO Group of charges after a federal grand jury in San Francisco charged AUO, its Houston-based U.S. subsidiary, and six executives with participating in a conspiracy to fix prices of thin-film- transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels from September 2001 to December 2006.
If convicted, the AUO executives could each face up to 10 years in prison and a US$1 million fine, while the company could be hit with a fine of US$100 million.
AUO Group Chairman K.Y. Lee has said there is no evidence of the alleged AUO participation in price fixing and vowed that his company will not plead guilty.
According to the U.S. Department of Justice, six electronics companies have already pleaded guilty in connection with the conspiracy case and a total of 17 executives have been charged.
The U.S. prosecutors said Friday that the three AUO executives are flight risks, given the lack of an extradition treaty between the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schumann's music meets traditional Chinese Nanguan

TEXT.P: When a pianist playing Schumann's classical music shares a stage with a musician playing traditional Chinese Nanguan songs, what kind of new excitement will be generated?
This is an idea that Taiwanese stage director Wei Ying-chuan felt interested in, so she accepted the challenge of directing an upcoming concert featuring the two very different musical approaches.

"The concept originated with conductor Chien Wen-Pin, who is now working in Germany but will return to Taiwan to be the music director and play the piano at the concert, which will be an event rarely seen in recent years," Wei told CNA.

The concert, titled "Timeless Love -- Concert of Dichterliebe & Nanguan," will feature Chien on piano, as well as German tenor Tilman Lichdi and traditional Nanguan artist Wang Xin-xin, performing together for the first time.

Nanguan is a type of Chinese classical music that originated hundreds of years ago in the southern Chinese province of Fujian. It has a totally different performance style compared to the Western classical style and finding ways to combine the two harmoniously has become an interesting experiment for Chien.

When he began to organize a concert to commemorate German composer Robert Schumann's 200th birthday, he recalled the first time he heard Nanguan music, played by Wang. "When she started to play, it was like being transported to another time and place, " he said.

Chien, the resident conductor of Deutsche Oper am Rhien, therefore invited Wang and Lichdi to share the stage to present an unprecedented crossover of musical genres featuring Nanguan performances plus Schumann's famous "Dichterliebe" (The Poet's Love), which are based on 16 works of the 19th century romantic poet Heinrich Heine.
Compared to staging a traditional performance, this is obviously a new challenge for Wang.

"I was not familiar with Schumann's music at the beginning, but I discovered a similarity of tone with some of the Nanguan songs, " she said, adding that she composited different pieces from several Nanguan works that harmonized well with the Western pieces.

In this new experiment, Chien arranged the traditional performance in a different way. "Schumann's songs will be the main focus, and Nanguan will be another story sung and told by Wang, " Chien noted, adding that sometimes two singers will convey a sense of love by singing together, while on other occasions the piano music will cut in as the third member of a love triangle.
To the music director, "it's not only a crossover of genres, but actually a brand new creation," Chien said.

Chien has previously cooperated with the Taipei Chinese Orchestra and the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, and has also led the National Symphony Orchestra in performances that have shared the stage with many theatrical groups. Those experiences have enabled him to create more interesting multi-faceted concerts.
This time he has invited Wei to be his partner to provide more variety in the new work.

"I expect to create a concert where audiences not only can listen to beautiful music, but also can see it, " Wei said, adding that she has designed a stage with a piano and modern Italian furniture on one side, while on the other side is Wang, wearing old-style clothes and playing a traditional musical instrument, in order to provide a contrasting image.
"As the director of the show, I will create an atmosphere reminiscent of a piano bar in old Shanghai," Wei said.

"I will utilize an abstract method to express the concept of a love triangle throughout the concert, " she went on, adding that the show mainly consists of the concert itself, without too many dramatic elements.
After one rehearsal together, Wei described the musical portion as quite outstanding. "My part is to let audiences `see' a truly beautiful love story through the staging," she said.
The concert will be held at the Guangfu Auditorium of Taipei's Zhongshan Hall Sept. 3-5 as part of the Taipei Arts Festival. By Sunnie Chen CNA staff reporter/J

DOC.HEADLINE: First post-ECFA forum on ASEAN ties slated for Aug. 26 in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 17:13:04 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An international seminar on relations among Taiwan, China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) after the signing of a landmark trade pact across the Taiwan Strait will be held in Taipei Aug. 26, organizers said Sunday.

The symposium will bring together prominent scholars and experts from major ASEAN countries who will discuss possible new developments in Taiwan-ASEAN relations in the wake of the signing of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , the organizers said.

The first post-ECFA large-scale academic event will also explore how Taiwan and ASEAN members can cooperate even more closely in promoting Asia-Pacific economic development and regional integration, said an executive of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) , which will join forces with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council to sponsor the seminar.

Noting that the ECFA signing has created new opportunities for Taiwan to reach out to ASEAN and other parts of the world, the executive said the conclusions obtained at the symposium will offer tips for Taiwan's policymakers in drafting visionary strategies for expanding trade and economic cooperation with China and ASEAN.

The seminar will comprise four panel sessions that will respectively address topics related to ASEAN perspectives on ECFA and cross-strait economic cooperation, strategies and outlook for ASEAN and Asia-Pacific economic integration, the current state of and barriers to Taiwan-ASEAN relations, and recommendations for development of a Taiwan-ASEAN partnership.

ASEAN academics and experts scheduled to present papers at the seminar include former Indonesian Ambassador to Australia Sabam Sigian and Somkiat Tangkitvanich, vice president of the Thailand Development Research Institute, as well as scholars from Singapore, Vietnam and the Philippines.
Senior Taiwanese officials in charge of cross-strait, diplomatic and economic affairs, as well as CHIER researchers, will also attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cheaper cost for exchanging yuan expected by end August
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 17:53:02 (By Kao Chao-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The state-owned Bank of Taiwan (BOT) said Sunday that the cost of exchanging Chinese yuan is expected to be cheaper from the end of August after authorized Taiwanese banks begin buying yuan directly from the Hong Kong arm of Bank of China.

BOT Vice President Yang Feng-yen said that after the BOT and the Hong Kong arm of Bank of China signed a cash settlement agreement July 26, the BOT was allowed to buy yuan cash with U.S. dollars. However, some issues remained to be settled, he noted.
Yang explained that settlement of yuan and New Taiwan dollar notes involves cross-border transport and security issues, and that the timing of the settlement is also very important.
"Those issues are expected to be settled by the end of August, " said Yang.

The BOT and the state-controlled Mega Bank -- Taiwan's top two foreign exchange banks -- were approved by the Central Bank of the Republic of China in July to engage in the yuan cash settlement services. Both banks have signed the new settlement agreements with the Chinese side.
Yang said the BOT is also in the process of signing contracts with Taiwan's financial institutions to provide them with yuan notes.

Taiwanese banks currently buy yuan in Hong Kong from HSBC and Bank of America. However, the supply of notes -- most of which are old -- from those two banks has not been very stable and the cost of procuring them is relatively high.
Taiwan's central bank has estimated that the new cash settlement agreements could lead to savings of about NT$1,000 on every procurement of 20,000 Chinese yuan.
Yang said that after the new services are launched, Taiwan will be able to get a more stable supply of newer yuan notes, as well as cheaper exchange costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schedule needed for passage of NHI reform bill: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 18:22:24 (By Chen Li-ting, Huang Ming-hsi and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A proposed date for the passing of National Health Insurance (NHI) amendments should be settled as soon as possible, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Sunday.

Yaung urged the lawmakers to continue reviewing the reform bill for a second- generation NHI program in a special legislative session scheduled for next week and to work out a plausible time schedule for the bill's passage.

He said the bill has already undergone several reviews by the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee, and that the DOH has held numerous public hearings on the issue. With the exception of 26 clauses in the bill that require further discussion, most have now been addressed, he said.

The legislature needs to give an indication of when the bill will be passed because the implementation of the second-generation NHI system is complicated and the relevant authorities must plan ahead, said Yaung.

In a move aimed at resolving a dispute over the bill between the rival parties, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng was scheduled to convene a negotiation meeting the following day between the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Although the KMT hopes to clear the bill by the end of the special session, the DPP could still throw a wrench into the works by calling into question the content of each individual article, said Lin Yi-shih, director-general of the KMT's Policy Committee.
Lin said the KMT will try to come to terms with the DPP in the negotiation meeting and will also seek support from KMT legislators who disagree with passing the bill in the ongoing special session.
On the other hand, the DPP has said the legislature should not hurry the bill through without full discussion and should hold off on the review until the next regular legislative session.
It will not be possible to pass the bill during the current special session, said DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming.

According to an anonymous legislative source, five representatives from the KMT, the Legislative Yuan and the Presidential Office had previously agreed that the purpose of the two-week special legislative session was to deal with four priority issues -- the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , the admission of Chinese students to Taiwanese universities and colleges, amendments to the election and recall law, and the NHI reforms.
As the three other items have all been dealt with, the KMT is determined to push NHI reform bill through by the end of August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidate's daughter prefers medicine to politics
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 18:38:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The daughter of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao- shun, a gynecologist and obstetrician, said Sunday that she will never enter politics, describing herself as having been a victim of politics since childhood.
Chen Ching-huei, nevertheless, vowed to be a solid campaigner for her mother, who has been nominated as the ruling party's candidate in the Kaohsiung municipality mayoral race slated for Nov. 27.

Speaking at a press conference to launch a campaign publicity video of Huang's titled "The Iron Carnation, " Chen said she was invited by KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung to talk in the film about her relationship with her mother.
"It was at that point that I came to the realization that mother had been a stranger to me, since I had seldom met her since childhood, " Chen said.
Chen said she was brought up in Taipei City by her grandmother and grandfather. Her grandfather was Huang Tsun-chiu, a former president of the Control Yuan who passed away in 2000.
"I remember once I asked my granddad to take me to mother's office after I saw a giant billboard in Taipei depicting a woman candidate campaigning, who I thought was my mother," Chen recalled.
"I cried when I was told by granddad that the woman was not my mother because she was running in Kaohsiung," Chen continued.
Chen said it was only after she had grown up that she realized how hard it was for her mother to be a politician, spending so much time away from home and never enjoying the happiness of family life.
"Mother has given the prime of her life over the past 30 years to politics," the ob-gyn doctor said.

Huang will run against the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) official nominee, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, and former DPP heavyweight Yang Chiu-hsing in a three-way race. Yang quit the DPP recently to run as an independent.
Initial polls show Huang and Yang trailing Chen by a wide margin in the three- way race.
Chen said she has filed for a temporary leave of absence from her work in the months of the run-up to the election so that she can serve as a doctor on Huang's campaign team.
"I will be back into my doctor's white coat as soon as the election is over," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Guangdong governor concludes US$7 billion procurement visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 19:03:50 (By Bian Chin-feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The governor of China's Guangdong Province concluded a week-long visit to Taiwan Sunday during which his delegation placed orders for local industrial and farm products worth more than US$7 billion.
"It has been a wonderful trip, as we had an excellent experience and reaped an abundant harvest during our stay, " said Huang Huahua at a press conference prior to his departure.

Huang, who arrived in Taiwan at the head of a 1,000-man delegation from his province Aug. 16, said they were met with hospitality from the Taiwanese people and witnessed for themselves the vitality of Taiwan's economy. As a result, "not only was deeper mutual understanding further solidified, but expanded cooperation in various fields between Guangdong and Taiwan was also achieved, " he added.

Huang said that during the past week, the members of his delegation, mostly representatives of Guangdong enterprises, signed agreements with their Taiwanese counterparts to buy a total of US$7.085 billion-worth of products -- 80 percent of which are manufactured by local small- and medium-sized enterprises. The figure also includes US$1.4 billion-worth of farm produce and US$10 million- worth of investment in Taiwan.
In addition, they signed 115 agreements or memorandums of understanding with their Taiwanese counterparts for cooperation in the areas of tourism, culture, education and medical care.

The delegation also gave away 10,000 tickets for the Asian Games to be held Nov. 22-27 in the Guangdong city of Guangzhou, and 1,000 tickets for the Asian Para Games to be held Dec. 12-19 there, in addition to donating 15 million Chinese yuan (NT$60 million) as relief funds for victims of natural disasters in the Kaohsiung area.
Huang said he also brought to Taiwan around 9,000 tourists, and that the total number of Guangdong tourist arrivals in Taiwan will break 180,000 by the end of this year.

The delegation came on the heels of visits by provincial-level groups from China's Sichuan, Shaanxi, Jiangsu, Zejiang, Jilin, Guangxi and Hubei provinces, as well as Shanghai that have arrived in Taiwan since the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public-sector wage hike should wait for stronger GDP growth: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 19:19:48 (By Cheng chi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Now is not the time for the government to raise public-sector wages because uncertainties still lurk in the global and domestic economic recovery in the second half of the year, Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

Wu was responding to an appeal by Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin for a central government raise in pay for middle- and low-echelon civil servants, military personnel and teachers in public schools in 2011 to let them have a taste of the fruits of the country's faster-than-expected economic growth in the first half of this year.

According to Hau, a moderate pay hike for grassroots public servants would boost their morale and stimulate the business sector to follow suit so that more people would be able to enjoy the fruits of the country's economic growth.

Wu said, however, that although Taiwan scored remarkable GDP growth rates in the first and second quarters of the year, the gains are still not enough to make up for the tax revenue shortfall resulting from last year's economic slump.
Furthermore, he went on, the economic outlook for the second half remains uncertain as the economic recovery in Europe, the United States, Japan and China seems to be slowing down.
Another dissuading factor for Hau's proposed pay hike at present lies in the fact that the government is still reliant on borrowing to make ends meet.

"An upward public-sector wage adjustment at the moment could leave an impression that the government is borrowing money simply to benefit civil servants," Wu said, adding that a pay raise might also fuel inflation of the domestic consumer price index.
Acknowledging that public-sector wages have not been adjusted for several years, Wu said he personally supports a pay hike for grassroots civil servants.

"But weighing our overall national situation, I feel compelled to decide against such a move, " Wu said, adding that if the domestic economic recovery continues to gather steam and the government's tax revenues continue to rise substantially, the Executive Yuan will raise public-sector wages at an appropriate time by seeking legislative approval for a budget increase.

Earlier in the day, Hau and three ruling Kuomintang legislators from Taipei City -- Chiang Nai-shin, Pan Wei-kang and Alex Fai -- hosted a news conference to drum up support for the pay raise proposal.
"With our GDP growth rate expected to hit a 21-year high this year, I believe the government can afford a modest salary hike for grassroots public servants," Hau said.

He also rebutted allegations that his proposal amounts to election bribery, arguing that the speculation is unfounded because the pay raise, if adopted, would not be implemented until next year, while the election will take place Nov. 27.

Fai threw his support behind Hau's appeal, saying that a 1 percent pay raise would only increase the government expenditure by an estimated NT$7 billion (US$218.75 million), or 0.45 percent of the government's total 2010 budget of NT$1.6 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 823 artillery bombardment veterans revisit Kinmen
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 20:01:55 (By Ni Guo-yen and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A group of veterans who survived a protracted communist Chinese artillery bombardment of the outlying island of Kinmen more than 50 years ago traveled to the island Sunday to pay tribute to their fallen comrades.

A total of 77 veterans, accompanied by Lu Fang-yen, chairman of the 823 Artillery Bombardment Veterans and Friends Association, flew to Kinmen to attend a commemoration ceremony in honor of the soldiers who gave their lives to safeguard Kinmen against a Chinese invasion in 1958.
"I came to mourn my brothers in arms so that they won't be lonely," said Lu, himself a veteran who served in the military police during the bombardment.
"Although our military success secured peace in the Taiwan Strait for 50 years, the battle brought tragedy to many people on both sides of the strait," Lu said.

On behalf of all the veterans, Lu urged the government to include information about the bombardment in school textbooks to teach children the heavy price of war and to promote peace between China and Taiwan.

On Aug. 23, 1958, Chinese forces launched a bombardment of Kinmen that was intended to soften the Nationalist forces prior to a communist invasion. Over the next 44 days, as many as 470,000 shells were fired at the 150 square kilometer island. The troops, however, stood firm against the devastating onslaught and the invasion attempt was an utter failure.

The victory for the Nationalist force helped lay the foundation for Taiwan's subsequent democratic and economic development, and the struggle later came to be referred to as the 823 Artillery Bombardment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$2 billion for centenary celebrations: cultural council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 20:22:17 (By Cheng Chin-wen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Sunday that it has budgeted approximately NT$2 billion (US$62.7 million) for celebrating the country's centenary next year and dismissed media reports that it will spend about NT$3.2 billion on related events.

The CCA said the NT$3.2 billion figure reported by the media includes various unrelated costs including NT$480 million for holding the 2011 International Design Alliance Congress, as well as the costs for other activities such as an exhibition on the Kangxi Emperor and King Louis XIV at the National Palace Museum.
It said that those activities, which have been planned by various departments, just happen to take place in 2011 and therefore are being promoted together with the centenary celebrations.

"Those activities have not been designed as part of the centenary celebrations, and therefore it is not appropriate to directly combine those costs and consider them part of the cost of celebrating the centenary," the CCA said in a statement.

The council said the planned budget of NT$2 billion will be allocated to activities planned by the CCA and the Republic of China (Taiwan) Centenary Foundation, activities held by 25 city and county governments, selected private celebration events, and broadcasting of the activities.
It also noted that the planned cost accounts for only 0.11 percent of the central government's 2011 budget of NT$1.7 trillion.
"For a family with an annual income of NT$1 million, it should be acceptable to spend NT$1,000 to celebrate the family's or a family member's 100th birthday, " the statement said.

President Ma Ying-jeou said Aug. 20 that the cost of celebrating the centenary is not high and represents 16.6 percent of the cost of holding the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung, or 50 percent of the cost of the Deaflympics in Taipei that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Do more to upgrade night markets

TEXT.P: Several noted local night markets have emerged as new tourist attractions because of the dazzling array of foodstuffs and merchandise they sell that vividly reflect ordinary Taiwanese people's everyday lives and leisure culture.
Not only are more and more foreign tourists regarding famous local night markets as must-visit locations, even high-profile international travel channels have run special reports to introduce them.

Riding on this new craze, the Tourism Bureau recently sponsored an online vote to select the most special and fascinating night markets in Taiwan, which generated an enthusiastic response from Internet users.

The charm and allure of Taiwan's night markets lie in their impromptu, casual, easy-going, flexible and playful atmosphere. They are often also characterized as overcrowded, noisy, chaotic and boisterous. These features, plus rich variety of local food delicacies on offer, make them very attractive to foreign visitors.
However, greater efforts should be made to ensure their cleanliness and sanitation if they are to be made into tourist attractions on a par of world standards and to ensure their lasting appeal.
Traffic conditions and signage should also be improved to enhance their accessibility. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 22, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai golfer wins PGA Taiwan championship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 21:29:38 (By Hsaio Po-hsing & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Chawalit Plaphol of Thailand won the Taiwan PGA Championship Sunday with a four- day total of 270 to pocket NT$1 million (US$31,000) in prize money.

Taiwanese golfers Lin Wen-tang and Chan Shih-chang shared the runner-up position in the NT$6 million event with 272, earning themselves each NT$510,000. The event was held at the Sunrise Golf and Country Club in northern Taiwan.

Lin, who started the last round six strokes behind the leader, had a shining performance, scoring the lowest six-under-par 66, eight birdies and two bogeys. Lin failed to draw even with the Thai due to a final-hole bogey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schedule needed for passage of NHI reform bill: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 18:22:24 (By Chen Li-ting, Huang Ming-hsi and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A proposed date for the passing of National Health Insurance (NHI) amendments should be settled as soon as possible, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Sunday.

Yaung urged the lawmakers to continue reviewing the reform bill for a second- generation NHI program in a special legislative session scheduled for next week and to work out a plausible time schedule for the bill's passage.

He said the bill has already undergone several reviews by the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee, and that the DOH has held numerous public hearings on the issue. With the exception of 26 clauses in the bill that require further discussion, most have now been addressed, he said.

The legislature needs to give an indication of when the bill will be passed because the implementation of the second-generation NHI system is complicated and the relevant authorities must plan ahead, said Yaung.

In a move aimed at resolving a dispute over the bill between the rival parties, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng was scheduled to convene a negotiation meeting the following day between the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Although the KMT hopes to clear the bill by the end of the special session, the DPP could still throw a wrench into the works by calling into question the content of each individual article, said Lin Yi-shih, director-general of the KMT's Policy Committee.
Lin said the KMT will try to come to terms with the DPP in the negotiation meeting and will also seek support from KMT legislators who disagree with passing the bill in the ongoing special session.
On the other hand, the DPP has said the legislature should not hurry the bill through without full discussion and should hold off on the review until the next regular legislative session.
It will not be possible to pass the bill during the current special session, said DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming.

According to an anonymous legislative source, five representatives from the KMT, the Legislative Yuan and the Presidential Office had previously agreed that the purpose of the two-week special legislative session was to deal with four priority issues -- the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , the admission of Chinese students to Taiwanese universities and colleges, amendments to the election and recall law, and the NHI reforms.
As the three other items have all been dealt with, the KMT is determined to push NHI reform bill through by the end of August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidate's daughter prefers medicine to politics
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 18:38:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The daughter of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao- shun, a gynecologist and obstetrician, said Sunday that she will never enter politics, describing herself as having been a victim of politics since childhood.
Chen Ching-huei, nevertheless, vowed to be a solid campaigner for her mother, who has been nominated as the ruling party's candidate in the Kaohsiung municipality mayoral race slated for Nov. 27.

Speaking at a press conference to launch a campaign publicity video of Huang's titled "The Iron Carnation, " Chen said she was invited by KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung to talk in the film about her relationship with her mother.
"It was at that point that I came to the realization that mother had been a stranger to me, since I had seldom met her since childhood, " Chen said.
Chen said she was brought up in Taipei City by her grandmother and grandfather. Her grandfather was Huang Tsun-chiu, a former president of the Control Yuan who passed away in 2000.
"I remember once I asked my granddad to take me to mother's office after I saw a giant billboard in Taipei depicting a woman candidate campaigning, who I thought was my mother," Chen recalled.
"I cried when I was told by granddad that the woman was not my mother because she was running in Kaohsiung," Chen continued.
Chen said it was only after she had grown up that she realized how hard it was for her mother to be a politician, spending so much time away from home and never enjoying the happiness of family life.
"Mother has given the prime of her life over the past 30 years to politics," the ob-gyn doctor said.

Huang will run against the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) official nominee, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, and former DPP heavyweight Yang Chiu-hsing in a three-way race. Yang quit the DPP recently to run as an independent.
Initial polls show Huang and Yang trailing Chen by a wide margin in the three- way race.
Chen said she has filed for a temporary leave of absence from her work in the months of the run-up to the election so that she can serve as a doctor on Huang's campaign team.
"I will be back into my doctor's white coat as soon as the election is over," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Guangdong governor concludes US$7 billion procurement visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 19:03:50 (By Bian Chin-feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The governor of China's Guangdong Province concluded a week-long visit to Taiwan Sunday during which his delegation placed orders for local industrial and farm products worth more than US$7 billion.
"It has been a wonderful trip, as we had an excellent experience and reaped an abundant harvest during our stay, " said Huang Huahua at a press conference prior to his departure.

Huang, who arrived in Taiwan at the head of a 1,000-man delegation from his province Aug. 16, said they were met with hospitality from the Taiwanese people and witnessed for themselves the vitality of Taiwan's economy. As a result, "not only was deeper mutual understanding further solidified, but expanded cooperation in various fields between Guangdong and Taiwan was also achieved, " he added.

Huang said that during the past week, the members of his delegation, mostly representatives of Guangdong enterprises, signed agreements with their Taiwanese counterparts to buy a total of US$7.085 billion-worth of products -- 80 percent of which are manufactured by local small- and medium-sized enterprises. The figure also includes US$1.4 billion-worth of farm produce and US$10 million- worth of investment in Taiwan.
In addition, they signed 115 agreements or memorandums of understanding with their Taiwanese counterparts for cooperation in the areas of tourism, culture, education and medical care.

The delegation also gave away 10,000 tickets for the Asian Games to be held Nov. 22-27 in the Guangdong city of Guangzhou, and 1,000 tickets for the Asian Para Games to be held Dec. 12-19 there, in addition to donating 15 million Chinese yuan (NT$60 million) as relief funds for victims of natural disasters in the Kaohsiung area.
Huang said he also brought to Taiwan around 9,000 tourists, and that the total number of Guangdong tourist arrivals in Taiwan will break 180,000 by the end of this year.

The delegation came on the heels of visits by provincial-level groups from China's Sichuan, Shaanxi, Jiangsu, Zejiang, Jilin, Guangxi and Hubei provinces, as well as Shanghai that have arrived in Taiwan since the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public-sector wage hike should wait for stronger GDP growth: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/22/10 19:19:48 (By Cheng chi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Now is not the time for the government to raise public-sector wages because uncertainties still lurk in the global and domestic economic recovery in the second half of the year, Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

Wu was responding to an appeal by Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin for a central government raise in pay for middle- and low-echelon civil servants, military personnel and teachers in public schools in 2011 to let them have a taste of the fruits of the country's faster-than-expected economic growth in the first half of this year.

According to Hau, a moderate pay hike for grassroots public servants would boost their morale and stimulate the business sector to follow suit so that more people would be able to enjoy the fruits of the country's economic growth.

Wu said, however, that although Taiwan scored remarkable GDP growth rates in the first and second quarters of the year, the gains are still not enough to make up for the tax revenue shortfall resulting from last year's economic slump.
Furthermore, he went on, the economic outlook for the second half remains uncertain as the economic recovery in Europe, the United States, Japan and China seems to be slowing down.
Another dissuading factor for Hau's proposed pay hike at present lies in the fact that the government is still reliant on borrowing to make ends meet.

"An upward public-sector wage adjustment at the moment could leave an impression that the government is borrowing money simply to benefit civil servants," Wu said, adding that a pay raise might also fuel inflation of the domestic consumer price index.
Acknowledging that public-sector wages have not been adjusted for several years, Wu said he personally supports a pay hike for grassroots civil servants.

"But weighing our overall national situation, I feel compelled to decide against such a move, " Wu said, adding that if the domestic economic recovery continues to gather steam and the government's tax revenues continue to rise substantially, the Executive Yuan will raise public-sector wages at an appropriate time by seeking legislative approval for a budget increase.

Earlier in the day, Hau and three ruling Kuomintang legislators from Taipei City -- Chiang Nai-shin, Pan Wei-kang and Alex Fai -- hosted a news conference to drum up support for the pay raise proposal.
"With our GDP growth rate expected to hit a 21-year high this year, I believe the government can afford a modest salary hike for grassroots public servants," Hau said.

He also rebutted allegations that his proposal amounts to election bribery, arguing that the speculation is unfounded because the pay raise, if adopted, would not be implemented until next year, while the election will take place Nov. 27.

Fai threw his support behind Hau's appeal, saying that a 1 percent pay raise would only increase the government expenditure by an estimated NT$7 billion (US$218.75 million), or 0.45 percent of the government's total 2010 budget of NT$1.6 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 23, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
2001: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opens with lively performances at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."
