DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Taiwan's delicate role
DOC.DATELINE: 08/23/10 10:34:15 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The increasing number of U.S. war games in the Asia-Pacific region and Washington's moves to further buttress ties with its military allies over the past several months have caused China concern.

The U.S. wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are basically over, leaving a legacy of enormous costs for discharge pay and medical care of the injured. This has prompting international political observers to suggest that America cannot afford a third war any time soon.
An agitated U.S is therefore turning its eyes toward the Asian Pacific.

Meanwhile, China's economic strength has translated into military might. Its growing influence has caused worry and fear among Southeast Asian countries, and they hope the U.S. will remain as a counterbalancing force in the region.
It is worth close observation to see how the situation involving these two powers will unfold and whether the long existing stability of the Asia-Pacific region will be threatened.

Taiwan, which has remained a close ally of the United States despite an absence of diplomatic relations and has improved its ties with China since President Ma Ying-jeou took office, is now torn between the two powers. With the situation in the Asia-Pacific changing swiftly, Taiwan's position will become even more delicate, and challenging, than ever. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS deputy head makes first visit to Taiwan since ECFA's signing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 10:56:48 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The deputy chief of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is currently on a visit in Taiwan to assess the response on the ground to a recently signed cross-strait pact, sources said Monday.

ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, who arrived in Kaohsiung Saturday in his capacity as a deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the Communist Party of China, was scheduled to visit southern Taiwan's Tainan City and County later Monday.
On his first stop, Zheng, accompanied by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chung Shao-ho, met with Taiwanese farmers in Kaohsiung County Sunday.

According to Chung, Zheng wants to get first-hand information about the export of Taiwan-grown fruits and other farm produce to China and learn about the problems that local farmers and traders encounter in their cross-strait business operations.

"On this trip, Zheng is mainly concerned with the trade of agricultural items that will be allowed tariff concessions under the terms of the 'early harvest list' of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA)," Chung said.
Kaohsiung County has been a stronghold of Taiwan's pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Zheng and Chung called on the government of county's Renwu township Sunday. Zheng told Renwu township chief Shen Ying-chang, a DPP member, that he was impressed by Renwu orderly development and that Taiwanese people are welcome to visit China.
Traveling with a delegation of Chinese officials, Zheng is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of a KMT think tank, Chung said.
Zheng has kept low profile on his current visit. Even Chinese journalists stationed in Taiwan were unaware of his arrival. He is scheduled to visit Taipei Aug. 25.
The Straits Exchange Foundation, the ARATS counterpart in Taiwan, said Zheng's itinerary does not include a visit to its office during his current trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- AUO vows 'business as usual' despite U.S. lawsuit
DOC.DATELINE: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) 08/23/10 12:19:39 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: reiterated Sunday that there will be no change in its corporate structure for the time being although three of its executives were barred by a U.S. judge from leaving the United States during an anti-trust probe.

AUO, the world's fourth largest manufacturer of liquid crystal display (LCD) panels, also said its corporate operations will not be affected by the ongoing U.S. price-fixing lawsuit against the company.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the news:
United Daily News:
AUO called an emergency meeting Sunday to discuss response strategies to the situation and its chairman Lee Kun-yao offered crisis management suggestions at the meeting, a company official said.
According to the official, the three AUO executives have not been detained and can stay informed about the company's operations through daily videoconferences.

Company sources said AUO will ask the U.S. court to lift the overseas travel ban on its three executives -- Lai-juh Chen, Hsuan Bin Chen and Hui Hsiung -- and that the company will post bail or other guarantee.
If the U.S. court rejects the request, the AUO executives will have to remain in California until the trial formally begins, which could take from a month to a year.

The U.S. Justice Department has accused AUO executives of participating in regular meetings with other industry stakeholders, in Taipei hotel rooms and restaurants, to discuss and fix LCD prices from 2001 to 2006.

In the subsequent probe, six companies pleaded guilty in the subsequent probe, including Taiwan's Chi Mei and Chunghwa Picture Tubes, South Korea's LG display and Japan's Sharp Corp., Epson and Hitachi Displays. AUO is the only company that has refused to yield.

Local stock market analysts said the U.S. court's travel ban on AUO executives is not expected to seriously affect the company's share prices because AUO has a well-devised management scheme and its executives can still maintain close contact with its Taipei headquarters. (Aug. 23, 2010).
China Times:
AUO management has stressed that the company is prepared to fight a long legal battle against the U.S. price-fixing charges.
"We are clean and will not plead guilty, " an AUO executive said, adding that the company has a lot of evidence to prove its integrity.

Legal experts familiar with U.S. anti-trust cases said the conviction rate is usually below 50 percent but the process is long and tedious. That's why many corporations usually choose to plead guilty in the first place, they said.
AUO has set aside a budget of NT$10 billion (US$312.5 million) in preparation for the legal battle.

Premier Wu Den-yih expressed concern Sunday about the fate of the three AUO executives. Wu said although he is not in any position to try to intervene in the judicial procedure, he has instructed Taiwanese officials posted in San Francisco to gain a better understanding of the incident and to render assistance if possible. (Aug. 23, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Some are happy, some aren't
DOC.DATELINE: 08/23/10 12:36:25 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Poet Yang Wan-li once wrote during the Southern Sung dynasty that some families were happy and some were sad as people in the south were leading peaceful lives while those in the north were miserable because of the invasion by the barbarians from the north.
Paraphrasing that poem, we could say that some rich people in Taiwan are happy, but many living below the poverty line or on the other side of the wealth gap are sad.

Taiwan has had a raft of good news that could make its people happy. The good news includes a year-on-year economic growth of 13.1 percent in the first half of the year, a forecast of a 21-year record high of 8.24 percent GDP growth for the whole of 2010, and strong exports in July that were the fourth highest in value ever.
Nevertheless, many people, particularly those from low-income families and ordinary wage and salary earners, are unhappy, as the new benefits of economic growth have not trickled down to everyone.
The latest government statistics show that the income gap between Taiwan's richest and poorest households has grown 66 times over the last 11 years.
Equitable distribution of wealth is the bedrock of a "common people's economy," Premier Wu Den-yih has advocated.

If it is not possible for the government to effectively bridge the gap between rich and poor, it should at least take some steps, such a imposing a luxury tax and giving a moderate pay raise to civil servants, to address the issue. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai forecast to see strong growth on Apple's orders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 13:02:15 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract maker of electronics products, is likely to see strong revenue growth next year, as orders for Apple's new iPhones are expected to arrive early, analysts said Monday.
Industry analysts have said that Apple is likely to launch iPhone 5 early next year as there have been a lot of issues with its iPhone 4 and that all iPhone- related shares will benefit.
Benson Huang, analyst with Taiwan International Securities, said that if iPhone 5 is launched early next year, instead of in June or July, then Hon Hai's revenue for the whole year will rise.
"Apple's orders usually boost Hon Hai's revenues in the second half of the year, but if Hon Hai receives iPhone orders in January, it will see several injections of revenue," Huang said.
It was reported in the local media Monday that Hon Hai, which makes Apple's iPads and iPhones, is expected to receive orders for 80 million units to 100 million iPhones and 40 million iPads in 2011.
This is expected to push Hon Hai's revenues next year up to NT$3 trillion (US$94 billion) -- the highest for private enterprises in Taiwan, the reports said.
Hon Hai declined to comment on the report, but Huang said that most investors are likely to believe any positive news about the company.
Kevin Lin, senior vice president of Fuh Hong Financial Planning Co., also said that the local market is quite confident that Hon Hai will receive more iPhone and iPad orders next year.
"As long as a company's business is related to those Apple devices, it will enjoy prosperous growth to the end of this year and into next year," Lin said.
In late morning trade, Hon Hai shares rose NT$1.00, or 0.74 percent, to NT$135.50.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Refine GDP statistics and projection

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) released its latest statistics and projection for Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) last week.

According to its statistics, Taiwan's year-on-year GDP growth reached 13.71 percent for the first quarter of this year, far higher than previous forecasts of 8.96 percent and 9.24 percent made in November 2009 and February 2010, respectively.

Similar deviation was also seen in its forecasts for the annual GDP growth rates for the second quarter of the year. The Q2 growth rate of 12.53 percent was more than double the 6.05 percent forecast in February and also far surpassed a May forecast of 7.66 percent.
Local academics have said the DGBAS tends to be relatively conservative in making growth projections when the economy is booming, and inclined to paint overly optimistic pictures during recession.

For instance, it forecast 4.3 percent annual GDP growth for 2008 when the global economy was already slowing steadily. It turned out that Taiwan only posted a meager 0.73 percent growth that year. When the global economy came to a sudden freeze at the end of 2008, the DGBAS still forecast 2.12 percent GDP growth for 2009. Much to its disappointment, Taiwan experienced its worst recession in decades last year.

GDP statistics and forecasting reflect the government's competence and operational efficiency. It's time for the DGBAS to build up a new economic projecting model to more accurately discern or identify changing economic development trends and chart response strategies in a more timely manner. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 23, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists urge government to close wealth gap
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 13:46:10 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Several civic groups called on the government Sunday to raise the minimum wage, revoke its pre-assessment of income for the jobless and raise taxes on the rich and on business conglomerates in order to close the wealth gap in the country.
Wang Jung-chang, head of the Alliance for Fair Tax Reform, said at a news conference that the government has been inert on the issue.
Government statistics for 2008 show that the income gap between Taiwan's richest and poorest households grew 66 times wider over the previous decade.

Wang said the alliance anticipated the wealth disparity problem a long time ago and has been urging the government to take the issue seriously. However, the government has not only turned a deaf ear but sees the problem as "not too bad," he said.
Lucas Hu, a member of Youth Labor Union 95, called on the government to raise the minimum wage, which he said would benefit the atypical workforce.

Supporting this view, Taiwan Labor Front Director-General Wu Yu-hsiang said that the Council of Labor Affairs should raise the minimum wage to at least NT$22,000 per month to allow workers to cover their basic living expenses.
Regarding pre-assessment of taxable income for the unemployed, Taiwan Women's Link Director Lin Lu-hung said this should be revoked.
Under the current regulations, the government taxes long-term unemployed individuals between the ages of 16 and 65 on an assessed income of NT$17,280 per month.

Once such individuals are not in school, severely ill or disabled, they are required to pay taxes based on this income assessment and are not eligible for social welfare, although some of them are living near or below the poverty line, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students call for trap-neuter-release programs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 15:20:04 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Students from 27 universities around the country have launched a campaign to end the euthanizing of stray animals found on Taiwan's campuses, a conservationist told the Central News Agency Monday.

Members of 29 student groups from the universities gathered in Taipei Aug. 13-15 for the first annual meeting of a league that aims to protect stray animals, and particularly stray dogs, said Chou Chin-shan, a spokeswoman for the non-profit Life Conservationist Association of Taiwan.
It was resolved at the meeting that the students will help create "no-kill campuses" for stray animals, based on the belief that caring for animals is part of showing respect for life.
League members called on the Taiwanese public to stop using brutal, inhumane methods to capture strays, and to stop euthanizing the animals.

Instead, they suggested that a TNR (trap, neuter and release) program be introduced on campuses to allow stray dogs to be caught using humane methods and neutered before being released to stay on campus or be adopted by dog lovers.

Participants at the meeting suggested that when spotting stray dogs on the campus, faculty or students find out why the animals are there before notifying government centers to have the animals captured and killed.
They also suggested that university authorities help student bodies financially to facilitate animal management on campus.

The TNR program, first launched at National Taiwan University in Taipei City in 2006, has also been promoted and implemented at National Chengchi University and National Yangming University in Taipei City, as well as Tamkang University in Taipei County, Chou said.

According to tallies compiled by the Council of Agriculture, a total of 68,018 stray animals were captured nationwide and sent to animal centers in 2002. The figure had risen to 132,905 by 2008 and was 125,106 in 2009.
Of these animals, 42,222 were euthanized in 2002, and the figure grew to 93,205 by 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 15:59:25 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher Monday as a rise in financial shares and heavy-weight electronics stocks offset the impact of a Wall Street drop on Friday, dealers said.

With local banks expected to reveal their China strategies at upcoming briefings to institutional investors, most investors pinned their hope on a brighter outlook for domestic banks following approval to expand their business in China, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 48.62 points or 0.61 percent to 7,975.93, after moving between 7,924.10 and 8,013.12 on turnover of NT$122.56 billion (US$3.8 billion).
A total of 1,903 stocks closed up and 1,860 were down, with 298 remaining unchanged.
The cement sector posted the highest gains, up 2.6 percent. Financial shares rose 2.2 percent, construction issues moved up 2.0 percent, and textile shares added 1.6 percent.
Plastics and chemical issues gained 1.3 percent, the paper and pulp sector closed up 0.7 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks edged up 0.1 percent, while foodstuffs fell 0.5 percent.

Smartphones and touch panel makers also performed relatively well, dealers said, adding that the buying in heavy-weight electronics shares pushed the index above the 8,000 level before the market mood turned cautious.

Kevin Lin, senior vice president at Fuh Hong Financial Planning Co., said that HTC's record-high close and the rise in Hon Hai helped stabilize the market despite losses on Wall Street and neighboring stock markets.
Smartphone maker HTC jumped NT$25, or 4 percent, to NT$644. Hon Hai, the maker of Apple's iPads and iPhones, rose NT$0.5, or 0.4 percent, to NT$135.
But there was still room for improvement, Lin said.
"The index will not be able to break the 8,000 level without stronger electronics shares," Lin said.
Benson Huang, an analyst at Taiwan International Securities, said that the turnover would have to expand to at least NT$130 billion for the index to stand firm above the 8,000 level.

Huang said that most people took a wait-and-see attitude before the Unites States releases its latest GDP figures and Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke delivers a speech on the U.S. economic outlook later this week.
"The U.S. economic outlook is being closely watched by investors because it will affect Taiwan's electronics industry," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.S. to start talks on e-commerce cooperation: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/10 16:12:40 (By Leaf Yeh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States have agreed to begin negotiations on cooperation in the area of e-commerce, a development that can be seen as a precursor to the resumption of bilateral talks under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA), Minister without Portfolio Yiin Chii-ming said in Los Angeles Sunday.
Taiwan and the United States signed the TIFA in September 1994, but the United States has suspended bilateral talks under this framework several times since in 1998.
The e-commerce cooperation negotiations between the two countries are likely to serve as stepping stone to TIFA talks, Yiin said.
Since Taiwan signed an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in June it has been stepping up it efforts to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, Yiin said.
Earlier this month, it reached an agreement with Singapore to explore the possibility of signing an economic cooperation agreement.
At the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meetings, Taiwan's proposal to start FTA talks with other countries has been warmly received, Yiin said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan and China have agreed to start negotiations on agreements on trade in products and services, investment, and dispute resolution, within six months after the ECFA takes effect, he said.

The arrangements for trade in goods and services "should not be too difficult, " given that 20-30 percent of products in Taiwan and China have already been granted tariff-free treatment under the ECFA and the fact that most information technology products are also eligible for zero-tariffs under the World Trade Organization framework.
In the area of investment, there is no big difference of opinion between Taiwan and China, he said.

Addressing fears that certain local industries would suffer as a result of the ECFA, Yiin said that the government will stick to its promise to delay trade liberalization in some areas to give vulnerable local industries time to adjust and upgrade.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 17:20:29 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.033 to close at NT$31.968.
Turnover totaled US$428 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.985 and moved between NT$31.930 and NT$32.0.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pins lowering jobless rate on rising domestic demand
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 17:24:14 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: After Taiwan's strong growth in the first half of the year fueled largely by domestic demand, more investment is hoped for in the coming months to help lower unemployment and narrow the rich-poor gap, Taiwan's economic policy planner said Monday.
Taiwan's top statistics bureau reported on Aug. 19 that the country's GDP grew by 12.5 percent in the second quarter of 2010, following 13.7 percent growth in the first quarter.

"The (strong growth) was not because it was being compared to a low baseline, because the U.S. and Europe have not fully recovered, but mostly because of domestic demand, " said Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Liu was speaking at a press conference during a break in an "Investing in Taiwan" forum held in Taipei that attracted 915 representatives from more than 500 foreign and domestic business associations.

Earlier at the forum, President Ma Ying-jeou said 87 percent of the growth in the first quarter and 60 percent of the growth in the second quarter could be attributed to domestic demand, of which investment played a major role.
In both theory and practice, Liu said, investment and employment are closely linked, so if investment is generating growth, then the employment picture is likely to improve.
Also, as companies' manpower needs increase, wages could be pushed slightly higher, which could also help narrow the widening gap in income between rich and poor, she said.

Addressing the income gap has gained urgency recently after the government announced, in conjunction with the overall economic growth figures, that the average annual disposable income of Taiwan's top 20 percent income-earning households was 6.34 times that of the bottom 20 percent income-earning households in 2009.
That was the widest gap since 2001, when the top 20 percent had average disposable income that was 6.39 times that of the bottom 20 percent.
Domestic demand has also assumed new importance, Liu said, because of the changing structure of Taiwan's export sector.

Though rising exports were able to boost employment in the export-oriented economy of the past, local businesses have more recently been inclined to "take orders in Taiwan and produce the orders overseas.
"That doesn't help Taiwan's employment much, " Liu said, contending that growing domestic demand will change that structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecom carriers accepting information for iPhone 4 pre-orders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 17:37:34 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Two of Taiwan's top telecom carriers began to accept information Monday for buyers to place pre-orders for Apple's new iPhone 4, which will be launched in Taiwan in September.

Although the new generation iPhone will be distributed by three instead of one mobile carrier in Taiwan, each carrier is likely to have only about 5,000 to 10,000 units, which means the product will be in short supply, according to reports.

The new model will be distributed by Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan's largest telecommunications operator which has exclusive distributing rights to iPhone 3GS, as well as by Far Eastone Telecommunications and Taiwan Mobile.
Both Far Eastone and Taiwan Mobile have begun accepting online pre-order information and are asking people to leave their contact information so that they can obtain iPhone 4 updates.
However, Taiwan Mobile makes it clear on its website that completion of the online registration process does not mean the order has been placed.
Chunghwa Telecom said it will start taking online orders after it gets approval from Apple.
None of the three companies have as yet decided on their package rates for iPhone 4.

Based on the imminent launch of the product, Far Eastone shares rose 0.5 percent Monday to close at NT$41.4 and Taiwan Mobile's climbed 0.3 percent to NT$63.2, while Chunghwa Telecom finished unchanged at NT$64.9.
The news also boosted the shares of touch panel and optical lens kit makers.
Touch panel maker Wintek Corp, shot up 5.8 percent to NT$42.2, while optical lens supplier Largan Precision rose 0.17 percent to NT$606.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese visitors impressed with checkups in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 17:48:56 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tourists from China have been highly impressed with the service provided by at least one local hospital when getting physicals as part of their trips here, according to results of a recent survey released Monday.

In a survey of the 300 Chinese nationals it has given non-invasive physicals to since the first Chinese medical tourism group arrived from Guangzhou in June 2009, Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in Taipei found that the exam was one of the visitors' best experiences in Taiwan.
It finished second only to trips to major Taiwanese tourist attractions, such as Sun Moon Lake or the National Palace Museum, said Hung Tzu-jen, general manager of the Shin Kong Medical Club.

The Chinese nationals, averaging 45 years of age, said the facilities they saw at Shin Kong were cutting-edge and sophisticated, and the consideration showed by the hospital's medical personnel was something they had not experienced in China, Hung said.
They were impressed by the fact that Taiwanese hospitals do not have a strong smell of disinfectant -- a common phenomenon in medical institutions in China, he said.
Hung was also told by Chinese patients that Chinese hospitals are not nearly as well managed and maintained as those in Taiwan.
One example they cited was that in China, hospital visitors do not have to ask where the bathroom is. "Their noses will tell them where to go, " he quoted them as telling him.
Meanwhile, the Chinese patients also commended Taiwanese medical personnel in the survey for being kind and hospitable, according to Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three-fourths of workers interested in green power sector: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 17:56:54 (By Hsieh Jun-wei and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: More than three-fourths of Taiwan's office workers would be interested in joining the green power sector as they believe the industry has promising prospects, a 1111 Job Bank's survey said.

According to the survey released on Monday, 95 percent of respondents said they thought the green power sector would flourish in the future, and 76 percent said they would like to find a job in a related field.

Major reasons cited by respondents for their interest were "positive industry prospects" (63.48 percent) , "identifying themselves with environmental protection" (61.24 percent) and "personal interest" (46.63 percent).

Among the reasons for their confidence in the industry's prospects, "global trend" topped the list (74.76 percent) , while other reasons mentioned included "global energy crisis" (44.76 percent) and "the need for environmental protection" (38.57 percent).
In contrast, 23 percent of respondents said they would not join the green power sector, mainly because of "a lack of professional ability."
"Jobs in the green power sector usually require specialized skills, which lifts the threshold for entering the field," said Henry Ho, the public relations director of 1111 Job Bank.
Ho suggested that people who are interested in green jobs join enterprises that make energy-saving and carbon-reducing efforts to develop related knowledge.
The poll was conducted online on Aug. 6-19 with 1,105 valid responses. It has a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.95 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese medical mission holds free clinics in Nicaragua
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 18:29:53 (By Wang Tung-yu and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: A medical team organized by Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) is now in Nicaragua offering free services to people in remote areas, diplomatic sources said Monday.
At a clinic on Aug. 19 in Pantasma, which is a four-hour drive from the capital Managua, the team provided free ultrasonic services for pregnant women who wanted to know the gender of their babies.

The 33-member team of specialist doctors, other medical personnel and volunteers then headed to Matiguas and Muy Muy in the north of the Central American country, where they set up other free clinics.
The mission, headed by Dr. Liu Chi-chun, also met with Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales in Managua.
Republic of China Ambassador to Nicaragua Wu Chin-mu extended the appreciation of Nicaragua President Daniel Ortega to the teram for its work.

Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, a non-profit organization established by Liu, frequently sends teams to countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan, with the aim of improving the quality of life by providing medical assistance and educational health material.
The mission in Nicaragua was scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 23 after its five-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Conservationists call for protection of humpback dolphins
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 18:51:37 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Wildlife protection activists urged the government Monday to designate a habitat for Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins living off the nation's west coast that are threatened by pollution.

At a news conference, the activists also called on the government to address potential pollution and other problems that could result from a project launched by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Corp., a subsidiary of CPC Taiwan Corp, to build refineries on coastal wetland in Dacheng Township, Changhua County near the estuary of the Jhuoshuei River.
The waters along the Changhua coast are home to a dwindling population of the dolphins, which are considered a national treasure by many Taiwanese.
Environmentalists say the planned refineries will block the migration routes of many fish that make up the bulk of the dolphins' diets.

According to Matsu's Fish Conservation Union member Gan Chen-yi, Kuokuang authorized Chou Lien-siang, a professor at National Taiwan University's College of Life Science, to investigate threats to the survival of the endangered dolphin species and come up with measures to save them.

Allen Chao-lun Chen, a fellow at the Academia Sinica's Research Center for Biodiversity, also said that Taiwanese experts commissioned by Kuokuang have injected NT$100 million in studying the species since 2005, but that they have failed to have any papers concerning the conservation of Taiwan's humpback dolphins published in international science journals.

It is worrisome, Chen said, that the conclusions and inferences of the studies have been taken as references for charting national policy even though they have not been examined by international academic circles.
Gan said that results of research teams' investigations should be examined by the international academic community and used to devise measures for conservation.
She also accused Kuokuang of being reluctant to face the fact that the land reclamation involved in the project is the root cause of the disappearance of the dolphin's habitat.

Yang Hong-chia, who in 1963 was the first person to record sightings of the dolphins, said that there were less than 100 in the waters along Taiwan's coast, compared to an estimate of more than 200 in 2006. The drop in numbers is mainly due to the influence of various industrial development projects along the coastline, he said.

The Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins inhabit waters within three kilometers of shore that are less than 30 meters deep, with no apparent preference for clear or turbid water, Chen said, citing an international journal on aquatic life. The government should designate a habitat for the conservation of the species based on the Wildlife Protection Act, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jobless rate in July up slightly to 5.20 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 18:56:08 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's nominal unemployment rate rose marginally in July but the seasonally adjusted rate fell to its lowest level in 19 months, according to figures released by the country's statistics bureau Monday.

Unemployment rose to 5.20 percent in July, an increase of 0.04 percentage points from the previous month, as a new batch of graduates and summer interns entered the job market, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.
The seasonally adjusted jobless rate, however, fell for the 11th consecutive month to 5.17 percent, down 0.03 percentage points from June.
It was the lowest since the 5.07 percent rate recorded in December 2008, just as the global economic meltdown began undercutting employment.

In July, the number of first-time unemployed job seekers rose 15,000 from June, and the number of those who became jobless after quiting their jobs to seek better opportunities was up 6,000, the DGBAS said.

"The impact of new graduates is going to last until August. The jobless rate is expected to fall from September and drop below 5 percent by the end of this year, " said Liu Tian-syh, deputy director of the DGBAS' fourth division.

The number of those who lost jobs due to business closures or downsizing fell 14,000 last month from June, while the number of those released from temporary jobs decreased by 2,000, the agency said, signs of the improving economy.
The DGBAS said on Aug. 19 that Taiwan's economy grew at a 12.53 percent pace in the second quarter and raised its forecast for 2010 growth to 8.24 percent, up from May's forecast of 6.14 percent.
Exports grew 46.2 percent in the quarter, the fastest among its Asian peers.
In the first seven months of this year, Taiwan's jobless rate averaged 5.43 percent, down 0.35 percentage points from a year earlier.
In July, the number of eligible workers with jobs totaled 10.53 million, 0.52 percent more than in June and 2.72 percent more than in July 2009.

Reducing the unemployment rate has been a pressing issue for the government. Taiwan's second-quarter jobless rate of 5.2 percent was the highest among the four Asian Tigers (also comprised of Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea.)
Premier Wu Den-yih has vowed to step down if his administration fails to bring the unemployment rate below 5 percent by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Curtain falls on extra session after schedule set for NHI bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 19:16:16 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The second extra legislative session concluded Monday after ruling and opposition party caucuses worked out a timetable to screen a package of legal amendments for reforming the country's debt-laden national health insurance (NHI) system.

"Legislative whips of the ruling and opposition parties have agreed to address the NHI reform package at Dec. 3 and Dec. 7 plenary sessions during which a third reading will be completed to pave the way for its enactment, " Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said after chairing a coordination meeting.

With caucus leaders of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) coming to terms on the NHI reform bill screening schedule, Wang also announced the closure of the second extraordinary legislative session.
According to Wang, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang was satisfied with the legislature's move to set a deadline for passing the NHI reform package.

Noting that Yaung has taken part in every legislative consultative meeting in the past few months to explain details of the package in hopes of winning legislative support, Wang said he was impressed and touched by his dedication and strong sense of mission.

"In the tedious inter-party coordination process, I vividly felt his firm resolve to overhaul our health insurance system," Wang said, adding that since the legislature has drawn up a time frame for passage of the reform package immediately after the Nov. 27 municipality mayoral elections, Yaung does not need to resign over the issue.

Yaung had offered to resign earlier this year after the legislature failed to pass the NHI reform bill in its previous session. He also made no secret of his intention to quit if the legislature continued to shelve the bill.
According to the consensus reached Monday, 79 articles that have cleared relevant legislative committees will not be discussed ahead of the Dec. 3 and Dec. 7 plenary sessions.

Inter-party consultations will focus on the 27 articles over which lawmakers remain divided, Wang said, adding that the legislature will continue negotiations with the DOH and public hearings will be called to solicit expert opinions.
The contentious provisions mainly deal with how premium rates should be set or adjusted, Wang said.
Legislative caucuses of various parties are required to present motions on further revising the NHI reform package before Nov. 30, Wang said.
He also expressed gratification for the accomplishments of the just-concluded extraordinary legislative session that began Aug. 17.

In addition to approving the newly signed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and five related packages to facilitate its implementation, the session also passed three drafts of legal amendments for admission of Chinese students to local tertiary education institutions and 13 other bills.
The next legislative session is scheduled to open Sept. 24, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists urge punishment of parents who make children smoke
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 19:28:24 (Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Shocked after viewing more than two dozen home videos online that feature parents giving cigarettes to young children, anti-smoking activists urged police on Monday to heavily punish anyone found guilty of such "shameless and detestable" acts.
The John Tung Foundation publicized the 22 video clips at a press conference after exposing two similar home videos on Aug. 17 that circulated on YouTube.
The foundation said that since then it received more video clips sent to the foundation by web users who downloaded them from local community websites, including social networking site Wretch.
They show that "forcing children to smoke is not an isolated incident" in Taiwan, foundation chief executive Yao Si-yuan said.
The videos were placed on the "family love, " "learn and growth" and "fun and entertainment" pages, proof that the videos were made to entertain people, the foundation said in a statement.

The adults in the videos are seen treating smoking children as a kind of performance at family gatherings, encouraging some children to hold a cigarette in their mouths to imitate older family members, the foundation said.
One of the videos featured a two-to-three-month-old baby with a cigarette in its mouth. Another clip showed an adult forcibly remove a straw from a toddler's mouth and replace it with a cigarette.
At the press conference, actor-turned-volunteer Sun Yueh urged the government to take measures to prevent parents from encouraging children to smoke as a form of entertainment.

Consumers' Foundation Vice Chairwoman Su Chin-hsia said that under the Children and Youth Welfare Act and the Tobacco Hazard Act, anyone who offers underage people cigarettes or encourages them to smoke is subject to a fine of between NT$10,000 (US$313) and NT$50,000.
Her foundation urged police to take legal action against the parents in the video clips, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese golfer has personal best on Champions Tour
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 19:44:04 (By Oscar Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Lu Chien-soon shot a final round 3-under-par 69 to finish tied for second in the Jeld-Wen Tradition in central Oregon, his best result since joining the PGA Champions Tour at the beginning of the year.

Lu, who earned the final exemption for this year's Champions Tour on the eighth hole of a playoff at last year's Q-School, finished tied for second place with Michael Allen at 11-under-par 277, one shot behind winner Fred Funk.
It was his sixth top 10 finish in 11 events on tour this year, and his performance this weekend left him ranked 12th on the Champions Tour 2010 money list with winnings of US$681,478.
Lu, who amassed 12 wins on the Asian PGA Tour, was out of golf from 2001-2008 with back problems before magically recovering in 2009, the result, he says, of physical therapy and herbal medicines.
In the Jen-Weld Tradition, Lu started poorly with rounds of 70 and 73, but a 65 on Saturday -- which tied for the best single round of the tournament -- pulled him back into contention.

Lu birdied the first, fifth and eighth holes to move to 11-under on the front nine Sunday, but a double bogey on the par-4 tenth left him with too much ground to make up against the consistent Funk, who won the tournament -- the fourth of the Champions Tour's five majors -- for the second time in three years.
Lu did have a chance to tie Funk at 18, but narrowly missed a 40-foot chip shot for birdie.
"I don't know how he missed that shot," Funk said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industrial production index hits new record high in July
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 20:29:41 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index surged 20.7 percent in July compared with the same month of last year, boosted by strong orders in the electronics, semiconductor and panel manufacturing sectors, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.
The industrial production index rose to 128.62 in July from the previous month's 125.71, setting a record high for the fifth consecutive month, the ministry said.
It was also the ninth consecutive month that the index saw double-digit growth.
The manufacturing sector index also reported a historical high for the fifth consecutive month in July, reaching 131.63, 22.22 percent higher than the same month of the previous year.
Among the sectors leading the robust growth was machinery production, which rose 64.02 percent year-on-year in July, the result of strong demand amid improving global economic prospects.
The electronics manufacturing sector also posted big gains in July with a 33.31 percent year-on-year rise in production, according to the figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- BBS news gatherer becomes online opinion leader

DOC.HEADLINE: Air Force provides hangar for business aviation zone in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 21:20:44 (By Lee Ming-chung and Maubo Chang)

Maj. Gen. Han Geng-sheng, deputy chief of staff of the Air Force, told a news conference Monday that the hangar was transferred on Aug. 18 to the Civil Aeronautics Administration "on loan, " although it will eventually be permanently turned over to the administration after related legal procedures are completed.
"We absolutely support the government's policy to set up a business aviation zone at the airport as long as it does not compromise the operation of the Songshan Air Base," Han said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts Taiwan's achievements in carbon reduction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 21:41:05 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that Taiwan has scored initial results in carbon reduction and energy conservation since he assumed office in May 2008.

Ostrom is known for her research and analysis of economic governance, especially common public goods. Ma said he believes Ostrom's theory could be useful to Taiwan as Taiwan has limited natural resources and often falls victim to natural disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet hoping to help AUO executives barred from leaving U.S.

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih asked Vice Premier Sean C. Chen Monday to study the possibility of helping three executives from local TFT-LCD giant AU Optronics (AUO) who have been barred from leaving the United States by a court in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA will not raise travel alert for the Philippines: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 21:48:02 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will not raise the travel alert for the Philippines after the hijacking of a bus of tourists from Hong Kong by an armed police officer in Manila on Monday.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said the ministry made immediate contact with the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in the Philippines following the incident and made sure no Taiwanese nationals were injured in the incident.
Philippines-based Taiwanese businessmen have also been accounted for, Chen said.
The ministry has no immediate plans so far to raise the travel alert from gray to yellow but will closely monitor the situation, he said.
A gray light is the lowest of the four-level travel warning system used by MOFA and advises travelers to take precautions to the region.
A yellow light is the next level up and asks travelers to take extra precautions and make a careful evaluation of the necessity of traveling to the destination.
Taiwanese media reported that the Travel Quality Assurance Association has said the hostage situation is an isolated case and that tour groups to the Philippines will depart as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: Iranian artist enlists local politicians for video art

TEXT.P: Iranian artist Shahab Fotouhi will collaborate with local politicians to create a video artwork to be presented both on cable TV and at the Taipei Biennial at the Taipei Fine Arts Museum in September, the museum said on Monday.

The work, entitled "Elevator Pitch," will take the form of a talk show and provide a quick overview of cultural issues in Taipei. Fotouhi invited Iranian curator Tirdad Zolghadr to appear as a moderator in the video, which will also include Chen Yu-chiou, ex-minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, and Joanna Lei, a former Kuomintang (KMT) legislator. The group will discuss cultural issues such as the Taipei International Floral Exhibition and this year's Taipei Biennial.

Before recording at the Unique Satellite TV studio in Taipei Monday afternoon, Zolghadr said that the concept of the video was not inspired by local TV shows, but was based on similar works the artist has previously presented about Iranian political issues.
With the involvement of local politicians and the use of a real TV network, Fotouhi will blur the line between art and reality, museum organizers said.
Lei said she hoped through her participation to emphasize the importance of collaboration.
"We should cooperate to elevate competitiveness while holding the floral expo and the biennial at the same time," she said.
Chen, an artist herself, stressed the importance of the public becoming involved in the arts.
The 25-minute program will air on Sept. 4 at 11 a.m. on Unique Satellite TV, channel 58, as well as be presented at the exhibition, which runs from Sept. 7 through Nov. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen soldiers who lost lives in 1958 shelling remembered
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:31:08 (By Ni Guo-yen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A commemoration ceremony was held in Kinmen Monday to remember the soldiers who sacrificed their lives in resisting China's intense shelling of the island more than 50 years ago.

Kinmen Defense Commander Chang Ching-hsiang and Kinmen County Magistrate Li Wo- shih led the ceremony in a Kinmen cemetery to mourn the soldiers who lost their lives in the battle that began on Aug. 23, 1958, also known as the 823 Artillery Bombardment.
"All Taiwanese should be grateful to the elder heroes because our peaceful life today has been made posible by their valiant efforts that cost them their lives," Chang said.
Chang also offered his respect on behalf of the Kinmen Defense Command to 77 veterans who survived the shelling and were invited to attend the ceremony.
Echoing Chang, Lee saluted the veterans and said people should remember the heavy price of war and promote peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Earlier on Sunday, the 77 veterans urged the government to include information about the bombardment in school textbooks and take better care of veterans' lives.
The Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie closer to China's southeastern coast than to Taiwan, were the front lines in hostilities between China and Taiwan during the Cold War.

Their contribution and the sacrifices of soldiers posted there, will also be recognized through a series of activities on Aug. 23, 2011 as part of next year's centennial celebration of the Republic of China.

Council for Cultural Affairs minister Emile Sheng announced Monday that a peace bell will be rung that day on the two islands -- which have been part of the ROC's territory for 100 years -- to promote the idea of peace.

In the shelling in 1958, over 470,000 shells from Chinese forces were fired at the 150 square kilometer island over 44 days as a prelude to a communist invasion, but the Nationalist troops withstood the bombardment, successfully deterring any attempt to invade Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trounces Indonesia at youth baseball championship
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:39:36 (By Lin Ching-ping and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan trounced Indonesia 21-0 on the second day at the 2010 Asian "AA" Baseball Championship in Bangkok Monday.
Taiwan scored six runs in the first inning, thanks to Indonesia's porous defense, and got four, eight and three runs respectively in the next three innings to bring their total to 21.
The game was stopped after five innings because Taiwan had a 10-run lead.
Taiwan, which beat Hong Kong 15-0 on the tournament's opening day, will play host Thailand Tuesday to wrap up pool play and then probably South Korea Wednesday in the semifinals.
Should Taiwan overcome the Koreans, it would likely face Japan in the finals on Aug. 26.
Taiwan manager Hu Jui-cheng told the Central News Agency that Taiwan has a good chance to defeat their rivals from South Korea and Japan because of their superior size, stamina and speed.
The championship, which opened Sunday and is sponsored by the Baseball Federation of Asia, has brought together seven teams that also include China, and Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wealth gap to shrink next year: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:43:16 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday he believes Taiwan's income gap will shrink next year thanks to growth in domestic demand in the first half of this year.
Addressing the opening of a seminar on investing in Taiwan, Ma said much of Taiwan's economic growth in the first two quarters of this year was generated by domestic demand.

Although that growth in domestic demand may not immediately be positively reflected in employment and wealth distribution figures, it will gradually contribute to job creation and lead to more equitable distribution of wealth under the correct development strategy, Ma said.
By next year, he said confidently, Taiwan's income gap will gradually narrow.

Statistics issued recently by the government show that the income gap between the richest 20 percent of families in Taiwan and the poorest 20 percent rose to a record 8.22 times in 2009, demonstrating that wealth distribution is becoming increasingly polarized.

Ma said domestic demand accounted for 87 percent of Taiwan's 13.71 percent growth in gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter of the year and 60 percent of the Q2 growth rate of 12.53 percent.

In addition to a stronger-than-expected economic recovery that has enhanced Taiwan's appeal for foreign investors, Ma said his administration has adopted many other measures to improve the investment climate, including increasing public spending on research and development by at least 8 percent annually, easing restrictions and updating regulations.
Over the past two years, Ma said, 540 laws and acts have been amended to make Taiwan more business- and investment-friendly.

Before he assumed office, the president said, more than 60 Taiwanese companies were listed in Hong Kong. But after recent reductions in the estate and gift taxes, many of them returned to Taiwan to seek new investment opportunities.

Contending that the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China has helped Taiwan break through its diplomatic isolation, Ma said his administration will actively reach out to the world in the years ahead.
Besides exploring the feasibility of an economic cooperation agreement with Singapore, Ma said, Taiwan is also looking to sign free trade agreement-like pacts with its other major trading partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG's offer of NT$500 million in compensation accepted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:58:18 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County government said Monday that local residents had agreed to accept an offer of NT$500 million (US$15.63 million) in compensation from the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) for agricultural and fishery losses caused by recent fires at the group's petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County.
Officials from Mailiao and the neighboring Taisi village agreed to the compensation offer, according to Yunlin County Deputy Magistrate Lin Yuan- chuan, who presided over the coordination meeting.
"After agreeing to the settlement, the next step will be to process the compensation applications," Lin said.
As for the development of a feedback mechanism requested by local residents, it will be discussed at further meetings, Lin said.

Formosa Plastics agreed to pay a maximum of NT$500 million in compensation for losses suffered after fires broke out at the complex on July 7 and July 25 during a meeting with Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen last Monday.

But local residents were dissatisfied with the amount, and they blocked all major roads leading to the complex for most of the following week before temporarily suspending the blockade last Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese table tennis player gets silver medal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 23:23:39 (By Oscar Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hung Tzu-hsiang of Taiwan won a silver medal in table tennis at the Youth Olympic Games in Singapore Monday after losing to Japanese rival Koki Niwa 4-2 in the men's singles gold-medal match.
Hung succumbed 9-11, 11-8, 13-11, 13-15, 11-7, 15-13 after taking a two sets to one lead as Niwa proved more steady in critical moments in the final two sets.
The match was extremely tight, with neither player ever leading a set by more than four points.

It was the third silver medal won by Taiwan at the games. Weightlifter Kuo Hsing-chun took silver in the women's 53kg division and Tan Ya-ting won silver in the women's individual archery competition.

The games, which are the first Olympics designed for athletes between the ages of 14 and 18, opened in Singapore Saturday. Some 3,200 athletes from around the world are competing in 26 sports over 12 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industrial production index hits new record high in July
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 20:29:41 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index surged 20.7 percent in July compared with the same month of last year, boosted by strong orders in the electronics, semiconductor and panel manufacturing sectors, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.
The industrial production index rose to 128.62 in July from the previous month's 125.71, setting a record high for the fifth consecutive month, the ministry said.
It was also the ninth consecutive month that the index saw double-digit growth.
The manufacturing sector index also reported a historical high for the fifth consecutive month in July, reaching 131.63, 22.22 percent higher than the same month of the previous year.
Among the sectors leading the robust growth was machinery production, which rose 64.02 percent year-on-year in July, the result of strong demand amid improving global economic prospects.
The electronics manufacturing sector also posted big gains in July with a 33.31 percent year-on-year rise in production, according to the figures.

Chang also offered his respect on behalf of the Kinmen Defense Command to 77 veterans who survived the shelling and were invited to attend the ceremony.
Echoing Chang, Lee saluted the veterans and said people should remember the heavy price of war and promote peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Earlier on Sunday, the 77 veterans urged the government to include information about the bombardment in school textbooks and take better care of veterans' lives.
The Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lie closer to China's southeastern coast than to Taiwan, were the front lines in hostilities between China and Taiwan during the Cold War.

Their contribution and the sacrifices of soldiers posted there, will also be recognized through a series of activities on Aug. 23, 2011 as part of next year's centennial celebration of the Republic of China.

Council for Cultural Affairs minister Emile Sheng announced Monday that a peace bell will be rung that day on the two islands -- which have been part of the ROC's territory for 100 years -- to promote the idea of peace.

In the shelling in 1958, over 470,000 shells from Chinese forces were fired at the 150 square kilometer island over 44 days as a prelude to a communist invasion, but the Nationalist troops withstood the bombardment, successfully deterring any attempt to invade Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trounces Indonesia at youth baseball championship
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:39:36 (By Lin Ching-ping and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan trounced Indonesia 21-0 on the second day at the 2010 Asian "AA" Baseball Championship in Bangkok Monday.
Taiwan scored six runs in the first inning, thanks to Indonesia's porous defense, and got four, eight and three runs respectively in the next three innings to bring their total to 21.
The game was stopped after five innings because Taiwan had a 10-run lead.
Taiwan, which beat Hong Kong 15-0 on the tournament's opening day, will play host Thailand Tuesday to wrap up pool play and then probably South Korea Wednesday in the semifinals.
Should Taiwan overcome the Koreans, it would likely face Japan in the finals on Aug. 26.
Taiwan manager Hu Jui-cheng told the Central News Agency that Taiwan has a good chance to defeat their rivals from South Korea and Japan because of their superior size, stamina and speed.
The championship, which opened Sunday and is sponsored by the Baseball Federation of Asia, has brought together seven teams that also include China, and Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wealth gap to shrink next year: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:43:16 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday he believes Taiwan's income gap will shrink next year thanks to growth in domestic demand in the first half of this year.
Addressing the opening of a seminar on investing in Taiwan, Ma said much of Taiwan's economic growth in the first two quarters of this year was generated by domestic demand.

Although that growth in domestic demand may not immediately be positively reflected in employment and wealth distribution figures, it will gradually contribute to job creation and lead to more equitable distribution of wealth under the correct development strategy, Ma said.
By next year, he said confidently, Taiwan's income gap will gradually narrow.

Statistics issued recently by the government show that the income gap between the richest 20 percent of families in Taiwan and the poorest 20 percent rose to a record 8.22 times in 2009, demonstrating that wealth distribution is becoming increasingly polarized.

Ma said domestic demand accounted for 87 percent of Taiwan's 13.71 percent growth in gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter of the year and 60 percent of the Q2 growth rate of 12.53 percent.

In addition to a stronger-than-expected economic recovery that has enhanced Taiwan's appeal for foreign investors, Ma said his administration has adopted many other measures to improve the investment climate, including increasing public spending on research and development by at least 8 percent annually, easing restrictions and updating regulations.
Over the past two years, Ma said, 540 laws and acts have been amended to make Taiwan more business- and investment-friendly.

Before he assumed office, the president said, more than 60 Taiwanese companies were listed in Hong Kong. But after recent reductions in the estate and gift taxes, many of them returned to Taiwan to seek new investment opportunities.

Contending that the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China has helped Taiwan break through its diplomatic isolation, Ma said his administration will actively reach out to the world in the years ahead.
Besides exploring the feasibility of an economic cooperation agreement with Singapore, Ma said, Taiwan is also looking to sign free trade agreement-like pacts with its other major trading partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG's offer of NT$500 million in compensation accepted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 22:58:18 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County government said Monday that local residents had agreed to accept an offer of NT$500 million (US$15.63 million) in compensation from the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) for agricultural and fishery losses caused by recent fires at the group's petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County.
Officials from Mailiao and the neighboring Taisi village agreed to the compensation offer, according to Yunlin County Deputy Magistrate Lin Yuan- chuan, who presided over the coordination meeting.
"After agreeing to the settlement, the next step will be to process the compensation applications," Lin said.
As for the development of a feedback mechanism requested by local residents, it will be discussed at further meetings, Lin said.

Formosa Plastics agreed to pay a maximum of NT$500 million in compensation for losses suffered after fires broke out at the complex on July 7 and July 25 during a meeting with Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen last Monday.

But local residents were dissatisfied with the amount, and they blocked all major roads leading to the complex for most of the following week before temporarily suspending the blockade last Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese table tennis player gets silver medal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/23/10 23:23:39 (By Oscar Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hung Tzu-hsiang of Taiwan won a silver medal in table tennis at the Youth Olympic Games in Singapore Monday after losing to Japanese rival Koki Niwa 4-2 in the men's singles gold-medal match.
Hung succumbed 9-11, 11-8, 13-11, 13-15, 11-7, 15-13 after taking a two sets to one lead as Niwa proved more steady in critical moments in the final two sets.
The match was extremely tight, with neither player ever leading a set by more than four points.

It was the third silver medal won by Taiwan at the games. Weightlifter Kuo Hsing-chun took silver in the women's 53kg division and Tan Ya-ting won silver in the women's individual archery competition.

The games, which are the first Olympics designed for athletes between the ages of 14 and 18, opened in Singapore Saturday. Some 3,200 athletes from around the world are competing in 26 sports over 12 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 24, 2010, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open little changed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 09:18:35 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened little changed Tuesday from its previous close, moving up 7.69 points at 7,983.62 on a turnover of NT$3.76 billion (US$117.62 million).
The weighted price index rose 48.62 points, or 0.61 percent, to close at 7,975.93 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talk of the day -- To raise or not to raise wages

TEXT.P: The issue of whether public-sector wages should be raised has become a focus of discussion in recent days. Although Premier Wu Den-yih decided last week against a pay raise for civil servants, the top leadership reportedly may agree to offer a higher year-end bonus to government employees if tax revenues increase.

Wage levels in the private sector are also a topic of concern. According to the latest government statistics, domestic average wages rose in the first half of this year as compared with the year-earlier level, but still failed to return to levels seen before the 2008-2009 global financial crisis. More frustrating is that today's average real wage is lower than in 1998.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Liberty Times:

Statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the nominal average wage for employed people amounted to NT$47,392 for the first six months of this year, up 7.37 percent year-on-year. The growth rate marked the largest annual gain in 17 years.

Liu Tien-su, deputy director of the DGBAS Fourth Bureau, attributed the gain in part to a relatively low baseline of comparison as the country was mired in a recession last year. Another factor lies in the economic recovery, which has helped boost corporate profitability.

The real or inflation-adjusted wage for the same period stood at NT$45,161, marking a 6.1 percent year-on-year gain, according to DGBAS tallies. The amount, however, was still lower than NT$45,596 posted in 1998. The figure means Taiwan's wage growth has not matched the inflation rate, causing average real wages to fall below the level posted 13 years ago. (Aug. 24, 2010).
China Times:
Son Yu-lian, secretary-general of Taiwan Labor Front, said a pay raise for government employees may help inspire private companies to follow suit.
"But the real effect remains uncertain as wage earners lack powerful bargaining chips in wage negotiations with employers, " Son said.
In his view, the first thing the government should do now is raise the minimum wage, which has not been adjusted for three years.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Ho Tsai-feng said she supports Son's appeal because the upward adjustment in the minimum wage will not increase the government's financial burden and can instead stimulate domestic consumption to bolster further economic growth.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, both of whom are running in the municipality mayoral elections, said the government should at least raise the pay of lower-echelon civil servants by 1 percent or 2 percent to boost their morale.
Eric Liluan Chu and Yang Chiu-hsing, candidates running for mayorship of Xinbei and Kaohsiung municipalities respectively, also threw their support behind the proposal.
KMT Legislator Alex Fai said the central government should consider offering a modest pay raise for grassroots public-sector employees to let them enjoy a piece of the domestic economic recovery.
With the economy regaining momentum, the government's tax revenues will definitely increase this year to help finance the proposed pay raise, Fai said.

As the corporate income tax rate will also drop from September, Fai said, local companies should also raise the wages of their lower-ranking employees to share with them the benefits of economic growth. (Aug. 24, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Why do people want to move out?

TEXT.P: According to Gallup's latest Potential Net Migration Index, Taiwan would see a net 21 percent decrease in its population if everyone who wanted to come in and wanted to leave could do so.
To explore this complicated problem, we should first get an idea of the background of those Taiwanese who emigrated out of Taiwan, most of whom went to the United States.

As shown from a report released last month by the Washington-based Migration Policy Institute (MPI) , 76 percent of adult Taiwanese immigrants in the United States own their own homes, and 72 percent hold bachelor's degree or higher. This demonstrates that the group of people who moved out of Taiwan were the elite of society.

The MPI report also found that the wave of immigration from Taiwan to the United States began in the 1960s and peaked in the 1980s, slowing down in the 1990s after Taiwan's democratization. So it's evident that changes in Taiwan's domestic political situation have been an important factor in influencing people's intentions to migrate.

While over 20 percent of Taiwanese would like to leave, most of those who stay will not benefit from the government's main policy approach of liberalizing cross-Taiwan Strait trade. They will be resigned to becoming part of the sinking middle class and suffer from worsening unemployment.
If the government still does not review its erroneous policy, it will become obvious why Taiwan got a potential net migration index score of -21 percent. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 24, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 11:37:04 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$31.975 at 9:45 a.m. Tuesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.007 from Monday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Little League team from Taiwan routs Canada in World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 12:23:23 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang, Jorge Liu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Little League team from Kaohsiung overwhelmed Canada 23-0 on Monday U.S. time to move within one win of reaching the International Championship game at the 2010 Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.

The Fu-Hsing Little League team from Taiwan coasted to victory behind a potent attack that pounded out 15 hits and drew 10 walks and near flawless pitching that yielded only one hit and one walk in the four-inning contest.
The regulation six-inning game was called early because of the 10-run rule.
It was the Taiwanese team's second consecutive shutout win in Pool D, after defeating a team from Saudi Arabia 18-0 on Saturday U.S. time.
It will next play the winner of the elimination game between Canada and the Latin American champion from Panama, tentatively set for Wednesday U.S. time.

Because this year's Little League World Series is using a double-elimination format for each pool, Taiwan's team could lose Wednesday's game but still win its pool with a victory against the same team in a rematch a day later.

If the Fu-hsing Little League team succeeds in winning Pool D, it will play the winner of Pool C -- comprised of the champions from the Caribbean, Japan, Mexico and Europe -- for the international championship.
Taiwan would likely play Japan, which has already secured two wins in Pool C and only needs to win one of two games against Mexico to advance.
The winner of the international championship will vie with the U.S. champion for the World Series title early Aug. 30 Taiwan time.

According to team leader Lee Su-chen, the players' good form and high morale suggest that they should have no problem winning Pool D, and the coaching staff has set its sights on a potential encounter with perennial rival Japan.
The last time a team from Taiwan won the Little League World Series was in 1996.

Taiwan was long a powerhouse at the annual tournament, winning 17 titles between 1969 and 1996, but it has had a dry spell since then, with this year's club from Kaohsiung only the fourth from Taiwan to even qualify for the World Series in the past 14 years.
Last year's team from Taoyuan rekindled local fans' interest in the tournament by reaching the World Series championship game before falling to a team from California.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese folk dance troupe enthralls European audiences
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/24/10 13:13:22 (By Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Yi Tzy Folk Dance Theatre from Tainan in southern Taiwan has captivated audiences in France and Italy over the past month with innovative dances imbued with Taiwanese cultural flavors.

The troupe, composed of 17 dancers and eight musicians, has traveled 7,000 kilometers between France and Italy since July 12 to perform in six international arts festivals in various French and Italian cities.

Yu Hao-yen, a noted choreographer who accompanied the troupe on its tour, said Yi Tzy dances blend special Taiwanese temple festival cultural elements with creative choreography that reflect youthful exuberance and Taiwanese folk culture.
On a limited budget, the group had to travel mainly by bus. The performers sometimes took 22-hour bus rides to reach the performance venues.
"Such long-haul travel was tiring, but the audience response was rewarding," Yu said.

Posters of the arts festival in the southern French city of Rouergue featured the Yi Tzy troupe's publicity photos, and organizers of the dance festival in the Italian city of Alatri arranged a flag-raising ceremony in which the Republic of China's national flag was hoisted as its national anthem was sung, Yu said.
Troupe leader Chou Ling-chuan said troupe members were often moved to tears by the passionate response of audiences.
"Many of them often exclaimed 'Taiwan's awesome' at the end of our performances," Chou recalled.
She said that although the month-long performance tour was energy consuming, it offered invaluable opportunities for troupe members to learn from their foreign peers.
"It was impressive and rewarding to collaborate with members of foreign troupes in presenting opening and closing shows at the behest of festival organizers," she added.

Michel Lu, Taiwan's representative to France, hosted a dinner in honor of the Yi Tzy troupe members Monday, praising them for helping elevate Taiwan's international profile and promoting cultural exchanges.
The troupe is scheduled to depart for home Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Pay hikes for civil servants

TEXT.P: In response to Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin's call for civil servants to be given a pay raise, Premier Wu Den-yih at first said the government could not afford to do that because of its tight budget. Wu later softened his stance, saying the proposed increases will depend whether there is enough tax revenue.

Over the last 15 years, Taiwan's gross domestic product has risen by 4.39 percent on average, but there has been little increase in the real earnings of workers. Civil servants have not had a pay raise in the last six years.
Under these circumstances, private-sector workers are hoping that if civil servants are give a pay increase, it will prompt their employers to follow suit.

It is unacceptable for the government to use "inadequate tax revenue" as a reason to postpone a pay hike for civil servants, because lower revenue has resulted precisely from a series of tax reductions by the government.

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou of course gained favor among corporations when it reduced their gift, estate and corporate income taxes. However, by ignoring the hope of workers and civil servants for a pay hike, the government has probably offended all salary earners.

The government must carefully analyze and calculate what to do with its revenue and expenditure. It should not wait until election time to pay attention to the seriousness of the situation and realize that it is in deep trouble. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to issue guarantee letter for AUO executives
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 13:39:44 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)
