TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will issue a second guarantee letter to a U.S. court in an attempt to persuade it to allow three present and former executives from flat-panel maker AU Optronics Corp. to leave the United States, a senior MOEA official said Monday.

The three executives -- AUO CEO Chen Lai-juh, AUO Vice Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin and former AUO Executive Vice President Hsiang Hui -- were barred from traveling outside the continent by the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on Aug. 19.
Hsiang is now president and CEO of ODM services provider Qisda Corp., which along with AUO is also a member of the BenQ group.

The three had traveled to the U.S. to plea their cases after being indicted in June on charges of participating in a conspiracy to fix the prices of TFT-LCD panels with other Asian manufacturers between September 2001 and December 2006.

Woody T.J. Duh, the director-general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, said he will write the letter on behalf of the government guaranteeing that the executives would appear at future court hearings.
He said he will argue that because AUO is a listed company, if the executives are not allowed to return to Taiwan and run the company, market order could be affected.
Duh will also contend that any disruption in AUO's operations due to the court order is likely to impact global flat panel supply since the company is one of the world's largest flat panel producers.

He said Taiwan and the U.S. already have a mechanism for mutual judicial assistance, and Taiwan's government can provide assurances that the three AUO executives will not go into hiding and will appear in court as requested if they are allowed to return to Taiwan.
"I think the government's guarantee will be helpful to some extent," Duh said.

Duh said the first letter of guarantee the three AUO executives brought to the court was issued by the government two weeks ago, but a change in the judge hearing the case and a prosecutor appeal led to the court order barring the three from leaving the U.S.
The court acted at the request of prosecutors, who said the three men were flight risks since they live and work in Taiwan, which has no extradition agreement with the U.S.
AUO has been one of many Asian flat panel makers indicted in the price fixing case, but it has insisted on its innocence and refused to plead guilty.

Pressure on AUO has mounted because seven other companies have already pleaded guilty to the price-fixing charges in the industrywide probe and nine executives have received jail terms, according to prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council to review basic wage in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 15:02:48 (By S. F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is set to review the basic wage in mid- September after a two-year freeze, CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said Tuesday.

The basic wage level will be decided by a CLA review committee composed of 21 representatives -- seven each from management and the labor sector, four academics and three government representatives, he said
The CLA was scheduled to hold a meeting in July to discuss the minimum wage, but had to wait for the Executive Yuan to approve a new set of screening regulations.
The delay angered labor rights groups, which accused the CLA of deliberately attempting to postpone the review process.
The CLA later decided to increase the number of labor representatives on the panel from four to seven and reduce the number of government representatives from eight to three.
Taiwan's basic wage stood at NT$15,840 in 1997 and was raised to NT$17,280 in 2007, covering some 1 million workers.

Wang said the recent decision by the Executive Yuan not to raise civil servants' pay next year is a different issue from that of the minimum wage and that the CLA committee will make a decision in line with public expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers create pen-size plasma sterilization device
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 15:31:44 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Local researchers have achieved a breakthrough by succeeding in developing and producing a pen-size device capable of sterilizing instruments and wounds, even in hard-to-reach places, that could have widespread medical and preventive uses in the future.

The handy device, introduced Monday by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan, can eliminate common bacteria such as e. coli, staphylococcus aureus and thermophilic bacilli within 90-120 seconds, the university said.

Liao Jiunn-der, a professor in NCKU's Department of Materials Science and Engineering who led the team that developed the device, envisions it as a key part of people's first-aid kits because it can be operated at room temperature, is non-toxic and works quickly, unlike more conventional sterilization systems in use today.

Its ability to sterilize all surfaces, including awkwardly located wounds or parts of instruments that are hard to reach, Liao said, make it ideal for oral cavity disinfection, surgical instrument sterilization and wound treatment.

The pen relies on plasma sterilization, a process in which an ionized gas with UV photons and radicals is released near the area requiring sterilization. The photons and radicals then react with and "blow up" atoms that the bacteria need to survive, the professor explained.
Before miniaturizing the system from a machine into a pen-size device, researchers first determined optimal sterilization parameters for the micro- plasma jet system they developed.
Liao said the team's goal is for the new "micro-plasma" device to replace laser machines, which cost in the neighborhood of NT$4 million to NT$5 million.
The plasma sterilization pen, he said, costs only about one-tenth as much and is more effective than a laser.
The research team has begun cooperating with the university hospital to conduct clinical trials using the device to disinfect oral cavities, according to NCKU.
The development of plasma medicine began in the United States and Germany in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.44 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 16:02:00 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.44 percent Tuesday on profit-taking following gains made in the previous session, but selling was limited as rises in China's markets encouraged some buying momentum, dealers said.
The weighted index closed down 35.29 points at the day's low of 7,940.64, off a high of 7,990.49, on turnover of NT$130.85 billion (US$4.10 billion).
The market opened up 7.69 points on follow-through buying, but pressure emerged immediately as investors sought to lock in recent gains because of weakness on Wall Street overnight, dealers said.
A total of 1,360 stocks closed up, 2,338 finished lower, and 274 remained unchanged.
Textile sector shares suffered the heaviest losses, down 1.1 percent. Foodstuffs and construction stocks fell 0.8 percent, and the machinery and electronics sector dropped 0.5 percent.
The financial, and plastics and chemical sectors closed down 0.2 percent each, while cement stocks gained 0.1 percent and paper and pulp stocks rose 1.0 percent.
Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said the gains posted by Shanghai's market Tuesday boosted investors' faith in China's fast-growing economy.
"Investors have high hopes that the strong demand from China's market will offset the impact of a slower pace of economic recovery in the United States and Europe, " he said.

Hsu said rising Chinese stocks also gave the local bourse some resilience against recent Wall Street weakness. The local market has been caught in a tug- of-war between concerns over U.S. markets and relief provided by Chinese demand.
"Because strong technical pressure ahead of the 8,000 point mark remains, it has not been easy for the index to jump over the barrier," Hsu said.
The index once challenged the key level Monday but failed, closing below 8,000 points, although it recorded gains on active rotational buying.
"But buying has rotated too quickly, meaning the market has been moving without a mainstream sector strong enough to create a breakthrough, " Hsu said.
He said consolidation is expected to continue to dominate trade in the local bourse.
In the transportation sector, China Airlines fell 3.07 percent to NT$20.55, while Evergreen Marine rose 0.22 percent to NT$23.05.
Among other old economy stocks, Taiwan Cement lost 0.33 percent to NT$30.00 and China Steel closed down 0.49 percent at NT$30.45.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. fell 0.83 percent to NT$59.60 and IC designer MediaTek closed down 0.22 percent at NT$447.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seventeen companies win Taiwan superior brand awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 17:00:31 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Seventeen companies were awarded the 2010 Taiwan Superior Brand title on Tuesday, which means they will receive government assistance to boost their brands and expand their markets overseas.
The award winners this year, selected from 70 candidates, were judged based on their financial standing, branding achievement, brand establishment, branding strategies and competitive advantage.

The Taiwan Superior Brands Award was designed by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) to identify outstanding domestic companies with brand earnings of more than 20 percent of their overall revenue or more than NT$1 billion (US$31 million) per year.

This year was the first time that the candidates were asked to meet the brand earnings requirements. Last year, the competitors had to prove that at least 30 percent of their revenue came from exports.
At the award ceremony, Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the BOFT, said that Taiwan needs to develop its own brands so that its products will be able to reach international markets.
"We need to have quality products, as well as own brands, to expand our markets," he said.
To this end, the government is seeking to sign trade pacts with other countries in the wake of its economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, he said.

Wang Chih-kang, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) which implemented the awards, said that the council will hold a total of 20 trade fairs in China by the end of 2013 and will promote Taiwanese brands at 20 shopping malls or street stands there.

The brand awards were presented in eight different categories -- information, communication and home appliances; machinery and hardware; sports and leisure; healthcare and biotechnology; fashion; cultural and creative industries; green energy; high-end agriculture; and other industries.

Five companies won the awards in the category of information, communication and home appliances. They were electronic dictionary maker Inventec Besta, CHIMEI, KVM switch solution provider ATEN International, switching power supply manufacturer Mean Well, and LCD multi-media display manufacturer Heran.

Sanitary ware manufacturer HCG and Delta Electronics were selected as superior brands in the green energy category, while Black Bridge Food and Jiu Zhen Nan Taiwan Pastry won the awards in the category of high-end agriculture.
Porcelain maker Franz Collection and band instrument maker JUPITER were chosen as the winners in the categories of cultural and creative industries, and sports and leisure, respectively.
The online shopping website Pay Easy, cord blood private banking service BIONET, and MedFirst Healthcare Services were also among the winners.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 17:08:55 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.112 to close at the day's high of NT$32.080.
Turnover totaled US$760 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$32.018 and moved to a low of NT$31.950 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese strategy expert to visit Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 17:12:48 (By Wang Shu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Japanese corporate strategy guru Kenichi Ohmae is expected to share his views on developing southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City in a speech on Friday, the Kaohsiung City Council said Tuesday.
Ohmae, a renowned forecaster of economic trends, previously visited Kaohsiung in January 2009 and delivered a speech on the strengths and opportunities of the harbor city at that time.

City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wang said that Ohmae had proposed ideas about establishing an Asia-Pacific operations center, similar to the government's current plan of positioning Kaohsiung as a city of trade and commerce.
"We hope Ohmae can offer valuable advice again on developing Kaohsiung City and also help evaluate the city's economy, " Chuang said at a press conference.
Chuang said 1,000 seats will be available to the public to attend Ohmae's speech at the Splendor Kaohsiung Hotel on Aug. 27 at 9: 30 a.m.
Ohmae, who visited Taipei last month to give a speech on global economic trends, is scheduled to stay in Kaohsiung City between Aug. 26 and Aug. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Let me be,' health minister pleads
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 17:52:44 (By Chen Li-ting, Chou Yung-chieh, Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Minister of Health Yaung Chih-liang pleaded Tuesday with reporters to let him be, as he tried to knock back rumors that he was planning to resign because his proposals for national health insurance (NHI) reform were sidelined again by the legislature.

The package of legal amendments proposed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to resuscitate the debt-laden national health insurance (NHI) system failed to clear the floor of the Legislative Yuan during an extra session that ended Monday.
The legislature has set a Dec. 7 deadline for completing the processing of the bill, which would pave the way for NHI reform, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.
However, Yaung told reporters Monday that he thinks the DOH would need new leadership to carry out the reform after the amendments clear the legislature.
He further said that if the legislature continues to shelve the bill, it would be an indication that he was not doing a good job and someone else should take over.
When asked Tuesday whether Yaung planned to resign, Wang said there was no need for that because the legislature has already worked out a timetable for the processing of the NHI reform package.
Legislators are still divided on some articles of the bill and should therefore be given more time to iron out their differences, he said
The controversial sections of the bill mainly have to do with premium rates, he said.
Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih said he trusts Yaung and believes the minister will do his best to have the NHI reform package passed in the legislature.
Wu did not respond directly to reporters' questions on whether or not Yaung will remain in his post.
Earlier this year, Yaung offered to resign after the legislature failed to pass the NHI reform bill and said he would quit if lawmakers continued to shelve the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panel names Liuho, Shilin 'most gorgeous' night markets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 18:14:52 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung's Liuho Night Market and Taipei's Shilin Night Market maintained their positions as Taiwan's most gorgeous night markets in the final stage of a "most special night market" competition, the Tourism Bureau said Tuesday.

Liuho won all six categories in the contest based on an online poll completed Aug. 15, but a panel of seven judges, whose opinions accounted for 60 percent of the final scores, distributed their votes among several markets.
The panel also named Liuho the most popular market.

Shilin, which was in second place for all six categories in the online poll, tied with Liuho for most gorgeous in the final rankings. Keelung's Miaokou Night Market and Luodong Night Market in Yilan emerged as the most visitor-friendly, while Miaokou and Fengchia Night Market in Taichung City were selected as the best for food. Taipei's Huaxi Street Night Market, also known as Snake Alley, was named the easiest to shop at.

Markets named most gorgeous, most visitor-friendly, best for food tastes and easiest to shop at received NT$100,000 each. Liuho received an additional NT$50,000 for winning in the most popular category.

The team of judges consisted of experts in cultural circles, the food industry, foreigners living in Taiwan, bloggers and representatives from the bureau. Although they had also been tasked with selecting the most environmentally friendly market in the country, no market was selected because none of them were up to standards, according to a bureau official.

The judges also recommended Chiayi City's Wenhua Road Night Market as the most unique old night market, Taipei Ningxia Night Market as the one with the most innovative marketing strategy, Tainan Garden Night Market as the most modern and Chunghua Road Night Market in Kaohsiung County's Fengshan as the most neighborhood-friendly.

At a function to unveil the results, President Ma Ying-jeou described Taiwan's night markets as a good representation of the country's grassroots culture and said the government has taken the food industry as an emerging service industry for prioritized promotion at home and abroad.
Ma said that night markets play a major role in driving Taiwan's tourism industry and help greatly in promoting Taiwan's food internationally.

Ma said that Taiwan has seen a boom in tourism since he took office in 2008 and that the country has 658 newly built or revamped hotels. He also said there were plans to invest NT$50 billion to build another 31 hotels and create more than 7,000 jobs. The number of foreign visitors is expected to reach 5.2 million this year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma announces nominees for Judicial Yuan chief, deputy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 18:26:48 (By Garfie Li, Chou Yung-chieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou nominated Rai Hau-min, currently chairman of the Central Election Commission (CEC), as a justice on the Constitutional Court and president of the Judicial Yuan Tuesday.
Su Yeong-chin, a law professor at National Chengchi University, was also nominated as a grand justice who would serve as vice president of the Judicial Yuan, Ma announced at a news conference.
Ma said he was confident that Rai and Su's personal integrity will help restore public faith in the judiciary.
The nominations are pending consent by the Legislative Yuan.

The positions of Judicial Yuan president and vice president were left vacant by Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsay-chuan, respectively, who resigned in July to take responsibility for a scandal in which three senior judges were detained for alleged corruption.

According to the Constitution, the president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan have to be appointed by the president of the country from among 15 justices of the Constitutional Court and confirmed by the legislature.
Justices serve eight-year terms, but their terms are not synchronized.
Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said later that day that legislators will review the nominations after the next regular legislative session opens in September.
Wang said Lai and Hsieh, who have continued to serve as justices on the Constitutional Court after stepping down from the Judicial Yuan leadership positions, will resign from the justice posts soon.

Commenting on the nominations, Lin Hung-chih -- a whip of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) caucus, which holds a two-thirds majority in the legislature -- said Rai and Su are suitable candidates who enjoy high prestige in the legal sector.
KMT Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, however, said that with Rai assuming the CEC chairmanship for less than a year, his new nomination could be challenged in the legislature.
Rai must also be able to present clear ideas regarding judicial reforms in order to win legislators' support, Hsieh Kuo-liang said.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus, meanwhile, said it will vote against the nominations because they are "unacceptable."

DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng said Rai's qualifications are questionable as he has never had a job related to the judiciary or judicial reforms. He said Rai's nomination is intended to draw attention away from Su, who is a former high school and university classmate of Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese firms to pull out of China cargo carrier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 18:33:47 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. and Wan Hai Lines said Tuesday they had decided to divest themselves of their stakes in Yangtze River Express Airlines, a China-based cargo carrier.

CAL, Taiwan's largest international carrier, will sell the 25 percent stake it owns in Yangtze River Express for 312.5 million Chinese yuan (US$46 million) back to Hainan Air Group, while Yang Ming Marine will dump its 12 percent stake, worth 150 million yuan, and Wan Hai will dispose of a 6 percent stake for 75 million yuan, also to Hainan Air.
The three companies bought Yangtze River Express stakes in 2005 with CAL becoming the largest foreign shareholder.

"The investment at the time was aimed at being a strategic alliance tapping the huge Chinese market in 2005, when no direct air links had been set up across the Taiwan Strait, " CAL spokesman Hamilton Liu said.

"But now things have changed as cross-Taiwan Strait business ties are getting closer than ever with direct flights having been launched. We have decided to divest our investment, looking for new business opportunities," Liu said.
Liu said that for CAL, its divestment will be carried out in phases over the next two or three years.
Yang Ming Marine and Wan Hai said they will hold talks with Hainan Air on further details of their divestments.

Local media said the divestment decision was made because the Chinese carrier has incurred large losses after soaring international fuel prices in 2007 and 2008 and the global financial meltdown in 2009.
However, Liu said the financial condition of Yangtze River Express has recently been improving.

"Although CAL will sell its stake, business ties with Yangtze River Express will not be cut completely, " Liu said, adding that CAL still leases two planes to the Chinese carrier, while training programs for its crew members are also provided by CAL.
Yangtze River Express, which was established in 2002, owns a fleet of 12 planes, operating domestic cargo flights and serving destinations in the United States and Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official meets farmers in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 18:55:45 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: China's second-highest-ranking envoy to Taiwan met farmers in southern Taiwan's Tainan County on Monday to promote the direct sale of locally grown agricultural products to China.

Zheng Lizhong, deputy chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , reportedly said that his trip to Tainan is aimed at gaining a first-hand understanding of Taiwanese farmers' ideas in the wake of the economic cooperation framework agreement signed between Taiwan and China in June.
The ARATS is a semi-official negotiating body authorized by Beijing to handle cross-Taiwan Strait affairs in the absence of official links between the two sides.
In an attempt to keep his visit to Tainan low key, Zheng refused to answer reporters' questions or provide news releases.
Local media sources, however, cited Zheng as saying he is visiting Taiwan in his capacity as deputy director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs of the Communist Party of China.

Zheng was also quoted as saying that during his current trip, which will last until the end of this month, he hopes to gain a better understanding of what types of agricultural products or fruit China can directly place orders for and the difficulties local farmers face in selling their products to China directly.
According to the reports, Zheng also said he will communicate with various Chinese government agencies over the matter after he returns to China.

He also suggested that farmers set up agricultural cooperatives, product production and sales units or companies to directly sell their products to China and save themselves from being exploited by middlemen, the reports said.

In light of brisk sales of Taiwan's milkfish in Shenzhen in southern China's Guangdong Province, the inspection of milkfish production and sales is also be a major part of his trip to Tainan, the reports said.
Zheng was at the head of an eight-member delegation that was mainly composed of Chinese officials responsible for Taiwan affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chimei Innolux files new patent infringement suits against Sony
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 19:11:28 (Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker Chimei Innolux Corp. said Tuesday it has filed additional lawsuits against Japanese electronics giant Sony in the United States and China for alleged patent infringement.
In a statement, Chimei Innolux said it had filed lawsuits against Sony with the Delaware Federal District Court of the U.S. and with courts in China's Beijing, Chengdu, Xian and Ningbo.
The Taiwanese firm said it has also filed a complaint against Sony with the U.S. International Trade Commission.
In the lawsuits, Chimei Innolux said, it accused Sony of infringing its patents when producing its gaming consoles, flat panel TVs, digital cameras and notebook computers.
In July, the Taiwanese firm sued Sony in the U.S. and China -- also for patent infringement involving production of flat panel TVs and digital cameras.
"For the latest lawsuits, we have found Sony's patent infringement extended to gaming consoles and notebook computer manufacturing, " a Chimei Innolux spokeswoman told the Central News Agency.
"Apart from seeking damages, we have asked the courts to bar Sony from selling its products to the U.S. and China, " the spokeswoman said.
In the statement, Peterson Tien, Chimei Innolux general counsel, said the company has shown great respect for intellectual property rights (IPR).
As the company has devoted itself to research and development, "once it finds its IPR violated, Chimei Innolux will try its best to protect those rights," Tien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animals in captivity trained to rehabilitate instincts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 19:13:56 (By Kuo Chu-chen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A wildlife rescue center in southern Taiwan has achieved success in helping abandoned aged tigers rehabilitate their animal instincts by giving them fitness training the center's director told CNA Tuesday.
The Pingtung Rescue Center has been giving tigers, bears, orangutans and other wildlife training courses, such as hiding food in a toy or on a pole, said Pei Chia-chi, the director of the center.
In the case of the tigers, the keepers normally place their meat two meters above the ground on a feeding pole so that the animals have to jump to get their food.

One of them initially failed to reach the meat because of weakness in her hindquarters, but the 15-year-old tiger can now jump up to three meters and climb up the pole to grab the meat after receiving training twice a day for the last six months.
Pei said the average lifespan of a tiger in captivity is 15-20 years, but added that the center expects the tigers there to live for 25 years thanks to the regular training.

In addition to the tigers, the keepers also stimulate the sun bears at the center by stuffing food into their toys and hiding them in their cages so that the bears have to actually hunt for their toys and food.

In the case of the orangutans, the food is placed in rotating baskets hanging from a mini-Ferris wheel. In order to sample every type of food, the orangutans have to turn the wheels, which provides them with exercise.
According to the rescue center, the training has improved the health of the animals and has helped the center to save on previously huge medical expenses.
The center currently cares for more than 800 animals rescued from circuses and private zoos around the country. About 20 animals are sent to the center every month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sunrise Golf & Country Club to get LPGA Tour event in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 19:20:41 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The LPGA Tour will come to Taiwan for the first time in 2011, giving local golf fans a rare opportunity to see the world's leading female golfers, including home favorite Tseng Yani, in person, an official announced Tuesday.
Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih-yang said the LPGA (Ladies Professional Golf Association) tournament will take place in October 2011 at the Sunrise Golf & Country Club in Yangmei.
"The contest will help promote Taiwan in the global sports community and provide opportunities for local residents to watch a high-level competition in person," he said.

The North America-based tour is scheduled to hold five events in Asia in 2010 (in Thailand and Singapore in February and in Malaysia, South Korea and Japan in October and November), and Taiwan's addition could make it six in 2011.

Hsu Tien-ya, chairman of the Golf Association of the Republic of China, said the event was formally confirmed by the LPGA on Aug. 12, and it will offer prize money of US$2 million, one of the highest offered on tour.
"I believe that more than 80 players of the world's top 100 will participate, including 8 of the top 10, " said Hsu, who added that Taiwan signed a deal to host an LPGA event for three years.
The biggest draw is expected to be Taiwan's Tseng Yani, currently ranked fifth in the world and winner of two of this year's four major championships.
Tseng will have a potential home course advantage because she spent a lot of time practicing when she was younger at the Sunrise Golf & Country Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA drafting regulations on waste from optronics factories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 19:31:49 (By Lin Szu-yu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday it is drafting a set of standards to manage waste produced by the optronics industry.
The regulations will cover levels of biological toxicity and levels of rare metals such as gallium, indium, and molybdenum in the effluent from optronics factories, the EPA said in press statement.
Gallium is used in the manufacture of light-emitting diodes (LEDs), indium is used in wires for semi-conductors, and molybdenum in transistors.
The EPA decided to work on the regulations after a court earlier this month rejected an environmental impact assessment for a project by the Central Taiwan Science Park.
The court's ruling was based mainly on the absence of regulations on effluent from hi-tech industries that were to be located in the planned Erlin Science Park.
The EPA said it will draft waste disposal standards specifically for the optronics industry before September and will publish them for public input before finalizing them.

They will be the first guidelines in the world on the levels of gallium, indium and molybdenum in factory effluent, the EPA said, noting that the effect of these metals on humans and the environment is not clear.
However, the administration said the standards will include biological risks, in an effort to push factories to reduce their level of waste by improving the manufacturing process.
Based on the proposals so far, about 20 percent of optronics manufacturers will have to reduce their levels of biological acute toxicity, the EPA said.
They can do this by using less chemicals during the manufacturing process and tightening control of waste solvents to prevent them from entering waste water, among other measures, it suggested.
Companies will be given a reasonable period of time to improve their manufacturing process before the standards are implemented, the EPA said.
Meanwhile, the EPA said, it will continue to monitor the contents of waste from the hi-tech industry, record the main pollutants and update standards as the sector grows.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei reports first indigenous dengue fever case in two years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 19:56:23 (By Chen Li-ting, Chen Hung-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Department of Health on Tuesday announced the first reported case of indigenous dengue fever in the city for two years.
According to the department, a 54-year-old man living in Beitou district was confirmed to have the disease on Aug. 22. He is now in recovery at home, department officials said.
The department does not yet know how the patient, who has not recently traveled out of the country or even Taipei City, was infected with the mosquito-born disease, the officials added.
The department said measures have been taken to prevent an outbreak after it received a report of the infection on Aug. 21.
So far this year, 31 cases of confirmed dengue fever infection were reported in Taipei City, 30 of which were determined to be imported cases, the department said.

Citing data from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health, the officials said dengue fever cases in Taiwan occurred earlier than usual this year due to global warming that led to a suitable climate for mosquito breeding.
According to CDC statistics, the number of recorded indigenous dengue fever cases in the country has risen to 30 since March, mostly in Taiwan's southern areas of Kaohsiung and Tainan.
CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao warned that as 18 of the cases were reported last week, it appeared that the outbreak was accelerating.

Recently, temperatures in Taiwan have hovered around 25-30 Celsius degrees. With afternoon showers common in the summer, it is easy for the mosquitoes that can spread dengue fever to reproduce if people allow stagnant water to remain in containers, Chou said.
"Weekly cleaning is necessary to control the outbreak," he noted.
Dengue fever causes a severe flu-like illness and sometimes leads to a potentially fatal complication called dengue hemorrhagic fever.
The last case of indigenous dengue fever in Taipei City was reported in the summer of 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu to boost tourism to prevent marginalization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:33:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outlying Matsu Island group is launching a drive to attract more foreign tourists in the hope that a local tourism boost can prevent marginalization amid the warmer ties between Taiwan and China, a local tourism official said Tuesday.

"If Matsu does not try to leverage its geographic advantages, its economy will be marginalized as cross-strait direct flights are now running at full steam, " said Tsao Erh-yuen, director of the Tourism Bureau of the Lianjiang county government, on the sidelines of a press conference to announce a three-day tourism promotional tour.

Matsu, an archipelago in the Taiwan Strait lying 190 km from Taiwan's Keelung and 19 km from the Chinese coast, is administered by Taiwan as a part of Lianjiang County. The other part of the county is in China and has been under the control of the People's Republic of China since 1949.

Matsu, which is located off the coast of eastern Fujian Province, and Kinmen, another Taiwan-controlled outlying island which is near China's Xiamen, were at the forefront of the cross-strait conflict and remained under the war-zone civil administration until 1992, five years after the lifting of martial law in Taiwan.

According to Tsao, the local economy received a boost in 2001 after the implementation of the "mini three links" that allow limited postal, transport and trade links between several Chinese cities and Kinmen and Matsu.

However, he added, since links allowing direct flights, shipping and postal between Taiwan proper and China were fully implemented in 2008, Matsu has become merely a "stopover" en route to Taiwan for Chinese tourists.

"Generally speaking, our local tourism really needs a shot in the arm, " he said. According to Tsao's bureau, total tourist arrivals to Matsu were around 20,000 in 2004, increasing to more than 80,000 in 2009. Kinmen attracts far more travelers than Matsu by a 5:1 ratio.

For this reason, Matsu, which is known for its liquor production, traditional Fujianese architecture and military tunnels and fortresses, intends to do everything it can to attract more foreign tourists, who account for less than 10 percent of its annual visitors, said Lianjiang Magistrate Yang Sui-sheng.

The tour will include three female Russian students studying at Kainan University in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County. Alexandria Zakhazova, 22, her 20 -year-old sister Daria and Maria Kravchenko, 18, will get first-hand experience of the archipelago, along with 12 foreign reporters.

"We came to Taiwan to study because this is a place where you can see multiple influences, including those from Japan, the United States and China. I think it's going to be an exciting experience to learn about a new place. And we would love to visit as many places as possibly can during our stay in Taiwan, " said Alexandra Zakhazova.

The girls appeared at the press conference dressed in Republic of China army uniform a day before their departure for Matsu, an area of less than 30 square kilometers that at one point was home to a garrison of more than 50,000 troops. The number of soldiers stationed there is now down to around 2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visiting Nobel winner urges local action on global warming
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:47:37 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nobel economics laureate Elinor Ostrom said Tuesday in Taipei that there is no need to wait for a global solution to tackle global warming and that local and regional actions are just as necessary as policies made at international and national levels.

"Instead of one global remedy, we need to apply polycentric theory to develop a notion of complex, multi-level political-economic-social systems to cope with complex, multi-level (ecological) problems, " Ostrom said in a public presentation on climate change.
"My basic argument is that if we are going to solve global problems and get better global governance, local must be involved, " the 2009 winner added.

Ostrom said the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, a provider of public power to the Sacramento region in California, allowed households in the region to see in their bills how much power their "efficient neighbors" saved the month before.
This method encouraged energy conservation by giving these households a desire to keep up with their neighbors' good work, Ostrom noted.

During the panel discussion, Christina Liu, the head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that the Taiwan government launched a measure years ago that successfully reduced the use of plastic bags.
"When the measure was launched to require people to spend at least NT$1 to buy plastic bags at local stores, many critics said that NT$1 would not stop people from using the bags," she said.
"However, we did see some results (of the measure) later on," Liu said. "People now bring their own bags when going to stores."
Liu added that the government will soon encourage 24-hour convenience stories to conserve energy.
"This is important because in Taiwan, local convenience stories account for 10 percent of the total electricity used," she noted.

To offer another example on how Taiwan works to reduce global carbon emissions, Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shen, another panelist, said that Taiwan passed amendments last year to encourage local consumers to buy energy-efficient home appliances and other products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County launches reforestation campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:53:27 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin county government launched a reforestation program Tuesday with a plan to promote the formation of 2,600 hectares of forest in the central county, which houses the Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG's) petrochemical complex.

The plan was drawn up after FPG agreed to provide the same amount of money as that put up by the county government as an incentive to encourage private landowners to plant trees, said Lu Cheng-chang, chief of the county's Department of Agriculture.

He pointed out that the petrochemical complex, located in Mailiao township, covers 2,600 hectares of land and emits 67 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) each year. As each hectare of forest can only absorb 20 tons of CO2 a year, the county would need to create forests spanning 3.38 million hectares to offset the massive pollution levels caused by the FPG plant, Lu noted.

With this in mind, the country government asked FPG to at least help the formation of 2,600 hectares of forests within 20 years, to match the area of land taken up by the petrochemical complex, Lu said.

Under the terms of the agreement, those who sign up for the reforestation program are entitled to subsidies of up to NT$3.7 million (US$115,300) for each hectare of forest they plant over a 20-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Organ donation is hard task in Taiwan: advocate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 21:59:21 (By Y. H. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The traditional idea that a corpse should not be moved for eight hours following death makes organ donations difficult in Taiwan, an advocate said at a news conference in Taipei Tuesday.
Chang Shang-chun, chairman of the Taiwan Organ Registry and Sharing Center, attributed problems with promoting organ donations to "conservative and conventional" practices.
Many Taiwanese believe that a corpse should not be moved for eight hours after a death, fearing that doing so could interfere with the deceased person's soul.
According to Chang, the number of organ donors lags far behind that of patients waiting for transplants in Taiwan.

Citing the latest figure compiled by relevant authorities earlier this month, he reported, there are an average of 7,000 patients waiting for organ transplants per year, a sharp contrast to the number of donors which averages just over 200.
Ho Tian-yang, a 20-year-old Marfan syndrome patient who unsuccessfully underwent four operations before receiving a transplant, told reporters that he was able to recover thanks to his new heart.
Expressing his gratification to the "kind" donor that saved his life, Ho said he is now leading a normal life and will soon enter a university.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine SMEs win Rising Star awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:02:14 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of nine companies have won the 2010 Rising Star Award, the Small and Medium Enterprises Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.
The nine winners include companies that produce LCD displays, rectifying diodes, cables for medical and communications uses, and photovoltaic systems.

The award, administered by the Chinese Management Association and sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, was set up in 1998 to honor the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) . In the last 12 years, a total of 213 companies have won the award for excellent export performance.

All of this year's winners have excelled in their specific fields and are examples of the contribution that SMEs have made to the country's economic development, said Ho Chin-chan, chief secretary of the administration, at news conference in Taipei.
Chen Chin-feng, vice manager of Solteam Opto Inc. in Taoyuan County, which was one of the nine winners, said that the award is a great honor and a milestone in Solteam's 10-year history.
Solteam will double its efforts to explore the overseas market for its audio/video equipment, he said.
The winners will be honored at ceremony at the Taipei International Conference Center Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to donate US$1 million for China flood victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:19:59 (By Liu Cheng-shing & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate US$1 million for relief and reconstruction in areas of China hit hard by recent flooding that left more than 1,000 dead and hundreds missing, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.
"The donation is to be made on humanitarian grounds in the wake of the floods that have devastated Gansu Province's Zhouqu and other parts of China," the MAC said.

Mudslides brought by flooding on Aug. 7 almost leveled Zhouqu, killing 1,435 and leaving 330 unaccounted for. In addition, heavy downpours also caused flooding in the basins of the Yangtze River, the Yellow River, the Huai River and the Songhua River, resulting in widespread casualties and property damage.

In addition to donating US$100,000 in emergency relief and rescue funds promised to victims in Zhouqu days ago, Taiwan's Red Cross Society also launched on Aug. 12 a month-long fund-raising campaign for the reconstruction of the devastated areas in China.
Last year, China donated 1,000 prefabricated houses to the victims of flooding and mudslides caused by Typhoon Morakot, which pounded southern Taiwan in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese ICT products to be promoted in Asian market: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:23:09 (By Lin Hui-chun and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A project has been launched to promote Taiwan's information and communication technology (ICT) products and Taiwanese brands in the Asian market, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.

According to TAITRA, 19 Taiwanese ICT operators have been invited to demonstrate their innovative commodities with the aim of selling them in the emerging markets of Southeast Asian countries such as Vietnam and Indonesia, as well as in India.

"I am getting more confident about the competitiveness of Taiwanese ICT companies based on their three advantages -- financial ability, proper timing and determination to achieve their goals, " said Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang.

Indonesian star Cathy Sharon, one of three international spokespeople for the project, said that many Indonesians have been impressed by the good quality of ICT products made in Taiwan. According to Sharon, the Indonesian media is also helping to improve the image of Taiwanese brands.

Indian movie star Lara Dutta and Vietnamese beauty queen Huong Giang have also been recruited to speak for the project and promote the logo of "Taiwan Excellence, " which is being used to brand the unique designs of Taiwan's ICT products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan airlines to cut prices of cross-strait flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 23:00:01 (By Chao Hsiao-huei and Elizbeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) announced Tuesday that from September for a limited period, it will cut prices by at least 10 percent for individual passengers flying economy class on routes between Taiwan and certain cities in China.

From Sept. 1-Dec. 31, passengers on CAL flights from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei's Songshan Airport to China's Beijing, Shanghai's Pudong and Hongqiao airports, Nanjing and Ningbo, as well as flights between Kaohsiung and Pudong Airport, will enjoy the cheaper prices, the company said.
Under the program, the prices of one-year, three-month, one-month and 14-day validity economy round-trip tickets on the routes will be cut, according to the company.
CAL said the biggest cut will be on one-year tickets for flights between Taipei and Nanjing and between Taipei and Ningbo, at 27.3 percent. Group tickets will not be entitled to the price cut.

CAL Vice President Brian Chou, who is in charge of marketing affairs, said the cuts are being initiated to celebrate the Aug. 31 first anniversary of the launch of regular direct flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Each week, 28 round-trip flights will be subject to the discounted fares, Chou said.

Asked about the expected impact of the cuts on the company's revenues in the fourth quarter, given the fact that 20 percent of the total CAL revenues are generated from cross-strait services, Chou declined to make a detailed assessment, saying only that "they will decline."

Following CAL's announcement, EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, announced that it would follow suit on its cross-strait flights, as well as on flights to elsewhere in Asia, Europe and America.

Prices for individual economy class flights from Taoyuan and Kaohsiung to Beijing, Shanghai, Ningbo and Nanjing will be cut by 10 percent to 15 percent, while a price drop of between 5 percent and 15 percent will be implemented on its global routes, according to the company.
Taipei-based TransAsia Airways, which also operates cross-strait services, said it would not decide whether or not to follow the price cuts until the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu to boost tourism to prevent marginalization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:33:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outlying Matsu Island group is launching a drive to attract more foreign tourists in the hope that a local tourism boost can prevent marginalization amid the warmer ties between Taiwan and China, a local tourism official said Tuesday.

"If Matsu does not try to leverage its geographic advantages, its economy will be marginalized as cross-strait direct flights are now running at full steam, " said Tsao Erh-yuen, director of the Tourism Bureau of the Lianjiang county government, on the sidelines of a press conference to announce a three-day tourism promotional tour.

Matsu, an archipelago in the Taiwan Strait lying 190 km from Taiwan's Keelung and 19 km from the Chinese coast, is administered by Taiwan as a part of Lianjiang County. The other part of the county is in China and has been under the control of the People's Republic of China since 1949.

Matsu, which is located off the coast of eastern Fujian Province, and Kinmen, another Taiwan-controlled outlying island which is near China's Xiamen, were at the forefront of the cross-strait conflict and remained under the war-zone civil administration until 1992, five years after the lifting of martial law in Taiwan.

According to Tsao, the local economy received a boost in 2001 after the implementation of the "mini three links" that allow limited postal, transport and trade links between several Chinese cities and Kinmen and Matsu.

However, he added, since links allowing direct flights, shipping and postal between Taiwan proper and China were fully implemented in 2008, Matsu has become merely a "stopover" en route to Taiwan for Chinese tourists.

"Generally speaking, our local tourism really needs a shot in the arm, " he said. According to Tsao's bureau, total tourist arrivals to Matsu were around 20,000 in 2004, increasing to more than 80,000 in 2009. Kinmen attracts far more travelers than Matsu by a 5:1 ratio.

For this reason, Matsu, which is known for its liquor production, traditional Fujianese architecture and military tunnels and fortresses, intends to do everything it can to attract more foreign tourists, who account for less than 10 percent of its annual visitors, said Lianjiang Magistrate Yang Sui-sheng.

The tour will include three female Russian students studying at Kainan University in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County. Alexandria Zakhazova, 22, her 20 -year-old sister Daria and Maria Kravchenko, 18, will get first-hand experience of the archipelago, along with 12 foreign reporters.

"We came to Taiwan to study because this is a place where you can see multiple influences, including those from Japan, the United States and China. I think it's going to be an exciting experience to learn about a new place. And we would love to visit as many places as possibly can during our stay in Taiwan, " said Alexandra Zakhazova.

The girls appeared at the press conference dressed in Republic of China army uniform a day before their departure for Matsu, an area of less than 30 square kilometers that at one point was home to a garrison of more than 50,000 troops. The number of soldiers stationed there is now down to around 2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visiting Nobel winner urges local action on global warming
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:47:37 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nobel economics laureate Elinor Ostrom said Tuesday in Taipei that there is no need to wait for a global solution to tackle global warming and that local and regional actions are just as necessary as policies made at international and national levels.

"Instead of one global remedy, we need to apply polycentric theory to develop a notion of complex, multi-level political-economic-social systems to cope with complex, multi-level (ecological) problems, " Ostrom said in a public presentation on climate change.
"My basic argument is that if we are going to solve global problems and get better global governance, local must be involved, " the 2009 winner added.

Ostrom said the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, a provider of public power to the Sacramento region in California, allowed households in the region to see in their bills how much power their "efficient neighbors" saved the month before.
This method encouraged energy conservation by giving these households a desire to keep up with their neighbors' good work, Ostrom noted.

During the panel discussion, Christina Liu, the head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that the Taiwan government launched a measure years ago that successfully reduced the use of plastic bags.
"When the measure was launched to require people to spend at least NT$1 to buy plastic bags at local stores, many critics said that NT$1 would not stop people from using the bags," she said.
"However, we did see some results (of the measure) later on," Liu said. "People now bring their own bags when going to stores."
Liu added that the government will soon encourage 24-hour convenience stories to conserve energy.
"This is important because in Taiwan, local convenience stories account for 10 percent of the total electricity used," she noted.

To offer another example on how Taiwan works to reduce global carbon emissions, Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shen, another panelist, said that Taiwan passed amendments last year to encourage local consumers to buy energy-efficient home appliances and other products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County launches reforestation campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 20:53:27 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin county government launched a reforestation program Tuesday with a plan to promote the formation of 2,600 hectares of forest in the central county, which houses the Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG's) petrochemical complex.

The plan was drawn up after FPG agreed to provide the same amount of money as that put up by the county government as an incentive to encourage private landowners to plant trees, said Lu Cheng-chang, chief of the county's Department of Agriculture.

He pointed out that the petrochemical complex, located in Mailiao township, covers 2,600 hectares of land and emits 67 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) each year. As each hectare of forest can only absorb 20 tons of CO2 a year, the county would need to create forests spanning 3.38 million hectares to offset the massive pollution levels caused by the FPG plant, Lu noted.

With this in mind, the country government asked FPG to at least help the formation of 2,600 hectares of forests within 20 years, to match the area of land taken up by the petrochemical complex, Lu said.

Under the terms of the agreement, those who sign up for the reforestation program are entitled to subsidies of up to NT$3.7 million (US$115,300) for each hectare of forest they plant over a 20-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Organ donation is hard task in Taiwan: advocate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 21:59:21 (By Y. H. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The traditional idea that a corpse should not be moved for eight hours following death makes organ donations difficult in Taiwan, an advocate said at a news conference in Taipei Tuesday.
Chang Shang-chun, chairman of the Taiwan Organ Registry and Sharing Center, attributed problems with promoting organ donations to "conservative and conventional" practices.
Many Taiwanese believe that a corpse should not be moved for eight hours after a death, fearing that doing so could interfere with the deceased person's soul.
According to Chang, the number of organ donors lags far behind that of patients waiting for transplants in Taiwan.

Citing the latest figure compiled by relevant authorities earlier this month, he reported, there are an average of 7,000 patients waiting for organ transplants per year, a sharp contrast to the number of donors which averages just over 200.
Ho Tian-yang, a 20-year-old Marfan syndrome patient who unsuccessfully underwent four operations before receiving a transplant, told reporters that he was able to recover thanks to his new heart.
Expressing his gratification to the "kind" donor that saved his life, Ho said he is now leading a normal life and will soon enter a university.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine SMEs win Rising Star awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:02:14 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A total of nine companies have won the 2010 Rising Star Award, the Small and Medium Enterprises Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.
The nine winners include companies that produce LCD displays, rectifying diodes, cables for medical and communications uses, and photovoltaic systems.

The award, administered by the Chinese Management Association and sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, was set up in 1998 to honor the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) . In the last 12 years, a total of 213 companies have won the award for excellent export performance.

All of this year's winners have excelled in their specific fields and are examples of the contribution that SMEs have made to the country's economic development, said Ho Chin-chan, chief secretary of the administration, at news conference in Taipei.
Chen Chin-feng, vice manager of Solteam Opto Inc. in Taoyuan County, which was one of the nine winners, said that the award is a great honor and a milestone in Solteam's 10-year history.
Solteam will double its efforts to explore the overseas market for its audio/video equipment, he said.
The winners will be honored at ceremony at the Taipei International Conference Center Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to donate US$1 million for China flood victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:19:59 (By Liu Cheng-shing & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate US$1 million for relief and reconstruction in areas of China hit hard by recent flooding that left more than 1,000 dead and hundreds missing, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.
"The donation is to be made on humanitarian grounds in the wake of the floods that have devastated Gansu Province's Zhouqu and other parts of China," the MAC said.

Mudslides brought by flooding on Aug. 7 almost leveled Zhouqu, killing 1,435 and leaving 330 unaccounted for. In addition, heavy downpours also caused flooding in the basins of the Yangtze River, the Yellow River, the Huai River and the Songhua River, resulting in widespread casualties and property damage.

In addition to donating US$100,000 in emergency relief and rescue funds promised to victims in Zhouqu days ago, Taiwan's Red Cross Society also launched on Aug. 12 a month-long fund-raising campaign for the reconstruction of the devastated areas in China.
Last year, China donated 1,000 prefabricated houses to the victims of flooding and mudslides caused by Typhoon Morakot, which pounded southern Taiwan in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese ICT products to be promoted in Asian market: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/10 22:23:09 (By Lin Hui-chun and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A project has been launched to promote Taiwan's information and communication technology (ICT) products and Taiwanese brands in the Asian market, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.

According to TAITRA, 19 Taiwanese ICT operators have been invited to demonstrate their innovative commodities with the aim of selling them in the emerging markets of Southeast Asian countries such as Vietnam and Indonesia, as well as in India.

"I am getting more confident about the competitiveness of Taiwanese ICT companies based on their three advantages -- financial ability, proper timing and determination to achieve their goals, " said Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang.

Indonesian star Cathy Sharon, one of three international spokespeople for the project, said that many Indonesians have been impressed by the good quality of ICT products made in Taiwan. According to Sharon, the Indonesian media is also helping to improve the image of Taiwanese brands.

Indian movie star Lara Dutta and Vietnamese beauty queen Huong Giang have also been recruited to speak for the project and promote the logo of "Taiwan Excellence, " which is being used to brand the unique designs of Taiwan's ICT products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 25, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: NHI should focus on fundamentals

TEXT.P: Because of its possible negative impact on the Nov. 27 local elections, the Legislative Yuan is not expected to deal with a bill that would introduce a second-generation national health insurance (NHI) premium until after the elections.
One of the disputes surrounding the second-generation NHI involves its premium rate, which was recalculated with the goal of controlling the program's deficit.

However, if the deficit is the result of poor management, how can people continue to fill the money pit willingly? Problems that remain to be resolved include the waste of medical resources and the non-stop expansion of medical spending.
In other words, improving the system's fundamentals is a more important issue than improving its finances, because good finances come with good fundamentals.

If the second-generation national health insurance system is the correct approach, Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang has the responsibility to stay to prove it. If there are still doubts about the reform, Yaung has an even greater responsibility to stay to ensure that it is functional. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Where is the DPP's policy blueprint?
DOC.DATELINE: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 08/25/10 11:03:42 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who is running for mayor of Xinbei City, said the ruling Kuomintang has "gotten it wrong" for making the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) an issue in the run-up to the Nov. 27 local elections.
Obviously, the DPP is pulling out of the ECFA battleground for a new one.

In a latest attempt to raise a new issue, Tsai's campaign team strongly challenged the huge pile of debt built up by her KMT rival, Eric Liluan Chu, during his two terms as Taoyuan County magistrate. In response, Chu admitted that Taoyuan County's debt had increased by NT$15 billion when he stepped down from the magistrate position, but he also stressed that the county's assets had risen by NT$220 billion over the same period.
This demonstrates that the DPP's bombardment has again missed the target.

Now that Chu has already presented his plan to develop Xinbei City, it would be better for the DPP to put forward its own policy blueprint than repeatedly questioning its rival's agenda-setting ability. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 25, 2010)
