DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Mixed reaction to Judicial Yuan nominations

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's nomination of Rai Hau-min, a veteran lawyer who now chairs the Central Election Commission, as the new Judicial Yuan chief, and Su Yeong-chin, a law professor closely associated with Ma, as Rai's deputy has drawn mixed reaction.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the development:
China Times:

President Ma told a news conference Tuesday that he expected that the Rai-Su team will lead what he called "national judicial reform, " in which the Judicial Yuan will join forces with incorruptible judicial personnel as well as legal experts and individual activists to clean up the beleaguered judicial system and restore public trust in the judiciary.

For the ongoing judicial reform to be successful, Ma said, it cannot just rely on a few elites but will need the help of everybody concerned with the issue. "Only through extensive consultations can we know what grassroots people think and how they feel," he added.
Rai said he was shocked to receive the nomination, but decided to accept the challenge with pleasure as he empathized with those disappointed in the judicial system.
If the Legislative Yuan confirms his nomination, the 71-year-old said, he will commit himself to judicial reform.
"I will take bold steps to overhaul the judicial system after forging a national consensus as our people cannot wait any longer for long overdue judicial reform," he added. (Aug. 25, 2010).
United Daily News:

President Ma outlined major reasons for nominating Rai and Su to head the Judicial Yuan, saying both are honest, highly professional and widely respected and have the enthusiasm to promote judicial reform.

Ma also mentioned their work as advisers to the government and their experience in leading independent administrative agencies. Su once headed the National Communications Commission, an independent regulatory body supervising media and telecom operations.
For his part, Rai said Taiwan's people are, in fact, not asking a lot of the judiciary.

"All they want to see are judges who are not corrupt, and who are fair, honest, even-tempered and effective, " Rai said. He added that measures would be taken to prevent delays in judicial proceedings in addition to launching a crackdown on corruption.

On the nomination of Rai and Su, former President Lee Teng-hui said Ma had only recruited his confidants to his administrative team. "He should instead employ truly competent persons," Lee contended. (Aug. 25, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Political sources said Ma originally intended to name Su, a core member of Ma's brain trust and the younger brother of former National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, as Judicial Yuan head, but instead named him as Rai's deputy to stem criticism that he had recruited a protege to manipulate the judiciary.

Ruling Kuomintang lawmakers generally responded favorably to Ma's nomination of Rai and Su for the Judicial Yuan leadership posts. Lin Hung-chi, the party's legislative whip, said Rai has no partisan affiliation and has never worked in the judicial system, allowing him a freer hand to clean up the ranks of the judiciary.

But Ker Chien-ming, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus convener, expressed his doubts about Rai's ability, saying he is too old and may be just a figurehead to pave the way for Ma's protege, Su, to take over the top judicial post in the future. Given Su's close ties with Ma, Ker said he believes that Su will pull the strings from behind the scenes, rendering Rai to a figurehead role. (Aug. 25, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan holds investment promotion event in Israel
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 12:21:01 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A recently signed trade pact between Taiwan and China will be advantageous to Israeli enterprises that want to invest in Taiwan or use Taiwan as a springboard or partner to enter Asian markets, Taiwan's representative to Israel said Tuesday in Tel Aviv.

In a briefing on the direction of Taiwan's efforts to solicit investment following the signing of the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in June, representative Chang Liang-jen touted Taiwan's geographic and economic position.
Located at the intersection of Northeast Asia and Southeast Asia, Taiwan occupies a strong strategic economic position in the region and can use China as a "hinterland," he said.

Taiwan and China have signed 14 agreements and the ECFA since President Ma Ying- jeou took office in 2008, Chang noted, and said that Israeli enterprises are welcome to invest in Taiwan or use Taiwan as a springboard or economic partner to venture into the vast Chinese market and other markets in Asia.

He said that Israeli businesses could enjoy tariff-free treatment for certain goods sold to China under the ECFA and could also take advantage of Taiwanese businesses' knowledge of business opportunities and China's commercial environment to expand their market there and secure dual legal protections.

Jerry M. J. Shyy, the economic division head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tel-Aviv, briefed those attending the event on Taiwan's economic development and competitive advantages, the current state of foreign investment in Taiwan and incentives for foreign businesses to invest in Taiwan.

Shyy also introduced Taiwan's 12 major infrastructure projects, six emerging industries for prioritized development, and an investment-solicitation forum Taiwan's government plans to hold on Sept. 23.
Wang Chun-chieh, a former adviser to the Taiwan branch of IBM, also delivered a speech on business opportunities in Taiwan's high-tech industry.

Saying that digital content will be a star industry in the coming decade, Wang suggested that Israeli enterprises in the sector capitalize on their R&D and innovation advantages to collaborate with Taiwanese companies.

According to Chang, Taiwan is aggressively promoting cultural as well as economic and trade cooperation with Israel, and this year two-way trade between the two countries is expected to reach US$1.2 billion and could increase further.
The briefing drew 60 people from the Israeli media, political and business sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Rebuilding corporate values

TEXT.P: A U.S. court recently prohibited three present and former executives of Taiwan- based AU Optronics Corp. from leaving California after they were indicted on charges of colluding to fix prices of TFT-LCD panels with other Asian manufacturers.
Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission (FTC) should seize this opportunity to build up a channel for information exchange and cooperation with the Antitrust Division under the U.S. Department of Justice.

Since 2006, the United States, the European Union, Japan and South Korea have launched extensive anti-monopoly investigations targeting the LCD industry that also involve some manufacturers from Taiwan. It is time for the FTC to exercise its authority by taking the initiative to investigate the situation.

Taiwan should also examine its Fair Trade Act, under which those engaging in collusion are currently first slapped with administrative penalties and do not face immediate imprisonment. However, the people of this country should rebuild basic values that reject monopoly controls, and acts violating these values should be punished by imprisonment. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese passenger among injured in China plane crash
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 13:30:28 (By Liu Cheng-chin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A passenger from Taiwan was among the people injured in a plane crash in China's northeastern province of Heilongjiang late Tuesday.
The Henan Airlines plane carrying 91 passengers and five crew crashed in heavy fog near Lindu Airport on the outskirts of the city of Yichun, killing 42 people and injuring 54.

Liu Ke-hsiang, head of the travel service section of the Straits Exchange Foundation, said the Taiwanese passenger, identified as Chen Chung-hua, suffered burns to his back in the accident and was being treated in a local hospital.
With the help of the Office of Taiwan Affairs in Heilongjiang, Chen talked to his family and refused to let them visit because his injury is not serious, Liu said.

The ERJ-190 jet, manufactured by Brazil's aerospace conglomerate Embraer and with maximum passenger capacity of 108, broke in two while attempting to land at 9:36 p.m. Tuesday, some 40 minutes after it took off from the provincial capital of Harbin.
The cause of the crash was still unclear, but the plane's black box flight data recorder had been found, Chinese state media said the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO executives play waiting game in California
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/10 13:34:53 (By Leaf Jiang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Three present and former executives of flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO), who have been barred by a court in San Francisco from leaving California, appeared to settle into normal routines Tuesday as they wait to appeal the travel ban.

AUO CEO Chen Lai-juh and AUO Vice Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin remained in San Francisco, where their case is being heard, to manage AUO's business interests there, while former AUO Executive Vice President Hsiung Hui returned to his residence in San Diego.

The three executives, along with AUO, its U.S. subsidiary, and other senior managers, were indicted in June by the U.S. Department of Justice for conspiring to fix the prices of TFT-LCD panels from Sept. 14, 2001 to Dec. 1, 2006.
AUO has repeatedly denied the accusations and vowed to fight the charges, even though other Asian flat panel makers have settled similar charges through plea bargains.
The three executives traveled to the U.S. at the end of July to plead their cases, but ended up being forced to stay there.

According to sources familiar with the case, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California originally agreed to release the men on US$10 million bail after receiving a letter from AUO guaranteeing their future court appearances.

But prosecutors appealed, saying the men posed a flight risk because they live and work in Taiwan, which does not have an extradition agreement with the U.S., and the court agreed, ordering on Aug. 19 that the executives' passports be confiscated and their movements limited.
According to the court order, the AUO CEO and vice chairman are restricted to northern California because they are still AUO executives.
Hsiung, who is now president and CEO of ODM service provider Qisda Corp., which along with AUO is also a member of the BenQ Group, is allowed to go anywhere inside California.
Within their restricted areas, the three have full freedoms and can communicate with AUO headquarters and their families in Taiwan without any limitations.
If they need to leave California for other U.S. states, they must first obtain the court's permission and return to the state immediately after handling their business outside state lines.

The executives are now waiting for further documents and evidence their lawyers are preparing in a bid to persuade the court that the three are not a flight risk and that the travel ban can be lifted.
Taiwan's government has tried to help the three executives by issuing letters to the court that guarantee they would show up in court as requested after returning to Taiwan.
Premier Wu Den-yih has also asked his Cabinet to work closely with AUO and local lawyers to do whatever they can to find a way to convince the U.S. court to rescind the order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan for health checks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 15:14:07 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: About 20 tourists from eastern China's Jiangsu Province will visit Taiwan Sept. 19 for six days of health checks and sightseeing, making it the first large medical tourism group to visit Taiwan since the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact in June.
The trip has been arranged by Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital in Taipei and the China-based Jiangsu China Travel Service (JSCTS).

Hung Tzu-zin, director of a health management center affiliated with the hospital, said that in addition to the positron emission tomography (PET) scanning previously offered, the Chinese visitors will also be given the newly added 256-slice cardiac computed tomography (CT) scanning. Both are non-invasive checks.

Hung said that 256-slice CT-scans are used as a fast and non-invasive method for detecting vascular calcification of the coronary arteries and for accurate diagnosis of cardiovascular, peripheral vascular and other diseases.
PET scans are performed to detect cancer, to determine whether a cancer has spread in the body, and is a popular health check item among Chinese medical tourists visiting Taiwan.
The tour package costs around 15,000 Chinese yuan (NT$70,666) per person, said JSCTS General Manager Yang Qilong.
At the end of this year, the number of Chinese tourists from Jiangsu to have visited Taiwan for health checks is expected to have reached 25,000, he added.

The hospital and the travel agency will hold an event Aug. 27 in the Chinese city of Nanjing to promote medical tourism in Taiwan, targeting representatives of travel agencies and tour operators in the city, according to Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF deputy chief visits Hangzhou seeking Chinese investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 15:33:36 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The vice chairman and secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) encouraged Chinese businesses to invest in Taiwan Wednesday during a visit to the city of Hangzhou in China's Zhejiang Province.

Kao Koong-lian said in a meeting with Hangzhou Deputy Mayor Zhang Jianting and Shaoxing Deputy Mayor Xu Mingguang that the clinching of the tariff-cutting economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will help create more business opportunities for companies on both sides and that Zhejiang firms are welcome to venture into Taiwan on that foundation.
Praising the vigor of the many Zhejiang-based businesses, he said Taiwan and China should take advantage of the ECFA to build mutually beneficial situations.

Traveling at the head of a delegation composed of officials of the SEF, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council, Kao also has Shanghai and several other Zhejiang cities, including Shaoxing and Ningbo, on the itinerary of his Aug. 21-28 trip.
Over the past few days, he also paid visits to several Taiwanese-funded companies there and voiced support for their efforts in technological upgrading and industrial transformation.
The SEF deputy chief was scheduled to chair a seminar with Taiwanese businessmen in Hangzhou later in the day and to proceed to Jiaxing City the following day.
A day earlier, Kao toured an animated film park in Hangzhou, where he called for broader cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in cultural innovation.
The SEF is responsible for cross-strait exchanges with China in the absence of formal government-to-government contact.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC Corp. to launch pilot project on geologic carbon storage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 15:44:14 (By Lin Hui-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: CPC Corp., Taiwan will launch a pilot project to capture carbon dioxide for geologic storage in the fourth quarter of this year, the state-run oil refinery said Wednesday.

The project is expected to be concluded in late 2011, with the storage volume estimated at 50,000 tons to 100,000 tons, according to Wu Jung-chang, president of the company's Exploration and Development Research Institute.
Wu said the storage site will be selected from among existing oil fields in Hsinchu and Miaoli.
The CPC has in recent years been engaging in research into carbon capture and storage, a technology aimed at reducing carbon emissions into the atmosphere.

The method mainly involves capturing carbon dioxide from large point sources such as fossil fuel power plants, steel mills and petrochemical plants. The gas is sequestered and compressed before being injected into deep geological formations 1,000-2,000 meters underground for long-term storage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 2.56 percent on Wall Street fall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 16:54:11 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 2.56 percent Wednesday in heavy trade as investors rushed to dump their holdings after a selloff on Wall Street overnight amid economic concerns, dealers said.
The weighted index closed down 203.66 points to the day's low of 7,736.98, off a high of 7,889.57, on turnover of NT$159.31 billion (US$4.98 billion).

The market opened down 0.64 percent after Wall Street's 1.3 percent fall, and selling accelerated across the board after the latest disappointing U.S. home sales data cemented fears that the slower pace of the U.S. economy will affect global demand, dealers said.
A total of 3,358 stocks closed down, 637 were up and 91 remained unchanged.
Textile stocks faced the heaviest selling, finishing down 5.4 percent. Construction stocks fell 4.2 percent, cement and foodstuffs lost 3.6 percent and financial shares shed 3.5 percent.
The paper and pulp, and plastics and chemical sectors closed down 2.2 percent each, and the machinery and electronics sector fell 2.1 percent.
"The expanded turnover showed investors acted in panic, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
"Investors have become much more cautious about the global economy, fearing the U.S. home sales data will breed further gloomy economic figures," he said.
Chiang said that by falling below the technical support level of 7,800 helped to destabilize the local bourse, leaving the market technically weaker.

"Further volatility on Wall Street is possible as the Dow Jones Industrial Average is on the brink of falling below the key 10,000 points, " Chiang said, "Foreign institutional investors are likely to cut their holdings here to meet demand for redemption back home."
Old economy stocks encountered higher pressure after making significant gains recently on hopes that increasing commerce with China would boost earnings, dealers said.
"Valuations of these traditional industrial stocks still remain high. It is possible that they will see more selling on profit-taking," Chiang said.
Large cap electronics and financial stocks, however, are worth the market's attention as they appear attractive after recent consolidation, he said.
Among old economy stocks, Shinkong Textile shed 6.88 percent to NT$37.90, Prince Housing fell 6.58 percent to NT$17.05 and Taiwan Cement lost 2.33 percent to NT$29.30.
In the electronics sector, flat panel producer AU Optronics fell 2.50 percent to NT$27.30 and smartphone firm HTC closed down 0.47 percent at NT$637.00.
Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract maker of electronics goods rose 2.13 percent to NT$119.50 after going ex-dividend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Revenues at three high-tech parks grow 66% in first half of year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 17:02:35 (By Lin Hui-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Helped by the global economic recovery, the combined revenues of Taiwan's three science parks rose by 66 percent in the first half of the year year-on-year, the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) said Wednesday.

Total turnover at the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu County, the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County and the Central Taiwan Science Park in Taichung city and county totaled NT$1.52 trillion (US$32.8 billion) from January to June 2010, easily eclipsing the parks' sales in the first six months of 2009.
More than nine-tenths (91.3 percent) of the revenues were generated by companies in the semiconductor and optoelectronic sectors, the NSC reported.
The NSC expected that the parks' combined revenues should surpass a record NT$2 trillion for 2010 as a whole.

Hsieh Chi C., the chairman of the Association of Industries in Science Parks, said earlier this month that the full-year revenues from Hsinchu Science Park, Central Taiwan Science Park, and Southern Taiwan Science Park, are expected to reach NT$1.1 trillion, NT$400 billion and NT$500 billion, respectively.
In 2009, the three parks recorded a combined turnover of NT$1.58 trillion, 13.9 percent down from the previous year because of the global economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: TransAsia Airways follows CAL, EVA with price cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 17:13:09 (By Wang Shu-fen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's TransAsia Airways announced Wednesday that it will reduce prices by up to 20 percent on two routes between Taiwan and China until the end of this year, just one day after price reduction announcements by China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways.

TransAsia said that from Sept. 1 to Dec. 31, it will reduce prices on routes between Taipei's Songshan Airport and China's Hangzhou and Tianjin airports, covering tickets valid for one year, three months, one month and 14 days.

The company said passengers who purchase one-year tickets between Taipei and Tianjin will enjoy the biggest reduction of 20 percent, or NT$4,000 (US$126) , while Taipei-Hangzhou tickets with the same validity will be down by 19 percent, or NT$3,500 (US$110).

A day earlier, CAL and EVA -- Taiwan's two largest carriers -- announced price drops on routes from Taiwan serving certain Chinese destinations, including Beijing, Shanghai's Pudong and Hongqiao airports, Nanjing and Ningbo.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 17:14:56 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.025 to close at NT$32.055.
Turnover totaled NT$958 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.080 and moved to a low of NT$32.000 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Survey says 70% of universities disregard student rights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 17:30:32 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Seventy percent of universities included in a nationwide student rights evaluation received failing scores, reflecting a general disregard for student rights in Taiwan, according to a panel of students who conducted the survey released Wednesday.

The evaluation, conducted among 65 universities around Taiwan, rated National Chung Cheng University (CCU) best in terms of protecting student rights, with a score of 82.71. Tatung University received the lowest rating of 21.29.
National Taiwan University (NTU) -- the country's most distinguished academic institute -- only ranked 13th, with a rating of 62.65.
The evaluation was carried out by a panel of students from NTU, National Sun Yat-sen University, Chang Gung University, National Taiwan Normal University and National Kaohsiung Normal University.
Rounding out the top five after CCU were Nanhua University, National Chi Nan University, National Dong Hwa University and Kaohsiung Medical University.
Besides Tatung University, others ranking in the bottom five were I-Shou University, Huafan University, Asia University, and National University of Tainan.

The results revealed that 57 percent of universities forbid students from organizing assemblies or parades, and 38 percent have a system for penalizing those who encourage student movements or protest activities.

The panel used 26 criteria to rate the universities, including whether the schools lock their gates at night to prevent students from entering or exiting, strictness of dormitory regulations, gender equality and freedom of speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics urged to step up accident prevention efforts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 17:58:14 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The head of a local petrochemical association urged the Formosa Plastics Group Wednesday to review two fires that broke out at its petrochemical complex in Yunlin County in July and prevent the recurrence of similar accidents.

Preston W. Chen, executive director of the Petrochemical Industry Association of Taiwan, said at a general assembly of the association that Formosa Plastics should reflect on the accidents, but he also urged the public to give the company more time to deal with the situation.

Chen also said he regretted that the petrochemical industry had not done enough to change the public's misconception about the sector and that one of the industry's main tasks in the future would be to do more to protect the environment to ease public concerns.

Despite mounting opposition to the development of the petrochemical industry, Chen said it makes a vital contribution to the country's economic growth, making its existence necessary, and many countries, including Singapore, are still expanding the scale of their petrochemical capacity.

Chen, who hopes to build a new Kuokuang petrochemical complex on Taiwan's western coast in Changhua County but is facing stiff resistance, said the industry's importance is reflected by the fact that 80 percent of the raw materials for the high-tech sector and 90 percent of consumer products are made from petrochemicals.
The annual output value of Taiwan's petrochemical industry is about NT$1.7 trillion, accounting for 30 percent of the value produced by the country's manufacturing sector, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. confirms approval of three arms sales to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/25/10 18:04:11 (By Zep Hu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of State confirmed Tuesday that it had notified Congress of its decision to allow U.S. companies to sell Taiwan defense articles and services to support and upgrade its existing air defense radar systems.

Philip Crowley, assistant secretary of state for public affairs, said during a regular news briefing that the State Department had notified Congress as required under the Arms Export Control Act of the proposed direct commercial sales (DCS) between Taiwan and private U.S. companies.

Under the DCS program, Crowley said, the foreign customer enters into a direct relationship with a private U.S. company, which must then apply for an export license from the State Department in accordance with U.S. law.

The decision to approve these export licenses will allow the commercial export to Taiwan of defense services, technical data and defense articles to support Taiwan's existing air defense radar system and improvements to existing radar used in Taiwan's Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighter aircraft, Crowley said.
He further said the authorizing of the export licenses is fully consistent with Washington's "one China" policy based on three U.S.-China joint communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act.
Asked whether the latest arms sales to Taiwan will draw strong protests from Chinese authorities, Crowley said that he will "let China react to this as they see fit."

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, said during a visit to Taiwan in June that the State Department had been forced to defer three arms sales to Taiwan under Chinese pressure.
However, the council, which groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan, said Tuesday that the U.S. administration notified Congress Aug. 12 of its decision to approve the sales.
The council further said it believes the latest State Department decision will contribute to returning to normal U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

In the past, the United States usually sold arms to Taiwan under its Foreign Military Sales (FMS) system, with the U.S. government supervising bidding, production and delivery of the defense articles, services and technological data.

Under the FMS system, the U.S. government is responsible for enforcing the sales contracts. The model operates as if it is the U.S. government procuring the items from private contractors and reselling them to the foreign customer. The FMS system is more costly for the procuring countries because they have to foot the U.S. government's administrative bill, but the deal is less risky and offers greater guarantee of success.

In contrast, the DCS system is more flexible and costs less for the procuring country. However, it is also less transparent and less secure. As export licenses issued under the DCS system remain valid for only four years, procuring countries face higher risks of any deal going into default.
State Department studies show that only 50 percent of approved DCS deals are actually substantiated and delivered.
According to statistics compiled by the Center for International Policy -- a U.S. think tank -- about 52 percent of U.S. arms deals struck between 1986 and 1996 were brokered under the DCS system.

The think tank said foreign countries that opt for the DCS system tend to be familiar with the U.S. defense industry and capable of directly negotiating prices with U.S. defense contractors. Taiwan on the other hand has seldom used the DCS system.

Both the DCS and FMS systems require the U.S. administrative branch to notify Congress of each approved arms deal worth more than a specified amount of money. The deal will automatically take effect if Congress does not pass a resolution against the deal within 30 days.
As the executive branch tends to reach consensus with Congress on specific deals before serving formal notice, there is little in the way of precedent in which Congress has voted against such deals.
However, it remained unclear why the State Department referred the Taiwan arms sales during the Congress recess rather than the normal practice of submitting the referral during the Congress session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Compal, LGD to set up joint venture in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 18:14:44 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Notebook computer firm Compal Electronics, Inc. said Wednesday that it plans to set up a joint venture in China with South Korea's flat panel maker LG Display Co., focusing on the production of components used in notebooks.

In a statement filed with the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Compal said its wholly owned unit Compal International Holding Co. will invest US$7.35 million in the joint venture, which will be located in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province.

The two partners have tentatively set the capital size of the new company at US$15 million. Based on this figure, Compal is expected to take a 49 percent stake and LGD will hold the remaining 51 percent.
Apart from the production of components, the joint venture will also be engaged in research and development in notebook production, assembly and marketing, the statement said.

"It is a good move for Compal to work with LGD, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said, "Amid fierce competition in the global notebook market, teaming up with a foreign firm is expected to pin down more potential buyers for Compal."
"How to boost shipments has become critical, as the gross margin of many contract notebook makers has been seriously squeezed," Tang said.
He estimated that Compal's gross margin has fallen below 5 percent as competition has escalated.
Tang said that in the first half of this year, notebook firms suffered from a shortage of components.
"The new joint venture... is expected to cushion the possible impact from future insufficient component supplies," Tang said.

Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu agreed, saying that as LGD is good at thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT LCD) production, one of the most important notebook components, the cooperation is expected to help Compal secure flat panel supplies.
More importantly, Hsu said, LGD is one of the suppliers for Apple's iPad. "I suspect Compal is eyeing orders from Apple through the joint venture," he added.
Compal officials were not available for comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Award-winning farmer maintains guava 'museum'
DOC.DATELINE: 08/25/10 18:25:54 (CommonWealth 453)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Chiang Tsai-lang's dedication to growing guavas for more than 40 years has seen him create a wealth of varieties, making his 4,850-square-meter farm in central Taiwan a "museum of guava" and a must-see attraction for anyone interested in his unique growing and cultivation techniques.

In addition to the common varieties of guava, the 68-year-old's farm in Changhua County's Yuanlin Township boasts such oddities as purple guavas and guavas that look like watermelons on the inside. To identify each variety, Chiang tags his trees with labels in various colors.

Chiang began to study farm management, pest control and growing techniques after becoming the first head of a local guava production and marketing group in 1989, and his work won him an "Outstanding Farmer" award from the Council of Agriculture in 2006.

"Farmers used to grow without a plan and focus on quantity rather than quality. All this had to change, " Chiang said, explaining what he learned from the group's poor sales at various fairs when it was first getting started.

Chiang's first success came when he developed a fragrant variety of guava in 1994 that sold for NT$160 (US$5) per jin -- a traditional measurement equal to about 600 grams -- at a time when the price for mainstream Thai-style guavas were selling for NT$30 per jin.

Wilma Ku, owner of the jam brand Red on Tree, which buys 360 kilograms of Chiang's fragrant guavas every month, said the variety is perfect for her jam not only because of its fragrance but also its durability while being transported.

In addition to new varieties, Chiang has developed his own method for producing seedlings from tree branches, which saves money and prevents diseases or pests brought in by seedlings purchased from outside.
He also uses sugarcane instead of chemical fertilizer on his farm and received "Good Agriculture Practice" (GAP) certification in 1998 -- well ahead of many other farmers.

As Chiang believes branding "is about a recognition of quality that stands out among others" and can solve the problem of production surpluses, one of his major projects was setting up a brand for the guava production and marketing group.

Chiang is getting older, but he remains determined to maintain the farm, despite the fact that currently there is no one set to take over. He has reduced his farm from five hectares to its present size and says he will share everything he knows as long as there are people willing to learn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China stage largest-ever joint raid on fraud rings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 19:11:36 (By Lin Shen-hsu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China police nabbed 450 suspects Wednesday in the largest-ever joint crackdown on fraud rings operating on the both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to Taiwan police.

Criminal Investigation Bureau Director Lin Teh-hua said the raids were launched simultaneously in Taiwan's 12 counties and cities and the Chinese provinces of Fujian, Huanan, Hubei, Anhui, Guangdong and Guangxi, and in Chongqing City.
Some 548 Taiwanese law enforcement officers and 2,720 Chinese police took part in the operation.

In Taiwan, 121 people were arrested and NT$11 million, believed to be swindled funds, was seized. Items such as computers, cell phones, servers, forged official seals, fake courier uniforms, pistols, "manuals" on fraud, and bank books were also confiscated.
Across the strait, Chinese police officers arrested 329 suspects and seized similar items that were believed to have been used in the operations of the fraud rings.

Taiwan police said that fraud rings usually swindle people by posing as prosecutors, failing to deliver goods bought on websites, convincing victims to remit money via ATMs, and delivering only empty boxes to people who purchased goods.

Lin said that police units on both sides of the strait had previously arrested more than 1,000 scammers in 16 joint raids since an agreement on cross-strait cooperation in crime fighting was signed last year.

Notably, Lin said, operators of several telecommunications companies in Taiwan and China, which helped transmit calls in cases of fraud, were arrested this time, as police found these operators were part of the scheme rather than innocent third parties as they had claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-yield millet variety developed in Taitung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 19:30:47 (By Yang Shu-min and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has developed a new variety of millet that yields nearly three times as much as regular millet, a local agricultural research group said Wednesday.
The new millet -- "Taitung No. 8" -- was unveiled recently in Taitung County in eastern Taiwan after years of research.

The new variety can yield up to 3,000 kilograms per hectare -- nearly 300 percent higher than regular millet, according to the Taitung District Agricultural Research and Extension Station under the Council of Agriculture.

The agricultural research station said that the high-yield millet is also easy to plant because it does not need as much water as rice. It can even be used a substitute for rice during periods of drought, the station said.

"With a global food shortage looming, millet can be a good source of nutrients because it contains more calories, proteins and fats than wheat or rice and almost as much fiber as oats, " said Chen Chen-yi, an assistant researcher at the Taitung station.
Millet contains vitamin A, vitamin B2, vitamin B6, vitamin B12, and vitamin E, which are rarely found in most grains, and traces of selenium, a mineral that is also good for health, the station said.
The total acreage of millet in Taiwan has dropped to less than 300 hectares from a peak of 6,000 hectares in the past when it was one the main staples in aboriginal communities, Chen said.
The quality and yield of millet, which is planted mainly in Pingtung and Taitung counties, have been relatively poor because the seed quality deteriorated over time, the station said.

The new variety will be made available to local aboriginal communities for planting and it is hoped that more millet-based food products will be developed to help diversify the agricultural industry, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to seek more liberal financial trade with China: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 19:45:29 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that the government will seek a better deal for local financial service companies in the new round of Taiwan-China trade talks, as he acknowledged that the previous negotiations did not result in financial liberalization.
"We know that we did not open the door wide enough for the financial sector, " he told business leaders and reporters before a closed-door breakfast meeting.

"There is still a lot of room for improvement (in easing restrictions on financial services between Taiwan and China) , " he said. "We should work together and act cautiously to seek stable development in the long run."

The premier said that the government will work to include financial services in the next round of negotiations under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that was signed by Taiwan and China in late June and ratified by the Taiwan legislature earlier this month.
Taiwan and China will launch a new round of trade talks within six months after the trade pact takes effect in September most likely.
Wu's remarks came amid calls for the government to help ease restrictions in the local financial sector.
For example, the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Taiwan (CNAIC), said after the breakfast meeting, Taiwanese banks can open branches in China, but not subsidiaries.
This bars Taiwanese banks from issuing bank cards and engaging in the Chinese currency-related business in China, which shuts them out from China's booming financial trade, the association said.
The restrictions also render Taiwanese banks less competitive as their foreign counterparts have been setting up subsidiaries since they entered China in late 2006, the association added.

Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , told reporters after the meeting that the government will continue to negotiate with China on these matters, and will also review its own regulations.
Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday at a meeting organized by the association that he agreed the government should give financial institutions more room and flexibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Adoption of global accounting standards will bring benefits: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:08:42 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The widespread adoption in the next three years of a set of international accounting standards, as required by the government, will create huge business opportunities for local and foreign information service providers, an expert said Wednesday.

"By 2013, 1,559 companies listed on Taiwan's bourse and over-the-counter market will be required to adopt the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)," Harry Yu, chairman of Taiwan's Ares International Corp., said at the launch of an alliance dedicated to promoting the IFRS.
"Some of the companies will begin testing the standards in 2012," said Yu, who is also the head of the alliance.
He said that 117 countries have adopted the IFRS, which requires companies to publish monthly rather than quarterly financial statements.

In Taiwan, the companies that switch to the IFRS are likely to spend NT$70 billion (US$2.2 billion) on the changeover, he said, adding that only NT$1.5 billion of that amount will go to Taiwanese software companies.
"Domestic software companies are less experienced in this field, so foreign enterprises such as Oracle will take the lion's share," he said.
After 2013, Taiwan's 1.23 million small and medium enterprises (SMEs) will follow suit and adopt the standards, Yu said.
When they make the change, many of these SMEs will choose local information service firms over foreign ones in an effort to save costs, he said.
The alliance, which comprises officials from the industrial bureau, accountants and business executives, is aiming to see at least 100 IFRS service providers in Taiwan, Yu said.
These service providers will also be able to explore business opportunities overseas by serving Taiwanese businesses operating in China, Vietnam and other countries, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan solar cell maker begins building new facility
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:13:42 (By Yang Szu-ruei, Maranda Hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Neo Solar Power Corp., a leading solar cell manufacturer, began on Wednesday to build a southern Taiwan operations hub that is expected to be capable of producing 3.4 gigawatts of solar cells a year after its scheduled completion in three to four years.
Quincy Lin, chairman of the company, said at a groundbreaking ceremony that the company's production of solar cells is about 620 megawatts at present and could grow to 800 MW by the end of this year.

To meet strong demand at home and abroad, the company will invest NT$30 billion to build the center at Tainan Science Park, Lin said, adding that its capacity could eventually reach 4.2 GW, which would make it one of the three largest manufacturers in the world.
It is expected to create 1,000 jobs and generate NT$140 billion in revenue, Lin said.
Currently, 40 percent of the company's products are sold to China, according to Lin.

Taiwan's production capacity of solar cells is higher than China's, while China produces more solar silicon wafers, he said, adding that the two sides should cooperate and complement each other in the sector.

Vice President Vincent Siew, who was also at the ceremony, said that the government is seeking balanced development of southern and northern Taiwan and that the solar energy sector is a promising industry. He said he hopes the establishment of the company's facility in southern Taiwan will create a solar industry cluster effect there.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Jung-chiou said that Taiwan's production of solar cells is about 2.5 GW a year and that after going into operation, the center is expected to sharply boost the country's production capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: First phase of `Taiwan Village' residence in Nicaragua completed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:26:52 (By Wang Tung-yu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Citizens in the municipality of Masatepe in Nicaragua held a ceremony Tuesday to celebrate the completion of the first phase of a "Taiwan Village" residential project in the city, according to sources with the Republic of China embassy in Nicaragua.

The "Taiwan Village" residential project, funded by the Care2Help Charitable Association, aims to build a total of 30 units at affordable prices for citizens of the city. The first phase saw 16 units completed.
Charity founder Weng Yen-tien and his wife presided over the ceremony, arriving to a warm welcome.
Republic of China Ambassador to Nicaragua Wu Chin-mun also attended the ceremony.

Masatepe Mayor Luis Manuel Morales said the "Taiwan Village" residences are built of cement and bricks, in sharp contrast to the existing housing in the city, which is mostly made of iron sheeting and plastic materials.
The mayor said the new buildings are expected to provide a safe and secure living environment for its residents.
Weng said he felt grateful to the mayor and to Wu for their efforts to push for the project, as it meant his association was able to complete the first phase of construction in just one year.

Weng said his association, which has devoted itself to boosting welfare in Nicaragua for eight years, will continue to work with non-profit groups in the Latin American country to carry out more charity projects providing care and assistance for the Nicaraguan people.
Wu for his part said Taiwan's government will keep cooperating with charity organizations to promote similar construction work in Nicaragua and further help the people there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi band to perform at Wonju Tattoo in S. Korea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:32:17 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A band from southern Taiwan will head to South Korea on Sept. 9 to participate in an international music festival, Chiayi Mayor Huang Ming-hui said Wednesday.

The Chia Yi Wind Orchestra has been invited to perform as part of the Wonju Tattoo Festival in Wonju, South Korea, Huang said. The military music event was founded in 2000, and this year's edition will include international bands from countries including Mexico, the Philippines, New Zealand, Russia and the United States.
The festival runs from Sept. 8-12.

"The city band has opened a door for music exchanges between Taiwan and other countries, helping Chiayi City win the right to host the biannual conference of the World Association for Symphonic Bands and Ensembles (WASBE) in 2011, " Huang said, adding that orchestras from around the world are welcome to join.
The association, which boasts more than 1,000 individuals and organizations from over 50 countries, will hold its conference in Chiayi on July 3-9 next year, according to the mayor.
Chen Jian-jou, head of the Chiayi City band, said that South Korea's Wonju Appassionata Wind Orchestra agreed to cooperate on musical events during a visit to Chiayi in 2006.
This year will mark the second time for the Chiayi band to perform in Wonju.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital uses light therapy for treating lung cancer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:37:56 (By Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An advanced cancer treatment known as photodynamic therapy (PDT) has been found to be efficient in extending the lives of terminal lung cancer patients, said a surgeon at the Taipei-based Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital Wednesday.

The hospital, which purchased the PDT technology from a U.S. group in 2006, said that since then, 11 terminal lung cancer patients have received the treatment, said Hsieh Yei-san, chief of the Thoracic Surgery Department.
Five of the patients are still alive, one of whom has survived since undergoing the therapy in November 2006, Hsieh said.
"Compared with chemotherapy and targeted therapy, PDT can extend patients' life by two times on average," he said.

Hsieh explained that lung cancer cells grow quickly. Many lung cancer patients are already in the terminal stage upon initial diagnosis and can only be prescribed the traditional treatments of chemotherapy or radiation therapy, he said.

Those treatments, however, have only limited efficiency in extending the lives of patients, Hsieh said, citing statistics showing the five-year survival rate of such patients is only 20 percent to 30 percent.
"Even with targeted therapy, life can only be extended for an additional three months on average," he added.

Noting that 30 percent of terminal lung cancer patients will develop the complication of fluid in the pleura, Hsieh stated that in such cases, patients can suffer from breathing difficulties and some will also develop rejection against chemo and targeted therapies.
Once the cancer spreads, the average survival rate will be reduced to between six and nine months, he said.
PDT is a treatment that uses light-sensitive medication (sometimes called a photosensitizing agent) together with a particular type of light to destroy cancer cells.
The therapy enables surgeons to kill cancer cells that other kinds of surgical operations cannot achieve, Hsieh said.
In Taiwan, a PDT procedure costs about NT$500,000 (US$15,600) , according to Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators argue pros and cons of bigger bonus for civil servants
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 20:49:19 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Legislators reacted along party lines Wednesday to a reported government plan to offer public sector employees an extra half-month's salary as a year-end bonus so that they can share in the benefits of the country's economic recovery.

The United Daily News reported the same day that the Executive Yuan is working on a plan to pay a bigger bonus to military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers and will also explore the feasibility of raising the minimum wage to spur private corporate owners to raise salaries.
If all goes well, the Chinese-language daily said, the minimum wage may be increased from the level of NT$17,280 (US$540) per month, where it has been stuck since 2007.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-che said at a news conference that the essence of rule of law lies in consistency.

"If an extra half-month's salary is paid as a bonus this year, will it be offered again next year? " he asked. "If the answer is yes, the proposal should be reviewed comprehensively and clear regulations should be formulated to support the adjustment, " Huang said.
Howevr, if a bigger bonus is being offered only this year, it could fuel speculations that it is an election bribe ahead of the mayoral polls in five special municipalities on Nov. 27, he argued.

This view was supported by Huang's colleague, Pan Men-an, who said that the DPP is not opposed to a public-sector wage hike but the decision should not be an impromptu or casual one. It is a matter that should be decided only after an extensive review of the government's finances and the country's unemployment rate and minimum wage level, he said.
Taiwan's civil servants have usually been paid one-month's salary as year-end bonus.
Legislator Yeh Yi-jin, also of the DPP, said remuneration for public-sector employees, including year-end bonus, should be determined in accordance with the existing law.

"The proposed extra year-end bonus for public-sector workers is a scheme to dodge legislative supervision, which undermines the existing system and is contrary to the spirit of rule of law, " Yeh said.
Any changes regarding monetary payments to public sector employees should be subject to institutionalized discussion and legislative scrutiny, she said.
Legislator George Hsieh of the ruling Kuomintang, however, said he supports the idea of giving public employees an extra year-end bonus instead of an across- the-board salary hike.
"Unlike a salary raise, a bigger year-end bonus is one-time move that will not put any long-term strain on the national coffers, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: No timetable for public-sector wage hike or bigger bonus: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 22:09:07 (By Yang Shu-min, Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government does not have any time frame for raising public-sector wages or offering bigger year-end bonuses for public-sector employees, Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

Wu dismissed a media report that had said the Executive Yuan is working on a plan to pay an extra half-month's salary in year-end bonuses to military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers.
"Nobody in the government has ever made such a statement, nor has any date been set for offering a bigger bonus for public-sector employees," Wu said.
Whether the government considers any rise in public-sector wages will depend on the country's economic performance in the second half of this year and the first half of next year, he said.

"Although we posted remarkable gains in gross domestic product (GDP) in the first two quarters of this year, our economic outlook for the third and fourth quarters remains hazy as economies of our major trading partners, including the United States, Japan, Europe, and especially China and Hong Kong have shown signs of slowing, " Wu said.
Since the government still has to rely on borrowing to make ends meet in the coming year, Wu said there was no plan to adjust public-sector wages or consider larger year-end bonuses this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to take on Japan for Asian 'AA' youth baseball title
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 22:30:40 (By Lin Ching-ping & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan overwhelmed South Korea 10-4 at the 2010 Asian "AA" Baseball Championship in Bangkok Wednesday to set up a final against Japan on Thursday.
Coach Cheng Chih-chiang said that only small errors by the pitcher and a baseman allowed South Korea four runs, and that he expected Taiwan to win the final.

"Based on what I've seen from Japan these past few days, they only have one or two players who can bat or field well. If Chinese Taipei plays like we usually do, we're confident we'll win the championship," Cheng said.
On Wednesday, Taiwan started strong with four runs in the top of the first inning on consecutive hits. They added a run in the third inning and four in the fourth to take a 9-0 lead.
The Koreans fought back in the six and took advantage of Taiwan's errors to narrow the gap to 9-4.
A double and a stolen base in the seventh helped set up Taiwan's last run, putting them in double digits for the fourth straight game.
Taiwan blanked Hong Kong (15-0) , Indonesia (21-0) , Thailand (16-0) in previous games at the event, which kicked off Aug. 20.
Japan beat South Korea (5-2), China (6-1), Sri Lanka (8-0) and Hong Kong (10-0) to advance to the final.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan travel businesses to attend fair in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 22:38:33 (by Tang Pei-chun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's travel businesses have organized a 164-member tourism promotion mission to attend a three-day consumer travel fair at Singapore Expo from Aug. 27-29, a tourism bureau official said Wednesday.

The National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (NATAS) organizes consumer travel fairs twice every year -- Travel in February-March and Holidays in August-September -- to showcase Singapore's tourist attractions. National tourism offices, tourism associations and travel agents from around the world also take the opportunity to promote travel destinations.

The Taiwanese mission, organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association, will introduce Taiwanese delicacies including the popular pearl tea, steamed dumplings, and a great variety of fruits at the exhibition, according to Philip Chao, head of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau office in Singapore.
The trade association has also invited the renowned Lan Yang Dance Troupe to give two performances of Chinese folk dances each day at the show ground to attract visitors.

Singapore has become a fast-growing market for Taiwan's travel businesses. Although the 14,041 visitors from Singapore in July represented an insignificant share of the total of 427,763 tourist arrivals to Taiwan in that month, the 35 percent year-on-year growth was impressive.

A survey conducted by the Singaporean newspaper Lianhe Zaobao in early July showed that 31 percent of young travelers polled said Taipei is their top choice of travel destinations, surpassing Bangkok, Shanghai and Sydney.
The newspaper said that the variety of recreational activities and the cultural diversity of Taipei were named the main attractions of the capital city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition lawmaker blasts government over energy policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 22:52:23 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker accused the Cabinet Wednesday of preferring a "black rather than green" energy policy as it is reportedly planning to set limits on the capacity of photovoltaic systems.

Legislator Tien Chiu-chin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said the government was moving at a snail's pace compared to other countries in the development of green energy and furthermore is planning to cap the growth of the industry.

According to a report in the Commercial Times on Aug. 17, the government is worried that it might not have enough funds to subsidize the procurement of green energy and is therefore considering a ceiling of 500 kilowatts capacity for photovoltaic systems.
Tien said she cannot understand this approach, especially as the government has pledged to help develop the country's photovoltaic industry.

At a press conference at the legislature, she questioned why the government would want to abandon its green policy, and instead support the construction of a new petrochemical complex in southern Taiwan.

The Commercial Times report said that since April when the government unveiled a system for buying renewable energy at a guaranteed price, there have been many applications for permission to build photovoltaic systems around the country.
If these systems are built, they will have a total capacity of 53,000 kilowatts (KWs), close to the government target of 65,000 KWs per year, the report said.
This does not include the proposed solar power projects by local governments, which will have a total capacity 1.77 million KWs, the paper said.

Officials at the Bureau of Energy could not be reached for comment, but the bureau on Wednesday issued a statement saying that the government must leave room for the installation of more advanced photovoltaic systems that are expected to be more efficient and to cost less.
The government is committed to the installation of photovoltaic systems around the country and plans to double its photovoltaic capacity target to 2,000 MWs by 2025, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top Chinese negotiator's visit to Taiwan likely to be postponed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/25/10 23:07:33 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan next month by a top Chinese negotiator is likely to be delayed due mainly to a tight schedule that month for exchange visits across the Taiwan Strait, the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

Taiwan and China agreed during negotiations in Chongqing in late June that Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will lead a business delegation on a visit to Taiwan on Sept. 5.
However, while there have been no changes in Taiwan's plans for Chen to visit, it is not yet known whether the trip will take place before the end of the year, the SEF said.
SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian is currently in eastern China to meet with Taiwanese businesspeople operating there.
After he returns to Taiwan, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin- kung will travel to China Sept. 16 to visit Taiwanese enterprises in Shanghai and Kunshan in Jiangsu Province, the SEF said.

On the Chinese side, Minister of Culture, Cai Wu is expected in Taipei soon, while Acting Shannxi Governor Zhao Zhenyong is scheduled to visit on Sept. 16 and two Chinese delegations concerned with intellectual property rights and judicial affairs will visit late next month, the SEF said.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contact between Taiwan and China.
Chen's last visit to Taiwan was in December 2009 for the fourth round of SEF- ARATS talks in the central city of Taichung.

Meanwhile, Kao said in Hangzhou earlier Wednesday that the SEF and ARATS will exchange instruments on the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement by the middle of next month. The pact was signed on June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 26, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Rebuilding people's trust

TEXT.P: Rai Hau-min, nominee for Judicial Yuan president, said after his nomination that people can no longer endure judges who are corrupt.
The most urgent task facing the new Judicial Yuan chief is to rebuild the people's trust in the judiciary.

In the near term, judicial reforms should first focus on restoring a clean judicial environment. The president should set an example for judges by rejecting unnecessary social invitations. He should also appoint supervisors who are responsible and willing to offend their superiors when necessary.

Another goal of the reforms should be to break the judges' inner circle, in which influence peddling is prevalent. In addition, a code of conduct should be set out for judges to overhaul their work discipline.

The medium and long-term goals of the reforms should include amending litigation laws, changing the method by which judges are appointed, and adjusting the Judicial Yuan's structure. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 26, 2010)
