DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. arms sales to return to normal track: Taiwan official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/10 11:36:36 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A senior Taiwan official posted in Washington expressed welcome Wednesday to the U.S. government's recent decision to allow U.S. companies to sell Taiwan defense articles and services directly without having to create "arms packages."

The U.S. Department of State confirmed Tuesday that it had notified Congress of its decision to allow U.S. companies to make commercial exports to Taiwan of defense services and articles to support and upgrade the island's existing air defense radar systems.

The latest sales, worth over US$100 million, will be carried out under a direct commercial sales (DCS) program between Taiwan and private U.S. companies, said the Taiwan official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"The new practice is poised to put U.S. arms sales to Taiwan back on their normal track," the official said.

He attributed the adoption of the DCS -- for the sales of items to support Taiwan's air defense radar system and improve existing radar used in the Ching- kuo indigenous defense fighter aircraft -- mainly to the fact that Taiwan's Air Force "is already familiar with the systems."

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan, also said Tuesday that it believes the latest State Department decision will contribute to returning U.S. arms sales to Taiwan to normal.

In the past, the United States usually sold arms to Taiwan under a more time- consuming Foreign Military Sales (FMS) system, with the U.S. government supervising bidding, production and delivery of the defense articles, services and technological data.

Under the FMS system, the U.S. government is responsible for enforcing the sales contracts. The model operates as if it is the U.S. government procuring the items from private contractors and reselling them to the foreign customer. The FMS system is more costly for the procuring countries because they have to pay the U.S. government's administrative bill, but the deal is less risky and offers greater guarantee of success.
The Taiwan official also attributed the U.S. decision to the fact that "package" sales and relevant announcements tend to make the matter "too high-profile, " triggering political implications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Teenage shooting suspect blames discrimination

TEXT.P: Liao Kuo-hau, a 17-year-old allegedly responsible for the high-profile murder of Taichung's gangland leader Weng Chi-nan on May 28, turned himself in to the police Wednesday, 90 days after the shooting.

He got in touch with ruling Kuomintang Legislator Justin Chou and expressed his intention to surrender Wednesday afternoon. He was quoted as having complained to Chou that he was a victim of Taiwan's education system, saying he was discriminated against in school because he was from a broken family.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the news:
United Daily News:

Liao reportedly contacted Chou through one of the lawmaker's supporters. In the conversation that ensued, the teenager said he wanted to turn himself in. After verifying his identity, Chou called Taichung City Police Chief Chiu Feng-kuang to arrange for the surrender of one of the country's most wanted fugitives.
Taichung City police officers later escorted Liao to the central Taiwan city from Taipei by high-speed rail.

Chou said he was sure that the teenager was the gunman when he first saw him. "He was expressionless and quite composed. He was dressed just like an ordinary teenage boy, but looked a bit haggard," the lawmaker recalled.

According to Chou, Liao expressed discontent with Taiwan's education system. "He told me that since he was a young child, his answers on examination sheets never won the approval of his school teachers," Chou said.

Liao's parents divorced when he was in elementary school and his father was a drug addict who was in and out of prison. He was raised by his grandparents. His grandmother operates a small restaurant staffed with young women. Liao told Chou that he was discriminated against in school due to his family background.
But Hsieh Sheng-nan, student affairs director of the junior high school from which Liao graduated, said the teenager's complaints were not fair.

"He should think about his own issues instead of blaming our education system. Our teachers spent a lot of energy trying to remold him. We contacted his grandparents and uncle more than 30 times in a single semester. Our teachers tried their best to help him, but to no avail, " Hsieh said disappointingly. (Aug. 26, 2010).
China Times:

Teachers at Taiping Junior High School in Taichung County said Liao often dozed off during lessons or skipped class. Even his grandmother had no way to get him to go to school regularly, his former teachers said. His classmates said he was a low-key person who seldom talked with classmates and just liked to be a silent bystander.

Police said Liao was escorted to Taipei by two underworld gang members -- Huang Chun-lung and Chen Chien-chih, both of whom have been detained -- after shooting kingpin Weng Chi-nan to death at Weng's office in Taichung on May 28.
Several other suspects in the case, including Lin Ying-hao, who allegedly drove Liao to and from Weng's office on the day of the crime, have also been arrested.
Police said Liao's surrender will help clarify the procedural details of the murder, but it remains uncertain whether the mastermind and motives behind the killing will be understood any time soon.

The case ignited a public outcry as it was later discovered that four police officers were at the scene playing mahjong, but did not intervene. The case prompted the government to outline a new crime-fighting program, code-named "Operation Thunder", to crack down on gang-related activities. The police authorities also vowed to institute better discipline in the police force.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Raising pay while in debt?

TEXT.P: The issue of pay hikes for civil servants has raised heated discussion over the past few days.

If politicians are serious about boosting the morale of civil servants, they should examine the stiff promotion system and salary structure of the government sector and find ways to reward excellent staff.

Small, across-the-board pay hikes do not help much to boost worker morale, but will lay a heavy burden on the already debt-ridden state coffers. It is estimated that increasing civil servants' salaries by 3 percent will cost the government NT$21.4 billion a year.

According to an audit report released in April by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, in addition to nearly NT$5 trillion in debt that fits the definition set out in the Public Debt Act, the government has another NT$13.7 trillion in hidden debt. This figure is equal to Taiwan's gross domestic product for a single year.
Tax reductions and pay hikes are both popular policies. But where does the money come from? (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO will not plead guilty: defense lawyer
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/10 13:09:13 (By Leaf Jiang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) will not plead guilty in plea bargains but will fight the price-fixing charges brought by the Department of Justice of the United States, a company defense lawyer said Wednesday.
"The company has not pled because it believes that it did not commit the crime for which it has been charged, " Christopher Nedeau, AUO's defense lawyer, said in a written statement.
"While the outcome of any case is uncertain, AUO is fighting the charges because it is the right thing to do," Nedeau said.
Three present and former AUO executives were barred from leaving the United States by a court in San Francisco on Aug. 19 after they appeared for a hearing on the case.
In June, AUO, a subsidiary in Houston, and six of its senior executives were indicted for allegedly conspiring to fix prices with other Asian flat panel firms between Sept. 14, 2001 and Dec. 1, 2006.
AUO has repeatedly denied the accusations and vowed to fight the charges, while other Asian TFT-LCD firms have settled similar charges through plea bargaining.
"Please keep in mind that under the US system of justice, the defendant is presumed innocent until proven guilty," the lawyer said.
"Neither AUO nor its employees have been convicted of any crime and the company looks forward to clearing its name before a jury," he said.
Nedeau said AUO is well-respected in Taiwan and throughout the world, and the company's success was achieved by its employees' hard work and dedication.

AUO CEO Chen Lai-juh and AUO Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin remain in San Francisco to manage AUO's business interests there, while former AUO Executive Vice President Hsiung Hui returned to his residence in San Diego.

The CEO and vice chairman are required to remain in northern California as they are still AUO executives, while Hsiung, who is now president and CEO of ODM service provider Qisda Corp., is allowed to travel anywhere inside California.
The three are free to communicate with AUO headquarters and their families in Taiwan without limitations.
If they need to leave California for other U.S. states, they have to obtain the court's permission and return to the state immediately after handling their business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Calling for green taxes

TEXT.P: The Economic Daily News held an international conference on climate change Aug. 24-25 to discuss important issues such as global warming and carbon reduction.
When addressing these problems, the government should adopt a macroscopic viewpoint and work out policies with significant external effect, such as green taxes.

Every year, the oil and gas excise tax and fuel surcharge generate nearly NT$100 billion in revenue for the government, but the revenue is not integrated for well-planned use, such as promoting a low-carbon economy and guiding the industrial sector to internalize the external cost of pollution.

The government has made no progress in terms of its policy on global warming over the past three years. It must not continue to do nothing, especially when green taxes were a campaign promise of President Ma Ying-jeou. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC to prioritize policy on financial leasing companies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) 08/26/10 14:07:56 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will prioritize policy on the opening of financial leasing companies in China by financial holding companies, and will introduce related proposals and measures within two days, an FSC official said Wednesday.

The announcement came after FSC Chairman Chen Yu-chang convened a meeting of local banks and financial holding companies earlier that day. More than half the participants gave suggestions concerning cross-Taiwan Strait financial links, FSC Vice Chairman Wu Tang-chieh said after the meeting.

They asked the country's top financial regulator to ease restrictions on investment in China by local banks, to relax rules for local banks to operate Chinese currency services, to allow Taiwan's insurance companies to do business in China, and to revise rules to allow Taiwanese securities firms to increase their presence in China, he said.

According to Wu, Chen told the attendants that the relationship between the FSC and the financial industry sector should be defined as a partnership, and that acting on the sector's suggestions, the FSC will first deal with policies on services that do not require legal amendments.
For example, Wu said, subsidiaries of financial holding companies are legally permitted to set up financial leasing companies in China.

As part of cross-strait liberalization, the Executive Yuan announced a list earlier this year that opened 11 types of Chinese investment to Taiwanese enterprises, including financial firms investing in China's finance leasing companies, Wu noted.

As for services that require legal amendments, the FSC will carry out further assessment and gather opinion from the banking and financial industries ahead of talks between Taiwan and China on further financial liberation, Wu added.

Some participants suggested that the government relax the Regulations Governing Approvals of Financial Institutions to Engage in Business and Investment Activities between the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Chinese Area, according to Wu.

The regulations stipulate that Taiwanese banks wishing to enter the Chinese market do so by establishing branches or subsidiary banks in China, or through equity investment in banks in China. Of the three methods, however, they are allowed to choose only two, and if they choose equity investment, their participation is limited to one Chinese bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA hopes to see Canada visa-free treatment by year-end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 14:25:51 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it was "cautiously optimistic" that Canada will grant Taiwan passport holders visa-free treatment by the end of the year.

Taipei and Ottawa agreed that the visa-free treatment for Taiwanese citizens should not be linked with imports of Canadian beef -- as hoped by Canada's agricultural ministry -- so political resistance to the issue has been overcome, Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said at a regular press briefing.

"It is expected to be settled after the Canadian side completes some internal administration procedures, " Tseng said. "We are cautiously optimistic that the deal will be sealed by the end of this year."
Since Taiwan has already lifted visa requirements for Canadian citizens, the Canadian government thinks it would be fair to grant the same privileges to Taiwanese nationals, Tseng said.
Ottawa has expressed hope that Taiwan will reconsider restrictions on beef imports from Canada, saying it is unfair to treat the U.S. and Canadian products differently, he added.

Tseng also said that it is unlikely that the United States will grant visa-free access for Taiwanese visitors by the end of this year because Taiwan may not be able to meet the requirements from Washington by that time.
The U.S. wants Taiwan to raise the percentage of in-person passport applications and stipulate that citizens have their ID photographs taken while applying for passports.
Many current Taiwanese passport holders applied for their passports through travel agents, but MOFA is now encouraging people to apply directly with the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electric motorbike subsidy to be extended for another year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 14:34:07 (By Lin Hui-chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government has decided to extend its offer of subsidies to buyers of electric motorbikes for another year, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
In 2009, the MOEA allocated NT$1.6 billion (US$50 million) for subsidies over four years to encourage people to buy environmentally friendly electric motorbikes and scooters.
The program was due to expire at the end of 2012 but will be extended for another year and will be expanded to include bikes equipped with fixed lithium fuel cells, IDB officials said.
Currently, only bikes equipped portable lithium ion battery packs are included in the program, which offers subsidies of NT$8,000 to NT$11,000 per vehicle.
Last year the government set a four-year target of 100,000 locally made electric motorbikes powered by replaceable batteries, as part of its efforts to save energy and cut carbon emissions.

The program started with three eligible manufacturers -- E-Ton Power Tech Co., Kwang Yang Motor Co. (Kymco), and China Motor Corp. (CMC). However, Sangyang Industry Co. (SYM) is also now on board, IDB officials said.

SYM manufactures a lightweight scooter model called EA1LU that is powered by a 48V portable lithium ion battery pack. The scooter weighs only 56 kilograms and the battery can give 50 kilometers on a single charge at a speed of up to 45 kph.
Other lightweight models that are included in the subsidy program are E-ton's EV3A, Kymco's EA10BB and CMC's EM198. Buyers of these models can apply for a subsidy of NT$8,000 each, the bureau said.
The bikes cost NT$55,000 on average.

Local manufacturers have been urging the government to raise its target for electric motorbike sales to one million over a four-year period. They have also asked the government to build recharging stations and dedicated lanes for electric motorbikes in cities throughout Taiwan.

Taiwan has the highest scooter density in Asia, averaging one per 1.6 people, according to government statistics. There are some 14.55 million scooters or motorcycles in the country of 23 million people, the figures show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes for 'flexible approach' in AUO case: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 15:19:19 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government hopes the U.S. will take a "flexible approach" in a case involving AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) after three active and former top executives were banned from leaving the U.S., a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said.

"The case is now in the middle of the legal process and the Taiwan government does not intend to interfere with the U.S. justice system. According to the principle of presumed innocence, however, we hope that the U.S. takes a flexible approach when dealing with this case, " Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said Thursday at a media briefing.

The three executives, along with AUO, its U.S. subsidiary, and other senior managers, were indicted in June by the U.S. Department of Justice for allegedly conspiring to fix the prices of TFT-LCD panels from Sept. 14, 2001 to Dec. 1, 2006.
The executives were barred from leaving the U.S. and told to remain in California by a court in San Francisco on Aug. 19 after they appeared for a hearing on the case.

AUO CEO Chen Lai-juh and AUO Vice Chairman Chen Hsuan-bin remain in San Francisco to manage AUO's business interests there, while former AUO Executive Vice President Hsiung Hui returned to his residence in San Diego.
Tseng said that the fact the executives traveled to the U.S. to plead their cases showed they were not aiming to avoid court appearances.
While the executives can still manage business within the U.S., a travel ban and a long legal process could affect their business operation, he said.

The ministry has been trying to consult the U.S. administrative branch on the case as well as contacting officials from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , the U.S. representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official bilateral diplomatic ties, Tseng said, but there was not much the government could do.
The ministry learned about the case as early as July and AUO has sought legal consultation from the ministry, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.61 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 15:43:34 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.61 percent Thursday on follow-through selling after the downside in the previous session amid lingering fears of a slower pace of the global economy recovery, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 47.24 points to 7,689.74, after moving between 7,666.51 and 7,758.14, on turnover of NT$119.44 billion (US$3.73 billion).

The market opened up 6.14 points after Wall Street's slight rebound overnight, but selling emerged immediately, putting pressure on old economy stocks that had scored significant gains on warming cross-strait business ties, dealers said.
After the index fell below the 7,700 points during the trade, bargain hunters began picking up select large cap high tech stocks, which supported the broader market to some extent, the dealers said.
A total of 2,619 stocks closed down and 1,053 up, while 222 remained unchanged.

The foodstuff sector suffered the steepest decline, dropping 2.4 percent. Cement stocks fell 1.9 percent, financials lost 1.5 percent, paper and pulp shares dropped 1.3 percent and textile stocks closed down 0.7 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector fell 0.5 percent and the construction sector lost 0.4 percent, while the plastics and chemical sector rose 0.3 percent.
"The market remained overshadowed by concerns about the global economic fundamentals, " TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said, referring to recent disappointing U.S. home sales figures.
"After yesterday's sell-off, market sentiment has been hurt badly, with the index failing to stage a technical rebound today," Shih said.
The local bourse closed down 2.56 percent Wednesday.

Shih said valuations of traditional industrial stocks, such as food and textile firms, remained high despite Wednesday's heavy losses, but added that these stocks may face further volatility in the near future.
However, select electronics, in particular integrated circuit designers, appeared attractive after recent consolidation, he said.
"They could serve as a safe haven to park money, " he said. "But, I think investors should boost cash positions in their portfolios for now and wait for fresh leads before acting."
In the foodstuff sector, Oceanic Beverages fell 6.93 percent to NT$25.50 and Wei-Chuan Foods dropped 3.33 percent to NT$33.40.
Among the financial stocks, Chang Hwa Bank fell 2.75 percent to NT$17.70 and Cathay Financial dipped 1.27 percent to NT$46.70.
On bargain hunting, IC designer MediaTek rose 1.62 percent to NT$438.00 and flat panel maker AU Optronics increased 1.28 percent to NT$27.65.

DOC.HEADLINE: China may notify WTO of ECFA: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 16:37:17 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: During recent talks with Taiwan, China did not rule out the possibility of notifying the World Trade Organization (WTO) of a recent trade pact with Taiwan, an official familiar with the matter said Thursday.

With Taiwan and China both playing a significant role in world trade, the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that they signed in June has drawn the attention of many WTO members, and the two sides recently discussed whether they should formally notify the WTO of the ECFA, according to the official.
During the meeting, the Chinese representatives said China would not rule out the possibility of doing so, the official said.

Because the ECFA was signed by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- two semi- official bodies responsible for handling two-way exchanges -- Taiwan will send the WTO a letter signed by Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang, explaining that the trade pact was inked with the authorization of the two governments.
The ECFA is considered a regional free trade agreement, therefore, notification of the WTO is required, according to WTO rules.

Meanwhile, the official said, since the Legislative Yuan ratified the ECFA earlier this month, the economics ministry has been carrying out follow-up work on the pact. The ministry has published an English version of the ECFA and confirmed the accuracy and validity of its contents, the official said.
Taiwan will hold further talks with China to confirm the content of the English version and to discuss when the pact will go into effect, he added.
SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian said the ECFA is likely to formally take effect and be implemented in September after an exchange of instruments between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: One-sixth of high school freshmen are Internet addicts: hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 17:15:20 (By Chen Li-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Eighteen percent of 16-year-old students are addicted to the Internet and are at a higher risk than others for emotional disorders, a local hospital said Thursday.
The Tri-Service General Hospital conducted a survey at a Taipei high school for three consecutive years and polled 2,600 freshmen with an average age of 16.
The hospital defined Internet addiction disorders as excessive computer use that interferes with an individual's job, schooling or social life.

Nearly 20 percent of those deemed Internet addicts suffered emotional disorders, with the rate for male students higher than that for females, said Wang Tzong- shi, a psychiatrist specializing in teenagers at the hospital.
Wang also said Internet addicts are more likely to suffer learning disabilities and impulse control disorders.
"If children surf the Net for six to seven hours a day and react very emotionally when asked to stop, parents need to pay extra attention to the addiction issue," Wang said.
The psychiatrist said previous studies had found 6 percent to 15 percent of Taiwan's high school students suffered from Internet addiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will contribute to regional peace and stability: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 17:18:44 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The recent signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will contribute to regional peace and stability in East Asia, a senior Taiwanese planner of China policy said Thursday.

"The ECFA will also enable Taiwan to serve as a springboard for companies in member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to tap into the vast Chinese market, " said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min at the opening of a symposium on the ECFA and relations among Taiwan, China and ASEAN.
In the wake of the ECFA's signing, Chao said, tensions across the Taiwan Strait will drop further as both sides will be less likely to touch on sensitive political issues and disputes.

With the continuing dialogue and engagement between the two sides, Taiwan has emerged as an ever-growing stabilizing force in the Asia-Pacific region and the possibility of its inclusion in the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) will increase, he said.

Noting that the ECFA has helped Taiwan break through its diplomatic isolation, Chao said Taiwan will now be able to actively reach out to the world. Against this backdrop, he said, the ASEAN countries will find the ARF incomplete without Taiwan's participation in its security dialogue mechanism.

The seminar on post-ECFA Taiwan-ASEAN relations, co-sponsored by the MAC and the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, was attended by scholars and experts from Taiwan and ASEAN countries, including Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines and Vietnam.

Fielding questions from reporters after delivering the opening remarks at the seminar, Chao said that a cross-strait economic cooperation commission will be formed after the ECFA takes effect later this year.
The commission will be headed by a vice ministerial-level economic official and will deal with matters related to the ECFA, he said.

On reports that Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will defer his plan to visit Taiwan in September, Chao said the MAC respects any arrangements reached between ARATS and its Taiwanese counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate sues environmental activists
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 17:37:13 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing filed a defamation suit Thursday against several environmental activists over an allegation of water pollution from a giant development project in the southern county.

Yang, who is running as an independent for mayor of Kaohsiung municipality, said at a press conference that the E-Da World development project near I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County is completely legal and compliant with government regulations.
Yang said that waste water from the project site is not being channeled into the Gaoping River -- a major source of drinking water for residents of greater Kaohsiung -- as the activists have claimed.
The Kaohsiung county government is monitoring the disposal of water from the project, he said.
The sprawling E-Da World project comprises two hotels, an amusement theme park, a residential complex and a shopping mall.

The Kaohsiung County government granted licenses to E-Da World only after the Ministry of Transportation and Communications authorized an alteration to the development plan in May 2009 and approved the environmental impact assessment in December that year, Yang said.

The Taiwan Water Resources Conservation Alliance accused Yang on Aug. 20 of covering up for E-Da World, which the alliance alleged has released massive volumes of waste water into the Gaoping River, polluting Kaohsiung's drinking water supply.

"I would not exclude the possibility that certain people have orchestrated this defamatory accusation because the election is approaching, " said Yang, who quit the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to run as an independent after he lost the party primary.

After the news conference, Yang's lawyer, Chen Miao-chuan, filed a defamation suit against Chen Shu-hua, a spokeswoman for the alliance; Lin Li-tsai, secretary-general of the Taiwan 228 Care Association; and several other people.

Chen Shu-hua said the alliance challenged Yang and the Kaohsiung county government after volunteers from the group received complaints from Kaohsiung residents and went to the site to see for themselves where the waste water was being discharged.
The volunteers visited the site four times between Aug. 6 and Aug. 14, she said.
Yang should apologize and "if he doesn't, we will sue him for defamation," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 17:43:56 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.018 to close at NT$32.037.
Turnover totaled US$834 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.075 and moved to a low of NT$31.975 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan beats Japan to clinch Asian `AA' youth baseball title
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 17:53:23 (By Lin Ching-ping and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan trounced Japan 3-0 Thursday to clinch the title of the 2010 Asian "AA" Baseball Championship being held in Bangkok.
The Taiwanese nine scored three runs at the bottom of the first inning and maintained the lead throughout the game.

Taiwanese manager Hu Jui-cheng attributed his team's win mainly to its strong defense, especially starting pitcher Lin Hua-ching, who used heaters and breaking balls to almost completely block the offense of the Japanese, allowing only one hit.
Prior to the Japanese shutdown, Taiwan blanked Hong Kong (15-0), Indonesia (21-0) , Thailand (16-0) and South Korea 10-4 in previous games of the event that kicked off Aug. 20.
Japan beat South Korea (5-2), China (6-1), Sri Lanka (8-0) and Hong Kong (10-0) to advance to the final.
Roy W.W. Wu, Taiwan's representative in Thailand, watched the game and immediately extended a congratulatory message from President Ma Ying-jeou to the team upon the victory.

Many Taiwanese consider baseball to be the "national sport" and this year, the country has done well in several international youth baseball titles, including the 2010 IBAF World Junior Baseball Championship in Canada that ended Aug. 1 and the Junior League Baseball World Series Championship in the United States that ended Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan student wins 'best of the best' red dot design award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 18:10:30 (By Tsai Hsin-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A student from National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST) has won a "best of the best" prize in the communication category of the 2010 red dot design award -- the world's largest and most prestigious design competition, the university said Thursday.
Lee Pei-wen was recognized for her project "Eros, " a 3D animated film about a battle for life.
It was the first time that an animated film from Taiwan was chosen as a red dot "best of the best, " NTUST said.

The 4-minute film depicts the human gestation process through a video game setting. The main character, a combat aircraft named "Eros, " is transformed from a baby who keeps moving inside its mother's womb as it struggles against various obstacles that could block its birth.
Lee said her inspiration came from her elder sister's first pregnancy and the experience of her own mother, who once considered an abortion.
The obstacles faced by "Eros" during the adventure in the womb symbolize the various psychological and physical challenges that arise during pregnancy, Lee said.
"Eros" is also one of nine works that have been nominated for the "red dot: junior prize" which comes with a 10,000 euro award. The winner will be announced Dec. 8.
The red dot design award is presented by the Design Zentrum Nordrhein Westfalen in Essen, Germany in three different categories: product design, communication design and design concept.

This year's communication design competition drew 6,369 entries from 44 countries, with 610 entries awarded a red dot for their design quality. The "best of the best" prizes are awarded to particularly outstanding design achievements, selected from among the red dot winners.

Besides Lee, four other NTUST students have also won red dot prizes this year. They are Kao Pei-wen, for "The Color of Mirrors;" Huang Chong-ming, for "Pimple;" Tsai Yun-chieh, for "Cafe de L'amour;" and Lu Hsuan-ying, for "Creation."
The winning projects will be shown at the red dot design museum on the premises of the Zollverein World Cultural Heritage site in Essen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayoral candidate to promote Kaohsiung as national film hub
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 18:20:20 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao-shun of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) promised Thursday to develop Kaohsiung as a film center based on its geographical and other advantages.

"Making Kaohsiung a national film and cultural center will generate higher industrial output and attract more foreign visitors," Huang said at a meeting with representatives from the film and cultural industries.

Speaking on the same occasion, George Hsu, deputy minister of the Government Information Office, said that because of Kaohsiung's geographical attributes, it has the potential to become an international movie mecca like Hollywood in the United States or Bollywood in India.

Hsu said the government plans to budget NT$10 billion per year to invest in the movie, television and pop music industry, with the aim of generating an annual output of NT$100 billion and creating 2,000 job openings.

Taiwanese director Joseph Kuo said at the meeting that the weather and landscape in Kaohsiung, which includes tall towers and a grand harbor, puts the city alongside the Manhattan area in New York as a movie location.
"With its low rainfall and skyscrapers, Kaohsiung is perfect for shooting movies," Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA to help with Taiwan's FTA efforts: Japanese expert
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 18:41:05 (By Mike Chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Taiwan signed with China in June is expected to spur interest among other countries in the region in forging free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan, a former Japanese economics official said in an article published Thursday in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a Japanese daily.

The ECFA will help strengthen economic relations and improve bilateral ties between Taiwan and China, said Japan Economic Foundation Chairman Noboru Hatakeyama, who is also a former official of Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry and a former director-general of the Japan External Trade Organization.
The article states that the ECFA's signing will help open the way for negotiations on FTAs between Taiwan and other countries, which have previously been concerned that doing so would offend Beijing.
It also said that the cross-strait economic pact will likely accelerate the establishment of FTAs in East Asia.

According to the article, out of concern that the ECFA's signing could undermine its competitiveness, South Korea began seeking a FTA with China during a summit between leaders of the two countries in June.

Meanwhile, Japan has taken part in a first round of FTA talks among representatives from the industrial, academic and government sectors from Japan, China and South Korea in May and has set 2012 as a goal for completing FTA deals.
However, the country is lagging behind South Korea in its FTA negotiations with China, according to the article.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pegatron to acquire two electronics component firms in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 18:54:36 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Pegatron Corp., a manufacturing arm of personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc., said Thursday it will acquire two electronics component companies based in China for US$220 million.

Pegatron's board of directors approved the investment plan to buy 100 percent ownership of RIH International Ltd. (Samoa), which wholly owns Ri Teng Computer (Shanghai) and Ri Kuei Precision (Shanghai).
The two China-based companies produce metal mechanical components for international notebook computer, tablet PC, e-reader, desktop computer and monitor brands, Pegatron said in a statement.

"The investment is an important milestone for Pegatron group's vertical integration efforts, " spokesman Charles Lin said in the statement, referring to the company's ambitions to extend its business into upstream component production from downstream assembly activity.
Lin said the acquisition is expected to enhance the company's production scale and manufacturing capability for mechanical parts used in electronic devices.
The company told the Central News Agency it expects the acquisition to be completed by the end of this year, and that it will combine the two Chinese companies.

Local media has reported that Pegatron is eyeing potential customers like Apple, Sony and Hewlett-Packard, as the two Chinese firms are suppliers of components for products from the electronics giants.
Pegatron would not directly comment on any specific clients cited in the report, but said the acquisition is expected to enlarge its customer base.
Mars Hsu, an analyst with Grand Cathay Securities, said the move is likely to boost the gross margin of the ODM service provider.
"The downstream assembly business has been tightly squeezed by fierce competition," Hsu said. "Once the company steps into component production, its bottom line will be enhanced accordingly."
Hsu estimated that the company's gross margin stood at about 4.1 percent in the second quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Little Leaguers sink Panama for semifinal berth in Series
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 19:13:13 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Fu-hsing Little League team defeated Panama 5-1 on Wednesday to sweep Pool D of the 2010 Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, setting up an International Championship appointment with Japan.

Chitre Little League team gave the Taiwanese team from Kaohsiung its biggest challenge at the Series so far, scoring the first run Taiwan has conceded in three games and holding Fu-hsing to just five runs. The boys from Taiwan previously scored 23 against Canada on Aug. 23 and 18 against Saudi Arabia on Aug. 21.

Fu-hsing is scheduled to play Japan -- a strong rival for the Taiwanese team -- in the International Championship on Aug. 28 U.S. time. Japan beat Mexico 4-2 on Aug. 24 U.S. time for its place in the semifinal.
The winner of that game will face the U.S. champion for the World Series title early Aug. 30 Taiwan time.

The last time a team from Taiwan won the Little League World Series was in 1996, although last year a squad from Taoyuan County made it to the final before losing to a team from Chula Vista, California 6-3.
Taiwan won 17 titles between 1969 and 1996, but has only qualified for the series four times in the past 14 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice defense minister calls for transformation of defense institute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 19:24:41 (By Ho Meng-kui and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang made a pitch Thursday for the transformation of the Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology into an administrative corporation.

Chao told a seminar at the Armed Forces Club in Taipei that by changing the Chung-Shan Institute -- which was set up by the Ministry of National Defense to develop weaponry -- into a corporation, it will no longer be bound by government regulations in the fields of budget and employment.

"This will enhance the institute's research and development capability, optimize the government's investment in defense technology, and transfer the institute's research results that could be used for peaceful purpose to private companies," he said.

Noting that the Executive Yuan approved March 25 a bill to transform the institute into a corporation, Chao said the proposed corporation will be supervised by the Ministry of National Defense but will have its own board of directors that will determine its operations.

An administrative corporation is a non-profit corporation set up by the government to carry out specific public functions, and the bill to transform the Chung-Shan Institute has already been submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
After being transformed into an administrative corporation, Chao said, the institute will be capable of running as a private corporation, bringing in qualified workers and improving its efficiency.
The institute, now under the Armaments Bureau of the Ministry of the National Defense, is manned mainly by military officers with only a few civilian scientists and technicians.

After the transformation, the institute will maintain its role as the country's major developer of defense technology, with the mission of strengthening the country's defenses and meeting the needs of the armed forces, Chao said.
The seminar, which drew many industrial leaders, government officials and scholars, was held to seek public input for the institute's future role as an administrative corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Tough discipline makes Taiwan Taxi industry leader
DOC.DATELINE: 08/26/10 19:35:54 (Business Weekly 1187) (Translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Five years after taking over Taiwan Taxi, C.T. Lin has successfully turned a taxi dispatch company on the brink of bankruptcy into a thriving, modern-managed enterprise with his unremitting insistence on discipline and outstanding communication skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China discussing joint thesaurus project: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 19:35:55 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Taiwan has been discussing with China a joint project to compile a new Mandarin thesaurus that will be accessible online to people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Ma said the online dictionary, the first of its kind in Chinese
history, will be commissioned by Taiwan's National Cultural Association and its counterpart in China, and compiled with the use of the cutting-edge cloud computing technology.

Some features of the dictionary, which will be presented in both traditional and simplified Chinese, could be available by the beginning of next year, Ma said at the Presidential Office in a meeting with the owners of several schools of classical learning in central and southern Taiwan.

The thesaurus, to be named the Chunghua (or Cross-strait) Chinese-Language Thesaurus, will help to narrow the language gap between people across the Taiwan Strait after a separation of more than six decades, the president said.
The project was first proposed during a cross-strait forum on economic and cultural exchanges in Changsha City, China, in July 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Q2 steel production value up 17.4 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 19:53:15 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's steel sector in the second quarter of this year rose 17.4 percent from the first quarter on a robust rebound in demand with the recovery of the global economy, the government said Thursday.

In the April-June period, the output of the local steel sector totaled NT$366.67 billion (US$11.44 billion), compared with NT$312.4 billion recorded in the first quarter, according to a report released by the Industry & Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS), a research institute of the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The output of the second quarter represented a 68.6 percent increase from a year earlier.
In the second quarter, Taiwan's exports of steel products saw a rise of 14.4 percent from the first quarter and a gain of 42.9 percent from a year earlier to total NT$133.44 billion, the report said.
China, Malaysia and Hong Kong ranked as the top three buyers of Taiwanese steel products in the second quarter, accounting for 37.3 percent of the total exports, it said.
During the same period, Taiwan imported a total of NT$107.12 billion in steel products, up 25.4 percent from the first quarter and also up 115.9 percent from a year earlier, the ITIS said.
According to the research institute, Japan was the largest supplier, accounting for 39.7 percent of the total imports, followed by China with 24.4 percent and South Korea with 15 percent.

The ITIS said that while the pace of the global economic recovery has appeared slower in the second half of this year, the impact on global steel demand is expected to be offset in the fourth quarter, a peak season for the steel sector.

The research institute estimated that the production value of the local steel sector in 2010 will rise 43 percent from 2009 to NT$1.37 trillion, while steel product imports are expected to increase 56.0 percent to NT$390.1 billion and exports might rise 36.5 percent to NT$548 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reports year's first dengue fever death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:17:53 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control confirmed Thursday the country's first reported case of dengue fever fatality for this year.

The victim, a 75-year-old woman from Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, succumbed to the disease Wednesday after being diagnosed Aug. 20 and reported Aug. 24 to have developed a potentially fatal complication called dengue hemorrhagic fever, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.
She was admitted to the hospital's intensive care unit because of a sudden drop in blood pressure, where she died of myocardial infarction, pneumonia and multiple organ failure, according to Chou.

Dengue hemorrhagic fever is caused by a family of viruses that are transmitted by mosquitoes, Chou said, adding that people suffering from chronic illnesses if infected with dengue fever are more likely to develop hemorrhagic fever, Chou added.

According to the CDC, the last local death from hemorrhagic dengue fever was reported in 2009. Since March, 41 cases of confirmed indigenous dengue fever infection have been reported so far this year, including five new cases reported Thursday.
The CDC urged the public to frequently clean up standing water containers around their homes to prevent the carrier mosquitoes from breeding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan manufacturers cautious about economic outlook: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:20:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing industry is conservative in its outlook for the country's economy in the next six months due to sluggish demand in Europe and a possible slowdown of demand in China, a local research institute said Thursday.
"This represents a new low this year, " said Chen Miao, director of the institute's macroeconomic forecasting center, at a press briefing.
Meanwhile, 17.7 percent of manufacturers were pessimistic about the outlook for that period, compared to 17.2 percent in June, which was a new high this year, he said.
Some 52.8 percent believe there will be no change in the economic prospects, a rise from the 48.7 percent that held that view in June, the survey showed.
TIER President David Hong forecast that the growth of the manufacturing industry will slow down on weaker demand in European markets and slower growth in China.
However, the global economy is expected to continue to grow as the economies of the U.S., major European countries and Japan continue to improve, he said.
"In Asia, the emerging economies are still expanding, which will also help drive the global growth," he said.

According to the survey, construction companies and developers see a dismal economic outlook for the next six months, as the central bank recently launched a measure to rein in residential property prices in Taipei.
"The trading volume in Taipei in July dropped nearly 10 percent from the previous month, but prices fell only slightly, " Arisa Liu, an associate research fellow with the institute, told reporters.
She said the tight controls maintained by banks on mortgages in the third quarter of this year and public concerns over high housing prices contributed to the gloomy outlook.
Another survey conducted by the institute on the local service industry showed that wholesalers and retailers were optimistic about the economic outlook as they were seeing increased turnover.
In the financial sector, the sentiment was bullish based on the rising stock market and improving domestic economy, the survey showed.

Both the tourism sector and the bulk transport industry were neutral about the economic outlook for the next six months as the number of tourists to Taiwan began to drop in the low season and there was less demand in China's steel industry for materials, the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to launch shopping festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:27:28 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government is ready to launch a shopping festival, with the participation of more than 300 stores, in an effort to attract more tourists to the central Taiwan city, Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday.

From Sept.1-Oct. 2, the city government will hold a series of shopping activities to coincide with a food festival on Sept. 18-19, international car- free day on Sept. 22 and Moon Festival celebrations, Hu said.
"Business plays an important role in a city's development, " he said. "In the absence of business activities, the city will lose its vitality."
Unlike the shopping festival in Hong Kong, Hu said, the event will be designed as a treasure hunt to make it more enjoyable for visitors.
In a previous tourism event, Taichung recorded revenue of NT$1.7 billion in 40 days, which indicated the level of consumption by the visitors to central Taiwan, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More investment, jobs needed to close wealth gap: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:31:48 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that the government will continue to boost private investment and increase job opportunities in order to close the wealth gap.

Wu said the government needs to improve the economic structure to address the wealth gap issue, which has gained urgency recently after the government announced that the average annual disposable income of Taiwan's top 20 percent income-earning households was 6. 34 times that of the bottom 20 percent in 2009.
It was the widest gap since 2001, when the top 20 percent had average disposable income that was 6.39 times that of the bottom 20 percent.

"We should continue to boost private investment, expand domestic demand and strengthen economic momentum in order to create more jobs, lower the jobless rate and raise salary levels, " Wu said at a Cabinet meeting.

Although the widening wealth gap could be attributed to the global economic crunch, Wu went on, closing the wealth gap, as well as improving the income distribution, are still the government's "unshirkable responsibilities."

Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at a press conference after the meeting that Taiwan's wealth gap is not high if compared to other countries.
"To solve the wealth gap issue, basically the government just needs to boost private investment in order to increase jobs, " according to Liu.
Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said at the meeting that tax breaks will not help much in closing the wealth gap.

In Taiwan, rich families do not pay less tax, according to the minister, contradicting what most people believe. Among more than 5 million households, 0.9 percent of them were levied the highest tax rate of 40 percent, and they accounted for up to 43 percent of the total tax revenues, Lee said.
About 71 percent of the households were taxed at below 6 percent, representing only 7 percent of the total tax revenues, he noted.
Lee also suggested that the government should increase average income by boosting domestic demand and investment.

In 2009, Taiwan's average annual disposable income in the richest group of families reached NT$1.79 million (US$56,113) , compared to NT$282,000 for those in the poorest bracket, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The average annual disposable income stood at NT$888,000 per household last year, or NT$266,000 per household member, representing year-on- year declines of 2.9 percent and 2.6 percent, respectively, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital weight loss program reports major success
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:38:30 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thirty people participating in a weight-loss program organized by Chiayi Hospital have shed a total of 100 kilograms in a healthy way, a hospital spokesman said Thursday.

The program, featuring regular exercise and diet control, has helped 30 of its members lose weight in the period June 8 to Aug. 26, said Chen Chao-jen, a physician at the hospital's Family Medicine Department.
Under the supervision of dieticians, the participants kept careful records of the food they ate every day and they each lost an average of 3-4 kg during the program, the organizers said.
Notably, a 60-year-old member of the program shed 9 kg over three months, the organizers said.
Head nurse Wen Hsiu-jung said that normally it will cost about NT$1 million to take part in a non-hospital program that produces such significant results.

A proper weight management program allows participants to get fit and improve their health, she said. Blood tests showed that the participants in the Chaiyi Hospital program succeeded in lowering their blood sugar and triglycerides and increasing their high-density lipoproteins, the so-called "good cholesterol," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hails breakthrough in probe of gangland murder
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:55:52 (By Chen ching-ping, Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih hailed Thursday the surrender of a shooting suspect in a high-profile gangland murder in central Taiwan's Taichung City in May, saying the development marks progress in a government crime-fighting campaign.

With the surrender of Liao Kuo-hau, the 18-year-old allegedly responsible for shooting gang kingpin Weng Chi-nan to death at Weng's office in Taichung May 28, all of the key suspects in the case have now been taken into custody.

Among those previously arrested are Lin Ying-hao, who allegedly drove Liao to and from Weng's office on the day of the crime, and Yang Ting-jung, a Taichung- based gangster suspected of being the mastermind behind Weng's murder.
Wu said Liao's surrender will help police get to the bottom of the case.

The case ignited a public outcry, as it was later discovered that four police officers were at the scene playing mahjong, but failed to intervene. The incident prompted the government to launch a new crime-fighting program codenamed "Operation Thunder" to crack down on gang-related activity. The police authorities also vowed to institute better discipline in the force.
Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday that he hopes the solving of the case will help restore public confidence and trust in the police force.

Given the complexity of the case -- as evidenced in the careful planning of the supply of the murder weapons, as well as the transporting and hiding of the suspected murderer, Jiang said it is commendable that the law enforcement authorities have managed to make such progress in less than three months.

As Liao committed the murder three weeks before he turned 18, he will be transferred to the juvenile court after the police inquiry is completed. Nevertheless, the court is likely to refer his case to the Taichung Prosecutors Office for further investigation because the crime he committed is a felony subject to a prison term of more than five years, legal sources said.

In an interrogation session that same day, Liao told police that after murdering Weng, he was driven to neighboring Taichung County. In the car, he disassembled the two guns used in the shooting and discarded the parts along the way. He guided the police on a search Thursday, but they found nothing.
Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu said he had asked the relevant authorities to thoroughly probe the details of the case, including the weapons used, as well as to bring everyone involved to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin magistrate backs down on threat to protest in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:31:36 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Yunlin Magistrate Su Chih-fen backed down Thursday on her threat to stage a demonstration in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei Saturday to pressure the Formosa Plastics Group to offer more generous compensation in a case of pollution in Yunlin County.

Citing progress in negotiations with Formosa Plastics, the magistrate said she will continue to help the people living in the vicinity of the company's naphtha cracking plant in Mailiao, Yunlin to push Formosa Plastics to devise a structured compensation system.
She urged the company to be more accommodating of the local people's requests or risk being vilified by the whole country.

On July 7 and July 25, there were two separate fires broke out at Formosa Plastics' naphtha cracker plant in Yunlin which belched smoke for several days, polluting the air and causing panic among the people who lived nearby.

For several days, the residents of the area blocked the highway leading to the plant, demanding compensation. The Formosa Group agreed to pay NT$500 million (US$15.62 million) in damages to the residents and help Yunlin County to plant 2,600 hectares of forest.

The people lifted the roadblock, but asked Formosa Plastics to subsidize their electricity bills and medical examination fees. They threatened to block the highway again on Aug. 30 unless the group meets their requests.
In order to show her solidarity with the residents, Su had threatened to stage a demonstration on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei Saturday during the negotiations.
The Formosa Group, with revenues of NT$1.75 trillion in 2009, is Taiwan's largest private business group in terms of total revenue, profit and the number of employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. judicial officials visit Taiwan over ex-president's assets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:39:41 (By Lin Chang-shun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: U.S. prosecutors and officials have recently visited Taiwan for discussions with their Taiwanese counterparts on issues related to U.S. civil forfeiture complaints against properties owned by former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife in New York and Virginia, a local prosecutor said Thursday.

The U.S. government filed the complaints in July seeking to expropriate the properties owned by Chen and former first lady Wu Shu-chen, which were allegedly bought with bribe money the couple took when Chen was in power between 2001 and 2008.

Chen Hung-ta, chief of the Special Prosecutors Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said the U.S. authorities are empowered by the laws of that country to confiscate the properties, without the need to wait until the trial of the former first couple is completed in Taiwan.

Chen and Wu were both sentenced to life in prison and fines of NT$200 million (US$6.23 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, in September last year on charges of taking bribes, money laundering and forgery.

They both appealed and had their sentences reduced to 20 years and their fines cut to NT$170 million and NT$200 million, respectively, June 11. Both prosecutors and the couple appealed the new sentences.
Chen Hung-ta said, however, that local and U.S. officials have not touched on the issue of how the properties, if confiscated, should be distributed between the two countries.

Chen Chih-chung, the ex-president's son, has argued that the U.S. government's civil forfeiture complaints against properties owned by his parents were "illogical, " claiming that they were procured with money from "political contributions donated to his farther."

According to the complaints filed in New York and Virginia, Taiwan's Yuanta Securities Co. paid a bribe of NT$200 million between 2005 and 2006 to Wu to ensure that Chen's administration would not interfere with its bid to acquire additional shares in Fuhwa Financial Co.

The complaints go on to say that Wu laundered the bribe money using shell companies and Swiss bank accounts controlled by her son Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching. Some of the money was transferred to the United States and used to buy a condominium in Manhattan and a house in Keswick, Virginia, the complaints say.

It was the second time the U.S. had sent officials to Taiwan for the investigations into Chen Shui-bian. A team of U.S. judicial affairs officials visited last year to discuss the issue with local prosecutors and Foreign Ministry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Extra cross-strait flights will not begin until mid-Sept: CAA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:43:40 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese airlines have applied to open additional direct flights across the Taiwan Strait, but none of them are expected to be inaugurated before mid-September, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.

Taiwan and China agreed in May to allow airlines from each side to offer 50 more direct cross-strait flights per week and carriers from each side smoothly opened 14 weekly flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport June 14.
The remaining quotas have so far not been used because of disputes about flight destinations and inconvenient scheduling given to local carriers by China's civil aviation authorities.
After the disputes were resolved in a new round of talks held early this month, however, the Taiwanese carriers came up with new applications last week, CAA officials said.

The planned extra flights include four to Beijing, four to Shenzhen, 15 to Fuzhou and Xiamen, two to Qingdao, two to Guangzhou and one to Changsha from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport; three to Fuzhou from Taichung Airport; two to Fuzhou, one to Xiamen and one to Guangzhou from Kaohsiung Airport; and one to Guangzhou from Songshan.
A CAA official said the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China had already referred the Taiwanese carriers' flight plans to its local branches to allocate takeoff and landing times.

"It remains unclear whether our carriers will all be able to obtain ideal schedules, " said the CAA official. "Even if they can acquire landing and takeoff times, they will need 10 days to two weeks to prepare for opening the extra flights, so they are not expected to take off until mid-September."

Chinese carriers have also filed applications with the CAA for operating extra flights, but the CAA had yet to approve any of them. Basically, however, the official said, the carriers from both sides will inaugurate their extra flights at roughly the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu to be venue for world assembly of science cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:44:59 (By Tseng Chih-shan and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A technology conference gathering representatives from 36 "science cities" around the world will be held in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City, Hsinchu Mayor Hsu Ming-tsai said Thursday.

The World Technopolis Association (WTA) , an international organization created to achieve shared development through exchanges among science cities, will hold its biannual general assembly in the city Sept. 1-4, Hsu said.
Hsu noted that Hsinchu has been a member of the WTA since 2003 and has continued to participate in the association's events, which earned it the right to host the 2010 assembly.

"With the aim of introducing the beauty of Hsinchu to the representatives, the city government has recruited volunteer guides from local schools such as National Tsing Hua University, National Chiao Tung University and National Hsinchu University of Education, " he said.

Lo Ta-hsien, director of the president's office of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , who is responsible for one of the forums that will be held as part of the assembly, said the attendees will discuss the sustainable development of science cities in the era of global climate change.
Meanwhile, 22 university heads from more than 15 countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea and China, will be invited to share their experiences.
The WTA General Assembly has been held in South Korea, China, Mexico, Sweden and Australia since it was founded in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local banks' non-performing loan ratio dips to record low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:58:34 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The average ratio of local banks' non-performing loans to their total loans dipped to a record low of 0.87 percent i n July, according to statistics released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
The ratio, which represents the percentage of loans that might not be repaid to the bank, is a vital index in measuring the quality of banks' loan systems.
The total non-performing loans stood at NT$167.9 billion (US$5.24 billion) in July, or NT$7.4 billion less than that of the previous month.
According to FSC figures, local banks' total outstanding loans stood at $19.32 trillion in July, representing a growth of NT$142.5 billion over the previous month.
All of the 37 domestic banks posted overdue loan ratios of below 2.5 percent, except for Cosmos Bank, which posted a ratio higher than 2.5 percent.
A ratio of below 3 percent is considered healthy.
Meanwhile, the domestic banks' average non-performing loan coverage ratio in July was 118.98 percent, or 5.6 percentage points higher than that of the previous month.
This ratio refers to the percentage of allowance for probable losses on non- performing loans to total non-performing loans.
