China, Malaysia and Hong Kong ranked as the top three buyers of Taiwanese steel products in the second quarter, accounting for 37.3 percent of the total exports, it said.
During the same period, Taiwan imported a total of NT$107.12 billion in steel products, up 25.4 percent from the first quarter and also up 115.9 percent from a year earlier, the ITIS said.
According to the research institute, Japan was the largest supplier, accounting for 39.7 percent of the total imports, followed by China with 24.4 percent and South Korea with 15 percent.

The ITIS said that while the pace of the global economic recovery has appeared slower in the second half of this year, the impact on global steel demand is expected to be offset in the fourth quarter, a peak season for the steel sector.

The research institute estimated that the production value of the local steel sector in 2010 will rise 43 percent from 2009 to NT$1.37 trillion, while steel product imports are expected to increase 56.0 percent to NT$390.1 billion and exports might rise 36.5 percent to NT$548 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reports year's first dengue fever death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:17:53 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control confirmed Thursday the country's first reported case of dengue fever fatality for this year.

The victim, a 75-year-old woman from Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, succumbed to the disease Wednesday after being diagnosed Aug. 20 and reported Aug. 24 to have developed a potentially fatal complication called dengue hemorrhagic fever, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.
She was admitted to the hospital's intensive care unit because of a sudden drop in blood pressure, where she died of myocardial infarction, pneumonia and multiple organ failure, according to Chou.

Dengue hemorrhagic fever is caused by a family of viruses that are transmitted by mosquitoes, Chou said, adding that people suffering from chronic illnesses if infected with dengue fever are more likely to develop hemorrhagic fever, Chou added.

According to the CDC, the last local death from hemorrhagic dengue fever was reported in 2009. Since March, 41 cases of confirmed indigenous dengue fever infection have been reported so far this year, including five new cases reported Thursday.
The CDC urged the public to frequently clean up standing water containers around their homes to prevent the carrier mosquitoes from breeding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan manufacturers cautious about economic outlook: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:20:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing industry is conservative in its outlook for the country's economy in the next six months due to sluggish demand in Europe and a possible slowdown of demand in China, a local research institute said Thursday.
"This represents a new low this year, " said Chen Miao, director of the institute's macroeconomic forecasting center, at a press briefing.
Meanwhile, 17.7 percent of manufacturers were pessimistic about the outlook for that period, compared to 17.2 percent in June, which was a new high this year, he said.
Some 52.8 percent believe there will be no change in the economic prospects, a rise from the 48.7 percent that held that view in June, the survey showed.
TIER President David Hong forecast that the growth of the manufacturing industry will slow down on weaker demand in European markets and slower growth in China.
However, the global economy is expected to continue to grow as the economies of the U.S., major European countries and Japan continue to improve, he said.
"In Asia, the emerging economies are still expanding, which will also help drive the global growth," he said.

According to the survey, construction companies and developers see a dismal economic outlook for the next six months, as the central bank recently launched a measure to rein in residential property prices in Taipei.
"The trading volume in Taipei in July dropped nearly 10 percent from the previous month, but prices fell only slightly, " Arisa Liu, an associate research fellow with the institute, told reporters.
She said the tight controls maintained by banks on mortgages in the third quarter of this year and public concerns over high housing prices contributed to the gloomy outlook.
Another survey conducted by the institute on the local service industry showed that wholesalers and retailers were optimistic about the economic outlook as they were seeing increased turnover.
In the financial sector, the sentiment was bullish based on the rising stock market and improving domestic economy, the survey showed.

Both the tourism sector and the bulk transport industry were neutral about the economic outlook for the next six months as the number of tourists to Taiwan began to drop in the low season and there was less demand in China's steel industry for materials, the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to launch shopping festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:27:28 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government is ready to launch a shopping festival, with the participation of more than 300 stores, in an effort to attract more tourists to the central Taiwan city, Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday.

From Sept.1-Oct. 2, the city government will hold a series of shopping activities to coincide with a food festival on Sept. 18-19, international car- free day on Sept. 22 and Moon Festival celebrations, Hu said.
"Business plays an important role in a city's development, " he said. "In the absence of business activities, the city will lose its vitality."
Unlike the shopping festival in Hong Kong, Hu said, the event will be designed as a treasure hunt to make it more enjoyable for visitors.
In a previous tourism event, Taichung recorded revenue of NT$1.7 billion in 40 days, which indicated the level of consumption by the visitors to central Taiwan, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More investment, jobs needed to close wealth gap: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:31:48 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that the government will continue to boost private investment and increase job opportunities in order to close the wealth gap.

Wu said the government needs to improve the economic structure to address the wealth gap issue, which has gained urgency recently after the government announced that the average annual disposable income of Taiwan's top 20 percent income-earning households was 6. 34 times that of the bottom 20 percent in 2009.
It was the widest gap since 2001, when the top 20 percent had average disposable income that was 6.39 times that of the bottom 20 percent.

"We should continue to boost private investment, expand domestic demand and strengthen economic momentum in order to create more jobs, lower the jobless rate and raise salary levels, " Wu said at a Cabinet meeting.

Although the widening wealth gap could be attributed to the global economic crunch, Wu went on, closing the wealth gap, as well as improving the income distribution, are still the government's "unshirkable responsibilities."

Christina Liu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at a press conference after the meeting that Taiwan's wealth gap is not high if compared to other countries.
"To solve the wealth gap issue, basically the government just needs to boost private investment in order to increase jobs, " according to Liu.
Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said at the meeting that tax breaks will not help much in closing the wealth gap.

In Taiwan, rich families do not pay less tax, according to the minister, contradicting what most people believe. Among more than 5 million households, 0.9 percent of them were levied the highest tax rate of 40 percent, and they accounted for up to 43 percent of the total tax revenues, Lee said.
About 71 percent of the households were taxed at below 6 percent, representing only 7 percent of the total tax revenues, he noted.
Lee also suggested that the government should increase average income by boosting domestic demand and investment.

In 2009, Taiwan's average annual disposable income in the richest group of families reached NT$1.79 million (US$56,113) , compared to NT$282,000 for those in the poorest bracket, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The average annual disposable income stood at NT$888,000 per household last year, or NT$266,000 per household member, representing year-on- year declines of 2.9 percent and 2.6 percent, respectively, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital weight loss program reports major success
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:38:30 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thirty people participating in a weight-loss program organized by Chiayi Hospital have shed a total of 100 kilograms in a healthy way, a hospital spokesman said Thursday.

The program, featuring regular exercise and diet control, has helped 30 of its members lose weight in the period June 8 to Aug. 26, said Chen Chao-jen, a physician at the hospital's Family Medicine Department.
Under the supervision of dieticians, the participants kept careful records of the food they ate every day and they each lost an average of 3-4 kg during the program, the organizers said.
Notably, a 60-year-old member of the program shed 9 kg over three months, the organizers said.
Head nurse Wen Hsiu-jung said that normally it will cost about NT$1 million to take part in a non-hospital program that produces such significant results.

A proper weight management program allows participants to get fit and improve their health, she said. Blood tests showed that the participants in the Chaiyi Hospital program succeeded in lowering their blood sugar and triglycerides and increasing their high-density lipoproteins, the so-called "good cholesterol," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hails breakthrough in probe of gangland murder
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 20:55:52 (By Chen ching-ping, Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih hailed Thursday the surrender of a shooting suspect in a high-profile gangland murder in central Taiwan's Taichung City in May, saying the development marks progress in a government crime-fighting campaign.

With the surrender of Liao Kuo-hau, the 18-year-old allegedly responsible for shooting gang kingpin Weng Chi-nan to death at Weng's office in Taichung May 28, all of the key suspects in the case have now been taken into custody.

Among those previously arrested are Lin Ying-hao, who allegedly drove Liao to and from Weng's office on the day of the crime, and Yang Ting-jung, a Taichung- based gangster suspected of being the mastermind behind Weng's murder.
Wu said Liao's surrender will help police get to the bottom of the case.

The case ignited a public outcry, as it was later discovered that four police officers were at the scene playing mahjong, but failed to intervene. The incident prompted the government to launch a new crime-fighting program codenamed "Operation Thunder" to crack down on gang-related activity. The police authorities also vowed to institute better discipline in the force.
Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday that he hopes the solving of the case will help restore public confidence and trust in the police force.

Given the complexity of the case -- as evidenced in the careful planning of the supply of the murder weapons, as well as the transporting and hiding of the suspected murderer, Jiang said it is commendable that the law enforcement authorities have managed to make such progress in less than three months.

As Liao committed the murder three weeks before he turned 18, he will be transferred to the juvenile court after the police inquiry is completed. Nevertheless, the court is likely to refer his case to the Taichung Prosecutors Office for further investigation because the crime he committed is a felony subject to a prison term of more than five years, legal sources said.

In an interrogation session that same day, Liao told police that after murdering Weng, he was driven to neighboring Taichung County. In the car, he disassembled the two guns used in the shooting and discarded the parts along the way. He guided the police on a search Thursday, but they found nothing.
Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu said he had asked the relevant authorities to thoroughly probe the details of the case, including the weapons used, as well as to bring everyone involved to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin magistrate backs down on threat to protest in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:31:36 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Yunlin Magistrate Su Chih-fen backed down Thursday on her threat to stage a demonstration in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei Saturday to pressure the Formosa Plastics Group to offer more generous compensation in a case of pollution in Yunlin County.

Citing progress in negotiations with Formosa Plastics, the magistrate said she will continue to help the people living in the vicinity of the company's naphtha cracking plant in Mailiao, Yunlin to push Formosa Plastics to devise a structured compensation system.
She urged the company to be more accommodating of the local people's requests or risk being vilified by the whole country.

On July 7 and July 25, there were two separate fires broke out at Formosa Plastics' naphtha cracker plant in Yunlin which belched smoke for several days, polluting the air and causing panic among the people who lived nearby.

For several days, the residents of the area blocked the highway leading to the plant, demanding compensation. The Formosa Group agreed to pay NT$500 million (US$15.62 million) in damages to the residents and help Yunlin County to plant 2,600 hectares of forest.

The people lifted the roadblock, but asked Formosa Plastics to subsidize their electricity bills and medical examination fees. They threatened to block the highway again on Aug. 30 unless the group meets their requests.
In order to show her solidarity with the residents, Su had threatened to stage a demonstration on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei Saturday during the negotiations.
The Formosa Group, with revenues of NT$1.75 trillion in 2009, is Taiwan's largest private business group in terms of total revenue, profit and the number of employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. judicial officials visit Taiwan over ex-president's assets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:39:41 (By Lin Chang-shun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: U.S. prosecutors and officials have recently visited Taiwan for discussions with their Taiwanese counterparts on issues related to U.S. civil forfeiture complaints against properties owned by former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife in New York and Virginia, a local prosecutor said Thursday.

The U.S. government filed the complaints in July seeking to expropriate the properties owned by Chen and former first lady Wu Shu-chen, which were allegedly bought with bribe money the couple took when Chen was in power between 2001 and 2008.

Chen Hung-ta, chief of the Special Prosecutors Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said the U.S. authorities are empowered by the laws of that country to confiscate the properties, without the need to wait until the trial of the former first couple is completed in Taiwan.

Chen and Wu were both sentenced to life in prison and fines of NT$200 million (US$6.23 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, in September last year on charges of taking bribes, money laundering and forgery.

They both appealed and had their sentences reduced to 20 years and their fines cut to NT$170 million and NT$200 million, respectively, June 11. Both prosecutors and the couple appealed the new sentences.
Chen Hung-ta said, however, that local and U.S. officials have not touched on the issue of how the properties, if confiscated, should be distributed between the two countries.

Chen Chih-chung, the ex-president's son, has argued that the U.S. government's civil forfeiture complaints against properties owned by his parents were "illogical, " claiming that they were procured with money from "political contributions donated to his farther."

According to the complaints filed in New York and Virginia, Taiwan's Yuanta Securities Co. paid a bribe of NT$200 million between 2005 and 2006 to Wu to ensure that Chen's administration would not interfere with its bid to acquire additional shares in Fuhwa Financial Co.

The complaints go on to say that Wu laundered the bribe money using shell companies and Swiss bank accounts controlled by her son Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching. Some of the money was transferred to the United States and used to buy a condominium in Manhattan and a house in Keswick, Virginia, the complaints say.

It was the second time the U.S. had sent officials to Taiwan for the investigations into Chen Shui-bian. A team of U.S. judicial affairs officials visited last year to discuss the issue with local prosecutors and Foreign Ministry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Extra cross-strait flights will not begin until mid-Sept: CAA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:43:40 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese airlines have applied to open additional direct flights across the Taiwan Strait, but none of them are expected to be inaugurated before mid-September, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.

Taiwan and China agreed in May to allow airlines from each side to offer 50 more direct cross-strait flights per week and carriers from each side smoothly opened 14 weekly flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport June 14.
The remaining quotas have so far not been used because of disputes about flight destinations and inconvenient scheduling given to local carriers by China's civil aviation authorities.
After the disputes were resolved in a new round of talks held early this month, however, the Taiwanese carriers came up with new applications last week, CAA officials said.

The planned extra flights include four to Beijing, four to Shenzhen, 15 to Fuzhou and Xiamen, two to Qingdao, two to Guangzhou and one to Changsha from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport; three to Fuzhou from Taichung Airport; two to Fuzhou, one to Xiamen and one to Guangzhou from Kaohsiung Airport; and one to Guangzhou from Songshan.
A CAA official said the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China had already referred the Taiwanese carriers' flight plans to its local branches to allocate takeoff and landing times.

"It remains unclear whether our carriers will all be able to obtain ideal schedules, " said the CAA official. "Even if they can acquire landing and takeoff times, they will need 10 days to two weeks to prepare for opening the extra flights, so they are not expected to take off until mid-September."

Chinese carriers have also filed applications with the CAA for operating extra flights, but the CAA had yet to approve any of them. Basically, however, the official said, the carriers from both sides will inaugurate their extra flights at roughly the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu to be venue for world assembly of science cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:44:59 (By Tseng Chih-shan and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A technology conference gathering representatives from 36 "science cities" around the world will be held in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City, Hsinchu Mayor Hsu Ming-tsai said Thursday.

The World Technopolis Association (WTA) , an international organization created to achieve shared development through exchanges among science cities, will hold its biannual general assembly in the city Sept. 1-4, Hsu said.
Hsu noted that Hsinchu has been a member of the WTA since 2003 and has continued to participate in the association's events, which earned it the right to host the 2010 assembly.

"With the aim of introducing the beauty of Hsinchu to the representatives, the city government has recruited volunteer guides from local schools such as National Tsing Hua University, National Chiao Tung University and National Hsinchu University of Education, " he said.

Lo Ta-hsien, director of the president's office of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , who is responsible for one of the forums that will be held as part of the assembly, said the attendees will discuss the sustainable development of science cities in the era of global climate change.
Meanwhile, 22 university heads from more than 15 countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea and China, will be invited to share their experiences.
The WTA General Assembly has been held in South Korea, China, Mexico, Sweden and Australia since it was founded in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local banks' non-performing loan ratio dips to record low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/10 22:58:34 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The average ratio of local banks' non-performing loans to their total loans dipped to a record low of 0.87 percent i n July, according to statistics released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
The ratio, which represents the percentage of loans that might not be repaid to the bank, is a vital index in measuring the quality of banks' loan systems.
The total non-performing loans stood at NT$167.9 billion (US$5.24 billion) in July, or NT$7.4 billion less than that of the previous month.
According to FSC figures, local banks' total outstanding loans stood at $19.32 trillion in July, representing a growth of NT$142.5 billion over the previous month.
All of the 37 domestic banks posted overdue loan ratios of below 2.5 percent, except for Cosmos Bank, which posted a ratio higher than 2.5 percent.
A ratio of below 3 percent is considered healthy.
Meanwhile, the domestic banks' average non-performing loan coverage ratio in July was 118.98 percent, or 5.6 percentage points higher than that of the previous month.
This ratio refers to the percentage of allowance for probable losses on non- performing loans to total non-performing loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 27, 2010, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
1999: Actress-singer Bai Guang dies at her home in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 79.
2003: A three-day six-nation meeting on North Korean nuclear weapon program opens in Beijing.
2004: Taekwondo athlete Chen Shi-hsin wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic gold medal in the Athens Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 10:02:56 (By Y.F. Low)

The weighted price index lost 47.24 points, or 0.61 percent, to close at 7,689.74 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: All are responsible

TEXT.P: Liao Kuo-hao had not yet turned 18 when he gunned down Taichung gang leader Weng Chi-nan in May. Upon finally turning himself in to the police two days ago, Liao complained that he is a victim of Taiwan's education system.

Liao was a low-performing student academically, but he was good at sports. Not every kid is good at studying, and helping students like Liao find their fields of interest and develop their strengths is perhaps what schools can do for them.
However, without family support, what the students do after school is probably beyond the reach of their teachers.
Liao's mother abandoned him when he was very young and his father, a drug addict who was in and out of jail, was only 16 when he became a father and was too immature to raise a child.

However, the boy himself has a responsibility to shoulder as well and cannot put all the blame on society and education. Among those children who come from similar environments and backgrounds, there are some who are willing to be responsible for themselves, overcome their plights and live a different life. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Cross-strait investment enters new stage

TEXT.P: The first restaurant wholly owned by a China-based business group is scheduled to open in Taipei early next month, while Taiwan's government-run New Labor Pension Fund has decided to invest in the Chinese stock market soon for the first time.

These moves signal that investment activities and capital flow across the Taiwan Strait will enter a new stage amid growing cross-strait reconciliation, particularly in the wake of the signing of a landmark economic cooperation framework agreement in June.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the new developments:
United Daily News:
The Yechun Teahouse, a famous "century-old-brand" restaurant in the eastern Chinese city of Yangzhou, will open its first overseas branch at Core Pacific City Living Mall in Taipei Sept. 3.

It will be the first Chinese fully owned restaurant in Taiwan and its owner, the Yangzijiang Group, attaches great importance to the venture. It has spent NT$40 million (US$1.25 million) to decorate its 500-ping (1,650-square meter) property into a classic Yangzhou-style setting.

Not only have wood craftsmen been hired from Yangzhou to carry out the interior decoration but the parent restaurant's head chef will stay in Taiwan for the first year of operation to ensure that the restaurant's dishes exactly match those sold at the Yangzhou outlet.

"The decorations, tableware and utensils used in the Taiwan branch all come from the original Yechun Teahouse. We want to present authentic Yangzhou-style gourmet offerings to win the hearts and minds of Taiwanese customers, " said Yangzijiang Group Chairman Zhu Yuanhao in a recent interview.

The restaurant will offer Yechun's signature dishes, including steamed buns, meat dumplings, green shao-mai, steamed thousand layer cakes and other quintessential Yangzhou delicacies. All the ingredients will be Taiwan-grown farm produce.
Because of legal restrictions, Chinese catering service providers previously had to collaborate with Taiwanese joint-venture partners when operating in Taiwan.

Divergences in marketing, packaging and management concepts led to the failure of those pioneering Chinese investors in the highly competitive Taiwanese catering industry and market analysts in Taiwan and China are now watching closely to see whether Yechun's new business venture will succeed. (Aug. 27, 2010).
China Times:

Taiwan's Labor Pension Fund Supervisory Committee decided recently that it will earmark NT$24 billion from the New Labor Pension Fund for investment in emerging stock markets, including those in China, as well as Russia, Brazil, India, South Africa, Malaysia, Thailand and Latin American countries.

It marks the first time that the New Labor Pension Fund will be used to invest in emerging stock markets and also the first time that the government-run pension fund will invest in the Chinese stock market.

China's B-shares and H-shares (shares of companies incorporated in China that are listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange or other foreign exchanges) will all be targets of the labor pension fund's investment, according to Lee Jui-chu, vice chairwoman of the Labor Pension Fund Supervisory Committee.

Basically, she said, B-shares -- which refer to those traded in foreign currencies on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges -- will account for no more than 10 percent of the fund's total investment in these emerging stock markets.

As of the end of July, the earnings rate or return on investment of the old Retirement Fund was minus 1.17 percent, which translates into a loss of NT$5.9 billion, while the earnings rate of the New Pension Fund was negative 1.49 percent, representing a loss of NT$7.5 billion, Lee said.

In comparison, she said, the two pension funds rank among the world's best in terms of management efficiency and profitability. "The losses of both funds are narrowing steadily, " she added. (Aug. 27, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: President's sister roots for Chinese Taipei baseball team
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/10 11:51:51 (By Jorge Liu and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: One of the "number one fans" of Taiwan's little league baseball, who has been showing up at Williamsport, Pennsylvania for every match, has turned out to be Ma Nai-hsi, one of President Ma Ying-jeou's sisters.

Since the Aug. 20 opening of the Little League Baseball World Series 2010, Ma's second-eldest sister and her husband have been driving for three to four hours from their home in New Jersey to Pennsylvania to root for the Chinese Taipei team.
Keeping a low profile, Ma Nai-hsi and her husband choose to sit among the Taiwanese expatriates and wave the Republic of China national flag as they cheer for their team.
They politely turned down an offer of VIP seats from Lee Su-chen, leader of Kaohsiung's Fu-Hsing Little League team.
Ma's sister also went to the athletes village to congratulate the players on their performance after they defeated Panama 5-1 Aug. 26 to proceed to the later rounds of the championship.
The team is scheduled to play against Pool C winners Japan Aug. 28 in the international championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan players cruise into world badminton quarterfinals
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/10 12:28:04 (By Lo Yuan-shao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese player Cheng Shao-chieh cruised into the top eight in the women's singles at the World Badminton Championships in Paris Thursday.
Cheng beat her eighth-seeded German opponent Juliane Schenk 21-13, 21-19, after losing to Schenk in the first set 19-21.
Cheng successfully defended her title in the women's singles at the Yonex Badminton Open in Taipei Aug. 8.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's Hsueh Hsuan-yi went through to the men's singles quarterfinals Thursday after trouncing his Thai challenger Boonsak Ponsana 21-13, 21-11.
Hsueh will meet fourth-seeded Chen Jin of China in his upcoming quarterfinal match.

Taiwan's Fang Chieh-min and Lee Sheng-mu breezed into the quarterfinals in the men's doubles, while Cheng Wen-Hsing and Chien Yu-chin made the women's doubles top eight at the world's most prestigious badminton championships that opened at the Pierre de Coubertin Stadium Aug. 23.
Cheng and Chien finished off their rivals from the Netherlands 21-14, 21-15 in a match that lasted just 26 minutes.
Fang and Lee, meanwhile, took 32 minutes to beat their Japanese opponents 21-19, 21-12.

Taiwan's mixed doubles team of Chien Yu-chin and Lee Sheng-mu also achieved success, beating their South Korean rivals Yong Dae Lee and Hyo Jung Lee 21-17, 22-20 to face China's Tao Jiaming and Zhang Yawen in the quarterfinals.
Some 400 of the world's top badminton players are competing at the 2010 World Badminton Championships, which is slated to wrap up Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Luxury Japan tours to be launched via Songshan-Haneda flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 13:10:25 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With direct flights between Songshan Airport in Taipei and Haneda Airport in Tokyo set to begin Oct. 31, Taiwanese travel agencies are planning to launch luxury tours to Japan via the flights, with a 33-day vacation priced at a whopping NT$1.25 million (US$39,000).

EzTravel Co., a leading local online travel agency, announced Thursday at a press conference that it will start to sell the top Japan travel package online -- with only 20 places available -- from Sept. 9.

Jack You, chief executive officer of ezTravel Co., said the tourists will travel business class on All Nippon Airways (ANA) and first class on the Shinkansen, Japan's high-speed railway, to 26 destinations in Japan.

Miya Shinsuke, head of ANA's Taiwan branch office, said that as Haneda Airport is ANA's major base for domestic flights, it will be easier for the airline to plan tours in Japan from that airport compared to Japan's other main gateway, Narita International Airport.

He was upbeat that the top-class tour will attract attention in Japan, as such tours have been rarely been seen, and he predicted that Japanese travel agencies might follow suit in designing similar packages.

The tourists on the one-month luxury tour will stay at top hotels with an average room rate of NT$26,000 per night, which would bring the total accommodation cost of the tour to NT$800,000, according to the online travel agency.

The Taiwanese online travel agency has been successful in launching various luxury vacations since the economy has recovered. In April, it sold out all 40 seats for a NT$2.25 million 60-day world tour.
Lion Travel Service Co., one of Taiwan's largest travel agencies, also said the Songshan-Haneda flights will provide more flexibility for planning top tours in Japan.
The company is also planning to launch top-level tours to Tokyo and Kyoto, with a seven-day tour priced at NT$300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Things that are more important than money

TEXT.P: Besides buying luxury residences, exquisite products and high-end cars, wealthy people in Taiwan should think more about "what are the things that are more important than money?"
In this regard, has "The Giving Pledge" philanthropic campaign initiated by American billionaires Warren Buffett and Bill Gates given them any inspiration?

Addressing the widening gap between the rich and the poor, Premier Wu Den-yih has said he hopes to collect more taxes from high-income earners and to use the money to help the disadvantaged. In reality, we have not seen the Cabinet carry out this policy.
Over the past year, many proposals to increase taxes have been put aside by the government because "the timing is not right." Instead, many proposals to cut taxes have been adopted.

Rich people in Taiwan like to talk about their achievements and those in the business sector also like to tout their contributions to society. However, when it comes to raising taxes to save state finances, they immediately broadcast their displeasure.

We look forward to seeing the emergence of generous entrepreneurs like Buffett and Gates in Taiwan, people who are not only rich in wealth but also in benevolence. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Argentine student receives scholarship from ROC mission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 13:25:32 (By Fang Pei-ching and Doris Hsu)

TEXT.P: An Argentinean student has recently received a music scholarship from the Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation, diplomatic sources said Friday.

The foundation began to offer the Lito Gonzalez Music Scholarship to Argentine students two years ago. This year's recipient was Emiliano Quinonez, a 16-year- old student from the Berisso school's orchestra in La Plata, the capital city of Buenos Aires Province, the sources said, adding that the scholarship will allow the student to pursue advanced training.

The scholarship award ceremony took place Aug. 19 at Taiwan's representative office in Argentina, with Dr. Austin Ou, director of the foundation and Lee Sing-ying, head of the Taipei Commercial and Cultural Office in Argentina, presiding over the ceremony.
With the financial aid from the foundation, Cynthia Gomez, the recipient of last year's scholarship, has performed violin recitals in both France and Venezuela, the sources said.
The Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation, founded in 1997, has served the needy worldwide by carrying out medical and educational programs to improve their quality of life.
In addition to the scholarship program, the foundation also operates a study guidance center in La Plata to subsidize 25 Argentine children from impoverished families.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA English news budget for Aug. 27

TEXT.P: lobar degeneration 13. President comments on restrictions for Chinese students

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan becomes full IATTC member
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 14:31:52 (By S.M. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan officially became a full member of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) Friday, which entitles it to vote in the commission's policy- making process and gives a boost to the rights of Taiwanese fishermen, the Council of Agricultural Affairs (COA) announced Friday.

At a time when international management of tuna stocks has become increasingly restrictive, Taiwan's full membership of the IATTC is very helpful in protecting Taiwanese fishing boats operating on the high seas, the COA's Fisheries Agency explained.

The IATTC is in charge of the management and conservation of tuna in the East Pacific, an important fishing ground for high-value species such as bigeye and yellowfin tuna for Taiwanese fishing vessels.
Taiwan has been an IATTC observer since 1973, but this status did not confer voting rights.
In the peak tuna years, more than 90 Taiwanese fishing ships operated in the East Pacific, yielding an average combined annual catch of 10,000-20,000 tons worth some NT$2 billion (US$62.5 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese-American couple complete round-the-world flight
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/10 15:49:05 (By Leaf Chiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese-American couple have recently returned from a daring 82-day, 41,843-km round-the-globe flight, becoming the first people of Chinese descent in history to successfully fly a single-engine aircraft around the world.

Jeffrey Ying and his wife Renee Chen departed Los Angeles May 4 aboard their single-engine Piper PA 46, heading north to Canada where they embarked on their epic global flight, returning to Los Angeles July 20 safe and sound.

Ying, who participated in the design and building of Taiwan's first self-made aircraft in the 1980s, told CNA that flying around the world had always been his dream, but it was only some 10 years ago that he began to work toward realizing that goal.
He said it was not until he actually started making the preparations for the trip that he realized how hard it is to fly around the world.
"I had a bumpy start with my first two aircraft, but managed to lead the endeavor back onto the right track after I obtained a third plane two years ago," he said.
By the time he and his wife were ready to kick off the flight, however, he realized that buying the aircraft was the easiest part of the round-the-globe project.

Charting flight plans, obtaining landing permits from the many airports they would need to use, and fly-over permits from governments in advance, as well as refueling, were the major issues that had to be surmounted, he added.
Those "human" matters, however, were nothing compared to what happens in the sky, he said.
"The weather issue was the biggest enemy for us," he went on.

Soon after they reached Iceland, they were stuck there by a massive ash cloud from a volcanic eruption in that tiny country, which caused chaos across Europe after all flights over the United Kingdom were canceled.

"Believing that getting stuck at London's Heathrow Airport was definitely not an option, we wandered from one small airport to another around Scandinavia, trying to inch our way south toward Africa, " Ying recalled.

They experienced another life-or-death challenge one day while flying from Brunei to Cambodia. Caught in a tremendous thunderstorm, all three radar and navigation systems on the aircraft became inoperable and it was only Ying's instinct and experience that got them down safely.
"We basically collapsed into our seats once we landed in Cambodia," Chen said.
Ying said that despite their adversities, they were helped along the way by many kind-hearted people.

On the day they arrived at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at midnight running on fumes, for example, they found to their horror that they did not have enough Taiwanese currency to pay for their fuel.
To their eternal gratitude, China Airlines ground staff had a whip-round and raised the money to pay for their gas.
Ying became the 166th pilot in the world to fly a single-engine plane around the world. He and his wife recorded their journey with more than 3,000 photographs taken in the 26 countries they visited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.43 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 16:26:08 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Boosted by strong buying in construction shares, Taiwan share prices closed up 0.43 percent Friday, recovering slightly from losses in the previous two days, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 33.17 points to 7,722.91, after moving between 7,702.59 and 7,722.91, on turnover of NT$92.1 billion (US$2.88 billion).
The market opened up 12.85 points, with investors more reluctant to continue to dump shares as the market found technical support after two days of correction, dealers said.
The construction sector, which gained the most at 2.7 percent, was boosted by a forecast by Credit Suisse research analyst Tao Dong that Taipei's real estate market will certainly go up.
Textile stocks rose 1.4 percent, and the foodstuff sector added 1.3 percent after suffering a 2.4 percent decline on Thursday.
Financial shares were up 0.9 percent, plastics and chemical issues advanced 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp shares rose 0.6 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector edged up 0.1 percent, while cement stocks remained unchanged.
A total of 1,780 stocks closed down and 1,683 finished higher, while 333 remained unchanged.

Allan Lin, assistant vice president of the research department at Concord Securities, said that the local shares market, after falling in the past two days, was shored up by bargain hunting buying, but it also encountered resistance as it rose.
Lin said he expects the market to enter a narrow consolidation phase, with the index hovering between 7,650 and 7,850 next week.
Taiwan International Securities analyst Benson Huang said that the market was still a bit bearish as foreign investors have turned to the sell side in the stock futures market.
He also said that the market mood was cautious ahead of the latest GDP figures from the U.S. and a speech by Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke later Friday on the U.S. economic outlook.
"The index would need to stand firm above the 90-day-average of 7,655 next week if it is to move upward," Huang said.

Kevin Lin, senior vice president of Fuh Hong Financial Planning Co., predicted that market investors will grow more cautious with the approach of November 27 municipal mayoral elections and the uncertainties over the U.S. and European economies.
"Local investors usually begin to turn cautious three months before an election," Lin said.
Foreign investors, including mainland Chinese investors, were net sellers of NT$5.93 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold job fair in U.S. to lure expatriates back home
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 16:52:27 (by Wu Hsien-shen and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan electronics companies and government agencies will launch a recruitment drive in Boston, Massachusetts next month to hire overseas Taiwanese for jobs in the fields of business, education and research.

The delegation, led by Minister without Portfolio Chang Jin-fu and Chairwoman Christina Liu from the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will conduct one-on-one interviews with eligible people on Sept. 15.

The participating companies and academic and research institutions are expected to offer a total of 1,000 positions in Taiwan, China and the U.S. under the Taiwan government's Overseas Science and Technology Personnel Recruitment Program.

The delegation consists of major Taiwan-based electronics companies such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) , Foxconn Technology Group, Mediateck, Delta Electronics and Chimei Innolux Corporation as well as U.S.-based Taiwanese companies like AcBel Polytech and the Aurora Group.

Because of expansion, Taiwan electronic companies have been experiencing a shortage of skilled technicians in LED and solar- production industry. They will be looking to fill the shortfall at the job fair.
In the field of education, National Cheng Kung University, National Chiao Tung University, National Yang Ming University, and China Medical University will be aiming to recruit teaching staff.

Major research institutions like the Development Center for Biotechnology, Industrial Technology Research Institute, Institute for Information Industry and National Applied Research Laboratories will also be seeking fresh talent.
Since the program was launched in 2003 to encourage the return of highly skilled nationals, thousands of overseas Taiwanese have returned home to work.

In March 2007, a new feature was introduced to allow Taiwanese male students in the U.S. who hold a master's degree from a university recognized by Taiwan's Ministry of Education to apply for research and development positions at home as an alternative to military service.

Another facet of the government's s overseas recruitment drive is its Talent Seeker Project that is aimed at attracting senior professionals in the hi-tech industry by offering them incentives to return home.
The delegation this year will meet potential job seekers from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Sept. 15 at Boston Sheraton Commander Hotel, which is located next to Harvard University.
Registrations will only be accepted online at http: //hirecruit.nat.gov.tw/bos.
Those who go through to the interview sessions will be eligible to take part in a lucky draw for an iPad, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President backs cautious attitude toward Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 16:58:46 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou defended Friday the government's cautious attitude toward opening Taiwan to Chinese students.

Ma, meeting with a delegation from the Association of Private Universities and Colleges, said that although some people think the restrictions set for Chinese students are unnecessary, he believes that caution is essential to sustain the policy over the long term.

The Legislative Yuan amended three laws last week to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan's universities and colleges, but three legal restrictions were also imposed on the students -- restrictions that some lawmakers in Ma's own party believed were unnecessary.

These are refusing to recognize diplomas issued by Chinese medical schools, forbidding Chinese students from enrolling in departments closely related to Taiwan's national security, and banning those without Taiwanese citizenship from taking state examinations to work as civil servants or professionals.
Ma noted that Taiwan's declining birth rate is putting tremendous pressure on enrollment at private universities and colleges, which might eventually force some of them to close down.
Under these circumstances, Ma suggested, the institutions should make good use of their resources to recruit international students, especially those from Southeast Asia.
Methods that can be used to attract the students include providing all-English courses and establishing a higher education accreditation system, he said.
According to the president, the signing of the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement in late June has provided greater incentive for foreign students to study in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 17:03:23 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.007 to close at NT$32.030.
Turnover totaled US$755 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.067 and moved to a low of NT$31.819 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police indict Briton for allegedly groping pedestrians
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 17:11:02 (By Lin Chung-sen and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Prosecutors indicted a male Briton on Friday for allegedly groping five female pedestrians in downtown Taipei on Aug. 10, according to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.

A prosecutor said 35-year-old Gary James Fennell was arrested near Taipei Main Station soon after police officers received complaints that he had attacked five women in 15 minutes on the evening of Aug. 10. He is being held at the Taipei Detention Center.

"The suspect caused chaos among the crowd before the police arrested him," the prosecutor said. "He insisted his actions were the result of a psychological disorder, but couldn't provide any medical proof."
According to the prosecutor, Fennell attacked most of the victims from behind and grabbed their arms or touched their hips or private parts.
The prosecutor added that Fennell entered the country in May saying he intended to visit relatives in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-Strait Cup baseball tournament planned
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 18:29:51 (By Feng Chao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The first Cross-Strait Cup Baseball Tournament is expected to take place next year in China and the second will be held in Taiwan, an official of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Baseball Association (CTABA) said in Beijing Friday.

"National baseball associations from the two sides have been discussing the tournament and decisions on details are expected to be finalized by the end of this year, " said CTABA Secretary-General Richard Lin.

Lin and CTABA board member George Chao, a former player on Taiwan's national team, are currently in Beijing to see the Xinlongqi Cross-Strait Baseball Invitational that opened in the Chinese capital Wednesday.

Chao said although the skills of China's baseball players and the game's general environment there lag far behind Taiwan's, Chinese baseball players occasionally perform outstandingly in international competitions.
"With Taiwan's competitiveness in baseball, both sides could cooperate to make the baseball market in the greater China area a bigger pie," Chao envisioned.

He suggested that the CTABA, its Chinese counterpart and Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) collaborate to sponsor baseball tournaments in both Taiwan and China to help elevate the game's competitive level, strengthen its structure and improve the caliber of the fans.
He called for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China to pitch in to "create the big pie" together.

Meanwhile, Liang Kung-ping, a Taiwanese businessman who founded Scoresports Co. in Beijing in 2008, said he has found that baseball has tremendous potential in many areas around China, particularly in remote provinces, where talented boys are willing to devote their time to working on their baseball skills.
Scoresports is the major sponsor of the Xinlongqi competition.

According to Liang, through the efforts of his Good Strike Project, Major League Baseball decided to sponsor two Chinese players over the past three years to develop their potential, paying for their schooling and baseball training.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica makes breakthrough in brain degeneration studies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 18:47:25 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An Academia Sinica research team has uncovered via a mouse model the secrets of the formation of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) , a brain disorder that causes dementia and for which there is currently no treatment, a researcher said Friday.

Tsai Kuen-jer, an assistant professor at National Cheng Kung University's Graduate Institute of Clinical Medicine who took part in the research, touted the finding as a major breakthrough in the study of the neurodegenerative disease.
Using the model will bring scientists closer to developing and creating efficient drugs or therapies to treat FTLD patients, Tsai said.

According to Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic research institute, FTLD is associated with atrophy in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain that can lead to memory loss, impairment of language ability and sometimes motor neuron disease.
It is one of the common causes of various kinds of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease.

The research team, led by Academician Che-Kun James Shen at the the Institute of Molecular Biology, found an abnormal level of a type of cellular protein known as TAR DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43) in the brains of FTLD sufferers.
The protein, which is capable of affecting neural cell activity, should exist in the nucleus of a cell but is found at an increased levels in the cell plasma of people with FTLD, Tsai said.
In the study, the researchers genetically engineered mice with increased levels of TDP-43 in the forebrain. They discovered that the mice exhibited symptoms that mimic FTLD.

"The finding that increased levels of TDP-43 protein in the forebrain are sufficient to cause FTLD and possibly other neurodegenerative diseases yields a new avenue for future studies of FTLD," said the institute in a statement.

It pointed out that Shen's research team has already started to test a few drugs with potential for treating FTLD and that a collaboration project with an Australia-based laboratory has also been established to conduct drug screening.

The results of the research paper, titled "Elevated Expression of TDP-43 in the Forebrain of Mice is Sufficient to Cause Neurological and Pathological Phenotypes Mimicking FTLD-U, " were published July 27 in the peer-reviewed Journal of Experimental Medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five candidates win British Council scholarships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 18:57:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Five Taiwanese aspirants have won the first IELTS (International English Language Testing System) Scholarships contested in Taiwan and will soon head overseas to start the fall semester in selected schools, the British Council Taipei announced Friday.

"We are delighted to announce the five winners of our new British Council IELTS scholarships for Taiwanese students planning to study at postgraduate levels at overseas universities," said Alison Devine, the new director of the British Council, the U.K.'s top international organization for cultural relations and educational opportunities.

Lin Nen-wei, Lee Yi-fang, Wu Pin-hsien, Li Yi-shan and Luh Tau-yu will each receive a scholarship of NT$100,000, said Devine, who assumed her post in late June. Except for Luh, who will be studying in the United States, the other winners will be going to the U.K.
Devine said the winners were among 15 individuals who were selected from a pool of 153 applicants in the first phase of the process before emerging through the second-phase interview process.
Most of the winners are professionals with working experience. Li, who was admitted to the University of Edinburgh, has taught at a junior high school in the central city of Taichung for five years.
Lee, who will attend University College London and major in preschool education, has been an auditor at PricewaterhouseCoopers for four years.

"Most Taiwanese students choose to study in the U.K. because it takes only a year, rather than two years in the U.S., to receive a degree. It takes a lot of financial pressure off students and their parents," Lee said.
Annual tuition in the U.K. ranges between NT$400,000-500,000, Lee said, about half what it costs in the U.S.

The winners also praised IELTS, an exam testing the ability to listen, speak, write and read in English, and compared it favorably to the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) , a U.S. Internet-based test, for its face-to-face interaction.

Prudence Chou, the British Council's Exam Service Manager, said the average score of Taiwanese students taking the test increased from 5.59 (out of nine points) in 2007 to 5.72 in 2009, but indicated that there was still room for improvement relative to the average scores of other Asian countries.
According to the British Council, female test takers outnumbered male test takers by a 7: 3 ratio, which one of the winners attributed to Taiwan's social traditions.

"I discussed the fact with my friends and most of them thought that it would be much harder for Taiwanese men to suspend their jobs without pay for a year like me. Men tend to shoulder more 'social pressure' to be financially stable in Taiwan's society, " said Li, who plans to resume her job as a teacher in late 2011.
The British Council Taipei said it will offer scholarships again in 2011 to help more Taiwanese students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung should treat China as business partner: strategist
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 19:08:32 (By Cheng Chi-feng and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung should shelve political concerns when doing business with China in the post-Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) era and treat China like any other business client, Japanese business strategist Kenichi Ohmae said Friday during a speech in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City.
Ohmae, a renowned forecaster of economic trends, said the risk of an economic bubble in China and the signing of the ECFA will boost Chinese investment in Taiwan in the near future.

Kaohsiung must grab this opportunity and prioritize economic development over political ideology, said Ohmae. Kaohsiung is considered to be a stronghold of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which opposes closer ties with China out of fear that Taiwan might become over-reliant on its giant neighbor.
He suggested that the Kaohsiung city government should demonstrate an entrepreneurial spirit and view China as an important business client.
He noted that Japan was initially intimidated by the idea of opening up to tourists from China, only to learn afterwards that the trepidation was unnecessary.

In fact, Japan's opening policy improved its stagnant economy, with an estimated 2 million Chinese tourists expected to have visited by the end of this year, a 1.2 million increase compared to last year, added Ohmae.

He said Kaohsiung Harbor has a great advantage with its potential for becoming an Asia-Pacific hub, provided it stops relying on exports, starts learning from the success of other transit harbors such as Hong Kong, Singapore and Dubai, and forms relations with ports along the coast of China and Japan.

He said the city government should also have sufficient business knowledge and should offer foreign investors business-oriented services such as like "one window" services and a safe investment environment.

The ruling Kuomintang's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chao- shun attended the speech and said that if she wins the municipality election there in November, she will invite Ohmae to serve as an economic consultant for the city government in a bid to generate more jobs in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pop diva named ambassador for Taiwan pavilion at Shanghai expo
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 19:20:33 (By Charles Kang and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese singer Jolin Tsai was named as the first one-day ambassador for the Taiwan pavilion at Shanghai World Expo, Chief Curator of the pavilion Yeh Ming- shui said Friday.
Tsai was invited to visit the Taiwan pavilion, where she performed its theme song "Taiwan's Heartbeat."
"I have been looking forward to visiting the Taiwan pavilion since I recorded the theme song," Tsai said.
The pavilion promotes the natural and the cultural attributes of Taiwan and gives visitors a chance to become more familiar with the country, she said.
After her song, Tsai danced with the pavilion's mascot, which is called the "Electronic Dance God of Taiwan," and released three electronic sky lanterns that she said carried her personal wishes.
"I hope the sky lanterns will bring peace to the country and the world and joy to all the people I love," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy picked up momentum in July: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 19:53:18 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy heated up in July as the job market gained some momentum, but leading indicators for the month dipped slightly, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.
The monitoring indicator for the overall economy gained one point in July to rise to 38 points and flashed a red light, which signifies the economy is booming, the CEPD said.
"In general, the local economy still maintained steady growth, " the CEPD said in a press release.
Non-agricultural employment went from yellow-red to red in July as the job market improved, which helped tip the monitoring index's scale to red after being yellow-red the previous two months.
The planning agency uses a five-color system to gauge the country's economic performance for any given month.
Blue implies a sluggish economy, yellow-blue represents a slowdown, green indicates a stable economy, yellow-red means the economy is mildly overheated, and red signifies overheating.
Taiwan's economy flashed a red light in the first four months of this year, and showed a yellow-red light in May and June.

The index of coincident indicators, which reflect economic activity in the period measured, rose 1.0 percent to 124.0 in July, but the index of leading indicators, which gauge economic performance in three to six months, fell 0.2 percent from June to 117.6.

Despite the small drop, the CEPD said it remained cautiously optimistic about the economy's prospects because strong growth in emerging economies will help maintain export momentum and government investment promotion drives are expected to spur private investment.

Taiwan's economy grew 13.7 percent year-on-year in the first quarter and 12.5 percent in the second quarter, the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported on Aug. 19. It revised its forecast for full-year growth upwards to 8.24 percent.
The country's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell for the the 11th consecutive month to 5.17 percent in July, and the government has vowed to pull it below 5 percent by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to discuss cultural agreements next year: SEF chair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 20:05:37 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Following their recent signing of agreements on economic cooperation, Taiwan and China are facing a more important task of launching "in-depth talks" in 2011 on cultural exchanges, Taiwan's top negotiator with China said Friday.

Chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chiang Pin-kung said he hopes the two sides will come up with relevant framework agreements next year through negotiations by the SEF and its China counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies assigned by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

The cultural links between the two sides are from the same root and are more important than economic and trade ties, Chiang said in Taipei City at the launch of a series of cultural performances and exhibitions by a group of visiting artists from China.

Increased cultural interaction will serve to promote harmonious development of cross-strait relations because culture can help to narrow the knowledge gap between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said.
Next year, "the focus will be on the cultural field," he said.
The Chinese delegation, led by a Hebei provincial official Nie Chenxi, arrived in Taiwan Thursday on a one-week performance tour of Taiwan's major cities.

The tour will include performances by the 40-member Peking Opera troupe and its leader Pei Yanling as well as a display of various traditional folks arts from Hebei Province, including music, wood paintings and handcraft.

Taiwan and China are looking at other areas of cooperation in the wake of a recent economic cooperation framework agreement under which the tariffs on hundreds of products from both sides will be removed or lowered.

In a meeting that will be held before the end of the year, Chiang and ARATS President Chen Yunlin are expected to work toward signing cross-strait agreements on cooperation in the medical and health care field.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Banker's wife changes Taipei's landscape with art
DOC.DATELINE: 08/27/10 20:25:28 (Business Today 713)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Maggie Tsai doesn't credit her success in improving Taipei's cultural landscape to being married to Fubon Financial Vice Chairman Richard Tsai. She credits it to a decade of hard work.

Ms. Tsai, CEO of the Fubon Art Foundation, held Taipei's first Very Fun Park event in 2001. She aimed to bring art into everyday city life by placing contemporary artwork at various shops and buildings in the capital.

With a limited budget and a staff of eight people, she and foundation Director Vivian Hsiung decided to focus the project around Taipei's affluent eastern district, hoping that businesses in the area would be more willing to cooperate in cultural activities.
"We were totally wrong! Shop space is precious because of the high rent in the area, " Tsai said. "Not many owners were interested in displaying artwork in their shops."
But Hsiung combed through alleys and talked with shop owners, struggling to convince them to participate. Meanwhile, Tsai backed Hsiung up by organizing events and selecting art.

In the end, dozens of artists' works including paintings, sculptures and installations were displayed in the area for a month in August and September that year. After a six-year break, the event returned in 2007 and has been an annual part of the city's art calendar since then, drawing more and more support each year.
Very Fun Park 2010 opened on July 16 and runs through Sept. 5. The event includes artwork at 36 locations throughout Taipei's eastern district -- and this time Hsiung didn't have to beg.
"Many businesses came to us and asked if they could take part, " she said. "Some of them even closed their shops for hours just to allow for the arrival and installation of the works."
The enthusiasm of shop owners shows that Tsai's efforts at planting cultural seeds are paying off.
"Friends have said I'm a fool attempting the impossible, " she said. "My answer is, 'Not at all. We're not fools. Can't you see what we're achieving bit by bit?'"

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady to depart on humanitarian trip to Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Port-au-Prince and Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 21:16:21 (By Jenny W. Hsu and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching is scheduled to make her first humanitarian trip to Haiti on Sunday after the Caribbean country was devastated by a major earthquake in January this year, World Vision Taiwan said Friday.
She will make the trip as honorary president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and "Love Ambassador" for World Vision.
Known for her advocacy for child welfare, the first lady will meet earthquake survivors and orphans in Petionville and Port-au-Prince. Chow also plans to visit a make-shift tent camp in Delmas.
She will also be visiting a Food For the Poor center to witness first-hand the distribution of rice donations from Taiwan.
According to World Vision, Chow will give away solar-powered light fixtures as part of Taiwan's continuing effort to help Haiti get back on its feet.

As Haiti's ally since the former French colony became an independent country in 1956, Taiwan was one of the first countries to offer humanitarian support during the initial aftermath of the earthquake. A 23-person search and rescue team from Taiwan's National Fire Agency was among the first foreign help to arrive in Haiti.

To date, Taiwan has donated more than 400 metric tons of rice to Haiti since the deadly 7.3 magnitude temblor on Jan. 12 that claimed more than 300,000 lives and displaced at least 1.5 million people.

Through the International Cooperation and Development Fund, the government of Taiwan has also pledged to outfit schools and orphanages in Haiti with 1,020 computer work stations, according to Food for the Poor, one of the biggest international relief agencies in the U.S.

In a meeting with Haitian Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive and Dominican Republic President Leonard Fernandez in Santo Domingo two weeks after the earthquake, President Ma Ying-jeou promised cash aid of US$10 million and said Taiwan would participate in the rebuilding effort by offering aid in public health care, resettlement of survivors and agricultural support.
After Haiti, Chow will also make a brief two-day stopover in the Dominican Republic, where she will visit a job training center, two primary schools, and a health center.

During the trip, Chow will meet six children whom she and the president are sponsoring in both countries, World Vision Taiwan said. She will bring gifts including story books, coloring books and ceramic flutes.
The first lady is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Sept. 5.

Chow visited the United States, Canada and Russia in January and February as honorary director of Taiwan's renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre. She made a similar trip to Italy and Spain in June and July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to target sectors to counter FTA among China, Japan, S. Korea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 21:29:42 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should prioritize several industries in follow-up talks with China under the framework trade pact the two signed in late June to counter a possible East Asian free trade zone, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Friday.

The BOFT said the service, petrochemical, steel, machinery, electronics and automobile industries should top the agenda in future negotiations under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) so that they would remain competitive in China's market even if China, Japan and South Korea form a free trade union.
The bureau made the suggestion in a report on the progress of a free trade agreement among the three nations and its impact on Taiwan.

The report noted that a private study conducted jointly by China, Japan and South Korea in December 2008 concluded that the establishment of a free trade zone of the three countries could optimize their interests.
It could boost Japan's GDP by 0.3 percent, China's GDP by 0.4 percent, and South Korea's GDP by 2.8 percent, the study said.

The bureau's report said the three countries have signed FTAs with other countries or regions in recent years that have adversely impacted Taiwan's exports, and if the three were to sign an FTA, then its threat to Taiwan could be even greater.

The BOFT also said that the threat of ASEAN plus three (China, Japan, South Korea), which is still being negotiated, was bigger than the existing ASEAN plus one (China), as all of Taiwan's major trading rivals would be economically integrated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks manufacturer for enterovirus 71 vaccine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 22:09:11 (By Chen Ching-fan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) said Friday it was seeking pharmaceutical manufacturers to produce a vaccine targeting enterovirus 71 (EV71) , a deadly virus that killed 78 children during a 1998 outbreak in Taiwan.
A public screening of companies has been launched and will continue until Sept. 8, the NHRI said, adding that human testing could begin as early as September.
Although research into making the vaccine has been conducted since 1998, the NHRI wasn't able to establish a reliable technique until March this year.
The technique involves the use of a Vero cell culture, part of a cell line originally isolated from an African green monkey's kidney.
The manufacturer will be required to produce the vaccine in Taiwan.

Enteroviruses are a large family of viruses responsible for many infections in children. EV71 is one of the major causes of hand, foot and mouth disease, and is sometimes associated with central nervous system diseases such as meningitis and encephalitis. Newborns and toddlers are most vulnerable to EV71.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amendment on constituencies could be unconstitutional: CEC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 23:38:30 (By He Meng-kuei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An amendment that stipulates legislative constituencies remain unchanged for 10 years could be unconstitutional, the nation's top election official said Friday.
Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Rai Hau-min was referring to an amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act that cleared the legislature during its extra session last week.
Rai said that the CEC "stands by its view that the amendment could be unconstitutional, " adding that he had previously expressed such a view during a legislative committee.
Rai made the remarks after meeting opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator William Lai, who is running in the year-end Tainan municipality election.
"I've come to visit Rai because the amendment violates the Constitution," Lai said.

Lai said that after the merger of Tainan City and Tainan County, the new municipality will see its legislative seats increase to six from the present five because the Constitution stipulates that one legislator be elected for every 300,000 people.
Kaohsiung municipality, on the other hand, could see one seat taken away.

Lai accused the ruling Kuomintang of using its overwhelming majority in the legislature to push through the amendment, which stipulates that the legislative constituency will be based on the present one and will be reviewed every 10 years.

Rai was nominated by President Ma Ying-jeou to serve as a justice on the Constitutional Court and president of the Judicial Yuan earlier this week. The nomination is pending consent by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan culinary exhibition showcases fusion of global cuisine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 23:49:41 (By Chen Hsieh-shun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday and showcased "New Taiwan cuisine, " described as the fusion of eight regional Chinese cuisines, as well western and Japanese dishes.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo touted Taiwan's dishes as "traditional, creative and environmentally conscientious."
He said the exhibition is held to introduce Taiwan cuisine to the world in the hope that people in other countries can experience Taiwan's "unique culinary culture."

The exhibition, which runs through Aug. 30, drew crowds of visitors, many of whom seemed keen to purchase meal coupons offered by popular hotels around the island, including the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
In addition to local and exotic dishes, celebrity chefs have also been invited to the show to demonstrate how to prepare certain dishes.
