DOC.HEADLINE: Amendment on constituencies could be unconstitutional: CEC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 23:38:30 (By He Meng-kuei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An amendment that stipulates legislative constituencies remain unchanged for 10 years could be unconstitutional, the nation's top election official said Friday.
Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Rai Hau-min was referring to an amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act that cleared the legislature during its extra session last week.
Rai said that the CEC "stands by its view that the amendment could be unconstitutional, " adding that he had previously expressed such a view during a legislative committee.
Rai made the remarks after meeting opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator William Lai, who is running in the year-end Tainan municipality election.
"I've come to visit Rai because the amendment violates the Constitution," Lai said.

Lai said that after the merger of Tainan City and Tainan County, the new municipality will see its legislative seats increase to six from the present five because the Constitution stipulates that one legislator be elected for every 300,000 people.
Kaohsiung municipality, on the other hand, could see one seat taken away.

Lai accused the ruling Kuomintang of using its overwhelming majority in the legislature to push through the amendment, which stipulates that the legislative constituency will be based on the present one and will be reviewed every 10 years.

Rai was nominated by President Ma Ying-jeou to serve as a justice on the Constitutional Court and president of the Judicial Yuan earlier this week. The nomination is pending consent by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan culinary exhibition showcases fusion of global cuisine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/10 23:49:41 (By Chen Hsieh-shun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday and showcased "New Taiwan cuisine, " described as the fusion of eight regional Chinese cuisines, as well western and Japanese dishes.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo touted Taiwan's dishes as "traditional, creative and environmentally conscientious."
He said the exhibition is held to introduce Taiwan cuisine to the world in the hope that people in other countries can experience Taiwan's "unique culinary culture."

The exhibition, which runs through Aug. 30, drew crowds of visitors, many of whom seemed keen to purchase meal coupons offered by popular hotels around the island, including the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
In addition to local and exotic dishes, celebrity chefs have also been invited to the show to demonstrate how to prepare certain dishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrochemical project a must despite environmental issues: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/10 00:08:24 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday a controversial petrochemical complex must be built to ensure the competitiveness of Taiwan's petrochemical sector, but he acknowledged that safety and environmental concerns had to be addressed.
"The planned Kuokuang petrochemical plant must be built to avoid skewed development of the industry or producers leaving Taiwan," Shih said at a news conference.

Admitting that there were legitimate environmental concerns, however, Shih said the government would strengthen its role in strictly monitoring the sector to put the minds of residents living near the complexes at ease while at the same time maintaining an appropriate scale of production.
Shih defined an appropriate scale as annual ethylene production of between 5 million and 6 million tons.
Taiwan's beleaguered petrochemical industry was dealt a blow recently when two fires broke out at the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical complex in Yunlin County in July.

Angry residents blockaded the complex to push for compensation for losses, and they also complained about possible long-term health consequences from living near the facility and demanded that the complex be shut down later this decade.

The planned Kuokuang complex, which has faced even stronger resistance, would replace the fifth naphtha complex operated by state-run CPC Corp., Taiwan, which the government committed 20 years ago to relocating in 2015.

Opponents of the project, planned for Tacheng Township in Changhua County, say it would threaten the survival of the Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin, which live along Taiwan's western coast, and deal a severe blow to the country's efforts to reduce emissions.
Environmentalists launched a movement to buy back the land and want the project canceled, but Shih said Tacheng Township is the only place the complex could be built.

"The plot of more than 1,000 hectares in Tacheng is the last hope of Taiwan's petrochemical industry. Considering the scarcity of land in Taiwan, there is no other parcel of land that is such an ideal base for petrochemical companies to set up a production facility, " Shih said.
The minister contended that the Kuokuang project is a vital investment for Taiwan's economy because it cannot enjoy persistent growth without a sound petrochemical industry.

Without the complex, midstream and downstream producers would be likely to leave Taiwan, leaving the local industry out of balance. At the same time, the CPC Corp. chain would be weakened, reducing the competition faced by the Formosa Plastics Group, he added.
Shih said the government's top priority now is to strike a balance between development and the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lafayette bribe taker sentenced to 15 years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/10 00:17:11 (by Lai Yu-chia, Tsao Yu-fan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court sentenced former Navy captain Kuo Li-heng to 15 years in prison Friday for taking bribes in the Ministry of National Defense purchase of Lafayette frigates from France.

The court also ruled that US$17.6 million in kickbacks Kuo received from an arms broker, which is now being held by prosecutors after being returned to Taiwan from a Swiss bank account, be seized by the government.
The court found Kuo's brother, Kuo Wen-tien, guilty of helping launder money that was deposited in the pair's bank accounts in Switzerland, and sentenced him to two years in prison.
Kuo Li-heng, a former Navy weapons procurement officer, is already serving a life sentence handed down by a military court in 1994 over another bribery case.

The 1991 procurement of six naval frigates by the Navy from the French company Thomson-CSF, which has changed its name to Thales SA, was complicated by a procurement kickback scandal that came to light after the body of Navy officer Yin Ching-feng was found floating off the coast of northern Taiwan in December 1993. Yin was widely suspected to have been murdered because he was about to blow the whistle on the kickback scandal.

Investigators found that arms dealer Andrew Wang had wired a total of US$17,588,141 in four installments to the brothers' bank account in Switzerland between December 1991 and September 1993. His brother helped him manage the money after Yin was murdered.

Under joint investigation of prosecutors, the military and the police, the US$520 million bribery scandal surfaced in the following years. In 2000, Wang was found to have deposited in a Swiss bank the huge sum he received from the French company for securing the US$2.5 billion deal. Wang has been wanted by the Taiwanese government since 2000 as a murder suspect and is still at large.

In 2001, a prosecutor's office in Switzerland demanded that Wang's Swiss bank account be frozen. Meanwhile, the Taiwanese government submitted an appeal to the International Court of Arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris, asking for compensation for bribes and kickbacks involving the former Thomson-CSF.
In 2003, then-French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas confirmed the existence of the huge commission in the Lafayette deal.

The International Court of Arbitration ruled in May 2010 that Thales pay US$591 million to the Taiwanese government for violating the contract by paying commissions. Thales currently has an appeal filed with a higher court.

While the Taiwanese government has sought to have the money in Wang's account returned to Taiwan, Wang has since 2003 filed appeals to Swiss courts in hopes the authorities will allow him to access the account.
Until now, Swiss authorities have shown no signs of unfreezing the estimated US$700 million now in Wang's bank account.

Replying to an inquiry of the Central News Agency on Friday, Folco Galli, a spokesman for the Swiss Justice Department, said that the Swiss authorities will continue to freeze Wang's deposits until a sentence on Wang is "final and executable."

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung police rescue foreign workers from illegal confinement
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/10 00:18:50 (By Chen Ja-fo and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung police officers rescued eight foreign workers from a manpower brokerage agency that was keeping them illegally confined, an official with the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office said Friday.

Seven of the eight victims, from Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines, were locked inside the manpower agency's office in Kaohsiung City, where the police found other evidence related to the case, such as foreign workers' passports, working visas and savings account passbooks, prosecutors said.
The other victim was being held in a rooftop apartment.

Following the police rescue of the foreign workers, some were deported from Taiwan because their visas had expired, while others were being cared for by the Kaohsiung County government's Labor Affairs Bureau.

Prosecutors said their office, in cooperation with the Kaohsiung County government Police Bureau and the Kaohsiung City Reconnaissance Brigade, also summoned three executives of the manpower agency for questioning, and they were later released on bail.
The three individuals are also suspected of illegally forcing the victims to work overtime and reducing their salary by all possible means, prosecutors said.
Earlier this week, the husband of a female foreign worker, who was the victim held in the rooftop apartment, reported to the Kaohsiung police that he had lost contact with his wife for days.
That triggered the police investigation and led to the rescue of the migrant workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 28, 2010, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Preventing the graying of society

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total fertility rate has been dropping in recent years, with a world low of 0.94 births per woman predicted for this year.

The decline in births will lead to a decrease in the young labor force, which will in turn slow the country's economy. This demonstrates that giving birth to children is an issue concerning the country's survival, and is the shared responsibility of all citizens.
In this sense, raising children is not a family affair, but a matter crucial to preventing the aging of the entire country and society.

Few countries facing the same problem have succeeded in boosting their birth rate, mainly because the costs involved in child rearing are getting higher and higher, leading many families to have less children and even give up parenthood altogether.

If the costs of childbirth, immunization, day care service and education are shared by the whole nation, parents would have a lighter burden and people would no longer be afraid of having children. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Figures send warning message

TEXT.P: Data released recently by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of the Interior all show a consistent trend: Taiwan's wealth gap is wider than 10 years ago.
Besides an imbalanced industrial structure, the widening gap between the rich and the poor can be attributed to the unfair tax system.

Even though Taiwan is one of the few countries in the world that do not impose a tax on capital gains, the government has been decreasing taxes for wealthy people in recent years. Such improper tax reductions are leaving the government in financial difficulty and having a direct impact on social welfare and education spending.

Three years ago, President Ma Ying-jeou criticized his predecessor Chen Shui-bian as "failing to see the urgent need of the poor." With Ma in office for more than two years now, the people want to ask if he has heard the voices of the poor. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Ease restrictions on embedded marketing
DOC.DATELINE: 08/28/10 13:46:06 (Editorial abstract-- Aug. 28, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Embedded marketing is becoming a more and more acceptable means of advertisement in modern world. An exception is Taiwan, which has been sticking to its traditional mindset and imposes strict bans on product placement for television programs.
The Audiovisual Media Services Directive passed by the European Union in 2007, which defines the conditions under which product placement is permitted, is an example that Taiwan should follow.

The National Communications Commission has since last year been working on a proposal to amend the Satellite Broadcasting Act and the Cable Radio and Television Act to relax the ban. Under the proposal, product placement would be allowed in TV shows except for news and children programs.
We urge the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan to support the bill. For the health of the public, however, the ban on embedded marketing should remain for tobacco and alcoholic beverages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan engineers lauded in Haiti, but excluded from reconstruction
DOC.DATELINE: Port-au-Prince, Aug 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 13:56:17 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The deadly earthquake that struck Haiti in January dealt the Caribbean country its most devastating blow in 200 years. The 35-second jolt killed more than 300,000 people, displaced 1.9 million and flattened 208,000 homes.
According to the Haitian government's Action Plan for National Recovery and Development of Haiti, more than 1,300 educational institutions and at least 50 hospitals and health centers were destroyed.

All but one government building were demolished in Port-au-Prince, the nation's capital. Even the Presidential Palace and the National Cathedral, both iconic structures of leadership and hope, were crushed.

While almost the entire city was leveled, two buildings designed and built by Taiwanese -- the National Public Health Laboratory and the dormitory of Tabarre City University -- sustained the earthquake unharmed and remain fully functional today.

The AIDS research laboratory, which cost US$2 million and took a year and a half to build, played a vital role in the four months after the earthquake by serving as an ad hoc office for the World Health Organization (WHO) , said David Chang, the director of the Haiti office for Overseas Engineering and Construction Company (OECC), the firm credited for the two projects.

OECC is an overseas construction company commissioned by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to head up Taiwan-sponsored public infrastructure and development projects in Taiwan's allies in Central America, Africa and the South Pacific.

Hsia Pei-ling, the general manager of the Taipei-based Overseas Investment and Development Corp., the mother company of OECC, said that while he never imagined the two buildings would be used in such a manner, it was fitting they would be employed in the emergency.
"I was not surprised at all when I heard all of the OECC construction projects in Haiti were not damaged in the earthquake, because we only do top quality works," he said.

Seven months after the temblor, Port-au-Prince bears many scars of the earthquake in the forms of huge heaps of debris on just about every corner, half-toppled buildings, and people living out of tattered tents on the street.

Chang, who has been heading up the Haiti office for almost a decade, said that Haitian contractors often shortchange their clients by doing shoddy work, and that the building code in the country is "nearly non-existent."

In the 10 years that OECC has been in Haiti, its engineers and contractors have completed over 30 major projects including bridges, roads, parks and government buildings -- all of which, said Chang, were undamaged in the earthquake.

"Frankly, we did not do anything out of the ordinary when we built the projects," Chang said. "What we did was simply abide by the basic rules of seismic retrofitting in construction, and that's how our buildings were able to survive the earthquake."

Hsia said that in order to cut down on costs, the OECC strives to use as much local raw material as it can find. The company also hires many local laborers to work on the projects as part of its pseudo-"cash-for-work" program.
But despite the fact Taiwan has proven its engineering ingenuity and construction ability, Hsia said OECC is not included in the multinational effort on the territorial reconstruction of the country.
He said the reason is that many huge foreign conglomerates that he refused to name have already staked claims on the US$9.9 billion donation pledged by the international community to rebuild Haiti.

"These big companies know there is money to be made in situations like this. OECC is considered a small-to-medium size company compared to them, so it will be unlikely that we will get a piece of that pie," Hsia said.

But not all is lost, he said. Although OECC might never receive any of the pledged money, the Haitian government has sought the company's advice on small projects that will be paid for with money that isn't from the donations, Hsia said, adding that OECC is always happy to share its experience with anyone seeking advice.
"Our strategy is simple. Just use the correct material and do honest work," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of disadvantaged households rises 27% in first half of year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 15:19:38 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The number of disadvantaged households rose nearly 27 percent to 15,077 in the first six months of this year, with 90,146 people receiving financial assistance from the government, the Ministry of the Interior said Saturday.
The government provided NT$228.9 million (US$7.2 million) to disadvantaged families from January to June, up 20 percent from the same period last year.

The ministry said that the number of hardship families increased because of an amendment last year that made single fathers and those families in which grandparents raise their grandchildren eligible for government subsidies and allowances.
The number of male parents applying for government help increased nearly 118.6 percent in the six-month period, compared to a 20.7 percent rise for female parents.
Female applicants still accounted for nearly 89.6 percent of the total applicants, the ministry said.

The Act for Assisting Families in Hardship -- originally aimed mostly at taking care of women -- was first implemented in March 2008. It was amended last year to include eligible single fathers, grandparents, and people under the age of 65 whose spouse has died.
The amendment also increased education subsidies for households with children in college and lifted some restrictions to allow more victims of domestic violence to receive start-up loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Pavilion allows visitors in Venice to 'Take a Break'
DOC.DATELINE: Venice, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 16:35:17 (By Huang Ya-shih and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese architects invited visitors at the 12th Venice Architecture Biennale to "Take a Break" in a former prison at the opening ceremony of the Taiwan Pavilion in Venice, Italy on Friday.

"In Venice's summer heat, people want to relax in a space without constraint, and that was the impetus for the design of the pavilion, " said Tseng Wei, the 41-year-old leader of the architect delegation from Taiwan. "I hope the air- conditioned space and beverages will attract them into the pavilion."

With the theme of "Take a Break -- Spatial Variability in Contemporary Taiwan, " the Taiwan Pavilion has turned the Palazzo delle Prigioni, a former prison built in the 16th century, into a comfortable salon.

This marks the sixth time Taiwanese architects have participated in the biennial event, which was founded in 1980 as part of the Venice Biennale, a major art exhibition held on alternate years with the architecture show. The event opened on Aug. 26 and runs through Nov. 21.
Tseng and his Taichung-based Red Space Design Association beat out 10 other architecture teams for the chance to design the pavilion.
"Take a Break" is also meant to suggest a metaphor for contemporary Taiwan, which he said was undergoing a release of political and social tensions as relations with China improve.

David Tseng, a professor at National Chiao Tung University's Graduate Institute of Architecture and promoter for the opening ceremony, said the installation of the exhibit was a challenge because using nails or bolts to attach items to the walls is prohibited in the historic building.
Instead, the group used floating air cushions to create a false ceiling and make the space more approachable to identify with the biennial's theme, "People meet in architecture."
"The design will bring people closer and redefine the meaning of this kind of a space, " David Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese women reaches two semifinals at badminton championships
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/28/10 17:02:28 (By Lo Yuan-shao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chien Yu-chin admitted to being tired at the end of play Friday at the 2010 World Badminton Championships in Paris, but she wasn't complaining after reaching the semifinals of both the women's and mixed doubles.

Chien and partner Cheng Wen-hsing, seeded third in the women's doubles and considered Taiwan's most serious threats for a top showing in badminton's most prestigious annual tournament, reached the final four with a 21-14, 21-17 victory over eighth-seeded Hyun Young-yoo and Jung Kyung-eur of South Korea.
The pair, the only team not from China left in the event, will face second seeds Du Jing and Yu Yang of China in the semifinals.
Both Chien and Cheng voiced excitement about the win -- their best-ever performance at the World Championships -- and said they looked forward to battling Du and Yu, whom they have never beaten.
"We'll be able to just let it loose tomorrow," Cheng said.

Earlier in the day, Chien partnered with Lee Sheng-mu in mixed doubles to stun the 10th-seeded Chinese duo of Tao Jiaming and Chang Yawen 14-21, 21-18, 21-17 in 57 minutes, considered a marathon in badminton.

It was the third come-from-behind three-set match the 16th seeds have played in four matches, with their only straight set win coming against seventh-seeded Koreans Lee Yong-dae and Lee Hyo Jung in the third round.
That sent them into the quarterfinals against Tao and Chang.
The two will now face sixth-seeded He Hanbin and Yu Yang of China in the semifinals, hoping to continue their surprise run, and Chien vowed not to give in to fatigue.
"I'm very tired, but the whole point of coming out to play in a tournament is to not go home empty-handed," she said.

Lee also had a chance to reach a second semifinals in the men's doubles, but he and Fang Chieh-min, seeded sixth in the event, fell to second seeds Markis Kido and Hendra Setiawan of Indonesia 21-14, 21-14 in 31 minutes.
Taiwan's last two singles players still alive at the World Championships also were eliminated in the quarterfinals of their respective events Friday.

In men's singles, unseeded Hsueh Hsuan-yi shocked fourth-seeded Chen Jin of China by winning the first set, but was unable to maintain the momentum and eventually lost their quarterfinal encounter 22-24, 21-5, 21-13 in 64 minutes.
In women's singles, unseeded Cheng Shao-chieh fell to fourth-seeded Tine Baun of Denmark 21-18, 21-13 in 34 minutes.
Cheng won the Yonex Open Chinese Taipei 2010 in early August, and continued her good form with wins over the 14th and eighth seeds at the World Championships in Paris before succumbing to Baun.
Some 400 elite badminton players are competing at the 2010 World Badminton Championships, which will conclude on Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two tropical depressions likely to become typhoons: CWB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 17:11:41 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Unstable weather is expected over Taiwan in the next couple of days, when two tropical depressions in adjacent areas are likely to develop into typhoons, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Saturday.
The tropical depression located near the Japan-held Ryukyu Islands was moving north-northwest at 25 kph, while the other one near the South China Sea was stagnant, forecasters said.
The systems do not pose any direct threat to Taiwan for the time being, they added.
Meanwhile, another tropical depression was taking shape in waters southeast of Taiwan, which together with the other two depressions will form a large depression belt, forecasters said.
As the belt moves closer to Taiwan Sunday, chances of rain will significantly increase around the island, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan-made helmets impress French designer
DOC.DATELINE: 08/28/10 17:32:49 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A helmeted model at French designer Michel Klein's Taipei fashion show made it onto the front page of a local newspaper, which said the event presented a new breakthrough in fashion.
Following Taiwan-made Giant bikes, made-in-Taiwan motorcycle helmets could be the next item to lead Taiwan into the world of fashionable living, the paper said.
The following is an except from the paper's coverage of the subject: United Daily News:

Michel Klein praised the great variety of styles and designs of the helmets that Taiwanese motorcyclists wear. "Taiwan's safety helmets are the best product I have ever seen, " said the fashion designer while shopping at local helmet shop "MoTo."

In Paris, he said, it is considered "gauche" to drive a car but fashionable to ride a motorcycle. However, unlike in Taiwan, the prices of helmets in France are too high with too few options available, said Klein, who sells his designs to nearly 30 countries.

Encouraged by a successful fashion show at the "Taipei In Style" exhibition at the Nangang World Trade Center Aug. 27, Klein disclosed that he hopes to cooperate with the Taiwanese producer of the helmet he used in the show in an attempt to transform the Taiwan-made helmets into a stylish fashion accessory.
Tai Nung-chia, the 29-year-old owner of the MoTo helmet chain store, began the business when he was 23, and now has six outlets, each generating revenues of NT$14 million (US$438,000) a year.
Tai was one of Taiwan's pioneers of hand-painted helmets, finding success in treating the indispensable accessory for local motorcyclists as a canvas for painting.

Klein was not the only foreign professional attracted by the helmets at MoTo stores. Tai said a French racer had ordered a helmet with a painting after being impressed by the helmets displayed at one of his outlets.
In seven years, Tai has created nearly 40 exclusive designs for motorcycle helmets. Each of the designer items has an average price of NT$1,000.

Traffic police, however, are not big fans of Tai's creative helmets. Fang Ying- ning, head of the Taipei City traffic police department, said the police discourage riders from fooling around with their helmets out of safety concerns.

In a normal situation, traffic police normally ask riders who wear "strange helmets" to stop for safety checks, Fang said, stressing that there are regulations stipulating helmet safety standards. Helmets that have not passed safety tests and received certification are not allowed on the road. (Aug. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC to build thin-film solar cell plant in September
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 18:10:21 (By Chang Chien-chung, Hsu Hsian-hsin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, announced Saturday that work on its first thin film solar cell plant is expected to begin in September.

Rick Tsai, president of TSMC's new businesses division, said the new plant will focus on developing modules for copper indium gallium diselenide (CIGS) thin- film solar cells, after it entered the silicon solar cell sector by purchasing a 20 percent stake in Motech Industries Inc., Taiwan's biggest solar cell maker, in January.
Addressing the opening ceremony of a green job fair, Tsai also said machines and equipment will be installed in TSMC's LED research and development center and plant in Hsinchu beginning next month.
Construction on the plant began last March and mass production is expected in 2011.

TSMC has aggressively moved into the solar industry this year, not only becoming Motech's single largest shareholder, but also acquiring a 21-percent stake in U.S. solar photovoltaic company Stion in July to obtain thin-film solar cell technology.

Industry analysts believe that TSMC's main rival, United Microelectronics Corporation (UMC), is ahead of TSMC in the thin-film solar cell market, as UMC established its own thin-film solar cell company NexPower Technology Corp. in 2005. NexPower has already entered mass production.

"TSMC believes that its past experience in developing semiconductor businesses will help speed its growth in the green energy industry, " said Tsai, who previously served as president and chief executive officer of TSMC from 2005 to 2009.
Tsai said TSMC is expected to recruit at least 500 people to help develop its green energy businesses in the next 12 months.
Meanwhile, Sino-American Silicon Products Inc., Taiwan's top maker of wafers for solar cells, also said at the job fair that it will increase its workforce from 2,400 to 6,000, in five years.

Sino-American Chairman Lu Ming-kuang said the company's consolidated revenues grew 80 percent year-on-year in the first six months of this year and predicted full-year revenues would surpass NT$21 billion, growing to NT$60 billion to NT$65 billion in 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Retired airport workers being asked back to solve facility's woes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 18:15:46 (By S. F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Stung by a string of mishaps at Taiwan's main international airport, authorities there hope to bring back former airport workers to help give the facility a new lease on life, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Saturday.

CAA officials acknowledged, however, that it will not be an easy task to persuade them to return to work at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport because many took preferential early retirement packages to leave their jobs.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) ordered the CAA to hire back some of the best-performing retirees -- many of whom are still under 55 years of age and have good engineering and management savvy -- to help the airport cope with its current woes as it moves toward privatization, according to CAA officials.

The Taiwan's largest airport is slated to become a private airport company in November, and many airport workers have applied for early retirement out of concern of facing bleak prospects and a loss of benefits under the new regime.

To find the root cause of the many problems at the airport, including leaky restrooms, poor facilities, expensive food and staff misconduct, the MOTC has been holding meetings almost every day with officials from supervisory agencies.
Meanwhile, airport authorities are planning to recruit some 50 new staffers, mostly engineers, in September.

A Taoyuan Airport Improvement Task Force, set up in July by the MOTC, has described the three-decades old airport as being "very ill" and vowed to raise its current world ranking from 27th to the top 10 in three years.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the panel between July 23-27 at Taoyuan Airport's two terminals, passengers are mostly dissatisfied with 16 of the most important services at the airport, such as the high cost of food, the airport's surrounding landscape, defective luggage trolleys and unclear direction signs in the transit area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to allow indigenous self-government on trial basis: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 18:26:49 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the government will set up an autonomous area for indigenous people on a trial basis to gradually promote indigenous self-government.
Ma said he understands that indigenous people hope to enjoy self-government as soon as possible, but this is a difficult goal that should be achieved step by step.
"We need to create conditions, " Ma said when addressing a meeting for indigenous civic groups held in Taipei County.

He reiterated that the government's indigenous policy is based on four principles: respecting differences, upholding fairness and justice, promoting self-government, and allowing for autonomous development.

The president stressed that he only makes promises that he can fulfill. They include providing an additional 32,000 jobs for indigenous people between 2009 and 2012 and gradually increasing an indigenous development fund to NT$10 billion, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan organizes first green energy job fair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 18:46:00 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan held its first ever job fair for the green energy industry Saturday, another initiative in boosting the industry's share of the overall economy in coming years.

More than 200 local companies including AU Optronics Corp. (AUO), Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , Hiwin Technologies Corp. and Nanya Technology Corp., offered more than 10,000 related jobs at the fair.

Taiwan is widely considered to be one of the countries that have the strength to develop a viable green energy industry, Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said at a ceremony formally opening the one-day event.
"The green energy industry in Taiwan has the support of well-developed semiconductor, photonics, machinery, materials and electronics industries," he said.
"Taiwan aims to play a leading role globally in the field of green energy applications in the future."

In terms of its green technology capability, Taiwan ranks sixth globally and second in Asia, behind Japan, according to a survey released by the Lausanne- based Institute for Management Development (IMD) in July.
Taiwan is already the world's largest producer of energy-saving LED lights and has the second highest output value globally, according to the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Meanwhile, Taiwan is the world's fourth largest maker of solar cells, said Taipei-based 1111 Job Bank, which co-organized the one-day event.
In his address at the opening ceremony, Premier Wu Den-yih expressed hope that the green energy industry will become one of Taiwan's main economic powerhouses.

"We hope that the green energy industry will be a leading force behind Taiwan's economic growth in the future, " he said. "We also hope that industries with high efficiency and high value but with low carbon emissions will take root in Taiwan."
Taiwan's green energy industry will generate an output value of over NT$200 billion (US$6.3 billion) and create 20,000 job opportunities this year, the energy bureau said.
The output of the industry is expected to reach NT$1.16 trillion by 2015, the bureau estimated.
The job fair attracted a total of 16,000 job seekers, the job bank said.

An Aug. 23 poll by the job bank shows that 76 percent of local office workers intend to become "green collar" workers as many of them were bullish about the green energy industry's prospects and supporting environmental protection.

Huang Yong-sheng, a 27-year-old job seeker who majored in computer science, told the Central News Agency that he visited the fair because he saw the green energy industry as "a future trend and thus wanted to enter the field."

However, more than 55 percent of the poll's respondents considered the lack of proper government promotion or the lack of private investment to be one of the major hurdles for green energy development in Taiwan, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic groups call for reform as education conference opens
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 18:59:49 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Civic groups called for education reform on a wide range of issues, including attention on special education, a 12-year compulsory education system and deregulation on the sidelines of the National Education Conference in Taipei on Saturday.

The two-day conference at the National Central Library gathered officials, teachers and representatives of civic groups from across the country with the aim of formulating "an education policy that will pave the way for Taiwan's 'golden decade, '" according to Minister of Education Wu Ching-ji.

The conference, which was the first of its kind in 16 years, planned to discuss 10 central themes, including the education system in general, higher education, special education, faculty training, internationalized campuses and education, and lifelong learning.
Across from conference, civic groups gathered to highlight issues related to education.

"Taiwan's education problems will not be solved by a conference, especially one that excludes people who have been working at the front line of education and spend time with students and children every day, " Lu Jen, a professor at Ming Chuan University, told the media in a "civic education conference" that was called by more than a dozen civic organizations.
"Deregulation is key in Taiwan's education reform. Taiwan's food culture has prospered without the government holding a food conference. The same results can happen for education," Lu said.
He called for the government to "take its hands off" education and let institutions develop under a free market concept.

In his opening speech at the conference, President Ma Ying-jeou said there was still a lot of work to do in developing the education system, but added that "Taiwan must have done something right" to allow Taiwanese students to shine in international competitions and continue its impressive technological development.

Ma stated several priorities of his education policy, such as narrowing the financial gap between public and private institutions, increasing student exchanges and improving the quality of vocational education. He also highlighted the importance of making adjustments for Taiwan's low birth rate, which the Council for Economic Planning and Development has projected will be the lowest in the world this year.

Outside the conference, representatives from civic groups voiced their concerns. The implementation of a 12-year compulsory education system should be a priority because the high school enrollment system puts too much pressure on students, said Hsieh Kuo-ching, president of the National Alliance of Parents Organization.
The current compulsory education system, which has been in place since 1968, requires six years of elementary school and three years of junior high school.
"We demand a timetable for implementation, because the discussion of a 12-year compulsory education has been going on for more than a decade but nothing has been done," he said.

Kuo Hsin-mei, president of the Association for Learning Disability in Taiwan, said that special education needs have not been addressed by the government at all, which she said was obvious because there isn't a single agency under the Ministry of Education to handle special education issues.

Khoo Jih-perng, an associate professor at Taipei Municipal University of Education who represents an academic alliance calling for the passage of a bill on childhood education and child care, said Taiwan lacks a preschool education policy.

Khoo said Taiwan needs a policy that integrates education and social welfare resources to tackle the issue of working parents not having enough money for child care and preschool education, especially single-parent families.
Other representatives urged the government to increase the budget for lifelong learning and carry out teacher evaluation at all levels to ensure high-quality education for students.

The conference concludes Sunday. Education Minister Wu said that his ministry would incorporate the results of the conference and that it aimed to release an education white paper by the end of the year as a blueprint for future policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese troupe to stage musical 'Dogs' for strays
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 19:10:04 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese children's group will stage a self-created musical featuring performers in various dog costumes in September to help raise the public's awareness of stray animal protection, the troupe said Saturday.

If Kids Theater Company will put on the Chinese-language musical free of charge and outdoors in the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Sept. 4 and the central city of Taichung on Sept. 11, the troupe announced at an event in Taipei.
At the event, some members of the troupe unveiled part of the Chinese-language musical, attracting a crowd of parents and children to watch.
The musical tells a story of how a family dog is abandoned by its owner and meets other stray dogs on the street.
"We want to use this musical to show how happy dogs are when their owners love and care for them, " said Chao Tzu-chiang, the head of the troupe and the musical's writer.
The troupe first launched the production in 2002, but it has now expanded it with new elements.
The Taiwan Carrefour Cultural and Educational Foundation, which is sponsoring the musical performances, hopes that the performances will educate children about the plight of stray dogs.
"We hope to teach the future generation how to respect life through the musical, " Winson Wu, chief executive of the foundation, told the Central News Agency at the event.
The Taipei event also featured a number of booths that allowed the public to adopt strayed cats and dogs or encouraged them to make donations.
At the event, the foundation also awarded a winner out of 143 dogs in a talent show and the troupe offered it an opportunity to "act" in the musical.

DOC.HEADLINE: As society ages, local retail market sees shift
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 20:34:01 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The aging of Taiwan's society has sparked a fundamental change in the country's consumer market, with demand growing for nutritional supplements and functional daily devices that help senior citizens live more comfortably and conveniently.

According to leading department stores, vitamins and other supplements along with health care products have became increasingly popular in the capital city of Taipei, in line with the country's growing over-65 population.
Dayeh Takashimaya Department Store in the Tianmu commercial circle in suburban Taipei said its sales of products targeting senior consumers have grown steadily in recent years.

That growth has been particularly evident this year, the retailer said, citing statistics showing sales at a pharmacy in the department store between January and July growing 7-10 percent year-on-year, with vitamins and nutritional supplements accounting for 40-50 percent of total revenue.
Aside from nutritional supplements, there has also been growing interest in handy daily appliances catering to older consumers, Dayeh Takashimaya said.

The trend is not likely to fade anytime soon. The proportion of Taiwan's population aged 65 or over has gone from 8.62 percent in 2000 to 10.6 percent in 2009 and is expected to hit 14 percent by 2017, according to government statistics and estimates.
Also, the country's aging index -- the ratio of the over-65-year-old population to the population of people aged between 0-14 -- was the second highest in Asia in 2009, trailing only Japan.

Another major retailer in Taipei, Pacific Sogo Department Stores, said it has also felt the impact of the demographic changes. It said it plans to open more counters selling items catering to seniors because sales of such goods have demonstrated steady growth.
According to the department stores, the most popular items in the senior market are imported from Japan, whose society began aging 20-30 years earlier than Taiwan's.
The products range from rolling walkers and light and folding crutches to ultra- light walking shoes and necklaces with magnifying glasses attached.

The retailers predicted that commercial opportunities related to elderly consumers would become as ripe as those in Japan within three to five years and expected more products geared to this market to be introduced in Taiwan in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Designers launch 'love tomorrow today' movement in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 20:46:17 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of designers have opened an exhibition that encourages people to carry out the idea of carbon reduction by making innovative tools in their daily lives, a promoter of the exhibition said at a press conference Saturday.

A total of 30 innovative works made by 42 inventors, including 37 from Taiwan and five from the United States, will be demonstrated at the CMP Block in Taichung from Aug. 27-Sep. 26 on the first stop of the exhibition's tour around central and northern Taiwan, said Tony Chang, chief executive of the Taiwan Design Center.

Chang said the exhibition, entitled "Love Tomorrow Today, " originated in the United States with the aim of sharing the concept of creativity in life and implementing carbon reduction ideas with creative devices.

"This is the first time such a practical concept of environmental protection has been introduced to Taiwan, " he said. "By creating useful tools and optimizing natural resources today, we can envision a better life tomorrow."

Chang highlighted one of the displays -- a camping tent made of plastic bottles and bamboos. He said the tent is designed to encourage city residents to get outside and cherish the natural resources around them.

The exhibition will also be incorporated as a part of the 2010 Taiwan Design Expo in Taipei on Dec. 11-19, and make its final appearance in three international hotels in Taipei from Dec. 24 this year to Feb. 20, 2011.
"Love Tomorrow Today" is a volunteer action promoted online. Designers who are interested in the project can join it at http:// lovetomorrowtoday.com.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exercise therapy proven effective for cardiac patients: doctor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 21:29:43 (By Chen Ching-fang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Adequate exercise designed by professionals has proven effective in helping prevent cardiac patients from having a heart attack, with the fatality rate reduced by at least 25 percent, a doctor said Saturday.
Wei Jeng, director of the heart center at Cheng Hsin General Hospital, said exercise is not necessarily unsuitable for myocardial infarction or heart- transplant patients as most people think.

"A good exercise therapy program can reduce the risk factors for heart attack, " Wei said. "It not only can improve cardiovascular sclerosis, some patients even recovered so well that an operation was no longer needed, " he said at an event introducing the hospital's exercise therapy program.
Several cardiac patients also shared their experiences from the hospital's therapy program.

David Sun, often dubbed the "godfather" of Taiwan's advertising industry who has four heart stents, said he successfully completed a 1,668-kilometer bike journey in China within 20 days in May 2009 after receiving the hospital's therapy for months.
"Most of my friends thought it would be inconceivable for me, a cardiac patient, to take on such a journey that even normal people considered difficult," Sun recalled.

Sun Yueh, an award-winning actor-turned-volunteer who suffers from cardiovascular disease and was operated on for lung cancer a few years ago, said he was not even able to ride an indoor-training bike for one minute when he began the therapy.
"But within one month, I was able to ride for 24 minutes without stopping," said the 80-year-old Sun.

Jacob Jou, a 57-year-old professor at National Sun Yat-sen University, said that even though he suffered a serious heart attack in 2003, his health has greatly improved after taking part in a three-month heart therapy program at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung politicians push for local fruit to be part of trade deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 22:05:34 (By C. P. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Local opinion leaders from central Taiwan's Taichung area called Saturday for locally grown fruit to be among the items received preferential tariff treatment from China while meeting a visiting Chinese official.

Legislator Yen Chin-piao and Taichung County Council Speaker Chang Ching-tang issued the call during a banquet with Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, the Chinese body authorized to deal with Taiwan.
He is visiting Taiwan, however, in his capacity as deputy director of the Central Office of Taiwan Affairs of the Communist Party of China.

"Many Taichung farmers are very disappointed that their high-end products were not included on the first 'early harvest list, '" Chang told the Central News Agency, referring to the list of items receiving favorable tariff treatment under the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed with China in late June.
"Therefore, I immediately suggested to Zheng that the next round of ECFA talks discuss the inclusion of Taichung produced pears, lichees and loquats in the second 'early harvest list,'" Chang said.

Taichung County Councilwoman Yang Chiu-yun clamored for more frequent exchanges between Taichung harbor and the ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen in China's Fujian Province on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait.

"The strategic location of the Taichung Harbor allows it to play a pivotal role in cross-strait cargo and passenger travel, which in turn will also help boost prosperity and development in the greater Taichung area," she contended.

Taichung Airport also stands a much better chance of attracting more passengers based on the foundation laid by the ECFA, Yang said, urging the Chinese side to authorize more flights between Taichung and Xiamen.
Heading an eight-member delegation of Chinese officials, Zheng arrived in Taiwan Aug. 22 at the invitation of a KMT think tank.
Keeping a low profile on his trip, Zheng also visited the Kaohsiung and Tainan areas in southern Taiwan, where anti-China sentiment is high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cambodian girl with swollen arm arrives in Taiwan for operation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 22:22:39 (By Lee Chun-chin, Hau Hsue-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A two-year-old Cambodian girl suffering from massive swelling in her right arm arrived at Taichung Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) in central Taiwan Saturday for treatment.

Reachny Mich, whose condition has been described as having an "elephant arm, " was discovered by a Taiwanese medical team when it was in Cambodia in April to provide local residents free medical services.
She then obtained the promise of Taiwan government's to treat her after Yu Tsi- hsun, a volunteer on the medical team, made repeated appeals on her behalf.

Following the hospital's initial examination of the girl Saturday, pediatric hematologist Chang Teh-kao said Mich's blood pressure, heartbeat and body temperature all appeared normal, but he feared that her disorder was far more "complicated" than originally thought.
Chang said Mich's right arm appears to be four to five times bigger than her left arm, possibly caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels or bones.
"It is rare to see such a deformation of blood vessels, " he said.

Earlier in the day after the girl, her mother and Yu arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Yu said Mich's mother was worried about the operation facing her daughter but also trusted Taiwan's doctors and felt grateful for their help.
A special team of pediatricians from different departments convened by Lee San- kang, deputy superintendent of the hospital, has been assembled to perform the surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on Chinese investment to be eased gradually: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 22:31:23 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Restrictions on Chinese businesses investing in Taiwan will be eased gradually, a visiting Taiwanese official said Saturday.
Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said Taiwan's policy has been set to gradually open its door to Chinese investment.
"But considering Taiwan's environment, the opening will only take place step by step, Kao said.

Kao, who led the first delegation to visit China since the two countries signed an economic cooperation framework agreement in late June, made the remarks during a seminar with Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai.

Kao has visited Hangzhou, Jiaxing and Shanghai in recent days to spread the message that Chinese investment was welcomed in Taiwan, but Lu Xiaoyan, deputy head of the Shanghai Taiwanese Compatriots Invested Enterprise Association, said Taiwan has placed too many restrictions on Chinese investment.

He cited as an example Taiwan's ban on Chinese state-owned businesses from investing in Taiwan, but he said that in fact the only major Chinese businesses capable of investing overseas are state-owned firms.
Kao also expressed concerns to his counterpart, Li Yafei, vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, over the high airfares of direct cross-strait flights.

Taiwanese businessmen attending the seminar complained about what they described as the unreasonably high price of Taipei-Shanghai airfares, which they said could surge to between 7,000 Chinese yuan (US$1,030) and 8,000 Chinese yuan.
They expressed the hope the fare could be cut to around 3,500 yuan.
They also suggested that air carriers offer preferential airfares prior to the Nov. 27 municipality elections in Taiwan as an incentive for them to return home to vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cambodian girl with swollen arm arrives in Taiwan for operation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 22:22:39 (By Lee Chun-chin, Hau Hsue-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A two-year-old Cambodian girl suffering from massive swelling in her right arm arrived at Taichung Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) in central Taiwan Saturday for treatment.

Reachny Mich, whose condition has been described as having an "elephant arm, " was discovered by a Taiwanese medical team when it was in Cambodia in April to provide local residents free medical services.
She then obtained the promise of Taiwan government's to treat her after Yu Tsi- hsun, a volunteer on the medical team, made repeated appeals on her behalf.

Following the hospital's initial examination of the girl Saturday, pediatric hematologist Chang Teh-kao said Mich's blood pressure, heartbeat and body temperature all appeared normal, but he feared that her disorder was far more "complicated" than originally thought.
Chang said Mich's right arm appears to be four to five times bigger than her left arm, possibly caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels or bones.
"It is rare to see such a deformation of blood vessels, " he said.

Earlier in the day after the girl, her mother and Yu arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Yu said Mich's mother was worried about the operation facing her daughter but also trusted Taiwan's doctors and felt grateful for their help.
A special team of pediatricians from different departments convened by Lee San- kang, deputy superintendent of the hospital, has been assembled to perform the surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on Chinese investment to be eased gradually: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/28/10 22:31:23 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Restrictions on Chinese businesses investing in Taiwan will be eased gradually, a visiting Taiwanese official said Saturday.
Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said Taiwan's policy has been set to gradually open its door to Chinese investment.
"But considering Taiwan's environment, the opening will only take place step by step, Kao said.

Kao, who led the first delegation to visit China since the two countries signed an economic cooperation framework agreement in late June, made the remarks during a seminar with Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai.

Kao has visited Hangzhou, Jiaxing and Shanghai in recent days to spread the message that Chinese investment was welcomed in Taiwan, but Lu Xiaoyan, deputy head of the Shanghai Taiwanese Compatriots Invested Enterprise Association, said Taiwan has placed too many restrictions on Chinese investment.

He cited as an example Taiwan's ban on Chinese state-owned businesses from investing in Taiwan, but he said that in fact the only major Chinese businesses capable of investing overseas are state-owned firms.
Kao also expressed concerns to his counterpart, Li Yafei, vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, over the high airfares of direct cross-strait flights.

Taiwanese businessmen attending the seminar complained about what they described as the unreasonably high price of Taipei-Shanghai airfares, which they said could surge to between 7,000 Chinese yuan (US$1,030) and 8,000 Chinese yuan.
They expressed the hope the fare could be cut to around 3,500 yuan.
They also suggested that air carriers offer preferential airfares prior to the Nov. 27 municipality elections in Taiwan as an incentive for them to return home to vote.
