DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Lionrock expected to bring showers to Taiwan: CWB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 10:44:57 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Showers of rain were expected to hit Taiwan Sunday as a tropical depression in waters south of the Dongsha (Pratas) Islands in the South China Sea already strengthened into a tropical storm early that day, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
The storm Lionrock has been moving directly toward southeastern China since its formation at 2 a.m. Sunday and is not expected to cause any direct threat to Taiwan, CWB officials said.
Nevertheless, they urged mariners navigating or operating in the Taiwan Strait, Bashi Channel and waters south of China's Guangdong Province to exercise caution against rough seas and rogue waves.

Lionrock is the sixth typhoon in the Pacific region so far this year. With a maximum sustained wind of 64.8 kph, the storm was centered in seas some 170 kilometers south of the Dongsha Island at 2 a.m. Sunday, according to CWB meteorologists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quixotic lexicographer hangs tough

TEXT.P: Despite his slender and fragile body, Liu Yun-guo has a brave heart. At 79, he is keenly aware of and amused by the fact that his life is fatefully linked to English, English news-writing and Chinese-English dictionary compilation.
Although he has a string of degrees, titles and accomplishments behind his name, Liu, also known as David Hanson Liu, is absolutely self-deprecating.

To promote his dictionary -- the Chuan-shi (Heritage) Chinese-English Thesaurus, which he compiled single-handedly with 20 years of painstaking effort, but with no publisher willing to print it due to its huge size and possible lack of a market -- Liu peddles his 1,952-page tome on a Taipei street teeming with cram schools and students.
His sales schemes include buying one copy of the thesaurus and getting six free steamed buns, which he and his 66-year-old wife make at home, or buying 60 buns to get one free thesaurus.

Some friends have tried to dissuade him from selling his book on the street, saying it does not befit his social status and old age. His wife, who retired from a successful career at Bank of Taiwan, has also tried in vain to stop him.

"What status counts? It counts only when the book is sold and used, " said Liu, who brings to mind Wu Xun, a legendary Qing dynasty beggar who saved every penny he got from the streets to establish schools in order to provide youths with the education that he had craved but could never get.

The son of landlord parents in China's Shandong Province who were vilified after the Chinese communists came to the fore, Liu fled to Taiwan with the Kuomintang troops in 1949 as a boy soldier. A hard worker, he graduated from a military officer candidate school before being assigned as a military inspector, working under Gen. Sun Li-jen, then commander-in-chief of the Republic of China army.
It was at that time Liu developed his close relationship with English, using all his off-duty time and holidays to study the language.

One day, he became so angry with himself for lacking self-discipline and being easily distracted that he cut off his left little finger with a kitchen knife. With the blood from the severed finger, he scrawled on a piece of paper: "Yun-guo, shameful." He framed the blood scrawl and put it on his desk to serve as a reminder.
So great was his dedication to English that he decided to leave the military at the age of 26 and enter civilian life because he just wanted to study English full time.

He split his time between studying in the daytime and pedaling a pedicab at night to earn a living. While pedaling, he often retrieved his notebook from his pocket to memorize a new vocabulary word. On his way home at midnight, there would be few pedestrians on the streets and he would recite his lessons aloud while pedaling.

Eventually, he passed the hotly contested joint college examination and entered the prestigious National Chengchi University, where he was top scorer in his class for five semesters and second in his class for three.

Liu joined the English Department of the Central News Agency even before he graduated from university to work as an English reporter and assistant editor. However, his career there was brief, as a result of a short-lived and disturbing marriage and some unfounded accusations against him because he was a right-hand man of Sun, who was exiled to the United States by then-President Chiang Kai- shek for his involvement in an attempted coup.

He then worked at the Korean Embassy in Taiwan as an English secretary for a period before joining the English-language daily China Post, where he honed his skills as an English news reporter and made friends with many figures in Taipei' s foreign diplomatic corps, who in turn helped improve his English. He published his first English book, "English Writing and Reporting, " in 1976, dedicated to professors Charles and Elizabeth Clayton and to professor Paul Hung-chun Wang, who he said led his way into journalism.

Robert J. Clarke, the then-director of the U.S. Information Service in Taiwan, wrote in a foreward for the book that Liu had written a book intended to explain the workings of his controversial profession and had succeeded in producing a volume that should be useful not only to the beginning journalist but should serve as a continuingly valuable reference work for those already in the trade.

That volume was followed by another book, titled "Liu's Thesaurus of Commonly Used English Expressions, " an 800-page production published in 1976 that was the precursor of the ambitious "Chuan-shi Chinese-English Thesaurus."

He opened his own translation company a few years later as an expansion of his keen interest in English writing and translation, which later culminated in his quixotic compilation of the giant Chinese-English thesaurus.

Throughout his career, Liu was always troubled by the lack of usable Chinese- English dictionaries. "None of them, including one compiled by Lin Yutang, could solve my writing or translating problems because their entries were neither graceful nor standard English, " he said. Lin is considered to be one of the best writers and translators in contemporary Chinese history.

In an attempt to address that deficiency and promote the use of graceful and precise English, Liu spent 20 years reading English and American sinologists' translations and writings, as well as international news agency dispatches.
"Only Chinese speakers proficient in English can differentiate the graceful and precise renderings from those which are not, " he said.

On former Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu's recent accusation of "the intolerant humiliation" of Taiwanese students who lag so far behind their Japanese and Korean counterparts in English proficiency as rated by an international organization, Liu said he wonders how Chu would comment if he was aware of the sheer number of glaring errors made in the official English-language websites of the government, leading Taiwanese companies and universities in Taiwan.

The most recent -- a slogan devised by the National Immigration Agency -- is a case in point. "NIA -- We care what you care" has already been lambasted by native English speakers for its complete lack of grammar, meaning or punch.
An old dog now, Liu's wish to help raise the English proficiency level of the Taiwanese public via his book remains strong.

"I will devote my old bones to do anything toward that goal. The buns-for-books drive on the street? It's nothing, if only the thesaurus can be distributed," the Taiwan Don Quixote said. By CNA staff writer Deborah Kuo/J
CNA photos 10,11,12

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Scandalous cram school culture
DOC.DATELINE: 08/29/10 13:48:30 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: While the soap opera-like conflict between two Taipei cram schools continues to steal headlines, another scandal has erupted at a third cram school, which allegedly bribed a data systems engineer to tamper with the scores of takers of major national exams.

Tung Shang-teh, an IT engineer at the National Vocational School Entrance Examination Center, has recently been charged by prosecutors for taking bribes worth some NT$4.25 million from the cram school to inflate the scores of some test takers on their vocational school entrance exams.

These cram school scandals were all results of money and greed. Running cram schools in Taiwan has been a thriving and lucrative business because of the country's questionable education policy. This business has also created a colosseum where people kill each other because of greed.

Cram schools have technically become part of Taiwanese students' daily life. The government should waste no time to regulate this sector and avoid labeling cram schools as "supplementary, " "temporary" or "short-term" any longer. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- First lady embarks on 'social welfare' mission

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching will depart for Haiti later Sunday to see for herself the situation in the Caribbean nation after it was devastated by a deadly magnitude-7.3 earthquake Jan. 12 that claimed more than 300,000 lives and displaced at least 1.5 million people.

Describing the trip as a "journey of care and concern," Chow will visit Haiti in her capacity as honorary president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and as a "Love Ambassador" for World Vision Taiwan (WVT) -- a Christian charity. She will be accompanied by her daughter, Lesley Ma, on the trip.

Chow has typically kept a low profile ahead of her overseas trip that will also take her to the Dominican Republic, another of Taiwan's diplomatic allies. Only the United Daily News carried a front-page report on her Haitian visit Sunday.

Meanwhile, the Liberty Times quoted a Wall Street Journal report as characterizing 2010 as the "year of Taiwanese athletic dominance" after a number of its baseball teams and individual athletes made their mark.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the topics:
United Daily News:

Chow has taken part in social welfare and post-disaster relief activities in collaboration with local charities or social welfare groups in the past couple of years. The Haitian trip will mark the first time that she has visited a diplomatic ally of Taiwan on her own and not in the company of her husband.
Instead of engaging in diplomacy, Chow will focus on visiting Haitian children orphaned or displaced by the devastating earthquake, a WVT spokesman said.

Her itinerary in Haiti will include meetings with orphans in Petionville and Port-au-Prince as well as visits to a makeshift tent camp in Delmas. She will also visit a Food For the Poor center to see first-hand the distribution of rice donations from Taiwan. Taiwan has donated more than 400 tons of rice to Haiti since January.

Taiwan's government and people have launched many aid projects to help get Haitian quake survivors back on track. WVT alone received NT$150 million (US$4.69 million) from Taiwanese citizens for post-disaster rehabilitation projects in Haiti.
After her visit in Haiti, Chow will make a brief two-day stopover in the Dominican Republic, where she will visit a job training center, two primary schools, and a health center.

During the trip, Chow will meet six children whom she and the president are sponsoring in both countries, according to the WVT. She will bring gifts, including story books, coloring books and ceramic flutes. The first lady is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Sept. 5. (Aug. 29, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Several outstanding Taiwanese athletes have made their mark on the sports scene this year, from golfer Yani Tseng winning two of the year's four majors in women's golf and Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo Hong-chih compiling a 1.37 earned-run average -- the best of any player with at least 40 innings pitched in the National League -- to Jeremy Lin becoming the first Taiwanese-American player to sign with an NBA team.
Their achievements attracted the attention of the Wall Street Journal, which ran an online article "Can Taiwan Keep the Streak Alive? "Saturday on the developments.

But these athletes tend to rely on their own efforts to stand out in the sports world. The Sports Affairs Council, as the country's top sports administrative agency, should do more to cultivate talent to help enhance Taiwan's visibility on the world stage amid the country's diplomatic isolation imposed by China. (Aug. 29, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Purchasing controversies dampen Taipei mayor's popularity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 15:24:10 (By Chen Hung-chin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin admitted Sunday that problems with procurement contracts handled by the city's government have dampened his popularity and clouded his bid for a second term.
"It is without a doubt a crisis, " admitted Hau, who said he had briefed President Ma Ying-jeou and Kuomintang Secretary-General King Pu-tsung on the problems and their political fallout.
He quoted King as urging him to solve the problems as soon as possible.

The Apple Daily reported that Hau, who has enjoyed a narrow lead over Democratic Progress Party (DPP) rival Su Tseng-chang in the polls since Su declared his candidacy for the Nov. 27 mayoral election in March, lagged 1.56 percent behind Su in the paper's latest survey.
In the poll carried out Saturday among 770 adults aged 20 or older, Su received 44.68 percent support from respondents compared to 43.12 percent for Hau.
The paper also said that more than 60 percent of respondents believed the controversial city contracts to improve the city's Xinsheng Overpass will cost Hau support in the election.
The controversies arose Aug. 19 and Aug. 20, with two opposition councilors charging separately that the contracted price for flowers to embellish the elevated highway was unreasonable high.
Another two city councilors charged on Aug. 27 that water pipes contracted for the overpass were bought a price 10 times as high as the market price.

The mayor replaced officials at the center of the controversies and ordered a thorough investigation into the allegations Aug. 27 but it came too late to stop the immediate damage to Hau's popularity.
In a separate poll conducted Saturday by cable news station TVBS, Hau still enjoyed a slim lead over Su, 51 percent to 49 percent.
Su, whose DPP has generally lagged behind the ruling Kuomintang in the capital, said the gaps were the narrowest ever seen between any DPP candidate and his or her KMT rival in Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local travel agent pushes for upgrade in medical tourism sector
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 16:16:52 (by Kuo Mei-lan and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of a local travel agency suggested Sunday that Taiwan make a more concerted effort to enhance the appeal of its medical tourism sector, especially as interest in visiting Taiwan for medical checkups is growing among Chinese nationals.

Jeff Chu, chairman of Grand Travel Inc., said the combination of sightseeing and getting a checkup or other procedures done in Taiwan is very appealing to many Chinese because Taiwan offers high-quality health care at a relatively low cost.

At present, however, only a limited number of the more than 1 million Chinese who visit Taiwan annually can receive medical services in Taiwan because of visa and itinerary limitations, and Chu urged China's government to issue medical visas to citizens who would like to get treatment or checkups in Taiwan.
He also recommended that Taiwan's medical institutions, health evaluation centers and spas work together to develop a new, integrated travel option for overseas visitors.
Special customized tours, for example, could be arranged for people interested in getting beauty and massage treatments and having micro-plastic surgery done, he suggested.
Customized services can also be arranged to cater to the needs of individuals, such as people accompanying major trauma patients, who need to stay in Taiwan for a longer period of time, Chu said.

While Taiwan is celebrated for its beautiful scenery, cuisine, and friendly people, its medical technology is also on a par with international standards, making it an ideal medical tourism destination, he said.

Medical tourism accounted for US$7.7 billion of the world's US$200 billion medical market in 2005, and the Executive Yuan has listed medical services as one of its core development industries in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy economic minister to visit India to promote trade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 17:32:34 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou is scheduled to lead a delegation of top executives on a trip to India early next month as part of the government's efforts to help local companies tap into the Indian market.

The delegation, to include representatives from the electronics, machinery, information technology, injection molding equipment and auto parts and components sectors, will attend the opening of an annual Taiwan trade fair to be held in the southern India city of Chennai, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said.
Hwang will also attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a Taiwan-funded industrial park in Chennai, the fifth most populous city in India and the main air gateway to southern India.

"The Chennai park is the first factory complex invested in by Taiwanese companies in India, " the official familiar with the affair said, adding that the park will mainly house small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) in non- high-tech industries, such as footwear and textiles.

Meanwhile, the official said, the ministry has decided to set up shops at two major international airports in New Delhi and Mumbai and five shopping malls in India to sell premium-quality or internationally renowned brand-name goods from Taiwan.

Besides inviting popular Indian Bollywood star Lara Dutta to help promote the Taiwan Excellence Award-winning products, the MOEA will also collaborate with noted Indian retailer Croma in operating stores exclusively showcasing and retailing top-quality goods from Taiwan.
The delegation to be headed by Huang is scheduled to depart for India Sept. 8, the official said.
Wu Wen-ya, vice chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, will lead a separate group of industry executives to the upcoming annual trade fair, dubbed "TAITRONICS 2010, " in Chennai.

Since Taiwan signed an economic cooperation framework agreement with China in June, the MOEA has singled out India and Indonesia as the two key target markets for premium Taiwanese goods, the official said.
As part of this drive, he said, Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang will lead a market promotion group to Indonesia in late September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese badminton players fall in semis at World Championships
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/10 17:46:38 (Lo Yuan-shao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two doubles teams still alive at the 2010 Badminton World Championships were denied spots in the finals of their respective events Saturday, falling victim to higher ranked Chinese opponents and fatigue.
On a day when players from China secured eight of the 10 spots in the finals of the World Championships' five events, Taiwan's mixed doubles and women's doubles teams were unable to resist the surge.

Taiwan's Lee Sheng-mu and Chien Yu-chin, having already outperformed their status as the 16th seeds in the mixed doubles event, succumbed to sixth-seeds He Hanbin and Yu Yang of China, 21-13, 21-8, in 29 minutes.
Later in the day, Chien and Cheng Wen-hsing, seeded third in the women's doubles, were knocked out by second seeds Du Jing and Yu Yang of China, 21-16, 21-15, in 33 minutes.
The Chinese duo's quickness and precision shotmaking were the difference in a match that often had the Taiwanese on the defensive.

Chien, who admitted to being tired Friday after reaching the semifinals in both the women's and mixed doubles, said after Saturday's matches that she had run out of gas, her energy particularly sapped by three three-set matches in the mixed doubles earlier in the week.
She did not feel that her Chinese rivals in the women's doubles were as difficult to play as expected, but she praised them for consistently playing shots to really good spots on court.
Cheng said she enjoyed the tournament and was generally satisfied with her team's bronze medal finish, but she admitted that she needed to improve her serve in the future.
China's Yu said her team's match against Cheng and Chien was "a real struggle" at certain points in the encounter.
But after having a poor run of form since the duo won the women's doubles gold medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Yu said she and Du were determined to win and shake off their recent doldrums.
The players on Taiwan's mixed doubles and women's doubles teams will receive bronze medals for making it to the semifinals.
The five finals, in men's and women's singles, men's and women's doubles, and mixed doubles will be contested Sunday in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sex-selective practices to have male babies illegal: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 17:59:09 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Medical institutions that take measures to ensure that women will have a male offspring is illegal and will result in fines or the voiding of doctors' licenses to practice medicine, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Sunday.
A DOH working group will be established soon to investigate such illegal practices at health institutions around the country, said Chiou Shu-ti, director-general the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion.
The DOH investigators will regularly visit clinics and hospitals to probe whether the gender of the babies born in their facilities are skewed toward males, Chiou said.
As in China, Taiwan has a bias in favor of male offspring because of the deeply rooted preferences for sons in Chinese societies.

Meanwhile, Chiou said, the DOH will keep an eye on clinics and hospitals' usage of the sex-detection reagent PCR and supplies of the reagent by biotechnology firms, which are cashing in on a gray area involving the enzyme's production and supply.
"Relevant regulations will also be worked out by the DOH to more tightly clamp down on illegal gender control of newborns," she said.

At present, advertising "precise" gender detection services for pregnant women who want to know the gender of their babies is illegal, subject to fines of up to NT$250,000 (US$7,813) based on the Medical Care Act, she noted.
Ob-gyn doctors who conduct sex-selective abortions are subject to fines up to NT$500,000, and serious violators could have their medical licenses suspended.
Based on the Medical Care Act, clinics and hospitals can have their operations suspended or be deprived of their licenses in the event of such illegal practices, Chiou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Draft cross-strait education ECFA ready for MAC review
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 18:28:29 (By Lin Szu-yu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A cross-strait education cooperation framework agreement, better known as the Education ECFA, has been drafted and referred to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for review, Deputy Education Minister Lin Tsong-ming said Sunday.

There is no timetable, however, for the signing of the pact, which would be an open-ended agreement whose contents and details could be reviewed periodically, Lin said during the National Education Conference, which opened in Taipei Saturday.

Chou Yi-shun, executive secretary of the Education Ministry's Mainland Affairs Task Force, said the draft has been ready since last year, but it still has to be incorporated into the overall planning of the MAC and Taiwan's intermediary body, the Straits Exchange Foundation, before it can enter the negotiating stage with China.
Currently, Taiwan caps the number of Chinese students coming to Taiwan for academic studies at 1,000 per year, but the actual number has reached around 200 a year so far, Chou said.
"The ceiling can be adjusted in the future," he added.

Also speaking at the conference, former Education Minister Yang Chao-shiang said the government should pay greater attention to the needs of Taiwanese students who travel across the strait to study in China.

He cited the case of one Taiwanese student who was caught in a bind after falling sick and needed an operation at midnight. The student's friends were forced to ask a Taiwanese businessman for money to pay the hospital a guarantee to make the operation possible.
Chou responded that such concerns would be addressed in Education ECFA talks in the future.

Wu Ching-shan, director of the National Academy for Educational Research Preparatory Office, said the two sides should clinch the Education ECFA as soon as possible to help systematize and institutionalize educational exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
He also suggested that plans for reciprocal visits by the two sides' education officials should be made to help enhance the decision making process.

On another discussion on academic organizations across the Taiwan Strait cooperating in establishing schools, Lin said Taiwan will closely monitor how funds flow between the two sides for that purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huayen Globalization Forum to be held in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 19:34:25 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Huayen Forum of Globalization and the Seventh General Conference of World Buddhist Sangha Youth (WBSY) will take place Sep. 4-6 at the Sansia campus of National Taipei University, the organizers said Sunday.

The events, to be organized by the Da Huayen Monastery and the Huayen Buddhist Community, will address the topic "Globalization in Buddhism: Ecological Sustainability of Nature and Comprehensive Harmony" to highlight the increasing concerns over balancing human life with the natural environment.

Other topics to be discussed during the forum will include Buddhist practices and richness of mind in the New Era, the dialogue and collaboration between globalization and environmental protection efforts, Buddhist culture and human core values, and the dialogue between Buddhism and other religions.

Master Hai Yun Jimeng, who heads the Da Huayen Monastery and the Huayen Buddhist Community, took the initiative in organizing the forum in the hope of bringing together the resources of Buddhists around the world to help promote environmental protection, a harmonious society and intelligent exploration.

The forum is aimed at applying Buddhism to strengthen universal values and ethics and reach a "comprehensive harmony" in relations among peoples, between people and nature and their families, and within themselves.

Min Bahadur Shakya, founder of the Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods in Nepal, Dr. Harsha Kumar Navaratne, president of the SEWA LANKA Foundation in Sri Lanka, and many other Buddhist heavyweights from around the world will take part in the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meteorologists warn of heavy rain as tropical storm forms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 19:47:43 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Heavy rain will hit Taiwan in the next few days now that a low pressure system in waters east of Taiwan and south of the Japan-held Ryukyu Islands has strengthened into a tropical depression, the Central Weather Bureau said.
The depression has been moving slowly in a north-northwest direction and may continue gathering strength to become a typhoon, the bureau said in a statement.
It said another tropical depression in waters south of the Dongsha (Pratas) Islands in the South China Sea had strengthened into a tropical storm at 2 a.m. Sunday.
Influenced by the two weather systems, the island will experience unstable weather in the coming days, bureau meteorologists said.
Some parts of Taiwan may even be hit by torrential rains, the bureau warned, and it urged residents in low-lying and mountainous regions to remain vigilant against flooding and mudslides.

The bureau noted, however, that the tropical storm, named "Lionrock, " has been heading directly toward southeast China since its formation early Sunday and is not expected to cause a direct threat to Taiwan.
Still, vessels navigating or operating in the Taiwan Strait, Bashi Channel and waters south of China's Guangdong Province should exercise caution against rough seas and rogue waves, the bureau said.

Lionrock is the sixth tropical storm in the Pacific region so far this year. With maximum sustained winds of 64.8 kilometers per hour, the storm was centered in seas some 170 kilometers south of the Dongsha Islands at 2 a.m. Sunday, according to bureau meteorologists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan suffers heartbreaking loss in Little League World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Williamsport, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/10 20:18:38 (by Hsiao Pao-hsiang, Liu Kun-yuen and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Just two outs away from advancing to the Little League World Series title game, Taiwan's Fu-Hsing Little League team from Kaohsiung crumbled and lost to Japan 3-2 in extra innings in the international final Saturday to end its championship hopes.

Entering the bottom of the sixth and final inning in regulation play with a 2-1 lead and star pitcher Huang Shao-fei, who had not yielded a hit to the Japanese in 4 2/3 innings, on the mound, victory seemed within Taiwan's grasp.

But Huang yielded a single to Koutaro Kamikura to lead off the inning, and then with one man out, catcher Shih Hsun-hao threw the ball past the first baseman on an ill-advised pickoff throw, sending Kamikura to second.
That allowed Kamikura to score on a line drive single to center by Ryota Norimatsu, which tied the game and shattered Taiwan's morale.

Then in the bottom of the seventh, Japan benefited from a wild pitch by Huang that advanced pinch-runner Ryusuke Ikeda and left him in position to score the winning run on Ryo Motegi's bouncer up the middle, which found its way under the glove of Taiwan's shortstop.
Taiwan's manager Ho Tung-yo said the mistakes contributing to the gut-wrenching defeat came from pressure.

"What I worried about most happened, " he said. "As soon as Japan got a hit to lead off the sixth, the kids got nervous and started making mistakes. In a game that's so even, whoever makes mistakes is less likely to win."
Ho, who felt Taiwan was subpar in all phases of the game, also felt the players were adversely affected by a supporting crowd.
"I warned them to ignore the crowd, but when they heard the crowd cheering for a home run, they started overswinging," Ho lamented.
Left-handed pitcher Wu Li Yung-heng admitted as much. "A lot of players concentrated on the crowd rather than on the field," he said.
But catcher Shih Hsun-hao made no excuses, describing the team's performance as "terrible." "Our opponent wasn't really that strong. We lost the game ourselves."

Taiwan had not won a Little League World Series since 1996 after winning 17 between 1969 and 1996, but after outscoring opponents 92-1 in Asia-Pacific qualifying and its first three World Series games in Williamsport, hopes were high that the title-less streak would finally come to an end this year.
Japan took a 1-0 lead in the first off of a nervous Chen Wei-chih, but Huang came in with one out and a runner on third and shut out Japan until the fateful sixth inning.
Taiwan scored its two runs in the top of the second on three hits, a walk and a wild pitch. But the team would only have one more hit the rest of the game, allowing Japan to stay close.

Despite the defeat, a group of fans who drove four hours every day to Williamsport from Washington, D.C. expressed their pride in the team and prepared 14 red envelopes, with US$100 dollars in each, for the 12 team members, the coach, and trainer Hsu Shao-lun.
Chinese Taipei will face Texas in the consolation game at 11 p.m. on Aug. 29 Taiwan time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei wins 1 silver and 4 bronze medals at Asia Junior Games
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 20:35:40 (by Chang Fang-ming and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei won one silver and three bronze medals in judo and a bronze medal in badminton at the three-day Asia Junior Sports Exchange Games that concluded in Tokyo on Sunday.
Taiwan's team from Taipei, along with teams from 15 other Asian cities, competed for titles in the two sports.

In the team badminton event, where teams played five matches against each other (one each men's and women's single, men's and women's double, and mixed doubles) , Taipei swept through the preliminary round with 5-0 whitewashings of defending champion Jakarta and Yangon.
But it lost to Kuala Lumpur 3-1 in the semifinals before defeating South Korea 3-1 for the bronze medal after winning the men's and women's doubles and men's singles.

Although Taipei failed to capture a medal in the judo team event, Kuo Yi-ting from Taipei Datong High School won a silver medal in the women's under 70kg class and three students from Taipei Dali High School won bronze medals in the men's under 60kg, under 66kg, and open weight classes, respectively.

For most of the athletes from Taipei, the event was their first opportunity to compete abroad, and the team's coaches were positive about the athletes' performance and said had they gained valuable experience from the trip.

The three-day Games, hosted by Tokyo Sports Benefits Corporation, drew teams from 16 Asian cities: Bangkok, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Yangon, Ulan Bator, Hong Kong, Macau, Astana, Vientiane, and Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: President delighted to open sports center in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 20:46:53 (Lin Shen-hsu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou presided over the opening of a sports center in Taipei's Wenshan District Sunday and said he felt delighted that each of the city's 12 districts now had at least one multipurpose sports facility.

"I am really happy that the plan, started by me with the building of the city's first sports center in Zhongshan District, was completed by Mayor Hau with the dedication of the Wenshan Sports Center," said Ma, who served as Taipei's mayor from late 1998 to late 2006.
Ma built six sports centers during his eight-year term, while his successor, Hau Lung-bin, completed the other six.

The president, who is himself an enthusiastic jogger, said many people didn't exercise because of the scarcity of exercise facilities in the city, or because of the long distances they had to travel to get to such facilities.
That is no longer the case in Taipei, he said. "It is the government's job to provide people with exercise places that are easily accessible and affordable.

"I hope the sports centers, like EasyCards, will become one of the administration's most popular policies, " Ma said, referring to the stored-value cards used mainly to pay mass transit system fares and bus fares.

Ma said his administration has pushed hard to boost the number of people in Taiwan who exercise regularly, which now stands at 24.4 percent of the population, with a high proportion of them in Taipei.

To support the initiative to make exercise a lifestyle, Ma's government plans to build 50 sports centers around the island, with 14 of them, evenly distributed around northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan, already in the planning stages.
Citing a plan drawn up by the Sports Affairs Council, the president said only cities with a population of more than 150,000 could apply for grant from the council to build sports centers.
"As a trailblazer in this regard, Taipei may share its experience with other cities."

The Wenshan Sports Center is a seven-storey building with a floor space of 12,500 square meters. It consists of a swimming pool, a gym, several dancing classrooms, badminton courts, table tennis tables, one basketball court and an indoor rock-climbing gym.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady departs on humanitarian mission to the Caribbean
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 20:53:34 (By Pien Chin-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching departed Sunday for a two-leg humanitarian trip that will take her to Haiti and the Dominican Republic to show concern for disadvantaged people in the two Caribbean nations.
Chow is visiting the two Caribbean allies as honorary president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and as a "Love Ambassador" of World Vision Taiwan (WVT), a Christian charity.
The five-day trip, described as a "journey of care and concern, " marks the first time that Chow has visited diplomatic allies of Taiwan on her own and not in the company of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Chow looked very happy when she arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the company of her eldest daughter, Lesley Ma. The pair typically kept a low profile and completed check-in procedures by themselves.
It was the first time they have joined together to engage in Taiwan's "social welfare" diplomacy.

WVT National Director Hank Du, who is accompanying the mother-daughter duo on the two-leg Caribbean tour, said they are bringing with them the love and concern of the people of Taiwan to disadvantaged people there.

During her visit in Haiti, Chow will meet with children orphaned in a deadly magnitude-7.3 earthquake that rattled the country Jan. 12 as well as visit tent camps built by World Vision Taiwan in Port-au-Prince and Delmas in the wake of the temblor.
She will also visit a Food For the Poor center to see first-hand the distribution of rice donations from Taiwan, which has donated more than 400 tons of rice to Haiti since January.
Also on her Haiti itinerary is a visit to an orphanage built by the ROC Red Cross Society.
In addition, Chow will meet with six children whom she and President Ma are sponsoring in both Haiti and the Dominican Republic, as well as their family members.
Du said Chow is bringing with her a collection of gifts, including story books, illustrated books, small giftwares and ocarinas, to disseminate love, concern and friendship during the trip.
Chow originally planned to visit Haiti in May, but was forced to cancel the travel plan after sustaining a waist injury, Du said.
As soon as she recovered, he added, she immediately expressed her wish to visit the quake-hit country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ophthalmologist helps cataract patients in Honduras
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/10 21:09:41 (By Sunrise Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An ophthalmologist from Cardinal Tien Hospital in Sindian in Taipei County successfully treated 42 cataract patients in Honduras during his two-week mission to the Central American ally early this month.

Yang Hsi-ming, director of the Ophthalmology Department of Cardinal Tien Hospital, said Sunday that he arrived in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa on Aug. 1 on a medical aid mission sponsored by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund.
"Ophthalmologists are much-needed in that country, which has only 75 ophthalmologists for a population of 7 million people, " Yang said in his office at Cardinal Tien Hospital.
"I had to treat about 500 patients a day. The clinic was overcrowded with people seeking treatment, and police had to be called in to maintain order," Yang said.
Due to the prevalence of diabetes and the scarcity of ophthalmologists in that country, cataracts are common in Honduras, and many patients end up losing their vision, Yang said.
A cataract is a clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye and obstructs the passage of light. It progresses slowly to cause vision loss and is potentially blinding if untreated.

A three-second surgical procedure that can cure the disease is not widely available in Honduras, Yang said, recalling that a young woman who was completely blinded by the disease regained 0.6 vision in one of her eyes the day after she was operated on.

During his two-week stay in Tegucigalpa, Yang operated successfully on 42 cataract patients, and he checked each of them again after their operations to ensure that they were recovering well before returning home.

Noting that he could only help a small portion of the cataract patients in that country, Yang said it would be better to improve the country's public health and people's diets there to prevent the disease.
It was Yang's first mission to Honduras, but the third run by the International Cooperation and Development Fund since launching an annual medical aid mission to the Central American country in 2008.
A total of eight doctors in various fields participated in this year's mission, offering health care services at different hospitals around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 30, or the 21st day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

Taiwan shares open higher

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Yang's 'no-longer-hostile' observation
DOC.DATELINE: After quitting the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 08/30/10 10:34:11 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: to run as an independent, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said recently that current cross-strait relations are no longer a "relationship of hostility."
As a former DPP heavyweight, Yang's espousal could be the greatest possible common ground for the development of cross-strait relations as well as politics within Taiwan.
Even the DPP, which now brands Yang a "traitor, " would not openly suggest that Taiwan should remain hostile toward China.

The DPP's Achilles' heel is its pro-independence ideology. "No unification" or "temporarily no unification" -- as suggested by President Ma Ying-jeou for the development of cross-strait relations -- will both contribute to peace in the strait. Insisting on Taiwan independence, however, leaves just one path to take: remaining hostile to China.

The DPP has until now not forsaken its Taiwan independence proposition. It not only brought Taiwan's cross-strait relations and political relations within Taiwan to a level of "hostility" during the DPP's eight-year rule, but the party itself has also been constrained by its pro-independence and anti-China ideology.

We probably cannot unify with China, now or ever, but maintaining peace with China is imperative. Only through a "peaceful development" process can peace eventually prevail across the strait. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 30, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--U.S. concerned about retired generals' China visit

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China Times prominently reported Monday that frequent visits to China by retired Taiwanese generals in the past two years have caused U.S. concern.
The U.S. government has reportedly asked the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to explain its stance on such visits.
The following is an excerpt from the daily's coverage of the development:
China Times:

Jason Yuan, Taiwan's representative in Washington, D.C., has reportedly told relevant government authorities about the U.S. concern over the high frequency and high level of interaction between retired Taiwanese generals and Chinese military authorities in recent years.

The United States has maintained close military cooperation with Taiwan for decades. It has typically briefed Taiwan on the itinerary and main purposes before its senior military officers depart for visits to China. The U.S. government has reportedly asked Taiwan to follow suit by giving briefings on retired generals' visits to and interaction with China.

Sources familiar with the affair said former National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi had reminded the Ministry of National Defense on many occasions of the U.S. concern. As Taiwan's law does not impose any restrictions on such visits, the ministry can only collect information about retired generals' China travel plans and report it to superior authorities.

When Hsu Li-nung, a former chief of the General Political Warfare Department under the ministry, led a group of retired senior generals to Beijing for a high-profile visit in April, he said one of the event's primary purposes was to promote the establishment of a military confidence-building mechanism.

His remarks drew much concern from U.S. authorities. Even scholars at the Washington-based think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies had repeatedly inquired during their Taipei visits about the possibility of Taiwan and China forging a military mechanism without U.S. participation.

Ministry officials have assured U.S. think tank researchers that cross-strait dialogue and engagements will continue to focus on economic issues and will not expand to political and security subjects in the near future.

Major alumni clubs formed by retired generals have often expressed hopes to receive government authorization to develop ties with Chinese military authorities. The Ma administration has adamantly rejected such requests, however, and declined to give any financial aid for their China visits as it believes that the time is not yet ripe for Taiwan to forge a political or military mechanism with China, security sources have said. (Aug. 30, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: The Liberty Times: Challenges lurk in growth figures
DOC.DATELINE: 08/30/10 12:35:14 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite brilliant growth figures reported over the past two months, Taiwan's economic outlook is probably no longer so optimistic. However, President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has apparently not become aware of the potential challenges that Taiwan is facing.
Taiwan's economy heated up in July as the job market gained some momentum, but leading economic indicators for the month dipped, marking the eighth consecutive monthly decline.

Economic growth is expected to slow in the second half of the year as a result of declines in the leading economic indicators in China, the United States and Europe -- the major markets of heavily export-reliant Taiwan.

The HSBC Chinese Purchasing Managers' Index dropped to a new low of 49.4 percent in July, indicating that China's manufacturing sector -- the prime mover behind that nation's economic growth -- has sagged. As the U.S. unemployment rate has persisted at around 10 percent, Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Krugman has said the American economy will not recover for a long time, while the EU economies remain stuck in a debt quagmire.

Ignorant and inattentive, how will the Ma administration be able to lead the Taiwanese people across the bridge over troubled waters? It might manage to cover its inefficiency when the winds are blowing favorably, but once global adversities set in again, Taiwan is not going to be spared. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 30, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Fu-Hsing settles for third in Little League World Series
DOC.DATELINE: Williamsport, Pennsylvania, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/30/10 12:46:24 (By Jorge Liu, Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A tough loss to Japan on Saturday didn't keep Taiwan's Fu-Hsing Little League team from battering Texas 14-2 in the consolation game Sunday.
The team from Kaohsiung came out swinging and stunned Texas with nine quick runs in the top of the first inning to create a deficit from which the Texans never recovered.

At a press conference after the game was ended on the mercy rule, reporters asked Fu-Hsing's players why their performance seemed so much better than in the previous day's 3-2 loss to Japan. Several of the players reportedly answered straightforwardly: Japan is much stronger than Texas.
Shih Shun-hao started the game with a three-run homer. Then after the big first inning, Taiwan went on to score a run in the second and three more in the third.

Texas managed to tally two points in the bottom of the third, but Taiwan added another nail in the coffin in the top of the fourth and held off Texas in the second half of the inning for the mercy-rule win.
"Yesterday (in Saturday's loss to Japan) we made a lot of mistakes we shouldn't have made, but today we avoided a lot of mistakes we could have made," Shih said.
Japan's team from Tokyo beat an American team from Waipahu for the title, something the Taiwanese had their eyes on until Saturday's disappointment.
"Scenes from (Saturday's) game against Japan kept coming back to me in my dreams," Hung Chun-yi, the team's captain, said Sunday.
Last year, Kuei-shan Elementary School from Taoyuan County represented Taiwan in the World Series and lost in the final.

DOC.HEADLINE: Haitian daily praises Taiwan's help in increasing rice production
DOC.DATELINE: Port-au-Prince, Haiti, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 12:51:42 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese agricultural mission stationed in Haiti is experimenting with a new rice variety in an effort to help the Caribbean nation increase its rice production.
The French-language Le Nouvelliste, Haiti's largest newspaper, gave heavy coverage of the Taiwanese mission's drive on its economic pages Aug. 14-15.
According to the report, the new rice strain Prosequisa-4, also known as P-4, is bringing new hope to the country's goal of increasing its annual rice crop.
The new variety has been planted in L'Artibonite valley plain, Haiti's most important rice production area, which used to contribute most of the country's annual output.
However, production declined substantially after the region was hit by an outbreak of crop disease in 1998, the report said.
The Taiwanese agricultural mission then collaborated with the Haitian government to introduce the Taiwan-developed Taichung Shan No. 10 variety on the plain, which thrived there.
The report quoted Hsiang Shui-sung, head of the Taiwanese agricultural mission there, as saying that the average rice productivity in L'Artibonite plain is no more than 2.5 tons per hectare.

With the introduction of P-4, however, production is expected to reach 4-6 tons per hectare, Hsiang said, adding that if the strain is planted in a "three harvests per year" model, production costs will be slashed while annual output will increase.
Haiti consumes about 500,000 tons of rice annually, with 70 percent imported from abroad. With 60,000 hectares of rice paddies, Haiti produces only about 150,000 tons of rice a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO hopes to resolve science park disputes through land swap
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 13:09:26 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) said Sunday that the company hopes disputes concerning the Central Taiwan Science Park will be resolved through a land swap.

AUO Chairman K.Y. Lee said the National Science Council (NSC) is planning to adjust its plan for the development of the fourth phase of the science park by proposing a land swap with the farmers who had their land taken from them by the government.

Lee said he hopes the proposed land swap will resolve the environmental protection disputes in the development of the fourth phase of the science park in Erlin, Changhua County, where AUO plans to build two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy facilities.

The government has expropriated the land for the development, but the farmers there oppose the expropriation and have refused to accept the offered compensation, saying that they want to keep their land and continue farming it.

In July, the Taiwan High Administrative Court ordered the suspension of the development of the third and fourth phases of the science park after residents sued the government for failing to present a reliable environmental impact assessment for the development.
The government has appealed the court decision.
Meanwhile, the investors who already operate facilities in the third phase of the development have been allowed by the government to continue their operations despite the court order.

AUO has completed the construction of an 8.5th-generation plant in the third phase of the development, located in Taichung County's Houli, and is scheduled to install production equipment by the end of this year.
Lee said the new plant will become operational next year with an initial monthly production capacity of 45,000 units.
The company also plans to build another 8.5th-generation plant in Houli.

In another development, Lee described a U.S. court order barring three AUO present and former executives from leaving the U.S. is inhumane as two of the three are now unable to care for their sick parents in Taiwan.

The three were ordered not to travel outside the U.S. Aug. 19 after they appeared in court in San Francisco to plead a case in which prosecutors accused AUO and the executives of participating in a price-fixing conspiracy with other Asian LCD makers between 2001 and 2006.
He said that although his company has assigned other executives to shoulder their workloads, the company's operations will be affected in the long run.
AUO has repeatedly denied the price fixing accusations and has vowed to fight the charges brought by the U.S. Department of Justice in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau forecasts torrential rain as storm approaches
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 13:32:28 (by Wang Shu-feng and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau forecast Monday that the outer bands of Tropical Storm Lionrock and a tropical depression system will together bring torrential rain nationwide and strong winds to coastal cities.

The storm was centered about 470 kilometers west-southwest of Hengchun in the southernmost county of Pingtung at 8 a.m. and was moving in a northeasterly direction at a speed of 2 kilometers per hour, with a probability of heading northwest in the future, the bureau said.

The bureau issued a torrential rain warning, saying the depression system, slowly approaching the island in a north-northwesterly track, will interact with the outer bands of Lionrock, causing heavy rainfall.

According to bureau statistics, rain accumulation from midnight to 8 a.m. Monday morning reached 122 mm in Sinwu Township in Taoyuan County and exceeded 50 mm in the Beitou and Yangmingshan areas of Taipei.

Another tropical storm, Kompasu, is forming in the Japan-held Ryukyu Islands but will not affect Taiwan, the bureau said, adding that it is closely watching for interaction between Kompasu and Lionrock.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to simplify visa procedures for Hong Kong people: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 14:10:44 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The government will introduce simplified procedures for visa issuance for Hong Kong citizens in the near future, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin- yuan said Monday.

During a meeting in Taipei to promote economic and cultural cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong, Lai said that over the past century, civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong have been active, even more so since the beginning of the 21st century, which she said has helped lay the foundation for economic and trade relations between the two sides.

In the aspect of economy and trade, Hong Kong is Taiwan's fourth-largest trade partner, and two-way trade and the number of travelers between the two sides are expected to reach US$38.8 billion and 3 million, respectively, Lai said.

Meanwhile, the number of China-based Taiwanese businesses listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange has reached 60, and some leading Taiwanese companies now consider Hong Kong as the main place for raising business capital, Lai added.

She noted that with the aim of promoting civilian exchanges between the two sides, the government last year relaxed employment restrictions on Hong Kong students, allowing them to enroll in graduate programs after graduating from local universities, and also began extending the duration of stay on visas for Hong Kong-based Chinese citizens visiting Taiwan.
The government is also seeking to further streamline visa application procedures for Hong Kong citizens, Lai added.
Despite the booming exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong, there are still some key details related to the exercise of public power to be addressed between the two sides, Lai went on.

The meeting was the first of its kind between the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Co-operation Council (ECCC) and its Hong Kong counterpart, the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Co-operation and Promotion Council (ECCPC) , since they were set up earlier this year to improve and strengthen relations between the two sides.
Lai said she hopes the two sides will engage in talks on topics of mutual concern and enhance economic and trade exchanges and interaction through the forum.
Also present at the meeting were Hong Kong Financial Secretary John Tsang, ECCC Chairman Lin Chen-kuo and ECCPC Chairman Lee Yeh-kwong.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stresses good ties with St. Vincent and the Grenadines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 14:15:28 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the signing of a landmark trade pact with China will not affect Taiwan's close relations with the Caribbean ally of St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

During a meeting at the Presidential Office with Louis Straker, the deputy prime minister and foreign minister of St. Vincent and the the Grenadines, Ma said that an investment protection agreement signed last December has already helped develop Taiwan's economic and trade relations with St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

Even though Taiwan has improved its relations with China in various fields over the past two years, Taiwan and St. Vincent and the Grenadines -- which have enjoyed diplomatic ties for 29 years -- will continue to carry out close bilateral exchanges, Ma said.
He also said the recently signed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is expected to reduce tensions across the Taiwan Strait and enhance peace and prosperity for the two sides.
"Under the new circumstances, Taiwan and St. Vincent and the Grenadines are still able to deliver on promises to each other and maintain close ties," Ma said.

Ma also expressed thanks to the Caribbean ally for sending its condolences to Taiwan during Typhoon Morakot last August, and for its continued support for Taiwan's participation in international events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.23 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 15:02:39 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.23 percent Monday after profit taking emerged to erode the earlier gains which were posted in reflection of a Wall Street rebound at the end of last week, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 18.29 points to 7,741.20, after moving between 7,737.28 and 7,806.91, on turnover of NT$87.90 billion (US$2.74 billion).

The market opened up 0.96 percent on the latest Wall Street upside after a downward revision of the U.S. economic growth in the second quarter was less than expected, but fears of a major pullback ahead of the strong resistance at the 7,900-8,000 point range prompted investors to lock in profit and capped the gains, dealers said.
A total of 1,673 stocks closed up and 1,871 down with 297 stocks remaining unchanged.

The foodstuff sector scored the highest gains, up 2.1 percent. Financials gained 0.8 percent, textile, construction, and plastics and chemical stocks rose 0.2 percent, and cement stocks added 0.1 percent.
The machinery and electronics sector fell 0.1 percent and the paper and pulp sector lost 0.2 percent.
"Investors remained cautious about the market outlook amid lingering fears of a slowing global economy in the second half of this year," MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
Tang said although the second quarter U.S. economic growth revision was better than expected, other economic data, in particular home sales figures, still disappointed investors.
"Wall Street is very likely to remain choppy on economic uncertainty," Tang said, "Friday's rebound in U.S. markets has failed to comfort investors as they are afraid that volatility will follow."

Tang said rotational buying has served as a driver behind the recent gains, but since the buying rotated so quickly that the market has been in short of a mainstream sector to help the broader market to make a breakthrough.
He said the buying focused on traditional industrial stocks, instead of the bellwether electronics sector, on concerns over global demand for high tech products.
"Investors had better keep cutting holdings once the market stages a rebound," Tang said.
In among non high tech stocks, Food firm Uni-President Enterprises gained 4.35 percent to NT$37.15, Prince Housing added 2.19 percent to NT$0.40 and Chang Hwa Bank rose 2.78 percent to NT$18.50.

The electronics sector was affected by Intel's downgrade of its sales forecast for the third quarter with memory chip maker Nanya Technology down 3.77 percent at NT$19.75 and United Microelectronics Corp. unchanged at NT$13.05.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will help bring investors to Taiwan: vice premier
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 15:19:44 (By Wang Shu-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is poised to pull out of its economic isolation and regain its global competitiveness now that it has clinched an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Vice Premier Sean Chen said Monday.

In the wake of the ECFA signing in late June, tension across the Taiwan Strait has dropped further, which will help Taiwan entice investors, funds and advanced technologies from around the world, Chen said during an "invest in Taiwan" workshop in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
He said that in the past, Taiwan's exports to China always surpassed exports by member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
However, ASEAN has overtaken Taiwan since 2005 in export volume to China, while Taiwan's overall competitiveness has also slid, he noted.

He attributed the jump of ASEAN exports to China mainly to the ASEAN Plus China free trade accord, under which ASEAN members enjoy tariff concessions on their shipments to China. The accord took effect Jan. 1 this year but ASEAN countries actually began benefiting from the process of drawing up the agreement several years ago.
"Taiwan has tried not to be left too far behind, which was the reason for its efforts to forge the ECFA with China, " the vice premier said.
He added that many businesses can "smell" the business potential in post-ECFA Taiwan.

Taking the domestic hospitality industry as an example, he said, fresh investment worth some NT$47 billion (US$1.47 billion) is expected to be channeled into the industry by 2012, representing an increase of 5,800 hotel rooms.

Chen said the country's rich resources of high-caliber workers and the strong ambition demonstrated by Taiwanese businessmen are two of Taiwan's major assets that will act as a magnet for attracting foreign investors.

Council of Economic Planning and Development Chairwoman Christina Liu, who also spoke at the workshop, said the event was aimed at "igniting the domestic consumption engine" to rev up investment at home, which will in turn power the country's overall economic growth.
The ECFA, ratified by the legislature Aug. 17, is expected to take effect in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials to visit Dubai to seek development tips
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 16:02:14 (By Wang Shu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation is scheduled to visit Dubai Sept. 19 with the aim of learning from the fast-growing free trade port about how to attract international investment, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials said Monday.

As Dubai successfully launched a "logistics city" program in 2007, the Taiwanese delegation, led by Chi Wen-chung, director of the Department of Navigation and Aviation, is hopeful of learning from Dubai's experience in developing logistics services, they said.

According to the MOTC, the port of Dubai has attracted up to 5,000 companies over the past 25 years, compared to Taiwan's four free trade ports, which between them have attracted just 102 firms -- none of which are internationally famous -- since the establishment of free trade ports in 2003.
Dubai, where the container cargo-handling amount is ranked No. 7 in the world, has grown very fast over the past 10 years -- with GDP reaching 230 percent growth in the period.
As crude oil only contributes about 6 percent of Dubai's GDP, the country has been aggressively promoting its tourism, logistics industries and free trade port, officials said.

Dubai's operating model is quite simple -- it levies a 5-percent tax on all companies investing in the port, the MOTC officials said, adding that the model has proved effective because as the port has attracted investment from most of the major international companies, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Awakening News fights on with unique vision

TEXT.P: If you are not convinced that good things come in small packages, try visiting the Awakening News Network website. The so-called "multivitamin of news" promises to provide you with all the news you need to know that day in less than 30 articles.

With only 12 staff members, the network is more than just a paper, despite its Chinese name -- "Taiwan Awakening Newspaper." Awakening transmits its news stories through radio broadcasts, television, the Internet, mobile phones, and of course, in print.
It is touted to be Taiwan's first mass media outlet that makes use of the full range of communication formats to convey its information to the public.

It seemed to be a bit off base for Catherine Y. L. Lin to found Awakening on Sept. 1, 2008 when newspapers around the world were falling victims to the rising popularity of the Internet and the island was in the grips of a financial crisis which took a heavy financial toll on the local mass media.

But as a veteran journalist who had served at the United Daily News and CommonWealth monthly, Lin was disappointed with the island's mass media, which bristles with papers and TV stations that are sympathetic to specific political parties and seem to try to brainwash their readers or audience with politically biased reports.
They also indulge in exposing groundless scandals, airing sensationalist stories, and go to great lengths to feed their readers and audience celebrity gossip.
Fair reporting and impartial political commentary are rare if not absent.

Former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh once cited a foreigner friend as complaining that his personal experience with local people told him that Taiwan was a lovable country, but that when he turned on the TV he found an ugliness contrary to what he knew.
In order to avoid this kind of unhealthy news, Awakening is devoted to providing stories that makes readers feel warm and encouraged.
The reports aim to carry the opinions of experts rather than well-known TV talk show figures and to discuss issues of public concern rather than stories about celebrities cheating on their spouses.
People who visit the Awakening News Network website will find that the stories posted are comprehensive yet condensed -- an epitome of Lin's belief that "less is more."
"Our principle is 'write in brief, report in depth.' Living in a world overwhelmed with information, modern people don't need to read more than 20 to 30 news items a day," Lin said.
As a university lecturer of journalism for more than 20 years, she knows a concise, all-inclusive story is worth more than a page of disorganized reports.
In her opinion, a good story should not exceed 500 to 600 words, but it should include the facts, their significance, perspective, impact, possible future developments and solutions.
If the story is about a person, the report should cover the opinions of people surrounding him or her, such as rivals and other people concerned.
By the same token, Lin said a story about the ruling Kuomintang must cover reactions from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and vice versa.
"Just like taking a picture, you need to shed light on the subject from different angles to highlight its true image," she said.

She posts minutes from daily meetings of the network's correspondents on the website, including senior editors' advice to rookie reporters about how to cover an event, even though some of the suggestions aren't always reflected in the final story.
"We want our readers and audience to know what we thought about," Lin said.

Visitors to the site can also find a section showing reporters reviewing their work that day, or their feelings during the coverage of news events, which gives a close-up of the scene, the people and the event being reported.

Lin often reminds the network's reporters to send out their stories ahead of their counterparts at the Central News Agency, Taiwan's state news agency, and tells them the stories should be more comprehensive than those from CNA. If CNA reporters interview one person, she said, Awakening's reporters should interview five.

In addition to writing, the reporters at the network also shoot news films, create and edit broadcast tapes, and serve as anchors to transmit their stories via radio, television, mobile phones and the Internet.
"I really feel sorry for my reporters, because I give them one person's salary but ask them to do the work of four people, and ask them to double in brass all the while," Lin said.
The reason is the network's tight budget, which comes entirely from Lin's personal savings. She even sold her house to raise the start-up funds.
Noting that Google, the world's largest web portal, made no profit in the first five years after its launch, Lin said she didn't expect her network to bring any profit soon, nor did she care.
"What I'm concerned about most is whether the network can exercise an influence," she said.
But she was confident the network can cater to the demand of many people who would rather cut to the chase and learn the real news.

This was borne out in May when Awakening became one of two local papers to provide news to Apple computer company's iPhone users, thousands of iPhone users downloaded the software needed to read Awakening in just a few days after its release, delighting Lin and her staff.
On Aug. 1, the network launched a weekly in print which was the last step toward Lin's dream of a multi-media network.

In the last two years, 10 web portals have subscribed to its news service and it is looking forward to selling its news to more cable TV channels, as only eight of the nearly 100 channels currently provide news reports.

Although the network's prospects look brighter now than they did two years ago, Lin is not certain how long it will survive, but she said it would be better to have fought and lost than never to have fought at all. By Maubo Chang CNA staff writer CNA photo 69, 70

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 16:57:14 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.03 to close at the day's high of NT$32.060.
Turnover totaled US$564 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$32.030 and fell to a low of NT$31.810 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solar cell firm's shares dive on net loss
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 17:04:28 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of solar cell maker E-Ton Solar Tech Co. fell sharply Monday after the company reported a massive net loss for the first half of this year, dealers said.
The over-the-counter market listed E-Ton as falling 6.94 percent to NT$45.60 (US$1.42 billion) with 772,000 shares changing hands, while the OTC index closed down 0.83 percent at 137.84 points.
E-Ton posted NT$3.01 billion in net losses in the first half of this year after a NT$2.34 billion net loss recorded in 2009.

"The company has incurred net losses for the sixth consecutive quarter, largely reflecting its unprofitable subsidiary in the United States, GIH," TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih told the Central News Agency Monday.

E-Ton acquired U.S.-based ADEMA Technologies in 2007 and combined the newly acquired business with one of its units -- Gloria Solar Ltd. -- to form Gloria Solar International Holding, Inc. (GIH), which is engaged in the production of upstream solar products, including monocrystalline ingots and photovoltaic modules.
Shih said E-Ton had previously wanted to extend its foothold to solar cell material production as part of its strategy for vertical business integration through the acquisition of ADEMA.
"ADEMA had a lot of unprofitable intangible assets, however, and E-Ton has had to incorporate the losses, "Shih said.

"A global financial crisis in 2008 made the situation even worse. E-Ton needed more provisions to cover the losses. That's why the market was stunned by its massive losses reported for the first half," Shih said.
MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said it was not easy for E-Ton, which was smaller than ADEMA in terms of capitalization, to run the acquired assets.
"It was like a funny scenario with a small child driving a big car," Tang said.
In the first half of this year, E-Ton's gross margin stood at only 6.48 percent, much lower than the average of about 14 percent in the solar cell industry.
Among E-Ton's rivals, Motech Industries reported a gross margin of 16.69 percent and Solartech Energy registered 17.44 percent for its gross margin.

"The weak gross margin reflected E-Ton's low production capacity utilization on falling orders after a major management reshuffle last year had an impact on the company's operations, " TLG's Shih said.
The reshuffle came after several senior executives resigned in a disagreement over E-Ton's management of the U.S. subsidiary, Shih said.
"The stock is very likely to fall further amid uncertainty over its outlook," Shih said. "Keep a distance from it, please."

DOC.HEADLINE: Downpour expected to ease drought in 'Rain City'
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 17:18:34 (by Pien Chin-feng, Wang Shu-fang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Heavy rainfall caused by the interaction of Tropical Storm Lionrock and a tropical depression could relieve Keelung's water shortage problem, the Central Weather Bureau said Monday.
Rainfall in Keelung reached 104 millimeters between 12: 00 a.m. and 1: 20 p.m. Monday and was expected to increase in the next few days, the bureau said.
Before the downpour, Taiwan Water Supply Corp. (TWSC) was considering the implementation of second-stage water rationing measures in Keelung, known as Taiwan's "Rain City, " beginning Sept. 1.

With the Hsinshan Reservoir water level dropping below the safe storage level this summer, Keelung and Taipei County's Sijhih began first-stage water rationing, which involves decreasing the water pressure at night.

TWSC said that second-stage measures would target heavy water users, forcing swimming pools, saunas, car washes, spas and similar facilities to cut their water usage to 20 percent of their monthly average.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students win titles at Pan-Pacific arithmetic contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 17:19:52 (By Sun Tien-mei and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese students won in their categories at the 11th Pan Pacific Abacus & Mental Arithmetic Association (PAMA) Competition in Malaysia, association officials announced Sunday.

Over 400 contestants participated in the 2010 PAMA competition, which was held that day at the Genting International Convention Centre in Malaysia, divided into five categories according to age group.
