"I was surprised to win because I did not start preparing for the competition until two months ago, " said Huang Kuang-chi, who won the championship of the over-14 group. Huang also seized a title in the 2006 PAMA competition held in Hong Kong.
Huang Jui-chieh, a two-time champion in 2006 and 2007, clinched this year's title in the 11-13 group.
Meanwhile, two students from Hong Kong won the titles of the under-6 group and the 9-10 group, while a Malaysian student took first place in the 7-8 group.
The children had to complete seven papers -- three papers on abacus in three minutes, three on mental arithmetic in one minute and one additional paper on abacus in one minute in the case of a tie.
PAMA was founded in 1999 and has a membership of 10 countries -- Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand, India, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, Canada and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign foundation donates money to Taichung food bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 17:40:59 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The Aurora Light Foundation, a Switzerland-based foundation, presented US$40,000 to the Taichung Ta-tun Food Bank Monday, a donation that will help approximately 4,000 households in central Taiwan, according to the food bank's founder.

It was the first donation ever received by the food bank from overseas, said the Department of Social Affairs of the Taichung City Government, which established the organization in 2009 to aid the poor and needy.
The food bank had been experiencing a decrease in donations since last year and was faced with a money shortage after this year's Chinese New Year, said department Director Chang Guo-huei.

The chief executive of Aurora Light Foundation in Asia, Huang Shih-ming, allocated the US$40,000 after hearing about the food bank's financial difficulties and reporting the issue to the foundation's headquarters.
Aurora Light Foundation is a charitable organization dedicated to assisting any country or organization in need, said Huang, adding that other cities in Taiwan are also eligible to apply for funding.

During the donation ceremony, Andrew Johnson, founder of Aurora Light Foundation, expressed hope to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu that the money will help the financially under-privileged, to which Hu responded that the food bank will indeed use the money to help the disadvantaged.
Chang noted that the fund will be distributed in four installments before June 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education conference lacks focus: experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 18:06:43 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: One day after Taiwan wrapped up its first national educational conference in 16 years, scholars who were at the two-day event concluded Monday that the conference lacked focus.

Asked to comment on the conference touted by the Taiwanese authorities as an important event in the education field, Tuan Chyau, a visiting professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, said at a press conference that "there were too many different themes to see a focus."
He expressed hope that a planned education white paper scheduled to be published before the end of the year will not be merely a record of the diverse opinions from the conference.
Echoing Tuan, Wu Wu-tien, an honorary professor at National Taiwan Normal University, expressed regret that the conference lost its focus.

Individual events that occurred at the same time as the conference took away media attention, while discussions were broken down into many various themes ranging from cross-Taiwan Strait educational exchanges to lifelong learning, Wu said.

One of the events Wu referred to was the case of a teenage gunman who turned himself in for the high-profile murder of alleged Taichung gangster Weng Chi-nan in late May and blamed his involvement in crime on poor education.

At the news conference, the scholars, who also included Chou Chu-ying, a professor at National Chengchi University's College of Education, talked about the surrender of Liao Kuo-hao -- a 17-year-old high school drop-out -- after 90 days as one of the country's most-wanted fugitives.
Urging the government to pay more attention to academic under-achievers, Chou said that so long as there is even one Liao Kuo-hao in society, no effort should be spared in educational reform.

The Eighth National Education Conference, which opened Saturday at the National Central Library, gathered officials, teachers and representatives of civic groups from across Taiwan with the aim of formulating "an education policy that will pave the way for Taiwan's `golden decade, '" according to Minister of Education Wu Ching-ji.

The conference had 10 central themes, including the education system in general, higher education, special education, faculty training, internationalized campuses and education, and lifelong learning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seats for concerts in Kinmen war tunnel available from Wednesday
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 18:25:33 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Free passes to a unique series of concerts on a stage floating down a tunnel waterway in the Cold War battleground of Kinmen will become available on Sept. 1, organizers said Monday.

"All the concerts will be free of charge, but as each one can only accommodate 300 people, those interested in attending should register as soon as possible, " said Tseng Wei-hung, director of the Kinmen National Park Administration.
Registration can be made online or by fax or phone, Tseng said.

The concert series, this year featuring six concerts of 40 minutes each on Oct. 16-17, will be the second of its kind presented in the 101-meter-long Zhaishan Tunnel, a war era relic that is now a tourist attraction.

Five prominent local musicians presented two "watery concerts" in the tunnel last October for the first time to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou, in which an outmanned Nationalist force repelled an invasion by the Chinese communists.
"As the unprecedented waterway concerts drew an enthusiastic response, we decided to host a music festival at the same venue this year, " Tseng said.
Those who successfully register for standing room passes will witness the special concerts from a walkway in the tunnel surrounding the A-shaped waterway.

Six musicians -- cellist Chang Cheng-chieh, flutist Wu Tsung-hsien, harpist Hung Chi-mei, violinists Liang Chien-wen and Wu Ting-yu, and violist Lee Ching- yi -- will perform in the concerts, with Chang serving as artistic director, Tseng said.
The Oct. 16 concerts will feature string quartet pieces and the Oct. 17 concerts will have recitals for the violin, harp, flute and cello, according to Tseng.

Chang, the driving artistic force behind last year's concerts, said after the performances that he was amazed by the acoustics at the venue, describing them as "much, much better" than he had expected.
"I have only one word to describe my first-ever concert in the waterway -- terrific," he said emotionally.

Located in the southwestern part of Kinmen Island, the underground Zhaishan Tunnel -- 101 meters long, 6 meters wide and 3.5 meters high -- opens into the Taiwan Strait. Its A-shaped waterway has a pier that can dock up to 42 small boats.

Construction on the tunnel got underway in 1961 and took five years to complete. It served as a small boat base for shipments of military supplies on the island, which was the front line of hostilities between Taiwan and China during the Cold War.

With the improvement of cross-strait relations, the number of Taiwanese troops stationed in Kinmen has been reduced, and the island is being gradually transformed into a tourist destination, with war sites as the main attraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan member applies for probe into overpricing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 18:32:21 (By Sophia Yeh, Chen Hung-chin, Lin Shen-hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Control Yuan member Yeh Yao-peng said Monday that he will apply to conduct an investigation into the overpricing of flowers used in Taipei City's Xinsheng Overpass reconstruction project and would not rule out the possibility of questioning Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

Yeh made the remarks after the city government came under fire for paying up to 30 times the market price for flowers to decorate Xinsheng Overpass and the Taipei International Flora Exposition and as much as 12 times the market price for other project materials.
Yeh said that because of numerous flaws found in the tender process for the project, it is necessary to look into the case.
His investigation will focus on whether the city government and other government agencies accepted kickbacks or neglected their supervisory duty, he said.

Meanwhile, Taipei City councilor candidate Juan Chao-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) visited the Control Yuan Monday, petitioning it to open an investigation into the overpricing.
Juan said that a task force headed by Hau that the city government formed couldn't be impartial and that it was inappropriate for the mayor to be "both player and referee."
On the other hand, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said that the party will not take advantage of the alleged scandal, which reportedly could hurt Hau's chances for re-election.
Hau said Sunday that the allegations of overpricing amounted to a "crisis" for him.

The Chinese-language Apple Daily reported Sunday that Hau, who had enjoyed a narrow lead over DPP rival Su Tseng-chang in the polls since Su declared his candidacy for the Nov. 27 mayoral election in March, lagged 1.56 percent behind Su in the paper's latest survey.
Su urged the city government to face the issue honestly and not take into account any political or electoral considerations when dealing with the problem.

In related news, Lin Chun-hung, who was among about 20 representatives from the floral, gardening and landscaping industry invited by the city government to an event Monday to show support for the Taipei Flora Expo, said during the event, "We don't support Hau."
According to Lin, some flower farmers who have worked for the expo for about six months have not yet received their pay.

Hau said at the event that the expo would be the pride of Taiwan and that the floral fair would provide a good opportunity for local flower farmers because more than 90 percent of flowers -- worth a total of NT$2.1 billion -- would be locally grown.

In response to allegations of overpricing, Hau said he would take his share of responsibility for the case and promised to look into the matter. He added that he would leave the decision as to whether he should assume political responsibility to voters.
He appealed to the public for help, however, saying that "you can choose not to support Hau Lung-bin, but you have to support the expo."

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate earthquake shakes Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 18:38:53 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale hit Yilan in northeastern Taiwan Monday, with no immediate damage reported, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The earthquake, which occurred at 4: 45 p.m., was centered 39.1 kilometers northeast of the Yilan City seismic station at a depth of 16.5 kilometers, the bureau reported.

The tremor was felt in northern Taiwan, with the largest measurement -- magnitude 4.0 -- recorded in Taipei County's Sandiaojiao. Yilan's Suao and Hualien's Heping recorded magnitude 3.0, while the temblor measured 2.0 in Yilan City, Taipei City, Jhongli, Taoyuan City and Hsinchu City, according to the bureau.
The Hsinchu Science Industrial Park said the quake did not affect manufacturing operations.
No damage was reported in the park, said Tu Chih-hsiang, deputy director-general of the park administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Chinese gamers looking for cyber freedom
DOC.DATELINE: 08/30/10 18:40:28 (Business Weekly 1187)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Chinese online game players are "flocking" to Taiwan using a variety of methods to evade their government's tight control over the Internet. The result is that the interaction between young people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is no less commonplace than cross-Strait trade and tourism exchanges in the real world.

Despite unavoidable misunderstandings due to cultural differences, the online exchanges offer Chinese web users what they consider Taiwan's most valuable contribution to the Chinese speaking world and what many Taiwanese take for granted: freedom.

The Chinese government's recent move to tighten censorship of online games, in combination with an existing regulation limiting the time players spend on games to prevent addiction, has given users extra incentive to break through the iron curtain that has descended on cyberspace in China.
Many popular online games designed around the world have been unable to gain approval for release in China, including new versions of existing games such as "World of Warcraft."

To play the new games, Chinese gamers instead starting using the games' Taiwanese servers, which are generally more updated than any others around the world and use a language Chinese users can easily understand.

That, however, has led Taiwanese game companies to build walls against Chinese users, because their numbers tend to overload Taiwanese servers and their intrusion has led to disputes over theft of user accounts.
With Taiwanese companies blocking Chinese games, another business opportunity arose -- setting up overseas proxy servers.

Even though the monthly fee is double the price Taiwanese gamers pay to play games, Chinese gamers are making connections to Taiwan through proxy servers so that Taiwanese companies cannot screen them by their IP address.

Chinese web users have not been stopped by multiple barriers from breaking through to the sites they like, but those barriers have made the users more appreciative of the freedoms they lack -- just one of the outcomes of closer ties between Taiwan and China, whether online or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan offers 'Hope' to Haitian quake survivors

TEXT.P: Seven months after Haiti was struck by a killer earthquake, more than 1.5 million displaced survivors in Port-au-Prince are still scrounging to find a permanent place to call home.

The city is still dotted with makeshift tents made from tattered tarpaulin. Heaps of debris and rusting exposed wires can be seen everywhere -- glaring indicators of the country's snailed-pace recovery.
But while the situation remains dismal for most survivors, 200 families are optimistic that they will soon go from being homeless to homeowners.
These 200 families were handpicked by the Haitian government as the first residents of Hope Village -- a rural resettlement community that Taiwan has volunteered to build from scratch.

The village will be spread out over 330 hectares in the mountainous central region of Savanne Diane and each family will be given a 40-square meter house and small plot of farm land. There will also be a school, a church, and a public square for social gatherings.
The project is a realization of one of the four pledges made by President Ma Ying-jeou two weeks after the quake to help with Haiti's reconstruction.

Lisa Hsu, deputy-director of the Department of the Disaster Relief of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, said the project is aimed at giving those who escaped Port-au-Prince during the earthquake a new lease of life.

"The Haitian government and many international non-government organizations have listed resettlement of survivors, especially those who have left Port-au-Prince, as top priority in an effort to alleviate the pressure of over-population in the city," she said.

The site of the village project is about a five-hour drive from the capital and the roads leading to it are extremely rugged. But the Haitian government purposely chose this part of the country for development in the hope that other countries and NGOs will follow Taiwan's lead, Hsu said.
This is a collaborative effort between the Taiwan government, which has pledged US$1 million, and the Red Cross Society, which will contribute the remaining US$2.2 million, she said.
The houses are being built with consideration for the local culture, Hsu said.

"We wanted to be sensitive to the Haitian style of living, so after conducting a field survey, we decided to build detached kitchens and outhouse bathrooms with sit-down toilets because that is what the people are used to," Hsu said.
However, the project will extend beyond housing and land ownership, said Yen Ming-hong, a project manager at Taiwan's International Cooperation Development Fund (ICDF).

Yen said the ICDF has agreed to offer long-term technical support to the village residents by sending an agricultural technical mission to train them in areas such as growing maize and raising chickens.
"We want to give the villagers a sustainable environment in which they can become self-reliant in the long-run," Yen said.
The Department of Health (DOH) will also send Taiwanese medical professionals to staff the community clinic, he added.
ICDF agricultural specialist Huang Kun-chung, who worked in Taiwan's overseas technical missions for 40 years, has been called out of retirement to head the farming project.
Since mid-May, Huang and some of the people who will live in Hope Village have been tilling a 40-hectare field in the blazing heat to experiment with the type of maize that would grow best there.
Huang said the agricultural mission has decided on two local varieties of maize and the rest of the field will be planted next week.

In addition to maize, Huang said, the team will also designate some land for sorghum and Congo beans, two popular staples among Haitians, to ensure that the villagers will have a food harvest all year round.
The community is expected to house 1,000 people in 200 households, and space has been reserved for possible expansion in the future, Hsu said.

A date has not yet been set for the groundbreaking but the plan for the layout of the village is expected to be finalized before the end of the year, he said. enditem /pc By Jenny W.Hsu CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: TV host breaks world record for eating grains of rice
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 19:30:40 (By Huang Hui-ming and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Canadian TV host Bob Blumer broke the Guinness World Record for eating 134 grains of rice in three minutes in Taipei on Monday, the seventh world record he has set in various food-related challenges.
Blumer, host of the Food Network's "Glutton for Punishment," set the new world record on the final day of the 2010 Taipei Culinary Exhibition.
His three tries at eating individual grains of rice with chopsticks all surpassed the previous world record -- 78 grains of rice in three minutes -- set nearly two years ago.
"I am still hungry! " said an excited Blumer after successfully eating 134 grains of rice during his second attempt.
Blumer picked up 125 grains, 134 grains, and 131 grains on his three attempts, respectively.
The previous record was set by Rob Beaton in November 2008 in the U.S., who picked up 23 grains of rice in one minute, and 78 grains of rice in three minutes.

Blumer is usually given five days to become proficient enough in an episode's featured specialty. After he arrived in Taiwan on Aug. 26, he quickly learned how to use chopsticks under a local chef's training.
"No one was able to beat me, " Blumer said after winning several challenges against local residents.
Among other Guinness World Records broken by the TV host include making 168 pizzas in 60 minutes in Canada in July 2010, flipping 559 pancakes in one hour, and cracking 2,069 eggs in one hour.
Blumer and his crew were scheduled to stay in Taiwan until Aug. 30 to film Taiwan's rice varieties and rice-related products.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP tops political donations report for 2009-2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 19:42:05 (US$5.31 million) , followed by the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) (By Sophia Yeh and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) received the most donations in the 2009-2010 accounting report of any of Taiwan's political parties and groups, Control Yuan officials said Monday.

According to the report released by the Control Yuan, the DPP tallied the most political donations with about NT$170 million NT$75.29 million, the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) NT$24.9 million, the People First Party's (PFP's) NT$9.89 million and the New Party's (NP's) NT$5.3 million.
The Control Yuan is responsible for handling political donation disclosures of the 22 political parties with open accounts based on the Political Donations Act.

In the categories of the DPP's income, "personal donations" took first place with NT$120 million, followed by "cooperate donations" of NT$31.51 million, "anonymous donations" of NT$14.11 million and "organizational donations" of NT$4.25 million.
In terms of the party's expense categories, meanwhile, "personnel expenses" ranked first with NT$100 million, followed by "public election funds" of NT$13.77 million.

Among the income categories of the KMT, "cooperate donations" topped the list at NT$43.48 million, followed by "personal donations" of NT$29.96 million, "organizational donations" of NT$600,000 and "anonymous donations" of NT$19,000.

Among its expense categories, "public election funds" accounted for NT$360 million and "personnel expenses" totalized NT$24.57 million, indicating an annual deficit that was subsidized by its party budget.

Among the top five parties that received the most donations, the DPP and the TSU were the only two with surpluses -- NT$5.89 million and NT$3.6 million, respectively, while the PFP and the NP suffered deficits of NT$450,000 and NT$130,000, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese banks set sights on five areas in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 19:56:01 (By Tien Yu-bin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Ever since the country's trade pact with China was signed June 29, local banks eager to venture into the Chinese market have set their sights on five areas densely populated by Taiwanese businessmen, officials from Hua Nan Financial Holdings said Monday.

The Yangtze River Delta in southern Jiangsu Province and northern Zhejiang Province and the Pearl River Delta in southern Guangdong Province where the largest numbers of Taiwanese businessmen in China are located, are the top priority of local banks, the officials said.
However, if they go there all together, the competition among them is expected to be fierce, they said.
The other three areas are Chengdu and Chongqing in western China, Bohai Bay in northern China's Hebei Province, and the Western Taiwan Strait Economic Zone in Fujian Province.

Chengdu and Chongqing, along with Bohai Bay, are attractive to local banks because China's authorities offer fast-track services in approving Taiwan banks operating there and also waive restrictions on the number of branch offices they can open, in attempts to boost economic development in those areas.

Among the local banks, Hua Nan Bank, First Bank, Taiwan Cooperative Bank, Chang Hwa Bank, Cathay United Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan have been approved by Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission to upgrade their representative offices in China to branches.

For those banks, their top priority is to make profits after the inauguration of their branches in China, as under Chinese rules, they will only be allowed to extend loans in Chinese yuan to Taiwanese businessmen one year after they begin to make profits.

Hua Nan Bank estimates that its Chinese branches will break even six months to one year after inauguration and it forecast that it will be able to lend out US$56 million in the first year, similar to a First Bank forecast of US$50 million to US$100 million.
However, since Taiwanese banks will not be allowed to receive savings in yuan, their ability to extend loans in yuan will be limited unless they can cooperate with Chinese banks.

Local bankers said Taiwanese banks used to be more cautious than their Chinese counterparts in extending loans and are more familiar with Taiwanese business operating in China, while Chinese banks have ample supplies of yuan, so that cooperation between them will benefit both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulls simultaneous trade suspension mechanism with Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 19:56:28 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) said Monday it is studying the feasibility of a mechanism that would immediately suspend trading of a Hong Kong-listed company's Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) if trading in that company's shares is halted in Hong Kong.
The plan emerged after TDRs issued by Hong Kong-listed Kith Holdings Ltd. continued to be traded for two days in Taiwan after the Hong Kong Exchange suspended trading of Kith's shares.
Kith, a China-based multi-color paper packaging product maker, listed its TDRs in February after being listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1998.

Trading of Kith shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange was suspended on Aug. 18 at 10: 10 a.m., pending a sensitive information announcement, but the company did not disclose the trading suspension information on the TWSE until 1:28 p.m. on the same day.

Even more problematic, its TDRs continued to trade in Taiwan for two days while trading in its shares in Hong Kong remained suspended, sparking criticism from investors who accused the TWSE of failing to closely monitor the market and leaving investors in the dark.
The TWSE said that in the future it will take into account a TDR-listed company's information disclosure practices before giving a green light to allow the company to issue new TDRs here.
The company has been fined NT$50,000 by the Taiwan Stock Exchange for violating the rules governing trading information disclosure.
In a statement on its website, the exchange said it has asked Kith to correct the inappropriate practices by following the information disclosure rules.
Trading of Kith shares resumed on Aug. 20 in Hong Kong after the company announced that United States-based Apex, one of its major customers, filed for bankruptcy protection.
According to Kith, Apex owes Kith US$12.07 million, but it said the amount is secured by a first priority security interest and lien against Apex's assets.
Kith operates production facilities in Yunnan, Heilongjiang and Anhui provinces in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese culture minister to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:16:31 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's Minister of Culture Cai Wu will visit Taiwan Sept. 2-8 at the head of a 50-member delegation, an executive with the Sheen Chuen-chi Cultural and Educational Foundation said Monday.

Cai will be the most senior People's Republic of China official to ever visit Taiwan, and his trip has triggered widespread speculation that cultural issues will make their way onto the agenda of the next round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun, however, dismissed the speculation as unfounded, stressing that the agenda for the sixth round of talks between the heads of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits has been set and does not include cultural subjects.

According to the Sheen Chuen-chi Foundation, Cai will attend a seminar on cross- strait cultural exchanges sponsored by the foundation and visit cultural institutions, tourist attractions, historic sites and leading enterprises in creative and cultural industries during his stay.
Cai may also travel outside Taipei to visit cultural attractions in other Taiwanese cities, such as Tainan and Hsinchu, the foundation said.
Both Cai and his Taiwanese counterpart Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng will attend the Sept. 6 seminar, to be held at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel, the foundation said.

The seminar will focus on themes related to cultural creativity, the visual and performing arts, tangible and intangible cultural heritage, and community culture and development, the foundation said, adding that 150 officials, academics and industry representatives from Taiwan and China will attend the symposium.
According to the foundation, Cai will visit Taiwan in his capacity as honorary chairman of the Chinese Cultural Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong to collaborate on service sector
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:17:50 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong were urged Monday to forge partnerships in the service sectors on each side to explore the growing Chinese market.

Taiwan has great potential to explore business opportunities in the Chinese service market due to the similarity of the cultures on either side of the Taiwan Strait and the recent signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , said Chen Tain-Jy, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, at a forum in Taipei on Taiwan-Hong Kong trade.
"We need to pay special heed to this, one of the biggest opportunities in China following the signing of the ECFA, " he said.
Taiwan and China have agreed to ease restrictions on certain financial and other services under the trade pact, which is expected to take effect in the near future.
In addition, Chen said, there is still a lot of room in which the service sector can grow in China, as it now accounts for just 40 percent of the country's GDP.

He suggested that Taiwan and Hong Kong can collaborate on medical treatment, environmental protection and cultural innovation, as the two sides have vowed to commit to these emerging fields and can complement each other in these respects.

"The development of these emerging service industries can use Taiwan's advantage in information and communications technology, " said Chen, a former head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
In terms of environmental protection, for example, Taiwan has achieved remarkable progress as it is already the world's largest producer of energy- saving LED lights, he noted.
In the field of medical treatment, meanwhile, Hong Kong has rich experience in epidemic prevention, while Taiwan is planning a system of insurance to cover long-term care, he said.
Chen also urged Taiwan and Hong Kong to remove trade barriers in the service trade, but he did not elaborate.

David Lie, who chairs the Business Cooperation Committee of the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council (ECCPC) , also said at the forum that Taiwan and Hong Kong should capitalize on each other's advantages to increase their respective shares of the Chinese and international markets.
Lawrence Lau, the former president of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, who also spoke at the forum, said that the service trade has long been important between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Taiwan was Hong Kong's fifth-largest export destination for service trade and its seventh-largest source of service trade imports in 2008, he noted.

He urged insurance companies in Taiwan, Hong Kong and China to set up an international insurance center in Hong Kong in view of the fact that the three places between them account for the world's largest life insurance market and shipping fleets.
Such an international insurance center would reduce the costs of Chinese and Taiwanese businesses and help enhance their international competitiveness, he said.
He also encouraged Taiwanese colleges and universities to attract students from Hong Kong.
In addition, Lau proposed that travel agencies in Taiwan, Hong Kong, China and Macao should work to attract foreigners to tour the four places under a single collaborative program.

The forum was held alongside the first meeting between the ECCPC and its Taiwanese counterpart, the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council (ECCC), since the two organizations were set up earlier this year to strengthen bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: BenQ Group forecasts revenue of over US$22 billion this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:27:41 (By Pan Chih-i and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The BenQ Group, the parent company of BenQ Corp. and AU Optronics, said Monday it expects to see revenue in excess of US$22 billion for this year as its business has been growing. K.Y. Lee, chairman of the BenQ Group, said that business has
recovered from the negative growth figures in 2008 and 2009, and
the group's 2010 revenue is sure to exceed the US$22 billion
recorded in 2007.
"BenQ will be a major export channel not only for the group, but also for other local industries," Lee told reporters on the sidelines of a BenQ sales conference.
The group said LCD monitors and projectors account for 50 percent of its revenues, with television sets generating 25 percent, and camera and notebooks 25 percent,
The Asia Pacific and Middle East, China, and Europe each account for 30 percent of the group's revenues, while Latin America contributes about 10 percent, it said.

The BenQ Group comprises 12 independent companies, spanning integrated manufacturing, components, services, and brand products in IT, consumer electronics and medical fields, according to its website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong intermediary bodies hold first joint meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:39:30 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official organization founded in May to promote economic and cultural exchanges with Hong Kong held the first joint meeting with its Hong Kong counterpart Monday, and the two decided to hold a similar meeting at least once a year.

Representatives of the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council (ECCC) and the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council (ECCPC) also established principles for communications and interaction between the two groups.
The principles include having the two parties take turns in holding joint meetings and convening such meetings whenever they are needed.

The ECCC and ECCPC also agreed to take turns in organizing at least one forum or conference a year to exchange opinions on issues concerning economic and cultural cooperation, while promising to send visiting delegations to forums organized by the other side.

ECCC Chairman Lin Chen-kuo and his Hong Kong counterpart Lee Yeh-kwong jointly made public the agreement at a press conference following the meeting, which was also attended by Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, and Stephen Lam, the Hong Kong Secretary for Constitutional Affairs.

The two bodies also agreed to accelerate bilateral cooperation in the promotion of financial supervision and double-taxation avoidance and strengthen cooperation in the travel and health care sector and in the fields of culture, education, and innovation, Lin said.
Taiwan inaugurated ECCC on May 26 after the former British colony established ECCPC on March 31.

Hong Kong's role as a major transit hub for the movement of people and goods between Taiwan and China has been weakened as a result of warmer cross-Taiwan Strait ties since Taiwan's president, Ma Ying-jeou, took office in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan official urges Japan to step up bilateral cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 21:10:15 (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang on Monday urged Japan to increase its trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan, saying such a move will be beneficial to both countries and the overall economic development of the region.
Chiang said that with Taiwan's recovery from the global economic crisis, it is time to develop cooperative ties with its major trading partners such as Japan.

Public opinion polls in both Taiwan and Japan have shown that the peoples of the two countries have good feelings about each other, which could lay the foundation for further bilateral trade and economic exchanges, he said.

Chiang was addressing the Foreign Correspondent's Club of Japan on a recently signed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and Taiwan's efforts to strengthen trade and economic relations with other countries in the Asian Pacific region and the rest of the world.

To this end, Taiwan has started discussions on an economic cooperation agreement with Singapore, he said, adding that achievement of this goal will be a significant step in Taiwan's efforts to sign similar pacts with its major trading partners, including Japan, which is Taiwan's second largest trading partner.

Chiang, who arrived in Japan Saturday for a four-day visit, attended an international seminar on the ECFA and cross-strait relations. He also visited Yokohama City and major information, culture and media organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Pavilion at Shanghai Expo to be sold in public tender
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 21:55:32 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council began to invite bids Monday for Taiwan's pavilion featured at the 2010 Shanghai Expo and fixed its floor price at NT$416.88 million (US$13 million).
According to the tender notice issued by the council, the deadline for tendering bids is Sept. 15, and the successful bidder will be chosen and announced the next day.
The council, which built and operated the pavilion at a cost of NT$1 billion at the Shanghai Expo, said the value of the pavilion and its logo is estimated at about NT$600 million to NT$700 million.
The council said it set the pavilion's floor price below its estimated value because the successful bidder will have to dismantle it and rebuild it in Taiwan at a cost of NT$338 million.

The council said it was ready to provide tender forms to interested buyers on Monday, and listed the governments of Taipei County and Chiayi City, and Yamay Recreation World, a theme park in Houli, Taichung County, as likely bidders.
Hualien, Kinmen and Miaoli counties and Keelung City have also expressed interest in purchasing the pavilion, according to the council.

The building, shaped like a sky lantern with a transparent exterior made of glass, was designed by prominent Taiwanese architect C. Y. Lee. It stands 23.8 meters above the ground and has floor space of 1,400 square meters.

At its center is a ball 16 meters in diameter consisting of 1 million LEDS that displays various images reflecting Taiwan's natural beauty and diverse culture. Inside the ball is a 12-meter wide screen that shows films of Taiwan.
According to the trade body, the Taiwan Pavilion has been one of the most popular exhibits at the Shanghai Expo, drawing more than 400,000 visitors thus far.
According to the tender notice, the successful bidder will get not only the building, but also its logo and two sets of computer software used to control the display of LED images.
The software has a market value of more than NT$200 million, according to the tender notice.

The winner of the tender will be required to relocate the pavilion after the expo closes on Oct. 31. A local shipping company has promised to help whoever acquires the pavilion ship it back to Taiwan without charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funding for classified programs cut in 2011 defense budget
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:16:40 (By Su Lung-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The 2011 national defense budget proposal of NT$297.2 billion that was sent to the legislature Monday contained a far less amount for classified programs than the previous year, a ruling party lawmaker said Monday.
Of the total amount, NT$272.7 billion was listed as open funds, while NT$24.5 billion was categorized as funds for classified spending, said Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang.
This was a significant cut of NT$14.7 billion, or 37.5 percent, in the amount of classified funds compared to the previous annual budget, Lin said.
The budget for classified programs was reduced to 8.25 percent of the total, shrinking it to below 10 percent for the first time, he said.
"The big drop was seen not because budgets have been cut significantly, but because many items that were listed under the classified category were moved to the open category," he said.
"The national defense budget for 2011 could be most transparent in history," he added.
The overall defense budget of NT$297.2 billion was NT$200 million less than the previous year, and represented a 16.6 percent of the 2011 national budget, he said.

Because big payments will have to be made soon in the arms deals with the United States, he said, other weapons procurement spending for 2011 will be less than NT$1 billion -- the lowest in recent years.
As result, several other arms procurement projects have been shelved or canceled, Lin said.
However, military production and research and development of defensive arms has remained steady, he said.
"This shows that the government, while seeking to improve cross-strait relations, has not ignored the importance of strengthening national defense," Lin said.
The Navy has listed an open budget of NT$891,000 to examine tank landing ships in the U.S., which indicates that it may want to lease one or two Newport-class tank landing craft, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan admitted to international tuna-fishing group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:23:06 (By Garfie Lee and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been admitted as a member of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission and will attend a meeting of the commission in La Antigua, Guatemala beginning Sept. 27, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement Monday.

Taiwan, which took part in the commission's 10-round negotiations that culminated in the 2003 Antigua Convention, was admitted to the body as a "cooperating fishing entity" under the name of Chinese Taipei -- which is used for Taiwan in many other international bodies.
Taiwan was invited to the body by the commission when it passed the Antigua Convention on June 27, 2003, and it became a full member when the convention took effect on Aug. 27, the statement said.
Belize, Canada, China, the Cook Islands, the European Union, Kiribati, and other countries were also admitted to the body as members under the designation "cooperating non parties."

The Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, established by international convention in 1950, is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna fishing stocks and other species targeted by tuna fishing vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Taiwan's accession to the commission has set a precedent for the island's participation in similar regional fishery management groups in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia to sign memorandum on green power cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:35:23 (By Yang Su-min and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia will sign a memorandum of cooperation on green power development at a two-day meeting that opened Monday in Taichung, according to officials of the Bureau of Energy.

The bureau said the two countries will sign a Taiwan-Australia memorandum of cooperation on energy and minerals at the 16th Taiwan-Australia Joint Energy and Minerals Trade, Investment and Cooperation Consultations, which has been held annually since 1993.

The deal represents an effort to improve mutual understanding in energy policy and to broaden the range of green power investments in response to the global trend of energy saving and carbon emissions reduction.

The meeting, which rotates between Australia and Taiwan and is taking place in Taichung on Aug. 30-31 this year, will discuss energy policy, supply-demand issues related to traditional energy, energy efficiency, renewable energy, carbon emission reductions and cooperation on green power technology.

The bureau noted that Taiwan imports over 2.5 million tons of coal, or roughly 50 percent of its needs, from Australia per year, and also relies heavily on Australia for its aluminum, iron and copper, highlighting the close relationship between the two countries.
A total of about 50 representatives participated in the meeting, including government officials and business executives from the energy and mineral sectors in Taiwan and Australia, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County, Taichung City ranked as best places to have children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 23:21:52 (By Lee Hsien-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Yilan County, Taichung City and Changhua County are the best counties and city in Taiwan in which to have a child, according to the results of survey released by a magazine Monday.

The survey ranking "the most suitable places to have children, " the main theme this year of Common Health Magazine's 11th annual healthy city survey, also judged Yunlin and Chiayi counties and Keelung and Kaohsiung cities as the most unfavorable places in Taiwan for children.

The magazine evaluated 24 cities and counties in Taiwan in the areas of child care, childbirth and health care, economic support and children-rearing environment to determine their competitiveness as suitable places for raising children.

Upon learning the results of the survey, the Yilan County Government said that although the county's resources are not abundant, it has used many different incentives to create an environment that is suitable for giving birth.

In an analysis of the results, the magazine said Taipei City ranked only average in the areas of its notification system for slow development children and completion of vaccinations for children under 3-year-olds.
It ranked at the bottom of the list in the examining children's eyesight.

Taipei County was at the bottom in terms of green land, playgrounds, stadiums and leisure centers per 10,000 people. The residents also believe that the county is not suitable for having and raising children.
The survey found that Kinmen and Changhua counties offer the most generous childbirth subsidies.
The parents of every new baby born in Kinmen can receive a subsidy of NT$48,355 (US$1,510), the highest in the country.
The survey was conducted between July 14 and August 8, with 13,444 valid samples collected. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.8-4.4 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese culture minister to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:16:31 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's Minister of Culture Cai Wu will visit Taiwan Sept. 2-8 at the head of a 50-member delegation, an executive with the Sheen Chuen-chi Cultural and Educational Foundation said Monday.

Cai will be the most senior People's Republic of China official to ever visit Taiwan, and his trip has triggered widespread speculation that cultural issues will make their way onto the agenda of the next round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun, however, dismissed the speculation as unfounded, stressing that the agenda for the sixth round of talks between the heads of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits has been set and does not include cultural subjects.

According to the Sheen Chuen-chi Foundation, Cai will attend a seminar on cross- strait cultural exchanges sponsored by the foundation and visit cultural institutions, tourist attractions, historic sites and leading enterprises in creative and cultural industries during his stay.
Cai may also travel outside Taipei to visit cultural attractions in other Taiwanese cities, such as Tainan and Hsinchu, the foundation said.
Both Cai and his Taiwanese counterpart Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng will attend the Sept. 6 seminar, to be held at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel, the foundation said.

The seminar will focus on themes related to cultural creativity, the visual and performing arts, tangible and intangible cultural heritage, and community culture and development, the foundation said, adding that 150 officials, academics and industry representatives from Taiwan and China will attend the symposium.
According to the foundation, Cai will visit Taiwan in his capacity as honorary chairman of the Chinese Cultural Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong to collaborate on service sector
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:17:50 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong were urged Monday to forge partnerships in the service sectors on each side to explore the growing Chinese market.

Taiwan has great potential to explore business opportunities in the Chinese service market due to the similarity of the cultures on either side of the Taiwan Strait and the recent signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , said Chen Tain-Jy, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, at a forum in Taipei on Taiwan-Hong Kong trade.
"We need to pay special heed to this, one of the biggest opportunities in China following the signing of the ECFA, " he said.
Taiwan and China have agreed to ease restrictions on certain financial and other services under the trade pact, which is expected to take effect in the near future.
In addition, Chen said, there is still a lot of room in which the service sector can grow in China, as it now accounts for just 40 percent of the country's GDP.

He suggested that Taiwan and Hong Kong can collaborate on medical treatment, environmental protection and cultural innovation, as the two sides have vowed to commit to these emerging fields and can complement each other in these respects.

"The development of these emerging service industries can use Taiwan's advantage in information and communications technology, " said Chen, a former head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
In terms of environmental protection, for example, Taiwan has achieved remarkable progress as it is already the world's largest producer of energy- saving LED lights, he noted.
In the field of medical treatment, meanwhile, Hong Kong has rich experience in epidemic prevention, while Taiwan is planning a system of insurance to cover long-term care, he said.
Chen also urged Taiwan and Hong Kong to remove trade barriers in the service trade, but he did not elaborate.

David Lie, who chairs the Business Cooperation Committee of the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council (ECCPC) , also said at the forum that Taiwan and Hong Kong should capitalize on each other's advantages to increase their respective shares of the Chinese and international markets.
Lawrence Lau, the former president of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, who also spoke at the forum, said that the service trade has long been important between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Taiwan was Hong Kong's fifth-largest export destination for service trade and its seventh-largest source of service trade imports in 2008, he noted.

He urged insurance companies in Taiwan, Hong Kong and China to set up an international insurance center in Hong Kong in view of the fact that the three places between them account for the world's largest life insurance market and shipping fleets.
Such an international insurance center would reduce the costs of Chinese and Taiwanese businesses and help enhance their international competitiveness, he said.
He also encouraged Taiwanese colleges and universities to attract students from Hong Kong.
In addition, Lau proposed that travel agencies in Taiwan, Hong Kong, China and Macao should work to attract foreigners to tour the four places under a single collaborative program.

The forum was held alongside the first meeting between the ECCPC and its Taiwanese counterpart, the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council (ECCC), since the two organizations were set up earlier this year to strengthen bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: BenQ Group forecasts revenue of over US$22 billion this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:27:41 (By Pan Chih-i and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The BenQ Group, the parent company of BenQ Corp. and AU Optronics, said Monday it expects to see revenue in excess of US$22 billion for this year as its business has been growing. K.Y. Lee, chairman of the BenQ Group, said that business has
recovered from the negative growth figures in 2008 and 2009, and
the group's 2010 revenue is sure to exceed the US$22 billion
recorded in 2007.
"BenQ will be a major export channel not only for the group, but also for other local industries," Lee told reporters on the sidelines of a BenQ sales conference.
The group said LCD monitors and projectors account for 50 percent of its revenues, with television sets generating 25 percent, and camera and notebooks 25 percent,
The Asia Pacific and Middle East, China, and Europe each account for 30 percent of the group's revenues, while Latin America contributes about 10 percent, it said.

The BenQ Group comprises 12 independent companies, spanning integrated manufacturing, components, services, and brand products in IT, consumer electronics and medical fields, according to its website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong intermediary bodies hold first joint meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 20:39:30 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official organization founded in May to promote economic and cultural exchanges with Hong Kong held the first joint meeting with its Hong Kong counterpart Monday, and the two decided to hold a similar meeting at least once a year.

Representatives of the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation Council (ECCC) and the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council (ECCPC) also established principles for communications and interaction between the two groups.
The principles include having the two parties take turns in holding joint meetings and convening such meetings whenever they are needed.

The ECCC and ECCPC also agreed to take turns in organizing at least one forum or conference a year to exchange opinions on issues concerning economic and cultural cooperation, while promising to send visiting delegations to forums organized by the other side.

ECCC Chairman Lin Chen-kuo and his Hong Kong counterpart Lee Yeh-kwong jointly made public the agreement at a press conference following the meeting, which was also attended by Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, and Stephen Lam, the Hong Kong Secretary for Constitutional Affairs.

The two bodies also agreed to accelerate bilateral cooperation in the promotion of financial supervision and double-taxation avoidance and strengthen cooperation in the travel and health care sector and in the fields of culture, education, and innovation, Lin said.
Taiwan inaugurated ECCC on May 26 after the former British colony established ECCPC on March 31.

Hong Kong's role as a major transit hub for the movement of people and goods between Taiwan and China has been weakened as a result of warmer cross-Taiwan Strait ties since Taiwan's president, Ma Ying-jeou, took office in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan official urges Japan to step up bilateral cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 21:10:15 (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chiang on Monday urged Japan to increase its trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan, saying such a move will be beneficial to both countries and the overall economic development of the region.
Chiang said that with Taiwan's recovery from the global economic crisis, it is time to develop cooperative ties with its major trading partners such as Japan.

Public opinion polls in both Taiwan and Japan have shown that the peoples of the two countries have good feelings about each other, which could lay the foundation for further bilateral trade and economic exchanges, he said.

Chiang was addressing the Foreign Correspondent's Club of Japan on a recently signed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and Taiwan's efforts to strengthen trade and economic relations with other countries in the Asian Pacific region and the rest of the world.

To this end, Taiwan has started discussions on an economic cooperation agreement with Singapore, he said, adding that achievement of this goal will be a significant step in Taiwan's efforts to sign similar pacts with its major trading partners, including Japan, which is Taiwan's second largest trading partner.

Chiang, who arrived in Japan Saturday for a four-day visit, attended an international seminar on the ECFA and cross-strait relations. He also visited Yokohama City and major information, culture and media organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Pavilion at Shanghai Expo to be sold in public tender
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 21:55:32 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council began to invite bids Monday for Taiwan's pavilion featured at the 2010 Shanghai Expo and fixed its floor price at NT$416.88 million (US$13 million).
According to the tender notice issued by the council, the deadline for tendering bids is Sept. 15, and the successful bidder will be chosen and announced the next day.
The council, which built and operated the pavilion at a cost of NT$1 billion at the Shanghai Expo, said the value of the pavilion and its logo is estimated at about NT$600 million to NT$700 million.
The council said it set the pavilion's floor price below its estimated value because the successful bidder will have to dismantle it and rebuild it in Taiwan at a cost of NT$338 million.

The council said it was ready to provide tender forms to interested buyers on Monday, and listed the governments of Taipei County and Chiayi City, and Yamay Recreation World, a theme park in Houli, Taichung County, as likely bidders.
Hualien, Kinmen and Miaoli counties and Keelung City have also expressed interest in purchasing the pavilion, according to the council.

The building, shaped like a sky lantern with a transparent exterior made of glass, was designed by prominent Taiwanese architect C. Y. Lee. It stands 23.8 meters above the ground and has floor space of 1,400 square meters.

At its center is a ball 16 meters in diameter consisting of 1 million LEDS that displays various images reflecting Taiwan's natural beauty and diverse culture. Inside the ball is a 12-meter wide screen that shows films of Taiwan.
According to the trade body, the Taiwan Pavilion has been one of the most popular exhibits at the Shanghai Expo, drawing more than 400,000 visitors thus far.
According to the tender notice, the successful bidder will get not only the building, but also its logo and two sets of computer software used to control the display of LED images.
The software has a market value of more than NT$200 million, according to the tender notice.

The winner of the tender will be required to relocate the pavilion after the expo closes on Oct. 31. A local shipping company has promised to help whoever acquires the pavilion ship it back to Taiwan without charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funding for classified programs cut in 2011 defense budget
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:16:40 (By Su Lung-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The 2011 national defense budget proposal of NT$297.2 billion that was sent to the legislature Monday contained a far less amount for classified programs than the previous year, a ruling party lawmaker said Monday.
Of the total amount, NT$272.7 billion was listed as open funds, while NT$24.5 billion was categorized as funds for classified spending, said Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang.
This was a significant cut of NT$14.7 billion, or 37.5 percent, in the amount of classified funds compared to the previous annual budget, Lin said.
The budget for classified programs was reduced to 8.25 percent of the total, shrinking it to below 10 percent for the first time, he said.
"The big drop was seen not because budgets have been cut significantly, but because many items that were listed under the classified category were moved to the open category," he said.
"The national defense budget for 2011 could be most transparent in history," he added.
The overall defense budget of NT$297.2 billion was NT$200 million less than the previous year, and represented a 16.6 percent of the 2011 national budget, he said.

Because big payments will have to be made soon in the arms deals with the United States, he said, other weapons procurement spending for 2011 will be less than NT$1 billion -- the lowest in recent years.
As result, several other arms procurement projects have been shelved or canceled, Lin said.
However, military production and research and development of defensive arms has remained steady, he said.
"This shows that the government, while seeking to improve cross-strait relations, has not ignored the importance of strengthening national defense," Lin said.
The Navy has listed an open budget of NT$891,000 to examine tank landing ships in the U.S., which indicates that it may want to lease one or two Newport-class tank landing craft, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan admitted to international tuna-fishing group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:23:06 (By Garfie Lee and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been admitted as a member of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission and will attend a meeting of the commission in La Antigua, Guatemala beginning Sept. 27, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement Monday.

Taiwan, which took part in the commission's 10-round negotiations that culminated in the 2003 Antigua Convention, was admitted to the body as a "cooperating fishing entity" under the name of Chinese Taipei -- which is used for Taiwan in many other international bodies.
Taiwan was invited to the body by the commission when it passed the Antigua Convention on June 27, 2003, and it became a full member when the convention took effect on Aug. 27, the statement said.
Belize, Canada, China, the Cook Islands, the European Union, Kiribati, and other countries were also admitted to the body as members under the designation "cooperating non parties."

The Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, established by international convention in 1950, is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna fishing stocks and other species targeted by tuna fishing vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Taiwan's accession to the commission has set a precedent for the island's participation in similar regional fishery management groups in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia to sign memorandum on green power cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 22:35:23 (By Yang Su-min and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia will sign a memorandum of cooperation on green power development at a two-day meeting that opened Monday in Taichung, according to officials of the Bureau of Energy.

The bureau said the two countries will sign a Taiwan-Australia memorandum of cooperation on energy and minerals at the 16th Taiwan-Australia Joint Energy and Minerals Trade, Investment and Cooperation Consultations, which has been held annually since 1993.

The deal represents an effort to improve mutual understanding in energy policy and to broaden the range of green power investments in response to the global trend of energy saving and carbon emissions reduction.

The meeting, which rotates between Australia and Taiwan and is taking place in Taichung on Aug. 30-31 this year, will discuss energy policy, supply-demand issues related to traditional energy, energy efficiency, renewable energy, carbon emission reductions and cooperation on green power technology.

The bureau noted that Taiwan imports over 2.5 million tons of coal, or roughly 50 percent of its needs, from Australia per year, and also relies heavily on Australia for its aluminum, iron and copper, highlighting the close relationship between the two countries.
A total of about 50 representatives participated in the meeting, including government officials and business executives from the energy and mineral sectors in Taiwan and Australia, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County, Taichung City ranked as best places to have children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/10 23:21:52 (By Lee Hsien-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Yilan County, Taichung City and Changhua County are the best counties and city in Taiwan in which to have a child, according to the results of survey released by a magazine Monday.

The survey ranking "the most suitable places to have children, " the main theme this year of Common Health Magazine's 11th annual healthy city survey, also judged Yunlin and Chiayi counties and Keelung and Kaohsiung cities as the most unfavorable places in Taiwan for children.

The magazine evaluated 24 cities and counties in Taiwan in the areas of child care, childbirth and health care, economic support and children-rearing environment to determine their competitiveness as suitable places for raising children.

Upon learning the results of the survey, the Yilan County Government said that although the county's resources are not abundant, it has used many different incentives to create an environment that is suitable for giving birth.

In an analysis of the results, the magazine said Taipei City ranked only average in the areas of its notification system for slow development children and completion of vaccinations for children under 3-year-olds.
It ranked at the bottom of the list in the examining children's eyesight.

Taipei County was at the bottom in terms of green land, playgrounds, stadiums and leisure centers per 10,000 people. The residents also believe that the county is not suitable for having and raising children.
The survey found that Kinmen and Changhua counties offer the most generous childbirth subsidies.
The parents of every new baby born in Kinmen can receive a subsidy of NT$48,355 (US$1,510), the highest in the country.
The survey was conducted between July 14 and August 8, with 13,444 valid samples collected. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.8-4.4 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 31, 2010, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 09:16:27 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Tuesday from its previous close, moving down 71.89 points at 7,669.31 on a turnover of NT$3.34 billion (US$104.18 million).
The weighted price index rose 18.29 points, or 0.23 percent, to close at 7,741.20 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Tropical storms to bring heavy rains to Taiwan: CWB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 10:16:52 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Extremely heavy rain is expected around Taiwan in the next two days as two tropical storms are coming at the island from different directions, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Tuesday.
After issuing land and sea warnings for Tropical Storm Namtheun late Monday, the CWB is likely to issue a sea warning for Tropical Storm Lionrock later Tuesday, forecasters said.
At 9 a.m. Tuesday, Namtheun was centered 90 kilometers northwest of Taipei, packing maximum sustained winds of 65 kph and moving south-southwest at 6 kph, according to CWB data.
Lionrock was located 400 kilometers west-southwest of Eluanbi, Taiwan's southernmost tip, and was moving at a very slow speed, forecasters said.

Meanwhile, another storm system, Kompasu, gained momentum and strengthened from a tropical storm into a typhoon early Tuesday. It was centered 870 kilometers east of Taiwan and was moving northwest at 24 kph.
Further observation is needed to see if the three storms will interact with each other, forecasters said.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 10:21:22 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.041 at 10 a.m. Tuesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.019 from Monday's close.
