DOC.HEADLINE: First lady arrives in Haiti
DOC.DATELINE: Port-au-Prince, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/31/10 10:36:40 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching arrived in Haiti early Monday afternoon local time after an overnight transit in New York, ready to begin her first overseas humanitarian trip as first lady to Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
Chow is the first first lady from Taiwan ever to visit Taiwan's two Caribbean allies.

Accompanied by her daughter Lesley Ma on the five-day trip, Chow is visiting earthquake-ravaged Haiti in her capacities as the honorary president for the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and as the "Love Ambassador" for World Vision Taiwan.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said the purpose of the trip is purely humanitarian-based to express concerns for Haitian children and victims of a devastating earthquake that struck Haiti on Jan. 12, 2010. The first lady is not scheduled to meet with any senior Haitian officials.

Chow has previously visited Taiwan's Central American allies as first lady, accompanying President Ma Ying-jeou on separate visits in May and June 2009 to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador and then to Honduras, Panama, and Nicaragua, respectively.
But she had not visited any of Taiwan's allies in the Caribbean as first lady prior to Monday.

She is expected to wrap up her trip to Haiti on Sept. 1 before heading to the Dominican Republic for a two-day humanitarian visit. She will return to Taiwan on Sept. 5 after an overnight stopover in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady and daughter visit Haitian orphanage
DOC.DATELINE: Port-au-Prince, Aug 30 (CNA) 08/31/10 11:52:09 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching was a big hit among the children of a Haitian orphanage on Monday local time as she kicked off her first overseas humanitarian trip as the first lady.

Immediately after she landed at Toussaint Louverture International Airport, Chow and her daughter Lesley Ma visited the children being cared for by Solidarite and Fraternite, a local school and orphanage located in Port-au- Prince.

The mother-daughter duo was warmly welcomed by the children, who greeted her by singing the national anthems of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and Haiti while unfurling the national flags of the two countries side by side.
The children also performed a traditional Haitian dance to welcome their guests.
Known for her strong advocacy of child welfare, the first lady returned the affection by showering the children with hugs and performing a tune on the clay flute she recently learned to play.
Chow and her daughter also taught the children how to make a bamboo dragonfly, a traditional Taiwanese toy, and a fruit gelatin dessert.
Among the major highlights of the trip still to come was the first lady's encounter with four Haitian children who are being sponsored by her and President Ma Ying-jeou, said World Vision.

She will also visit nongovernmental organization Food for the Poor, a big relief agency in the United States that enjoys a close partnership with Taiwan, and refugee camps to offer comfort to people left homeless by a devastating earthquake that ravaged Haiti on Jan. 12, 2010.

Chow was expected to conclude her day Monday by hosting a banquet attended by distinguished guests such as Taiwan's ambassador to Haiti Liu Bang-zyh, the head of Taiwan's agricultural and technical mission in Haiti Carlos Hsiang, local Taiwanese businessmen and Taiwan embassy staff.

The embassy explained that because the first lady is not making an official state visit and the trip is purely for humanitarian purposes, she will maintain her typically low-key profile and will not meet with any top Haitian government officials.
The first lady and her daughter are expected to end their visit in Haiti on Sept. 1 and head to the Dominican Republic for a two-day humanitarian visit. She will return to Taiwan on Sept. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai shares plunge on lower than expected earnings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 11:57:41 (By Chang Liang-chih and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, fell sharply in Tuesday morning trade after the company reported lower than expected earnings for the first half of this year, dealers said.
As of 11: 30 a.m., Hon Hai shares had fallen 5.79 percent to NT$114.0 (US$3.56) with 61.70 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index was down 1.35 percent at 7,636.92.
Hon Hai reported Monday that it posted NT$34.74 billion in net after-tax earnings in the first half of the year, up 22.6 percent from a year earlier, with earnings per share at NT$3.61.
Tom Tang, an analyst with MasterLink Securities, said the market consensus was that Hon Hai's EPS for 2010 would hit NT$8.5.

"Now, the EPS in the first half was less than half of the forecast," Tang said. "With concerns over global demand for high-tech products running deeper, investors are afraid that it is very unlikely that Hon Hai will meet the forecast."
Tang said he suspected the current selling largely came from foreign institutional investors, who hold about 50 percent of Hon Hai's shares in circulation.
Tang attributed the worse than expected earnings for the first half reflected the disappointing results reported by Hong Kong-listed subsidiary Foxconn International Holdings.
The company reported Monday it registered a net loss of US$143 million in the first six months, compared with a net loss of US$18.70 million recorded in the first half of last year.

"I estimate that Foxconn International's higher losses eroded Hon Hai's EPS by about NT$0.4. As the global economy is slowing, uncertainty over Foxconn International's bottom line has unnerved investors," Tang said.
Daiwa Securities said it fears Hon Hai's gross margin will fall in the second half of this year as the group announced two wage hikes for its Chinese workers in late June.
In the second quarter of this year, Hon Hai's consolidated gross margin fell to 8.11 percent from 8.65 percent recorded in the first quarter.
Daiwa Securities rated Hon Hai a market underperformer with a target price of NT$105.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Don't undermine statistics independence

TEXT.P: Widespread debate over Taiwan's widening wealth gap emerged following the release of the country's wealth distribution statistics for 2009 by the Directorate General for Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

In a Cabinet meeting held last week, Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the DGBAS to maintain contact with the Council for Economic Development and Planning (CEPD) before releasing important statistics in the future, so that the CEPD could help interpret the figures from a macroeconomic perspective.

Wu's directive may seem reasonable, but it has interfered with the independence of the government's statistics. Once deprived of their independence, government statistics will become political publicity, with all bad news blacked out.

What Taiwan needs today is reflection, rather than optimistic interpretation, by government leaders. The government must abandon its ostrich mentality and respond rapidly to problems in order to chart a bright future for Taiwan's economy. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Grandma Puli' battles age and illness to help youth

TEXT.P: As the elderly woman got out of a car at a parking lot near the Liang-shean Tang Foundation complex in Puli township, she was greeted with shouts of "Grandma, Grandma" from a group of teenagers waiting nearby for shuttle bus to take them to night school.
Chen Chou, 80, was carrying bags of vegetables and groceries that she planned to cook for the teenagers, who were in fact not related to her.
"I like to cook for them because they are still growing, and boxed and bagged ready-to-eat meals are not good for their health, " she said.

Cooking fresh healthy meals is just one the services Chen performs for young people in her community. She also offers scholarships to children from impoverished families and provides shelter, care and counseling to teens and pre-teens who get into trouble with the law.
Undeterred by age or by illness, Chen has been working for 40 years to help disadvantaged families avoid the pain that she suffered.

Born into a poor family herself, Chen was adopted by a couple in Puli, near her hometown of Yuchi. She did not receive a formal education and didn't learn to read, or write until she was around 50. She got married at the age of 18 and had seven children.

However, within a few years, Chen was struck by a series of tragedies that ripped her family and her life apart. Three of her children died young from illnesses because the family could not afford medical treatment, and another committed suicide at the age of 17 because he could not bear to watch his parents struggle financially and otherwise.
"It was the deepest pain in my life and one that I cannot forget, " Chen said. "Now all the children in the world are my children. We must cherish every one who is still."

At the age of 39, Chen was diagnosed with colorectal cancer. As chemotherapy and other medical treatments proved ineffective, she decided to spend some time at a temple in Puli praying for healing. Chen said that by some miracle she went into remission.
It was at this point that her focus in life changed.
"God gave me more time so I had to dedicate the rest of my life to doing good," she said.
Chen set about working to raise funds to build temples. Over the next 14 years, she helped to fund the construction of 13 temples, including Liang-shean Tang, by making and selling rice cakes.

At the same time, she began offering religious counseling to people who came to her for advice about problems in their lives. She also got involved in volunteer community work and helping to rescue young people who were going astray.

"A temple is a place that provides support for faith and spiritual living, but religion is not just about erecting temples, " said Chen, who became known as Grandma Puli. "It would be a pity we didn't go beyond building temples."
From the Liang-shean Tang Temple grew a charity foundation by the same name, which was established in 1983 in Puli with donations from the public and proceeds from the sale of Chen's family property.
At a juvenile center that is part of the foundation, young people and children from disadvantaged families can find shelter, food and guidance.
"Fortunately, Grandma appeared at a time when I had lost my way and she guided me onto the right path, " said a young man only by his surname Lee.
At first, Chen managed to keep the center running by selling wild vegetables, handmade rice cakes and rice dumplings.
Today, the center is supported by charity donations and houses some 26 teenagers, most of whom are delinquents or from broken families.
"It is not the children's fault (that their families have broken apart)," Che said.
Grandma Puli said she knows nothing about psychological counseling, but through example, she tries to instill in the children the values of love and compassion.
"My efforts have been rewarded," she said, adding that she was happy to see almost 100 children get back on track with her help at the center.
"If we can reach them in time, they can become pillars of the nation," she said.

Many of the children and youth she has helped have gone on to become her godchildren and they usually gather twice a year, in June and December, to celebrate her birthday and express their gratitude to her.
"Grandma always told us we are human beings and should act as such, " said one of the young men who is known by his surname Lin. "I felt so well cared for when I was at Liang-shean Tang."
Inspired by Grandma Puli, Lin and Lee have set themselves the goal of raising NT$1 million to help her realize her dream of building a home for juvenile delinquents.

Chen launched the project last year with the aim of providing accommodation, education and career guidance for close to 100 juvenile delinquents and school dropouts between the ages of 12 and 18. If she can raise the NT$30 million shortfall in the NT$140 million budget, the home will be completed by the end of the year.
Her chances of reaching her goal seem to be growing, as her efforts are gaining high-level support.

Earlier this month, President Ma Ying-jeou attended a fundraiser that Chen held in Taipei for the juvenile home project. Soon after, Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching made a commitment to nominate Grandma Puli for inclusion on various philanthropist lists worldwide, which he said would give her international publicity and help to promote the project.
But Chen later turned down Lee's proposal. In a letter to the county government on Aug. 30, she said that she is just a facilitator and that many other people have contributed to the work.

However she defines her role, Chen has no intention of giving up or even slowing down, despite her continued battle over the years with various types of cancer -- gastric, nasopharyngeal, laryngeal and cervical -- and the debilitating pain she suffers as a result of chemotherapy.
"There are lots of things that I still have to do - I cannot die right now, " she said. "Maybe God will let me go after the work is done." CNA Staff Writer Y.L. Kao CNA photo nos. 33-35

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--National defense budget for 2011 in five-year low

TEXT.P: The proposed 2011 national defense budget of NT$297.2 billion was sent to the Legislature Monday. The figure was the lowest in nearly five years and represents less than three percent of the GDP.
Of the total amount, NT$272.7 billion was listed as open funds, while NT$24.5 billion was budgeted for classified spending, down nearly 40 percent, or the lowest in history.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the subject: China Times:
Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang said that NT$45 billion of the total national defense budget for 2011 will be used to pay for weapons bought from the United States.
Lin said this is mainly because the U.S. has announced up to US$11 billion in arms sales to Taiwan over the past two years, so big payments will have to be made next year.
For this reason, other weapons procurement spending for 2011 will be less than NT$1 billion -- the lowest in recent years, Lin said.

Even if some weapons purchases originally scheduled for next year may be shelved or canceled, military production and research and development of counterattack or defensive weapons has remained steady, he said.

Lin also said the production of Hsiung Feng 2E surface-to-surface cruise missile system developed by the Chunghsan Institute of Science and Technology in Taiwan has been on track, and some of them are expected to be commissioned at the end of the year.
Lin said this will prove that the Ma administration, while improving cross- Taiwan Strait relations, has not ignored the importance of strengthening national defense capability. Liberty Times:
Legislator Lin said classified funds under the 2011 national defense budget will be NT$24.5 billion, down 37.5 percent from the NT$39.2 billion budgeted this year.
The big drop was not because the classified budget was cut significantly, but because many items that were listed as classified were moved to the open category, he said.
Meanwhile, the financial straits of the nation have squeezed the scale and progress of the recruiting system.

The Ministry of National Defense said in its five-year military personnel buildup report that under the military streamlining program, the number of servicemen in Taiwan's military will be set at 215,000 people. Reflecting the difficulty of recruiting people, it set a recruiting goal of 90 percent of the total, or 193,000 people, for 2011.

Though the military said it will gradually increase the number of recruits, it will not stress pushing for the completion of the new recruiting system by 2014 as had been originally planned. (Aug. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Everybody wants pay hikes

TEXT.P: The issue of whether to increase the pay of civil servants sparked a heated debate recently. Notably, both the proponents and opponents are aiming at a wider goal: raising the wages of ordinary workers.

This indicates that the government should not focus only on pay hikes for civil servants, but should think about how to expand employment and boost the income of average citizens so as to share the fruits of economic growth with more diligent people.
Another more important purpose of raising workers' salaries is to narrow the wealth gap between the rich and the poor.

In this regard, the government of President Ma Ying-jeou should not assume the sole responsibility. The business sector, which has been granted various tax reductions by the Ma administration at the cost of over NT$100 billion in revenue, also has a responsibility to give back to society. (Editorial abstract -- Aug. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly half of high-tech workers want to leave their jobs: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 14:34:37 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people working in the high-tech industry do not want to stay in their jobs because of long working hours and heavy work pressure, according to the results of an online survey released Tuesday.

The survey, conducted by the online 104 Job Bank, found that 34 percent of respondents with work experience at high-tech companies have left the sector, while another 12 percent said they are planning to quit, for a total of 46 percent unwilling to stay in the high-tech field.
In contrast, however, about 67 percent of workers who have no experience said they would like to work for high-tech companies.

To respondents who had never worked in the sector but wanted to, the most desirable companies to work would be Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract maker of electronics products (49 percent), Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (47 percent) and ASUSTek Computer Inc. (33 percent).
For workers in the industry, the best three companies to work for are TSMC (44 percent) , MediaTek Inc. (32 percent) and HTC Corp. (29 percent).

When respondents who had left the high-tech sector were asked why they quit their jobs, 24 percent cited job cuts and furloughs, 23 percent cited long working hours, 21 percent pointed to heavy stress at work, and 21 percent said their income was not in proportion to their effort.

Experienced high-tech workers warned those without high-tech experience to not have high expectations of salaries and benefits (58 percent) from high-tech companies and said they should be prepared for long working hours (45 percent) and sudden big job changes (34 percent).

In the view of these respondents, engineering R&D talent will be most in demand over the next five years (45 percent) , while the LED industry is expected to become a leading sector (33 percent) during that time, the survey said.

The poll, which was conducted August 10-11, collected 3,002 valid samples, of which 2,000 were from people with high-tech working experience and 1,002 were from those without high-tech experience. It had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 1.7 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan government rejects sale of Nan Shan Life
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 14:50:48 (By Tien Yu-pin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government has rejected the sale of the country's biggest life insurance company, Nan Shan Life, to a Hong Kong consortium, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

The consortium, which comprises Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings, agreed last October to buy the company for US$2.15 billion after it was put up for sale by its parent group American International Group (AIG) . However, the deal stalled a few months later due to regulatory concerns in Taiwan.
The MOEA's Investment Commission on Tuesday turned down the application for the sale after reviewing the deal.

Several buyers, including Taiwan's Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. Ltd., and some Japanese and Middle East companies, had expressed interest in bidding for Nan Shan Life if the consortium failed to secure the deal.
Chinatrust FHC had previously bid for Nan Shan when AIG, amid financial troubles, put up the Taiwan unit for sale last year.
Nan Shan Life has approximately 4 million policyholders and about 4, 000 employees in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 1.61 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 15:28:16 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 1.61 percent Tuesday as investors reacted to a Wall Street fall overnight amid renewed concerns over weakening global economic fundamentals, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 124.92 points to 7,616.28, after moving between 7,577.10 and 7,687.47, on turnover of NT$115.80 billion (US$3.62 billion).
The market opened down 0.93 percent after Wall Street's 1.39 percent decline pushed the Dow Jones Industrial Average to the brink of tumbling below the key 10,000 barrier, dealers said.

Selling accelerated across the board with Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, dragging down the index on weaker-than-expected results for the first half of 2010, they said.
A total of 3,087 stocks closed down and 692 finished higher, with 151 remaining unchanged.
Machinery and electronics stocks suffered the steepest decline, losing 2.3 percent. Paper and pulp stocks fell 2.1 percent, and cement, foodstuff and construction shares lost 1.9 percent.
The textile sector fell 0.8 percent, the financial sector lost 0.7 percent and the plastics and chemical sector lost 0.6 percent.

"It was no surprise that Wall Street remained choppy on lingering worries over the economy, " Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said. "It was also no surprise that the local bourse followed suit, triggering stop loss selling throughout the session."
Huang said it is very possible that the Dow will test 10,000 points again soon, "and as a result market sentiment has turned very cautious."

Judging from the losses suffered by large cap stocks on Tuesday, Huang believed the selling largely came from institutional investors, in particular foreign institutional investors who hold a big chunk of high-tech bellwether firms.
Foreign and Chinese institutional investors were net sellers of NT$5.3 billion in shares on the day.
The local market could fall to below the nearest technical support level at around 7,600 points soon on weak confidence, the analyst said.

Huang said the high-tech sector remained haunted by concerns over weakening global demand in the second half of this year, adding, "Its disappointing results for the first six months cemented such fears."
"Without a resilient electronics sector, the local market is not likely to reverse its weakness," he said.

In the electronics sector, Hon Hai fell 6.61 percent to NT$113.00, smartphone maker HTC shed 6.25 percent to NT$585.00 and Largan Precision, a digital camera lens producer, lost 6.02 percent to NT$578.00.
Among old economy industrial stocks, Taiwan Pulp & Paper fell 3.58 percent to NT$14.80 and Wei-Chuan Foods lost 5.08 percent to NT$32.70.

TEXT.P: life 17. Changhua county share experience in boosting fertility rate 18. Chunghong Holding to list in Taiwan

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County offers counseling for foreign spouses
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 16:08:33 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Changhua County Government said Tuesday that it has been holding free counseling sessions for foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens to help them adapt to life in the country.
The sessions deal with topics such as fear of living abroad and the pressures of being treated differently by local residents, said Changhua County Deputy Magistrate Chang Ruei-bin.
In a meeting on Aug. 24, a group of foreign spouses was invited to share their experience of living in Taiwan, he said.
"By sharing their experiences and knowledge related to Taiwan, foreign spouses in such a forum can relax and learn to identify more closely with the country," Chang said.

In a broader program that was launched in 2002, areas such as education, work, health issues, food and language are also covered, and 3,030 foreigners have participated so far, the county government said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based PCB firm seeks to raise funds in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 16:53:37 (By Tian Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Chunghong Holdings Ltd., a Chinese printed circuit board (PCB) firm, is seeking to raise funds in Taiwan through a primary listing on the local main board, underwriter Capital Securities said Tuesday.

Capital Securities said Chunghong, which is registered in the Cayman Islands, is planning to issue 7.61 million new shares to raise about NT$216.8 million (US$6.77 million) and has filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange for the listing.
According to its prospectus, Chunghong expects the listing plan to be completed in the first quarter of next year.
Aside from making PCBs, Chunghong also provides surface mount technology (SMT) to make electronic circuits in which the components are mounted on the surface of the PCBs.
The prospectus said the company will allocate a large portion of the funds it raises from the primary listing to add three SMT production lines.

Currently, Chunghong operates production facilities in China's Suzhou, Shenyang and Yantai, and it teamed up with LG Electronics to set up a plant in Poland in 2007, aiming to boost sales in the European market.
In 2009, 68.98 percent of Chunghong's total sales went to Asia, 21.58 percent went to the Americas, and 9.44 percent went to Europe.
Among its major customers are Samsung Electronics, Kingston Technology and LG Electronics, the prospectus said.
Chunghong, which was founded by Taiwanese businessmen operating overseas, was listed on the Singapore Exchange in 2007 but delisted voluntarily in 2009.

The company decided to come back to Taiwan for its primary listing after years of effort by the government to persuade Taiwanese companies operating abroad to use the island as a fund-raising site, the Taiwan Stock Exchange said in a statement on its website.
The company's net profit in the first of the year was NT$96.66 million, on pace to exceed its net income of NT$112 million for all of 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, premier inspect preparations as typhoons approach
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 17:14:20 (By Lin Sheng-hsu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou visited the Central Emergency Operation Center Tuesday to inspect preparations amid the approach of Tropical Storm Namtheun, as the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) predicted a possible threat from Lionrock, another tropical storm.
Ma instructed all relevant units to be on alert, even though weather reports had forecast Namtheun's strength to be weakening.

Ma said it is the responsibility of local governments to make every effort to prevent disasters and to launch rescue missions, while the central government is obliged to offer every possible support for the local governments in this regard.

Noting that rainfall had surpassed 300 mm in Taipei City's Zhuzihu area, Ma said the runoff will flow directly into the Keelung River, which runs through the city, so the city must take precautions against possible flooding.
Earlier in the day, Premier Wu Den-yih also visited the center to hear briefings on the movement of the storms.
The CWB reported that as of 4 p.m., Namtheun was centered 130 km west-northwest of Taipei, packing maximum sustained winds of 65 kph and moving west-southwest at 6 kph.
The tropical storm was expected to threaten the northern Taiwan area covering Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli counties, even though it was weakening, the CWB said.
The bureau also said Lionrock was currently at sea close to the Tongsha islands, moving slowly in an easterly direction.

Earlier, CWB forecasters reported that another storm system, Kompasu, had gained momentum and had strengthened from a tropical storm into a typhoon earlier in the day. It was centered 870 km east of Taiwan, moving northwest at 24 kph.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County shares experience in boosting birth rate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 17:29:02 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Besides offering a child care subsidy, providing an environment in which residents can live safely and easily find jobs is a key to success in boosting the birth rate, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said Monday.

According to the results of a survey released Monday by Common Health Magazine, Changhua County, Yilan County and Taichung City are the three localities in Taiwan that were rated as the most favorable places to have a child.
The main criteria used in the survey was care for children, childbirth care, financial support and child-rearing environment.
Cho pointed out that Changhua's fertility rate stood at 1.15 births per woman in 2009, which was higher than the nation's average of 1.02 births per woman.
He attributed the achievement to the favorable living environment provided by Changhua, which has the second-lowest unemployment rate and the lowest crime rate in Taiwan.
Also, the county has provided free lunches to elementary and junior high school students since 2009, greatly reducing the financial burden on parents, the magistrate said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 17:30:45 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.042 to close at NT$32.102.
Turnover totaled US$1.082 billion during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.120 and moved to a low of NT$31.850 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: China military budget rises sharply: defense ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 17:54:27 (By Kelven Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China increased its defense budget in 2010 by 7.5 percent to US$78 billion, while most other countries were cutting military spending, according to the latest report on China's military strength.

The annual report, submitted Tuesday by Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) to the Legislative Yuan, said China did not follow the general trend of reduced defense budgets in the wake of the global financial crisis.

Meanwhile, Taiwan was among the countries that cut defense spending, the report said. Taiwan's 2011 defense budget proposal of NT$297.2 billion (US$9.27 billion) is NT$200 million less than the previous year and accounts for 16.6 percent of the country's entire budget, the report said.

However, the MND has allocated NT$77.6 billion for the construction of living quarters for military personnel and their families, which brings the ministry's full budget to NT$374.8 billion or 2.73 percent of the country's gross domestic product.

President Ma Ying-jeou promised during his presidential election campaign to raise the defense budget to 3 percent of GDP, which is the level it was at before the Democratic Progressive Party came to power in 2000.
The MND report warned that Beijing has launched a "charming offensive" against Taiwan and is only being accommodating on issues that do not undermine its claim to Taiwan.

Beijing has never let up in its efforts to block the U.S.' sale of arms to Taiwan and would go to great lengths to strengthen its ability to invade Taiwan, despite warming ties across the Taiwan Strait, the report said.
If Taiwan pushes for permanent independence from China, acquires weapons of mass destruction, or erupts into civil chaos, China could decide to attack, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fans oppose scrapping Zhongshan Soccer Stadium after Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 18:13:51 (By Chen Hung-chin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's soccer community voiced its opposition Tuesday to a plan by the Taipei City government to convert the country's only dedicated soccer stadium into a permanent exhibition hall after the conclusion of the Taipei International Flora Exposition.

Taipei City Councilor Wu Su-yao and representatives of local soccer groups said at a press conference that the city government should keep its promise to restore the stadium to its original use after the Flora Expo, to be held between Nov. 6, 2010 and April 25, 2011.

They said Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin promised two years ago that the stadium would be closed only "temporarily" to serve as the venue for indoor floral design competitions and special exhibits during the Flora Expo.

But now the city government and the Ministry of Economic Affairs are planning to permanently convert the stadium and the surrounding area into a display center for top quality products from Taiwan, Wu said.

"It is really sad for soccer fans that the Zhongshan Soccer Stadium will no longer exist and function as a sports facility because of the Flora Expo, " said Chang Yao-min, a former soccer player who now coaches a soccer team for the Shilin Sports Federation.

Kuo Cheng-deng, founder of the Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) Football Association, also stressed that the Zhongshan Soccer Stadium is the only stadium in the country designed for soccer and approved by FIFA for international matches.

"If it is demolished, soccer matches will have to be held at non-soccer- specific stadiums, such as the Kaohsiung Stadium or Taipei Stadium, " Kuo said. "Soccer will therefore have to share limited space with other sports," he added.
The Taipei City government responded that it has planned some supplementary measures to deal with the issue.
Wang San-chung, chief secretary of the Department of Economic Development under the city government, said that more soccer fields will be built for the city's schools with soccer teams.
He also suggested using Yin Feng Sports Park, Bailing Sports Park, and Taipei Stadium for soccer matches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quanta Computer cuts Q3 shipment forecast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 18:26:06 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Quanta Computer Inc., the world's largest notebook computer ODM, said Tuesday it has lowered its forecast for shipments for the third quarter of this year to reflect weakening global demand.

Quanta Vice Chairman and President C.C. Leung said at an investors' conference that based on the market reality, notebook computer shipments for the third quarter could either rise 5 percent or fall 5 percent from the second quarter figures.
The company had previously forecast that shipments for the July-September period would increase 10 percent to 15 percent from the previous quarter.
Leung said the forecast was cut based on a slowing global economy and weakening economic fundamentals, which have dragged down demand for consumer electronics in developed countries.

However, Leung said, demand is expected to pick up in the fourth quarter, which is the peak season for the global hi-tech sector. Quanta, therefore, has no plans to lower its forecast of 40 precent growth for the entire 2010, he said.
The company expects to record notebook computer shipments of 50 million units for the year.
In the first half of this year, Quanta posted NT$10.43 billion (US$326 million) in net profit, up 12 percent from a year earlier, with earnings per share at NT$2.76.
In the second quarter, the company's gross margin fell to 3.4 percent from 4.1 percent recorded in the first quarter, largely on higher operating costs.
The decline was worse than expected, analysts said.
The company is preparing to diversify its business in an attempt to offset the falling gross margin in notebook computer ODM business, the analysts said.

Leung said the notebook computer ODM business currently accounts for about 78 percent of the company's total sales, but the figure is expected to fall to 75 percent in October and the company is aiming to further lower its percentage of notebook computer ODM business year by year.
Despite the smaller gross margin, the company remained profitable based on its EPS and was still competitive in the world market, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Ireland to discuss energy-efficient technology
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/31/10 18:31:27 (By Jennifer Huang and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Ireland opened a two-day conference in Dublin Monday to discuss cooperation on sustainable energy technology, Taiwan's representative to Ireland said that same day.

The joint conference, sponsored by the National Science Council (NSC) of Taiwan and the Science Foundation Ireland (SFI) in Ireland, has five major topics on its agenda -- applications of information and communication technology, ocean energy, renewable energy, solar energy and smart grids.

The conference has been planned for about two years and has finally been organized thanks to the aid of the NSC and the SFI, Republic of China Representative to Ireland Lee Nan-yang said at the opening ceremony.

"Taiwan and Ireland are both devoted to the development of green power, " Lee said. "I hope the joint conference will increase the opportunities for cooperation on green power technology between the two countries," he added.
Speaking on the same occasion, SFI project manager Wendy McLoone said the Irish government expects to see more exchanges as the session will cover both the industrial and academic perspectives.
Over 70 representatives attended the conference, including officials of state- owned companies and scholars from both countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to issue centenary passports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 18:48:29 (By Sophia Yeh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday it will issue commemorative passports in December in celebration of the 100th founding anniversary of the Republic of China.
Passports issued to ROC nationals who apply during the period Dec. 6-17, will carry the issue date of Jan. 1, 2011, said Chen Hua-yu, deputy director-general of the MOFA Bureau of Consular Affairs.
Normally, Jan. 1 is not entered as the date of issue on Taiwan passports because it is a holiday, Chen said.
The special commemorative issue is also a means of encouraging people to apply for the new electronic passports that carry a security chip, she said.
Since Taiwan adopted chip-embedded passports in December 2008, it has issued 1.9 million, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expo to present local cultural creative industry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 19:12:39 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan international cultural creative industry exposition, the first of its kind, will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall in November, the organizers announced Tuesday.
"The event is designed to show the world our strong creativity, " said Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Minister Emile Chihjen Sheng, adding that the expo will be held every year.
The Nov. 11-14 event is being organized by the CCA and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China.

Sheng said that building a platform for designers and local and international buyers is the first step and that the council will also help local brands and young designers to attend international exhibitions to break into the world market.
Sheng said the focus of the event is not to generate revenue as is the case with most trade shows but to showcase the high quality of Taiwanese creative products.
He added that 20 percent of the approximately 450 exhibitors will be from the United Kingdom, The United States, Hong Kong and Shanghai.

The event will not only present modern creative products from Taiwan and overseas but will also introduce through a series of films many disappearing traditional Taiwanese skills, with the aim of preserving them, a show official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government rejects sale of Nan Shan Life (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 19:56:26 (By Lin Shu-yuan, Fanny Liu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The government has rejected the American International Group's (AIG's) sale of its subsidiary, Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., to a consortium, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

"The members of the review commission did not give approval as the case did not obtain the permit or consent of the regulator, " Investment Commission Chairman Hwang Jung-chiou told reporters soon after the commission meeting.
The consortium, comprising Primus Financial Holdings Ltd. and China Strategic Holdings Ltd., can appeal the decision within 30 days of receiving the notice, he said.
The consortium agreed last October to buy AIG's 97.57-percent stake in Nan Shan for US$2.15 billion after AIG put the Taiwanese insurer up for sale following a U.S. government bailout.
However, the deal stalled a few months later due to regulatory concerns in Taiwan, including the alleged involvement of funds from China.
Chinese investors are banned by law from investing in Taiwanese insurance companies.
The consortium replaced several of its shareholders at different times after they were considered to be Chinese investors.

The series of changes prompted Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission to cast doubt over the consortium's management and long-term commitment, said Emile Chang, deputy executive secretary of the commission.
Some of Nan Shan's 37,000 sales staff have staged several street rallies to demand protection of their work rights over the controversial sale.
Wedding Lan, a spokesman for Nan Shan's labor union, told CNA in a telephone interview that he welcomed the government's rejection of the proposed sale.
He added that if any new buyers come forward, they should abide by the law and protect the rights of Nan Shan clients and employees.
Founded in 1963, the Taiwanese insurer has some 4 million policyholders. It has NT$1.73 trillion-worth of assets, accounting for 15.32 percent of Taiwan's total insurance sector.
The insurance company has a net worth of NT$140.3 billion, exceeding 30 percent of the total in Taiwan's overall insurance industry.

Several buyers, including Taiwan's Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. Ltd., and some Japanese and Middle East companies, had expressed interest in bidding for Nan Shan Life if the consortium failed to secure the deal.
Chinatrust had previously bid for Nan Shan when AIG, amid financial troubles, put the unit up for sale last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition lawmakers pick holes in government's budget
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 20:09:17 (By Ho Meng-kui and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers criticized the government Tuesday over a mounting national debt and some of its proposed spending, as the Legislative Yuan prepared to debate the government budget for 2011.

In a news conference called by the legislative caucus of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), lawmaker Wong Chin-chu said that three years into its first term the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has run up a debt of NT$1.42 trillion (US$44.31 billion) , compared to the NT$1.3 trillion that existed after the DPP had been in power for eight years.

Of that NT$1.3 trillion, Wong said, NT$778.8 billion was borrowed to cover payments on debts accumulated by the previous KMT government, and NT$93.2 billion was used to replenish the Food Stabilization Fund.
That means only NT$518.3 billion was actually used by the DPP administration, Wong said.
Another DPP legislator, Huang Wei-cher, said the Ma administration has set a record for the lowest debt service ratio and the highest rate of debt accumulation.
"The record low debt service ratio is an indication of how fast the government is running up the national debt," he said.
He suggested that a national debt meter be set up in front of the Presidential Office to alert the public to the heavy financial burden being imposed by the government.
Wong also questioned the necessity for a publicity budget of NT$177.68 million for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) next year.

Noting that the allocation has risen from NT$31.66 million in 2009 to NT$125.31 million in 2010 and NT$177.68 million for 2011, Wong said this represents an amazing year-on-year growth of 295.78 percent and 41.8 percent, respectively.
She questioned why the MAC needed so much money for publicity now that its major task, the economic cooperation framework agreement with China, has been concluded.

The MAC also came under fire from Legislator Huang Wei-cher, who said the MAC is supposed to be a watchdog of the country's cross-strait policy and should therefore apply the brakes whenever the government tries to rush recklessly into reconciliation with China.
"The council mistakenly sees itself as the Cultural and Information Commission of the Kuomintang or as China's Taiwan Affairs Office," Huang said.
The government's 2011 budget will be reviewed in the legislature when the new session opens on Sept. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors close investigation of Typhoon Morakot case
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 20:21:32 (By Chen Fa-fo, Chen Shou-gow and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: More than a year after Typhoon Morakot struck southern Taiwan, taking hundreds of lives, a local prosecutors office closed an investigation into the deaths Tuesday with the conclusion that the casualties were caused by natural disaster.

According to Prosecutor Wang Chun-li of the Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office, the case was formally closed as no crime suspects or clear evidence of illegal conduct was found after the year-long investigation.
Wang said the prosecutors visited local residents and places devastated by the storm to investigate whether there were any individuals or agencies suspected of illegal conduct involved in the case.

They also consulted various government departments such as the 7th River Management Office under the Water Resources Agency, the Pingtung Forest District Office under the Forestry Bureau, the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, and the Kaohsiung County government, to collect information, Wang said.
An assessment team led by university professors also produced a report to assist the investigation, he added.
However, some survivors of mudslide-battered Siaolin Village in Kaohsiung County voiced concern about the investigation.
Tsai Sung-yu, head of a reconstruction and development association in the village, said that survivors did not get enough respect because they were not invited to take part in the investigation.
The government should hold a briefing for these survivors to explain the investigation report and also propose concrete measures to prevent such disasters from happening again, he said.

Typhoon Morakot slammed into Taiwan last August, bringing powerful wind and torrential rain that left more than 700 people dead or missing, including an estimated 400 buried in the village of Siaolin alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Date of mayoral elections in five municipalities officially announced
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 20:29:08 (By Chieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Mayoral, city councilor and borough chief elections in the five special municipalities will be held Nov. 27, according to a Central Election Commission (CEC) statement scheduled to be formally announced Wednesday.

The statement will also specify the number of city councilor seats in the municipalities -- 62 seats in Taipei City, 66 seats in Xinbei City (an upgrade of Taipei County), 63 seats in Taichung City (a merger of the city and county of Taichung) , 57 seats in Tainan City (a merger of the city and county of Tainan) , and 66 seats in Kaohsiung City (a merger of the city and county of Kaohsiung) , the officials said.

According to the CEC, those who intend to run in the elections must deliver their applications between Sept. 13 and Sept. 17, after which their names will be drawn in an Oct. 29 lottery to determine their election numbers.

Between Nov. 12 and Nov. 26, the commission will invite candidates for the mayoral elections to present their political platforms in public. The government-organized hustings for city councilor candidates are slated for Nov. 17-26, the CEC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dominates World University Woodball Championship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 21:45:08 (By Hsiao Pao-hsian and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan took five gold medals, five silvers and one bronze in the third World University Woodball Championship that concluded Monday in Kampala, Uganda, the Chinese Taipei Woodball Association said Tuesday.

The four-day competition, organized by the International University Sports Federation (FISU) on the shores of Lake Victoria Aug. 24-30, hosted a total of 55 athletes from 11 countries -- Estonia, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, India, Kenya, Nigeria, Sudan, Tanzania, Zambia and Uganda.
The contenders were competing in seven major categories.
In the ladies singles, Tseng Hsin-I took the gold medal with 321 strokes, while Peng Ying-chi won silver with 323.
In the men's singles, meanwhile, Tsai Meng-hung won the silver medal with 310 -- only two strokes short of the gold medal-winning 308. Chang Chia-hao took bronze with 339.
Ladies doubles pair Peng Ying-chi and Tsai Chih-ya won gold with 111 strokes over 24 gates, while Tseng Hsin and Wu Chih-han seized the silver medal with 120.
The men's doubles was won by Hsiao Chia-hung and Tsai Meng-hung with 107, while Su Bing-ruei and Ching Chia-Hao came second with 109 strokes.
Taiwan won both the men's and ladies categories in the team competition, while Lee Ming-ru and Yeh Hui-chen took silver in the mixed doubles.

Woodball is a recent sport created by Wong Ming-hui, a former chairman of the Chinese Taipei Woodball Association, in which players use mallets to hit a ball through a series of gates. The final outcome is determined by the total stroke number.

DOC.HEADLINE: General budget for 2011 shows NT$225 billion shortfall
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 22:10:32 (By Yuang Ming-hsi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have to borrow money and issue government bonds to raise NT$225 billion (US$7 billion) to balance its planned expenditures and revenues in 2011, according to the proposed general budget for next year delivered to the legislature Tuesday.

The general budget bill submitted by the Executive Yuan shows that national revenues in 2011 will increase to NT$1.63 trillion, posing a growth of NT$82.6 billion, or 5.3 percent, from the previous year.
The national expenditure, meanwhile, will grow by NT$74.6 billion, or 4.4 percent, to NT$1.789 trillion.
The figures reveal a revenue-expenditure imbalance of NT$159 billion, representing a decline of NT$8 billion, or 4.8 percent, compared with the imbalance in 2010.
The government also set aside NT$66 billion for debt repayment.

The Executive Yuan has written a budget of NT$357.3 billion for expenditure on education, science and culture next year, accounting for 20 percent of the total. This is followed by NT$346.9 billion for social welfare, or 19.4 percent of the total, and NT$297.2 billion for military spending, or 16.6 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: Room for U.K.-Taiwan collaboration: BTCO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 22:34:13 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Low carbon economy, creative industries and digital economy are among areas in which the United Kingdom and Taiwan can collaborate further under Britain's new coalition government, the top British representative in Taiwan said Tuesday.

The British government's position on Taiwan and China relations remains unchanged and is in line with that of the European Union, David Campbell, director of the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) -- the U.K.'s representative office in Taiwan in the absence of official bilateral diplomatic ties -- said at a media briefing.

Updating the media about the policy of the new government led by Conservative Party Prime Minister David Cameron and his Liberal Democrat deputy, Nick Clegg, Campbell said the administration "places trade and commercial interests at the heart of its foreign policy."

The coalition, which took office in May, is also tackling the biggest issue -- the scale of its deficit -- and is trying to re-balance the economy away from consumption toward saving, investment and enterprise, he said.

Taiwan can play a big role in the development of low carbon economy, creative industries, digital economy and the 2012 London Olympics, he said, adding that Taiwan-based computer manufacturer Acer, one of the International Olympic Committee's global partners, which will provide information technology services for the Olympics, serves as a good example of this.

The U.K. government is committed to developing a sustainable low carbon economy with an ambitious target of getting 15 percent of its energy from renewable sources by 2020, Campbell said. With respect to the creative industries, the U.K. has the largest creative industry sector in the EU and many creative sub- sectors such as architecture, design and digital media.

Green energy and culture and creation are listed as two of the Taiwanese government's "Six Key Emerging Industries, " project that includes tourism, medicine and health care, biotechnology, and high-end agriculture, so the two countries share similar strategies and have common ground to foster closer collaboration and exchanges, he said.

Responding to a reporter's question on whether his office has noticed a loss of Taiwanese investors to China after the two sides signed the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) to further liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade, Campbell said that while the U.K. shares the same position as the EU in welcoming the signing of the ECFA, "it is too early to tell" what the impact of the trade pact will be.

"We would say there's good news and bad news for us. The good news is we attract a very large portion of Taiwanese investment in the EU. The bad news is that the percentage of Taiwan's investment in the EU is very small."

Campbell said his office is trying to explain the advantages in terms of Europe rather than just the U.K., because Taiwanese companies are not only interested in the U.K. market of 61 million but also in the EU market of 500 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: American International Group asked to keep Taiwan subsidy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 22:55:06 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) asked the American International Group, Inc. (AIG) Tuesday to keep running its Taiwan subsidy, Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., after the Ministry of Economic Affairs nixed a bid by Hong Kong- based Primus Financial Holdings Ltd. to acquire it.
FSC Vice Chairman Wu Tang-chieh said the commission will negotiate with AIG with an eye to persuading the group to keep its stake in Nan Shan and run it for the best interests of Nan Shan.
"We would like to talk with AIG on any proposal it might come up with for Nan Shan, as long as it is helpful for the insurance company's future development," Wu said.

However, he admitted, much as the commission would like AIG to keep Nan Shan, it cannot stop AIG from selling, as long as AIG can find a buyer suitable for the best interests of AIG, Nan Shan, its customers and employees.

Noting that Nan Shan is a significant domestic insurance company, Huang Tien-mu, an FSC official in charge of insurance business, said his office will keep a close eye on any transfer of Nan Shan's ownership.

AIG, which received billions of dollars in a bailout from the U.S. government to tide it over the global financial crisis in 2008, decided that same year to shed assets worldwide to streamline its operations.
It agreed to sell Nan Shan for US$2.15 billion to Primus Financial and China Strategic Holdings on Oct. 13, 2009.

However, the deal was rejected Tuesday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs out of concerns over the new owners' ability to increase capital in the future and its lack of experience in life insurance.
Founded in 1963, Nan Shan has some 4 million policy holders and NT$1.73 trillion-worth of gross assets, accounting for 15.32 percent of Taiwan's overall insurance sector.
The insurance company has a net assets of NT$140.3 billion, exceeding 30 percent of the total in Taiwan's overall insurance industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than a quarter of Taiwan's population prone to anger: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) 08/31/10 23:04:52 (By Chen Li-ting and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Some 4.8 million people in Taiwan -- 25.1 percent of the population -- are prone to anxiety and anger, according to a survey conducted by the Taiwan Suicide Prevention Center.
Unemployed people were found to be the biggest group, accounting for 33 percent of the total, followed by laborers at 31 percent and investors and business operators at 28 percent.

Liu Chia-yi, chief of the Department of Psychiatry at the Linko Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taoyuan County, said anxiety and anger are forewarnings of mental disorders, and can negatively affect people's lives and interpersonal relationships.

Chang Chia-ming, head of the Suicide Prevention Center, advised that people who are prone to anger and anxiety should practice deep breathing, try to avoid unpleasant situations, and think positively.
The survey, which was carried by phone between July 22 and Aug. 4 among people aged 15 and over, asked the respondents whether they were predisposed to anger and anxiety.
A total of 2,129 valid samples were collected in the poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.1 percentage points and a confidence level of 95 percent.
